b"Save It Print\nCauliflower Pasta with Bacon and Parmesan Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n3 to 4 ounces thick-cut sliced bacon, cut into half inch pieces\nExtra virgin olive oil\n1/2 cup panko bread crumbs\n3/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 Tbsp fresh chopped parsley\n1 teaspoon fresh thyme or 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme\n2 cups thinly sliced red onion (1 large red onion)\n1 Tbsp minced garlic (about 3 cloves)\n4 cups small bite-sized cauliflower florets (see How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n1/2 pound cavatappi, gemelli, or fusilli dry pasta\n2 teaspoons grated lemon zest\n1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Bring salted water for pasta to a boil: Place a large pot of salted water (2 quarts of water, 1 Tbsp salt), on to the stove to boil. While the water is heating, continue with the recipe.\n2 Cook the bacon: Place the bacon pieces in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Cook until lightly browned and much of the fat rendered, about 5-6 minutes. Remove the bacon from the pan to a bowl, retaining the fat in the pan.\n3 Brown the panko: While the bacon in step 2 is rendering, brown the panko in a separate skillet on medium high heat, stirring occasionally. When most of the panko is browned, remove from heat and place in a bowl. Stir in 2 tablespoons of olive oil, 3/4 teaspoon salt, 1/8 teaspoon of pepper, the parsley and thyme. Set aside.\n4 Cook the onions and garlic: Increase the heat to medium high. You'll want about a tablespoon to a tablespoon and a half of fat in the pan. If your bacon has not yielded that much fat, then add some olive oil to the pan. Add the sliced red onion. Cook until lightly browned, about 4 to 5 minutes. Add the garlic and cook an minute more.\nRemove the onions and garlic from the pan, adding them to the bowl with the bacon.\n5 Saut\xc3\xa9 the cauliflower: Add 2 more tablespoons of olive oil to the pan and heat on high heat. Add the cauliflower florets and toss to coat with the olive oil. Brown on high heat for 5 minutes, and then lower the heat, cover, and cook for 5 more minutes, or until the cauliflower florets are cooked through and tender.\n6 Cook the pasta: About the same time that you start cooking the cauliflower, add the pasta to the boiling pasta water. Cook the pasta at a rolling boil for 8 to 10 minutes, until cooked through, but still a little firm to the bite, al dente. Reserve 1 cup of the pasta water and drain the pasta.\n7 Combine bacon, onions, cauliflower, pasta, lemon zest, Parmesan: Add the bacon and onions into the pan with the cauliflower. Stir in the pasta, lemon zest, grated Parmesan. Drizzle in another tablespoon of olive oil.\nSprinkle with some of the reserved pasta water to loosen the pasta and cauliflower if it seems a bit dry. Serve topped with toasted seasoned breadcrumbs.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nTomato, White Bean, Bacon Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nWe've used canned white beans here for their convenience. If you want you can take this soup up a notch and use dried beans, you can make them on the stovetop or in a pressure cooker.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 pound bacon, diced\n1 large onion, chopped (about 2 cups)\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n2 cups peeled (about 3/4 lb), chopped potatoes (recommend Yukon Gold)\n6 cups peeled, chopped fresh tomatoes (or canned whole tomatoes with juice)*\n2 cups chicken stock or broth\n1 Tbsp dark brown sugar\n1 15-ounce can white beans, drained\nSalt and pepper to taste\n* To peel fresh tomatoes, cut a shallow cross on one end, blanch in boiling water for about 30 seconds, remove from boiling water and the peels should easily come off.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook bacon: Cook bacon on medium heat in a large thick-bottomed pot (5 to 6 quart) until lightly browned and fat is rendered.\nUse a slotted spoon to remove bacon from the pan. Set on a plate lined with a paper towel. Drain off all but 1 Tbsp of bacon fat.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onion and garlic, add potatoes: Add the chopped onion to the pot, cook in the bacon fat on medium heat until soft.\nAdd the minced garlic and cook a minute more.\nAdd the chopped peeled potatoes and cook a few minutes more.\n3 Add tomatoes, stock, simmer: Add the tomatoes and chicken broth. Bring to a boil, lower heat to maintain a simmer. Cover and cook until potatoes are cooked through, about 20 minutes (or longer).\n4 Add beans, blend half the soup: Stir in the brown sugar. Add half of the beans to the mixture. Use an immersion blender to blend about half of the soup mixture (or blend half of the soup in a standing blender and return to the pot).\n5 Add bacon, remaining beans: Add bacon to the soup and the rest of the beans. Add salt and pepper to taste.\nServe with crusty bread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nClassic Wedge Salad with Blue Cheese Dressing Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: Makes 6 servings\nMake-ahead Tip: The bacon and the dressing can both be prepared several days ahead. Reheat the bacon briefly in the microwave before serving, if desired.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 thick strips bacon\n2 ounces blue cheese, crumbled\n1/4 cup mayonnaise\n1/4 cup sour cream\n1 tablespoon cider vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce, or more to taste\nDash hot sauce, like Tabasco, or more to taste\n1/4 teaspoon salt, or more to taste\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper, or more to taste\nHeavy cream or milk, as needed to thin the dressing\n1 head iceberg lettuce\n12 red or yellow cherry tomatoes, quartered\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh chives\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the bacon: In a heavy skillet, fry the bacon strips, turning often, for 5 minutes, or until they are evenly golden and crisp all over.\nTransfer to a plate lined with paper towels. Cool and crumble.\n2 Make the blue cheese dressing: In a food processor, combine the blue cheese, mayonnaise, sour cream, vinegar, Worcestershire, hot sauce, salt, and pepper. Pulse the mixture until smooth. Taste for seasoning and add more Worcestershire, hot sauce, salt, or pepper, if you like. If you need to thin the mixture, add heavy cream or milk, 1 teaspoon at a time.\n3 Prepare the iceberg lettuce: Discard the outer leaves of the lettuce. Halve the lettuce through the core. Cut each half into 3 wedges so each piece has some core attached to it. With the wedges flat on the cutting board, trim out the tough part of the core from each wedge, but leave enough so that the wedges stay intact.\n4 Assemble the salads: Arrange the wedges on six salad plates. Spoon some dressing over the wedges. Sprinkle with bacon, tomatoes, and chives.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nArugula Corn Salad with Bacon Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n4 large ears of corn\n2 cups of chopped arugula (about one bunch)\n4 strips of bacon, cooked, chopped\n1/3 cup chopped green onions\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 tablespoon white wine vinegar\n1/8 teaspoon ground cumin\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the corn: Cook the corn ears, in their husks, either on the grill for a smoky flavor, or by steaming in a large covered stock pot with an inch of boiling water at the bottom of the pot, for 12-15 minutes, or by cooking in a microwave.\nLet the corn cool (can run under cold water to speed up the cooling), remove the husks and silk.\nI recommend cooking the corn in the husks for the added flavor that the husks impart. If you boil or steam the corn ears after you've already husked them, or if you cook them in the microwave, reduce the cooking time by a few minutes.\n2 Remove the corn kernels from the cobs: To remove the kernels from the cobs, stand a corn cob vertically with the tip on a small bowl that is inverted inside a larger, shallow bowl.\nUse a sharp knife to make long, downward strokes, removing the kernels from the cob, as you work your way around the cob.\nNote: it may help to work over a low table, to be in a better ergonomic position to cut the cobs this way.\n3 Make the dressing: In a separate bowl, whisk together the oil, vinegar, salt and pepper, and cumin.\n4 Assemble the salad: In a medium sized bowl, mix together the corn, chopped arugula, bacon, and onions.\nMix dressing into salad just before serving. Taste and add more vinegar if necessary to balance the sweetness of the corn.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nRoasted Cabbage with Bacon Gremolata Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: 4 to 6 servings\nFrom Andrea Bemis:\n"This is one of our favorite winter side dishes, and we get rave re\xc2\xadviews each time we serve it for company. I\'ve brought back the bacon gremolata yet again because it pairs so nicely with the roasted cabbage. I hope you and your guests find as much joy and pleasure in this simple recipe as we do."\nAdapted from Dishing Up the Dirt by Andrea Bemis, copyright \xc2\xa9 2017. Published by Harper Wave, an imprint of Harper Collins Publishers.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cabbage:\n1 medium-sized head of cabbage (about 1 1/2 pounds)\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nFor the bacon gremolata:\n3/4 cup roasted unsalted almonds\n4 strips (about 1/4 pound) good-quality thick-cut bacon\n3 tablespoons minced fresh parsley\n1 teaspoon freshly grated lemon zest\nPinch of kosher salt\nTo serve:\nFreshly grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 400F. Arrange two oven racks in the upper and lower third of the oven.\n2 Slice the cabbage: Peel off one or two of the thin, limp outer layers of the cabbage. Trim the stem so that it is flush with the bottom of the cabbage (if it isn\'t already).\nSet the cabbage upright and slice into 1-inch thick slices. Don\'t worry if a few of the outer layers unfurl or fall away.\n3 Brush the cabbage slices with olive oil: Use a pastry brush to cover both sides of the cabbage slices with olive oil, or use your fingers to rub the oil in. Season both sides with a little salt and pepper.\n4 Roast the cabbage: Arrange the cabbage slices in a single layer on a baking sheet. Roast on the lower oven rack for 35 to 45 minutes, flipping the slices halfway through cooking.\nWhen done, both sides should be seared an even golden-brown with crispy edges and the center of the slices should be tender.\n5 While the cabbage is roasting, prepare the bacon gremolata. If using unroasted almonds, arrange them on another sheet pan and roast in the upper part of the oven for about 10 minutes, until toasted and fragrant. Remove from the oven, cool briefly, then finely chop using a chef\'s knife (or pulse a few times in a food processor, but be careful not to over process or you\'ll make almond butter!)\nCook the bacon in a skillet over medium heat until very crispy. Transfer to a plate lined with paper towels to drain. When cool, roughly chop.\nCombine the chopped almonds, chopped bacon, minced parsley, lemon zest, and a pinch of kosher salt in a small mixing bowl. Toss to combine and set aside. (This bacon gremolata can be prepared ahead and kept refrigerated in an airtight container for about a week.)\n6 To serve: As soon as the cabbage slices are done roasting, transfer to a serving platter or individual plates. Sprinkle with a few spoonfuls of bacon gremolata and grated Parmesan cheese. Serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBLT with Arugula Recipe\nCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes one BLT sandwich\nINGREDIENTS\n2-3 slices thick smoked bacon\n1-2 thin slices of a fresh, large tomato\n1-2 ounces (a couple handfuls) fresh baby arugula (can substitute watercress)\n2 slices of bread\nMayonnaise\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the bacon: Heat a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan or cast iron pan on medium low heat. Lay the strips of bacon in a single layer on the pan. Slowly cook the bacon, rendering out the fat, until lightly browned on one side. Using a fork or tongs, turn the strips of bacon over to cook the other side.\nWhen the bacon strips are sufficiently cooked remove from pan and place on a plate lined with a paper towel to absorb the excess fat.\nPour out excess fat from the pan (leaving about half a teaspoon in the pan) into a jar or a container to either dispose of or to store. (Never pour bacon grease down the sink, it will clog your pipes.)\n2 Wilt the arugula: In the same pan, add handfuls of fresh baby arugula or watercress. Toss in the remaining remaining fat. As soon as the greens start to wilt, remove from heat and remove from the pan to stop the cooking.\n3 Toast bread, build sandwich: Toast bread slices in a toaster. Spread mayonnaise (or your favorite spread, butter will do too) over the slices. Layer the sandwich with bacon, sliced tomato, and lightly wilted arugula. Cut on the diagonal.\nEat immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHot Dogs with Pineapple Bacon Relish Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes enough relish for 8 hot dogs\nIf you are grilling the hot dogs, if you want you can grill the onion instead of saut\xc3\xa9ing. Just cut into thick rounds, coat with olive oil, and grill for about 5 minutes per side. Then chop.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 pound thick cut bacon\n1/2 large red onion, chopped, about 1 cup\n2 cups finely chopped fresh pineapple (about 10 oz)\n1/4 cup chopped sweet pickles\n1 Tbsp sweet pickle juice\n8 hot dogs\n8 hot dog buns\nMETHOD\n1 Pre-cook the bacon: Place the strips of bacon in a skillet on medium heat. Slowly cook the bacon, turning the strips over occasionally until much of the fat is rendered and the bacon is lightly browned. Remove the bacon strips to a paper towel lined plate.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: Pour off all but a teaspoon of the bacon fat (do this into a jar, do not pour down the drain or you will clog your pipes). Increase the heat to medium high and add the chopped onion. Cook, stirring occasionally until the onions are translucent, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat.\nWhile the onions are cooking, finely chop the cooled bacon strips.\n3 Make pineapple bacon relish: In a large bowl stir to combine the bacon, onion, pineapple, and sweet pickles. Mix in a tablespoon of sweet pickle juice. You can make ahead at this point, chill until ready to serve with the hot dogs.\n4 Cook the hot dogs: Heat the hot dogs your favorite way. The hot dogs are already cooked when you buy them, so all you really need to do is heat them through.\nOver a grill, grill for about 5 minutes on a medium flame, until lightly browned, and toast the buns for a minute if you wish.\nOr, put the dogs in a saucepan and cover with water. Bring to a simmer and simmer for 5 minutes.\nOr, pierce the hot dogs all over with a fork and put on a plate in the microwave for 20 to 30 seconds per hot dog.\n5 Assemble: Place a hot dog in a bun and top with a couple spoonfuls of relish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nCauliflower with Pine Nuts and Bacon Recipe\nCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4-6 as a side dish\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cauliflower head, cut into florets (see How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n1/4 cup pine nuts\n1/4 pound bacon or pancetta, cut into batons\n4-5 garlic cloves, sliced thin\n1-2 teaspoons dried oregano\n1-2 teaspoons red pepper flakes\nSalt and black pepper to taste\nLemon juice to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Boil cauliflower in salted water: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil and cook the cauliflower for 5 minutes. Drain and set aside.\n2 Toast pine nuts: While the water is heating, toast the pine nuts in a dry saut\xc3\xa9 pan until lightly browned. Keep an eye on them, as pine nuts go from toasted to burnt quickly. Set the pine nuts aside when they are toasted.\n3 Fry bacon: Add the bacon to the pan and fry gently over medium heat until crispy. Remove the bacon and set aside with the pine nuts.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 the garlic for 1 minute on medium-high heat, then add the cauliflower, pine nuts, bacon, oregano and red pepper flakes. Toss to combine and saut\xc3\xa9 for 3-4 minutes, stirring often. Do not let the garlic burn.\n5 Turn off the heat and add salt and lemon juice to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nBacon and Blue Cheese Guacamole Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nBlue cheese and bacon are salty, so this guacamole might not need as much salt as you are used to adding.\nINGREDIENTS\n5 slices bacon, preferably thick cut\n3 large ripe avocados\n2 to 3 teaspoons red or white wine vinegar\n1/4 cup minced red onion\n1/2 teaspoon garlic powder\nDash hot pepper sauce, such as Tabasco\n1/2 cup crumbled blue cheese, divided\nSalt to taste\nFor serving:\nTortilla chips\nPretzel chips\nSaltines\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the bacon: Lay the bacon strips in a large skillet. Turn the heat to medium and cook, turning frequently, until the bacon is crisp, 5 to 10 minutes. Lay on a paper towel-lined plate to drain. When the bacon is cool enough to handle, crumble it and set it aside.\n2 Scoop and mash the avocados: Cut the avocados in half pole-to-pole and twist them open. Remove the pit. (See How to Cut and Peel and Avocado.) With a large spoon, scoop the avocado flesh into a medium bowl. Mash it with a large fork until it\xe2\x80\x99s chunky-smooth.\n3 Add the seasonings: Add 2 teaspoons vinegar, the garlic powder, and the hot pepper sauce; mix well. Reserve 1 tablespoon each bacon and blue cheese for garnish, and gently fold the rest into the guacamole. Taste the guacamole on a chip or cracker, then adjust seasoning with salt. If it tastes flat, add another 1/2 to 1 teaspoon vinegar.\n4 Garnish and serve: Transfer to a serving bowl, then garnish with reserved blue cheese and bacon. This guacamole is best enjoyed within 2 hours, but you can refrigerate leftovers up to a day.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nOven-Baked Bacon\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 12 strips\nIf you use thick-cut bacon, plan to cook for an extra 5 to 10 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\n12 strips bacon\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\nWire baking rack\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the bacon: If you have an oven-safe baking rack, place it inside a sheet pan. (For even easier clean-up, you can also line the sheet pan with foil.)\nLay out the bacon strips on the wire rack. Make sure they don\xe2\x80\x99t overlap. Sprinkle bacon strips with black pepper, if you want.\n2 Bake the bacon: Place the bacon in a cold oven, and set the oven temperature to 375\xc2\xb0F. Bake the bacon in the oven for 15-20 minutes total.\nIf you are doing more than one pan of bacon, rotate sheet pans from top to bottom halfway through. If you are not using a baking rack, flip the bacon strips halfway through cooking.\nStart checking the bacon around 18 minutes, as some bacon cooks faster depending on the fat content. The bacon is done when it turns a dark tan color. Remember that the bacon crisps up as it cools, so don't worry if it's not completely crispy when you take it out of the oven.\n3 Drain and cool: When the bacon comes out of the oven, place it on a few paper towels to drain and cool. If you like, pour off the bacon grease from the pan and save it for cooking. (I love to cook eggs in my bacon grease!)\n4 Store the bacon: Bacon can be kept in the fridge for a few days and reheats well in a skillet over low heat. You can also freeze the bacon if you made a big batch. Just make sure to freeze the strips individually, or in between pieces of parchment paper, so they don't stick together.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nHow to Make Candied Bacon\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 12 strips, serves 4 to 6\nThis recipe is easily doubled. Space the bacon as closely together as you can on the two baking sheets. It's okay if they touch in places, but don't let them overlap.\nMAPLE BACON ALTERNATIVE: As an alternative to the standard recipe, stir two tablespoons of maple syrup into the brown sugar and brush this onto the bacon before baking. Bake just as you would the normal version.\nINGREDIENTS\n12 strips bacon (not thick-cut, about one pound)\n1/4 cup light brown sugar\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n2 baking sheets\n2 oven-safe wire racks\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the bacon: Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0 F with one rack in the top third and another rack in the bottom third of the oven. Line two baking sheets with foil, and place an oven-safe wire rack on each. Lay out the bacon strips perpendicular to the lines on the wire rack, divided between the two pans and making sure they don\xe2\x80\x99t overlap. (If you lay them out parallel to the rack, the bacon may fall through the cracks while cooking!)\nSprinkle the bacon strips with brown sugar and (optionally) add some freshly ground black pepper. I like to use about 1 teaspoon of brown sugar per bacon strip, spreading it out along the length of the strip.\n2 Bake the candied bacon: Bake the bacon in the oven for 20 to 25 minutes. I recommend rotating the pans once during baking to ensure the bacon is cooking evenly. Start checking the bacon around 18 minutes, as some slices will cook faster, depending on the fat content and thickness of the slices.\nThe bacon is done when the brown sugar is melted and the bacon is a deep brown color. Remember that the bacon will continue to crisp up as it cools, so don\xe2\x80\x99t worry if it\xe2\x80\x99s not completely crispy now.\n3 Cool the bacon: Let the bacon cool right on the wire rack for a few minutes. (If you eat it right away, you'll burn your mouth on the molten sugar.) The bacon will crisp up as it cools and as the melted sugar hardens. Then serve!\n4 Store the bacon: Candied bacon can be kept in the fridge for a few days and reheats well in a skillet over low heat.\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t think candied bacon is worth freezing, although if you made a huge batch you absolutely could. You could just want to make sure to freeze the strips individually so they didn\xe2\x80\x99t stick together.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nAir Fryer Bacon-Wrapped Figs Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesSoaking the figs time: 20 minutesYield: 12 bacon-wrapped figs\nThis recipe is easily doubled or tripled! Just air fry in separate batches.\nINGREDIENTS\n12 dried Turkish or mission figs\n6 strips regular center-cut bacon (not thick cut)\nGoat cheese or blue cheese for stuffing, optional\nSalted, roasted almonds for stuffing, optional\nHoney, for serving\nNonstick spray, for air fryer\nSpecial equipment:\nAir fryer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Reconstitute the figs: Add the dried figs to a bowl filled with steaming hot water. Let them sit for 20 minutes to reconstitute. Drain the figs and cut off the stems. Cut a small slit in each fig and spoon in a little blue cheese or goat cheese, or half an almond, if desired. You could also do a mix of fillings.\n2 Wrap the bacon around the figs: Cut the strips of bacon in half and trim them down to about 1/2 to 3/4 inches wide. Wrap one bacon strip around each fig. Secure with a toothpick.\n3 Air fry the figs: Spray the basket of your air fryer with nonstick spray. Add bacon-wrapped figs in a single layer so they aren\xe2\x80\x99t touching. Air fry the figs at 350\xcb\x9aF for 8-9 minutes, flipping once halfway through.\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t have an air fryer, broil the figs on high for about 3 minutes per side.\n4 Serve the figs: Once the figs have cooled slightly, serve them drizzled with honey.\nLeftover figs (yeah right!) will keep in the fridge for up to 5 days. Reheat in a 350\xcb\x9aF oven, or reheat in the air fryer for a few minutes before eating.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nGouda and Bacon Stuffed Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 16 stuffed mushrooms\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound white button mushrooms, thoroughly cleaned\n8 strips bacon (not thick cut)\n1/2 yellow onion, diced\n8 ounces gouda cheese, grated\n1/2 cup bread crumbs\n1/2 teaspoon dried thyme\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat your oven to 400\xcb\x9aF.\n2 Cut the stems out of the mushrooms: Use a small paring knife to cut the stems out of each mushroom. Make a good-sized divot in the mushrooms, but make sure to leave enough mushroom around the edges to hold the filling. Finely dice the stems and cored bits.\n3 Cook the bacon: Meanwhile, add bacon to a medium or large skillet over medium heat. Cook until bacon is browned and crispy, about 6 to 7 minutes. Remove the cooked bacon, leaving the grease, and chop into tiny bits.\n4 Cook the filling ingredients: Add the chopped mushroom cores, diced onions, and thyme to the skillet with the reserved bacon grease. Saut\xc3\xa9 the filling ingredients over medium heat until the onions are soft, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in breadcrumbs and chopped bacon. Let cool.\n5 Add the gouda: After mixture has cooled slightly, stir in the grated gouda cheese.\n6 Stuff the mushrooms: Line up the cored mushrooms in a baking dish that has been lightly oiled to prevent sticking. Spoon about 2 heaping tablespoons of the filling into each mushroom, piling it high and packing it in. It\xe2\x80\x99s okay if the mushrooms are almost overflowing. You should use all the filling!\n7 Bake the mushrooms: Bake the stuffed mushrooms for 20 minutes at 400\xcb\x9aF. Let cool slightly before serving.\nStuffed mushrooms can be made completely in advance and reheated in a 350\xcb\x9aF oven until warmed through. They keep fine in the fridge for up to 3 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nEasy Potato Soup with Bacon Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n6 strips bacon, chopped\n1 small yellow onion, diced\n2 stalks celery, diced\n2 medium carrots, peeled and diced\n1 parsnip, peeled and diced\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour\n2 cups whole milk\n2 cups vegetable or chicken broth\n1 1/2 pounds (3 cups) peeled and chopped Yukon Gold potatoes\nFresh chives, garnish\nFor the Crispy Skillet Croutons (Dad Add) \n2 cups chopped bread, cut into 1/4-inch cubes\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/4 teaspoon dried thyme\nPinch of salt and pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the skillet croutons: In a small bowl, toss chopped bread with olive oil, dried thyme, and a pinch of salt and pepper. Toast croutons in a nonstick skillet over medium heat for 4 to 5 minutes, stirring occasionally. It\xe2\x80\x99s okay if the char on them becomes uneven. Some sides should be crunchy and some soft still. Remove and set aside.\n2 Cook the bacon: Add chopped bacon to a large pot over medium heat. Cook until fat renders out and bacon is crispy. Transfer the bacon to a plate lined with a paper towel and set aside as a topping for the soup. Reserve the bacon grease in the pot.\n3 Make the soup: Add onions, celery, carrots, and parsnips to pot. Season with salt and pepper and cook until vegetables soften, 3 to 4 minutes.\nStir in flour, cook for another minute, then add broth and milk. Slowly stir. Bring to a slight simmer, then add potatoes and simmer for about 15 minutes, or until potatoes are very tender.\n4 Blend half of the soup: When potatoes are very tender, remove half of the soup from the pot and let cool briefly. Blend until smooth and return to the pot, stirring it into the non-blended soup base.\nAlternatively, blend half the soup directly in the pot with an immersion blender; be careful not to over-blend! Some chunks are good. Taste the soup and adjust seasoning to your liking. Keep warm until serving.\n5 Serve: Serve the soup topped with fresh chives, crispy reserved bacon, and skillet croutons.\nLeftover soup keeps well in the fridge for up to a week, or you can freeze it for 3 months. Reheat gently on the stove with a splash of water.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nLoaded Baked Potatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n6-8 strips bacon\n6 medium-large russet potatoes, scrubbed well\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 pound fresh broccoli, cut into florets (or use frozen)\n8 ounces grated sharp cheddar cheese\nTo serve:\nSour cream\nFresh chives\nDad Add: Quick Home Fries (serves 2):\n1 baked potato, diced\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon seasoned salt\nEggs, for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the bacon: Line a baking sheet with foil, then top with a wire baking rack (cookie cooling rack). Lay the bacon strips on the wire rack perpendicular to the wires, making sure the bacon pieces don\xe2\x80\x99t overlap.\n2 Bake the bacon and scrub the potatoes: Place the bacon in a cold oven and set the temperature to 375\xc2\xb0F. Bake for 15-20 minutes. Check the bacon around the 18-minute mark. Some types of bacon cook faster than others. (See How to Make Bacon in the Oven for full details.)\nWhile the bacon bakes, scrub potatoes well and then stab each potato about 10 times with a fork to prevent the possibility of a potato exploding in the oven. (It can happen!)\nRemove the bacon from the oven; transfer to a paper towel-lined plate.\n3 Bake the potatoes: Increase the heat to 400\xcb\x9aF. Place potatoes on a baking sheet, drizzle well with olive oil, and sprinkle with coarse salt. Bake potatoes for about an hour until the skins are shriveled slightly and the potatoes are very tender. (See How to Bake a Potato for more details.)\n4 Blanch the broccoli: While the potatoes bake, cook your broccoli. Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add a big pinch of salt to the water to season it. Add broccoli to the water and boil for 3 minutes until the broccoli is just tender, but not mushy at all.\nDrain broccoli once it is tender and set aside for assembly. We will warm everything up once the potatoes are assembled at the end.\n5 Open the potatoes: Once your potatoes are baked, let them cool slightly so you can handle them. Cut each potato down the center, being careful not to cut all the way through. Then cut two perpendicular cuts near the end of each potato; this will allow you to open each potato up easier. I like to use a small paring knife to slice up the interior of the potato, making it easier to unfold and stuff.\n5 Stuff the potatoes: Sprinkle some cheese over the potato. I like a lot of cheese, but feel free to use as much or as little as you\xe2\x80\x99d like. Top with about 1/2 cup of cooked broccoli and 1 piece of crumbled bacon. Sprinkle the broccoli with more cheese and more broccoli or bacon depending on the size of the potato and the size of your appetite!\n6 Reheat the potatoes: Place the stuffed potato back in the oven for 5-10 minutes to really melt the cheese and warm the fillings.\n7 Serve: Top the warm potatoes with sour cream and chives and serve.\nLeftovers: Store any extra potatoes before filling them. Leftover potatoes can be used within a week for baked potatoes, loaded potatoes, or quick Dad Add home fries!\n8 How to Make Dad Add Home Fries: Cut a leftover potato into about 1/4-inch cubes. Into a medium skillet set over medium heat, add the olive oil. When the oil starts to shimmer, add the potato cubes and seasoned salt. Cook for 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes are crispy and browned on the edges. Remove from skillet and serve with eggs.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nWhipped Goat Cheese 7-Layer Dip Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 6-8 as an appetizer\nHelpful tip! Slice the figs, then chop the figs and pistachios together. This helps prevent the pistachios from flying all over the place when you chop them.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the whipped goat cheese:\n10 ounces goat cheese, at room temperature\n1/4 cup plain whole milk yogurt\n1/4 cup whole milk\n1/2 lemon, juice only\nPinch of salt\nFor the toppings:\n4 strips cooked, crispy bacon, chopped\n2 tablespoons honey\n2 tablespoons golden raisins\n2 tablespoons chopped pistachios\n2 tablespoons chopped dates or dried figs\n1 tablespoon sunflower seeds\n1 tablespoon minced chives\nPita chips, for serving\nSpecial equipment:\nHand mixer or stand mixer\n2 1/2 quart baking dish or 8x8 baking dish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Whip the goat cheese: In a medium bowl, add goat cheese, yogurt, milk, lemon juice, and a pinch of salt. Use a hand mixer or a stand mixer to whip the goat cheese mixture until it has a smooth, light consistency. (If you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a hand mixer or stand mixer, you can use a fork to mash the ingredients together, but they won't have the same whipped consistency.)\nThe finished dip should be easily spreadable with a knife. If it is too thick or seems dry, add more milk by the tablespoon.\n2 Assemble the dip: Spread the whipped goat cheese in a thin, even layer along the bottom of a 2 1/2-quart baking dish or an 8x8 baking dish. It shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be more than 1/2-inch thick in any part of the dip. Drizzle the honey over the dip; then sprinkle the bacon, golden raisins, pistachios, dates, sunflower seeds, and minced chives evenly over the top.\nKeep covered in the fridge until ready to eat, then serve with pita chips.\nThis dip can be easily made 2-3 days in advance and keeps well in the fridge. If you make it in advance, wait to add the honey and chives until right before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nGrilled Cheese BLT Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 4 sandwiches\nINGREDIENTS\n8 slices sourdough bread\n4 tablespoon unsalted butter, at room temperature\n8 ounces (2 cups) shredded cheddar cheese\n2 slicing tomatoes (such as beefsteak, Brandywine, or Cherokee purple), sliced 1/4-inch thick\n8 to 12 slices cooked bacon\n12 leaves butterhead or other crispy lettuce\nKosher salt and black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Melt the cheese: For each sandwich, spread 1 tablespoon butter on one side of two pieces of bread. Place the bread buttered-side down in a large skillet or on a griddle over medium-low heat. Sprinkle 2 ounces (1/2 cup) shredded cheese evenly over both slices. Cook until the cheese has melted and the bread is crisp, about 2 minutes.\n2 Assemble the sandwich: Remove from the skillet. Layer one side with 2 to 3 pieces of bacon, the slices from half a tomato seasoned with some salt and pepper, and 3 leaves of lettuce. Close the sandwich. Repeat for remaining sandwiches. Slice in half and eat warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nEasy Breakfast Casserole with Prosciutto Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 6 to 8\nYou can make and bake this savory strata all in one fell swoop, or assemble and refrigerate it the night before (but leave the cheese off until morning). Pull it out of the fridge 30 minutes before baking; add the cheese, and pop it into the oven.\nIf you have vegetarians at your table, feel free to skip the prosciutto and add one teaspoon of smoked paprika instead.\nThe strata holds up well as a leftover, so enjoy it for breakfast the next day, or pack up a slice for your desk lunch.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil\n1 medium yellow onion, chopped\n2 big handfuls tender greens, such as arugula, dandelion greens, baby kale, or spinach (tough stems removed)\n1 1/2 cups asparagus, cut into 3/4-inch pieces\n1 teaspoon kosher salt, divided\n3 ounces thinly sliced prosciutto\n2 packed cups cubed crusty bread, such as levain, baguette, or Italian bread (slightly stale is ok)\n8 large eggs\n1 cup low fat cottage cheese\n1 cup 2% milk (or whatever kind you have in the fridge)\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1 1/2 cups (3 oz) grated cheddar, divided\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the vegetables: Add oil to a 12-inch ovenproof skillet set over medium heat. I use cast iron, but any ovenproof skillet will do.\nAdd the onion and saut\xc3\xa9 until tender, about 5 minutes. Add the greens, asparagus, and 1/2 teaspoon salt and saut\xc3\xa9 until the greens wilt, about 2 minutes. Remove from heat.\n3 Add the prosciutto and bread: Tear the prosciutto slices into smaller pieces and distribute over the vegetables. Add the bread and stir everything together. Leave that to cool while you whisk the eggs.\n4 Whisk the eggs: In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs, cottage cheese, milk, the remaining 3/4 teaspoon salt, and several generous grinds of black pepper. Add 1/2 cup of the cheese and stir again. Pour the eggs over the vegetables and scatter the remaining cheese on top.\n5 Bake the casserole: Place the casserole in the oven and bake until it is just set with no obvious liquid remaining, about 35 minutes. It should be a little jiggly. Keep in mind that it will continue to cook a bit once it\xe2\x80\x99s out of the oven.\n6 Serve: Cool for 10 minutes. Cut into wedges and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nEASY Baked Apple Slices Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: Serves 2\nAs you slice up the apples, check for their flavor. If they don't taste good raw, believe me, they aren't going to taste good cooked.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups of peeled, sliced apples - use apples that cook up well, like Fuji or Jonagold\n3 Tbsp sugar\nA sprinkle of cinnamon\n1 Tbsp maple syrup\nMETHOD\n1 Sprinkle apples with cinnamon and sugar: Put apple slices in a glass bowl. Sprinkle on top the 3 Tbsp of sugar. Add a light sprinkle of cinnamon.\n2 Microwave on high for 5 minutes or more: Bake in microwave oven for 5 minutes on high heat. Adjust the time for your microwave and how many apples you are doing. Ours has a powerful high setting so 4 cups of apples only takes 5 minutes.\nIf you use more apples, you will probably need to cook it a little longer. I suggest starting with 5 minutes and testing for doneness with a fork. If it needs more cooking time, give it more.\n3 Add maple syrup to taste: When done, remove and mix so the sugar coats well all the apple pieces. Add maple syrup to taste, about 1 Tbsp.\nDelicious with whipped cream on top, or with vanilla ice cream on the side.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nSlow Cooked Boston Baked Beans Recipe\nCook time: 8 hoursYield: Serves 5-6 as a main dish or 10-12 as a side\nWhy pre-soak the beans? You don't have to (see this great Russ Parsons article in the LA Times about why you don't need to soak beans), but not doing so in this recipe will increase the cooking time. With the beans pre-soaked, they'll still take 8 hours to cook and soften in a slow-cooker. Once beans come in contact with the molasses, the sugar in the molasses will keep the beans firm. That's why they take so long to cook.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound (2 to 2 1/4 cups) dry white beans such as Navy beans or Great Northern beans (can also use kidney beans)\n1/3 cup molasses\n1/3 cup brown sugar\n3-4 Tbsp Dijon mustard\n1/8 teaspoon ground cloves\n3 cups hot water\n1/2 pound salt pork (can sub bacon), cut into 1/2-inch to 1-inch pieces\n1 medium onion, (1 1/2 cups) chopped\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak beans in water: Place beans in a large pot and cover with 2 inches of water. Soak overnight and drain. Alternatively, bring a pot with the beans covered with 2 inches of water to a boil, remove from heat and let soak for a hour, then drain.\n2 Mix molasses, brown sugar, mustard, ground cloves with water: Whisk together the molasses, brown sugar, mustard, and ground cloves with 3 cups of hot water.\n3 Add ingredients to slow-cooker, layering them, starting with the salt pork: Line the bottom of a slow-cooker (or a Dutch oven if you are cooking in the oven) with half of the salt pork (pick the fattiest pieces). Layer over with half of the drained beans. Add all of the chopped onion in a layer.\nTop with another layer of beans and the remaining salt pork. Pour the molasses water mixture over the beans to just cover the beans.\n4 Slow cook until beans are tender: Cover and cook in a slow-cooker on the low setting for 8 hours (or in a 250\xc2\xb0F oven), until the beans are tender. Check the water level a few hours in, and if the beans need more water, add some. Add additional salt to taste if needed.\nNote that fresher beans will cook faster than older beans. Your beans may be ready in less than 8 hours, or they may take longer. Best the next day.\nServe with Boston brown bread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBaked Beans in Tomato Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 2 hours, 45 minutesYield: Serves 8-10 as a side\nIf you want to save time, you can used canned beans instead of dry. Use 3 or 4 15-ounce cans, drained and rinsed and proceed to step 3. If you want a vegetarian version, skip the bacon, increase the olive oil, and use vegetable stock.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dry cannellini, borlotti or Great Northern beans\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/4 pound bacon or pancetta, roughly chopped\n1/2 medium onion, chopped\n4 garlic cloves, chopped\n1 tablespoon fresh sage, minced (can sub fresh rosemary)\n1/2 to 1 teaspoon chile flakes (depending on how spicy you want it)\n2 tablespoons honey\n1/4 cup tomato paste\n1 15-ounce can crushed tomatoes or tomato sauce\n2 cups beef or chicken stock (use gluten-free stock for gluten-free version)\nSalt\n1/2 cup chopped fresh parsley\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak the beans in water: Pre-soak the beans, either by covering with two inches of water and soaking overnight, or by pouring boiling water over them and soaking them for an hour.\n2 Drain beans, cover with water, cook until tender: Drain the beans and put them in a medium-sized pot and cover with 2 inches of water. Bring to a simmer, cover, reduce the heat to a low simmer and cook until the beans are just soft enough to eat, about 1 hour, give or take 15 minutes or so, depending on how old the beans are (older beans will take longer to cook).\n3 Cook bacon or pancetta: Preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. In a 3 or 4 quart heavy-bottomed, oven-proof, lidded pot such as a Dutch oven, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the bacon or pancetta and cook slowly until lightly browned and crispy.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions: Add the chopped onions and increase the heat to medium-high. Cook, stirring often, until the onions begin to brown. Use a wooden spoon to scrape any browned bits off the bottom of the pot.\n5 Add garlic, chili flakes, sage, then add tomatoes and stock: Add the garlic, chile flakes and sage and cook for 1-2 minutes, then add the honey and tomato paste. Stir well to combine.\nAdd the tomatoes or tomato sauce and the stock. Bring to a simmer. Taste for salt and add some if needed.\n6 Add the beans, cover, cook in oven: Drain the beans and add them to the pot. Stir well.\nCover the pot and cook in a 325\xc2\xb0F oven for 1 hour and 15 minutes.\nIf still a bit wet, remove the cover and cook for 15 minutes more.\nNote that the cooking time will depend on several things, the most important being how thoroughly the beans were cooked to begin with when they were simmered.\nIf the beans are still a bit hard when they go in the oven, it may take several hours to soften them, once the tomato and honey have been added.\n7 Stir in parsley and balsamic vinegar: Right before serving, gently stir in the chopped parsley and balsamic vinegar. Taste for salt, add more if needed to taste.\nServe either hot or at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nPressure Cooker Baked Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCooking (including pressure release) time: 2 hoursYield: 8 to 10 servings\nThis recipe uses an electric pressure cooker. Pressure cooking times will be slightly less if you\'re using a stovetop pressure cooker.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dried Great Northern beans\n1/3 cup molasses\n1/3 cup brown sugar\n3 tablespoons Dijon mustard\n1/8 teaspoon ground cloves\n8 ounces bacon, cut into 1/2-inch pieces\n1 medium onion, diced\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart electric pressure cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Par-cook the beans: Combine the dried beans and 8 cups of the water in an electric pressure cooker. Secure the lid on the pressure cooker. Make sure that the pressure regulator is set to the \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d position.\nIf you are using an Instant Pot, select the \xe2\x80\x9cBean/Chili\xe2\x80\x9d program, then adjust the time to 15 minutes. If your pressure does not have a \xe2\x80\x9cBean/Chili\xe2\x80\x9d program, set it manually to \xe2\x80\x9cHigh Pressure\xe2\x80\x9d for 15 minutes.\nIt will take about 20 minutes for your pressure cooker to come up to pressure, and then the 15 minutes of actual cooking will begin. \n2 Naturally release the pressure and drain the beans: When the timer goes off, wait for the pressure to release naturally for 15 minutes, then release the rest of the pressure by moving the pressure release knob from \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cVenting.\xe2\x80\x9d It will take a minute or two for the pressure to release completely.\nAt this point, the beans should be mostly cooked through, but still firm. It\'s fine if there\'s still a little bit of white at the center. If you\'d like to use some of the bean cooking liquid to make your baked beans, scoop out 1 1/2 cups of liquid and set it aside.\nWearing a pair of heat-proof mitts, lift the inner pot out of the pressure cooker and drain the beans into a colander in the sink. Wash out the pot and return it to the pressure cooker.\n3 Prepare the cooking liquid: In a small bowl, whisk together the molasses, sugar, mustard, ground cloves, and 1 1/2 cups water or reserved bean cooking liquid. Set aside.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 the bacon and onions: Reset the electric pressure cooker, then select its \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d program. Add the bacon to the pot and saut\xc3\xa9 it until it begins to render some fat, about 5 minutes.\nAdd the onions and saut\xc3\xa9 until they are translucent, about 5 more minutes. When done, hit "Cancel" to stop saut\xc3\xa9ing.\n5 Finish cooking the beans: Gently stir the beans and the cooking liquid into the pot with the bacon and onions. Secure the lid on the pressure cooker, again making sure that the pressure regulator is set to the \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d position.\nIf you are using an Instant Pot, select the \xe2\x80\x9cBean/Chili\xe2\x80\x9d program, then adjust the time to 15 minutes. If your pressure does not have a \xe2\x80\x9cBean/Chili\xe2\x80\x9d program, set it manually to \xe2\x80\x9cHigh Pressure\xe2\x80\x9d for 15 minutes.\nIt will take about 15 minutes for your pressure cooker to come up to pressure, and then the 15 minutes of actual cooking will begin.\n6 Let the pressure release naturally: When the cooking program finishes, let the pressure cooker completely release its pressure naturally. This will take about 30 minutes.\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t perform a quick release, as the thick cooking liquid will sputter out of the pressure release valve.\n7 Serve the beans warm: They are very good straight out of the pot, and taste even better the next day. Reheat beans over low temperature on the stovetop, in a low oven, or in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nThree Bean Baked Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 7 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 pound sliced bacon\n2 cups chopped onion\n1 Tbsp dry mustard\n1 teaspoon minced fresh thyme (or 1/2 teaspoons dry thyme)\n3/4 cup ketchup\n3 tablespoons apple cider vinegar\n1/4 cup dark molasses\n1/3 cup water\n1 bay leaf\n1 15-ounce can red kidney beans, rinsed, drained\n1 15-ounce can black beans, rinsed, drained\n1 15-ounce can cannellini (white kidney beans), rinsed, drained\n1 teaspoon Tabasco\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Cook and crumble the bacon: Cook the bacon in a large Dutch oven over medium heat until browned and crisp. Remove bacon and place on paper towels to soak up excess fat. Crumble up the bacon and set aside.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: Remove all but a tablespoon of the bacon drippings from the pot. Add the chopped onions and cook on medium high heat until translucent, about 5 minutes.\n4 Add the rest of the ingredients: Sprinkle the onions with dry mustard and thyme. Stir in the ketchup, vinegar, molasses, bay leaf, beans, Tabasco, and water. Add salt and pepper to taste.\n5 Cover and bake: Cover the pot and put into a 350\xc2\xb0F oven. Bake for 1 hour, checking every 15 minutes to stir and add more water if needed. Stir in the bacon the last 15 minutes of cooking.\nAlternatively, cook in a slow cooker 4 hours on high, or 8 on low.\nDiscard bay leaf before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nEasy Stovetop Baked Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 pound thick-cut bacon, cut crosswise into 1/4-inch wide strips\n1/2 peeled onion, stem intact\n4 (15-ounce) cans navy beans, rinsed and drained\n1 (8-ounce) can tomato sauce\n3 tablespoons molasses\n2 tablespoons brown sugar\n2 teaspoons dry mustard powder\n1 bay leaf\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 cup water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the bacon: In a large soup pot over medium heat, cook the bacon, turning often, for 5 minutes, or until browned. Pour off and discard about half the excess fat. Set aside about 1/4 cup bacon for garnish.\n2 Cook the beans: Add the onion half, drained beans, tomato sauce, molasses, brown sugar, mustard powder, bay leaf, salt, and water to the pot. Bring to a simmer over medium heat.\nCover the pot and simmer for 25 to 30 minutes, or until the sauce is thick. If your sauce doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be thickening to your liking, remove the lid for the final 5 minutes of cooking. Remove the onion half and bay leaf.\n  3 To serve: Serve the beans from the pot, or transfer them to a bowl, and sprinkle the reserved bacon on top.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nRoasted Beets with Balsamic Glaze Recipe\nCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds red beets, medium sized, scrubbed clean, green tops removed (see beet greens recipe for what to do with beet greens)\n2 teaspoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt\n1/2 cup balsamic vinegar\n2 teaspoons sugar\n1 teaspoon grated orange zest\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F and line pan with aluminum foil.\n2 Prepare the beets: Place the beets in the pan. Rub olive oil over the beets, and sprinkle with salt. Cover the beets with another sheet of aluminum foil.\n3 Roast the beets: Roast for 1 to 2 hours, depending on the size of the beets and how old they are. After 1 hour, test every fifteen minutes by poking a beet with the tines of a fork. Once the fork tines go in easily, the beets are tender and cooked. Remove from the oven.\n4 Prepare balsamic glaze: While the beets are cooling, prepare the balsamic glaze. In a small, shallow saut\xc3\xa9 pan, add the balsamic vinegar and sugar. Heat on high until the vinegar has reduced to a syrup consistency. Remove from heat.\n5 Peel and cut cooked beets: After the beets have cooled for several minutes, but are still warm to the touch, peel off the outer skins and discard. Cut the beets into quarters or more bite-sized pieces.\n6 Pour glaze over beets: Place beets in a serving bowl. Pour balsamic glaze over the beets. Stir in grated orange zest, and add salt and pepper to taste.\nGarnish with a little orange zest to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nKale Salad with Balsamic Dressing Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesRest in dressing time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nSlightly adapted from a Dan Barber recipe that appeared in Bon Appetit in 2009.\nFeel free to sub out the pine nuts with toasted slivered almonds, and the dried sweetened cranberries with golden raisins. We use both interchangeably in this salad.\nIf you are using regular kale instead of dinosaur kale, you might want to let the salad marinate a bit longer, two hours or more, before serving.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup dried sweetened cranberries, chopped (or whole golden raisins or currants)\n1/3 cup pine nuts (can substitute slivered almonds)\n1 pound fresh Lacinato kale (also called Tuscan kale or dinosaur kale), about 2-3 bunches, rinsed and patted dry\n1/4 cup balsamic vinegar\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1 tablespoon seasoned rice vinegar\n1 tablespoon honey\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon pepper\n1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, packed\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toast the pine nuts: Heat a small skillet on medium high heat. Spread the pine nuts in an even layer on the bottom of the pan. Cook, stirring occasionally, until lightly browned. Then remove to a bowl to allow to cool.\nHint when toasting nuts: do not take your eyes off of them! Nuts can go from browned to burned very quickly.\n2 Prep the kale: Use a sharp knife to cut out the tough midrib of each kale leaf, and discard or compost. Slice the leaves crosswise into thin, 1/4 inch wide, slices.\nThe easiest way to do this is to work with a small bunch of leaves at a time, stack the leaves and roll them into a loose cigar shape. Then using a sharp knife, work from one end of the "cigar" to the other, slicing a 1/4 inch off from the end.\nPlace the kale slices into a large bowl.\n3 Make the dressing: In a smaller bowl, whisk together the balsamic vinegar, olive oil, rice vinegar, honey, salt, and pepper.\n4 Dress the kale and toss with nuts and cranberries: A half hour to an hour or two before serving, toss the kale together with the toasted pine nuts, the dried cranberries, and the dressing, allowing the kale to marinate a bit.\n5 Right before serving, stir in the grated Parmesan cheese.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nRoasted Brussels Sprouts with Pomegranate-Balsamic Glaze Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 6 servings\nThe pomegranate-balsamic glaze can be made ahead and will keep in the refrigerator for up to a month.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the glaze:\n1 cup pomegranate juice\n2/3 cup balsamic vinegar\n2 tablespoons brown sugar\nFor the Brussels sprouts:\n1 1/2 pounds Brussels sprouts\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 to 2/3 cup pomegranate arils\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the glaze: Combine the pomegranate juice, balsamic vinegar, and brown sugar in a saucepan and bring to boil over medium heat. Reduce the heat to medium-low and let the liquid simmer for 25 to 30 minutes, until reduced to a syrupy glaze that coats the spoon. Stir occasionally. You should have about 2/3 cup of pomegranate balsamic glaze when done. (Once cool, store the glaze in the refrigerator for up to a month.)\n2 Preheat oven to 375F. Move the oven racks to the upper third and lower third positions. Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.\n3 Roast the Brussels sprouts: Trim the ends of the Brussels sprouts and slice them in half. Chop very large sprouts into quarters. Toss with the olive oil and a good pinch of salt. Divide the sprouts between 2 baking sheets and roast for 20 to 25 minutes, stirring halfway through.\n4 Toss the sprouts with the glaze: Let the Brussels sprouts cool for a few minutes before tossing them with 2 to 3 tablespoons of the pomegranate balsamic reduction and the pomegranate arils. Taste and add more glaze if you like. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nBalsamic-Glazed Red Onions Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the onions:\n4 medium red onions (1 1/2 to 2 pounds total)\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar (See our Guide to Balsamic Vinegar)\n1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon chopped fresh oregano\n1/8 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper\nFor the glaze:\n1 tablespoon balsamic vinegar\n1 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/8 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the onions: Preheat the oven to 400F. Slice off any straggly roots from the onions, leaving the firm root centers intact. Cut the onions in half from tip to root. Peel off the skins until all the papery layers are removed. Cut each half into 4 wedges, slicing through the root so that the wedges stay intact.\n2 Pack onions into baking dish: Pack the onions as tightly as you can into a 1 to 1 1/2 quart baking dish (9-inch round or oval, 8-inch square).\nSprinkle the olive oil, balsamic, 1 tablespoon of the oregano, salt, pepper evenly over the top. (No need to stir or you'll disturb the pretty arrangement!)\n3 Roast the onions: Cover the baking dish with foil and roast the onions for 30 minutes. Remove the foil and continue roasting the onions uncovered for 30 minutes more.\n4 Make the glaze: In a bowl, whisk the balsamic, mustard, salt, and pepper. Gradually whisk in the olive oil.\n5 Pour the glaze over the roasted onions and return the dish to the oven. Continue cooking another 10 minutes, or until the onions are very tender when pierced with the tip of a knife.\n6 Sprinkle the onions with the remaining 1 teaspoon oregano before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nBalsamic Roasted Brussels Sprouts and Shallots Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds Brussels sprouts, tough outer leaves removed, base trimmed, sprouts cut in half\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSeveral large shallots, peeled and thickly sliced, about a cup\n4 cloves garlic, peeled, sliced in half\n2 tablespoons plus 2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar\nSalt\nPepper\n3/4 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves or 1/4 teaspoon dried thyme\n1/2 cup walnuts, toasted (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 shallots in olive oil: Heat the olive oil in an oven-safe saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the shallots, spread them out in an even layer, lower the heat to medium low, and let them cook for 6 to 8 minutes, until softened and lightly browned.\n2 Add Brussels sprouts, garlic, balsamic: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Add the Brussels sprouts and the garlic to the shallots. Cook for 5 to 6 minutes more, until the sprouts begin to brown.\nDrizzle with 2 tablespoons of balsamic vinegar. Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Toss to coat.\n3 Bake in oven: Place in oven, uncovered. Roast at 425\xc2\xb0F for 15 to 20 minutes, until cooked through and caramelized on the edges.\n4 Sprinkle with balsamic, thyme, walnuts, salt, pepper: Remove from oven. Sprinkle with remaining 2 teaspoons of balsamic vinegar, the thyme, and toasted walnuts (if using). Stir to combine. Add more salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nRoast Quail with Balsamic Reduction Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 2\nQuail, properly cooked, still have a blush of pink inside. They are delicate-tasting birds and need this delicate treatment to truly shine. If you are aiming for a temperature, 150\xc2\xb0F in either the leg or breast is ideal; quail are so small the whole bird will likely be the same temperature throughout.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 whole quail\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\nSalt\n1 celery stick\n1/2 cup chicken stock\n1/2 cup inexpensive balsamic vinegar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Defrost frozen quail: If you are working with frozen quail, either defrost overnight in the refrigerator, or place the package in a large bowl and cover with a couple inches of room temperature water for 20 minutes.\n2 Truss the quail: Pre-heat the oven to 500\xc2\xb0F. Truss the quail with kitchen string. Cut off a length of string about 18 inches long. Cross the middle of the string over the quail's legs and bring the string around to the front of the bird, making sure it holds the wings close to the bird's flanks. Tie the string tightly around the neck.\n(Chowhound has an excellent video on how to truss a chicken, and quail are the same, only smaller.)\nAllow the quail to come to room temperature for at least 20 minutes.\n3 Arrange quail in roasting pan: Pat the quail dry with paper towels. Coat the quail with the olive oil and salt well. When the oven is hot, arrange the quail, breast side up, in a small roasting pan. Use pieces of the celery stick to keep the birds upright while they roast.\n4 Roast quail: Roast quail for 10-12 minutes in a 500\xc2\xb0F oven. Remove the birds from the pan and set aside on a plate to rest for 10 minutes, loosely tented with foil.\n5 Make balsamic reduction: As the quail are resting, make the sauce by putting the roasting pan on a burner set to medium heat. Discard the celery sticks.\nAdd the chicken stock and deglaze the pan by scraping all the browned bits off the bottom. Bring this to a simmer and pour into a small pot or saut\xc3\xa9 pan.\nAdd the balsamic vinegar, increase the heat to high and boil down to a syrup. Halfway through the boil, pour any accumulated juice from the resting quail into the sauce. When the sauce thickens and will coat the back of a spoon, it's ready.\n6 Serve: Serve the quail with the sauce drizzled over everything. Serve with a side of polenta, or rice pilaf.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBalsamic Risotto with Tomatoes and Basil Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 3 to 4\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups of stock (I use homemade vegetable stock or Better Than Bouillon)\n1 Tbsp butter\n1/2 cup chopped shallots\n1 clove garlic, minced\n1 cup (200 g) risotto rice (arborio, carnaroli, or vialone nano)\n1/3 cup dry white wine (I recommend a New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc)\n1/2 cup grated or shredded Parmesan cheese\n1 to 2 Tbsp balsamic vinegar\nWhite pepper\n1/4 teaspoon fresh thyme or a pinch of dried thyme\n1 1/2 cups cherry tomatoes, halved\n4 basil leaves, thinly sliced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the stock: Bring 4 cups of stock to a low simmer in a small pot. Keep the stock warm while making the risotto.\n2 Cook shallots and garlic: Melt a tablespoon of butter in a wide saucepan on medium heat. Add the chopped shallots and cook until translucent, a couple of minutes.\nAdd the minced garlic and cook until fragrant, a half minute more.\n3 Lightly brown the rice: Add the risotto rice to the pan and toss to coat with the shallots. Increase the heat to medium high and let the rice start to brown.\n4 Add the white wine: Stir in the white wine. The pan will steam up. Let the rice absorb the wine.\n5 Start adding the stock, 1/2 cup at a time: Here is the real process of making risotto. Add the stock, a half cup or ladleful at a time, slowly stirring the rice, and allowing the rice to absorb the stock for a minute or two, before adding another ladleful of stock.\nYou\'ll want to stop adding the stock when the rice is cooked through, but still a little firm to the bite, "al dente". Note that you may not need all of the stock you have heated for this recipe.\n6 Add balsamic, tomatoes, thyme with last 1/2 cup of stock: When it comes time for that last 1/2 cup of stock to add to the risotto, add it, as well as the balsamic vinegar. Balsamic vinegar can vary in its acidity and intensity. So, add 1 tablespoon to start, and add another tablespoon if you want more of the balsamic flavor.\nAdd half of the cherry tomatoes and add the thyme. Let the tomatoes soften with the cooking of the risotto in those last few minutes.\n7 Remove from heat, stir in Parm: When the risotto has reached it\'s "al dente" stage, remove it from heat. Stir in the shredded Parmesan cheese. Sprinkle with pepper.\n8 Serve: Serve with remaining halved fresh cherry tomatoes and thinly sliced basil on top.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nRicotta-Mascarpone Mousse with Balsamic Strawberries Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesChilling time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup heavy whipping cream\n1 pound whole milk ricotta cheese\n8 ounces mascarpone cheese\n3/4 cup granulated sugar\nGrated zest of one lemon\n2 pounds strawberries, hulled and cut into quarters\n1/4 cup balsamic vinegar, or to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Whip cream to soft peaks: In a medium bowl, beat the cream until soft peaks form.\n\n2 Beat ricotta mascarpone mixture: In a large bowl combine the ricotta, mascarpone, 1/2 cup of the sugar, and lemon zest. Using an electric beater, whip the ricotta-mascarpone mixture until thoroughly combined and smooth.\n3 Fold whipped cream into ricotta mixture, chill: Gradually fold the whipped cream into the ricotta until the mixture is smooth. Cover and refrigerate for a couple of hours.\n4 Mix strawberries with sugar and balsamic: Put strawberries in another bowl. Half an hour before serving gently mix in the remaining sugar and balsamic vinegar. Make sure you don't let the strawberries sit in the balsamic vinegar much longer than 30 minutes before serving or the acidity of the vinegar will cook the strawberries.\n5 Assemble: When you are ready to serve, fill glass bowls halfway with the strawberries and their juices. Spoon on the ricotta-mascarpone mousse or use a pastry bag to pipe the mousse.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nEasy Broiled Steak\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 8 minutesMarinating time: 2 - 24 hoursYield: Serves 4\nIf your balsamic vinegar is very aged and thick, replace the 2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar with 1 tablespoon balsamic and 1 tablespoon red wine vinegar.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n2 tablespoons soy sauce\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1 teaspoon ground coriander\n1 teaspoon garlic powder\n1/2 teaspoon smoked paprika\n1 1/2 pounds (four 6-ounce) sirloin, ribeye, or strip steaks, about 1 inch thick\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine the marinade ingredients: In a small bowl or jar, stir together the vinegar, soy sauce, olive oil, salt, pepper, coriander, garlic powder, and smoked paprika.\n2 Marinate the steaks: Place the steaks in a gallon zip-top bag or a lidded container that just fits the steaks\xe2\x80\x94you want them to get cozy with the marinade. Pour the marinade over the steaks, turning them to coat the steaks on all sides. Close the bag or container, pushing as much air out as possible. Refrigerate and marinate the steaks for at least 2 hours, or up to 24 hours.\n3 Heat your broiler: Preheat your oven broiler to 550\xc2\xbaF (or as high as your broiler goes) with the oven rack in its highest position (about 4 to 6 inches from the broiler element), and line a baking sheet with aluminum foil.\n4 Dry the steaks: Pat the steaks dry with paper towels and place them on the lined baking sheet. Patting the steaks dry is very important\xe2\x80\x94you don\xe2\x80\x99t want a bunch of extra marinade on the steaks and the sheet pan, as it will just burn under the broiler.\n5 Broil the steaks: Broil the steaks for 4 minutes on the first side, then use a pair of tongs to flip them and broil for 4 minutes more on the second side. Use a digital thermometer to test for doneness.\nI aim for around 130\xc2\xbaF in the center for medium-rare to medium steaks\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99ll continue to cook a bit after you take them out of the oven. If the steaks are not yet done, flip and broil for an additional minute, and test again. (I usually end up broiling my steaks for 4 to 6 minutes per side, depending on their thickness.)\nIf the steaks are already charred after 4 minutes per side, but still undercooked in the middle, lower the oven rack a rung for the remainder of cooking, or even just turn the oven off and use the carryover heat to finish cooking the steaks for another minute or two.\n6 Rest and Serve: Transfer the steaks to a cutting board. Let them rest for about 5-7 minutes. Then plate and serve with your favorite side.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nInstant Pot Pot Roast with Balsamic and Rosemary Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 45 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nStovetop Pressure Cooker Instructions:\nFollow the recipe as written, but lower the cooking time for the pot roast to 50 minutes at high pressure. Lower the cooking time for the potatoes and carrots to 4 minutes at high pressure.\nStovetop/Oven Instructions:\nPreheat the oven to 300\xc2\xb0F. Season the roast with the salt and pepper, then sear in a Dutch oven on the stovetop over medium-high heat. Remove it to a dish, then saut\xc3\xa9 the onions, garlic, and rosemary, then add the broth and vinegar as in the recipe below.\nAdd the pot roast back to the Dutch oven, then add enough water to come about a third of the way up the roast. Cover the Dutch oven with its lid and place in the oven.\nRoast the pot roast for 3 hours, or until it is tender, adding the carrots and potatoes during the last 1 1/2 hours of cooking. Check the pot roast every 45 minutes or so\xe2\x80\x94if too much liquid has evaporated, add an extra splash of water.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne (2 1/2 to 3-pound) boneless beef chuck pot roast\n2 teaspoons salt\n1 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1 tablespoon vegetable oil\n1 jumbo (12-ounce) onion, sliced\n4 cloves garlic, chopped\n2 (4-inch) sprigs fresh rosemary\n3/4 cup beef broth or vegetable broth\n1/4 cup aged balsamic vinegar\n1 1/2 pounds new potatoes (halved if over 1 1/2 inches in diameter, quartered if even larger)\n1 pound baby carrots (or regular carrots, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch rounds)\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh parsley, for serving (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart electric pressure cooker, such as the Instant Pot\nFat separator\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Dry and season the roast: Place the roast on a dish and pat it dry with a paper towel. Season it all over with the 1 1/2 teaspoons of salt and pepper.\n2 Sear the pot roast on the top and bottom: Select the Saut\xc3\xa9 setting on your electric pressure cooker and heat the oil for 3 minutes, until the oil is shimmering. Using a pair of tongs, lower the pot roast into the pot and sear it for 4 minutes on top and bottom (8 minutes total), until browned. Transfer the pot roast back to the dish.\n3 Cook the onions and seasonings: Add onions and 1/2 teaspoon of salt to pot and saut\xc3\xa9 them for about 3 minutes, until they are a bit softened. Add the garlic and rosemary and saut\xc3\xa9 1 minute more, until the garlic is no longer raw. Add the beef broth and balsamic vinegar, then use a wooden spoon to nudge any browned bits from the bottom of the pot.\n4 Pressure cook the roast: Use the tongs to lower the pot roast back into the pot, and spoon some of the cooking liquid over the top of the roast.\nSecure the lid on your pressure cooker in its Sealing position. Cancel the Saut\xc3\xa9 program, then select the Manual or Pressure Cook program for 55 minutes at high pressure. (It will take about 5 minutes for the pot to come up to pressure before the cooking program begins.)\n5 Release the pressure: When the cooking program ends, let the pressure release naturally for at least 15 minutes, then move the pressure release valve from to Venting to release any remaining steam. \nYou can also leave the pot roast on the Keep Warm setting for up to 10 hours. You do not need to vent the steam.\n6 Rest the pot roast: Open the pot and use the tongs to transfer the roast to a cutting board. Cover the roast with aluminum foil to keep it warm.\n7 Strain the cooking liquid: Set a strainer over a fat separator in the sink. Wearing heat-resistant mitts, lift the inner pot out of the pressure cooker housing and pour the cooking liquid through the strainer and into the fat separator. (If you don't have a fat separator, you can pour the liquid into a ziplock bag, tilt it, let the fat rise to the top. Then, cut a hole in the bottom corner of the bag to let the liquid strain out, stopping before you get to the fat.)\nDiscard the rosemary stems, then add the strained onions, garlic, and rosemary leaves back to pot. Pour the liquid from fat separator back into the pot as well. Discard the fat.\n8 Pressure cook the vegetables: Add the potatoes and carrots to the pot and place it back in its housing. Secure the lid in its Sealing position.\nCancel the cooking program, then select the Manual or Pressure Cook program for 5 minutes at high pressure. (It will take about 15 minutes for the pot to come up to pressure before the cooking program begins.)\n9 Release the pressure: When the cooking program ends, perform a quick pressure release by moving the pressure release valve to Venting to release the steam.\n10 Serve: Open the pot, then use a slotted spoon to transfer vegetables to serving dish. Taste the cooking liquid for seasoning, adding salt and/or pepper if needed.\nRemove any string from the pot roast, then carve it into 1/2-inch thick slices. Arrange the pot roast on the serving plate with the vegetables. Ladle some of the cooking liquid over the meat and vegetables, garnish with parsley (if using), and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nChocolate Banana Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes one 9x5-inch loaf\nUse very ripe or over-ripe bananas. The peels should be at least half browned, and the bananas inside squishy and browning.\nDo not use Dutch processed cocoa for this recipe, only natural unsweetened.\nMelted coconut oil can be used in place of the butter. The flavor will change a little and you may get a hint of coconut in the result.\nThere is only 1 egg and 1 teaspoon of baking soda in this recipe for leavening, so make sure your baking soda is still good! (See more info on baking soda and baking powder.)\nINGREDIENTS\n3 large ripe bananas (easily mashable)\n1/3 cup melted butter\n3/4 cup brown sugar (packed, light or dark)\n1 teaspoon salt (1/2 a teaspoon if using salted butter)\n1 large egg, beaten\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 1/4 cup all purpose flour\n1/4 cup natural unsweetened cocoa powder\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1/4 teaspoon ground allspice\n1/2 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips\nSpecial equipment:\n1 5x9-inch loaf pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare pan and preheat oven:  Butter or spray with cooking spray the inside of a 5x9-inch loaf pan. Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) with a rack in the middle.\n2 Pur\xc3\xa9e bananas: Using a blender, food processor, or a fork, pur\xc3\xa9e the peeled ripe bananas until smooth. You should have 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 cups of banana pur\xc3\xa9e.\n3 Mix wet ingredients and sugar: Place the banana pur\xc3\xa9e into a large mixing bowl. Stir the melted butter. Stir in the brown sugar and salt. Whisk to break up any clumps of brown sugar. Stir in the beaten egg and vanilla extract.\n4 Mix dry ingredients: In a separate bowl, vigorously whisk together the flour, cocoa, baking soda, and allspice.\n5 Add the flour mixture to the banana mixture and stir until just incorporated.\nStir in the chocolate chips.\n6 Bake: Pour batter into a buttered loaf pan. Place in a 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) oven and bake for 1 hour.\nNote that because of the chocolate chips that melt in the bread as it cooks, it's hard to check for doneness using a tester that you insert.\nOne way to test is to gently push the center top of the chocolate banana bread down with your finger. If it feels relatively firm and bounces back when you release your finger, that's a good sign that it's done.\n7 Let cool: Remove from oven and let cool for 10 minutes in the pan.\nGently remove the loaf from the pan and place on a rack to cool completely.\nSlice with a serrated bread knife to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBanana Nut Muffins Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes 12 muffins\nNo need for a mixer with this recipe.\nDon't want the nuts?
