Brush the legs all over with 1/4 cup of the barbecue sauce, reserving the rest.\nCover, and set in fridge to marinate at least 30 minutes or as long as overnight.\n2 Prepare the chicken for cooking: Set the broiler to high with a rack positioned a few inches below. Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil and set a metal cooling rack (like the ones used for baking) inside (or use a broiler pan).\nArrange the marinated chicken legs on the wire rack with a little space between each leg.\n3 Sear the chicken: Slide the pan under broiler, and broil chicken on one side until you begin to see dark brown charred spots, 5 to 7 minutes. Flip, and sear the second side until also browned, another 3 to 5 minutes or so.\n4 Turn the oven to 350F and reposition the rack in the middle of the oven.\n5 Finish cooking the chicken: Brush chicken all over with all but a tablespoon of the remaining sauce. Slide into the oven and bake 15 minutes. Flip chicken, and brush with the remaining sauce anywhere it's needed.\nContinue baking until the internal temperature of the chicken reaches 165\xc2\xb0F when testing with a meat thermometer, another 15 to 20 minutes.\n6 Serve chicken right away while hot, with extra barbecue sauce on the side.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nMemphis-Style Pork Ribs Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 hoursYield: Serves 4\nTry to get St. Louis-cut ribs for this recipe, not baby back ribs. Regular spare ribs are fine, too.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup sweet paprika\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n1 Tbsp black pepper\n1 Tbsp garlic powder\n2 teaspoons cumin\n2 teaspoons salt\n2 teaspoons cayenne\n1 teaspoon dry mustard\n1/2 teaspoon celery seed\n1/2 teaspoon dried oregano\n2 St. Louis-cut or spare rib racks\nMETHOD\n1 Make the dry rub, rub all over ribs: Mix all the dry ingredients together. Rub them all over the ribs and, if you have time, set them in the fridge overnight.\n2 Grill over low, indirect heat initially for one hour: Get your grill or smoker going. You want pretty low heat, about 200-220\xc2\xb0F if you can measure it. Make sure you have a spot to put the ribs that is not directly over the heat source. Lay the ribs down. They should not sizzle. If they do, cool the grill down until the ribs no longer sizzle when placed down. Cover the grill or smoker and walk away for an hour.\n3 Every hour or so after that, turn and rotate the ribs so they cook evenly. You should not have to baste them if you do this: The fat in the ribs will do the basting for you. Depending on how hot your set-up is and at what stage of doneness you like your ribs, they will be done in 4-8 hours.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBarbecued Pork Shoulder on a Gas Grill Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 8 hoursYield: Serves 6-8\nNote that this cooking time is for a 4-pound Boston butt pork shoulder. A general rule on barbecued pork is to cook it at about 215\xc2\xb0F to 225\xc2\xb0F for 90 minutes per pound.\nIf using a rub, you\'ll need to get the rub on the night before and refrigerate.\nCooking a 4 pound roast, allowing time for the barbecue to heat up and for the meat to rest once done, can easily take 9 hours, so start early in the morning if you want to have the roast done in time for dinner.\nYou need to keep smoke on the meat for at least 4 hours for a 4 pound roast. If the roast isn\'t done after 6 hours, finish it in the oven, wrapped tightly in foil to hold in the moisture.\nTwo rub recipes are provided here. Pick one for a 4 pound roast, or if barbecuing two roasts, try one each.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 4 pound pork shoulder roast, preferably Boston butt, boneless or bone-in (you can easily make two 4 pound roasts in about the same amount of time if your grill is big enough to accommodate them both)\n5 to 6 cups of wood chips, hickory, oak, apple, or other fruit wood\nBBQ Rub (enough for a 4 pound roast)\n2 Tbsp brown sugar, packed\n2 Tbsp white sugar\n2 Tbsp paprika\n1 Tbsp kosher salt\n1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin\n1 1/2 teaspoons garlic powder\n1 1/2 teaspoons chipotle chile powder\n1 1/2 teaspoons black pepper\nSanta Maria Rub (enough for a 4 pound roast)\n1 Tbsp salt\n1 Tbsp finely ground black pepper\n1 Tbsp garlic powder\n1 Tbsp onion powder\n1 teaspoon cayenne\n1 Tbsp dried oregano\n1 teaspoon dry rosemary (or fresh, finely minced)\n1/2 teaspoon dry sage\n1/4 teaspoon sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nThe day before:\n1. Prepare the rub. Mix all the ingredients for the rub together, breaking up any clumps. Taste the rub as you make it and see if you like the taste, adjust accordingly.\n2. Rub the roast with the rub. Unwrap the pork roast and place it on its butcher paper or in a roasting pan, something that can catch the rub. With your (clean) hands work the rub mixture into the pork shoulder all over, including inside any crevasses you may find in a boneless roast where the bone had been. Be generous with the amount of rub.\nRewrap it in the butcher paper or wrap it in plastic and place it in a pan (to catch any liquid that may drip out), and refrigerate it overnight.\nThe night before:\n3. Soak the wood chips. Take 3 or 4 large handfuls of wood chips (hickory, oak, apple or other fruit wood) and place them in a bowl and cover them with water to soak them overnight (can also do for an hour before using).\nI think it helps to have a mix of sizes, from small chips to larger (1-inch x 2-inch) chunks. The smaller chips will get smoking more quickly, but will burn out more quickly too. The larger chunks will take longer to catch, but last well past when the smaller chips have burned themselves out.\nThe Day Of:\n4. Bring the chilled roast to room temp. 1 to 2 hours before you start the barbecue, take the pork out of the refrigerator to come to room temperature.\nNow, if you forget to do this, which I have done, you can still go ahead and BBQ it. You\'ll likely be finishing it in the oven anyway. It will just take a bit longer to cook.\n5. Prepare your grill. Remove one of the grill grates. This will be your "hot" side, where the wood chips will go. The other side of the grill will be the "cool" side, and where the meat will be, away from direct heat.\nDepending on the structure of your grill, you may want to remove the "flavor bar", the thin metal piece with lots of holes in it that sits over the burner. The wood chips will smoke more easily if they lay in a (fireproof metal or foil) container directly on the burner.\n6. Place a tray of water on the grill: If there is room on your grill, place a small aluminum tray of water on the grill to help moderate the heat and help keep the roast from getting too dry. A good place to place this is on an upper rack if you grill has one.\n7. Get the grill smoking. Create a double layered aluminum foil boat with a handful or two of damp wood chips in it.\nPlace the boat directly on the burner on the "hot" side of the grill if you can (otherwise place on the flavor bar). Turn the grill on to medium flame, cover the grill and let it heat up until the the wood chips start smoking.\nYou\'ll either see smoke coming out of the grill, or if you raise the lid, you\'ll see smoke coming out of the wood chip boat. You should see and smell the smoke.\nYou\'ll be replenishing the wood chips periodically for the next several hours so put more dry chips into water to soak if needed.\n8. Cook roast on cool side of grill, fat side up: Once the grill is smoking, place the roast on the grill grates on the cool side of the grill, away from direct heat. If your grill has a hot spot, position the roast away from it. If there is a fatty side to the meat, put that side facing up; the fat will render over time and baste the pork.\nCover the grill, lower the flame, and let the cooking begin. The temperature you want to maintain ideally is 225\xc2\xb0F. Try to keep it close to that temperature, within a range of 210\xc2\xb0F to 240\xc2\xb0F. If the temperature goes too high, the roast may dry out. If it\'s too low, it will take forever to cook.\n9. Maintain the smoke and the 225\xc2\xb0F temperature. This is the tricky part. You will want to maintain smoke in the grill for at least 4 hours (6 hours for a bigger roast). You will also want to maintain a cooking temperature of around 225\xc2\xb0. So, you have to check the grill!\nCheck if the temperature is being maintained between 210\xc2\xb0F and 240\xc2\xb0F, and check to make sure the chips are still producing smoke, every half hour. About once an hour you will likely need to replenish the chip boat with more wood chips.\nResist the temptation to open the grill more than once an hour. Every time you open the grill the inside temperature drops and you increase your overall cooking time.\nI found the best way to check the temperature, since I don\'t have a gauge in the grill itself, is to put an instant read meat thermometer into an opening in the hood on the meat side (cool side) of the grill, and just keep checking it. Make sure sensor tip of the probe is not touching the meat itself.\nYou want to avoid opening up the hood too often, because every time you do that, you lose heat. Of course, if your gas grill gets too hot, opening the hood can cool it down quickly.\nExpect a minimum cooking time, if you have been diligent at maintaining a 225\xc2\xb0F, of 90 minutes per pound. So if you are cooking a 4 pound roast, total cooking time will be at least 6 hours (and easily more). An 8 pound roast will take at least 12 hours of cooking time.\nIf you want to cook 8 pounds of pork shoulder more quickly, I recommend starting with two 4 pound roasts, spaced on the grill a few inches apart, which will cook in just a little more time than an 8 pound roast.\n10 Reposition the roast: After 2 or 3 hours, during one of your hourly opening of the grill to refresh the wood chips, reposition the roast so that the side that was closest to the heat is now furthest from the heat.\n11. Test internal temperature of meat. After about 5 hours, start taking the pork\'s internal temperature: You can eat it at 165\xc2\xb0F, but if you are making pulled pork the meat needs to be ideally 195\xc2\xb0F.\n12 Remove from heat, let rest: When the meat reaches 195\xc2\xb0F, remove it from the heat, tent it loosely with foil over a cutting board (to catch the juices) and let it rest for at least 30 minutes, and preferably 1 hour.\nIf after 6 hours of cooking, if the meat hasn\'t reached 195\xc2\xb0 internal temp (usually after 6 hours, the internal temp on my roasts is about 155\xc2\xb0F), my recommendation is to remove it from the grill and finish in the oven.\nTo finish in the oven, wrap the roast in aluminum foil to help prevent it from drying out in the oven, and place it in a roasting pan, in a 300\xc2\xb0F oven.\nCook until the internal temperature of the roast reaches 195\xc2\xb0F. If your starting internal meat temperature is 150\xc2\xb0F or so, this can take anywhere from an hour to two hours.\nWhen it reaches temperature, remove the roast from the oven and let rest for at least 30 minutes, up to an hour.\n13. Pull the pork. Pull the pork with 2 forks. Only now do you add any barbecue sauce (and any accumulated juices) to the meat. Taste it first! It might not need sauce at all, and if it does, add only a little at a time. One of the biggest sins of barbecue is to over-sauce perfectly good meat.\nServe on a bun with or without sauce, and with or without coleslaw. Also great with grilled or raw pineapple.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nHow to Turn Your Kettle Grill into a Smoker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1. Prep your meat and wood. I like to brine pork in a salt-sugar solution. Mine is typically 1/4 cup kosher salt with 1/2 cup brown sugar mixed with 4 cups of water. You can add any spices or herbs you want. How long? 3-6 hours for ribs or even overnight for a pork butt.\nGet your smoking wood ready by soaking it in water for at least 2 hours. Overnight is better. And when you are using a kettle grill, make sure you have wood chips: Not big blocks, not sawdust. Chips.\nAnywhere from an hour to a day before you start cooking \xe2\x80\x93 depending on how deeply spiced you want your meat \xe2\x80\x93 you can remove your meat from the brine and apply a dry rub to the meat. This is optional, especially if you have a full-flavored sauce. But most professional pit masters will use a rub as a base flavor with a sauce that complements it.\n2. Place water pans in the grill. Start barbecuing by getting your hands on some cheap metal pans you can fill with water. Disposable tin pans from the supermarket are great for this, and you do not have to toss them after each use. Fill these pans halfway with water and place them beneath the meat you are barbecuing. You want the pan or pans to take about half the space at the bottom of the grill.\nWhy water pans? Several reasons. First, it lets sauce and fat drip into something that will not wreck the bottom of your grill or cause flareups. Second, it helps keep the meat moist, which helps smoke adhere to the meat. Third, it moderates the temperature around the meat, which is vital in such a small space.\n3. Get the coals hot and put water-soaked wood chips on the coals. A chimney starter is the easiest way to get the coals lit for the grill. What kind of fuel should you use? Up to you, of course, but I would use either standard briquettes or lump hardwood charcoal. I am especially fond of lump charcoal because I get a better flavor and a cleaner smoke. Could you go all wood? Sure, but it needs to be something like oak or hickory, which burn steadily and slowly. And no logs! You must use chunks.\nYour life will be easier if you have a grill top that has hinged edges that lift up. These allow you to position one end over the coals and add more charcoal or wood as needed as you cook. If you do not have one of these grill tops, make sure you can slip briquettes through the slim opening. If you cannot, you can carefully lift the whole grate and add more when needed.\nOnce the coals are good and hot, add a couple handfuls of the soaked wood on the coals. Place the top grill grate on the grill. Position the grill grate in a way that if you are using a hinged grill grate, one of the hinged areas lifts up over the coals so you can easily get to them.\n4. Put the meat on the grill away from the coals. Lay the meat over the water pans as far away from the coals as possible. Under no circumstances should you let the meat rest directly over the coals. Cook in batches if you have to, and keep the finished meat in an oven set to \xe2\x80\x9cwarm\xe2\x80\x9d while you do more.\nCover the grill, positioning the vent on the cover directly over the meat. This helps direct the smoke over the meat. Close all vents (bottom one, too!) to keep the temperature as low as you can go; if you have an especially tight lid, keep the vents open just a little. You are now barbecuing.\n5. Watch the temperature. This would be a good time to open a beer or drink some lemonade and sit back. Keep one eye on the grill to make sure you see some smoke coming out of it. Wander over from time to time to check the temperature if your grill lid has a thermometer. It should read no higher than 325 degrees, preferably somewhere under 300. Ideally you want the temperature at the meat level around 225-250; heat rises and a lid thermometer will show the temperature at the lid, and not at the meat level. If your kettle grill does not have a thermometer built-in (most don't), put a meat thermometer into the cover vent and check it from time to time.\nIf your temperature starts to soar, open the lid and let the coals burn off a bit. Then add some more soaked wood and close the lid again; you should be OK.\nIf your temperature begins to drop below 225 degrees, open the vents. If that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t get the temperature rising, open the lid and add more coals and soaked wood.\n6. Check the coals and rotate the meat. Regardless of temperature, check your coals every hour to 90 minutes. You may need to add more. Always add more soaked wood at this point, and always turn or rotate your meat at this point, too.\n7. Timing. How long should you cook things? Depends. Fish will take from 45 to 90 minutes. Chicken an hour to two hours. Baby back ribs, such as these, will take from 90 minutes to 2 hours and 15 minutes. A Boston butt, beef brisket or tri-tip can take as long as 6 hours.\nIf you are using a barbecue sauce \xe2\x80\x93 and with everything other than a Memphis-style dry rib you probably will be \xe2\x80\x93 wait to brush it on until the final 30-45 minutes of cooking. You do not want it to burn, and because most barbecue sauces have a lot of sugar in them, they will burn easily. When barbecuing fish, do not sauce until the last 15 minutes.\nYou will be able to spot doneness with some visual cues. Meat on bones will begin to pull away. When you turn or rotate meat it will begin to fall off the bone. The flakes on fish will separate easily. The interior of a Boston butt will be somewhere around 160 degrees \xe2\x80\x93 this is the only meat I barbecue with a meat thermometer.\nWhat happens if your heat was just too high and things are looking charred? Well, hopefully you did not let it go this far because you\xe2\x80\x99d been checking every hour to 90 minutes. But if it looks like you have too much char and the meat is not yet done, have no fear: Finish the meat in a 225-degree oven. You will still have enough smoky taste to impress your guests.\nOnce your meat is done, remove it to a platter, add more sauce and let it rest for 10-15 minutes. Let a big tri-tip or Boston butt rest for 20-25 minutes. Add even more sauce right at service and enjoy! You\xe2\x80\x99ll know you cooked real barbecue if everyone has sauce under their fingernails\xe2\x80\xa6\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nKansas City Barbecue Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Makes about 2 1/2 cups\nThis makes enough sauce for 10-20 chicken legs or thighs, 4 racks of ribs or a regular pork shoulder.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups tomato sauce or ketchup\n1/2 cup apple juice\n1/2 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n5 Tbsp butter\n3 Tbsp paprika\n2 Tbsp chili powder\n1 Tbsp chipotle powder (optional)\n4 finely chopped garlic cloves\n1/2 medium onion, finely chopped\nSalt to taste\nCayenne to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the butter in a pot over medium heat for 2-3 minutes. Add the onion and saut\xc3\xa9 until it begins to brown. Add the garlic and saut\xc3\xa9 for another 2 minutes.\n2 Pour in the remaining ingredients and stir well to combine. Simmer slowly for at least 30 minutes, and up to 2 hours.\nAdjust the heat and salt levels with the cayenne and salt right before you plan to use this sauce, which is great on ribs, chicken and pork shoulder.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGrilled Chicken with South Carolina-Style BBQ Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nTo save some prep time, the BBQ sauce can be made ahead and kept refrigerated for up to two weeks.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the BBQ sauce:\n1 cup prepared yellow mustard\n1/4 cup packed dark brown sugar\n2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar\n1 tablespoon ketchup\n1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce\n1/2 teaspoon garlic powder\n1/2 teaspoon bottled hot sauce, plus more to taste\nFor the chicken:\n4 chicken thighs, bone-in with skin\n4 drumsticks, bone-in with skin\n1 tablespoon sea salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make barbecue sauce at least 30 minutes ahead of grilling: Combine all the ingredients for the sauce in a 2-quart saucepan and set over medium-high heat on a back burner. Cook, stirring constantly for 2 minutes or until mixture is very steamy. (The sauce can bubble and spit, so use caution. To avoid burns, stir the sauce constantly to distribute heat.)\nTurn the heat to medium-low, and cook until sauce has thickened, 5 to 7 minutes more. When done, the sauce should be thick enough that a spoon will leave trails through the sauce when you stir. Set aside to cool.\nOnce cool, measure 3/4 cup into a small bowl for the chicken. Set aside remaining sauce for serving. (Prepared sauce can also be made ahead and kept refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.)\n2 Twenty minutes before cooking, rub the chicken pieces on both sides with sea salt. Set in fridge while you prep grill.\n3 Prepare a charcoal grill. When coals are gray and very hot, carefully move them to one side of the grill so that one side has hot, direct heat and the other side has indirect heat. (Alternatively, prepare a gas grill with two temperature zones for cooking.)\n4 Brush chicken generously on both sides with 3/4 cups of prepare barbecue sauce.\n5 Grill the chicken over high heat to sear: Place the chicken on the hot side of grill directly over coals, placing thighs skin-side down. After 2 to 3 minutes, flip chicken and grill another 2 to 3 minutes, or until chicken is nicely browned or even slightly blackened on both sides.\n6 Finish cooking the chicken over indirect heat: Move the chicken over to side without coals to finish cooking over indirect heat. Brush once more with barbecue sauce. Cover the grill.\nAfter 5 to 7 minutes, flip chicken. Cook another 12 to 15 minutes until chicken is a rich golden brown, cooked through, and reaches an internal temperature of at least 175\xc2\xb0F when tested with a meat thermometer.\n(I usually cook these thighs and drumsticks to a slightly higher internal temperature to be sure the meat is thoroughly cooked; the sauce and indirect heat keep the chicken from drying out.)\n7 Serve immediately with extra barbecue sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBourbon Barbecue Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes enough for 4-6 racks of ribs\nNote that most (not all) of the alcohol from the bourbon will boil away while the sauce reduces, leaving bourbon's distinctive caramel-flavored tang.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup vegetable oil, such as canola or peanut\n1/4 cup butter\n1 chopped chile pepper, such as a serrano\n1 medium yellow or white onion, grated\n1 cup bourbon or Tennessee whiskey\n1/2 cup ketchup or tomato sauce\n1/2 cup lemon juice\n1/2 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/3 cup dark molasses\n1/3 cup Worcestershire sauce\n2-3 tablespoons brown sugar\nSalt to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the butter and oil in a sauce pan over medium-high heat.\n2 Grate the onion through the coarse grate of a box grater, or finely mince the onion if you don't have a grater.\n3 Add grated onion and chile to the oil/butter combination and cook over medium heat for 3-4 minutes, or until onions turn translucent. You do not want the onions to turn color.\n4 Add the bourbon: Take the pan off the heat and add the bourbon. Return to the stove, turn up the heat to medium-high again and boil down the bourbon for 5 minutes.\n5 Add the ketchup, lemon juice, vinegar, Worcestershire sauce, molasses, and the sugar. Mix well and return to a simmer.\n6 Cook the sauce for a few minutes to combine the flavors and then taste test it. Is it salty enough? (It should be from the Worcestershire sauce). If not, add salt. Is it spicy hot enough? If not, add a little cayenne powder. Is it sweet enough? If not, add some molasses.\n7 Let the sauce cook down slowly until it thickens, about 20 minutes. Keep it on low heat while your ribs cook. Alternatively, you can make this sauce ahead of time and reheat it when you cook the meat. It will stay good in the fridge at least a week; I've held mine for two weeks with no problem.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nSmoky Barbecue Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Makes 2 cups\nWhen handling the hot chiles in adobo, use gloves, or a plastic bag to protect your hands. After handling chiles wash your hands thoroughly in hot soapy water. Do not touch your eyes for several hours.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 Tbsp butter (can substitute vegetable oil)\n1/2 grated onion\n1 15-ounce can crushed tomatoes\n1/2 cup cider vinegar\n2 Tbsp brown sugar\n1/4 cup molasses\n1-4 chipotle chiles in adobo (depending on how hot you want your bbq sauce)\n1 teaspoon liquid smoke\n1 Tbsp finely chopped fresh sage\nSalt to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the grated onion in butter: Heat the butter in a heavy pot over medium-high heat until it froths (or heat vegetable oil until hot), then add the grated onion. Sprinkle a little salt over the onion. Saut\xc3\xa9 until the onion just begins to color, about 4-5 minutes.\n2 Mince the chipotle chile: While the onions are cooking, finely chop the chipotle chiles in adobo. They are hot, so start with one chile. You can add as many more as you want later.\n3 Add chipotle and remaining ingredients to the onions: Add the chipotle to with the onions, then add the tomatoes, vinegar, molasses, sugar, liquid smoke, and chopped sage. Stir to combine and let this simmer for 5 minutes. Taste it and add salt and more chipotle if you want.\n4 Simmer 1 hour: Simmer the sauce gently, uncovered, for 1 hour. Before serving, taste one more time for salt and chile.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBourbon BBQ Meatloaf Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 medium red or yellow onion, roughly chopped\n1 medium carrot, roughly chopped\n1 stalk celery, roughly chopped\n1/4 red bell pepper, roughly chopped\n3 cloves garlic\n2 pounds ground beef (90/10 blend)\n1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce\n2 large eggs\n1 cup breadcrumbs\n1/4 cup fresh parsley, minced\n2 teaspoons salt\nFor the Bourbon BBQ Glaze:\n1 cup BBQ sauce, homemade or store-bought (I like Stubb\xe2\x80\x99s)\n1/4 cup bourbon\n1 tablespoon brown sugar\n1 tablespoon honey\nSpecial equipment:\n9x5 loaf pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Cook the vegetables: Add chopped onion, carrot, celery, red pepper, and garlic to a food processor and pulse until minced. Transfer the veggies to a large skillet with olive oil.\nCook over medium heat for 5 to 6 minutes until veggies are soft and most of the liquid has cooked out of them.\nLet veggies cool briefly before combining with meatloaf ingredients. The cooler the mixture, the easier it will be to handle; plus, if it's too hot, you might accidentally end up with scrambled eggs when you add the eggs in!\n3 Mix and shape the meatloaf: Add the cooked vegetables to a large bowl with all the other meatloaf ingredients and mix well with your hands. Then press the mixture in a 9x5 loaf pan.\n4 Bake the meatloaf: Bake the meatloaf at 350\xc2\xb0F for 60 minutes, or until the internal temperature of the meatloaf reaches 160\xc2\xb0F.\n5 Make the glaze while the meatloaf bakes: Add glaze ingredients to a small saucepan and bring to a simmer over low heat. Simmer for 4 to 5 minutes until mixture forms big bubbles and is thick enough to coat the back of a spatula or spoon. It will continue to thicken as it cools.\n6 Glaze the meatloaf: When the meatloaf has about five minutes left of baking, add 1/4 cup of glaze to the top of the meatloaf and let it finish cooking.\n7 Serve: Let the loaf cool in the pan for 5 minutes, then unmold and serve (or serve from the pan). Serve the rest of the glaze on the side for people to drizzle onto their slices.\nLeftovers can be kept in the fridge for a few days. If you want to freeze this meatloaf, I recommend slicing it and freezing individually wrapped slices, rather than freezing the entire loaf, which will be difficult to defrost later. Reheat slices in a medium-heat skillet with a drizzle of oil until warmed through, 4 to 5 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nInstant Pot BBQ Baby Back Ribs Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 5 minutesRest in fridge time: Overnight, if possibleYield: 2 full racks of ribs (serves 6)\nThese ribs do best when the dry rub is applied up to a day in advance so the seasoning really penetrates the ribs.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 full racks baby back ribs (3-4 pounds)\nabout 1/3 cup dry rub for pork, store-bought or homemade\n3/4 cup water\n3/4 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon liquid smoke (optional)\n2 cups barbecue sauce, favorite store-bought or homemade\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the ribs: Working with one rack at a time, use a paring knife to separate the thin transparent membrane on the inside of the ribs. Peel it away from the ribs. It should come off in one big piece. This will make it easier to slice and serve the ribs.\n2 Apply the rub: Rub the ribs well on all sides with dry rub. If possible, cover and let rest in the fridge overnight.\n3 Cook the ribs: In the bottom of your Instant Pot, add some foil balls or a rack to raise the ribs above the liquid. Pour water, vinegar, and liquid smoke (optional) into the Instant Pot. Add ribs, bending them to fit. You should be able to fit two racks of baby back ribs in a 6-quart Instant Pot or pressure cooker.\nLock the pressure cooker and cook on high pressure for 30 minutes. Release the pressure naturally for 10 minutes, then vent off remaining pressure.\n4 Broil the ribs: Remove ribs from the Instant Pot and spread them out on a baking sheet. Brush liberally with barbecue sauce and broil on high heat for 5 minutes. Slice ribs and serve with sides and extra sauce.\nTo reheat leftover ribs, wrap them tightly in foil and heat them in a 350\xcb\x9aF oven until heated through, about 15 minutes. You can also grill them for 10-15 minutes over medium heat. Serve with extra sauce!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nGrilled BBQ Chicken Sandwiches Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 8 sandwiches\nINGREDIENTS\nPickle Slaw:\n1/2 cup mayonnaise\n1/4 cup dill pickle juice\n1 tablespoon sugar\n1/2 green cabbage, thin shredded (about 4 cups)\n2 medium carrots, grated (about 1 cup)\n1/4 cup chopped dill pickles\nChicken Filling:\n2 pounds boneless skinless chicken breasts, butterflied\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n1 \xe2\x80\x93 1 1/2 cups Hank\xe2\x80\x99s Kansas City BBQ Sauce or store-bought\n8 hamburger buns\nDAD ADD! Serrano Mayo:\n2-3 grilled serrano peppers, seeds removed\n1 cup mayonnaise\nJuice from 1/2 lime\nPinch of salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the slaw: Whisk together mayo, pickle juice, and sugar. Stir in shredded cabbage, carrots, and pickles. Stir together and taste. Season to your liking. Slaw can be made a day or two in advance with no problem.\n\n2 Heat the grill and prepare the chicken: Preheat grill to medium-high heat. To butterfly the chicken, use a sharp knife to slice the chicken horizontally \xe2\x80\x93 leaving the edge connected so you can open the chicken breast \xe2\x80\x93 making it thinner and therefore faster-cooking. Then drizzle with olive oil, salt, and pepper.\nPour 1/2 cup of BBQ sauce into a bowl and set it aside. You will add it to the cooked chicken later.\n3 Grill the chicken and chiles (if using): Add chicken to grill and spoon BBQ sauce over each piece of chicken. You will use 1/3 to 1/2 cup of BBQ sauce for this part of cooking.\nGrill for 5 to 6 minutes on the first side. Flip and add BBQ sauce to the second side. Grill for another 5 to 6 minutes on the second side or until the chicken breasts reach 165\xcb\x9aF. Remove from the grill.\nAs the chicken grills, add 2 to 3 serrano peppers to the grill. Grill them for 2 to 3 minutes per side. Remove and let cool.\nNOTE: If you do not butterfly your chicken breasts, you will need to grill them for 8 to 10 minutes longer than this.\n4 Shred the chicken: When chicken comes off the grill, let it cool briefly and then use two forks to shred or roughly chop the chicken. Stir the 1/2 cup of BBQ sauce you set aside in step 1 into the shredded chicken.\n5 Making the serrano mayo: Split grilled peppers in half and remove seeds. Add to a small food processor with mayo, lime juice, and salt. Pulse until combined.\n6 Make your sandwich: Toast your sandwich buns (if you want to) and smear with serrano mayo if you\xe2\x80\x99re using it. Top with a heap of pickle slaw and shredded BBQ chicken. Serve with chips and pickles on the side.\nLeftover chicken will keep in the fridge for 3 to 4 days or freeze in an airtight container for up to three months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBBQ Chicken Sheet Pan Pizza Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nIf your dough is store-bought or has been refrigerated for a long time, set out on the counter for at least 30 minutes to bring it to room temperature to make it easier to work with.\nIf you don't have leftover chicken or a rotisserie chicken to make this recipe, quickly poach a few chicken breasts following this method.\nOptional topping: It's not a favorite of mine, but some people like pineapple on a pizza like this.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound pizza dough, store-bought or homemade, room temperature (See Recipe Note)\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n2 cups cooked shredded chicken\n1 cup BBQ sauce, such as Hunt's Hickory BBQ Sauce\n6 ounces (about 1 1/2 cups) shredded mozzarella cheese, divided\n1/2 red onion, thinly sliced\n1 jalape\xc3\xb1o, thinly sliced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xbaF. Place a rack in the lowest position.\n2 Stretch the dough onto the baking sheet: Place the dough in the center of the baking sheet and drizzle with the oil. Turn the dough to coat it well, spreading some of the oil over the baking sheet.\nGradually stretch the dough until it reaches the edges of the baking sheet, being careful not to rip any holes in the dough. If it springs back or is difficult to stretch, this usually means that the dough is too cold. To remedy the situation, cover with plastic wrap and let rest for 10 minutes before continuing.\n3 Top the pizza: Mix together the shredded chicken and barbecue sauce in a bowl, then spread evenly over the pizza dough, leaving a little bit of a border around the pizza.\nSprinkle evenly with two-thirds of the cheese, scatter the red onion and then the jalape\xc3\xb1o, and then sprinkle with the remaining cheese. (I like to have cheese both under and over the toppings, but you can assemble it however you choose.)\n4 Bake the pizza: Set the pan on lowest shelf of the oven and bake until the cheese melts and the pizza is golden brown, about 15 minutes. Cut into squares and serve hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nKansas City Barbecue Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Makes about 2 1/2 cups\nThis makes enough sauce for 10-20 chicken legs or thighs, 4 racks of ribs or a regular pork shoulder.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups tomato sauce or ketchup\n1/2 cup apple juice\n1/2 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n5 Tbsp butter\n3 Tbsp paprika\n2 Tbsp chili powder\n1 Tbsp chipotle powder (optional)\n4 finely chopped garlic cloves\n1/2 medium onion, finely chopped\nSalt to taste\nCayenne to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the butter in a pot over medium heat for 2-3 minutes. Add the onion and saut\xc3\xa9 until it begins to brown. Add the garlic and saut\xc3\xa9 for another 2 minutes.\n2 Pour in the remaining ingredients and stir well to combine. Simmer slowly for at least 30 minutes, and up to 2 hours.\nAdjust the heat and salt levels with the cayenne and salt right before you plan to use this sauce, which is great on ribs, chicken and pork shoulder.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nGrilled Chicken with South Carolina-Style BBQ Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nTo save some prep time, the BBQ sauce can be made ahead and kept refrigerated for up to two weeks.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the BBQ sauce:\n1 cup prepared yellow mustard\n1/4 cup packed dark brown sugar\n2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar\n1 tablespoon ketchup\n1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce\n1/2 teaspoon garlic powder\n1/2 teaspoon bottled hot sauce, plus more to taste\nFor the chicken:\n4 chicken thighs, bone-in with skin\n4 drumsticks, bone-in with skin\n1 tablespoon sea salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make barbecue sauce at least 30 minutes ahead of grilling: Combine all the ingredients for the sauce in a 2-quart saucepan and set over medium-high heat on a back burner. Cook, stirring constantly for 2 minutes or until mixture is very steamy. (The sauce can bubble and spit, so use caution. To avoid burns, stir the sauce constantly to distribute heat.)\nTurn the heat to medium-low, and cook until sauce has thickened, 5 to 7 minutes more. When done, the sauce should be thick enough that a spoon will leave trails through the sauce when you stir. Set aside to cool.\nOnce cool, measure 3/4 cup into a small bowl for the chicken. Set aside remaining sauce for serving. (Prepared sauce can also be made ahead and kept refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.)\n2 Twenty minutes before cooking, rub the chicken pieces on both sides with sea salt. Set in fridge while you prep grill.\n3 Prepare a charcoal grill. When coals are gray and very hot, carefully move them to one side of the grill so that one side has hot, direct heat and the other side has indirect heat. (Alternatively, prepare a gas grill with two temperature zones for cooking.)\n4 Brush chicken generously on both sides with 3/4 cups of prepare barbecue sauce.\n5 Grill the chicken over high heat to sear: Place the chicken on the hot side of grill directly over coals, placing thighs skin-side down. After 2 to 3 minutes, flip chicken and grill another 2 to 3 minutes, or until chicken is nicely browned or even slightly blackened on both sides.\n6 Finish cooking the chicken over indirect heat: Move the chicken over to side without coals to finish cooking over indirect heat. Brush once more with barbecue sauce. Cover the grill.\nAfter 5 to 7 minutes, flip chicken. Cook another 12 to 15 minutes until chicken is a rich golden brown, cooked through, and reaches an internal temperature of at least 175\xc2\xb0F when tested with a meat thermometer.\n(I usually cook these thighs and drumsticks to a slightly higher internal temperature to be sure the meat is thoroughly cooked; the sauce and indirect heat keep the chicken from drying out.)\n7 Serve immediately with extra barbecue sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nDr Pepper Barbecue Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 35 minutesYield: Makes 2-3 cups\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup minced onion\n1/4 cup vegetable oil\n1 1/2 cups Dr Pepper\n1 can of crushed tomatoes, about 15 ounces\n1/2 cup orange juice\n1/4 cup cider vinegar\n1/2 cup honey\n1/2 to 1 teaspoon cayenne\nSalt to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the vegetable oil in a pot over medium-high heat. Add the onions and saut\xc3\xa9 for 4-5 minutes, stirring often.\n2 When the onions are just beginning to brown, add the remaining ingredients and stir well to combine. Simmer for 30 minutes.\n3 Pour the sauce into a blender or food processor and pur\xc3\xa9e it until it is smooth. (Note that if you are using a blender, either work in batches, filling the blender no more than a third of the way at a time with the hot sauce, or slowly add the sauce while the blender is running on low speed.)\n4 Put the sauce into a saucepan, bring to a simmer and continue to simmer, uncovered, for 1-2 hours.\nThe sauce will store for several weeks in the fridge.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBourbon Barbecue Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes enough for 4-6 racks of ribs\nNote that most (not all) of the alcohol from the bourbon will boil away while the sauce reduces, leaving bourbon's distinctive caramel-flavored tang.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup vegetable oil, such as canola or peanut\n1/4 cup butter\n1 chopped chile pepper, such as a serrano\n1 medium yellow or white onion, grated\n1 cup bourbon or Tennessee whiskey\n1/2 cup ketchup or tomato sauce\n1/2 cup lemon juice\n1/2 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/3 cup dark molasses\n1/3 cup Worcestershire sauce\n2-3 tablespoons brown sugar\nSalt to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the butter and oil in a sauce pan over medium-high heat.\n2 Grate the onion through the coarse grate of a box grater, or finely mince the onion if you don't have a grater.\n3 Add grated onion and chile to the oil/butter combination and cook over medium heat for 3-4 minutes, or until onions turn translucent. You do not want the onions to turn color.\n4 Add the bourbon: Take the pan off the heat and add the bourbon. Return to the stove, turn up the heat to medium-high again and boil down the bourbon for 5 minutes.\n5 Add the ketchup, lemon juice, vinegar, Worcestershire sauce, molasses, and the sugar. Mix well and return to a simmer.\n6 Cook the sauce for a few minutes to combine the flavors and then taste test it. Is it salty enough? (It should be from the Worcestershire sauce). If not, add salt. Is it spicy hot enough? If not, add a little cayenne powder. Is it sweet enough? If not, add some molasses.\n7 Let the sauce cook down slowly until it thickens, about 20 minutes. Keep it on low heat while your ribs cook. Alternatively, you can make this sauce ahead of time and reheat it when you cook the meat. It will stay good in the fridge at least a week; I've held mine for two weeks with no problem.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nSouth Carolina Mustard BBQ Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: About 2 cups\nUse this sauce toward the end of barbecuing meat because the sugar will caramelize fast, then burn. So leave it until the last 45 minutes or so, and paint it on in coats, letting each coat cook into the meat a bit before adding the next one.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 Tbsp. butter\n1/2 onion, grated\n1/2 cup yellow mustard (the kind you get at the ballpark)\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n1/2 cup cider vinegar\n1 Tbsp dry mustard (like Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s)\n1 teaspoon cayenne\n1 bay leaf\nSalt to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the butter over medium heat until it's frothy, then add the onion and saut\xc3\xa9 for 3-4 minutes. Do not let the onions brown.\n2 Add everything else, stir well and simmer slowly for 30 minutes or more.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nSmoky Barbecue Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Makes 2 cups\nWhen handling the hot chiles in adobo, use gloves, or a plastic bag to protect your hands. After handling chiles wash your hands thoroughly in hot soapy water. Do not touch your eyes for several hours.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 Tbsp butter (can substitute vegetable oil)\n1/2 grated onion\n1 15-ounce can crushed tomatoes\n1/2 cup cider vinegar\n2 Tbsp brown sugar\n1/4 cup molasses\n1-4 chipotle chiles in adobo (depending on how hot you want your bbq sauce)\n1 teaspoon liquid smoke\n1 Tbsp finely chopped fresh sage\nSalt to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the grated onion in butter: Heat the butter in a heavy pot over medium-high heat until it froths (or heat vegetable oil until hot), then add the grated onion. Sprinkle a little salt over the onion. Saut\xc3\xa9 until the onion just begins to color, about 4-5 minutes.\n2 Mince the chipotle chile: While the onions are cooking, finely chop the chipotle chiles in adobo. They are hot, so start with one chile. You can add as many more as you want later.\n3 Add chipotle and remaining ingredients to the onions: Add the chipotle to with the onions, then add the tomatoes, vinegar, molasses, sugar, liquid smoke, and chopped sage. Stir to combine and let this simmer for 5 minutes. Taste it and add salt and more chipotle if you want.\n4 Simmer 1 hour: Simmer the sauce gently, uncovered, for 1 hour. Before serving, taste one more time for salt and chile.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBBQ Meatloaf Bites Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 18 meatloaf bites\nThese meatloaf bites freeze well. Bake them as directed and allow them to cool completely. Then place them on a baking sheet and freeze until frozen solid. Wrap each bite tightly in foil and store in a freezer safe bag for up to three months. Reheat frozen bites either in a muffin tin in the oven for 15 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F. or until warmed through or in the microwave for about 2 minutes on high (not in a muffin tin).\nIf you want to make mini meatloaf bites, divide the mixture into mini muffin tins. You will get about double the amount (my kids liked the smaller ones). It\xe2\x80\x99s pretty impossible to line a mini muffin tin with foil, though, so cleanup will be more intense unless you\'re using nonstick muffin tins. Also, total baking time will be shorter, about 20 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the meatloaf bites:\n2 pounds lean ground beef (no more than 10% fat)\n1 large egg\n3/4 cup breadcrumbs\n1 small white onion, 1/2 cup diced\n1 stalk celery, 1/3 cup diced\n1 medium carrot, 1/3 cup diced\n1/2 green pepper, 1/3 cup diced\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n1 teaspoon chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce\nFor the BBQ Glaze:\n1 cup barbecue sauce (I like Stubbs)\n1/4 cup brown sugar\n1 tablespoon hot sauce (optional)\nDAD ADD: "Meatball" Sub (makes 1 sub)\n1 soft French roll\n2 to 3 cooked meatloaf bites\n2 tablespoons marinara sauce, store-bought or homemade\n2 ounces provolone cheese\nBanana peppers\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the meatloaf mixture: In a large bowl, combine ground beef, egg, breadcrumbs, onion, carrot, celery, green pepper, garlic, chili powder, salt, pepper, and Worcestershire sauce. Mix well\xe2\x80\x94I think using your hands works best.\n3 Fill the muffin tin with meatloaf: Line a muffin tin with foil for easier cleanup, and then divide the meatloaf mixture between the muffin tins. I like to use about 1/4 cup of meatloaf mixture for each muffin tin, which ends up being about 3/4 full on each muffin tin. You should get about 18 meatloaf bites out of the recipe.\n4 Bake the bites: Place the meatloaf-packed muffin tins in the oven and bake for about 20 minutes.\n5 Make the glaze: Stir together the barbecue sauce, brown sugar and, if using, hot sauce in a small bowl. After the bites have baked for 20 minutes, remove and brush the glaze right on the meatloaf tops.\n6 Finish baking: Return to the oven and bake for another 10 minutes until meatloaf bites are cooked through. If you have a meat thermometer handy, the meatloaf bites should reach an internal temperature of 160\xc2\xb0F.\n7 Serve! Remove meatloaf bites once they have cooled slightly and serve with steamed veggies and potatoes. The meatloaf bites should hold together easily and not crumble.\n8 Make the Dad Add Sub with the leftovers: Heat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Cut open a soft French sub roll and slather on a few tablespoons of marinara sauce. Top with provolone cheese, a few meatloaf bites cut in half, and a few banana peppers.\nBake the sub for 6 to 7 minutes until it\xe2\x80\x99s the edges are crispy and the cheese is melted and bubbling. Serve while warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nAztec Chocolate Bark Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesFreezer time: 5 minutesYield: 6-8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup of hulled, unsalted pumpkin seeds\n1/4 teaspoon of cayenne pepper, plus a dash extra\n3/4 teaspoon of cinnamon, plus a dash extra\n3/4 teaspoon of ancho chili powder, plus a dash extra\n12 oz. of bitter or semi-sweet chocolate\nMETHOD\n1 Toast the pumpkin seeds: Place the pumpkin seeds in a skillet over medium-low heat. Toast the pumpkin seeds for about 5 minutes, they'll pop and jump a bit as they release their oils and moisture. Allow to cool.\n2 Melt chocolate, stir in spices, pumpkin seeds: Melt the chocolate according to the manufacturer's directions. Once melted add the cinnamon, cayenne pepper, ancho chili powder, and most of the pumpkin seeds saving some to decorate the top with.\n3 Spread on lined baking sheet and chill: Spread onto a flat baking pan lined with a Silpat or parchment paper.\nSprinkle over and press into the chocolate the last few pumpkin seeds and sprinkle on a dash more of the spices for color and taste.\nPlace in the freezer for 5 minutes or until hardened. Break into pieces and serve or store in the fridge in an airtight container. Best consumed in one or two days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nBeef and Barley Stew with Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nIf you can't find celery root, you can substitute turnips, rutabagas or potatoes. Just be sure to adjust your cooking times\xe2\x80\x94potatoes cook faster than celery root. Save time in the prep work by prepping the onions and mushrooms while the beef is browning.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp unsalted butter\n2-3 pounds beef chuck, cut into chunks\nSalt\n3 cups chopped onions\n1 pound button or cremini mushrooms, quartered if small or 1/4-inch sliced\n1 quart beef or chicken broth\n3 cups water\n2 teaspoons dried marjoram\n1 cup pearl barley\n1 cup roughly chopped carrot\n3 cups celery root, peeled and chopped into 3/4-inch to 1-inch chunks\nBlack pepper\nAbout 1/2 cup sour cream (around 1 Tbsp sour cream per serving)\nDill for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sear the beef: In a large, thick-bottomed pot, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add enough pieces of the beef to sear in the pot without crowding.\nYou will need to brown the meat in several batches. Salt the beef as it cooks, and set aside browned pieces in a bowl.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: When all the beef has browned, add the onions. As the onions release some of their water, use a wooden spoon to scrape any browned bits off the bottom of the pot.\nSprinkle a little salt over the onions as they cook. Lower the heat to medium and cook the onions until they begin to brown, 5-6 minutes.\n3 Add the mushrooms: When the onions have lightly browned, mix in the mushrooms and increase the heat to high. Cook the mushrooms until they release their water, about 2-3 minutes.\n3 Add back beef, add marjoram, stock, water, then simmer: Add the beef back to the pot and sprinkle with marjoram.\nAdd 1 cup of the stock and use the wooden spoon to scrape any browned bits off the bottom of the pot. Add the rest of the stock and water and bring to a simmer.\nCover the pot, lower the heat to low and simmer very gently for 1 hour.\n4 Add barley, celery root, carrots, continue to simmer: Add the barley, celery root and carrots, stir well and recover the pot. Simmer gently until the barley and celery root are tender, between 40 minutes and an hour.\n5 Serve with sour cream and dill: Ladle servings into bowls, then top with a dollop of sour cream and a few sprigs of dill. Grind a little black pepper over right before you serve. To eat, stir in the sour cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nVegan Mushroom Barley Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: 6 to 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 ounce dried porcini or other dried mushrooms\n2 cups hot tap water\n1 1/2 pounds fresh mushrooms (button, shiitake, large or baby portobello, or a mix)\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1 clove garlic, minced\n1 large onion, diced\n2 stalks celery, diced\n2 carrots, diced\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n3/4 cup pearl barley\n1 medium Yukon Gold potato, cut into 1/2-inch chunks\n8 cups water, plus more if needed\n2 tablespoons soy sauce, plus more to taste\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar, plus more to taste\n1 bay leaf\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\n1/4 cup chopped fresh dill\n3 ounces baby spinach (2 cups packed), tough stems removed\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak the dried mushrooms: In a bowl, combine the porcini or other dried mushrooms and the 2 cups hot water. Set aside for 30 minutes to soak.\nWith a slotted spoon, lift the mushrooms out of the bowl and transfer to a cutting board. Coarsely chop them. Strain the soaking liquid through a sieve lined with a paper towel to catch any grit and reserve.\n2 Prep the fresh mushrooms: Whip any dirt from the mushrooms with a damp paper towel. Remove the stems from all except the button mushrooms. Coarsely chop the large mushrooms and thinly slice the small mushrooms. Set aside.\n3 Cook the vegetables: In a large stock pot over medium heat, heat the oil. Add the garlic, onion, celery, carrots, salt, and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 10 minutes until the vegetables have softened.\nAdd the mushrooms, stir well, and continue cooking, stirring occasionally, for another 10 minutes. Add the potato and barley and cook, stirring, for 1 minute more.\n4 Add the liquids: Stir in the reserved mushroom soaking liquid, water, soy sauce, vinegar, bay leaf, half the parsley, and half the dill.\nBring to a boil, then lower the heat. Partially cover and simmer for 45 to 50 minutes, or until the barley and potatoes are both tender. If the mixture seems too thick at any point, add more water, 1/2 cup at a time.\n5 Finish the soup: Add the spinach and stir well. Cover the pot and let the spinach wilt for 2 minutes. Stir the soup and taste for seasoning. Add more salt, soy sauce, or balsamic vinegar, if you like. Sprinkle with the remaining parsley and dill. Ladle into bowls.\nLeftovers will keep refrigerated for up to a week, or frozen for up to 3 months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nTurkey Soup with Lemon and Barley Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6\nIf you are cooking gluten-free, use rice instead of barley.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 large onion, grated or minced\n3 garlic cloves, minced\n1 teaspoon ground turmeric\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger\nSalt\nPepper\n6 cups turkey stock or chicken stock\nStrips of lemon zest, from one lemon*\n1/2 cup to 1 cup barley (more barley will yield a thicker soup)\n2 cups chopped cooked turkey\n2 tablespoons lemon juice\n1/4 cup chopped parsley\n1/4 cup chopped cilantro (can sub with more parsley)\n*Use a vegetable peeler to peel strips of zest from a lemon. Use a sharp knife to scrape out and discard any of the white pith that still remains on the inside of the zest strips.\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onion, garlic, spices: Heat the olive oil over medium-high heat in a heavy pot or Dutch oven. Add the grated onion and cook until the onion is translucent, about 3 minutes. Stir in the minced garlic and cook another minute, then mix in the turmeric, cumin, ground ginger and a generous pinch of salt.\n2 Add stock, zest, bring to simmer then add barley: Pour in the turkey stock and add the strips of lemon zest. Bring to a simmer, then add the barley. Simmer gently until the barley is cooked, about 20-30 minutes.\n3 Add cooked turkey, lemon juice, parsley, cilantro, salt, pepper: When the barley is cooked through, add the chopped cooked turkey, lemon juice, parsley and cilantro, and salt and pepper to taste. Cook gently just until the turkey is warmed through, about 3-5 minutes. Remove the lemon zest strips before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nMoroccan Chickpea Barley Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups barley\n1 1/2 cups chicken or veggie broth (use veg broth for vegan version)\n1 1/2 cups water\n1 teaspoon salt\nExtra virgin olive oil\n1 15-ounce can of chickpeas (garbanzo beans), rinsed and strained, or 1 1/2 cups cooked\n1 cup shelled pistachio nuts\n1 cup diced dried apricots\n2-3 chopped green onions or scallions\n1 cup chopped parsley\nZest and juice of a lemon\n1 tablespoon of ras el hanout spice mix*\nSalt to taste\n*Ras El Hanout Spice Mix:\n1 teaspoon black pepper\n1 teaspoon cardamom\n1/4 teaspoon cayenne\n1/4 teaspoon ginger\n1/4 teaspoon nutmeg\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon turmeric\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the barley: Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a large pot on medium high heat. Add the barley and saut\xc3\xa9 for 3-4 minutes, stirring often.\nAdd the broth, water, and a teaspoon of salt. Bring to a simmer and simmer until the barley is tender, anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour, depending on how old the barley is.\n2 Strain the barley, toss with olive oil: Strain the cooked barley through a colander or sieve and run cold water over to cool it quickly. Toss and mix in the colander to strain as much water as you can.\nLay out the barley on a sheet pan and drizzle olive oil over it. Mix to coat well and set aside.\n3 Combine salad ingredients: In a large bowl, add the chickpeas, pistachios, apricots, green onions and parsley and mix well.\nAdd the zest and juice of the lemon and mix again.\nAdd the barley and mix.\nSprinkle the ras el hanout spice mixture over the barley and mix well. Taste, and add salt if needed.\n4 Marinate before serving: Let the salad marinate for an hour or so before serving. If the barley has absorbed all the olive oil, drizzle a little more on right before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nInstant Pot Barley Lunch Jars Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesCooling time: 10 minutesYield: 5 jars\nThe ingredients listed are suggestions for where to start, but this is meant to be a flexible recipe. See above for other add-in suggestions, and modify where you like.\nThis makes a light lunch. If you want something more filling, serve with a half sandwich or some grilled chicken for a complete meal.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup pearl barley\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n4 cups water\n2 1/2 cups salad greens\n10 to 12 cherry tomatoes, halved\n5 small sweet peppers, sliced\n2 small cucumbers, sliced\n5 radishes, sliced\nVinaigrette, for serving\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart Instant Pot or other pressure cooker\n5 pint jars, for assembly\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the barley: Add dried barley to your Instant Pot or other multi cooker/pressure cooker. Stir in salt and water. Replace lid and cook on high pressure for 15 minutes.\nOnce finished, let pressure naturally release for five minutes. Vent steam, remove lid, drain off any extra water, and let barley cool to room temperature.\n2 Assemble the jars: There\xe2\x80\x99s no single way to assemble these lunch jars. I like to add 1/2 cup of cooked barley to the bottom (make sure it is room temperature). Top that with a mix of salad greens and lots of sliced vegetables.\n3 Store the jars: The jars will keep in the fridge for 4-5 days. After that the greens start to wilt. You cannot freeze these jars. They are intended to be made and eaten within the week.\n4 Enjoy! When it\xe2\x80\x99s time for lunch, drizzle vinaigrette into the jar, season with a pinch of salt and pepper, then eat the barley salad right out of the jar. Alternatively, pour onto a plate. (Don\xe2\x80\x99t add the vinaigrette to the salad until right before serving, as it will make the vegetables soggy.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nFresh Basil Pesto Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 1 cup\nBasil pesto darkens when exposed to air, so to store, cover tightly with plastic wrap making sure the plastic is touching the top of the pesto and not allowing the pesto to have contact with air. The pesto will stay greener longer that way.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups fresh basil leaves, packed (can sub half the basil leaves with baby spinach)\n1/2 cup freshly grated Romano or Parmesan-Reggiano cheese (about 2 ounces)\n1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1/3 cup pine nuts (can sub chopped walnuts)\n3 garlic cloves, minced (about 3 teaspoons)\n1/4 teaspoon salt, more to taste\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, more to taste\nSpecial equipment:\nA food processor\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Pulse basil and pine nuts in a food processor: Place the basil leaves and pine nuts into the bowl of a food processor and pulse a several times.\n2: Add the garlic and cheese: Add the garlic and Parmesan or Romano cheese and pulse several times more. Scrape down the sides of the food processor with a rubber spatula.\n3 Stream in the olive oil: While the food processor is running, slowly add the olive oil in a steady small stream. Adding the olive oil slowly, while the processor is running, will help it emulsify and help keep the olive oil from separating. Occasionally stop to scrape down the sides of the food processor.\n4 Stir in salt and freshly ground black pepper, add more to taste.\nToss with pasta for a quick sauce, dollop over baked potatoes, or spread onto crackers or toasted slices of bread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nEasy Cucumber, Peach, and Basil Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nBlending this vinaigrette in a food processor allows all of the ingredients to disperse most evenly. While the dressing may be whisked by hand instead, the flavors will not be as pronounced.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 (12-14-inch) English cucumber, cut into 1-inch chunks\n2 fresh peaches, cut into 1-inch chunks\nFor the vinaigrette:\n2 tablespoons avocado oil or olive oil\n1 tablespoon white wine vinegar\nZest of one lime\n1 tablespoon fresh-squeezed lime juice\n1 tablespoon honey\n4 large fresh basil leaves, plus more for garnish\n1/8 teaspoon salt or to taste\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper, or to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the vegetables: Add the chopped peaches and cucumbers to a large bowl.\n2 Make the vinaigrette: In the bowl or a mini food processor or blender, combine the oil, vinegar, lime zest and juice, honey, basil, salt and pepper. Pulse until the basil is finely chopped and the vinaigrette is completely emulsified.\n3 Dress the produce: Pour the vinaigrette over the peach and cucumber mixture. Stir to coat evenly.\n4 Serve: Transfer to a serving platter, garnish with torn basil leaves and serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nHow to Store Parsley, Cilantro, and Other Fresh Herbs\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Snip off the bottom of the stems.\n2 Make sure the leaves are completely dry. Better to hold off rinsing them until you're about to use them.\n3 Fill a jar or a water glass partially with water and place the stem ends of the herbs into the water in the jar.\n4 If you are storing the herbs in the refrigerator, cover loosely with a plastic bag. Cilantro loves cool temperatures and should be stored in the refrigerator. Parsley can be stored at room temperature or in the refrigerator. According to Harold McGee, basil is ideally stored at room temperature and not in the refrigerator, because it is susceptible to damage from cold.\n5 Change the water after several days if the water starts to discolor.\nFresh parsley, cilantro, basil, and other fresh herbs can last up to 2 weeks or longer when stored this way.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nPesto Pasta Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nPrep the salad while the water is on to boil for the pasta.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups uncooked fusili pasta (use rice pasta for wheat-free version)\n1 cup fresh basil pesto\n2 tablespoons chopped green olives, or olive tapenade\n1/3 cup pine nuts\n1 cup frozen peas, defrosted (or fresh if you can get them)\n12 ounces cherry tomatoes, halved\nSeveral fresh basil leaves, coarsely chopped\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\nSalt and pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the pasta: Cook pasta according to instructions on the package. Make sure the water is salted (one and a half teaspoons per quart). Remove pasta from heat and strain when pasta is cooked, but still firm (al dente).\n2 Toast pine nuts: While the pasta is cooking, toast the pine nuts in a small pan over medium-high heat. Keep an eye on them because pine nuts can go from lovely and toasty to acrid and burnt in seconds.\nWhen most of the nuts have a blush of golden brown on them, move them to a cool bowl to rest. They will burn if you leave them in the pan.\n3 Mix pasta with pesto, pine nuts, olives, tomatoes, basil, olive oil: Put pasta in a big bowl. Mix in fresh basil pesto, green olives, and pine nuts. Gently mix in cherry tomatoes, peas, fresh basil leaves and olive oil. Salt and pepper to taste.\nServe at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBasil Vinaigrette Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: Makes a little more than one cup\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup roughly chopped basil leaves\n1 shallot, chopped,\n1 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1 teaspoon sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 cup white wine vinegar\n3/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\nMETHOD\n1 Place the basil, shallot, mustard, sugar, and salt in a blender or food processor. Pulse several times to combine. Scrape the sides of the blender down with a spatula.\n2 Add the vinegar and pulse again.\n3 Slowly add the olive oil: Turn the blender on low and take off the cap in the center of the blender\xe2\x80\x99s lid. Slowly pour in the olive oil while the blender is going.\nThe mixture may sputter a little out of the open cap, so hold your hand over it to minimize splashing.\n4 Pur\xc3\xa9e for 1-2 min: When the olive oil is incorporated, turn off the blender and scrape the sides down one more time. Cover and pur\xc3\xa9e everything for 1-2 minutes.\nStore covered in the fridge for up to a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCaprese Salad with Tomatoes, Basil, and Mozzarella Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nOne medium tomato (1/3 pound) yields enough for a salad for one person, a large tomato (3/4 to 1 pound)  yields enough for two people. So scale the recipe up or down accordingly. If you are serving 4 people, you'll need about 4 medium-sized tomatoes or 2 large tomatoes. (These proportions yield a generously portioned salad.)\nFor a completely different flavor, you can substitute the mozzarella with thin slices of Parmesan.\nFeel free to omit the balsamic vinegar if you want highlight more of the flavor of the tomatoes.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 to 2 pounds heirloom tomatoes, cored and sliced 1/4 to 1/3-inch thick (a serrated knife works best for slicing tomatoes)\nCoarse salt like kosher salt or sea salt\n1 bunch fresh basil, leaves carefully chopped or torn as not to bruise\n8 ounces, fresh mozzarella cheese, sliced\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\nDash of balsamic vinegar (optional)\nFreshly ground black pepper\nSpecial equipment:\nSerrated paring knife for slicing tomatoes\nMETHOD\n1 Salt the tomatoes: Sprinkle salt lightly over the tomato slices.\n2 Assemble the salad: Assemble the salad by arranging alternating slices of tomatoes, basil leaves, and mozzarella slices.\n3 Dress the salad: Drizzle extra virgin olive oil over the salad. Add a dash of balsamic vinegar, if using. Sprinkle lightly with pepper.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. b'Save It Print\nMozzarella Stuffed Sweet Mini Peppers Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 12 stuffed peppers\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound of sweet mini peppers (about a dozen)\n1/4 pound (115 g) smoked mozzarella cheese, cut into 1/4-inch thick and 2 inch long batons\n12 basil leaves (as many basil leaves as peppers)\n2 teaspoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar\nSalt to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Stuff mini peppers with smoked mozzarella and basil: Working one pepper at a time, place flat side down in a way that is most stable for the pepper.\nWith a small sharp knife, cut a 2 1/2 inch slit down the middle on the top of the pepper.\nIf there is a seed pod, scoop it out with a spoon.\nStuff the pepper with a basil leaf wrapped mozzarella stick.\nWhen you have stuffed all the peppers, brush them on all sides with olive oil. Drizzle balsamic vinegar in the cut openings.\n2 Cook on grill, in oven, or under broiler: Preheat grill, oven, or broiler for high direct heat (if oven, set to 400\xc2\xb0F).\nIf grilling, grill covered, cut side up on high direct heat until you have grill marks, then lower the heat to medium until the cheese is melted and the peppers have begun to soften, about 5 to 10 minutes.\nIf broiling or baking, place on a roasting pan and cook until the cheese is melted and peppers have browned and softened, about 5 to 10 minutes.\nSprinkle with salt to taste.\nLet rest for a few minutes before serving.\nHello! b'Save It Print\nVegetable Soup with Sweet Basil Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6\nNote from Wolfgang Puck: His mother only uses water, because her vegetables are peak-of-the-season, just-picked, and therefore full of flavor, but you can use stock if you like. Pistou, the puree of tomatoes, basil, garlic, and olive oil in this recipe, is a traditional French condiment that adds a burst of flavor just before serving.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 small leeks, white part only\n1 large potato, peeled\n1 small onion\n2 stalks celery\n1 medium zucchini\n12 green beans\n2 medium carrots, peeled\n6 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n3 tablespoons water\n2 quarts chicken stock (or 2 qts water, 4 bouillion cubes, a pinch of thyme, and 1/2 bay leaf OR you can use vegetable broth for a vegetarian option)*\n4 to 6 ripe tomatoes, peeled and seeded\n4 medium garlic cloves\n30 fresh basil leaves, washed and dried\nSalt\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nA few drops of Tabasco sauce\n*Use gluten-free stock or bouillon for gluten-free version.\nMETHOD\n1 Prep vegetables: Cut the leeks, potato, onion, celery, zucchini, green beans, and carrots into 1/4 inch diced cubes.\n2 Cook the vegetables: In a 6-quart stockpot, combine 3 tablespoons of the olive oil with the 3 tablespoons of water. Add the vegetables and cook over medium-low heat until all the water evaporates. Do not brown the vegetables.\n3 Add stock and simmer: Add the stock to the pot and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer and cook for 30 minutes.\n4 Make the basil pistou: Put the tomatoes, basil, garlic, and remaining 3 tablespoons of olive oil into a food processor. Pulse until pur\xc3\xa9ed.\n5 Stir the pur\xc3\xa9e into the cooked soup. Do not let the soup return to a boil. Season, to taste, with salt, pepper, and a few dashes of Tabasco. Serve the soup hot or cold.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nFarmers\xe2\x80\x99 Market Salad with Peaches, Goat Cheese, and Basil Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nIf you can, use yellow or orange tomatoes for this recipe because they are less acidic than red ones. However, if you can't find them, red ones will do just fine!\nINGREDIENTS\n1/3 cup thinly sliced red onion (about 1/2 small onion)\n2 to 3 tablespoons lemon juice (from 1/2 of a lemon)\n1/3 cup raw, shelled pistachios\n3 to 4 peaches, skins left on, cut into chunks (about 3 cups)\n1 tablespoon honey\n2 tablespoons champagne or white wine vinegar\n1/3 cup olive oil\n5 ounces mixed greens, like baby spinach, sorrel, or other seasonal farmers' market greens\n1/3 cup chopped fresh basil\n1/3 cup crumbled goat cheese\n1/2 cup chopped yellow or orange tomatoes (1 large tomato)\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak the onion: Place the lemon juice in a small bowl and add the onions, gently tossing them with your fingers to coat. Let them soak for 10 to 15 minutes, then drain and set aside. This will take some of the bite out of the onion.\n2 Toast the pistachios: In a small, dry skillet over medium heat, toast the pistachios, stirring frequently, for about 5 minutes until fragrant and lightly toasted. Remove from the heat and set aside to cool.\n3 Combine the peaches and honey: In a medium bowl, combine the peaches and honey until coated.\n4 Make the dressing and toss the salad: In a large bowl, whisk together the vinegar and olive oil. Add the mixed greens and basil, and toss them together with your clean hands.\n5 Assemble the salad. Place the greens on individual plates or a large platter. Evenly distribute the peaches, goat cheese, tomatoes, pistachios, and red onions over the greens. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nCaprese Mini Sandwiches Recipe\nYield: Makes 12 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n4 Middle Eastern flatbread (pita bread rounds without pockets)\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/4 cup (1 ounce) coarsely grated fresh Parmesan cheese\n1/4 teaspoon mixed dried Italian seasoning herbs (basil, oregano, marjoram)\n1/2 cup lightly packed fresh basil leaves, finely chopped\n1/4 cup toasted walnuts, finely chopped\n1 garlic clove, pressed or finely minced\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n2 tablespoons vinaigrette or light balsamic salad dressing\n2 cups mixed baby salad greens or spinach leaves\n2-3 balls fresh mozzarella cheese, sliced (about 8 ounces)\n2 large plum tomatoes, sliced\nMETHOD\n1 Sprinkle flatbread with Parmesan and toast in the oven: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xbaF. Place flatbread rounds on a pizza stone or baking pan; drizzle with oil, spreading evenly.\nSprinkle evenly with Parmesan cheese and seasoning mix. Bake 8-10 minutes or until edges are light golden brown and cheese is melted.\n2 Make pesto with walnuts, basil, garlic, salt: While the flatbread is toasting, create a light pesto by mixing together in a small bowl the walnuts, fresh basil, garlic and salt.\n3 Assemble the sandwiches: Remove flatbread from the oven to a cutting board. Turn the pieces over. Drizzle with dressing, spreading evenly to the edges.\nUsing a sharp chef's knife, cut each round into six wedges. Top each wedge with a small amount of the greens. Place one slice of mozzarella cheese over greens; top with pesto and one slice of tomato.\nTop with remaining pita wedges, cheese side up forming 12 mini sandwiches. Serve immediately.\nHello!
