b"Print\nHow to Make Shellfish Stock\nYield: Makes 2-3 quarts\nINGREDIENTS\n4-6 cups shellfish shells, from shrimp, lobster, and/or crab\n1/2 cup dry white wine\n1 large yellow onion, sliced or chopped\n1 carrot, roughly sliced or chopped\n1 celery stalk, roughly sliced or chopped\n2 Tbsp tomato paste\n2 sprigs of thyme\nSeveral sprigs parsley\n1 bay leaf\n10-15 whole peppercorns\n2 teaspoons salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Break up larger pieces of shell: Break thick shells (lobster or crab) into smaller pieces by putting in a sealed, thick plastic bag and either rolling with a rolling pin or hitting with a meat hammer to crush.\nCut up thinner shrimp shells with a chef's knife. Don't crush or cut too small. You can even skip this step if you want, if you are already dealing with broken up shell pieces (like cracked crab).\n2 Roast shells (optional): Place in a large roasting pan and roast at 400\xc2\xb0F for 10 minutes (this step you can skip, but it greatly enhances the flavor).\n3 Cover shells with water and heat to not quite a simmer: Put the shells in a large stock pot and add enough water to cover the shells with an inch of water. Heat the water on high. As soon as you see that little bubbles are starting to come up to the surface, reduce the heat to medium.\nDo not let the water boil! You want to maintain the temperature at just at the edge of a simmer (around 180\xc2\xb0F), where the bubbles just occasionally come up to the surface.\nDo not stir the shells! Stirring will muddy up the stock.\nSkim the foam. As the bubbles come up to the surface a film of foam will develop on the surface. Use a large metal spoon to skim away this foam. Let the shells cook like this for about an hour; skim the foam every few minutes. The foam comes from shells releasing impurities as their temperature increases.\n4 Add the wine, onions, carrots, celery, tomato paste, herbs, peppercorns: Once the stock has stopped releasing foam, add the wine, onions, carrots, celery, tomato paste, thyme, parsley, bay leaf, and peppercorns.\nBring to a low simmer and reduce heat so that the stock continues to barely simmer, but not boil, for 30 minutes. If more foam comes to the surface, skim it off. Add salt and remove from heat.\n5 Strain through a lined sieve: Use tongs, a large slotted spoon, or a spider strainer to lift out and remove most of the solids from the stock. (Later put in a plastic bag and put outside in the trash! Shellfish shells have a way of stinking up a kitchen.)\nDampen a few layers of cheesecloth and place over a large, fine mesh strainer, over a large pot or bowl.\nPour the stock into the strainer. Either use the stock right away, or cool for future use.\nIf you aren't going to use in a couple of days, freeze (remember to leave some headroom at the top of your freezer container for the liquid to expand as it freezes.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nProvencal Seafood Bisque Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nThe soup is particularly good served with crusty French or Italian loaf bread for dipping.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 slices of bacon, roughly chopped (can substitute extra virgin olive oil or butter, 3 Tbsp)\n1 medium white or yellow onion, chopped\n1 large celery stalk, chopped\n1 large carrot, chopped\n2 garlic cloves, chopped\n2 plum tomatoes, chopped\n1 pound white fish fillets, roughly chopped\n1 teaspoon of orange zest\nA pinch of cayenne\nA large pinch of saffron\n1 quart of shellfish stock, OR 16 ounces of clam juice plus 16 ounces of fish stock or water\n1/4 cup heavy cream\nSalt to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the bacon: Cook the bacon on medium heat in a 6 to 8 quart pot until it is crispy. Remove the bacon from the pot with a slotted spoon. Set aside on a paper towel to use for garnish later.\n2 Cook the onions, celery, carrot: Increase the heat to medium high and add the onions, celery and carrot. Cook for 3-4 minutes, stirring often, until the onions are translucent. Do not brown. Sprinkle some salt over everything as it cooks.\n3 Add the fish, tomatoes and the garlic and cook for another 2-3 minutes, stirring often.\n4 Add the orange zest, cayenne and saffron, then add the shellfish stock or whatever stock you are using. In a pinch you could even use chicken or vegetable stock, but the flavor of the soup will be different. Simmer this gently \xe2\x80\x93 do not let it get to a rolling boil \xe2\x80\x93 for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally.\n5 Pur\xc3\xa9e the soup: Get another pot ready. Fill a blender a third of the way with the soup and blend it on high (starting on low then increasing to high) for 1 minute, or until it is well pur\xc3\xa9ed. Work in batches to pur\xc3\xa9e the rest of the soup. Pour the pur\xc3\xa9ed soup into the clean pot.\n6 Add cream: Put the soup on medium-low heat and add the cream. Stir well and taste for salt, adding if needed. Do not let this boil! Or it might break.\nServe garnished with bacon bits or dill fronds, and alongside some crusty bread. A dry rose or light red wine would go well with this; I\xe2\x80\x99d suggest a Beaujolais or a Pinot Noir.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSmoked Salmon Bisque Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 5-6\nHot-smoked salmon has a much stronger smoky flavor than cold-smoked salmon, so I recommend using hot-smoked salmon for this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup butter (1/2 stick)\n1 cups thinly sliced leeks\n1/2 chopped yellow onion\n1 cup thinly sliced mushrooms\n1 Tbsp minced garlic\n1 quart (32 oz) clam juice\n3/4 pounds salmon fillet, chopped 1/2 inch cubes\n2 to 4 ounces hot smoked salmon (depending on how strong a smoked flavor you want, and how strongly smoked the salmon is), chopped\n2 cups canned whole or stewed tomatoes\n2 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley\n1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro\n2 Tbsp chopped fresh dill\nPinch black pepper\nPinch crushed red pepper\n1/2 teaspoon Old Bay seasoning (optional)\n3 Tbsp all-purpose flour\n1 cup cream\n1 cup milk\nSalt to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Cook onions, leeks, mushrooms garlic in butter: Melt butter in a medium stockpot over medium heat. Add onion, leeks, mushrooms, garlic and cook until onions are translucent and mushrooms have given up their moisture (7 to 10 minutes).\n2 Add the clam juice, smoked salmon, tomatoes (break up tomatoes while putting them in the soup), parsley, cilantro, dill, black pepper, red pepper flakes, and Old Bay seasoning. Cook until heated through.\n3 Make a slurry with flour, milk, cream: Put flour into a separate bowl. Slowly add the milk, beating with a wire whisk until smooth. Mix in the cream. Stir cream flour slurry into the soup.\n4  Stir in fresh salmon and simmer for 5 more minutes.\n5 Pur\xc3\xa9e (optional): If you want, use an immersion blender to pur\xc3\xa9e the soup, or pour some or all of the soup into a standing blender and pur\xc3\xa9e. Salt to taste.\nGarnish with fresh dill.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSlow Cooker Taco Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesSlow cooking time: 6 to 7 hoursYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 pound (450g) lean ground beef\n1 1/2 cups (180g) diced yellow or red onions\n2 to 3 cups (475ml to 710ml) chicken or beef broth (use more if you want a thinner soup)\n1 15-oz. (425g) can diced tomatoes\n1 15-oz. (425g) can black beans, drained and rinsed\n1 15-oz. (425g) can kidney beans, drained and rinsed\n1 4-oz. (115g) can chopped green chiles\n1 1/4 cups (135g) corn kernels, fresh or frozen\n2 1/2 teaspoons chili powder\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1 teaspoon paprika\n1 teaspoon salt\nTo serve:\nTortilla chips, lightly crushed\nSour cream\nChopped cilantro\nFinely diced red onion\nLime juice\nChopped red onions\nSpecial equipment:\n4-quart or larger slow cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the beef with the onions (can be done a day or two ahead): Heat the olive oil in a large skillet or saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat. Add beef and onions and cook 2 to 3 minutes, until the ground beef is browned but not completely cooked and the onions are starting to look soft around the edges. Use your spatula to break up the ground beef into smaller pieces as it cooks. Remove from heat and use immediately, or refrigerate for a day or two until needed.\n2 Combine and cook: Combine the browned beef, onions and the remaining soup ingredients in a slow cooker and stir. Cover and cook on low for 6 to 7 hours. It\'s fine if the soup cooks a little longer or the slow cooker switches to the "warm" setting.\n3 Serve the soup: Serve soup in bowls and top with crushed tortilla chips, sour cream, cilantro, red onion and lime juice.\nThis soup will keep refrigerated for 1 week or frozen for up to 3 months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHow To Make Fast, No-Soak Beans in the Instant Pot\nCook time: 30 minutesYield: about 5 cups cooked beans\nDon\'t skip the olive oil. This helps reduce foam during cooking, which could clog the pressure valve on the pressure cooker.\nIf cooking red kidney beans, I recommend boiling the beans for about 10 minutes first to break down the lectins.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dried beans (see below for cooking times for specific beans)\n8 cups water\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 to 2 teaspoons salt\n2 o 3 cloves peeled garlic, optional\n1 bay leaf, optional\nSpecial equipment:\n6- to 8-quart pressure cooker (I use a 6-quart Instant Pot)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine all ingredients in the pressure cooker. Do not fill the pressure cooker more than half full.\n2 Secure the lid. Make sure the pressure regulator valve is closed. (On an Instant Pot, this means it will be set to the the "sealing" position.)\n3 Cook the beans: Here are the cooking times for unsoaked beans in the Instant Pot. Cooking times will be similar for other electric pressure cookers; cooking time will be slightly less for stovetop pressure cookers. Double-check the manual that came with your pressure cooker for more exact cooking times:\nBlack beans: 20 to 25 minutes\nBlack-eyed peas : 20 to 25 minutes\nGreat Northern beans: 25 to 30 minutes\nNavy beans: 25 to 30 minutes\nPinto beans: 25 to 30 minutes\nCannellini beans: 35 to 40 minutes\nChickpeas (garbanzo beans): 35 to 40 minutes\nRed kidney beans: 25-30 minutes (boil for 10 minutes before pressure cooking)\nCook beans at high pressure for the time recommended above. The pressure cooker will take 15 to 20 minutes to come to full pressure before cooking begins.\n4 Let the pressure release: Once cooking is complete, you can let the pressure release naturally on its own, which takes about 20 to 30 minutes, or you can do a "quick release" by opening the pressure valve on the top of the pressure cooker. If doing a rapid release, be careful because the bean liquid sometimes foams into the valve.\nI recommend letting the pressure release naturally for as long as you\'re able before the beans are needed. This helps the beans retain their shape and avoids the bean liquid foaming.\nWhat to do if your beans aren\'t quite done: Put the lid back on the pressure cooker and make sure the release valve is set back to "sealing." Cook at high pressure for another 5 to 10 minutes (depending on if you think your beans need just a little more time or a little more time to finish). The pot will quickly come back up to pressure because the contents are already hot. Check your beans after the extra cooking time and continue cooking for longer if needed.\n5 Using and storing your beans: The beans can be strained and used right away, or cooled and stored in their cooking liquid. They will keep for up to a week refrigerated or up to 3 months in the freezer.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nQuinoa Bowls with Sweet Potatoes, Black Beans, and Spinach Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the sauce:\n1/4 cup sour cream\n1 teaspoon Frank\xe2\x80\x99s Red Hot Sauce or more to taste\n1 teaspoon fresh lime juice\n1 1/2 teaspoon water\nFor the quinoa:\n2 cups water\n1 cup dry quinoa\n1 teaspoon olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the pepitas:\n1/2 teaspoon olive oil\n1/4 cup pepitas\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the sweet potatoes:\n1 pound sweet potatoes, peeled, and cut into \xc2\xbd inch cubes.\n2 teaspoons olive oil\n1/4 cup water\n2 tablespoons brown sugar\n1/4 teaspoon smoked paprika\n1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the black beans:\n1 teaspoon olive oil\n1/2 medium yellow onion, diced small\n2 cloves minced garlic\n2 teaspoons dried oregano\n1 teaspoon cumin\n1 bay leaf\n1 (15-ounce) can black beans, rinsed and drained\n1/4 cup water\n1 teaspoon apple cider vinegar or lime juice\nFor the spinach:\n8 ounces baby spinach, two large handfuls per person\n3 tablespoons water\n2 teaspoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the garnish:\n2 ounces cotija cheese, crumbled\nLime wedges\nChopped fresh cilantro\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the sauce: In a small bowl, combine sour cream, Frank\xe2\x80\x99s Red Hot, lime juice, and water. Cover and place in the refrigerator.\n2 Cook the quinoa: Put the quinoa in a fine mesh strainer and rinse it under cold water for about a minute. In a medium-sized pot, combine water, quinoa, 1 teaspoon oil, and 1/2 teaspoon salt.\nCover and cook over medium heat until the water is absorbed, about 15 minutes. Remove from the heat, fluff with fork, and keep it covered.\n3 Toast the pepitas: Set a large skillet over medium heat. Add 1/2 teaspoon of olive oil. When the oil shimmers, add the pepitas and the salt. Stir frequently and toast for about 5 minutes until the seeds start popping and some parts turn a toasty brown.\nTransfer to a large plate. Scoot pepitas to one side. You\xe2\x80\x99ll put the sweet potatoes on the other side.\n4 Cook the sweet potatoes in sugar and spices: Using the same skillet you used to toast the pepitas, keep the heat at medium and add 2 teaspoons oil. Once the oil starts to shimmer, add the cubed potatoes. Stir to coat. Cook for about 1 minute. Stir again. Add the water. Cover and leave untouched for 5 minutes.\nCombine sugar, paprika, cayenne, and salt in a small bowl. Add the spice mixture to the potatoes. Stir to coat.\nCook uncovered for 7 additional minutes. Don\xe2\x80\x99t stir. The sugar should be caramelized, one side of the potatoes should be brown, and the potatoes should be tender but still hold together.\nRemove the potatoes from the skillet and place them on the plate alongside the pepitas. Tent with foil to keep them warm.\n5 Make the beans: Return the skillet to the burner over medium heat and add 1 teaspoon of olive oil. Once the oil shimmers, after about a minute, add the diced onion, garlic, oregano, cumin and bay leaf. Cook until the onions are softened, about 2 minutes.\nAdd the beans, 1/4 cup of water, and 1 teaspoon apple cider vinegar. Turn to medium-high, stirring occasionally until the liquid is reduced, about 5 minutes.\nDivide the beans evenly among four bowls. Wipe out the pan with a paper towel and set it over medium heat.\n6 Wilt the spinach: Add 3 tablespoons of water to the pan followed by all of the spinach. Drizzle with 2 teaspoons of olive oil and 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt. Toss gently until the spinach is wilted\xe2\x80\x94this should take about 2 minutes.\n7 Serve the bowls: To the bowls with the black beans, add a 1/2 cup of sweet potatoes, 1/2 cup quinoa, and the spinach. Top with toasted pepitas, crumbled cotija, a squeeze of lime, and a drizzle of creamy lime hot sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nRefried Black Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hour, 10 minutesCook time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 6\nThis recipe gives instructions for making refried beans from scratch, starting with dry beans which must first be cooked. You can also start with three 15-ounce cans of whole black beans, in which case, skip to step 5, rinse and drain the beans and add to the pan with a little water in step 6.\nINGREDIENTS\nIngredients for cooking the dry beans:\n1 pound dry black beans\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/2 large white onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n1 garlic clove, minced\n2 teaspoons salt\n1/2 cup chopped fresh cilantro (leaves and tender stems)\nAdditional ingredients for frying the beans after they've been cooked:\n1 teaspoon chipotle chili powder\n1 teaspoon chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/2 large white onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n1 garlic clove, minced\nGreen onion\nCilantro\nCrumbled cotija or queso fresco cheese (omit for vegan version)\nTortilla chips or corn tortillas\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak dry beans: Place dry black beans in a bowl and add enough water to cover the beans by two inches. Let sit overnight.\nAlternatively, if you don't have time to soak the beans overnight, place the dry beans in a large bowl and pour boiling water over the beans, covering the beans with at least an inch of water, and let sit for one hour.\nNote, if your dry beans are a little old, or if you have reason to believe that they will be tough to cook (beans stored in hot or humid climates can get tough), you can add some salt to the water (1 1/2 teaspoons of salt 2 quarts of water) which at this stage will help the beans soften when they cook later.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 cumin, onion, garlic:  Heat a tablespoon of olive oil in a large thick-bottomed pot (the pot you will use to cook the beans) on medium high heat.\nAdd the cumin. Once the cumin is sizzling, add the chopped onion. Cook for 5 minutes or so, until translucent. Add the minced garlic and cook for a minute more.\n3 Add drained beans and water, simmer 2 hours: Once the beans have soaked, they should have expanded noticeably. Drain the soaking liquid.\nAdd the drained beans and 2 quarts of water to the onions. Bring to a simmer. Partially cover the pot and lower the heat to maintain a simmer. Simmer for 2 hours.\n4 Add Salt and Cilantro, cook 30 min more: After the beans have simmered for 2 hours, add 2 teaspoons of salt (if you salted the soaking water in step 1, then taste first, and only add a teaspoon or so more of salt if you think it needs it).\nAdd 1/2 cup chopped fresh cilantro. Let cook uncovered for another half hour, or until the beans are tender.\n5 Saut\xc3\xa9 the spices, then add onions and cook: Heat 2 Tbsp of olive oil in a large frying pan on medium high heat. Add the chipotle powder, chili powder, and cumin.\nOnce the spices are sizzling, add the chopped white onion and cook until translucent.\nAdd the garlic and cook a minute more.\n6 Add beans, then mash: Add the cooked black beans (and liquid from the pot) to the frying pan. Use a potato masher to mash the beans in the pan.  Let them cook 3 to 4 minutes longer.\nIf the beans are a little soupy for your taste, just let them cook longer. If too thick or dry, add more water. Adjust seasonings to taste.\n7 Serve: Garnish with chopped green onions, fresh cilantro, and crumbled cotija or queso fresco cheese.\nServe with tortilla chips or corn or flour tortillas (corn if you are gluten-free). Great in tacos or burritos, or for a dip, or a side with steak.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nSweet Potato and Black Bean Tacos Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nBe sure to let the sweet potatoes roast for the full 30 minutes: as they cook, they will first get quite soft, then they will slowly crisp as their sides puff up and the edges brown.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the roasted sweet potatoes:\n1 to 2 medium sweet potatoes, cut into 1/2-inch cubes (about 2 cups cubed)\n2 tablespoons neutral cooking oil (such as grapeseed or canola)\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 teaspoon chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\nFor the beans:\n2 tablespoons neutral cooking oil (such as grapeseed or canola)\n1/2 medium yellow onion, diced (about 1/2 cup diced)\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more to taste\n1 clove garlic, minced\n1 jalape\xc3\xb1o, stemmed, seeded, and minced\n1 15-ounce can black beans, drained and rinsed\nApple cider vinegar or water, as needed\nTo serve:\n10 to 12 corn tortillas\n1/2 cup tomatillo salsa verde, homemade or store-bought\n1 ripe avocado, sliced thin\nFresh cilantro, roughly chopped\nLime wedges\n1/4 cup crumbled cotija cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Roast the sweet potatoes: In a medium-sized bowl, toss the sweet potatoes, 2 tablespoons oil, salt, cumin, and chili powder. Spread on a baking sheet in an even layer. Bake 15 minutes, then use a spatula to flip and stir the sweet potatoes. Roast another 15 minutes or until sweet potatoes have puffed up and have crisp, roasted edges.\n3 Make the black beans: While the sweet potatoes roast, heat 2 tablespoons oil in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Add the onions and 1/2 teaspoon salt, and saut\xc3\xa9 until soft and translucent, 5 to 7 minutes. Add the garlic and jalape\xc3\xb1o, and saut\xc3\xa9 2 minutes more. Fold in beans.\nCook, stirring occasionally, until the beans are soft and seasoned, about 10 to 15 minutes. If beans seem dry or bottom of pan starts to sizzle, add a splash of apple cider vinegar or water as needed. Taste and add salt as needed.\n4 Warm the tortillas: Briefly heat the tortillas one or two at a time in a dry skillet until warm. Transfer to a plate and cover with a towel to keep warm. Alternatively, warm a stack of 5 or fewer tortillas a time in the microwave, covered with a damp paper towel, in 30 second bursts until warmed through.\n5 Serve the tacos: Layer tacos with sweet potatoes and black beans. Serve with avocado slices, salsa, minced cilantro, and cotija cheese, letting everyone top their own tacos.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nFeijoada, Brazilian Black Bean Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 hoursYield: Serves 10 to 12\nBlack beans are a must in this recipe if you want it to be authentically Brazilian. A Portuguese version uses white beans, however.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound (450 grams) dry black beans\n4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 pound (450 grams) pork shoulder, cut into chunks\n2 large onions, sliced\n1 head of garlic, peeled and chopped\n1 pound (450 grams) carne seca or corned beef, cut into chunks\n1/2 pound (225 grams) fresh sausages, such as chorizo or Italian sausage\n1 pound (450 grams) smoked sausage, such as linguica or kielbasa\n1 smoked ham hock or shank\n3-4 bay leaves\nWater\n1 14.5 ounce can (411 grams) of crushed tomatoes\nSalt\nMETHOD\n1 Soak beans in hot water: Pour boiling water over the black beans and let them sit while you prepare the rest of the stew.\n2 Brown the pork shoulder: Heat the olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat and brown the pork shoulder. When the meat has browned, remove the meat from the pot, set aside.\n3 Brown the onions, add garlic: Add the onions to the pot. Brown them, stirring occasionally, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the pot.\nSprinkle a little salt over the onions and add the garlic. Stir well and saut\xc3\xa9 2 more minutes.\n4 Add meat, bay leaves, cover with water, simmer: Add back the pork shoulder, and the other meats and add enough water to cover. Add the bay leaves, cover and bring to a simmer. Cook gently for 1 hour.\n5 Add soaked black beans, simmer: Drain the black beans from their soaking liquid and add them to the stew. Simmer gently, covered, until the beans are tender, about an hour and a half.\n6 Add tomatoes and simmer: Add the tomatoes, stir well and taste for salt, adding if it's needed. Simmer this, uncovered, until the meat begins to fall off the ham hock, which will probably take 2-3 hours.\nServe with white rice and hot sauce. A classic side dish would be saut\xc3\xa9ed collard greens.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nEasy Black Beans and Rice Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup uncooked white rice\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 small onion, chopped\n1/2 green bell pepper, thinly sliced\n1/2 red bell pepper, thinly sliced (for added flavor you can substitute roasted red bell peppers or some chopped pimentos)\n3 cloves minced garlic\n2 16-ounce cans of black beans, rinsed and drained\n2 tablespoons white vinegar\nA few dashes of Tabasco or 1/4 teaspoon cayenne powder\n1 teaspoon dried oregano OR 1 heaping tablespoon chopped fresh oregano\nSalt and pepper to taste\nOptional Lime wedges and cilantro for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the rice: Cook rice according to package instructions. White rice usually takes 15 minutes to cook once the water is simmering, and 10 minutes to sit.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, bell peppers, garlic: Heat oil in a large skillet on medium high. Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and bell peppers for 3-4 minutes, until just beginning to soften, then add garlic and saut\xc3\xa9 a minute more.\n3 Add beans, vinegar, Tabasco, then simmer: Add the black beans, vinegar and Tabasco or cayenne. Bring vinegar to a simmer, reduce heat, cover and simmer for 5 minutes.\n4 Stir in rice and oregano. Add salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nBlack Bean Burrito Bowl Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 8\nCook time and prep time depends on if you are using canned beans and already prepared rice, or if you cooking dry beans and rice from scratch.\nThis recipe makes a lot, but the leftovers keep well. You can easily cut the recipe in half.\nINGREDIENTS\n1  pound dry black beans\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 tablespoon ground cumin\n4 bay leaves\n2 teaspoons Kosher salt\n3 cloves garlic, minced\nOR\n4 15-ounce cans of whole black bean (preferably S&W premium black beans, or Bush's best black beans)\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1 teaspoon garlic powder\n1/2 cup chopped cilantro\n  3 cups, uncooked rice, white or brown\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n4 1/2 to 6 cups of water, depending on the type of rice (read package)\nSliced red cabbage\nRipe avocado, peeled and cut into chunks\nFresh tomato salsa\nChopped fresh cilantro\nQueso fresco Mexican farmer's cheese (or Cotija cheese) (skip if cooking vegan)\nSour cream or crema fresca (skip if cooking vegan)\n  METHOD\nPREPARING DRY BEANS\n1 Soak the beans: Place black beans in a large bowl or pot. Cover with 2 inches of water, let soak overnight, then drain. You can skip overnight soaking, place black beans in bowl, and cover with 2-inches of boiling water. Let soak for one hour. Then drain.\n2 Bring beans to a simmer: Place soaked and drained beans in a large pot. Cover with 2 inches of water. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 spices and garlic, add to beans: While the beans are coming to a boil in step 2, heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a small pan on medium heat. Stir in the ground cumin and cook until fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes. Add the minced garlic, cook a minute more. Once the beans are boiling, add the cumin and garlic to the pot with the beans. Add bay leaves and salt to the pot as well.\n4 Cook beans until tender: Cook the beans, uncovered, until tender, but not mushy, 30 minutes to 2 hours, depending on the size and age of the beans.\n5 Strain the beans: When the beans are done, place a strainer over a separate pot. Pour the beans into the strainer, to collect the cooking water into the pot. Set aside the beans, and boil down the cooking liquid until thickened and slightly syrupy. Return the cooking liquid to the beans and stir.\nPREPARING CANNED BEANS\n1 Place the beans and the liquid from the can in a sauce pan. (Taste the liquid first; if it tastes good, use it, if not, drain the beans first, and add as much liquid to the pot with the beans as you strained out.)\n2 Add the cumin and garlic powder to the beans. Bring to a simmer and simmer for a minute or two to heat the beans through. Stir in the cilantro and remove from heat.\nPREPARING THE REST\n1 Cook the rice: Place 3 cups of rice in a large saucepan. Depending on the type of rice you are using (short grain, long grain, white, brown) you will add any where from 4 1/2 cup of water to 6 cups of water to the pot. Check the rice package instructions.\nAdd 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Bring to a boil, lower the heat to low to maintain a very low simmer.\nCover and cook from 15 minutes to 45 minutes, depending on the type of rice (again, check the package instructions for the rice you are using).\nRemove from heat and let rest for 10 minutes, covered, before fluffing with a fork to serve.\n2 Construct the burrito bowl:  Place a serving of cooked rice at the bottom of a serving bowl. Top with black beans. Top with assorted garnishes\xe2\x80\x94thinly sliced cabbage, chopped avocados, chopped cilantro, queso fresco and sour cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nBlack Bean Turkey Chili Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 6\nThis recipe produces a mildly spicy chili. You can easily add more chili powder or some cayenne to intensify the spice level if you wish. You can also add chipotle chili powder or chipotle Tabasco to give a smoky note to the chili.\nAs for the red bell peppers, Trader Joe's has frozen sliced bell peppers that work well for this dish.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 medium onion, chopped (about 1 cup)\n1 carrot, chopped (about 1/2 cup)\n2 to 3 red bell peppers, chopped (about 2 cups)\nSalt\n2 cloves garlic, minced (about 2 teaspoons)\n2 tablespoons chili powder (more to taste)\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1 pound ground turkey (I use ground turkey thighs for more flavor)\n3 cups chicken stock\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1 bay leaf\n1 tablespoon tomato paste\n1 tablespoon cider or white vinegar\n2 (15-ounce) cans black beans, drained\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 carrots, onions, bell peppers: Heat the oil in a large, thick bottomed pot (6- to 8-quart) on medium heat. Add the chopped onion, carrot, and bell peppers, and sprinkle with salt. Cook until softened, 6 to 8 minutes.\n2 Add the minced garlic, chili powder, and cumin and cook for a minute more.\n3 Add the ground turkey and break it up with a wooden spoon. Increase the heat to medium high. Stir and cook until the turkey is no longer pink, about 5 minutes.\n4 Add the chicken stock, oregano, bay leaf, vinegar, and tomato paste. Use a straight edge spatula or wooden spoon to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan.\n5 Simmer the chili: Add the black beans. Bring the chili to a boil, lower to a simmer. Cover and cook for half an hour.\nUncover and cook for another half hour, or until the the liquid thickens.\n6 Serve: Remove the bay leaf. Taste the chili and adjust seasonings, adding salt and pepper to taste.\nServe with rice or heated corn tortillas.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBlack Bean Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nWe've sample many brands of canned black beans (see our Black Bean Burrito Bowl for details). Our favorites for flavor are S&W Premium Black Beans, Bush's Best Black Beans, and Goya.\nThis black bean salad uses cilantro. For those of you who don't like cilantro, feel free to substitute with fresh basil.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 (15 ounce) can of black beans, rinsed and drained (or 1 1/2 cups of freshly cooked black beans)\n1 1/2 cups frozen corn, defrosted (or fresh corn, parboiled, drained and cooled, or grilled and cooled)\n1/2 cup chopped green onions (including onion greens) or shallots\n1/2 fresh jalape\xc3\xb1o pepper, seeded and minced, or 1/2 pickled jalape\xc3\xb1o pepper, minced (not seeded)\n3 fresh plum tomatoes, seeded and chopped and/or 1 red bell pepper, seeded and chopped\n2 tablespoons lime juice (about the juice from one lime)\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 avocado, peeled, seeded, and cut into chunks\n1/2 to 1 teaspoon of sugar (to taste)\nSalt and pepper to taste\n1/2 cup chopped fresh cilantro\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 In a large bowl, gently combine the black beans, corn, chopped green onions, minced jalape\xc3\xb1os, chopped tomatoes (or red bell pepper), lime juice, and olive oil. Gently fold in the chopped avocados.\n2 Add salt and pepper to taste. Sprinkle with sugar to taste, enough to balance the acidity from the lime juice.  Chill.\n3 Right before serving, add the chopped fresh cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBaked Sweet Potato Taquitos Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 24 taquitos, enough for 6 to 8 for dinner or 8 to 12 as an appetizer\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the filling:\n1/2 pound sweet potatoes, peeled and shredded (about 2 cups)\n1 (15-oz) can black beans, drained and rinsed; liquid reserved (or about 2 cups homemade beans)\n2 teaspoons garlic powder\n2 teaspoons chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon fine sea salt\n6 tablespoons minced fresh cilantro\n24 6-inch corn tortillas\n4 tablespoons olive oil for brushing\nFor the dip:\n1 cup creamy vegan cashew \xe2\x80\x9ccheese\xe2\x80\x9d sauce\n1/2 cup lightly packed chopped cilantro\n2 cloves garlic, crushed\n1/2 teaspoon sea salt\nTo serve:\nCilantro\nMinced red onion\nMETHOD\n1 Make the filling: In a medium skillet, combine the shredded sweet potatoes with the black beans, garlic powder, chili powder, salt, and 3 tablespoons of the bean liquid.\nSimmer the mixture until the sweet potatoes are tender; 6 to 8 minutes. Lightly mash the black beans and stir in the minced cilantro.\n2 Warm the tortillas: Wrap tortillas in a damp towel and place in a 300\xcb\x9aF oven for roughly 10 minutes to warm. Alternatively, wrap the tortillas in damp paper towels and place in the microwave for 20 seconds or so.\n3 Assemble the taquitos: Place a tortilla in front of you. Scoop 2 to 3 tablespoons of the filling onto the third of the tortilla closest to you. Roll the edge closest to you over the filling and tuck the edge tightly under. Then, continue to roll.\nPlace the taquito seam side down on a baking tray lined with parchment. Stick with a toothpick if necessary to keep the filling from falling out. Repeat with remaining filling. (Depending on how much filling you've used with each taquito, you may have tortillas leftover.)\nAt this point, the taquitos can be frozen for up to 6 months; see headnotes for detailed freezing and reheating instructions.\n4 Bake the taquitos: Preheat your oven to 425\xcb\x9aF. Brush with olive oil and bake for 18 to 22 minutes until tortillas are browning and crisp.\n5 Assemble the dip: While the taquitos are baking, in a small bowl combine the cashew cream with the cilantro, garlic, and salt.\n 6 Serve: Serve the taquitos with the cashew dip drizzled on top, along with a sprinkle of cilantro and minced red onion, if desired.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nSpicy, Citrusy Black Beans Recipe\nCook time: 2 hoursBean soaking time: OvernightYield: Serves 8\nAdapted from a recipe in the Fields of Greens cookbook.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups dried black beans\n2 1/2 quarts (10 cups) water\n2-3 fresh sprigs oregano, or 1 tablespoon dried\n3 bay leaves\n6 small or 3 large sage leaves\n2 teaspoons salt\n4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 yellow onions, chopped\n2 chopped peppers \xe2\x80\x93 bell pepper, Anaheim, or jalape\xc3\xb1o (your choice, depending on taste for heat), seeds, stems and ribs discarded\n6 cloves crushed garlic\n2 tablespoons Ancho red chili sauce, or chili powder or Tabasco to taste*\n1-2 teaspoons of pur\xc3\xa9ed chipotle in adobo, chipotle Tabasco, or chipotle powder (to taste)\n1 tablespoon cumin, (crushed whole toasted cumin seed is best, if possible)\n3 tablespoons frozen orange juice concentrate or 1/2 cup fresh orange juice\nJuice of 1 lime\n2 tablespoons rice wine vinegar\nChopped fresh cilantro for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Soak the beans (optional): Rinse and sort the beans, discarding any stones or shriveled beans. You can soak the beans overnight in cold water (cover with several inches of water) OR pour enough boiling water over them to cover by a few inches and soak them for an hour OR skip the pre-soaking step.\nSoaking will speed up the cooking process. If you soak, discard the soaking liquid after soaking.\n2 Cook the beans: Add beans to a large pot with 2 1/2 quarts (10 cups) of water. Add oregano, bay leaves, and sage. Bring the beans to a boil and reduce heat to a simmer.\nCook until the beans are soft, but not quite done. The time will vary depending on how large, dry, or old your beans are, and if you have pre-soaked them, from anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour and a half.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and peppers, add spices: While the beans are cooking, saut\xc3\xa9 onions and peppers in olive oil until soft. Add chili sauce, chili powder, and/or chili pur\xc3\xa9e, cumin, and garlic. Saut\xc3\xa9 until spices are fragrant.\n4 Fish out and discard the bay leaves, stems of oregano, and sage leaves from the pot of beans. Remove, but reserve, extra cooking liquid until there is about 1/2-inch of liquid above beans.\n5 Add the onion mixture and salt to the pot of beans. Cook another hour or so until thickened. Add reserved liquid if needed.\n6 Add half of the orange juice, and simmer. Adjust chili heat at this point \xe2\x80\x93 you may or may not want to add more of your chili paste.\nJust before serving, add remaining orange juice, lime juice, and vinegar. Salt to taste. Garnish with chopped fresh cilantro.\nServe with corn tortillas, and/or rice, sour cream, and salsa.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nMexican Quinoa Salad with Black Beans, Corn, and Tomatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nIf you are working with frozen corn, you can add more flavor by taking the frozen corn kernels and searing them directly on a hot pan, without defrosting first. Save time by prepping most of the ingredients while the quinoa is cooking.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup uncooked quinoa, well rinsed\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 cups water\n1/3 cup diced red onion\n2 Tbsp lime juice\n1 15-ounce can black beans, drained and rinsed\n1 cup frozen corn, defrosted, OR 1 cup of fresh corn, parboiled, drained and cooled (approximately the amount of kernels from one ear of corn)\n3 medium tomatoes, seeded and cut into chunks\n5 ounces Queso fresco, Queso Panela, fresh Mozzarella or other mild farmer's cheese, cut into 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch cubes\n1 jalape\xc3\xb1o, seeded and finely chopped\n1/4 cup chopped cilantro, including tender stems, packed\n3 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the quinoa: Put the rinsed quinoa, salt and water into a pot and bring it to a boil. Cover and simmer gently until the quinoa absorbs all the water, about 10-15 minutes.\nRemove from heat and let sit for 5 minutes. Place into a large bowl and fluff up with a fork to help it cool more quickly.\n2 Soak onions in lime juice: While the quinoa is cooking, prepare the rest of the salad. Soak the red onions in the lime juice and set aside. Soaking the onions in lime juice (or lemon juice or water) helps take the edge off of them.\n3 Mix the prepped black beans, corn kernels, tomatoes, cheese, jalape\xc3\xb1os, cilantro, and oil into a large bowl.\n4 Add quinoa and onions to bean mixture: When the quinoa has cooled, mix it into the bean mixture. Add the red onion and the lime juice and add salt, more oil or lime juice to taste.\nServe at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nThree Bean Baked Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 7 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 pound sliced bacon\n2 cups chopped onion\n1 Tbsp dry mustard\n1 teaspoon minced fresh thyme (or 1/2 teaspoons dry thyme)\n3/4 cup ketchup\n3 tablespoons apple cider vinegar\n1/4 cup dark molasses\n1/3 cup water\n1 bay leaf\n1 15-ounce can red kidney beans, rinsed, drained\n1 15-ounce can black beans, rinsed, drained\n1 15-ounce can cannellini (white kidney beans), rinsed, drained\n1 teaspoon Tabasco\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Cook and crumble the bacon: Cook the bacon in a large Dutch oven over medium heat until browned and crisp. Remove bacon and place on paper towels to soak up excess fat. Crumble up the bacon and set aside.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: Remove all but a tablespoon of the bacon drippings from the pot. Add the chopped onions and cook on medium high heat until translucent, about 5 minutes.\n4 Add the rest of the ingredients: Sprinkle the onions with dry mustard and thyme. Stir in the ketchup, vinegar, molasses, bay leaf, beans, Tabasco, and water. Add salt and pepper to taste.\n5 Cover and bake: Cover the pot and put into a 350\xc2\xb0F oven. Bake for 1 hour, checking every 15 minutes to stir and add more water if needed. Stir in the bacon the last 15 minutes of cooking.\nAlternatively, cook in a slow cooker 4 hours on high, or 8 on low.\nDiscard bay leaf before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nSanta Fe Pork and Black Bean Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nWe are using canned black beans in this recipe, but you could easily use dry beans if you cook them ahead. Here's how to make beans on the stovetop or in a pressure cooker.\nThis recipe makes a relatively small batch for a stew (serves 4). You can easily double the recipe to make a larger batch.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 pounds of pork shoulder, trimmed of excess fat, cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 large onion, chopped (about 2 cups)\n4 cloves garlic\n1-2 jalape\xc3\xb1o chili peppers, less or more to taste, seeded, stems removed\n2 tablespoons cornmeal\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n2 teaspoons ground cumin\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1/2 teaspoon cayenne (less or more to taste)\n1 1/2 tablespoons molasses\n1 red bell pepper, diced, about 3/4 cup\n2 long 1-inch wide strips of orange zest (optional)\n1 cup water\n1 15-ounce can black beans (we recommend Bush's or S&W premium), liquid included\nMore salt to taste\n1 to 2 limes\nCilantro for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Sprinkle 1 teaspoon salt over the pork pieces and let sit while you prep the other ingredients.\n2 Brown the pork: Heat 2 Tbsp olive oil in a thick-bottomed stew pot on medium high heat. Add the pork pieces to the pot and brown them on all sides.\n3 Add the onions: Once the pork pieces have browned, add the chopped onions to the pot with the pork. Lower the heat to medium and cook until the onions are translucent, about 7-10 minutes more.\n4 Make garlic jalape\xc3\xb1o spice mixture: As the onions are cooking, work on the garlic spice mixture. Place the garlic and the jalape\xc3\xb1os in the bowl of a food processor and pulse until minced. Then add the oregano, cumin, cinnamon, cayenne, and cornmeal and pulse everything until ground.\n5 Add spice mixture to pork and onions: Once the onions are cooked, add the spice mixture to the pork and onions.\n6 Add molasses, bell pepper, zest, cover and cook: Add the molasses, bell pepper, orange zest (if using), and water to the pot. Bring it to a simmer and then reduce the heat to the lowest setting. Cover and let cook until the pork is completely tender, about 1 1/2 hours. Stir occasionally and scrape up any browned bits stuck to the bottom of the pot.\n7 Remove zest, add black beans: When pork is tender, remove the orange zest and add the black beans to the pot and cook for 20 minutes more on low heat.\n8 Remove from heat, and stir in the lime juice. Add more salt to taste.\nServe garnished with fresh cilantro. Great with warm corn tortillas.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nTurkey Black Bean Enchiladas Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 6\nFeel free to substitute cooked chicken meat for the cooked turkey.\nINGREDIENTS\nEnchilada sauce:\n7 Tbsp chili powder (note that chili powders vary in strength, you may want to start with less and add more to taste)\n2 teaspoons ground cumin\n1 teaspoon crushed oregano\n1 teaspoon garlic powder\n1 teaspoon cinnamon\n1/8 teaspoon ground cloves\n1 teaspoon sugar\n2 teaspoons salt (less if using salted stock)\n1/4 cup flour\n2 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n2 cups of turkey or chicken stock\nEnchilada filling:\n1 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 medium onion, chopped\n3 garlic cloves, minced\n1 to 2 jalape\xc3\xb1o chili peppers (1 for mild, 2 or more for spicy), seeded, minced\n3 cups cooked turkey meat, chopped\n1 15-ounce can black beans, rinsed and drained, or homemade\n8 ounces Monterey Jack cheese, grated (makes 2 cups grated cheese)\n1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro\n2 Tbsp lime juice (can sub lemon juice)\n1 to 2 teaspoons salt or more to taste\n8-16 flour tortillas, depending on size and thickness\nGarnishes:\nChopped red onion\nChopped avocado\nChopped fresh cilantro\nSour cream or crema fresca\nIce berg lettuce, sliced thin and sprinkled with salt and vinegar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make enchilada sauce: In a medium bowl, whisk together the chili powder, cumin, oregano, garlic powder, cinnamon, ground cloves, sugar, salt, and flour.\nHeat olive oil on medium heat in a cast iron pan (or other thick-bottomed saut\xc3\xa9 pan). Add the spices and cook for a minute or two, until fragrant.\nSlowly whisk in the stock, until smooth. Let come to a simmer, cook for a minute, then remove from heat, cover and set aside.\n2 Prepare the filling: Heat olive oil in a saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the chopped onion and jalape\xc3\xb1os and cook until the onions are translucent, about 3-4 minutes. Add the garlic and cook a minute more. Remove from heat.\nPlace onion mixture in a medium mixing bowl. Mix in the cooked turkey meat, the beans, 1 cup of the grated cheese, 1/4 cup of chopped cilantro, 2 Tbsp lime juice, and 1/2 a cup of the enchilada sauce. Add 1 to 2 teaspoons of salt, or more to taste. Set aside.\n3 Assemble the enchiladas: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Heat the pan with the enchilada sauce on medium heat. Spread 1/2 cup of the sauce over the bottom of a 9x13 casserole dish (pyrex works well).\nWorking one at a time, dip the flour tortillas in the sauce to coat them on both sides. If the sauce is too thick, thin it with a little water.\nPlace the tortilla in the casserole dish and place anywhere from 1/4 of a cup to 1/2 cup of the filling in the middle of the tortilla.\nRoll up the tortilla around the filling and place it in the casserole dish. Continue to roll up the rest of your tortillas until they fill the casserole dish. Cover the enchiladas with the remaining sauce, and sprinkle with the remaining cheese.\n4 Bake: Place in the oven and bake, uncovered, for 15 to 20 minutes, until the enchiladas are heated through and the cheese has melted.\n5 Sprinkle with lime juice, serve with garnishes: Sprinkle with a little more lime juice before serving. Serve with chopped red onion, chopped avocado, fresh cilantro, sour cream or crema fresca, and thinly sliced iceberg lettuce that has been dressed with vinegar and salt (no oil).\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nTurkey Black Bean Quinoa Bake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nTo save time, prep the ingredients and start on the onions and peppers while the quinoa is cooking.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup uncooked quinoa\n2 cups water\nSalt\n3 cups shredded, chopped cooked turkey\n2 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n2 cups onion, chopped\n2 bell peppers, seeded and chopped\n4 cloves garlic, minced\n1 cup frozen corn, defrosted\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1 teaspoon chili powder (chipotle chili powder if available), less or more to taste\n1 15-ounce can black beans, drained\n1/2 cup chopped cilantro\n3 cups grated cheddar cheese, divided 2 cups and 1 cup\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the quinoa: Cook the quinoa according to package directions. Typically package directions ask you to put 1 cup of quinoa with 2 cups of water and a pinch of salt into a pot, bringing it to a boil, reduce to a very low simmer, cover and cook for 15 minutes. Then remove from heat and fluff with a fork.\n2 Cook peppers and onions: Heat olive oil in a large skillet on medium high heat. Add the onions and the bell peppers and cook until softened and browned at the edges, about 10 minutes.\n3 Add garlic, spices, corn: Add the garlic, cumin, chili powder, and corn, and cook a minute more. Remove from heat.\n4 Place the cooked quinoa, black beans, onion mixture, cilantro, 2 cups of grated cheddar cheese, and cooked turkey in a large bowl. Toss to combine.\n5 Top with cheese and bake: Place in a casserole dish. Sprinkle the top with remaining 1 cup of cheddar cheese, and bake at 350\xc2\xb0F uncovered for 15 minutes, until the cheese is melted and bubbly.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCheesy Quinoa Black Bean Stuffed Bell Peppers Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nFor a non-vegetarian option, cook up some Mexican chorizo on medium heat until cooked through, and mix that in with the stuffing!\nAlthough I've focused on the orange and red bell peppers in the photographs, personally I prefer the green bell peppers with this dish.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup uncooked quinoa (white or red or both)\nSalt\n6 large bell peppers, any color\n1 15-ounce can black beans, drained\n4 cups grated sharp cheddar cheese, 2 cups for stuffing, 2 cups for topping\n3 to 4 green onions, finely sliced\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/2 cup loosely packed chopped fresh cilantro (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the quinoa: Place 1 cup of quinoa, 2 cups of water, and 1/2 teaspoon of salt in a medium saucepan. Bring to a boil, cover, reduce to a simmer and cook for 15 minutes.\nRemove from heat and let sit for 10 minutes, covered. Spread cooked quinoa out in a baking dish to cool quickly.\n2 Steam the bell peppers:  Cut the top 1/2 to 1 inch off of the bell peppers and remove the core and seeds inside. (If you want, you can finely chop the pieces of good bell pepper you've removed and include them in the stuffing, otherwise, save them for another use.)\nFill a large pot with an inch of water. Place a steamer rack in the pot, place the pepper shells on the steamer rack, cut side up. Bring to a boil, cover and steam the peppers 5 to 10 minutes, until they begin to soften.\n3 Make the filling: In a large bowl mix the cooked quinoa, drained black beans, 2 cups of the grated cheddar cheese, most of the green onion (save some for topping), cumin, and cilantro if using.\n4 Stuff the bell peppers with the stuffing you've prepared. You should have plenty of stuffing, you can pack it and mound the stuffing in the peppers. Place 1/4 cup of water at the base of the peppers.\n5 Bake: Cover with aluminum foil. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 35 minutes. Then remove from oven, uncover, top with the remaining 2 cups of cheese, and return to the oven to cook, uncovered, until the cheese has melted about 5 to 10 minutes.\nSprinkle with remaining finely sliced green onions to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBBQ Chicken Burrito Bowl Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 4 servings\nIf you're making this for lunch, assemble the bowls in a lunch container, but pack the lettuce and salsa separately. Heat the bowls, then add top with the lettuce and salsa.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the BBQ sauce (or substitute 3/4 to 1 cup bottled sauce):\n1 cup ketchup\n1/2 cup tomato sauce\n2 tablespoons distilled white vinegar (apple cider vinegar also works)\n2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce\n1 tablespoon honey (light brown sugar or maple syrup also works)\n2 1/2 teaspoons paprika\n1/2 teaspoon granulated garlic\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon ground cumin\nFor the burrito bowls:\n1 pound (450g) chicken breasts (or substitute 2 cups cooked, shredded chicken)\n4 cups chicken broth or water, for cooking the chicken\n1 cup uncooked brown rice (or substitute 3 cups cooked rice)\n1 1/4 cup fresh or frozen corn kernels\n1 15-ounce (425g) can black beans, drained and rinsed\n6 to 8 romaine lettuce leaves, chopped into strips\n1 cup pico de gallo or your favorite salsa\n1 cup shredded cheddar or monterey jack cheese, optional\nCrushed tortilla chips, for topping\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nDo-ahead steps:\n1 Make the barbecue sauce (or substitute 3/4 to 1 cup bottled sauce): Mix all of the ingredients for the BBQ sauce (ketchup through cumin) in a saucepan and heat over medium heat. When the sauce starts bubbling, reduce the heat to low and simmer for 5 minutes, stirring frequently. (This sauce splatters everywhere once it heats up. Be prepared to wipe down your stovetop and countertops after making this!) Remove from heat.\nYou should have about 1 2/3 cups of sauce.  The sauce will keep for 1 to 2 weeks refrigerated.\n2 Cook the chicken (or substitute 2 cups shredded cooked chicken): Place the chicken breasts in a 4-quart or larger pot with a lid and pour the chicken broth over top. The chicken should be covered by about an inch; add additional broth or water if needed. Place over high heat and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to low, cover, and cook for 10 minutes. Check that the chicken is cooked through and registers 165F in the thickest part. Cook another few minutes if needed. Use tongs to transfer the cooked chicken breasts to a cutting board to cool briefly.\nWhen the chicken is cool, shred the meat into bite-sized pieces. Refrigerate in an air-tight container for up to 5 days.\n3 Cook the rice (or substitute 3 cups cooked rice): Combine the rice with 1/2 teaspoon of salt and 2 cups of water (or enough to cover by about an inch). Bring to a simmer over medium heat, then lower the heat and cover. Cook until the rice is tender, 35 to 45 minutes (or according to package instructions). Check occasionally and add more water if the pan seems dry before the rice is cooked.\nCool the cooked rice, and then transfer to a storage container. Refrigerate for up to 5 days.\n  To assemble the burrito bowls:\n1 Mix the chicken with the barbecue sauce: Warm the barbecue sauce for a few minutes in a small pan or skillet over medium-high heat. Add the shredded chicken and stir to coat with the barbecue sauce. Leave the chicken in the pan until it has warmed through, about 2 to 3 minutes. Turn off heat.\n2 Warm the corn and beans: Heat the corn and black beans together or separately in a pan or skillet over medium-high heat for 2 to 3 minutes. Add a pinch of salt to your corn and beans and turn off heat.\n3 Warm the rice in the microwave or on a pan. If you are using the microwave, pour the rice into a large bowl and cover it with a damp paper towel. Microwave the rice on high for about 1 minute. Check to see if the rice has warmed through. If it is still cold in some spots, give everything a stir and continue microwaving at 15-second intervals, until the rice is heated to your liking.\n4 Assemble the burrito bowls: Divide the rice, chicken, corn, beans, romaine lettuce, and pico de gallo into 4 bowls. Top with cheese, if using, and then crush a few tortilla chips on top of each bowl for extra crunch.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nTexas Stacked Enchiladas with Corn and Black Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the sauce\n2 garlic cloves, sliced\n1/2 yellow onion, coarsely chopped\n1 (28-ounce) can whole, peeled tomatoes\n2 tablespoons all-purpose flour\n2 teaspoons ancho chile powder, or to taste\n1/2 teaspoon dried oregano\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup water\n1 tablespoon olive oil\nFor the tortillas\n12 corn tortillas (6 to 7-inch size)\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nFor the filling\n2 tablespoons finely chopped red or yellow onion\n1 cup frozen corn\n1/4 teaspoon salt\nPinch black pepper\n1 can black beans, rinsed and drained\nFor the garnishes\n4 ounces queso fresco, crumbled (or feta or Monterey jack)\n1 ripe avocado, cut into slices\n4 to 6 radishes, thinly sliced\nLeaves from 1/4 bunch cilantro\nSpecial equipment:\n2 baking sheets\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xbaF.\n2 Make the sauce: In a blender, puree the garlic, onion, tomatoes, flour, chili powder, oregano, salt and water until smooth.\nIn a deep skillet over medium heat, heat the oil. Add the sauce and cook, stirring often, until it comes to a boil.\nLower the heat and cook the sauce at a steady simmer for 10 minutes. It may sputter like mad, so either stir often or top with a spatter guard. The sauce should have the consistency of heavy cream. Add more water to thin it if necessary.\nNote: you may have a bit more sauce than you need. It can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 5 days and used for leftovers.\n3 Bake the tortillas: Using a pastry brush, brush both sides of one tortilla with oil and place it on a plate. Set a second tortilla on top and brush the top with oil. Continue to brush and stack the tortillas in the same manner.\nWhen done, press down on the stack gently so that that both sides of each tortilla are lightly coated with oil. This way, all the sides get covered with oil as you create the stack.\nSpread them out on two baking sheets. Bake for 10 minutes, or until slightly crisp at the edges.\nNote: You can prepare the tortillas up to a day ahead. Cool completely, then transfer to a plastic zip-top bag and store at room temperature.\n4 Prepare the filling: In a microwave-safe bowl, combine the onion, corn, salt and pepper. Microwave for 2 minutes. Add the beans and microwave for one minute longer, or until the filling is hot all the way through. Cover and keep warm.\nNote: The filling can be prepared up to a day ahead and refrigerated. \n5 Assemble the enchiladas: Set 4 plates next to the stove.\nDip one tortilla in the sauce and set it on one of the plates. Spread 2 tablespoons of the filling over the tortilla. Dip a second tortilla in the sauce and place it on top. Spread with 2 more tablespoons of the filling. Dip a third tortilla in the sauce and place on top of the stack. Spoon a little more sauce over the top.\nSprinkle the stack with one-fourth of the cheese, one-fourth of the avocado slices, one-fourth of the radishes and top with one-fourth of the cilantro leaves.\nRepeat with remaining tortillas, sauce, and garnishes.\nIf desired, transfer each stack to a baking sheet in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven to keep warm as you finish assembling the rest. Serve all the stacks together at once.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nChicken and Black Bean Tostadas Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 4 servings\nA little shortcut: If you don\xe2\x80\x99t have time to fry the tortillas, you can cheat and crack open a hard corn taco shell and place the two halves on the plate as a base, then build the tostada from there.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken:\n2 boneless skinless chicken breasts (3/4 to 1 pound total)\n1 teaspoon Kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground pepper\nOptional for flavoring the poaching liquid: whole peppercorns, sprigs of fresh thyme or oregano, bay leaves, whole garlic cloves or halved shallots, and lemon slices\nFor the chipotle dressing:\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 tablespoon lime juice (from about 1 lime)\n1 teaspoon pureed chipotles in adobo sauce (optional)\n1 tablespoon minced shallots\nFor the cilantro crema:\n1 teaspoon lime juice\n1/2 cup sour cream\n2 tablespoons minced cilantro leaves\nFor the tostadas:\nVegetable or canola oil for pan frying\n4 6-inch corn tortillas (or tortillas with a blend of flour and corn such as La Tortilla Factory 50/50)\n1 teaspoon minced garlic\n1 (15-ounce) can black beans, drained and rinsed\n1/2 teaspoon cumin\n1 heart of romaine, thinly sliced crosswise into slivers (about 4 cups)\n1/2 cup diced plum tomato\n1 ripe avocado, peeled and cubed\n1/2 cup shredded cheddar or Mexican blend cheese, or crumbled cotija cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the chicken. Place the chicken breasts, salt, pepper, and any optional flavoring extras in a small pot. Add water to cover by 1 inch and place over medium-high heat.\nCover the pot and bring the chicken to simmer for 8 to 12 minutes until it is cooked through and registers at least 165\xc2\xb0F with a digital thermometer. Exact cooking time will depend on the thickness of the chicken breasts.\n2 Shred the chicken: Remove the chicken from the heat and remove the chicken from the liquid. Scoop out 1/2 cup of the cooking liquid and set to the side (the remainder can be strained and saved for another recipe).\nWhen cool enough to handle, shred the chicken into bite-sized pieces.\n3 Make the chipotle dressing: In a small bowl or container with a lid, combine the olive oil, 1 tablespoon lime juice, the pureed chipotle in adobo (if using), and shallot. Taste and season with salt and pepper to taste.\n4 Make the lime crema: In another small bowl or container, combine the sour cream, 1 teaspoon lime juice, and the cilantro.\n5 Pan fry the tortillas: Heat a thin layer of canola oil in a skillet over medium-high heat until a tiny flick of water into the pan sizzles on contact. Pan fry the tortillas one at a time, for about 2 minutes on each side until lightly browned and fairly crisp.\nAdd a bit more oil if needed during the frying process.  Transfer the tortillas to paper towels as they finish cooking.\n6 Cook the garlic and beans: Pour off any excess oil from the skillet, leaving a thin film on the bottom of the pan. Return to medium heat. Stir in the garlic and cumin and saut\xc3\xa9 for 30 seconds until you can smell the seasonings and the garlic starts to turn golden.\nAdd the beans and stir well, then add 1/4 cup of the reserved cooking liquid and bring to a simmer. Simmer for about 5 minutes until the beans are hot and the liquid reduces to a glaze on the beans\xe2\x80\x94if it starts to look dry you can add a bit more of the reserved liquid.\n7 Serve the tostadas: Place each of the tortillas on a plate and pile 1 cup of lettuce onto each.\nDivide the warm beans equally over the lettuce, then repeat the same process with the chicken, tomatoes, and avocados. Finally, top the tostadas with the cheese and cilantro. Drizzle the dressing evenly over the tostadas and finish with a dollop of crema. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlack Bean Burgers with Spicy Mayonnaise Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 10 minutesChill time: 1 hourYield: 4 to 6 burgers\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the spicy mayonnaise:\n1/2 cup mayonnaise\n3/4 teaspoon ancho chile powder\n2 teaspoons lime juice\nFor the burgers:\n1 clove garlic, thinly sliced\n1 poblano pepper, seeded and cut into 1-inch chunks\n1/2 medium onion, cut into 1-inch chunks\n1 medium zucchini (about 9 ounces), cut into 1-inch chunks\n4 tablespoons olive oil, divided\n1 slice whole wheat bread, or 1/2 burger roll, torn into pieces\n2 (15-ounce) cans black beans, rinsed, drained and patted dry with paper towels\n1 large egg, well beaten\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper\n4 to 6 ounces shredded Monterey jack or pepper jack cheese\nFor serving:\n4 to 6 hamburger rolls\n1 large red onion, sliced\n1 large tomato, sliced\n1 medium ripe avocado, sliced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the spicy mayonnaise: In a bowl, stir together the mayonnaise, ancho chili powder and lime juice. Set aside, or refrigerate for up to a week.\n2 Chop the vegetables: In a food processor, finely chop the garlic. Add the pepper and onion and pulse until finely chopped. Add the zucchini and pulse again to chop it into small pieces.\n3 Cook the vegetables: In a large nonstick skillet over medium heat, heat 2 tablespoons of the oil. Add the chopped garlic, pepper, onion, and zucchini. Cook, stirring often, for 5 minutes, or until most of the liquid has evaporated. Transfer to a large bowl. Wipe out the skillet.\n4 Make the breadcrumbs: Without cleaning the food processor, add the torn bread pieces and pulse until they form soft breadcrumbs. Add to the bowl of vegetables.\n5 Chop the beans: In the food processor (again, don\xe2\x80\x99t bother to wash it), pulse the beans until they are in small pieces, but not pasty. Transfer to the bowl with the vegetables and breadcrumbs.\n6 Mix and refrigerate the burger mix: Add the egg, salt, and pepper to the bowl. With a spatula, stir until well mixed. Refrigerate for an hour.\n7 Shape the patties: Shape the chilled mixture into 4 to 6 patties about 3 inches wide. At this point, the patties can be cooked immediately, or stacked between parchment and refrigerated for up to 2 days.\n7 Cook the burgers: In a large non-stick skillet over medium heat, heat the remaining 2 tablespoons of oil. Add the patties and cook for 5 minutes on a side, or until browned and hot all the way through. Top with the grated cheese, cover the pan, and cook for 2 to 3 minutes, or until the cheese melts.\n8 Assemble the burgers: Spread the spicy mayonnaise on the bottoms and tops of the buns. Add the burgers and top with sliced tomatoes, onions, avocados and lettuce. Serve extra mayonnaise on the side.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nGrilled Lime Chicken with Black Bean Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 2 hoursCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIf you don't have access to a grill, you can saut\xc3\xa9 the chicken breasts in a cast iron pan on medium high to high heat until lightly browned on both sides and just cooked through.\nINGREDIENTS\nGrilled Chicken Ingredients:\n6 Tbsp lime juice (from 3 to 4 limes)\n2 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 cup+ (more to taste) chopped fresh cilantro\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 1/2 lbs boneless, skinless chicken breasts, thin cutlets\nGarnish:\n1/2 cup chopped red onion\n2 Tbsp seasoned rice vinegar\nSliced avocados, sour cream, cilantro\nBlack Bean Sauce Ingredients:\n1 Tbsp olive oil\n1/2 cup chopped red onion\n2 cloves garlic, crushed and minced\n1 (15 oz.) can black beans\n1 3/4 cups water\n1 bay leaves\n1/2 cup chopped cilantro, including stems, loosely packed\n1/2 teaspoon dried oregano\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/4 teaspoon Kosher salt, or more to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate chicken breasts: Combine the lime juice, olive oil, cilantro, oregano, salt and pepper in a glass bowl and mix well. If the chicken breasts are not already thin cutlets, make them so by cutting them in half horizontally.\nThey should be no more than 3/4-inch thick at their thickest point. Trim the chicken breasts of excess fat, then add them to the marinade. Cover with plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for 2 hours.\n2 Soak chopped red onion for garnish in rice wine vinegar and water: Place 1/2 cup chopped red onion in a small bowl and add a couple tablespoons of rice wine vinegar, and enough water to just cover the onions. Chill until dish is ready for garnish.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions for black bean sauce: First, taste the liquid in the canned beans. If it tastes good, use it, if not, drain the can, and rinse the beans. (Depending on the brand of canned beans, the liquid might be good tasting or not.)\nHeat 1 Tbsp of olive oil in a saucepan on medium heat. When hot, add the chopped red onions and cook for 5 minutes, until translucent. Add the minced garlic and cook a minute more.\n4 Add beans, water, bay leaf, spices, then simmer: Add the beans to pot, including the can liquid if using (if not, replace with water). Fill up the empty can with water and add that to the pot as well (about 1 3/4 cups of water).\nAdd the bay leaf, chopped cilantro, oregano, black pepper, and salt. Increase the heat to bring to a boil, then reduce heat to maintain a low simmer.\nSimmer uncovered  for 10 to 15 minutes. Remove from heat and let sit for a few minutes.\n5 Pur\xc3\xa9e sauce: Remove the bay leaf. Pulse in a blender (or use an immersion blender) until somewhat smooth. (Remember to only fill a blender a third of the way if you are blending hot liquids, and hold the top down while you blend.)\n6 Grill chicken breasts: Prepare your grill for medium-high, direct heat. Place the chicken breasts on the grill, and grill until they are just cooked through (approximately 1 1/2 to 2 minutes on each side). Remove to platter when grilled.\nServe the grilled chicken with the black bean sauce. Sprinkle with the strained red onions, and garnish with sour cream, guacamole, tomatoes or fresh cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nTurkey Taco Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nFor a lighter version of this salad, skip cheese or swap the sour cream for yogurt \xe2\x80\x93 or both!\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the bean and turkey topping:\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 medium onion, finely chopped\n1 clove garlic, finely chopped\n2 1/2 teaspoons ancho chili powder (or substitute regular chili powder)\n2 teaspoons ground cumin\n1 teaspoon oregano\n1/4 teaspoon salt\nFresh ground black pepper\n1/2 pound ground turkey\n1 can (15 ounces) diced fire-roasted tomatoes\n1 can (15 ounces) black beans, rinsed and drained\n1 cup fresh or frozen corn kernels\nFor the salad:\n2 tablespoons sherry vinegar\n1/4 teaspoon salt\nFresh ground black pepper\n5 tablespoons olive oil\n2 hearts of romaine, chopped or sliced\n1/2 pint cherry tomatoes, halved\n1/2 red onion, sliced\n6 radishes, thinly sliced\n2 ripe avocados, sliced\n1 cup (4 ounces) shredded Monterey jack cheese, or more, to taste\nHandful of cilantro leaves, stems removed\n1/2 cup sour cream\n1 lime, cut into wedges\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the onion, garlic and spices: In a large, deep skillet over medium heat, heat the olive oil. Add the onion, garlic, chili powder, cumin, oregano, salt and a few grinds of fresh black pepper.\nCook, stirring occasionally for 5 minutes, or until the onions soften.\n2 Add the ground turkey and continue cooking. Break up the meat into small bits as it cooks using a stiff spatula. Cook for about 4 minutes, or until the turkey is no longer pink.\n3 Stir in the diced tomatoes, black beans and corn. Reduce the heat to medium-low and cook for about 10 more minutes to allow the flavors to mingle and the mixture to thicken. If the mixture seems dry, add water 2 tablespoons at a time.\nRemove the skillet from the heat. Taste for seasoning and add more salt, if you like. Cool briefly.\nThis topping can be made ahead and kept refrigerated for up to 5 days. Serve cold, or warm briefly in the microwave or a warm skillet before serving.\n4 Dress the greens: In a bowl large enough to hold the lettuce, whisk together the vinegar, 1/4 teaspoon salt and a few grinds of fresh black pepper. Gradually whisk in the olive oil until the dressing looks combined.\nAdd the lettuce to the bowl. Toss to coat it with the dressing. Taste for seasoning and add more salt and pepper, if you like.\n5 Assemble the salad: Divide the lettuce among 4 to 6 plates. Divide the filling between the plates, and garnish with the tomatoes, onions, avocado, radishes, shredded cheese and cilantro. Top each salad with spoonful of sour cream and a lime wedge, and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nButternut Squash and Black Bean Skillet Dinner Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 4-6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound peeled and seeded butternut squash, cut into 1/2-inch cubes\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1 cup red quinoa\n1 medium onion, finely chopped\n2 cloves garlic, finely chopped\n1 teaspoon ancho chili powder, or chili powder of your choice\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1 1/4 cups water or low-salt vegetable stock\n1 (15-ounce) can fire-roasted diced tomatoes\n1 (15-ounce) can black beans, rinsed and drained\n2 large handfuls baby spinach leaves\n1/3 cup pepitas (green pumpkin seeds)\n3 ounces (1/2 cup) crumbled cotija cheese (optional)\nTo garnish:\n1/2 cup cilantro leaves\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xbaF.\n2 Roast the squash: On a rimmed baking sheet, mound the squash in the center. Sprinkle it with 1 tablespoon of the oil, 1/4 teaspoon salt, and 1/8 teaspoon pepper. Toss to coat the squash, massaging the oil into the cubes to coat them.\nSpread into a single layer and roast for about 20 minutes, turning it once after 15 minutes, until tender and browned in places. Remove from oven and let cool.\n3 Rinse the quinoa: Place the quinoa in a fine-mesh strainer and rinse it with cold running water for 1-2 minutes, shaking the strainer and stirring with your hands to remove the bitter coating (saponin) from the seeds.\n4 Cook the onion and spices: In a large skillet over medium-high heat, add 2 tablespoons of oil. Once the oil shimmers, add the onion, and cook, stirring occasionally, for 4 minutes or until lightly browned. Add the garlic, oregano, chili powder, and cumin, and stir for 1 minute.\n4 Cook the quinoa: Add the quinoa, water or broth, diced tomatoes (including the juices), drained beans, and 1/2 teaspoon salt and bring to a boil.\nReduce the heat to medium, cover the pan, and simmer for 18 to 20 minutes, or until the liquid is absorbed. Stir in the spinach and cook for another minute, or until the spinach wilts.\n5 Toast the pumpkin seeds while the quinoa cooks: In a small skillet over medium heat, add the pumpkin seeds and stir for 4 to 5 minutes, or until they begin to crackle and turn golden brown. Transfer to a plate to cool. (If you leave them in the hot pan, they may burn.)\n6 Finish and serve the quinoa: Fold the squash into the skillet. Sprinkle with the toasted pumpkin seeds, cheese, and cilantro, and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nButternut Squash Enchiladas Recipe\nPrep time: 45 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 6 servings\nIf want to cut down on some of the preparation time, buy grated cheese and pre-peeled and seeded squash, to be cut into 3/4-inch pieces (you will need 5 to 6 cups).\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the vegetables:\n1 (2-pound) butternut squash, seeds removed and cut into 3/4-inch pieces\n1 large onion, cut into 8 wedges\n2 cloves garlic\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper\nFor the sauce:\n1 (28-ounce) can whole tomatoes with juice\n1 tablespoon ancho chili powder, or regular chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon oregano\n1/2 teaspoon cumin\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 tablespoon olive oil\nFor the filling and assembly:\nAbout 1/4 cup olive oil, to brush on the tortillas\n1 (15-ounce) can black beans, rinsed and drained\n12 (7-inch) corn tortillas\n2 cups grated Monterey Jack cheese\nFor the garnishes (optional):\n1 handful cilantro leaves\n1 avocado, sliced\n6 radishes, thinly sliced\n1/4 red onion, sliced\n1/2 cup sour cream, thinned with milk to the consistency of thick cream\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xbaF.\n2 Roast the squash, onion, and garlic: On a large, rimmed baking sheet, mound the squash cubes in the center and place the onion wedges and garlic on the side.\nSprinkle everything with the olive oil, salt, and pepper. Toss to coat the vegetables and spread them evenly over the baking sheet, segregating the onion and garlic alongside the squash. Bake for 25 minutes, or until tender.\nRemove the pan from the oven, and reduce the oven temperature to 375\xc2\xbaF. Let the squash and onion cool slightly on the baking sheet.\n3 Make the sauce: In a blender, combine the tomatoes, chili powder, oregano, cumin, and salt. Add the garlic and half of the roasted onion slices. Puree until smooth.\nIn a medium skillet set over medium heat, add 1 tablespoon olive oil. Once the oil shimmers, add the pureed sauce to the pan and bring to a simmer. Cook, stirring often, for 5 minutes. Set aside.\n4 Make the filling: Transfer the squash and the remaining onion slices to a bowl. Separate the onion slices. Stir in the drained beans. Taste and add more salt, if you like.\n5 Warm the tortillas: Using a pastry brush, brush both sides of each tortilla with oil. Place up to 6 tortillas in a stack on a microwave-safe plate.\nLoosely cover and microwave in 30-second intervals until the tortillas are warm and pliable; this takes about 1 minute.\nWait to repeat the process with the remaining 6 tortillas until you\xe2\x80\x99ve filled the first batch.\n6 Assemble the enchiladas: Spread a thin layer of sauce over the bottom of a 9x13-inch baking dish.\nDip one tortilla in the sauce and set it on a plate. Place about 1/3 cup of the filling in a line down the center of the tortilla. Sprinkle with about 1 tablespoon of cheese.\nRoll up the tortilla to enclose the filling and set it in the baking dish with the seam side down.\nRepeat until all 12 of the tortillas are filled.
