Pour the remaining sauce over the enchiladas and sprinkle the remaining cheese on top.\n7 Bake the enchiladas: Bake for 25 minutes at 375\xc2\xbaF, or until the cheese melts and the enchiladas are hot all the way through. Serve with the garnishes of your choice.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nTex-Mex Shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s Pie Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 pounds (5 to 6 medium) Yukon Gold potatoes\n1 tablespoon salt, divided\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter, cut into slices\n1/2 cup milk, or more as needed\n1 1/2 cups grated sharp cheddar cheese\n1/8 teaspoon pepper\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 medium onion, finely chopped\n1 large garlic clove, finely chopped\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\n1 (15-ounce) can black beans, rinsed and drained\n1 cup frozen corn\n2 cups shredded, cooked chicken\n2 cups of your favorite salsa\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven: to 425\xc2\xbaF. Have on hand a 9- x 13-inch or 2-quart, shallow baking dish.\n2 Cook the potatoes: Wash and cut the potatoes into 1-inch chunks (peeling optional). Place them in a large pot. Fill the pot with cold water until there is about an inch of water above the potatoes.\nAdd 2 teaspoons salt and taste; the water should taste as briny as the sea. If it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t, add a few more pinches of salt.\nBring to a boil over high heat. Reduce the heat to a simmer and cook the potatoes, uncovered, for 15 to 20 minutes, or until tender when pierced with the tip of a paring knife.\nDrain in a colander and return to the potatoes to the pot. Set the pot over low heat and stir the potato chunks for 1 to 2 minutes to dry them.\n3 Mash and season the potatoes: Add the butter to the pot of hot, drained potatoes (still over low heat) and mash well with a potato masher until the butter melts. There may be a few \xe2\x80\x98rustic\xe2\x80\x99 lumps. Push the potatoes to one side of the pot to make a space for the milk. Add the milk and heat it until hot (this only takes a few seconds.)\nUse a sturdy whisk to stir in the milk, whisking until the potatoes are fluffy and adding more milk, 1 tablespoon at a time, if the potatoes seem dry. Stir in 1/2 cup of the cheese, 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/8 teaspoon pepper. Taste, and add more salt, if you like.\n4 Meanwhile, make the filling: In a large skillet over medium heat, heat the oil. Add the onions and garlic and cook for 5 minutes, or until softened. If the onions are cooking to fast reduce the heat to medium-low.\nAdd the oregano and cumin, and cook for 30 seconds. Add the beans, corn, chicken, and salsa to the skillet. Stir in 1/2 teaspoon salt. Taste and add more salt, if you like.\n5 Assemble the casserole: Transfer the filling to the baking dish. Spread the mashed potatoes over the top and sprinkle with the remaining 1 cup cheese.\n6 Bake the casserole: Bake for 25 to 30 minutes, or until the filling bubbles and the cheese is golden. Leftovers will keep in the fridge for up to 3 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBreakfast Quesadilla with Black Beans and Eggs Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n2 teaspoons butter\n1/4 cup chopped red onion\n6 large eggs, beaten in a bowl\n1/8 teaspoon salt, or to taste\nPinch black pepper\n1 (15-ounce) can black beans, rinsed and drained\n1 (4-ounce) can chopped mild green chiles, drained\n1/2 cup cilantro leaves\n6 (9-inch) flour tortillas\nPickled jalape\xc3\xb1o peppers from a jar (optional)\n1 1/2 cups grated sharp cheddar or Monterey jack cheese, or more, to taste\nVegetable oil, to reheat the quesadillas\nTo serve:\nSalsa\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Scramble the eggs: In a nonstick skillet over medium heat, melt the butter. Add the onion and cook, stirring, for 30 to 40 seconds (just to soften them). Add the eggs, salt, and pepper, and cook and stir until they are set to your preference. Remove the pan from the heat.\n2 Make the filling: Stir the beans, mild green chiles, and cilantro into the eggs in the pan.\n3 Assemble the quesadillas: On one-half of each tortilla, spread about 1/2 cup of the filling. Top with a few jalapeno slices (if using) and 1/4 cup cheese. Fold and press together to flatten them.\n4 Cook the quesadillas: Spray or brush a skillet with vegetable oil, then place the skillet over medium heat. Cook the quesadillas for 1 to 2 minutes on each side, or until the cheese melts and the tortillas are lightly browned and crisp on the outside.\nYou can either cook all of the quesadillas, cool them, cut them in half then freeze them. Or just cook what you want to eat right now, and freeze the rest, uncooked for later (this just saves you a little cooking and cooling time now).\n5 To serve: Enjoy with salsa, if you like.\nTO FREEZE: Line a baking sheet that will fit in your freezer with parchment paper or waxed paper. Spread as many assembled quesadillas as will fit on the baking sheet, top with a layer of paper, and add a second layer.\nCover loosely with plastic wrap, and freeze until firm, about 3 hours. Transfer the frozen quesadillas to plastic freezer bags, stacking them between small pieces of parchment or waxed paper. Store for up to 2 months.\nTO REHEAT: Remove as many quesadillas as you like from the freezer. Spread on a microwave-safe plate and microwave for 2 minutes to partially defrost them. At this point, the tortillas can be a little soggy, but that can be remedied. Just follow the "Cook the Quesadilla" instructions in step 4.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nEasy Avocado and Black Bean Quesadillas Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nQueso fresco doesn't exactly grate or shred easily when you use a box grater\xe2\x80\x94it kind of crumbles. I grated it, because it allowed me to achieve a more even distribution of cheese, but you could also crumble it with your fingers if you prefer.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the avocado mash:\n2 large or 3 small avocados\nJuice of 1/2 lime\nPinch of kosher salt\nFor the quesadillas:\n2 tablespoons olive oil, divided\n1 cup red onion, sliced into 1/4-inch half moons\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 1/2 teaspoons cumin\n1 1/2 teaspoons dried oregano\n3/4 teaspoon coriander\n1/2 yellow, red, or orange bell pepper, deseeded and chopped into 1/2-inch pieces\nJuice of 1/2 lime\n1 (15.5-ounce) can black beans, drained and rinsed\n4 8-inch flour tortillas\n1 cup queso fresco, crumbled or grated\n1 cup sharp cheddar cheese, grated\nTo serve:\nSour cream\nPico de gallo or salsa\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the avocado mash: In a small bowl, mash the avocado with a fork, and add a dash of kosher salt and the juice of half a lime. You want it to reach a consistency that feels close to guacamole\xe2\x80\x94a little chunky, but still spreadable. Set aside.\n2 Cook the veggies and beans: In a cast iron skillet or other large, heavy skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil over medium heat. Add the red onion and cook, stirring every minute or so, until the onion starts to soften, about 3 to 4 minutes. Add the salt, cumin, oregano, and coriander, stirring until the onions are completely coated.\nAdd the bell pepper and stir to combine. Cook for another 3 minutes, until the peppers just begin to soften. Add the lime juice and black beans and stir the whole mix together. Cook for about 2 minutes, just to warm the black beans through.\n3 Warm the tortillas: Heat the second tablespoon of olive oil in a separate skillet or grill pan over medium high heat. Add 1 flour tortilla and let it heat up for a minute or so. Using tongs, flip the tortilla over, and repeat the process for the other side, until you see a couple of bubbles welling up in the center of the tortilla.\n4 Assemble the quesadilla: Layer the filling, then the avocado, and then the cheese\xe2\x80\x94about 1/4 cup of each, but if you want more cheese than that I\xe2\x80\x99m not the cheese police, so go for it!\n5 Cook the quesadilla: Fold the tortilla over to seal the quesadilla. Cook for 2 to 3 minutes per side, until it\xe2\x80\x99s crispy, and the cheese has melted. Repeat the process for the other quesadillas, although if your skillet is large enough you can make two at a time in the same skillet.\n6 Serve the quesadillas: Cut the quesadillas into triangular portions and serve with sour cream, avocado, and/or the pico de gallo, if desired. Quesadillas are best served and eaten immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nInstant Pot Chicken Tortilla Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n2 cloves garlic, chopped\n1 medium yellow onion, diced\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n4 cups chicken broth\n1 (4-ounce) can fire-roasted diced green chilies\n1 (15-ounce) can black beans, rinsed and drained\n1 1/2 cups corn kernels (fresh or frozen)\n1 (14.5-ounce) can fire-roasted crushed tomatoes\n1 pound chicken tenders or thighs, boneless and skinless\nFor the corn tortilla strips:\n6 street taco-sized corn tortillas\n1 tablespoon avocado oil or olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nTo garnish:\n3/4 cup shredded Monterey Jack or Mexican blend cheese\n1 large avocado, sliced\n1/2 cup fresh chopped cilantro\n1 lime, cut into 6 wedges\nSpecial equipment:\nInstant Pot\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions and garlic: Select the \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d setting on your pressure cooker and heat the olive oil. Add the garlic, onion, and salt and saut\xc3\xa9 for about 3 minutes until the onion begins to soften.\n2 Add the remaining soup ingredients: Add the chicken broth, using a wooden spoon or spatula to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pot. Stir in the green chilies, black beans, corn, tomatoes, and chicken.\n3 Cook the soup: Cancel the \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d program to reset your pressure cooker. Place the lid on the pressure cooker. Make sure the pressure regulator is set to the \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d position. Select the \xe2\x80\x9cPressure Cook\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d setting and set the cooking time for 10 minutes at high pressure. (The pot will take about 15 minutes to come up to pressure before the cooking program begins.)\n4 While the soup cooks, make the tortilla strips: Preheat a toaster oven, air fryer, or oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Pour the oil into a bowl large enough to toss the tortilla strips. Cut the tortillas into 1/4-inch strips, then toss them in the bowl with the oil.\nBake or air fry the tortillas until they are golden and slightly browned around the edges, about 7-9 minutes. Right when you take the strips out of the toaster oven or air fryer, sprinkle them with the salt. Set aside to cool.\n5 Release and serve or keep warm: When the cooking program ends on the Instant Pot, let the pressure release naturally for at least 15 minutes. The pot will default to its \xe2\x80\x9cKeep Warm\xe2\x80\x9d setting. You can serve the soup right away or leave it for up to 10 hours.\n6 Shred the chicken: Once the pressure has released, open the pot. Use tongs to transfer the cooked chicken to a cutting board. Use a pair of forks to shred the chicken, then add it back to the soup and stir to combine. Taste for seasoning, adding more salt if you like.\n7 Serve the soup: Ladle the soup into bowls. Top each bowl with shredded cheese, sliced avocado, and cilantro. Serve with wedges of lime and tortillas alongside.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlack-Eyed Pea Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nYou can substitute canned black-eyed peas for the dry peas. Use approximately two 15-ounce cans. Rinse thoroughly. Skip step 1 and step 3 in the method instructions.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups dry black-eyed peas\nSalt\n1 package of feta cheese, about 7 ounces\n1 jar of sun-dried tomatoes in oil, about 8 ounces\n1 cup black olives, preferably Kalamata or oil-cured\n1 finely chopped green onion\n1 finely chopped garlic clove\n1 large bunch of spinach, about 1 pound, washed, chopped\nZest and juice of a lemon\nMETHOD\n1 Bring a medium pot of water to a boil. Add enough salt to make the water taste like the sea. Turn the heat down to low and add the black-eyed peas. Let them cook slowly, uncovered, until they are done, anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour, depending on how old the peas are. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let the water simmer.\n2 Add the spinach to a large bowl. Crumble the feta cheese into the bowl and add all the other ingredients except the lemon juice. Mix well.\n3 When the black-eyed peas are done, pour them into a colander and spray them with cold water to stop the cooking. Pick through and discard any loose skins or mashed peas; you\xe2\x80\x99ll find a few, but hopefully not many.\n4 Add the black-eyed peas to the salad, mix well and serve. Squirt some lemon juice over each serving before you take them to the table.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nBlack Eyed Pea Salsa with Cheese Quesadillas Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 6\nIf starting with dry beans, use 2 cups, put in a pot, cover with a couple inches of salted water, bring to a boil, reduce to a very low simmer, and cook uncovered until done, anywhere from 30 to 90 min. Rinse with cold water and drain.\nI used a combination of freshly roasted poblano chiles and pickled jalape\xc3\xb1os. This is because the poblanos I had were exceptionally mild and I wanted more heat, which I was able to get from the pickled jalape\xc3\xb1os. Use some combination of cooked green chiles, either canned or fresh. Taste for heat and adjust to your preference.\nINGREDIENTS\nBlack-eyed Pea Salsa\nAbout 3 1/4 to 4 cups cooked black-eyed peas (2 15.5-ounce cans, rinsed, drained)\n1/2 to 2/3 cups of chopped, cooked, mild green chiles (2 large poblanos or 3 Anaheims, roasted, seeded, and chopped) AND/OR 1/4 cup chopped pickled jalape\xc3\xb1os (to taste)\n1/2 to 2/3 cups of chopped roasted red bell pepper (can use jarred marinated or roast fresh red bell peppers by charring over a gas flame or under a broiler, placing in a covered bowl for a few minutes, wiping off the char, seeding, and chopping)\n6 to 8 green onions, thinly sliced including at least half of the greens, about 1/2 to 2/3 cup total\n1 bunch of cilantro, chopped, tender stems included (about a cup)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 tablespoons red wine vinegar\n1 teaspoon dried oregano, crumbled\nLarge pinch of ground cumin\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nQuesadillas\n1 dozen flour tortillas\n8 ounces Monterey jack cheese, sliced or grated\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nIf you haven't already done so, prep your ingredients. Char and peel your chiles and/or red bell peppers if using fresh not jarred or canned. Cook your black-eyed peas if not using canned.\n1 Assemble the salsa: Place the drained cooked black eyed peas in a large bowl. Add the chiles, red bell peppers, and most of the chopped onions and cilantro (reserving some for garnish).\nDrizzle with olive oil and red wine vinegar. Sprinkle with crumbled, dried oregano, cumin, salt, and pepper.\nToss and let marinate while you prepare the quesadillas.\n2 Make the quesadillas: Heat a large cast iron pan on medium high heat. If you are using something other than a well-seasoned cast iron pan, add a small amount of oil or butter to lightly coat the bottom of the pan. Add a flour tortilla to the pan. Let it heat up on one side for half a minute.\nFlip it over and place a light layer of cheese over the tortilla. If you are using grated cheese, you can just sprinkle it all over. If using sliced cheese, lay the slices down on only one side of the tortilla.\nWhen tortilla begins to form air pockets or the cheese begins to melt, use a spatula to lift up one edge of the tortilla and turn it over to the other edge, as if you were making an omelette.\nLet cook until lightly browned, and then flip the whole quesadilla over to the other side and let cook until lightly browned on that side. Remove from the pan and prepare the other quesadillas in the same manner.\n3 Cut the quesadillas into pie-shaped wedges and serve with the black-eyed pea salsa.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBlackberry Muffins Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes about 18 muffins\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 cups (320g) all purpose flour\n1 tablespoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon cinnamon\n2 large eggs\n1 cup (236ml) sour cream\n1 teaspoon milk or water\n1 cup (200 g) sugar\n8 tablespoons warm melted butter (1 stick, 112 g)\n1 teaspoon vanilla\n1 1/2 cups (about 5-6 oz, about 150g) of blackberries, fresh or frozen (if using fresh berries, cut them in half, if using frozen berries, defrost first, drain excess liquid, then coat them lightly in flour)\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven, prepare muffin pan: Position rack in center of oven. Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F (200\xc2\xb0C). Grease a standard 12 muffin pan or line with paper muffin cups. (Actually, with the berries you'll have more batter than just for 12 muffins. This batch made 18 muffins.)\n2 Combine dry ingredients: Whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon and salt in a large bowl.\n3 Combine wet ingredients and sugar: In a separate bowl, whisk together eggs, sour cream, milk, sugar, butter and vanilla.\n4 Add wet ingredients to dry, then add berries: Add the wet mixture to the dry mixture, and mix together with a few light strokes, just until the dry ingredients are moistened.\nAdd the berries. (If you are using frozen berries, defrost them first, then drain the excess liquid, then coat them lightly in flour.)\nDo not over-mix! Over-mixing will cause the muffins to be dense, not fluffy. The batter should not be smooth, but rather lumpy.\n5 Put into muffin cups and bake: Divide the batter evenly among the muffin cups. Bake at 400\xc2\xb0F (200\xc2\xb0C) until a toothpick inserted into the middle of 1 or 2 of the muffins comes out clean, 17-20 minutes (or longer).\n6: Let cool: Let cool for 2 to 3 minutes before removing from the pan. If not serving hot, let cool on a rack.\nServe as soon as possible, preferably within a few hours of baking.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nBlackberry Cobbler Recipe\nPrep time: 35 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes 9 servings\nYou can use fresh or frozen berries for this blackberry cobbler. If using frozen, defrost and drain first.\nMake sure you do a taste test to adjust sugar levels. Some berries are more tart than others and need more sugar for balance.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the berry mixture:\n4 cups blackberries, rinsed clean\n1/2 cup white granulated sugar (less or more to taste, depends on how sweet the berries are and how sweet you would like your cobbler to be)\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 1/2 tablespoons cornstarch (or instant tapioca)\nFor the cobbler topping:\n1 cup all purpose flour\n3 tablespoons sugar\n1 1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1/4 cup milk\n1 large egg, lightly beaten\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the berry mixture: Put the blackberries, sugar, lemon zest and juice, cinnamon and cornstarch in a 9x9 baking dish. Stir to combine everything and make sure that the berries are all evenly coated with sugar.\nLet sit for 30 minutes for the berries to macerate so that the sugar dissolves and the berries release their juices.\n2 Preheat your oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n3 Make biscuit dough topping: Vigorously whisk together the flour, 3 tablespoons of the sugar, baking powder, and salt in a medium bowl. Cut the butter into the flour mixture with your fingers or a fork until the topping mixture resembles coarse crumbs.\nMake a well in the center and stir in the milk and beaten egg until the dough is just moistened.\n4 Top the cobbler: Scoop up the dough in large spoonfuls, and drop over the berries in the baking dish like cobblestones.\n5 Bake: Bake for 30 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F, or until the berry mixture is bubbly and the topping is nicely browned.\n\n\nGreat served with whipped cream or vanilla ice cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBerry and Banana Terrine Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesChilling time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 envelopes (1/4 ounce each) unflavored gelatin\n2 cups white grape juice, divided\n1/2 cup white granulated sugar\n6 cups of mixed fresh berries and slices of banana (berries can include blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, and sliced or quartered strawberries)\nMETHOD\n1 Soften the gelatin: Put 1/4 cup of the white grape juice into a small bowl. Sprinkle the gelatin over the grape juice and let sit for 2 to 3 minutes while the gelatin softens.\n2 Make grape juice gelatin base: Put another 1/4 cup of the white grape juice and a 1/2 cup of sugar into a saucepan and heat on medium high heat until the sugar has dissolved.\nRemove from heat and stir in the gelatin mixture until it has dissolved. Stir in the remaining 1 1/2 cups of grape juice.\n3 Put fruit in loaf pan, cover with grape juice gelatin mixture: Put the berries and banana slices in a 4x8 loaf pan. Pour the grape juice mixture over the berries, and press down on the berries to submerge them into the juice/gelatin mixture.\n4 Chill: Cover with plastic wrap. Chill in the refrigerator until firm, 3 hours.\n5 Un-mold: To un-mold, fill a basin half-way with hot water. Carefully lower the bottom of the loaf pan into the hot water and hold for 5 to 8 seconds. This will melt the gelatin at the edge of the pan, helping it to release.\nRun a dull knife around the edge of the pan as well.\nPlace a serving platter topside down on top of the loaf pan and turn the whole thing over. Shake gently to release the mold.\nSlice to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBlackberry Slump Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nThis recipe uses blackberries, but you could easily use any berry you would like, such as blueberries, raspberries, or strawberries.\nINGREDIENTS\nDumplings:\n1 cup all purpose flour\n1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 Tbsp sugar\n2 Tbsp butter\n1/3 cup whole milk\nBerries:\n4 cups fresh or frozen (defrosted and drained) blackberries\n1/2 to 3/4 cup sugar (depending on how sweet your berries and how sweet you would like your slump to be)\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1/3 cup water\nWhipping cream or vanilla ice cream for topping\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dumplings: In a medium sized bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar.\nCut the butter into small cubes and add to the flour. Using a pastry cutter, two knives, or your clean hands, cut the butter into the flour until the flour resembles a coarse meal.\nAdd the milk all at once and stir until the flour is just moistened. Handling the dough as little as possible, form into a ball. Set aside.\n2 Heat berries with sugar, cinnamon, lemon, water until boiling: In a 2-qt saucepan, add the berries, sugar, cinnamon, lemon juice, lemon zest, and water. Heat until boiling, stirring a few times so that the berries are well coated with the sauce.\n3 Add chunks of dumpling dough: Once the berry mixture is boiling, tear off spoonful chunks from the dough ball and drop onto the fruit around the edges of the pot. You should have enough dough for 6 dumplings.\n4 Cover and simmer: Cover the pot and reduce the heat to a simmer. Cook for 25 minutes, without peeking at the dumplings.\nPlace dumplings in serving bowls and top with berries. Serve with cream or ice cream. Serve hot or chilled.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBerry Cobbler with Coconut Walnut Streusel Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\nFilling\n4 cups mixed berries (i.e. blackberries, raspberries, blueberries, boysenberries, strawberries), fresh or frozen\n1/4 cup plus 1 Tbsp sugar\n2 Tbsp instant tapioca\n1 Tbsp fresh lemon juice\nTopping\n1/2 cup flour\n1/2 cup shredded coconut\n1/4 cup sugar\n1/4 cup chopped walnuts\n1/4 teaspoon baking powder\nPinch of salt\n4 Tbsp (1/4 cup) cold, unsalted butter, cut into cubes\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. Butter a 9x9 inch baking dish.\n2 In a large bowl, mix together the filling ingredients - berries, sugar, tapioca, and lemon juice. Pour into the baking dish.\n3 In a medium sized bowl, stir together the flour, coconut, sugar, walnuts, baking powder and salt from the topping ingredients. Use your fingers to mix in the cubes of butter. Rub the butter into the other ingredients until the mixture looks like coarse crumbs.\n4 Sprinkle the topping over the filling. Bake for 35-40 minutes, until the topping is golden brown and crispy, and the filling is bubbling.\n5 Let cool for at least an hour. Serve with vanilla ice cream or whipped cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nBlackberry Shortcake Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\nBlackberries:\n2 to 2 1/2 pounds of blackberries (6 to 8 cups), gently rinsed if fresh, defrosted if frozen (save any juices that come from defrosting!)\n1/4 cup to 1/2 cup of sugar (to taste, depending on the tartness of the berries)\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon lemon zest\nBiscuits:\n3 cups flour\n3 Tbsp sugar\n4 teaspoons baking powder\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n8 Tbsp cold butter, cut into small cubes\n1 1/2 cups heavy cream\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nWhipped Cream:\n1 cup heavy whipping cream\n2 teaspoons powdered sugar\nA few drops of vanilla extract\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Macerate the berries with sugar: Put the blackberries into a large bowl, sprinkle with sugar, and toss to coat all the berries with sugar. Use a potato masher to gently mash about half of the berries, releasing their juices.\nStir in lemon juice and zest.\nLet sit for 20 minutes to an hour to macerate, allowing the sugar to help release more of the juices from the blackberries.\n2 Whisk flour, sugar, baking powder salt. Cut in butter: In a large bowl vigorously whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt. Add the chilled butter cubes and use your fingers (or a fork, pastry cutter, or food processor) to break up the butter and mix with the flour until the largest pieces of butter are the size of peas.\n3 Add cream and vanilla: Make a well in the center of the flour mixture and pour in the cream and vanilla. Use a fork to mix the flour and the cream until the dough just comes together.\nIt should have a rather shaggy appearance. Empty on to a clean surface and knead a few times to form a loose ball. Do not over mix or over-knead!\n4 Form into square shape and chill: Place ball on a small tray or baking sheet and form into an 8-inch by 8-inch square. Cover with plastic wrap and place in the refrigerator to chill for 15 to 20 minutes.\n5 Cut into squares, arrange on baking sheet: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Once the dough has chilled sufficiently, remove it from the refrigerator and cut it into 9 even squares. Arrange them on a baking sheet with an inch or two between each square.\n6 Bake: Bake at 425\xc2\xb0F until the biscuits are nicely browned, about 18 minutes.\n7 Make whipped cream: While the biscuits are baking place the heavy whipping cream into a large chilled bowl (I usually put a metal mixing bowl into the freezer for a few minutes if I know I'm going to be making whipped cream.)\nSprinkle with powdered sugar and a few drops of vanilla extract. Use a hand mixer to beat until you have peaks that somewhat hold their shape. Chill until ready to serve.\n8 Assemble shortcakes: When the biscuits are ready, remove them from the oven and let them cool for a few minutes. To serve, place one in a bowl or dessert plate, pull it apart in half.\nPlace a large scoop of berries and the juices from the berries over the bottom half. Top with the other half of the biscuit and a generous dollop of whipped cream.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBlackberry Frozen Yogurt Recipe\nYield: Makes a little more than a quart\nThe berries release a lot of water when cooked, which is why I add cream to the mix. The additional fat helps keep the frozen yogurt from getting too icy. The brandy will help the frozen yogurt from getting too icy too, but you can leave it out if you want.\nINGREDIENTS\n3-4 cups blackberries or boysenberries (fresh or frozen)\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 cup sugar\n2 cardamom pods, crushed\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n2 cups whole milk yogurt\n2 Tbsp heavy whipping cream\n2 Tbsp brandy (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Simmer blackberries, sugar, zest, spices: Place blackberries, lemon zest, cardamom, cinnamon, and sugar in a saucepan. Bring to a simmer, stirring to help break up the berries and release their juice. Simmer for 10 minutes, then remove from heat to cool for 15 minutes.\n2 Push berry mixture through sieve: Place a sieve over a bowl. Push the berries through the sieve to capture the concentrated syrup below. Use the back of a spoon or a rubber spatula to help press the berries against the side of the sieve. Discard the berries in the sieve, save the syrup.\n3 Stir in yogurt and cream, then chill: Stir the yogurt and cream into the berry syrup. Cover with plastic wrap and chill for several hours.\n4 Add brandy, process in ice cream maker: Right before processing in your ice cream maker, add the brandy if using. Process in your ice cream maker according to the maker's instructions. Then either eat while still rather soft, or scoop into a container and freeze for several hours until firm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nRhubarb Berry Pie Recipe\nYield: Makes 8 servings\nThe green leaves of rhubarb are poisonous, so when prepping rhubarb, make sure to discard any remnants of leaves.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups sliced rhubarb\n1/2 to 3/4 cup sugar (1/2 cup will yield a pie slightly on the tart side)\n3 Tbsp quick-cooking tapioca\n1 cup sliced strawberries\n1 1/2 cups blackberries, boysenberries, or mixed berries (if you use frozen berries, first defrost them and then drain them of excess moisture)\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla\nDash of ground mace or nutmeg\n1 pie dough recipe for top and bottom crust\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roll out one pie dough and line the bottom of a pie pan: Roll out one ball of pie dough on a lightly floured surface to 12-inch diameter. Line the bottom of a 9-inch pie pan with the dough. Chill in refrigerator while you prepare the fruit.\n2 Prepare the rhubarb berry filling: Stir sugar and quick cooking tapioca pearls together in a large bowl. Add the rhubarb, strawberries, and other berries. Add the lemon juice, vanilla, and mace or nutmeg. Stir gently to coat berries with the sugar. Let sit for 15 minutes, stirring once.\n3 Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Roll out second ball of pie dough. If you plan to do a lattice top, as pictured, prepare the dough strips as described in How to Make a Lattice Top for a Pie Crust.\n5 Scoop fruit mixture into dough-lined pie dish.\n6 Prepare the top crust: If you would like a lattice top, weave strips of pie dough over the top of the fruit-filled pie dish as described in How to Make a Lattice Top for a Pie Crust. (If you would like a solid top for your pie, place the second rolled-out pie dough crust on top of the pie.) Press ends of strips into the rim of the bottom crust.\nTrim the edges to 1/2-inch. Fold the edges back over themselves and crimp to seal.\nIf you are using a solid top crust, score the top to create air vents.\n7 Bake: To protect the crust edges from burning, cover the edges of the crust with aluminum foil or an aluminum pie protector. Bake at 375\xc2\xb0F in the middle rack for 25 minutes. Remove the foil.\nReturn to oven and bake for an additional 20-30 minutes, until the top is golden and the juices are bubbling. Cool completely before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nRicotta and Summer Berry Parfaits Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n4 ounces cream cheese, cut into chunks and softened to room temperature\n2 tablespoons honey\n2 teaspoons finely grated lemon zest\n2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice\n1 teaspoon vanilla\n1 1/2 cups (12 ounces) whole milk ricotta cheese\n3 tablespoons strawberry jam\n4 cups mixed fresh berries, such as blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, and sliced strawberries\n2 tablespoons chopped pistachios (for garnish)\nMint leaves (for garnish)\nMETHOD\n1 Make the ricotta cream: Combine the cream cheese, honey, lemon zest, 1 tablespoon of the lemon juice and vanilla in a mixing bowl, and beat with an electric mixer for 1 to 2 minutes on medium speed, until light and fluffy. Beat in the ricotta until smooth.\n2 Glaze the berries: Use a spatula to push the jam through a fine mesh strainer into a small mixing bowl; this will remove any tiny seeds in the jam. Add the remaining1 tablespoon of the lemon juice to the strained jam and mix until smooth. Add the berries and stir to coat them.\n3 Assemble the parfaits: Into four dessert glasses or bowls, layer 1 to 2 tablespoon of the berries and 2 to 3 tablespoons ricotta mixture. Repeat, ending with berries on top. Sprinkle with chopped pistachios, and garnish with mint leaves.\nThe fruit and ricotta can be layered into dishes and refrigerated for up to a day. Sprinkle with pistachios and mint until just before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBerry Almond Crumble Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 6\nRecipe by Melissa Clark of The New York Times.\nInstant tapioca is needed as a thickener. You can make this without it, but it will be quite runny. If you don't have instant tapioca, you can try substituting corn starch.\nINGREDIENTS\nFilling:\n8 cups mixed fresh berries: blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, strawberries\n1 Tbsp quick-cooking tapioca\n2 to 3 tablespoons granulated sugar, depending upon sweetness of berries\n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest\nCrumble Topping:\n1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour\n1/3 cup dark brown sugar\n1/3 cup granulated sugar\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger\nA pinch of salt\n1/2 cup melted butter\n1/2 cup finely chopped almonds.\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Mix berries with tapioca, sugar, zest: In a large bowl put berries and mix with tapioca, sugar and lemon zest. (Without tapioca, crumble will be very runny.) Set aside.\n3 Make the topping: Whisk together the flour, sugars, spices and salt in a large bowl. Stir in the melted butter and almonds until coarse crumbs form.\n4 Assemble: Pour the filling into a 9-inch square or round pan (do not grease first). Using your fingers, form topping mixture into 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch crumbs and spread over cake.\n5 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F until filling bubbles and topping is light golden, about 45-55 minutes.\nLet cool at least half an hour. Serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nApricot Berry Cobbler Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nINGREDIENTS\nCobbler Filling:\n5 cups pitted, quartered apricots (Blenheims if you can get a hold of some)\n3 cups blackberries (or boysenberries or blueberries)\n1 cup white granulated sugar\n2 Tbsp flour (for thickening)\nCobbler Topping:\n2 cups all purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 Tbsp white granulated sugar\n1/2 cup (1 stick or 4 ounces) butter softened plus 1/4 cup melted butter\n1 cup buttermilk\n1/2 teaspoon almond extract\n2 Tbsp brown sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toss the apricots with sugar and flour, place in baking dish: In medium bowl toss the apricots, berries, 1 cup white sugar, and 2 Tbsp flour together.\nPlace filling into baking dish (one 9x13x2 baking dish, or two smaller baking dishes).\n2 Whisk flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, sugar, then work in butter: Whisk together the 2 cups of flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, 1 Tbsp white sugar in a medium bowl.\nCut the butter into small cubes and toss into the flour mixture. Work the butter with your fingers to smear it and crumble it into the flour, until the mixture resembles a coarse cornmeal.\nTip: at this point, if you briefly heat the apricot berry mixture in the microwave or oven, until it is warm, it will help the biscuit topping to rise.\n3 Add almond extract and buttermilk: Add almond extract to the buttermilk, then form a well in the middle of the flour mixture and pour in the buttermilk.\nGently mix (with wooden spoon or your hands) until the dough just comes together. Do not over-mix.\n4 Form "cobblestone" shapes of the dough and arrange on the top of the apricot berry mixture. (You can also just crumble the dough over the top.) Sprinkle brown sugar over the top of the dough. Drizzle melted butter over the top (aim for the fruit more than the biscuits).\n5 Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Let the cobbler sit and rise for 10-20 minutes before baking.\n6 Bake: Bake at 425\xc2\xb0F for 10-15 minutes or until the top is just beginning to brown, then reduce the heat to 350\xc2\xb0F. Cook for an additional 30 to 40 more minutes, until the center fruit is thickened and bubbly.\nCheck during cooking, if the topping is getting too brown, cover it with foil and turn the heat down to 325\xc2\xb0F.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nLemon Mascarpone Blondies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes 9 blondies\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup (1 stick, 112 g) of butter, melted\n1 cup (220 g) of tightly packed dark brown sugar\n1 egg, lightly beaten\n1/4 teaspoon of vanilla\n8 ounces (225 g) of mascarpone cheese\n2 tablespoons of lemon juice\n2 1/2 teaspoons of lemon zest\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/8 teaspoon of baking soda\nPinch of salt\n1 cup (128 g) of all-purpose flour\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). Lightly butter and flour an 8X8 pan (20cmX20cm). Whisk together the melted butter and sugar in a bowl.\n2 Add the egg and vanilla extract and whisk.\n3 Add the lemon juice, zest, and mascarpone cheese and mix thoroughly.\n4 Add the flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt, mix it all together.\n5 Pour into the pan and spread evenly. Bake for 25-30 minutes or until a toothpick comes out clean. Allow to cool on a wire rack. Cut into squares and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. b'Save It Print\nChewy Almond Squares (Blondies) Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes 9 squares.\nTo make the decorative almond halves, take a whole raw almond and pinch it between your fingers. Use a serrated bread knife to carefully cut the almond in half. The almond has a natural break-point so it should split easily once you start to cut it.\nNo need for a mixer for this recipe, all you need is a whisk and a strong spoon.\nYou can easily double this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup butter (1 stick, 112 g), melted, plus butter for greasing the pan\n1 cup tightly packed light brown sugar\n1 egg, lightly beaten\n1 tablespoon of almond extract\n1 cup (128 g) all purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/8 teaspoon baking soda\nPinch of salt\n1/3 cup toasted, blanched almonds, chopped\nWhole almond halves for decoration\n  One 8x8-inch baking pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven, prep pan, toast almonds: Preheat your oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Grease an 8x8-inch baking pan with butter. Toast blanched almonds if you have not already done so, and when cool, roughly chop them.\n2 Mix wet ingredients: In a mixing bowl, whisk together the melted butter and brown sugar until there are no more lumps of brown sugar. Whisk in the beaten egg and almond extract.\n3 Whisk dry ingredients: In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and pinch of salt.\n4 Make batter: Add the dry mixture to the wet mixture and mix until smooth. Stir in the chopped almonds.\n5 Pour into baking pan, add almond halves: Pour into the prepared baking pan and smooth the surface. You can "cut" the surface with a knife to make it easier to see where you will want to make cuts once the squares are done. Place an almond half, cut side down, in the middle of each square.\n6 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 20 to 25 minutes or until a tester comes out clean. Cool completely before cutting into squares.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nChewy Tahini Blondies Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 16 blondies\nTo make these tahini blondies dairy-free, replace the butter with a 1/2 cup olive oil or vegetable oil, plus more for greasing the pan.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, melted and cooled, plus more for buttering the pan\n1 1/4 cups all-purpose flour\n3/4 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon ground cardamom (or more to taste if you really like this flavor)\n1/2 teaspoon fine sea salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n2 tablespoons lightly toasted black sesame seeds\n2 tablespoons lightly toasted white sesame seeds\n1 1/4 cups lightly packed light brown sugar\n2 large eggs\n1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract\n1/2 cup pure tahini paste\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven and prep the pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\nButter an 8-inch square baking pan, then line the pan with 2 criss-crossing strips of parchment paper, buttering between each layer and leaving a 2-inch overhang on all sides. Butter the top and sides of the parchment.\n2 Make the batter: In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, cardamom, salt, pepper, and the black and white sesame seeds.\nIn another medium bowl, whisk together the brown sugar, 1/2 cup melted butter, eggs, and vanilla until smooth. Fold the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until just incorporated, then fold in the tahini until smooth.\n3 Bake blondies: Pour the batter into the prepared pan and bake until golden on the outside and the center doesn\xe2\x80\x99t jiggle but is still soft, 25 to 30 minutes.\n4 Serve: Remove from the oven, cool in the pan, and cut into 16 equal squares.\nHello! b'Save It Print\nMoroccan Orange Dessert Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesMarinating time: 1 hourYield: Serves 2, and can be doubled\nWhile we used blood oranges here, any sweet orange will work. Orange flower water can be found at Whole Foods or at a Mediterranean market.\nINGREDIENTS\n3-4 oranges\n1/4 cup orange flower water\n1-2 Tbsp powdered sugar\n1-2 teaspoons cinnamon\nMETHOD\n1 Marinate orange slices in orange flower water: Slice the top and bottom off each orange. Slice off the rind and all the pith and then cut the orange into 1/4 inch rounds.\nSprinkle a little orange flower water in the bottom of a wide-bottomed glass or plastic container and lay the orange slices on top. If you need to do more than one layer of oranges to get them all in the container, sprinkle more orange flower water over each orange layer as you go.\nAdd any remaining orange flower water, cover the container and set aside at room temperature for 1 hour.\n2 Sprinkle with powdered sugar and cinnamon to serve: To serve, take the oranges out of the container and arrange on a plate. Add a little of the liquid from the container. Just as you serve, sprinkle some powdered sugar and cinnamon over the oranges.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. b'Print\nFestive Beet Citrus Salad with Kale and Pistachios Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesMarinating time: 1 hourYield: Serves 8 to 10\nSave time by prepping the ingredients while the beets are cooking.\nBecause the kale resists wilting, this salad holds up remarkably well, several days in the fridge.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 - 10 large beets (about 4 to 5 pounds), a mix of red, pink, and golden\n2 - 3 blood oranges (or cara cara or navel oranges or a mixture)\n1 bunch of kale (lacinato or dinosaur kale if available), center ribs removed, leaves thinly sliced\n1 cup roasted pistachios, roughly chopped\n1/4 cup chopped fresh mint leaves\n3 Tbsp chopped Italian parsley\nDressing:\n2 Tbsp lemon juice\n1/2 cup good quality extra virgin olive oil\n6 Tbsp seasoned rice vinegar (or unseasoned rice vinegar plus 2 teaspoons of sugar)\nZest of one orange\nZest of one lemon\n2 Tbsp capers, coarsely chopped\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nFreshly ground black pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the beets: Scrub the beets clean, leaving the skin on. You can boil or roast the beets to cook them.\nIf boiling, boil the beets separately by color (otherwise the red beets will run into the the orange, turning the orange beets red). Place each batch of beets in a pot and cover with water by about an inch. Add a couple teaspoons of salt. Bring to a boil and reduce to a simmer. Simmer until you can just pierce easily with a fork, 30 to 60 minutes, depending on the size of the beets. Drain. Let cool. Rub the skins off.\nTo roast the beets, wrap them in foil and roast them in a 400\xc2\xb0F oven for 1 to 1 1/2 hours, until fork tender. Then cool and peel. See our roasted beets recipe.\n2  While the beets are cooking, prepare the dressing and prep the rest of the ingredients. Place all of the dressing ingredients into a jar, cover and shake until well blended.\n3 Marinate beets in dressing: Cut the beets into 1/2-inch to 1-inch pieces. Separate by color and place in separate bowls and toss with a little of the dressing (use about a third of the dressing). Chill for an hour or up to two days.\n4 Sprinkle sliced kale with some dressing: 15 minutes to an hour or two before serving, place the thinly sliced kale in a serving bowl. Sprinkle half of the remaining dressing over the sliced kale and toss to lightly coat the leaves.\n5 Serve: Either create a composed salad by placing the beets, citrus, mint, parsley, over the kale, sprinkling with the chopped roasted pistachios, and drizzling with the remaining dressing, OR toss everything together, sprinkling with with pistachios at the end.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBlood Orange French 75 Cocktail Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: Makes one cocktail\nTo make a twist of zest, use a vegetable peeler to peel a long strip of zest from the blood orange. Cut it into thin strips with a sharp knife. Twist it into a curly shape and hold it that way for a few seconds.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 tablespoons (3/4 ounce) freshly juiced blood orange juice, strained\n1/2 tablespoon (1/4 ounce) lime juice\n1 1/2 tablespoons (3/4 ounce) simple syrup*\n1 1/2 ounces (3 tablespoons) gin\n1/4 cup (2 ounces) champagne, prosecco, or other sparkling white wine\nA twist of blood orange zest\n*To make simple syrup, put equal parts of sugar and water into a small saucepan. (I usually make syrup with 1 cup sugar and 1 cup water, and store the excess for other uses.) Bring to a rolling boil. If you have a few strips of blood orange zest, add them to the water for extra flavor. When the sugar has all dissolved in the water, remove from heat and let cool. Remove the zest. Pour into a mason jar and store in the fridge.\nMETHOD\n1 Place the blood orange juice, lime juice, simple syrup, and gin into a cocktail shaker (or something that can be used as a cocktail shaker) with a few ice cubes.\n2 Shake to mix well and strain, pouring into a champagne flute.\n3 Top with champagne, Prosecco, or sparkling white wine.\n4 Add a twist of blood orange zest to the glass.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nAir Fryer Crispy Cauliflower Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: Serves 6\nTo cook without an air fryer: Preheat the oven to 350\xcb\x9aF. Spread the cauliflower florets out on a baking sheet and bake for 20-30 minutes, or until cauliflower is crisp. Rotate the cauliflower once during baking so they cook evenly.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the blue cheese dip:\n1/4 cup Greek yogurt\n1/4 cup mayonnaise\n1/4 cup crumbled blue cheese\nPinch of ground black pepper\nDash of hot sauce\nFor the crispy cauliflower:\n1 head cauliflower\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon garlic powder\n2 large eggs + 1/4 cup water\n1 cup breadcrumbs\nNonstick spray, for air fryer\nSpecial equipment:\nAir Fryer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the blue cheese dip: Stir together ingredients in a medium bowl. Keep in fridge until needed.\n2 Prepare the cauliflower: Cut the cauliflower into florets. It\xe2\x80\x99s okay to have a few different sizes, but try to make sure there are no florets bigger than about 1 1/2 inches.\n3 Bread the cauliflower: In a medium bowl toss florets with salt, chili powder, and garlic powder. In a separate small bowl, add eggs and water and whisk together. Add the egg mixture to the bowl with the cauliflower and toss to coat. Once the cauliflower is coated with the egg mixture, toss with breadcrumbs and coat well.\n3 Air-fry the cauliflower: Spray the basket of an air fryer with nonstick spray and place as many cauliflower florets in the basket as will fit in a single layer. Return the basket to the fryer and cook at 350\xcb\x9aF for 7 minutes. Then flip the florets and fry for another 7 minutes.\nRepeat until all cauliflower is done.\n4 Serve! Serve cauliflower immediately once all batches are done, or serve on a rolling basis as the batches come out of the fryer. Cauliflower is best right out of the fryer! Serve with the blue cheese dip as an appetizer or side dish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nEndive Salad with Walnuts, Pears, and Gorgonzola Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 2 to 3\nThis recipe is presented as a salad, but you could also chop the pears and walnuts more finely, and place with some crumbled blue cheese in the endive leaves, like filling little boats, for appetizers.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 endive heads, sliced first lengthwise, then crosswise in 1/2-inch slices\n2 tablespoons chopped walnuts\n2 tablespoons crumbled gorgonzola or other blue cheese\n1 Bartlett pear, cored and chopped\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 teaspoons cider vinegar (balsamic is good too)\nSprinkle of kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Place the chopped endive in a large bowl. Add the walnuts, crumbled gorgonzola, and chopped pears. Toss to combine.\n2 Drizzle olive over the salad. Drizzle cider vinegar over the salad.
