I do not recommend using boxed or canned veggie stock for this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\n12-14 ounces day-old rustic bread, cut into 1-inch cubes\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt\n1 tablespoon butter\n2 cups thinly sliced onions (sliced vertically, from tip to root)\n1 tablespoon minced garlic\n6 to 8 ounces cremini or button mushrooms, sliced 1/4-inch thick\n10 to 12 ounces fresh chard, rinsed\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1 1/2 teaspoons minced fresh thyme (or 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme)\n1/2 cup hearty red wine\n1 tablespoon honey\n2 quarts stock (chicken, beef, or vegetable, use vegetable stock for vegetarian option)\n1 cup grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the cubed bread in the oven: Pre-heat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Toss the cubed bread with a tablespoon of olive oil, sprinkle with a little salt. Arrange bread on a baking sheet and toast for 20-30 minutes (check timing!) or until nicely browned.\n2 Gently cook the sliced onions, add the garlic: While the cubed bread is in the oven, prepare the onions. Heat 2 tablespoons olive oil and the butter on medium heat in a 5 to 7 quart Dutch oven. Add the onions and stir to coat with the butter and oil. Cook gently, stirring occasionally for 10 to 15 minutes.\nIf the onions begin to dry out at all, lower the heat. They should begin to caramelize and lightly brown.\nAdd the garlic, cook for a minute more, remove from heat.\n3 Dry saut\xc3\xa9 the mushrooms: While the onions are browning, heat a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the sliced mushrooms. "Dry" saut\xc3\xa9 them (saut\xc3\xa9 without any added fat) until they release their moisture and are lightly browned.\n4 Prep the chard: Cut away the tough central stems of the the chard leaves. Cut across the leaves into 1-inch wide strips.\n5 Layer Dutch oven with onions, chard, mushrooms, bread, spices: Remove half of the browned onions from the Dutch oven and set aside. Spread the remaining onions evenly over the bottom of the pot.\nLayer over with half of the chard and half of the browned mushrooms. Sprinkle with pepper, half a teaspoon of salt, and thyme.\nPut down a layer of toasted bread cubes. Add the remaining onions, chard, and mushrooms. Layer on top the remaining bread cubes.\n6 Add honey wine mixture: Mix together the honey and wine, until the honey is dissolved. Pour over the bread mixture. Pour the broth over everything.\n7 Scatter the top evenly with the grated cheese.\n8 Bake in oven: Cover the pot with foil (not the lid) and seal it around the edges. Cut 4 or 5 vent holes in the top. Put it in a 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) oven. Bake for 1 hour 15 minutes. Serve immediately, digging into the layers to get a bit of everything for each portion, or let cool and refrigerate, covered.\nTo reheat, gently simmer a portion until hot. Plate and garnish with additional cheese and thyme.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBlueberry Maple Breakfast Bake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes 9 servings\nCan be prepared the night before, and baked before serving.\nRecipe barely adapted from US Highbush Blueberry Council.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 loaf of rustic white bread, crusts removed, bread cut into 1-inch cubes (about 10 cups)\n4 oz cream cheese, cut into small cubes (about 1 cup)\n2 cups fresh or frozen blueberries, divided (if using frozen berries, defrost and drain them first)\n8 eggs, beaten\n1 1/2 cups milk\n1/4 cup melted butter\n1/4 cup maple syrup plus more for serving\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven, prep baking dish: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Grease an 8 or 9-inch square baking dish.\n2 Layer cubed bread, cream cheese, and blueberries in baking dish: Place half of the bread cubes in the dish. Sprinkle cream cheese cubes and half of the blueberries over the bread. Top with remaining bread cubes and blueberries.\n3 Combine eggs, milk, maple syrup, and melted butter in a large bowl and pour over bread mixture.\nTo make ahead, cover and chill overnight, and proceed the next morning to bake.\n3 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F until a knife inserted in the center comes out clean, about 1 hour to 1 hr 20 min. Cover with aluminum foil if you notice the edges browning too much during baking.\n4 Serve: Let stand for 10 minutes before serving. Cut into squares to serve. Serve with additional maple syrup.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nPeach Melba French Toast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 12\nYou can use frozen or fresh peaches in this baked French toast. If using fresh peaches, peel them first. If using frozen, thaw them first and check the size. Most frozen peaches are cut thick. If they look to be an inch thick or more, just slice them in half lengthwise.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large loaf brioche, challah, or crusty bread (about 21 ounces)\n2 tablespoons butter, softened\n8 ounces fresh or frozen peaches, peeled and sliced 1/2 inch thick\n6 ounces fresh or frozen raspberries\n8 large eggs\n2 1/3 cups heavy whipping cream\n3/4 cup sugar\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract\nFor the topping:\n2 tablespoons sugar\n1/2 cup sliced almonds (optional)\nFor the raspberry sauce:\n10 ounces fresh or frozen raspberries\n1/4 cup sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/8 teaspoon salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Prepare the baking dish: Generously spread 2 tablespoons of butter on the bottom and sides of a 9x13 baking dish.\n3 Prepare the bread and fruit: Cut or tear the bread into 2x2-inch pieces. Place an even layer of bread on the bottom of the prepared baking dish. Dot the top of the bread with 2/3 of the raspberries, and layer all of the peach slices around the raspberries. Top with another layer of bread pieces. Tuck the remaining berries into cracks and crevices on the top of the dish.\n4 Make the custard: In a large bowl, aggressively whisk together the eggs so they are one homogeneous color (about 30 seconds). Add the heavy cream, sugar, extract, and salt. Whisk aggressively together for about a minute.\nPour the custard over the bread and fruit mixture. Gently smoosh the bread down into the custard so everything is moistened.\n5 Finish the casserole prep: Sprinkle the top evenly with 2 tablespoons sugar and sliced almonds.\nAt this point, the casserole can be baked right away, or covered and refrigerated overnight and baked in the morning. Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F when ready to bake.\n6 Bake: Bake the casserole for 50 minutes. The bread will puff up and the top should be golden with toasty bits.\n7 While the casserole is baking, make the raspberry sauce: Set a fine mesh strainer over a bowl and set aside.\nSet a small sauce pan over medium heat. Add frozen raspberries, sugar, vanilla, and salt. Stir occasionally while mashing the berries down with the back of a spatula, allowing the berries to release their juices while gently simmering. You don\xe2\x80\x99t want this to boil or aggressively simmer, because it would reduce the sauce too much. This should only take about 5-7 minutes.\nOnce the berries have released their juices, pour the sauce through the fine mesh sieve, pressing down to release as much of the sauce as you can. Discard the solids.\n8 Serve: Remove the French toast casserole from the oven and let rest for 10 minutes. Cut into pieces, and transfer to a plate. Drizzle each piece with raspberry sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSlow Cooker Banana Bread Pudding Recipe\nPrep time: 40 minutesCook time: 3 hoursSoaking Time time: 1 hourYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the bread pudding:\n16-ounce French brioche loaf, cut into 3/4-inch cubes  (12 cups)\n1 tablespoon unsalted butter (softened)\n8 large eggs\n4 cups half-and-half\n1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar\n1/2 cup (100g) dark brown sugar, packed\n1 tablespoon pure vanilla extract (bourbon vanilla recommended)\n1 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n3 medium ripe bananas, mashed\nFor the caramel sauce (Makes about 1 cup)\n1 cup (200 g) sugar\n1/4 cup water\n1/4 cup heavy cream\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1/8 teaspoon salt\nSpecial equipment:\nCandy thermometer\n6-Quart Slow Cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Get ready: Set the oven rack to the center position and preheat the oven to 300\xc2\xbaF for toasting the bread. Grease the inside of a 6-quart slow cooker with the softened butter.\n2 Toast the bread: Spread the bread cubes in a single layer on a large sheet pan or two smaller pans. Bake for 20 minutes, stirring halfway through toasting. The bread should be lightly golden, dry, and crisp. Remove the bread cubes from the oven and let them cool for 10 minutes.\nOnce cool, transfer toasted bread to the slow cooker and arrange in an even layer.\n3 Make the custard: In a medium bowl, whisk the eggs. Add the half-and-half, granulated sugar, brown sugar, vanilla extract, cinnamon, nutmeg, salt, and mashed bananas to the bowl with the eggs, and whisk to combine.\n4 Add the custard to the bread cubes: Pour the custard mixture over bread. Press the bread into the liquid to submerge. Cover and transfer to the refrigerator for at least 60 minutes, or up to 24 hours.\n5 Bring the casserole to room temperature: Remove the casserole from the refrigerator and let it sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.\n6 Cook casserole: Place the slow cooker insert into the slow cooker base, cover it with a lid, and cook it on the high setting for 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 hours, or on the low setting for 4 to 5 hours.\nThe casserole is ready when the custard is set in the center and puffy; it should not be runny or jiggle. It will shrink slightly once the heat is turned off. The center of the casserole should be above 175\xc2\xbaF when tested with a thermometer.\n7 Make the caramel sauce: In a medium high-sided saucepan add the sugar and water. Set the pan over medium-low heat and let the sugar dissolve without stirring. This should take about 3 to 5 minutes.\nWhen it\xe2\x80\x99s ready, the granules will be dissolved, and it will look just like gently bubbling clear water. (If you see sugar granules on the sides of the pan. Dip a pastry brush into a cup of tap water, and \xe2\x80\x9cpaint\xe2\x80\x9d the inside of the pan with the wet brush to wash away any undissolved sugar.)\nOnce the sugar has dissolved completely, increase the heat to high and bring sugar to a low boil. Stir with a whisk until a deep amber color is formed and the temperature reads between 320\xc2\xbaF to 340\xc2\xbaF on a candy thermometer. This should take about 5 to 7 minutes. If your sugar boils rapidly, reduce the heat to medium high.\nRemove the caramel from the heat.\nSlowly and carefully whisk in 1/3 of the heavy cream in a thin stream. The caramel will bubble as the cream is added; allow it to subside before adding the rest of the cream. Whisk in the butter, cinnamon, and salt until smooth.\nLet the sauce cool at room temperature for about 10 minutes before using, it will thicken as it cools, but still be pourable. (You can store the sauce in an airtight container for up to one week in the refrigerator.)\n8 To serve: Allow the casserole to rest for at least 15 minutes before serving. Serve warm with a scoop of vanilla ice cream, caramel sauce, and a sprinkle of cinnamon.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nHow to Make Eggs Benedict Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 4 one-egg one-muffin servings\nEggs benedict is also great made with slices of smoked salmon in place of the bacon. If you are in or around New Jersey, try it with Taylor ham.\nINGREDIENTS\n8 pieces of bacon or 4 pieces of Canadian bacon\n2 tablespoons chopped parsley, for garnish\n4 eggs\n2 teaspoons white or rice vinegar\n2 English muffins\nButter\nBlender Hollandaise\n10 tablespoons unsalted butter (if using salted butter, omit the added salt)\n3 egg yolks\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nDash of cayenne or tabasco\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the bacon: Heat a large skillet on medium low heat. Add the strips of bacon or the slices of Canadian bacon. Slowly fry, turning occasionally, until the bacon is browned on both sides, and if using strip bacon, much of the fat is rendered out (about 10 minutes).\nUse tongs or a fork to remove the bacon from the pan, set on a paper towel to absorb the excess fat.\nDon't pour the bacon fat left in the pan down the drain! Either sop it up with paper towels when it has cooled a bit, or pour it into a jar to be used later (see rendering bacon fat).\n2 Bring poaching water to a simmer: While the bacon is cooking, bring a large saucepan two-thirds-filled with water to a boil, then add the vinegar. Bring the water to a boil again, then lower the heat to a bare simmer.\n3 Make Hollandaise sauce in blender: To make blender hollandaise, melt 10 Tbsp unsalted butter.\nPut 3 egg yolks, a tablespoon of lemon juice, 1/2 teaspoon salt in a blender, blend on medium to medium high speed for 20-30 seconds, until eggs lighten in color.\nTurn blender down to lowest setting, slowly dribble in the hot melted butter, while continuing to blend. Taste for salt and acidity and add more salt or lemon juice to taste.\nTransfer it to a container you can use for pouring and set it on a warm\xe2\x80\x94but not hot\xe2\x80\x94place on or near the stovetop.\n4 Poach the eggs: Here is an easy method for poaching eggs. Essentially, working one egg at a time you crack an egg into a small bowl and slip it into the barely simmering water. Once it begins to solidify, you can slip in another egg, until you have all four cooking.\nTurn off the heat, cover the pan, and let sit for 4 minutes. (Remember which egg went in first, you'll want to take it out first.) When it comes time to remove the eggs, gently lift out with a slotted spoon.\nNote that the timing is a little variable on the eggs, depending on the size of your pan, how much water, how many eggs, and how runny you like them. You might have to experiment a little with your set-up to figure out what you need to do to get the eggs exactly the way you like them.\n5 Toast English muffins: As soon as all the eggs are in the poaching water, begin toasting your English muffins. If you can\xe2\x80\x99t get all the muffins toasted by the time the eggs are ready, gently remove the eggs from the poaching water and set in a bowl.\n6 Assemble your Eggs Benedict: To assemble, butter one side of an English muffin. Top with two slices of bacon or 1 slice of Canadian bacon. You can trim the bacon to fit the muffin if you\xe2\x80\x99d like.\nPut a poached egg on top of the bacon, then pour some hollandaise over. Sprinkle some parsley over it all and serve at once.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nEasy Poached Eggs\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 4 minutesYield: 1 or more poached eggs\nFresh eggs work best for poaching. Their whites hold together better than older eggs. Some people put a little vinegar in the poaching water\xe2\x80\x94the vinegar helps the proteins in the egg whites coagulate. But the vinegar does affect the taste. I usually skip it.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 or more fresh eggs\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the water: Fill a saucepan with several inches of water. Heat the water on high until it reaches a boil and then lower the heat until the water is at a bare simmer (just a few bubbles coming up now and then).\n2 Crack egg into a small bowl and gently slip it into the water: Working with the eggs one at a time, crack the egg into a small bowl or cup. Place the bowl close to the surface of the hot water and gently slip the egg into the water.\nIf you want, use a spoon to push some of the egg whites closer to their yolks, to help them hold together. Add all of the eggs you are poaching to the pan in the same way, keeping some distance between them.\n3 Turn off heat, cover pan, set timer for 4 minutes: Turn off the heat and cover the pan. Set a timer for 4 minutes (or count out loud to 60, four times). At this point the egg whites should be completely cooked, while the egg yolks are still runny.\nNote that the timing depends on the size of the eggs, the number of eggs in the pot, and if you are cooking at altitude, so adjust accordingly. If you are at altitude, want firmer egg yolks, or are poaching more than 4 eggs at once, you may need to cook them longer. If you try 4 minutes and the eggs are too cooked, reduce the time.\n4 Remove eggs with slotted spoon: Gently lift the poached eggs out of the pan with a slotted spoon and place on a plate to serve.\nUSING A FINE MESH SIEVE\nOne way to help your poached egg whites stay together is to remove some of the thin wispy egg whites before you add your eggs to the hot water. An easy way to do this is with a fine mesh sieve.\n1 Strain thin whites with a fine mesh sieve: Place the raw egg into a fine mesh sieve over a bowl. The very thin egg whites will drain out through the sieve.\n2 Gently add to hot water: Then gently ease the raw egg into your pot of simmering hot water.\n3 Turn off heat, cover pot, cook 4 minutes: Notice how there is much less stray egg whites with this method? Turn off the heat and cover the pot (or just lower the heat to low), and cook for 4 minutes until the whites are cooked through. (You may need to add more time if cooking at altitude or poaching more than 4 eggs at once.)\nRemove from the pot with a slotted spoon.\nUSING AN EGG POACHER\nIf you don\'t want to futz around with trying to keep the eggs from spreading or bumping into each other, the easiest way to make poached eggs is with an egg poacher.\nThe "poacher" is actually coddling the eggs, not truly poaching them, but if what you want is an egg with a cooked white and runny yolk, this is an easy way to do it.\nTo use an egg poaching pan, remove the cups from the pan that you intend to use.\nFill the pan with only 1/2-inch of water and bring it to a low boil. Put a drop or so of olive oil in each of the egg cups you are using and spread around. (The cups are stick-free, but the oil helps.)\nCrack the eggs into the egg cups, one egg per cup. Place the egg filled cup back in the slot for it in the pan.\nCover the pan and cook for 4 minutes.\nRemove from heat and carefully lift the egg cups out of the pan. Slide the cooked eggs out of the cups onto serving plates or bowls.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSausage Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 6 to 8\nBread that is a little bit dry will hold up better in the casserole and provide more structure, which is why breakfast casseroles tend to call for "day old" bread. If your bread is fresh or soft, after you cube it, spread it out on a sheet pan and put it in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 to 12 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Italian pork sausage\n10 large eggs, beaten\n4 cups whole milk\n1 teaspoon dry mustard\n1/4 teaspoon onion powder\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\nFresh ground pepper to taste\n5 cups cubed day old bread (we recommend rustic French or Italian loaf), cut into 3/4-inch to 1 inch-wide cubes\n2 cups shredded sharp cheddar cheese\n1/2 cup sliced mushrooms (optional)\n1/2 cup peeled, cored, chopped tomatoes (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the sausage: Heat a skillet on medium. Break up the sausage into chunks and cook, working in batches if need be, until cooked on all sides. As you cook the sausage, you can break up the larger chunks into smaller crumbles (which are easier to distribute evenly over the casserole).\nWhen lightly browned, remove from pan to a paper towel lined plate to absorb any excess fat.\n2 In a large bowl whisk together the eggs, milk, dry mustard, onion powder, salt and pepper.\n3 Assemble the casserole: Place the cubed bread in a well-buttered 9x13 inch baking pan. Sprinkle with cheese. Sprinkle with chopped tomatoes and mushrooms, if using. Top with the browned crumbled sausage, distributing it evenly. Pour the egg milk mixture evenly over the bread and cheese.\n4 Cover and chill, if making ahead: At this point, the casserole can be covered and chilled in the fridge until ready to bake and serve, up to overnight.\nIf baking immediately, let the casserole sit for 10 minutes before putting in the oven (to give the bread a chance to absorb the milk-egg mixture.\n5 Bake the casserole: When ready to cook, preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. Bake uncovered for about one hour. Tent with foil if the top begins to brown too quickly.\n6 Serve: Let the casserole cool for about 10 minutes before serving. Leftovers will keep in the refrigerator for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nEasy Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8\nThe ingredient proportions are estimates. The more eggs, the firmer and less likely to deflate the casserole will be.\nMushrooms tend to hold a lot of moisture, so if you use a lot of them, you may want to saut\xc3\xa9 them first to release some of their water.\nDon't have day-old bread? Put slices of fresh bread into a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the breakfast casserole base:\n6 to 10 large eggs\n2 to 3 cups grated cheddar cheese\n6 slices day-old bread, cut into 3/4-inch to 1-inch-wide cubes\n2 cups milk\nSalt\nPepper\nFor the possible additions: \n1 cup corn (cooked or frozen)\n1/2 cup chopped broccoli (cooked or raw, raw will turn out crunchier)\n1/2 cup sliced mushrooms\n1/4 cup sliced green onions\n1 cup cubed ham and/or cooked Italian sausage\nA few slices cooked bacon, chopped\n1 teaspoon Herbes de Provence, or other dried herbs, (or 1 tablespoon of fresh chopped herbs such as basil, rosemary, or thyme)\n1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon of cumin or curry powder\nSpecial equipment:\n9x13 inch casserole dish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Beat eggs, add milk and cheese: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Beat the eggs in a large bowl. Mix in the milk and cheese.\n2 Add the bread and carefully stir until all pieces of bread are moistened (don't over mix or the bread may disintegrate).\n3 Add the additions: Add salt and pepper to taste (if using Italian sausage, you won't need either.) If you have a lot of additions, you might need a couple more eggs to make sure that everything is at least touching some egg mixture. Just whisk in 2 tablespoons of milk for every beaten egg you add.\n4 Bake: Butter a 9x13-inch casserole dish. Pour the mixture into the casserole dish.\nBake in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for 50 minutes to an hour, until the top is browned and the center springs back when touched.\nRemove from oven and let cool for 10 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nHuevos Rancheros Recipe\nCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 2-4 servings\nThe recipe is flexible, sometimes we use canned salsa and just add a few more chopped tomatoes and some chopped pickled jalape\xc3\xb1os to make the sauce.\nSometimes if we have some leftover refried beans, we'll spread some on the tortillas before topping them with the eggs and salsa. My mother has been known to add a pinch of sugar to the salsa sauce if she feels it's too acidic for her taste.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 medium onion, chopped (about a half cup)\n1 15-ounce can whole or crushed tomatoes, preferably fire-roasted, (or 1 -2 large fresh vine-ripened tomatoes, when in season)\n1/2 6-ounce can diced green Anaheim chiles\nChipotle chili powder, adobo sauce, or ground cumin to taste (optional)\n4 corn tortillas\nButter\n4 fresh eggs\n2 tablespoons fresh cilantro, chopped (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the sauce: Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions in a little olive oil in a large skillet on medium heat. Once the onions are translucent, add the tomatoes and their juices. If using whole canned tomatoes, break them up with your fingers or a spatula as you put them in the pan.\nIf you are using fresh tomatoes, chop them first, then add. Note that fresh tomatoes will take longer to cook as canned tomatoes are already cooked to begin with.\nAdd chopped green chilies. Add additional chili to taste, either chipotle chili powder, adobo sauce, regular chili powder, or even ground cumin.\nBring to a simmer, reduce heat to low, and let simmer while you do the rest of the cooking, stirring occasionally. Reduce to warm after it has been simmering for 10 minutes. Add salt to taste if needed.\n2 Warm the plates: Heat the oven to a warm 150\xc2\xb0F, place serving plates in the oven to keep warm.\n3 Prepare the tortillas: Heat a teaspoon of olive oil in a large non-stick skillet on medium high, coating the pan with the oil.\nOne by one (or more if your pan is big enough) heat the tortillas in the pan, a minute or two on each side, until they are heated through, softened, and pockets of air bubble up inside of them.\nThen remove them and stack them on one of the warming plates in the oven to keep warm while you continue cooking the rest of the tortillas and the eggs.\n4 Fry the eggs: Using the same skillet as was used for the tortillas, add a little butter to the pan, about two teaspoons for 4 eggs. Heat the pan on medium high heat. Crack 4 eggs into the skillet and cook for 3 to 4 minutes for runny yolks, more for firmer eggs.\n5 Assemble and serve: To serve, spoon a little of the sauce onto a warmed plate. Top with a tortilla, then a fried egg. Top with more sauce, sprinkle with cilantro if desired.\nServe either one or two eggs/tortillas per plate, depending on how much you want to eat. I'm a 2-egg 2 tortilla person myself.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nChorizo and Eggs Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 2 to 3\nINGREDIENTS\nExtra virgin olive oil or bacon fat\n1/3 cup chopped onions (green, red, or yellow onions) optional\n1/4 pound of Mexican chorizo sausage, removed from sausage casing\n3 tablespoons raisins - soaked in hot water for 10 minutes and drained\n5 to 6 eggs\nSalt\nTortillas - optional\nCilantro - optional\n\nChorizo sausage from Whole Foods. Whole Foods has a standard recipe and spices for making chorizo sausage and may make some up for you upon request if you don't see it displayed.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the onions: Heat a large skillet on medium high heat. Heat a tablespoon of olive oil or bacon fat in the pan. Add the chopped onions (optional) and cook until softened.\n2 Add the chorizo and raisins: Once softened, move the onions to the side of the pan and add clumps of chorizo into the pan. Use a wooden spatula to break up the pieces of sausage. Add the raisins.\nStir until the sausage is cooked through, though not necessarily browned. If you are not using lean chorizo, drain the excess fat from the pan before proceeding.\nIf you are not using lean chorizo, you may want to cook the chorizo first, draining the excess fat, then remove to a plate while you cook the onions in the remaining fat. We usually cook with lean chorizo, so excess fat isn't an issue.\n3 Add the eggs: Crack the eggs one at a time, into the pan. Break the yolks and stir the eggs into the sausage. Add a light sprinkling of salt.\nStir constantly until the eggs begin to set, but are still moist. Remove from heat.\nServe immediately with a side of warmed corn tortillas and cilantro as a garnish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCloud Eggs (Egg Nests) Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 2\nINGREDIENTS\n2 eggs\n2 small pinches of salt (a pinch of salt per egg)\n1/4 cup grated cheese such as Gruyere, Swiss, or Parmesan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven and prep baking sheet: Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xb0F (230\xc2\xb0C) with a rack in the middle. Line a roasting pan, or baking sheet that can take high temperatures without warping, with parchment paper or Silpat.\n2 Separate the eggs: Separate the egg yolks from the whites. Make sure there are no little pieces of egg yolk in the whites or you will have difficulty getting the whites to beat properly. It helps if you are making more than one egg nest to keep each egg yolk in a separate prep bowl.\n3 Beat eggs to stiff peaks: Place the egg whites in a very clean mixer bowl (any residual oil in the mixer bowl will keep the egg whites from whipping up properly).\nAdd a small pinch of salt to the egg whites. Beat the egg whites with a whisk attachment in a mixer (or using a hand mixer), starting on low speed and then slowly increasing to high speed, until stiff peaks form.\n4 Gently fold in the grated cheese, taking care not to deflate the egg whites.\n5 Create two mounds of the egg white mixture on the lined baking sheet. Form the mounds so they look like nests, with indentations in the centers.\n6 Bake: Place in the 450\xc2\xb0F (230\xc2\xb0C) oven for 3 minutes. After 3 minutes, open the oven, pull out the rack with the egg white nests, and gently add an egg yolk to the center of each nest. Return the baking sheet to the oven and cook for 3 more minutes.\n\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nTomatillo Scrambled Eggs Recipe\nPrep time: 8 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: Serves 2 to 3\nIf you don't have access to tomatillos you can use prepared salsa verde, about a half cup for this recipe.\nUse as much or as little jalape\xc3\xb1o for this recipe as you want. Skip it if you don't want the heat at all.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 pound tomatillos, papery husks removed and discarded, rinsed, roughly chopped\n1/2 cup chopped onion\n1 garlic clove, minced\n1 fresh or canned jalape\xc3\xb1o chile pepper, minced (more or less depending on how hot the pepper is, and how much heat you want)\nSplash of lemon or lime juice (optional)\n5 to 6 eggs\nSalt and pepper\nSome chopped fresh cilantro for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook chopped tomatillos, onion, garlic, jalape\xc3\xb1o in skillet: Heat a tablespoon of oil in a medium-sized skillet on medium heat. Add the chopped tomatillos, onion, garlic, jalape\xc3\xb1o chile pepper, and if you want, a small squeeze of lemon or lime juice. Sprinkle with a little salt.\nCook on medium to medium heat for about 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions have softened, and the tomatillos are no longer bright green.\n2 Add eggs to pan, gently stir: Add the eggs directly to the pan (no need to whisk first). Break up the yolks with your stirring spoon. Cook gently, stirring and scraping the bottom of the pan with a wooden spoon. Salt and pepper to taste.\n3 Remove from heat: Remove from heat when the eggs begin to set, but are still moist, about 3 minutes.\nServe immediately. Add salt and pepper to taste. Sprinkle with chopped fresh cilantro for garnish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCinnamon Toast Recipe\nPrep time: 1 minuteCook time: 2 minutesYield: Makes two slices of cinnamon toast (and lots of smiles).\nFeel free to play with the ratio of cinnamon to sugar to get it to how you like it. Some people like 1:3 cinnamon to sugar, some 1:12, and some in between.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 slices of sliced bread\n2 pads of butter, softened or room temp\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 Tbsp white granulated sugar\nMETHOD\nIn a small bowl or jar, stir together the cinnamon and sugar so they are well mixed. Toast your bread. Slather the toast with butter. Sprinkle the cinnamon sugar over the buttered toast.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGerman Farmer\xe2\x80\x99s Breakfast Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n3 large potatoes, skinned and quartered lengthwise\n3 tablespoons bacon fat or extra virgin olive oil\n2 cups roughly chopped green and white onions (include the greens from the green onions)\n2 cups roughly chopped bell peppers\nSalt to taste\n1-2 cups chopped ham\n1/4 cup chopped parsley\n4 eggs, whisked\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Boil the potatoes in a saucepan of lightly salted water for 10-15 minutes until just cooked (test for doneness). Drain, rinse with cold water to cool. Cut into 1-inch squares. Set aside.\n2 Brown the onions and bell peppers: Heat 2 Tbsp bacon fat (or olive oil) in a large skillet on medium high heat. Add the onions and chopped bell peppers. Increase the heat to high. Brown the onions and bell peppers, stirring frequently, about 2-3 minutes.\n3 Add the potatoes and then the ham: Push the vegetables to the side of the pan, add the potatoes and another Tbsp of bacon fat (or olive oil) to the pan.\nBrown the potatoes for about 2 minutes, stirring frequently. Sprinkle on salt to taste as you cook.\nAdd the ham to the potatoes and cook, stirring frequently until the ham is heated through, 1-2 minutes.\n4 Add parsley, eggs: Mix all of the vegetables, potato and ham together and mix in the parsley. Add the eggs, stirring to distribute the eggs among the vegetables and ham.\nAs soon as eggs begin to firm up, remove from heat.\nServe immediately. Great with ketchup on top.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nHuevos a la Mexicana Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 2 to 4\nTry to avoid handling jalape\xc3\xb1o peppers with your bare hands. Remove the pepper from the jar with a fork, place on a small plate, and cut with a knife holding the pepper with the fork. If you by accident rub your eyes after directly handling a jalape\xc3\xb1o pepper, you'll never forget it. The stinging can be quite painful. If that happens wash your eye out directly with water.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 fresh eggs\n2 green onions, chopped all the way including the green parts\n1 fresh tomato, peeled and chopped if in season, (2 tomatoes from a can if good fresh tomatoes are not available)\nOne canned jalape\xc3\xb1o pepper, sliced\n2 Tbsp olive oil\nOregano, a sprinkling of fresh if available, dry if not\nSalt, one shake from a salt shaker for every egg used\nCilantro leaves, fresh and chopped, a couple of Tbsp\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, add tomatoes, oregano, jalape\xc3\xb1o: Heat olive oil in a large frying pan on medium high heat. Add the onions and brown them for a minute or two.\nAdd the chopped tomatoes and let them cook for a few minutes on medium high until they are somewhat cooked and mushy and some of the moisture has evaporated. It's okay if the tomatoes brown a bit.\nAdd the oregano. Add the jalape\xc3\xb1o.\n2 Add eggs and scramble them into the sauce: Crack the eggs directly into the pan with the sauce. Add salt. Stir the mixture with a spatula to mix in the sauce and to lightly scramble the eggs.\nRemove from heat when the eggs are cooked to the desired consistency.\nIf you are using a cast iron pan, remove the eggs from the pan and put into a serving bowl. Otherwise the eggs will continue to cook in the heat of the pan.\n3 Serve: Sprinkle the eggs with chopped fresh cilantro. Serve with bread or heated tortillas. Serves 2 or 3, depending on how many eggs per person you want.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nGrab-and-Go Oatmeal Chia Cups Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: 1 serving (scale up for more servings)\nThe recipe below is for one single-cup serving. Prepare additional servings in their own jars using the same ratios. You can prepare as many servings as you'll eat within 5 days!\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons old-fashioned rolled oats (gluten-free, if needed)\n1 tablespoon chia seeds\n1/3 cup milk, any kind, including non-dairy\n1/3 cup plain or vanilla yogurt, any kind, including non-dairy\n1 teaspoon honey, maple syrup, or sweetener of your choice, to taste (optional)\n1/4 cup blueberries, sliced strawberries, raspberries, or other chopped fruit of your choice\n1 tablespoon raisins or other dried fruit\n1 tablespoons chopped or sliced almonds, cashews, walnuts or other nut of your choice\nSpecial equipment:\nHalf-pint (8 ounce) canning jar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine the oats, chia seeds, and milk in an 8-ounce or larger jar: Stir to mix the ingredients together. Let stand for 10 minutes to allow the mixture to thicken slightly.\n2 Layer the remaining ingredients on top: Once the chia and milk mixture has thickened slightly, top it with layers of yogurt, honey (if using), berries, raisins and nuts. Cover the jar with a cap and refrigerate until needed, or for up to 5 days.\n3 Enjoy! Eat your breakfast straight from the jar, mixing everything together as you go, or pour the contents into a bowl, if you prefer.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCrunchy French Toast Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 2 or 3 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n2 or 3 slices of bread, cut into quarters\n1 cup cornflake cereal\n2 large eggs\n1/3 cup milk\n1/2 teaspoon all-purpose flour\n2 drops of vanilla\nButter and pancake syrup\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven, prepare baking sheet: Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone mat.\n2 Lightly toast bread in oven: Put the bread pieces on a lined baking sheet into the warming oven (it does not need to be at full temperature) to toast lightly for 5 minutes. Cool the bread completely.\n3 Crush the Corn Flakes: Seal the Corn Flakes in a heavy plastic bag. Crush them with a rolling pin to the size of rolled oats. Pour into a pie pan or a shallow dish. Set aside.\n4 Soak bread slices in egg mixture: In a large bowl, whisk to mix the eggs, milk, flour and vanilla until blended. Be sure there are no lumps of unmixed flour. Pour into a pie pan or shallow dish. In batches, lay the bread pieces in the egg mix. Soak about 1 minute on each side in the egg mixture. Be careful not to rip the bread.\n5 Coat with crushed Cornflake crumbs: Place the bread pieces in the cornflake crumbs. Coat both sides with the crumbs. Place on the lined baking sheet.\n6 Bake: Bake at 400\xc2\xb0F for 10 minutes on one side. Then flip over with tongs or a spatula and bake another 5 to 10 minutes, until the crumbs begin to turn brown.\nEat warm with butter and pancake syrup.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nChia Pudding with Blueberries and Almonds Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesSoaking time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 2 to 3\nThe honey is optional, skip it if you are going vegan, or use maple syrup instead.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups unsweetened almond milk\n1 cup (divided, 3/4 cup and 1/4 cup) fresh or frozen (defrosted) blueberries\n1/2 cup chia seeds\n2 Tbsp honey (optional)\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/4 cup toasted slivered or sliced almonds\nMETHOD\n1 Blend together 2 cups almond milk and 3/4 cup blueberries in a blender. Pour out into a bowl or quart-sized mason jar.\n2 Stir in the chia seeds, honey, cinnamon, vanilla extract. (Or just cover and shake if using a jar.) Let sit for 10 minutes, then stir again to  break up any clumping.\n3 Chill for 2 hours or overnight.\n4 When ready to eat, stir again. Top with toasted almonds the remaining blueberries.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nHow to Make Eggs Benedict Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 4 one-egg one-muffin servings\nEggs benedict is also great made with slices of smoked salmon in place of the bacon. If you are in or around New Jersey, try it with Taylor ham.\nINGREDIENTS\n8 pieces of bacon or 4 pieces of Canadian bacon\n2 tablespoons chopped parsley, for garnish\n4 eggs\n2 teaspoons white or rice vinegar\n2 English muffins\nButter\nBlender Hollandaise\n10 tablespoons unsalted butter (if using salted butter, omit the added salt)\n3 egg yolks\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nDash of cayenne or tabasco\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the bacon: Heat a large skillet on medium low heat. Add the strips of bacon or the slices of Canadian bacon. Slowly fry, turning occasionally, until the bacon is browned on both sides, and if using strip bacon, much of the fat is rendered out (about 10 minutes).\nUse tongs or a fork to remove the bacon from the pan, set on a paper towel to absorb the excess fat.\nDon't pour the bacon fat left in the pan down the drain! Either sop it up with paper towels when it has cooled a bit, or pour it into a jar to be used later (see rendering bacon fat).\n2 Bring poaching water to a simmer: While the bacon is cooking, bring a large saucepan two-thirds-filled with water to a boil, then add the vinegar. Bring the water to a boil again, then lower the heat to a bare simmer.\n3 Make Hollandaise sauce in blender: To make blender hollandaise, melt 10 Tbsp unsalted butter.\nPut 3 egg yolks, a tablespoon of lemon juice, 1/2 teaspoon salt in a blender, blend on medium to medium high speed for 20-30 seconds, until eggs lighten in color.\nTurn blender down to lowest setting, slowly dribble in the hot melted butter, while continuing to blend. Taste for salt and acidity and add more salt or lemon juice to taste.\nTransfer it to a container you can use for pouring and set it on a warm\xe2\x80\x94but not hot\xe2\x80\x94place on or near the stovetop.\n4 Poach the eggs: Here is an easy method for poaching eggs. Essentially, working one egg at a time you crack an egg into a small bowl and slip it into the barely simmering water. Once it begins to solidify, you can slip in another egg, until you have all four cooking.\nTurn off the heat, cover the pan, and let sit for 4 minutes. (Remember which egg went in first, you'll want to take it out first.) When it comes time to remove the eggs, gently lift out with a slotted spoon.\nNote that the timing is a little variable on the eggs, depending on the size of your pan, how much water, how many eggs, and how runny you like them. You might have to experiment a little with your set-up to figure out what you need to do to get the eggs exactly the way you like them.\n5 Toast English muffins: As soon as all the eggs are in the poaching water, begin toasting your English muffins. If you can\xe2\x80\x99t get all the muffins toasted by the time the eggs are ready, gently remove the eggs from the poaching water and set in a bowl.\n6 Assemble your Eggs Benedict: To assemble, butter one side of an English muffin. Top with two slices of bacon or 1 slice of Canadian bacon. You can trim the bacon to fit the muffin if you\xe2\x80\x99d like.\nPut a poached egg on top of the bacon, then pour some hollandaise over. Sprinkle some parsley over it all and serve at once.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nEasy Poached Eggs\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 4 minutesYield: 1 or more poached eggs\nFresh eggs work best for poaching. Their whites hold together better than older eggs. Some people put a little vinegar in the poaching water\xe2\x80\x94the vinegar helps the proteins in the egg whites coagulate. But the vinegar does affect the taste. I usually skip it.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 or more fresh eggs\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the water: Fill a saucepan with several inches of water. Heat the water on high until it reaches a boil and then lower the heat until the water is at a bare simmer (just a few bubbles coming up now and then).\n2 Crack egg into a small bowl and gently slip it into the water: Working with the eggs one at a time, crack the egg into a small bowl or cup. Place the bowl close to the surface of the hot water and gently slip the egg into the water.\nIf you want, use a spoon to push some of the egg whites closer to their yolks, to help them hold together. Add all of the eggs you are poaching to the pan in the same way, keeping some distance between them.\n3 Turn off heat, cover pan, set timer for 4 minutes: Turn off the heat and cover the pan. Set a timer for 4 minutes (or count out loud to 60, four times). At this point the egg whites should be completely cooked, while the egg yolks are still runny.\nNote that the timing depends on the size of the eggs, the number of eggs in the pot, and if you are cooking at altitude, so adjust accordingly. If you are at altitude, want firmer egg yolks, or are poaching more than 4 eggs at once, you may need to cook them longer. If you try 4 minutes and the eggs are too cooked, reduce the time.\n4 Remove eggs with slotted spoon: Gently lift the poached eggs out of the pan with a slotted spoon and place on a plate to serve.\nUSING A FINE MESH SIEVE\nOne way to help your poached egg whites stay together is to remove some of the thin wispy egg whites before you add your eggs to the hot water. An easy way to do this is with a fine mesh sieve.\n1 Strain thin whites with a fine mesh sieve: Place the raw egg into a fine mesh sieve over a bowl. The very thin egg whites will drain out through the sieve.\n2 Gently add to hot water: Then gently ease the raw egg into your pot of simmering hot water.\n3 Turn off heat, cover pot, cook 4 minutes: Notice how there is much less stray egg whites with this method? Turn off the heat and cover the pot (or just lower the heat to low), and cook for 4 minutes until the whites are cooked through. (You may need to add more time if cooking at altitude or poaching more than 4 eggs at once.)\nRemove from the pot with a slotted spoon.\nUSING AN EGG POACHER\nIf you don\'t want to futz around with trying to keep the eggs from spreading or bumping into each other, the easiest way to make poached eggs is with an egg poacher.\nThe "poacher" is actually coddling the eggs, not truly poaching them, but if what you want is an egg with a cooked white and runny yolk, this is an easy way to do it.\nTo use an egg poaching pan, remove the cups from the pan that you intend to use.\nFill the pan with only 1/2-inch of water and bring it to a low boil. Put a drop or so of olive oil in each of the egg cups you are using and spread around. (The cups are stick-free, but the oil helps.)\nCrack the eggs into the egg cups, one egg per cup. Place the egg filled cup back in the slot for it in the pan.\nCover the pan and cook for 4 minutes.\nRemove from heat and carefully lift the egg cups out of the pan. Slide the cooked eggs out of the cups onto serving plates or bowls.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSausage Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 6 to 8\nBread that is a little bit dry will hold up better in the casserole and provide more structure, which is why breakfast casseroles tend to call for "day old" bread. If your bread is fresh or soft, after you cube it, spread it out on a sheet pan and put it in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 to 12 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Italian pork sausage\n10 large eggs, beaten\n4 cups whole milk\n1 teaspoon dry mustard\n1/4 teaspoon onion powder\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\nFresh ground pepper to taste\n5 cups cubed day old bread (we recommend rustic French or Italian loaf), cut into 3/4-inch to 1 inch-wide cubes\n2 cups shredded sharp cheddar cheese\n1/2 cup sliced mushrooms (optional)\n1/2 cup peeled, cored, chopped tomatoes (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the sausage: Heat a skillet on medium. Break up the sausage into chunks and cook, working in batches if need be, until cooked on all sides. As you cook the sausage, you can break up the larger chunks into smaller crumbles (which are easier to distribute evenly over the casserole).\nWhen lightly browned, remove from pan to a paper towel lined plate to absorb any excess fat.\n2 In a large bowl whisk together the eggs, milk, dry mustard, onion powder, salt and pepper.\n3 Assemble the casserole: Place the cubed bread in a well-buttered 9x13 inch baking pan. Sprinkle with cheese. Sprinkle with chopped tomatoes and mushrooms, if using. Top with the browned crumbled sausage, distributing it evenly. Pour the egg milk mixture evenly over the bread and cheese.\n4 Cover and chill, if making ahead: At this point, the casserole can be covered and chilled in the fridge until ready to bake and serve, up to overnight.\nIf baking immediately, let the casserole sit for 10 minutes before putting in the oven (to give the bread a chance to absorb the milk-egg mixture.\n5 Bake the casserole: When ready to cook, preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. Bake uncovered for about one hour. Tent with foil if the top begins to brown too quickly.\n6 Serve: Let the casserole cool for about 10 minutes before serving. Leftovers will keep in the refrigerator for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nEasy Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8\nThe ingredient proportions are estimates. The more eggs, the firmer and less likely to deflate the casserole will be.\nMushrooms tend to hold a lot of moisture, so if you use a lot of them, you may want to saut\xc3\xa9 them first to release some of their water.\nDon't have day-old bread? Put slices of fresh bread into a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the breakfast casserole base:\n6 to 10 large eggs\n2 to 3 cups grated cheddar cheese\n6 slices day-old bread, cut into 3/4-inch to 1-inch-wide cubes\n2 cups milk\nSalt\nPepper\nFor the possible additions: \n1 cup corn (cooked or frozen)\n1/2 cup chopped broccoli (cooked or raw, raw will turn out crunchier)\n1/2 cup sliced mushrooms\n1/4 cup sliced green onions\n1 cup cubed ham and/or cooked Italian sausage\nA few slices cooked bacon, chopped\n1 teaspoon Herbes de Provence, or other dried herbs, (or 1 tablespoon of fresh chopped herbs such as basil, rosemary, or thyme)\n1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon of cumin or curry powder\nSpecial equipment:\n9x13 inch casserole dish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Beat eggs, add milk and cheese: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Beat the eggs in a large bowl. Mix in the milk and cheese.\n2 Add the bread and carefully stir until all pieces of bread are moistened (don't over mix or the bread may disintegrate).\n3 Add the additions: Add salt and pepper to taste (if using Italian sausage, you won't need either.) If you have a lot of additions, you might need a couple more eggs to make sure that everything is at least touching some egg mixture. Just whisk in 2 tablespoons of milk for every beaten egg you add.\n4 Bake: Butter a 9x13-inch casserole dish. Pour the mixture into the casserole dish.\nBake in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for 50 minutes to an hour, until the top is browned and the center springs back when touched.\nRemove from oven and let cool for 10 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nHuevos Rancheros Recipe\nCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 2-4 servings\nThe recipe is flexible, sometimes we use canned salsa and just add a few more chopped tomatoes and some chopped pickled jalape\xc3\xb1os to make the sauce.\nSometimes if we have some leftover refried beans, we'll spread some on the tortillas before topping them with the eggs and salsa. My mother has been known to add a pinch of sugar to the salsa sauce if she feels it's too acidic for her taste.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 medium onion, chopped (about a half cup)\n1 15-ounce can whole or crushed tomatoes, preferably fire-roasted, (or 1 -2 large fresh vine-ripened tomatoes, when in season)\n1/2 6-ounce can diced green Anaheim chiles\nChipotle chili powder, adobo sauce, or ground cumin to taste (optional)\n4 corn tortillas\nButter\n4 fresh eggs\n2 tablespoons fresh cilantro, chopped (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the sauce: Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions in a little olive oil in a large skillet on medium heat. Once the onions are translucent, add the tomatoes and their juices. If using whole canned tomatoes, break them up with your fingers or a spatula as you put them in the pan.\nIf you are using fresh tomatoes, chop them first, then add. Note that fresh tomatoes will take longer to cook as canned tomatoes are already cooked to begin with.\nAdd chopped green chilies. Add additional chili to taste, either chipotle chili powder, adobo sauce, regular chili powder, or even ground cumin.\nBring to a simmer, reduce heat to low, and let simmer while you do the rest of the cooking, stirring occasionally. Reduce to warm after it has been simmering for 10 minutes. Add salt to taste if needed.\n2 Warm the plates: Heat the oven to a warm 150\xc2\xb0F, place serving plates in the oven to keep warm.\n3 Prepare the tortillas: Heat a teaspoon of olive oil in a large non-stick skillet on medium high, coating the pan with the oil.\nOne by one (or more if your pan is big enough) heat the tortillas in the pan, a minute or two on each side, until they are heated through, softened, and pockets of air bubble up inside of them.\nThen remove them and stack them on one of the warming plates in the oven to keep warm while you continue cooking the rest of the tortillas and the eggs.\n4 Fry the eggs: Using the same skillet as was used for the tortillas, add a little butter to the pan, about two teaspoons for 4 eggs. Heat the pan on medium high heat. Crack 4 eggs into the skillet and cook for 3 to 4 minutes for runny yolks, more for firmer eggs.\n5 Assemble and serve: To serve, spoon a little of the sauce onto a warmed plate. Top with a tortilla, then a fried egg. Top with more sauce, sprinkle with cilantro if desired.\nServe either one or two eggs/tortillas per plate, depending on how much you want to eat. I'm a 2-egg 2 tortilla person myself.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nChorizo and Eggs Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 2 to 3\nINGREDIENTS\nExtra virgin olive oil or bacon fat\n1/3 cup chopped onions (green, red, or yellow onions) optional\n1/4 pound of Mexican chorizo sausage, removed from sausage casing\n3 tablespoons raisins - soaked in hot water for 10 minutes and drained\n5 to 6 eggs\nSalt\nTortillas - optional\nCilantro - optional\n\nChorizo sausage from Whole Foods. Whole Foods has a standard recipe and spices for making chorizo sausage and may make some up for you upon request if you don't see it displayed.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the onions: Heat a large skillet on medium high heat. Heat a tablespoon of olive oil or bacon fat in the pan. Add the chopped onions (optional) and cook until softened.\n2 Add the chorizo and raisins: Once softened, move the onions to the side of the pan and add clumps of chorizo into the pan. Use a wooden spatula to break up the pieces of sausage. Add the raisins.\nStir until the sausage is cooked through, though not necessarily browned. If you are not using lean chorizo, drain the excess fat from the pan before proceeding.\nIf you are not using lean chorizo, you may want to cook the chorizo first, draining the excess fat, then remove to a plate while you cook the onions in the remaining fat. We usually cook with lean chorizo, so excess fat isn't an issue.\n3 Add the eggs: Crack the eggs one at a time, into the pan. Break the yolks and stir the eggs into the sausage. Add a light sprinkling of salt.\nStir constantly until the eggs begin to set, but are still moist. Remove from heat.\nServe immediately with a side of warmed corn tortillas and cilantro as a garnish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCloud Eggs (Egg Nests) Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 2\nINGREDIENTS\n2 eggs\n2 small pinches of salt (a pinch of salt per egg)\n1/4 cup grated cheese such as Gruyere, Swiss, or Parmesan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven and prep baking sheet: Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xb0F (230\xc2\xb0C) with a rack in the middle. Line a roasting pan, or baking sheet that can take high temperatures without warping, with parchment paper or Silpat.\n2 Separate the eggs: Separate the egg yolks from the whites. Make sure there are no little pieces of egg yolk in the whites or you will have difficulty getting the whites to beat properly. It helps if you are making more than one egg nest to keep each egg yolk in a separate prep bowl.\n3 Beat eggs to stiff peaks: Place the egg whites in a very clean mixer bowl (any residual oil in the mixer bowl will keep the egg whites from whipping up properly).\nAdd a small pinch of salt to the egg whites. Beat the egg whites with a whisk attachment in a mixer (or using a hand mixer), starting on low speed and then slowly increasing to high speed, until stiff peaks form.\n4 Gently fold in the grated cheese, taking care not to deflate the egg whites.\n5 Create two mounds of the egg white mixture on the lined baking sheet. Form the mounds so they look like nests, with indentations in the centers.\n6 Bake: Place in the 450\xc2\xb0F (230\xc2\xb0C) oven for 3 minutes. After 3 minutes, open the oven, pull out the rack with the egg white nests, and gently add an egg yolk to the center of each nest. Return the baking sheet to the oven and cook for 3 more minutes.\n\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nTomatillo Scrambled Eggs Recipe\nPrep time: 8 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: Serves 2 to 3\nIf you don't have access to tomatillos you can use prepared salsa verde, about a half cup for this recipe.\nUse as much or as little jalape\xc3\xb1o for this recipe as you want. Skip it if you don't want the heat at all.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 pound tomatillos, papery husks removed and discarded, rinsed, roughly chopped\n1/2 cup chopped onion\n1 garlic clove, minced\n1 fresh or canned jalape\xc3\xb1o chile pepper, minced (more or less depending on how hot the pepper is, and how much heat you want)\nSplash of lemon or lime juice (optional)\n5 to 6 eggs\nSalt and pepper\nSome chopped fresh cilantro for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook chopped tomatillos, onion, garlic, jalape\xc3\xb1o in skillet: Heat a tablespoon of oil in a medium-sized skillet on medium heat. Add the chopped tomatillos, onion, garlic, jalape\xc3\xb1o chile pepper, and if you want, a small squeeze of lemon or lime juice. Sprinkle with a little salt.\nCook on medium to medium heat for about 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions have softened, and the tomatillos are no longer bright green.\n2 Add eggs to pan, gently stir: Add the eggs directly to the pan (no need to whisk first). Break up the yolks with your stirring spoon. Cook gently, stirring and scraping the bottom of the pan with a wooden spoon. Salt and pepper to taste.\n3 Remove from heat: Remove from heat when the eggs begin to set, but are still moist, about 3 minutes.\nServe immediately. Add salt and pepper to taste. Sprinkle with chopped fresh cilantro for garnish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCinnamon Toast Recipe\nPrep time: 1 minuteCook time: 2 minutesYield: Makes two slices of cinnamon toast (and lots of smiles).\nFeel free to play with the ratio of cinnamon to sugar to get it to how you like it. Some people like 1:3 cinnamon to sugar, some 1:12, and some in between.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 slices of sliced bread\n2 pads of butter, softened or room temp\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1 Tbsp white granulated sugar\nMETHOD\nIn a small bowl or jar, stir together the cinnamon and sugar so they are well mixed. Toast your bread. Slather the toast with butter. Sprinkle the cinnamon sugar over the buttered toast.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGerman Farmer\xe2\x80\x99s Breakfast Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n3 large potatoes, skinned and quartered lengthwise\n3 tablespoons bacon fat or extra virgin olive oil\n2 cups roughly chopped green and white onions (include the greens from the green onions)\n2 cups roughly chopped bell peppers\nSalt to taste\n1-2 cups chopped ham\n1/4 cup chopped parsley\n4 eggs, whisked\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Boil the potatoes in a saucepan of lightly salted water for 10-15 minutes until just cooked (test for doneness). Drain, rinse with cold water to cool. Cut into 1-inch squares. Set aside.\n2 Brown the onions and bell peppers: Heat 2 Tbsp bacon fat (or olive oil) in a large skillet on medium high heat. Add the onions and chopped bell peppers. Increase the heat to high. Brown the onions and bell peppers, stirring frequently, about 2-3 minutes.\n3 Add the potatoes and then the ham: Push the vegetables to the side of the pan, add the potatoes and another Tbsp of bacon fat (or olive oil) to the pan.\nBrown the potatoes for about 2 minutes, stirring frequently. Sprinkle on salt to taste as you cook.\nAdd the ham to the potatoes and cook, stirring frequently until the ham is heated through, 1-2 minutes.\n4 Add parsley, eggs: Mix all of the vegetables, potato and ham together and mix in the parsley. Add the eggs, stirring to distribute the eggs among the vegetables and ham.\nAs soon as eggs begin to firm up, remove from heat.\nServe immediately. Great with ketchup on top.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHam and Potato Hash Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons butter\n1 small onion, finely chopped\n1/2 green bell pepper, finely chopped\n2 medium potatoes, peeled\n1 cup finely diced cooked ham\n1/4 teaspoon salt, or to taste\n1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/4 teaspoon dried crumbled thyme\nMETHOD\n1 Partially cook the potatoes, then dice: Cut the potatoes in half, cook in a saucepan of simmering water until not quite done and still firm, about 10 minutes. Rinse in cold water to stop cooking. Drain. Dice to 1/2-inch thick pieces. Set aside.\n2 Cook the onion and bell pepper in butter: Melt butter in a large cast-iron* skillet over medium low to medium heat. Add onion, cook until softened, about 4 minutes. Add the chopped bell pepper, cook another 2 minutes.\n3 Add the potatoes, ham, salt, pepper, and thyme: Add remaining ingredients; mix well. Cook hash until well browned, about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.\n*The hash will brown better in a cast iron pan than in a stick-free pan. \nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nGrab-and-Go Oatmeal Chia Cups Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: 1 serving (scale up for more servings)\nThe recipe below is for one single-cup serving. Prepare additional servings in their own jars using the same ratios. You can prepare as many servings as you'll eat within 5 days!\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons old-fashioned rolled oats (gluten-free, if needed)\n1 tablespoon chia seeds\n1/3 cup milk, any kind, including non-dairy\n1/3 cup plain or vanilla yogurt, any kind, including non-dairy\n1 teaspoon honey, maple syrup, or sweetener of your choice, to taste (optional)\n1/4 cup blueberries, sliced strawberries, raspberries, or other chopped fruit of your choice\n1 tablespoon raisins or other dried fruit\n1 tablespoons chopped or sliced almonds, cashews, walnuts or other nut of your choice\nSpecial equipment:\nHalf-pint (8 ounce) canning jar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine the oats, chia seeds, and milk in an 8-ounce or larger jar: Stir to mix the ingredients together. Let stand for 10 minutes to allow the mixture to thicken slightly.\n2 Layer the remaining ingredients on top: Once the chia and milk mixture has thickened slightly, top it with layers of yogurt, honey (if using), berries, raisins and nuts. Cover the jar with a cap and refrigerate until needed, or for up to 5 days.\n3 Enjoy! Eat your breakfast straight from the jar, mixing everything together as you go, or pour the contents into a bowl, if you prefer.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nLemon Ricotta Pancakes Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings, about 12 pancakes\nIf you have any leftover pancakes (highly unlikely, but just in case), the pancakes can be frozen. Spread them on a baking sheet between layers of parchment paper and freeze until firm. Then stack them between parchment squares and place in a heavy plastic freezer bag. The pancakes will keep well for about 1 week.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 large eggs\n1/3 cup plus 1 tablespoon sugar, divided\n1 cup all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt, plus 1 pinch for beating the egg whites\n1 cup whole milk ricotta\n3 tablespoons lemon juice\n2 teaspoons finely grated lemon zest\n1/2 cup whole or 2% milk\nButter or vegetable oil, for the griddle\nFresh berries, to serve\nMaple syrup, to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Separate the eggs: Carefully separate the eggs, placing the yolks and the eggs in separate bowls.\n2 Beat the egg whites: In a squeaky clean mixer bowl, beat the egg whites with a pinch of salt at high speed until very frothy. With the mixer still on high, slowly add 1 tablespoon of sugar. Continue beating until stiff peaks form, about 5 minutes. Set aside.\n3 Mix the dry ingredients: In a bowl, whisk the flour, baking powder and 1/2 teaspoon of the salt until blended. Set aside.\n4 Make the ricotta mixture: In a large bowl, whisk the egg yolks and the remaining 1/3 cup of sugar together. Add the ricotta, lemon zest, and lemon juice and whisk until smooth. Stir in the milk until blended.\n5 Make the batter: Add the flour mixture to the egg yolk mixture and stir with a spatula just until combined. Fold in one-third of the beaten egg whites to lighten the batter. Add the remaining egg whites and gently fold until only a few streaks of white remain.\n6 Cook the pancakes: Set a griddle, cast iron pan, or non-stick skillet over medium-low heat and brush with oil. When the pan is hot enough that a flick of water sizzles on contact, use a 1/2-cup measure to scoop the batter and drop onto the pan. With the back of a spoon, spread the batter of each pancake into a 4- to 5-inch round.\nKeep the temperature of the pan at medium to medium-low. Cook each pancake for 2 to 3 minutes, or until bubbles form on top. Flip and cook for 1 to 2 minutes longer, until the pancakes are cooked through.\nServe each batch immediately or transfer the pancakes to a sheet pan in a warm oven to keep warm until ready to serve.\n7  Serve: Serve warm with butter, maple syrup and fresh berries.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nChia Pudding with Blueberries and Almonds Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesSoaking time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 2 to 3\nThe honey is optional, skip it if you are going vegan, or use maple syrup instead.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups unsweetened almond milk\n1 cup (divided, 3/4 cup and 1/4 cup) fresh or frozen (defrosted) blueberries\n1/2 cup chia seeds\n2 Tbsp honey (optional)\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/4 cup toasted slivered or sliced almonds\nMETHOD\n1 Blend together 2 cups almond milk and 3/4 cup blueberries in a blender. Pour out into a bowl or quart-sized mason jar.\n2 Stir in the chia seeds, honey, cinnamon, vanilla extract. (Or just cover and shake if using a jar.) Let sit for 10 minutes, then stir again to  break up any clumping.\n3 Chill for 2 hours or overnight.\n4 When ready to eat, stir again. Top with toasted almonds the remaining blueberries.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBiscuits and Gravy Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 12 servings\nThe cornstarch in the biscuit dough reduces the gluten content to help keep the biscuits light and fluffy.\nIf you have White Lily Flour, use 2 1/2 cups of White Lily flour instead of all-purpose, and omit the cornstarch.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the biscuits:\n2 1/4 cups (315 g) all-purpose flour (see Recipe Note)\n3 tablespoons cornstarch\n1 tablespoon baking powder\n3/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 cup unsalted butter, cold\n1 cup buttermilk, cold\nFor the gravy:\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1/2 pound sliced mushrooms\n1/4 cup chopped yellow onions\n1 pound breakfast pork sausage\n6 tablespoons all-purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon ground sage\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/8 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n3/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 1/2 cups milk, preferably whole\nFor topping:\n1 tablespoon unsalted butter, melted\nSpecial equipment:\n2-quart glass or ceramic baking dish, rectangular or square\n2 1/2-inch biscuit cutter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the biscuit dough: Combine the flour, cornstarch, baking powder, and salt in a large bowl. Cut the butter into 1/2-inch chunks and sprinkle it over the dry ingredients. Using a pastry blender, a butter knife, or a fork, cut the butter into the dry ingredients until most of it is the size of peas. Don\xe2\x80\x99t overwork it; you want to leave some of the butter in chunks.\nAdd the buttermilk and toss the mixture with a spatula until it starts to look shaggy, and most of the buttermilk has been absorbed. It won\xe2\x80\x99t form a dough yet; that\xe2\x80\x99s OK.\n3 Bring the dough together: Turn out the contents of the bowl onto a clean surface dusted with a little flour. Gather the dough together with your hands into a mound, then roll it out until it is about 10-inches wide. Again, don\xe2\x80\x99t worry if the dough is crumbly!\n4 Fold the dough to create flaky layers: Use a spatula (like the kind you use to make fried eggs) or bench scraper and flip 1/3 of the dough over from the left to the center. Then flip the other side over that side. You\xe2\x80\x99re basically folding the dough over like a letter.\nRotate the dough 90-degrees and roll it out again to about a 10-inch square. It will start to feel more like a dough and less crumbly at this point, but there will still be some loose chunks. Just press them back into the dough if they fall out, and resist the urge to add more liquid.\nRepeat the process of rolling out and folding two more times. By the fourth time, the biscuit dough will hold together and feel like actual dough.\n5 Cut the biscuits: Roll out the dough to a 10-inch square that\xe2\x80\x99s roughly 1/2 inch thick. Using a 2 1/2-inch biscuit cutter, cut out 16 circles. When you press down to cut out the dough, don\xe2\x80\x99t twist the biscuit cutter, which will \xe2\x80\x9cseal\xe2\x80\x9d the edges of the dough. Instead, just cut straight down, so the biscuit will rise and be as flaky as possible.\n5 Bake the bottom layer of biscuits: Set aside 12 of the biscuit rounds. Place the remaining 4 biscuit rounds on the bottom of a 2-quart glass or ceramic casserole dish. Cut up the remaining scraps of dough and jigsaw-puzzle the remaining dough into the bottom of the casserole dish, making sure to cover the bottom in a single layer.\nPlace on a rimmed baking sheet (for ease of removal from the oven and to catch any drips). Bake in the oven for 15 minutes or until the top of the biscuits start to look dry but not brown at all. (There might be a slight darkening around the edges, but don\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed if the biscuits still look pale white.)\n6 Meanwhile, make the gravy: While the bottom biscuits are baking, make the gravy by placing the oil, mushrooms, and onions in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan. Cook on high heat, stirring constantly, until the mushrooms start to soften, and the onions start to look translucent, about 5 minutes. Add the sausage, breaking it up with a wooden spoon or spatula, and cook until the sausage starts to brown, about 5 minutes.\nKeep the heat on high, and add the flour, sage, black pepper, nutmeg, and salt to the pan. Stir until the ingredients are absorbed. Pour in the milk, reduce heat to medium, and cook, continuing to stir until the liquid has started to bubble and thicken, about 3 to 7 minutes. You\xe2\x80\x99re now ready to assemble the casserole!\nIf the first layer of biscuits isn\xe2\x80\x99t done baking, lower the heat on the gravy to a simmer until the biscuits are done. If you still need time to finish the gravy, but the biscuits are done\xe2\x80\x94remove the casserole dish from the oven, and let it sit on the counter or stovetop while you finish the gravy.\n7 Assemble and bake the casserole: Once the gravy has thickened and the first layer of biscuits is done baking, pour or spoon the gravy over the biscuit layer in the casserole dish. Place the 12 reserved biscuits over the gravy and brush the top of the biscuits with the melted butter.\nReturn the dish to the oven and bake until the biscuits are golden brown and the gravy is bubbling and thick, about 18 to 23 minutes.\n8 Cool and serve: Let cool 10 minutes before serving warm from the casserole dish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nFrench Toast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesChill time: overnight (optional)Yield: 6 to 8 servings\nMake-ahead instructions: Assemble the casserole through Step 4, cover well, and refrigerate overnight. The next day, uncover, drizzle the casserole with the topping, and bake. Baking time will be slightly longer.\nThis casserole reheats well, though the chunks of bread on the top will gradually lose some crunch. The best way to reheat it is to bake it in the oven at 350F for 10 to 15 minutes to warm through and re-crisp the top.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the casserole:\n1 large loaf good-quality French loaf, sourdough, ciabatta, or challah (enough to yield 10 cups of chunks of bread)\n1/2 cup (45g) chopped pecans\n5 large eggs\n1 1/2 cups whole milk\n1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar\nZest from one medium orange (optional)\n1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon salt\nFor the topping:\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted\n3 tablespoons (40g) dark brown sugar\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\nPinch of salt\nOptional toppings for serving:\nDried cranberries\nPowdered sugar\nMaple syrup\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 375F (190C). Place an oven rack in the center position.\n2 Slice the bread into 1-inch slices and then cut them into 1-inch cubes. You can also tear the bread apart with your hands. Leave the crusts on.\n3 Layer the bread and pecans in a baking dish: Lightly grease a 2-quart (if you want thicker slices) or 3-quart baking dish (if you want thinner slices) with cooking spray or butter. Add enough bread cubes to cover the bottom. Sprinkle a few tablespoons of pecans on top. Continue layering the bread chunks and pecans.\n4 Prepare and add the custard: In a small bowl, whisk the eggs together. Add the milk, sugar, orange zest, 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon, and salt, and mix well. Pour the egg and milk mixture evenly over all the bread chunks. (I found it easier to pour the mixture into a large measuring cup with a spout first before pouring the mixture over the bread.)\nAt this point, the casserole can be baked right away, or covered and refrigerated overnight.\n5 Drizzle with topping: In another bowl, mix the melted butter with the brown sugar, 1 teaspoon cinnamon, and a pinch of salt. Using a spoon, drizzle the mixture evenly over all the bread chunks.\n6 Bake the casserole for 35 to 45 minutes. I baked mine for about 38 minutes. Leave the casserole in the oven longer if you want the chunks of bread on the top to be more brown and crunchier.\n7 Remove the casserole from the oven and let it cool for about 10 minutes before serving. Sprinkle dried cranberries and dust powdered sugar on top, if you like. Serve with maple syrup at the table.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSausage Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 6 to 8\nBread that is a little bit dry will hold up better in the casserole and provide more structure, which is why breakfast casseroles tend to call for "day old" bread. If your bread is fresh or soft, after you cube it, spread it out on a sheet pan and put it in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 to 12 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Italian pork sausage\n10 large eggs, beaten\n4 cups whole milk\n1 teaspoon dry mustard\n1/4 teaspoon onion powder\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\nFresh ground pepper to taste\n5 cups cubed day old bread (we recommend rustic French or Italian loaf), cut into 3/4-inch to 1 inch-wide cubes\n2 cups shredded sharp cheddar cheese\n1/2 cup sliced mushrooms (optional)\n1/2 cup peeled, cored, chopped tomatoes (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the sausage: Heat a skillet on medium. Break up the sausage into chunks and cook, working in batches if need be, until cooked on all sides. As you cook the sausage, you can break up the larger chunks into smaller crumbles (which are easier to distribute evenly over the casserole).\nWhen lightly browned, remove from pan to a paper towel lined plate to absorb any excess fat.\n2 In a large bowl whisk together the eggs, milk, dry mustard, onion powder, salt and pepper.\n3 Assemble the casserole: Place the cubed bread in a well-buttered 9x13 inch baking pan. Sprinkle with cheese. Sprinkle with chopped tomatoes and mushrooms, if using. Top with the browned crumbled sausage, distributing it evenly.
