So, watch the time, and don't let the broccoli overcook!\n4 Dress with your favorite topping: Dress to taste with butter, olive oil, mayonnaise, lemon zest or juice, seasoned rice vinegar, balsamic vinegar, ground black pepper, toasted almonds, or sesame seeds.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nRoasted Broccoli with Parmesan Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 3-4 as a side dish\nThe measurements are just a guideline. Add more or less olive oil, lemon juice, salt, pepper, or cheese to taste.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 pounds (680g) broccoli, cut into florets of even size\n3-4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nJuice from half a lemon, about 1 Tbsp\nKosher salt\n2-3 garlic cloves, minced\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, or to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F (220\xc2\xb0C).\n2 Toss broccoli and garlic with olive oil, lemon juice, salt: In a large bowl toss the broccoli florets and minced garlic with olive oil and lemon juice until lightly coated. Sprinkle salt over the broccoli and toss to coat.\n3 Arrange florets in a single layer on baking sheet: Arrange the broccoli florets in a single layer on a baking sheet that has been rubbed with some olive oil or lined with parchment paper or aluminum foil.\n4 Roast for 16-20 minutes: Roast at 425\xc2\xb0F (220\xc2\xb0C) for 16-20 minutes until cooked through (check by poking with a fork, should be fork tender) and lightly browned. The browned bits are the best! So don't worry if you see some charring.\n5 Toss with Parmesan and black pepper: Put the roasted broccoli back in the bowl and toss with lots of freshly ground black pepper and the grated parmesan cheese. Be generous with the black pepper, broccoli loves it!\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nBroccoli Cheddar Bites Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes 24 broccoli bites\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large bunch of broccoli florets\n2 eggs, lightly beaten\n1/2 cup, packed, torn fresh bread (no crust)\n1/4 cup grated onion\n1/4 cup mayonnaise\n1 cup (4 ounces, 114 g), packed, grated sharp cheddar cheese\n1 1/2 teaspoons lemon zest\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Steam and chop the broccoli: Place 1 inch of water in a pot with a steamer basket. Bring to a boil. Add the broccoli florets. Steam the broccoli florets for 5 minutes, until just tender. Rinse with cold water to stop the cooking.\nFinely chop the steamed broccoli florets. You should have 2 to 2 1/2 cups.\n  2 Make filling: Place the beaten eggs and the torn bread in a large bowl. Mix until the bread is completely moistened.\nAdd the grated onion, mayonnaise, cheese, lemon zest, salt and pepper. Stir in the minced broccoli.\n3 Distribute broccoli mixture in mini muffin pan wells:  Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Coat the wells of 2 mini muffin pans (1 dozen wells each) with olive oil (so the bites don't stick). Distribute the broccoli mixture in the muffin wells.\n4 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 25 minutes until cooked through and lightly browned on top.\nIf you don't have mini muffin pans, you can cook the bites freeform. Just grease a baking sheet and spoon large dollops of the mixture onto the pan. Baking time is the same.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBeef and Broccoli Ramen Stir Fry Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the stir fry sauce:\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n1 tablespoon grated fresh ginger\n1/3 cup soy sauce\n1/4 cup honey\n1/4 cup hoisin sauce\n3/4 cup beef broth\n2 tablespoons rice vinegar\n2 tablespoons sesame oil\n2 tablespoons cornstarch\nFor the stir fry:\n2 (3-ounce) packages dried ramen noodles, seasoning packets discarded\n2 tablespoons olive oil, divided\n1 pound sirloin steak, trimmed of fat and sliced into 1/4-inch thick strips\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n3 cups fresh broccoli florets\nSesame seeds, garnish\nSriracha, garnish (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n12-inch anodized wok\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the stir fry sauce: Add garlic and ginger to a bowl and whisk in soy sauce through sesame oil. Whisk in cornstarch last, and try to whisk out as many lumps as possible. It\xe2\x80\x99s okay if there are a few lumps, as they will cook out when you add the sauce to the skillet.\nThis makes a lot, because I like this dish to be very saucy. You could halve the recipe if you like a drier stir fry. If you have leftover sauce, it stores well in the fridge for a week in an airtight container or jar.\n2 Prepare the noodles: Cook dry ramen noodles in boiling water until they are tender, 2 to 3 minutes. Drain the noodles and rinse with cold water to stop them from cooking.\n3 Cook the stir fry: In a large skillet or wok over medium-high heat, add 1 tablespoon olive oil. Season the steak with 1/2 teaspoon salt and pepper.\nOnce the skillet is glistening hot, add the steak strips. Cook for about 3 minutes, undisturbed, to allow them to sear well on one side. Then stir and continue to cook for 2 to 3 more minutes, until the steak is cooked through.\nRemove the steak from skillet, and add another tablespoon of olive oil and the broccoli florets. Add 1/2 cup of water to the skillet and cover. Steam broccoli for 2 minutes. Broccoli should be bright green and tender, and not mushy at all.\nAdd the steak back to the skillet, along with cooked and rinsed noodles. Pour in all of the sauce. (If you prefer a drier stir fry, you can start with half the sauce.) Use tongs or a large rubber spatula to stir together ingredients as sauce cooks. Cook for another 2 to 3 minutes until sauce thickens.\n5 Serve: Serve stir fry immediately, garnished with sesame seeds and, optionally, sriracha.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBroccoli Cheddar Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Serves 5 as a main course, 10 as a side\nPrep your ingredients while you are heating the blanching water to save time.\nSave your broccoli stems! You can use vegetable peeler to peel them, then slice and eat like celery.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds (900g) broccoli, stems removed (can use vegetable peeler to peel, then slice and eat like celery) and crowns cut into florets (about 8 cups of broccoli florets)\n2 strips thick-cut bacon (about 2 ounces), cut crosswise into 1/4-inch wide strips\n5 large eggs, beaten\n1/3 cup (43g) all-purpose flour\n1/2 cup (118 ml) heavy cream\n1 cup (236 ml) whole milk\n2 to 3 teaspoons freshly ground black pepper (1 to 2 teaspoons if using fine ground black pepper)\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 teaspoons Dijon mustard\n8 ounces (225g) cheddar cheese, grated\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch the broccoli florets: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil (1 Tbsp salt for 2 quarts of water). Add the broccoli florets and boil for 3-5 minutes or until just tender enough so that a fork can easily pierce the floret, but still firm. Strain and rinse with cold water to stop the cooking.\n2 Cook the bacon: While the water in step one is coming to a boil, cook the bacon pieces on medium heat in a frying pan until lightly browned, but not crisp. Remove to a plate lined with paper towels to absorb the excess fat. Set aside.\n3 Make the egg mixture: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F (220\xc2\xb0C). Butter a 2 1/2 quart casserole dish. In a bowl, whisk the eggs into the flour, then whisk in the cream and milk. Add the black pepper (more or less to taste), salt, and mustard. Mix in about a third of the cheese.\n4 Assemble the casserole: Place the blanched broccoli florets in the casserole dish, sprinkling about a third of the cheese over the broccoli florets as you lay them down. Sprinkle the bacon pieces over the broccoli.\nPour the egg, cream, milk, cheese mixture over the broccoli, moving the broccoli pieces a bit so that the mixture gets into all the nooks and crannies. Sprinkle the casserole with the remaining cheese.\n5 Bake for 25 to 40 minutes, or until set. Once the top has browned, you may want to tent with aluminum foil to keep from burning.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBroccoli Cheddar Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large head or two small heads broccoli (a little more than 1 pound), chopped into florets and stems\n1/4 cup unsalted butter\n1/2 white onion, chopped\n1 small carrot, peeled and grated\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour\n1 quart vegetable stock\n2 cups whole milk\n8 ounces cheddar cheese, grated\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon fresh black pepper\nBread, for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch the broccoli: Bring a large pot of water to a boil and add a few big pinches of salt. Add broccoli stalks and blanch for 2 to 3 minutes until they are bright green and fork tender, but still slightly crispy.\nDrain broccoli. Scoop out and set aside about 1 cup of the florets for the topping.\n2 Cook the onions and carrots: Wipe out the pot, place over medium heat, and melt the butter. Once melted, add the onions and carrots, and cook until veggies soften, 4 to 5 minutes, stirring regularly.\n3 Cook the soup: Stir in the all-purpose flour. The flour will form a paste with the veggies. Cook for a minute or two to coat the vegetables, and then start to slowly pour in vegetable stock. Stir constantly as you pour in the stock to avoid lumps.\nOnce all the stock is added, bring soup up to a low simmer. Add milk and the blanched broccoli (except what you're saving for the topping). Simmer for about 10 minutes over low heat.\n4 Puree the soup: Blend with an immersion blender, or let the soup cool until no longer steaming and blend in batches in a blender. (If using a blender, be careful to let the soup cool a bit and do not overfill the blender to avoid splattered hot soup!)\n5 Season to taste and serve: Add the grated cheese, salt, and pepper to the pureed soup and stir over low heat until the cheese has melted. Taste soup and season with additional salt and pepper to your liking.\nLadle the soup into bowls and garnish with some reserved broccoli and extra cheese on top. Serve with bread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nClassic Pasta Primavera Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 pound angel hair pasta or spaghetti\n1 small bunch broccoli, about 1 heaping cup of florets\n1 small zucchini, diced\n4 asparagus spears\n1/2 cup peas, fresh or frozen\n1/2 cup snow peas\n3 minced garlic cloves\n3 Roma or other paste tomatoes, seeded and diced\n12 basil leaves, chopped\n4 tablespoons butter\n1/4 cup chicken broth (use vegetable broth for vegetarian option)\n1/2 cup heavy cream\n1/2 cup grated parmesan cheese\nSalt\nMETHOD\n1 Blanch the broccoli, asparagus, snow peas: Get a large pot of water boiling. Salt it well. It should taste like the sea. Fill a large bowl with ice water. Boil the broccoli for 1 minute.\nAdd the asparagus and boil another minute. Add the snow peas and boil for 30 more seconds.\nRemove all the vegetables and plunge them into the ice water. Once they\xe2\x80\x99re cool, drain in a colander.\nIf you want, you can boil your pasta in the same pot you boiled the vegetables in, or you can start over and boil new water; I use the same water.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 zucchini and garlic, then add tomatoes: In a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan, heat the butter over medium-high heat. When the butter is hot, add the garlic and zucchini and saut\xc3\xa9 1 minute.\nAdd the diced tomatoes and saut\xc3\xa9 another 2 minutes, stirring often.\n3 Add broth, cream, blanched vegetables, peas: Pour in the chicken or vegetable broth and turn the heat to high to bring it to a boil.\nAdd the cream and toss in all the vegetables you boiled, plus the peas. Stir to combine.\nTurn the heat down until the cream-chicken broth mixture is just simmering, not boiling.\n4 Add Parmesan: Add the Parmesan cheese and stir to combine. If the sauce seems too thick \xe2\x80\x93 it should be pretty thick, but not gloppy \xe2\x80\x93 add some more chicken broth, cream or water.\n5 Boil the angel hair pasta: If you are using spaghetti, you will want to start cooking it before you begin saut\xc3\xa9ing the garlic and zucchini. Angel hair will only need 1-2 minutes to cook, vermicelli or spaghetti can take 8-12 minutes.\n6 Transfer cooked pasta to sauce and vegetables: As soon as the pasta is done, transfer it with tongs into the sauce and stir to combine.\nAdd the basil now, and taste for salt. Add salt if needed. Grind some black pepper over everything and serve immediately.\nYou will want a dry white wine with this, ideally a dry French white.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBroccoli Beef Stir Fry Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 3 to 4\nPro tip: Put the steak in the freezer for 15-30 minutes before slicing, it will be firmer and easier to slice thin.\nSee this recipe and more in Jaden's fabulous The Steamy Kitchen Cookbook: 101 Asian Recipes Simple Enough for Tonight's Dinner!\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the beef:\n1 teaspoon soy sauce\n1 teaspoon Chinese rice cooking wine or dry sherry\n1/2 teaspoon cornstarch\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n3/4 pound flank or sirloin, sliced thinly across the grain\nFor the sauce:\n2 tablespoons oyster sauce\n1 teaspoon Chinese rice cooking wine or dry sherry\n1 tablespoon soy sauce\n1/4 cup chicken broth\nFor the stir fry:\n3/4 pound broccoli florets\n2 tablespoons high-heat cooking oil\n2 cloves garlic, very finely minced or pressed through a garlic press\n1 teaspoon cornstarch, dissolved in 1 tablespoon water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the beef: Stir together the beef marinade ingredients (1 teaspoon soy sauce, 1 teaspoon Chinese rice wine, 1/2 teaspoon cornstarch, 1/8 teaspoon black pepper) in a medium bowl.\nAdd the beef slices and stir until coated. Let stand for 10 minutes.\n2 Prepare the sauce: Stir together the sauce ingredients (2 Tbsp oyster sauce, 1 teaspoon Chinese rice wine, 1 teaspoon soy sauce, 1/4 cup chicken broth) in a small bowl.\n3 Blanch or steam the broccoli: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Add the broccoli and cook until tender-crisp, about 2 minutes. Drain thoroughly.\n4 Stir-fry the beef: Heat a large frying pan or wok over high heat until a bead of water sizzles and instantly evaporates upon contact. Add the cooking oil and swirl to coat.\nAdd the beef and immediately spread the beef out all over the surface of the wok or pan in a single layer (preferably not touching).\nLet the beef fry undisturbed for 1 minute. Flip the beef slices over, add the garlic to the pan and fry for an additional 30 seconds to 1 minute until no longer pink.\n5 Add sauce, cornstarch, and broccoli: Pour in the sauce and the cornstarch slurry (1 teaspoon cornstarch dissolved in 1 tablespoon of water). Stir until the sauce boils and thickens, 30 seconds. Stir in the the broccoli.\n6 Serve immediately: Serve the stir fry immediately, either on its own or over cooked rice.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nSheet Pan Chicken with Roasted Broccoli and Potatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 servings\nMix up the seasonings in this recipe with any favorite spice mix!\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds chicken thighs, bone-in and skin on\n1 pound marble-sized baby potatoes (or small waxy potatoes cut into bite-sized pieces)\n1 tablespoon olive oil, divided\n1/2 teaspoon paprika (sweet, hot, or smoked \xe2\x80\x93 your choice)\n1 teaspoon garlic granules, or garlic powder\n1 teaspoon onion granules, or onion powder\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon pepper\nA pinch of cayenne (optional)\n1 1/2 pounds broccoli, cut into small florets\nZest of 1 lemon, to serve\nMince chives, to serve\nLemon wedges, to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Place baking sheet in oven and preheat to 500F for at least 15 minutes.\n2 Season the chicken and potatoes: Combine the chicken and potatoes in a bowl. Sprinkle with 1/2 tablespoon of oil, paprika, garlic granules, onion granules, 1/2 teaspoon of the salt, pepper, and cayenne.\nUse your hands to toss the chicken and potatoes with the oil and spice, mixing until everything is evenly coated.\n3 Roast the chicken and potatoes: Pull the hot pan out of the oven and place the chicken skin-side down. Scatter the potatoes around the chicken. Place the pan with the chicken and potatoes in the oven. and immediately lower the heat to 425F.\nRoast for 15 minutes.\n4 Add the broccoli: Toss the broccoli in a clean mixing bowl with the remaining 1/2 tablespoon of olive oil and sprinkle with the remaining 1/4 teaspoon salt. Remove the pan from oven (and close the oven door so the heat doesn't escape). Use tongs to flip the chicken and potatoes. Arrange the broccoli on the pan around the chicken.\nRoast for another 15 to 20 minutes until the chicken is cooked through and registers at least 165F in the thickest part of the thigh. The potatoes and broccoli should also be tender.\n5 To serve: Rest chicken thighs for 5 minutes before serving. Sprinkle the chicken, broccoli, and potatoes on the sheet pan with lemon zest and chives, then serve with lemon wedges\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nPotato and Broccoli Curry Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nIf you don't already have rice prepared, begin cooking a pot before you start making this recipe so that it's ready by the time you're ready to serve.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 large (1 1/4 pounds, 670 g) Yukon Gold or other golden potatoes\n3 big stalks broccoli with fist-sized crowns, or one larger melon-sized crown\n1 piece (2 inches) fresh ginger, peeled and coarsely chopped\n1 clove garlic, chopped\n1 can (14 to 16 ounces, 400 to 453 g) diced tomatoes\n3/4 cup roasted unsalted whole almonds\n1/2 teaspoon salt, or more to taste\n2 tablespoons canola oil\n1 teaspoon ground coriander\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/2 teaspoon red chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon ground turmeric\n3 cups vegetable stock\n1 stick cinnamon\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh cilantro, for garnish\n2 to 3 cups cooked rice, to serve\nSpecial equipment:\nDutch oven, or other large, heavy pot with a lid\nFood processor or blender\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the potatoes: Without peeling, cut the potatoes into 1/2-inch cubes. Steam the potatoes over boiling water in a vegetable steamer, tightly covered, for 10 minutes. When done, the potatoes should be firm, but tender and easily pierced with a fork. Drain.\n2 Prepare the broccoli: Cut the stems from the crown. Use a paring knife to peel the tough outer skin from the broccoli stems. Slice the stems into 1/4-inch pieces. Cut the crown into florets about 3-inches long.\n3 Make the sauce: In a food processor or blender, combine the ginger, garlic, tomatoes, 1/2 cup of the almonds (set aside the remaining 1/4 cup for garnish), and salt. Pulse the mixture until it is smooth.\n4 Cook the spices: In a Dutch oven or other large, heavy pot with a lid, heat the canola oil over medium heat. Add the chili powder, coriander, cumin, and turmeric. Cook, stirring, for 1 minute until the spices are fragrant.\n5 Simmer the sauce: Add the pureed tomato mixture to the pot with the spices \xe2\x80\x93 stand back as it may splutter as you add it to the pan. Cook, stirring, for 2 minutes. Add the stock and cinnamon stick. Bring to a boil. Simmer uncovered, stirring occasionally, for 10 minutes.\n6 Cook the vegetables: Add the potatoes and broccoli to the sauce and bring to a boil. Cover the pot and simmer for 8 minutes, or until all the vegetables are tender when pierced with a skewer.\n7 Serve the curry: Remove the cinnamon stick. Coarsely chop the remaining 1/4 cup almonds. Ladle the curry into bowls with rice and garnish with almonds and cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBroccoli Stir Fry with Ginger and Sesame Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon sesame seeds\n1/2 cup chicken or vegetable stock (use vegetable stock for vegan option)\n1 tablespoon soy sauce (use gluten-free soy sauce for gluten-free option)\n1 tablespoon dark sesame oil\nPeanut oil or canola oil\n1 pound broccoli florets, rinsed, patted dry, cut into bite-sized pieces\n2 cloves of garlic, minced (about 1 Tbsp)\n1 Tbsp minced fresh ginger\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toast the sesame seeds: Toast the sesame seeds by first heating a small, stick-free saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the sesame seeds and jiggle the pan so they spread out in a single layer.\nLet them cook until lightly browned, stirring occasionally, about 2-3 minutes. Do not walk away from them while cooking, as once they start to brown they can easily burn. Once lightly toasted remove from heat and put into a small bowl.\n2 Mix stock, soy sauce, sesame oil: Mix the stock, soy sauce, and dark sesame oil together in a small bowl, set aside.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the broccoli, garlic, ginger: Heat 1 tablespoon of peanut oil or canola oil in a large, cover-able saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the broccoli florets, stir to coat the florets with the oil, Saut\xc3\xa9 for about a minute.\nClear a space in the middle of the broccoli and add the ginger and garlic. Add a little more oil to the ginger and garlic (about a teaspoon) and saut\xc3\xa9 for half a minute, stirring just the garlic and ginger, until fragrant. Then stir the garlic and ginger in with the broccoli.\n4 Add the stock soy mixture and simmer: Add the stock soy sesame oil mixture to the pan. Bring to a simmer, reduce the heat and cover. Let cook for 2-3 minutes, until broccoli is still firm, but can be pierced with a fork. Remove from heat.\nRemove broccoli with a slotted spoon to a bowl. Return pan to heat, increase heat to high and boil down the liquid until just a couple tablespoons remain.\nTurn off heat, return broccoli to the pan, add the toasted sesame seeds, toss with the liquid. Put into a serving bowl.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBroccoli Cheddar Mac and Cheese Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nFor vegetarian option omit the Worcestershire sauce or use vegetarian Worcestershire sauce, and use vegetarian Parmesan.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 bunch of broccoli, cut into florets\nSalt\n2 cups dry elbow macaroni\n4 Tbsp butter\n3 Tbsp all purpose flour\n3 cups milk (low fat or whole)\n1/2 teaspoon dry mustard\nPinch of ground nutmeg\n1 1/2 teaspoons freshly grated black pepper\n1/4 teaspoon paprika\n1/2 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce\n2 cups (packed) grated sharp cheddar cheese (8 ounces), divided 1 1/2 cups and 1/2 cup\n1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Boil the pasta: Heat 4 quarts of water with 2 Tbsp salt in a large pot on high heat (for pasta). When the water comes to a boil, add the pasta and cook uncovered at a rolling boil for 2 minutes less than the time given on the pasta package instructions. (You want to cook the pasta al dente because it will continue to cook with the cheese mixture.) Rinse quickly in cold water to stop the cooking, drain and set aside.\n2 Steam the broccoli: While the pasta water is coming to a boil, steam the broccoli. Put a steamer rack in a pot with an inch of water. Bring to a boil. Add the broccoli florets, sprinkle with a little salt, and cover. Steam for 4 minutes. Then remove the broccoli from the pot to a bowl.\n3 Heat the milk: In a microwave or in a small pot on the stovetop, heat the milk until steamy. (Preheating the milk saves time in the next step when you are making the bechamel sauce.)\n4 Preheat oven broiler at 500\xc2\xb0F.\n5 Make roux with butter and flour: Melt 4 Tbsp butter in a thick-bottomed oven-safe pot on medium high heat. When the butter is melted and starts to foam sprinkle with 3 Tbsp of flour. Whisk to combine. Lower the heat to medium and cook for 1 to 2 minutes.\n6 Add milk and spices to roux: Pour in the hot milk and whisk vigorously to combine, breaking up any clumps of flour. Lower the heat to medium low and let cook, whisking frequently, until the sauce is smooth and thick enough to coat the back of a spoon.\nStir in the dry mustard, paprika, nutmeg, black pepper, Worcestershire sauce, and 1 teaspoon of salt.\n7 Whisk in cheeses: Whisk in 1 1/2 cups grated cheddar and the 1/2 cup of Parmesan cheese. Stir until the cheese is melted and the sauce is smooth.\n8 Stir in broccoli, top with cheese, broil: Stir in the broccoli and the pasta until well combined. Sprinkle the remaining 1/2 cup grated cheddar cheese on top and place under preheated broiler for 5 to 7 minutes until bubbly and lightly browned.\nAdd more salt and pepper to taste.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBroccoli and Cheddar Quesadillas Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 4 quesadillas (1 will serve two small kids)\nWe suspect you can prepare this with frozen broccoli, but we haven't tried it and we offer this caveat: Make sure you gently squeeze as much water out of the broccoli as possible once it's defrosted, and blot it with paper towels or a clean dish towel.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups broccoli florets\n12 ounces grated cheddar cheese (about 4 loosely-packed cups)\n4 large 12-inch flour tortillas\nVegetable oil, for tortillas\n1 medium avocado, sliced thin or chopped for serving\nSour cream, for serving\nDAD ADD: Quick Spicy Pico de Gallo\n1/2 red onion, minced\n1 ripe tomato, minced\n1 jalape\xc3\xb1o, seeded and minced\nFresh lime juice\nPinch of salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch and chop the broccoli: Bring a medium pot of salted water to a boil. Add the broccoli and blanch until it\xe2\x80\x99s bright green and fork tender, about 3 minutes. Then drain the broccoli, let it cool slightly and chop it finely.\n2 Make the pico de gallo: If you\xe2\x80\x99re using the Dad Add, now would be a good time to chop that stuff up (highly recommended). Combine the minced ingredients in a bowl and set aside.\n3 Preheat a large skillet over medium-low heat. If you haven't already grated your cheese, do it now.\n4 Assemble and cook the quesadillas: Brush one tortilla lightly with vegetable oil on one side and add it to the warmed skillet, oiled side down. Sprinkle a loosely packed cup of grated cheese (about 3 ounces) on one half of the tortilla. Top with 1/2 cup of chopped broccoli.\nFold the tortilla over to cover the filling and form a half-circle. Cook the quesadilla for about 3 minutes per side until it\xe2\x80\x99s crispy and the cheese is melted.\nRepeat with making the other quesadillas. (Though if you\xe2\x80\x99re good\xe2\x80\x94and your skillet is large enough\xe2\x80\x94you can make two at a time in the same skillet!)\n5 Serve the quesadillas: Cut the quesadillas into triangular segments, and serve with sour cream, avocado, and the spicy pico!\nHello! b'Print\nOven Roasted Broccolini Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 8 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIf you want, squeeze a little lemon juice over the broccolini, right before serving.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 bunches broccolini (about 1 1/4 pound total), trimmed\n3 cloves garlic, minced (about 3 teaspoons)\n4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt\nPepper\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven broiler.\n2 Line a roasting pan with aluminum foil. Spread the broccolini out in an even layer. Sprinkle the garlic over the broccolini. Drizzle the olive oil over the broccolini. Sprinkle with salt and pepper.\n3 Place under the broiler and cook for 6 to 8 minutes (keep an eye on it!), until lightly browned and the stalks are fork tender.\nServe immediately.\nHello! b"Print\nBroccoli, Chicken, and Almond Saut\xc3\xa9 Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4\nThe amounts are estimates, adjust to your taste.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 pound to 3/4 pound boneless skinless chicken breasts\nKosher salt\nExtra virgin olive oil\nYour favorite spice rub for grilling (optional)\n1 pound broccoli florets\n1/4 teaspoon chile flakes (more to taste)\n1/3 to 1/2 cup toasted almonds, roughly chopped\n1 teaspoon dark sesame oil\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Put salted water on to boil: Put a 2 quart pot of salted water (about 1 Tbsp of salt) on to boil. While the water is heating, start the chicken cooking in the next step.\n2 Season the chicken breasts: Place the chicken breasts in a bowl and sprinkle seasoning on all sides. Use at a minimum some salt. Or if you have a favorite spice rub, you can use that too.\n3 Sear and slice the chicken breasts: Heat a grill pan, or prepare a grill, for high, direct heat. (If you don't have a grill pan or grill, use a cast iron skillet, and only season the chicken with salt.)\nRub some olive oil all over the chicken breasts. Grill the breasts for a few minutes on each side to get some nice char marks, then lower the temperature to low and leave on the grill until the breasts are just almost cooked through.\nThey'll cook a little longer in the saut\xc3\xa9 pan, so they can still be a little pink in the middle at this point.\nRemove from pan or grill, set aside for a minute, then thinly slice.\n4 Blanch broccoli florets: Once the chicken has cooked and the water is boiling, add the broccoli florets to the salted boiling water. Allow the water to come back to a boil, and once boiling again, let cook for about 1 minute. Drain.\n5 Stir-fry chili flakes, broccoli, chicken, toasted almonds: Heat a tablespoon of olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on high heat. Add the red chili flakes. Once the red chili flakes are sizzling, add the broccoli florets, sliced grilled chicken, and toasted almonds.\nDrizzle dark sesame oil over the broccoli and chicken, sprinkle with salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste. Toss and cook until all of the chicken pieces are no longer at all pink in the center, a minute or two.\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBroccoli Slaw with Cranberry Orange Dressing Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesYield: 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the dressing (makes about 1 cup):\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n2 tablespoons dried sweetened cranberries, plumped up in warm water for 5 to 10 minutes, then drained\n1 teaspoon whole grain mustard\n2 tablespoons red wine vinegar\n1 tablespoon honey\n1 small clove garlic\n1 tablespoon orange juice\n1 teaspoon orange zest\n1/2 teaspoon Kosher salt, more to taste\n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1/4 cup mayonnaise\nFor the salad:\nAbout 6 stalks broccoli (about 4 cups grated; can substitute pre-grated packaged broccoli)\n2 cups grated carrots (from 4 to 6 carrots)\n2 cups shredded cabbage (Napa cabbage, green, or red cabbage)\n1 cup thinly sliced green onions\n1/2 cup sweetened dried cranberries, coarsely chopped\n1 teaspoon grated orange zest\n1/2 teaspoon (or more to taste) Kosher salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the broccoli: If using fresh broccoli stalks, cut them away from the broccoli crowns. Peel the tough outer layer with a vegetable peeler. Either use the grater blade of a food processor or the large holes of a box grater to grate the broccoli stalks. You should have about 4 cups of grated broccoli.\n2 Make the dressing: Put the balsamic and red wine vinegars, plumped dried cranberries, mustard, honey, garlic, orange juice, orange zest, and salt into a blender or a mini food processor and pulse until pur\xc3\xa9ed smooth.\nSlowly add the olive oil, while pulsing or blending, to form a good emulsion. Then add the mayonnaise and pulse until blended.\n3 Assemble the salad: Place grated broccoli stalks, carrots, cabbage, the onions, dried cranberries, orange zest, and Kosher salt into a bowl.\nAdd the dressing and toss to combine, until the dressing is evenly distributed.\nYou can make this several hours ahead of time before serving. Keep refrigerated until ready to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nSous Vide Chicken and Broccoli Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 2 hoursYield: 4 to 6 servings\nIf you are cooking the chicken from frozen, add thirty minutes onto the cooking time. You can cook the broccoli for an extra thirty minutes as well without any harm.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 medium chicken breasts (6 to 8 ounces each)\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\n1 lemon, sliced thin\n1 1/2 pounds broccoli florets\n2 teaspoons sesame oil\n1/2 teaspoon red pepper flakes\nPinch of Kosher, sea or table salt\nSpecial equipment:\nSous vide immersion circulator\nGallon-sized zip-top plastic freezer bags\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the water: Fill a pot with water and place your immersion circulator inside. Set the temperature to 158\xc2\xb0F and let the water come up to temperature.\n2 Prep the chicken: Season the chicken breasts with salt and pepper, and place them in gallon-sized zip-top freezer bag with the lemon arranged over top.\nMake sure the chicken is in a single layer. If you need to use two bags, that\xe2\x80\x99s better than having overlapping chicken pieces.\n3 Seal the bag: Seal the bag with as little air as possible by using water-displacement method to press out all the air: Just slowly lower the bag with the chicken into the water, letting the pressure of the water press the air out of the bag. Once the top of the bag reaches the water line and all the air has been pressed out, seal the bag. (Read more here.)\nYou can do this in the pot of water as it heats. (Just be careful if the water is already steaming!)\nSet the chicken aside on a kitchen towel until the water has finished heating. At this point you can also freeze the bag if you want to store the prepared chicken for later.\n4 Prepare the broccoli: Place the florets in a gallon-sized zip-top freezer bag, and season with red pepper flakes and sesame oil. To weight the broccoli down, add a few heavy soup spoons to the bag (or plan to place a heavy bowl over the top of the water bath to keep the broccoli submerged).\nUse the same water displacement technique to seal the broccoli bag.\n5 Cook the broccoli and chicken. Once the water has come to temperature, add the chicken and broccoli to the water and cook for 2 hours. Make sure your cooking bags are completely submerged in the water; place a heavy bowl over the pot if the spoons aren't keeping the broccoli submerged.\nI also like to rotate all the bags halfway through cooking to make sure they are cooking evenly, as sometimes they can get jostled around in the water.\nWhen cooking time ends, remove from the water and turn off the circulator.\n   6 Serve the chicken: Remove the chicken and broccoli and portion in lunch-sized portions or serve for dinner.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nCreamy Polenta with White Beans and Roasted Broccoli Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the polenta:\n2 cups water\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup yellow polenta\nFor the roasted broccoli:\n4 cups chopped broccoli\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon sea salt\nFor the white beans:\n1 cup white beans, homemade or canned, drained and rinsed\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1 tablespoon nutritional yeast\n1 teaspoon garlic powder\n1/4 teaspoon onion powder\nPinch of salt\nFor the chili oil:\n1/4 cup olive oil\n2 teaspoons chili flakes\nMETHOD\n1 Make the polenta: Bring the water and salt for the polenta to a boil over medium heat in a 2-quart saucepan. Once it's boiling, add the polenta and whisk until the polenta is fully incorporated.\nLower the heat (as low as it can go) and cook the polenta for 20 to 25 minutes, stirring every 5 to 10 minutes with a whisk to break up any clumps.\n2 Roast the broccoli: Heat your oven to 425\xcb\x9aF. Arrange the chopped broccoli on a rimmed baking sheet and toss with the 2 tablespoons of olive oil and salt. Roast until the broccoli is tender and beginning to char, about 15 to 20 minutes.\n3  Make the bean puree: While the polenta and broccoli are cooking, combine the drained beans with the olive oil, nutritional yeast, garlic powder, onion powder, and salt in the bowl of a food processor or in a high speed blender. Puree until smooth, adding a few tablespoons of water as needed to help smooth it out.\nWhen the polenta is done cooking, stir the bean puree into the polenta.\n4 Make the chili oil: Heat the oil in a small skillet. Add the chili flakes, remove from the heat, and let it rest until ready to serve. (You can make this ahead of time!)\n5 Assemble the bowls: Divide the polenta among four bowls. Top with the broccoli and a drizzle of the chili oil.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBroccoli Apple Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large bunch of broccoli (about 3 heads with stems)\n3 Tbsp butter\n1 cup of thinly sliced or finely chopped yellow or white onion\n1 good cooking apple (a non-tart apple such as Jonagold, golden delicious, McIntosh), peeled, cored, chopped\n3 cups of chicken stock\n1 cup of unfiltered apple juice or apple cider (not hard cider)\n4 sprigs of lemon thyme or thyme\n2 long strips of lemon zest\n1 Tbsp chopped fresh chives for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the broccoli: Separate the broccoli florets from the stems. Peel the outer tough skin of the stems with a vegetable peeler. Slice the stems into rounds and chop finely (a mini chopper food processor works well for this step).\n2 Cook the sliced onions and apples in butter: Heat a thick-bottomed medium large (4-quart) saucepan on medium heat. Melt the butter in the pan. Add the onion and the apple and lower the heat to low. Cover and cook for 10 minutes, until onions are translucent and apples are softened.\n3 Add broccoli, stock, cider, thyme, lemon zest: Add the broccoli florets and the chopped broccoli to the apple onion mixture. Add the stock and the cider.\nTie up the thyme sprigs with kitchen string and add to the pot. Add strips of lemon zest to the pot as well.\nIncrease the heat, bring to a boil, reduce the heat to maintain a low simmer, covered. Cook for 20 to 25 minutes.\n4 Pur\xc3\xa9e soup: Remove from heat. Remove thyme and lemon peels from the soup (discard)! Working in batches, filling up the blender bowl to no more than one third full at a time, pur\xc3\xa9e the soup.\n5 Adjust seasonings: Return soup to the pot, reheat and adjust seasonings to taste. Garnish with chopped fresh chives to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nRomanesco Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesMarinating time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nPrep the ingredients while you are steaming the romanesco in the first step.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 heads romanesco (2 1/2 to 3 pounds total)\nSalt\n2 stalks celery, thinly sliced\n1/2 large red onion, or one small red onion, thinly sliced\n1 cup loosely packed fresh parsley leaves\n2 tablespoons capers, rinsed and drained\n1 teaspoon grated lemon zest\nFreshly ground black pepper\nFor the dressing:\n1 clove garlic\n3 tablespoon red wine vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 anchovy, minced (optional, omit if cooking vegetarian)\n1/4 cup high quality extra virgin olive oil\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Steam romanesco wedges: Cut the romanesco heads into quarters, stalk to tip. Cut out the tough core and any outside green leaves. Cut again lengthwise.\nPlace into a steamer basket in a pot with about an inch of water.  Sprinkle the romanesco florets with a little salt. Bring water to a boil. Cover and steam until just tender, about 7 to 10 minutes.\nRemove romanesco florets from steamer, place into a bowl, and chill.\n2 Soak onion slices in water a few minutes: Thinly slice the red onion, across the grain. Place the red onion slices in a bowl and cover with water. This will take the onion-y edge off the onion, making it easier to eat raw in the salad.\n3 Make dressing: Smash the whole clove of garlic (not cut, just smash with the flat side of a chef's knife) and place in the bottom of a small bowl. Add the vinegar and salt, stir to dissolve the salt. Add the minced anchovy if using. Then whisk in the olive oil.\n4 Marinate the salad: Break up the wedges of romanesco into smaller chunks of florets. Place into a large serving bowl. Add celery, onions (drained of the water), parsley, capers, and lemon zest.\nRemove the garlic clove from the dressing and add dressing to the romanesco salad. Toss to coat with the dressing. Let marinate for at least 15 minutes, preferably an hour. Even better overnight.\nSprinkle with freshly ground black pepper to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nRoasted Broccoli Salad with Feta, Barley, and Pomegranate Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 servings\nIf you have the time, try roasting the broccoli for closer to 30 minutes. This gives them a deeply roasted flavor and makes the crowns of the florets extra-crispy.\nTo make this gluten-free, substitute cooked quinoa.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the salad:\n2/3 cup pearl barley\n2 pounds broccoli with the stems\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/4 teaspoon salt\nFreshly-ground black pepper\n1/3 cup sliced almonds\n4 handfuls fresh baby spinach leaves\n1/2 cup crumbled feta\nSeeds (arils) from 1/2 pomegranate, about 1/2 cup\nFor the dressing:\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n1 teaspoon Dijon mustard\nSalt and pepper, to taste\n1/3 cup olive oil\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the barley: Bring a medium saucepan of salted water to a boil. Add the barley, turn the heat to simmer, and cook, uncovered, for 30 minutes, or until tender. Drain and set aside.\n2 Meanwhile, begin heating the oven to 450F. Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment.\n3 Prep the broccoli: Separate the broccoli crowns from the stems. Separate the crowns into florets. Peel off the tough outer skin from the stems with a vegetable peeler, and then cut into bite-size pieces.\n4 Roast the broccoli: On the baking sheet, spread the broccoli florets and stems and sprinkle with the oil. Use your hands to massage the oil into the broccoli so it is well coated, and spread in one layer. Sprinkle with 1/4 teaspoon salt and some freshly-ground black pepper.\nRoast for 15 minutes, or until tender. Remove and let cool.\n5 Toast the almonds: As the broccoli roasts, spread the almonds in one layer on a baking sheet and toast in the oven for 3 to 5 minutes, or until golden. Watch carefully so they don't burn. Remove and let cool\n6 Make the dressing: In a small bowl, whisk the vinegar, lemon juice, mustard, salt and pepper together. Gradually whisk in oil.\n7 Assemble the salad: In a bowl, toss the barley, broccoli and spinach with the dressing. Transfer to plates or bowls and sprinkle with the almonds, feta and pomegranate seeds.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCreamy Shrimp and Broccoli Fettuccine Recipe\nYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\n2 to 3 cups broccoli florets, cut into bite-sized pieces\n1 pound fettuccine (use rice-pasta for gluten-free version)\nExtra virgin olive oil\n2 cups heavy cream\n2/3 cup white wine\n6 garlic cloves, thinly sliced\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1 pound peeled, deveined shrimp (if using frozen shrimp, defrost by running cold water over them for a few minutes)\n2 Tbsp finely chopped fresh parsley\nSalt\nMETHOD\n1 Heat salted water for pasta: Fill a large 8-quart stock pot at least half full with water and with 2 Tbsp of salt; bring to a boil.\n2 Blanch broccoli: While the water is the large stockpot is heating, bring a smaller saucepan (2-3 quarts) half filled with water to a boil. Blanch the broccoli in the boiling water for 1 minute. Remove from heat. Drain and run the broccoli under cold water to stop the cooking. Set aside.\n3 Cook and drain pasta: Cook the pasta in the large pot of boiling water according to the directions on the package (anywhere from 3 to 12 minutes, depending on the type of pasta you have) until al dente, or still slightly firm. Drain and toss with a little olive oil to keep from sticking.\n4 Make the sauce: While the pasta is cooking, combine the cream, wine, garlic, and black pepper in a large skillet and bring to a simmer over high heat. Reduce the heat to medium and simmer for 7 to 10 minutes until the mixture thickens.\n5 Add the shrimp: Add the shrimp and cook 2 to 3 minutes, until the shrimp have turned pink on all sides.\n6 Combine: Toss in the broccoli and the parsley. Mix in the fettuccini. Salt to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGrilled Pizza with Red Peppers, Broccoli, and Onions Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 2 12-inch pizzas, or 4 6-inch pizzas\nThe prep time reflects using store-bought dough and sauce.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 (1-pound) ball pizza dough, store-bought or homemade\nOlive oil for saut\xc3\xa9ing vegetables, and coating and brushing the dough\n1/2 cup sliced red onions\n1/2 bell pepper, thinly sliced\nKosher salt and freshly ground pepper to taste\n1/2 cup chopped broccoli\n1/2 cup sliced black olives\nCoarsely ground cornmeal or flour for rolling and stretching the dough\n1 cup tomato sauce, store-bought or homemade\n2 cups (8 ounces) shredded mozzarella cheese, preferably fresh\n1/4 cup slivered fresh basil leaves (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Divide and rest the dough: Divide the dough in half and gently shape into two balls. Gently coat each with olive oil and allow the dough to come to room temperature for about an hour, either in a large bowl or on the counter covered with a dishtowel.\n2 Prep the toppings: Heat 1 tablespoon olive oil in a large skillet with a lid over medium heat.  Add the onions and peppers, season with salt and pepper, and saut\xc3\xa9 for 6 minutes, until tender and lightly browned.\nAdd the chopped broccoli and saut\xc3\xa9 for another minute. Add 2 tablespoons water, and cover the pan with a lid. Cook for 1 minute, then remove the lid, and saut\xc3\xa9 for another minute or two until the broccoli is just tender and the water has evaporated. Stir in the olives and transfer the vegetables to a plate.\n3 Shape the pizza rounds: Sprinkle a lightly oiled baking sheet with cornmeal or flour. Use two baking sheets if you want more space or are making multiple pizzas. Gently begin to stretch or roll each ball into a 12-inch circle, or a rectangle shape.\nYou will need to stretch or roll it a bit, give it a few minutes to relax, and then continue to stretch it so that it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t keep springing back into a smaller shape, which is easier to do when your dough is at room temperature. The goal is about to get it about 1/4 inch thick (it will puff up on the grill). Give it one final stretch and don\xe2\x80\x99t worry if it\xe2\x80\x99s unevenly shaped.\n4 Heat the grill and gather your toppings: Heat a gas or charcoal grill to medium heat. Put your sauce in a small bowl, and bring that along with a brush, grill tongs, a grill spatula, the cheese, the dough, and the vegetables out to the grill.\n5 Grill the dough on the first side: Brush the top of the shaped pizza rounds with olive oil, and with a swift motion, pick up one round of the dough by one edge and flip it, oiled-side down, onto the grill. Repeat with the other round of dough.\nClose the lid and don\xe2\x80\x99t open it for 2 minutes, so the dough can rise a bit and firm up. Open the lid, peek underneath the dough using tongs, and check to see that it\xe2\x80\x99s firm on the bottom (no wet dough), lifts easily, and has some light grill marks.\nLightly brush the unbaked tops of the crusts with olive oil, and then flip them over to the other side.\n6 Immediately add the sauce and toppings: Carefully brush the surface of each crust with the sauce. Sprinkle the cheese evenly over the tops followed by the toppings.\nClose the lid and cook for 4 minutes. Lift the lid and check the pizzas: the cheese should be completely melted and the crust should have a nicely browned underside and barely bend when you lift it with tongs.\n7  Serve the pizzas: Remove the pizza from the grill with a large spatula, sprinkle with the fresh basil if using Let it sit for 1 to 2 minutes for the cheese to firm up slightly before cutting it into pieces.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSheet Pan Salmon and Broccoli with Miso Butter Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n4 tablespoons (1/2 stick) unsalted butter, at room temperature\n2 tablespoons red, white or yellow miso\n1 1/2 pounds whole broccoli heads or crowns, with stems\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\n4 (6-ounce) center-cut salmon fillets, 1 to 1 1/2 inches thick\n2 tablespoons chopped parsley, to garnish\n2 scallions, thinly sliced, to garnish\nBaked or roasted potatoes, to serve (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\nRimmed baking sheet\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven: Center a rack in the oven and preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xbaF.\n2 Make the miso butter: In a small bowl, stir the miso and butter until smooth.\n3 Prepare the broccoli: With a paring knife, cut a sliver off the tough end of the broccoli stalk. Separate the stalk from the head\xe2\x80\x94where the stalk starts to branch. Peel the stalk with a vegetable peeler and slice it into 3- to 4-inch sticks. Cut the crown lengthwise into 3 to 4 pieces.\n4 Roast the broccoli: Mound the broccoli in the center of the baking sheet. Sprinkle with the oil, salt, and pepper and use your hands to massage the oil over the broccoli.\nSpread the oiled broccoli on the baking sheet in one layer. Roast in the oven for 15 minutes, stirring and flipping the veggies halfway through. Remove the broccoli from the oven and turn the temperature down to 425\xc2\xbaF.\n5 Roast the salmon: Make space on the baking sheet for the salmon, and place the salmon on the sheet with the skin side down. Sprinkle lightly with salt and pepper. Use a butter knife to spread the miso butter over the fillets.\nRoast the salmon and broccoli together for 10 minutes longer, or until a thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the salmon registers 135\xc2\xbaF. Remove from the oven.\n6 Finish under the broiler. Move an oven rack close (3- to 4-inches) to the broiler and turn on the broiler. If necessary, spread the now-softened miso butter evenly over the fillets, and broil for 1 to 2 minutes, or until the fillets are charred at the edges.\nRemove and let the salmon rest for 5 minutes. Sprinkle with parsley and chopped scallions and serve with baked potatoes, if you like.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nLoaded Baked Potatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n6-8 strips bacon\n6 medium-large russet potatoes, scrubbed well\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 pound fresh broccoli, cut into florets (or use frozen)\n8 ounces grated sharp cheddar cheese\nTo serve:\nSour cream\nFresh chives\nDad Add: Quick Home Fries (serves 2):\n1 baked potato, diced\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon seasoned salt\nEggs, for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the bacon: Line a baking sheet with foil, then top with a wire baking rack (cookie cooling rack). Lay the bacon strips on the wire rack perpendicular to the wires, making sure the bacon pieces don\xe2\x80\x99t overlap.\n2 Bake the bacon and scrub the potatoes: Place the bacon in a cold oven and set the temperature to 375\xc2\xb0F. Bake for 15-20 minutes. Check the bacon around the 18-minute mark. Some types of bacon cook faster than others. (See How to Make Bacon in the Oven for full details.)\nWhile the bacon bakes, scrub potatoes well and then stab each potato about 10 times with a fork to prevent the possibility of a potato exploding in the oven. (It can happen!)\nRemove the bacon from the oven; transfer to a paper towel-lined plate.\n3 Bake the potatoes: Increase the heat to 400\xcb\x9aF. Place potatoes on a baking sheet, drizzle well with olive oil, and sprinkle with coarse salt. Bake potatoes for about an hour until the skins are shriveled slightly and the potatoes are very tender. (See How to Bake a Potato for more details.)\n4 Blanch the broccoli: While the potatoes bake, cook your broccoli. Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add a big pinch of salt to the water to season it. Add broccoli to the water and boil for 3 minutes until the broccoli is just tender, but not mushy at all.\nDrain broccoli once it is tender and set aside for assembly. We will warm everything up once the potatoes are assembled at the end.\n5 Open the potatoes: Once your potatoes are baked, let them cool slightly so you can handle them. Cut each potato down the center, being careful not to cut all the way through. Then cut two perpendicular cuts near the end of each potato; this will allow you to open each potato up easier. I like to use a small paring knife to slice up the interior of the potato, making it easier to unfold and stuff.\n5 Stuff the potatoes: Sprinkle some cheese over the potato. I like a lot of cheese, but feel free to use as much or as little as you\xe2\x80\x99d like. Top with about 1/2 cup of cooked broccoli and 1 piece of crumbled bacon. Sprinkle the broccoli with more cheese and more broccoli or bacon depending on the size of the potato and the size of your appetite!\n6 Reheat the potatoes: Place the stuffed potato back in the oven for 5-10 minutes to really melt the cheese and warm the fillings.\n7 Serve: Top the warm potatoes with sour cream and chives and serve.\nLeftovers: Store any extra potatoes before filling them. Leftover potatoes can be used within a week for baked potatoes, loaded potatoes, or quick Dad Add home fries!\n8 How to Make Dad Add Home Fries: Cut a leftover potato into about 1/4-inch cubes. Into a medium skillet set over medium heat, add the olive oil. When the oil starts to shimmer, add the potato cubes and seasoned salt. Cook for 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes are crispy and browned on the edges. Remove from skillet and serve with eggs.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nCheesy Crustless Quiche with Broccoli and Ham Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nVegetable oil spray (for the pan)\n1 medium stalk broccoli, stem and crown\n5 ounces ham steak, cubed\n1 1/2 cups grated cheddar (about 7 ounces)\n2 large eggs\n3 large egg yolks\n1 1/2 cups heavy cream\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper\nSpecial equipment:\n9-inch round baking dish or pie pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the oven and baking dish: Place a rack in the center of the oven. Preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. Spray a 9-inch round ceramic baking dish or pie pan with vegetable oil. Have a baking sheet on hand.\n2 Prepare the broccoli: Bring a large saucepan of salted water to a boil. Cut a sliver off the bottom of the broccoli stem and peel the stem with a vegetable peeler. Slice the stem into 1/2 inch-thick, bite-size pieces. Cut the broccoli crown into small florets.\nCook the broccoli in the boiling water for 4 to 5 minutes, or until tender. Strain the broccoli to remove the water, and spread the broccoli over the bottom of the baking dish.\n3 Add the ham and cheese to the baking dish: Distribute the ham cubes over the broccoli. Reserve 1/2 cup of the cheese to sprinkle on top of the filled quiche. Sprinkle the remaining cheese over the broccoli.\n4 Make the custard: In a medium bowl, whisk the eggs and egg yolks together. Whisk in the cream, salt, and pepper. Pour the cream mixture over the filling in the pan and sprinkle the top with the reserved cheese.\n5 Bake the quiche: Set the baking dish on the baking sheet and place it in the oven. Decrease the oven temperature to 350\xc2\xbaF.\nBake the quiche for 30 minutes, or until the top is golden and the center puffs, but is still slightly wobbly in the center.\n6 Cool the quiche: Set the baking dish on a wire rack to cool for at least 30 minutes before cutting into wedges. Quiche can be served warm or at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nCharred Skillet Broccoli Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 4 as a side dish\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re comfortable prepping as you work, you can start cooking the first half of your chopped-up broccoli as you continue chopping the rest of it, adding it to the hot skillet as you go.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 medium head broccoli (about 1 pound)\n1 tablespoon olive oil\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the broccoli: Rinse the broccoli. Trim off and discard the woody lower part of the stem (likely an inch or half an inch). Cut the remaining stem off from the head.\nWith a vegetable peeler, peel the outer layers of the stem off and discard them. Cut the tender centers into coins across the grain, then chop those up into little bits. Shred up the blossom ends of the broccoli. You\xe2\x80\x99re aiming for pieces between the size of a pea and an almond.\n2 Cook the broccoli: Set a large skillet over medium-high heat for a minute or less. Add the olive oil; when it shimmers, add the broccoli. Stir it around every minute or so. Season generously with salt.\nAfter 5 minutes of cooking, reduce the heat incrementally so the broccoli does not burn. You\xe2\x80\x99ll end at medium heat. Some bits will get charred and brown, while others steam and become soft and sweet. This is exactly what you want.\nAfter about 10 total minutes of cooking, your broccoli will be ready. The volume will have reduced by about half, and there will not be any raw pieces of broccoli left.\n3 Season and serve: Taste the broccoli, and, if needed, adjust the seasoning with salt and pepper. Serve hot. Leftovers will keep about 5 days in the refrigerator, or 6 months in the freezer.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nLemony Broccoli Rabe with White Beans Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 bunch broccoli rabe, ends trimmed (about 2 1/2 pounds)\n1/2 teaspoon salt, or more to taste\n4 tablespoons olive oil\n1 lemon, very thinly sliced\n1 clove garlic, chopped\n2 (15-ounce) cans cannellini beans, drained and rinsed\n1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper\n1/2 cup water, or more if needed\n1 lemon, cut into wedges, for serving\nExtra crushed red pepper, for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the broccoli rabe: Cut any thick stems (with leaves still attached) in half lengthwise. Then cut all the stems into 4-inch pieces.\n2 Blanch the broccoli rabe: Bring a saucepan of water to a boil and add 1/4 teaspoon of the salt. Add the broccoli rabe and cook for 1 minute, turning them in the water occasionally so they cook evenly.\nDrain and rinse with very cold water until the broccoli is no longer warm. Pat dry with paper towels.\n2 Cook the lemon slices: In a large heavy skillet over medium-high heat, heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Add the lemon slices, overlapping if necessary, and cook without disturbing for 2 minutes. Turn and cook the other sides for 2 minutes more. The slices should be browned in spots. Transfer to a clean plate.\n3 Warm the white beans: In the same skillet over medium heat (no need to clean), heat the remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil. Add the garlic, white beans, red pepper, and remaining 1/4 teaspoon salt. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 2 minutes. Add the water and bring to a boil, lower the heat, and simmer for 1 minute more.\n4 Add the broccoli rabe to the pan and cook: Add the broccoli rabe and cook, stirring often, for 3 minutes, or until it is tender when the stems are pierced with the tip of a knife. During cooking, add more water if the pan seems dry. Stir in the lemon slices and turn them in the mixture until the slices are just heated through.\nTaste for seasoning and add more salt, if you like. Serve with lemon and red pepper.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBroccoli Rabe with Caramelized Onions Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 yellow onion, sliced into slivers, lengthwise (with the grain)\n1 large bunch of broccoli rabe (raab, rapini), rinsed and cut into 2-inch long pieces\n2-3 garlic cloves, sliced\n1/4 teaspoon red chili flakes\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the onions: Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the onions, spread out in a thin layer. Cook, stirring occasionally until softened and then lightly browned.\n(Tip: to speed up the caramelization process you can sprinkle a pinch of sugar over the onions.) If the onions start to dry out at all, lower the heat (you can add a little water to them too.) They should brown, but not get dried out.\n2 Blanch the broccoli rabe: After you start the onions, bring a large pot of water to a boil. The onions take at least 15 minute to cook, so you'll have time to get the water boiling. Salt the water (about a tablespoon of salt for 3 quarts of water).\nPrepare an ice bath, fill a large bowl half way with ice water.\nAdd the rabe to the boiling water. Blanch for 1 minute. Use a slotted spoon to remove from the boiling water and put in the ice bath to stop the cooking. Shocking the rabe with ice water will also help keep the rabe bright green colored.\nNote that some people blanch their rabe, some do not. Rabe can be rather bitter, so blanching will help take the edge off of the bitterness. If your rabe isn't particularly bitter, or you like bitter greens, you can easily skip this blanching step.\nDrain the ice water from the rabe. Use a clean tea towel to gently wring out the excess moisture from the rabe.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the rabe and onions with chili flakes and garlic: Once the onions are lightly browned, remove them from the pan to a bowl. Using the same pan, add another tablespoon of olive oil and heat the pan on high heat. Add the chili flakes. Once the chili flakes start to sizzle, add the garlic.\nOnce the garlic just starts to brown at the edges add the broccoli rabe and the onions.\nToss the rabe mixture so that it gets well coated with the olive oil. Cook on high heat until most of the moisture is gone, about 5 minutes if you blanched first, a minute or too longer if you skipped the blanching.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nShell Pasta with Sausage and Greens Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nFor extra tang, squeeze a little lemon juice over everything before serving.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound (450 g) shell or ear-shaped "Conchiglie" pasta\nSalt\n1 1/2 cups (350 ml) water or chicken stock\n12 ounces (340 g) Italian sausage, sweet or hot, or a mixture of both\n12 ounces (340 g) bunch of kale, broccoli rabe, or other green, chopped (if using kale, or leafy green, remove and discard center stem)\n2 green onions, chopped\n6 garlic cloves, minced\n1/4-1/2 teaspoon hot red pepper flakes\n1/4 cup (25 g) grated fresh Parmesan cheese\nMETHOD\n1 Cook pasta in salted water: Bring 2 quarts of salted water to a boil (1 tablespoon of salt for 2 quarts of water). Add the pasta and cook as directed on the package, until al dente.\n2 Cook the greens in salted water: While pasta is being prepared, heat 1 1/2 cups of water with 1/2 teaspoon of salt in a saucepan until simmering. (Can use chicken stock instead for added flavor). Add the kale or rabe and cook for 8 minutes, or until tender. Strain and set aside.\n3 Lightly brown the sausage: While greens are cooking, remove the sausage from their casings (if in links) and crumble onto a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan. Heat on medium heat and gently cook until lightly browned, about 8 minutes. Use a slotted spoon to remove the sausage from the pan to a bowl, set aside.\n4 Cook green onions and garlic: Add the chopped green onions to pan, saut\xc3\xa9 until soft. Add garlic and cook for a minute more.\n5 Combine pasta, onions, sausage, greens, Parmesan: When pasta is done, drain and add to the pan with the green onions. Add the sausage and kale (or rabe) to the pan and toss to combine. Sprinkle with Parmesan cheese. Add chile pepper flakes to taste.\nNote: You might want to try experimenting with adding some saut\xc3\xa9ed bell pepper.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBroccoli Rabe with Pasta and Sun Dried Tomatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4 as a side dish\nFeel free to toss in a few salty black olives, toasted pine nuts or walnuts, and or a dash of lemon juice.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound (a large bunch) broccoli rabe, rinsed, cut into 1 1/2 to 2 inch pieces\nSalt\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon red pepper flakes (depending on how spicy you like things)\n1 large clove garlic, chopped (about 1 to 2 teaspoons chopped)\n2 ounces sun dried tomatoes (packed in oil), roughly chopped\n8 ounces penne pasta (or other favorite short pasta)\n1/2 ounce freshly grated Parmesan cheese\nMore salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch the broccoli rabe: Bring two large pots (4-quart pots filled at least half-way) of water to a boil, one pot for blanching the broccoli rabe, the other for the pasta.\nWhichever pot comes to a boil first, into it place the broccoli rabe. Blanch only for one minute, then use a slotted spoon to remove the rabe from the hot water to a large bowl of ice water to stop the cooking.\nDrain the rabe and pat dry with paper towels.\n2 Cook the pasta: Typically penne pasta takes about 10 minutes to cook to al dente. So start the pasta before you start saut\xc3\xa9ing the rabe.\nWhen the water comes to a rolling boil, add a tablespoon of salt to it, let the salt dissolve, then add the pasta.\nOnce the water returns to a boil, start the timer. Let the pasta cook, at a rolling boil, uncovered, for whatever time is necessary to cook it to al dente, cooked through but still a little firm.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the blanched broccoli rabe with garlic and chili flakes: Once the pasta is in the water, heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium to medium high heat.\nAdd the chopped garlic and the red chile flakes. Cook until the garlic just begins to brown at the edges.\nThen add to the pan the blanched broccoli rabe. Toss to coat with the olive oil, chile flakes, and garlic. Sprinkle with salt.\n4 Add sun dried tomatoes, pasta, and Parmesan: Cook the broccoli rabe about 5 minutes, until just tender. Stir in the chopped sun dried tomatoes.\nWhen the pasta is done, drain it and add it to the rabe.\nSprinkle everything with black pepper and the grated Parmesan cheese. Toss to combine.\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nOven Roasted Broccolini Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 8 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIf you want, squeeze a little lemon juice over the broccolini, right before serving.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 bunches broccolini (about 1 1/4 pound total), trimmed\n3 cloves garlic, minced (about 3 teaspoons)\n4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt\nPepper\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven broiler.\n2 Line a roasting pan with aluminum foil. Spread the broccolini out in an even layer. Sprinkle the garlic over the broccolini. Drizzle the olive oil over the broccolini. Sprinkle with salt and pepper.\n3 Place under the broiler and cook for 6 to 8 minutes (keep an eye on it!), until lightly browned and the stalks are fork tender.\nServe immediately.\nHello! b"Print\nRoasted Broccolini with Creamy Mustard Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nLook for broccolini near the broccoli and other leafy green vegetables in the produce section of your grocery store. Substitute regular broccoli if you can't find broccolini.\nYou will likely have leftover sauce. Store for up to a week and serve over any other roasted vegetables, or use as a dipping sauce.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the sauce (makes 1 1/4 cups):\n1 cup raw unsalted cashews\n1/2 cup water\n1/4 cup fresh lemon juice\n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil\n2 tablespoons Dijon mustard\n1 teaspoon apple cider vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon onion powder\n1/2 teaspoon garlic powder\n1/2 teaspoon fine sea salt (or regular salt)\n1/8 teaspoon red pepper flakes\nFor the broccolini:\n1 pound (460g) broccolini\n3 1/2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, plus more to taste\n2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh garlic\n1/2 cup sliced raw almonds\n1 1/2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest, plus more to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Soak the cashews for the sauce: Soak the cashews for 2 hours in a bowl covered with filtered water, then drain. Alternatively, quick-soak the cashews by covering them with boiled water and soaking for 10 minutes, then draining.\n2 Preheat the oven to 425F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.\n3 Roast the broccolini: Toss the broccolini with 2 tablespoons of the olive oil, 1/4 teaspoon of the salt, and the pepper. Roast for 10 to 15 minutes or until tender and slightly crispy.\n4 While the broccolini is roasting, make the dressing. Throw the soaked and drained cashews, water, lemon juice, olive oil, mustard, vinegar, onion powder, garlic powder, salt, and red pepper flakes into your blender. Blast on high for 30 to 60 seconds until smooth and creamy.\n5 Prepare the garlic and almonds: In a small pan over medium-low heat, warm the remaining 1 1/2 tablespoons of olive oil and cook the garlic for 1 to 2 minutes until fragrant and just starting to brown.\nAdd the almonds, and stir for about 1 minute, or until just warmed. Stir in the lemon juice and zest. Remove the pan from heat.\n6 Top the broccolini and serve: Remove the roasted broccolini from the oven and transfer to a platter. Sprinkle the almond mixture over the top of the broccolini, and season with additional lemon juice, zest, salt, and pepper to taste.\nDrizzle with a small amount of the sauce, and pass the remaining sauce at the table. Serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nOatmeal Chocolate Chip Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes about 30 cookies\nBrown the butter first, as the butter is cooling, prep the other ingredients. Never browned butter before? See our detailed how-to here: How to Brown Butter.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup (2 sticks, 8 ounces, 225 g) unsalted butter\n1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon nutmeg\n1 cup brown sugar, packed\n1/2 cup white granulated sugar\n2 large eggs, lightly beaten\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n2 tablespoons water\n1 1/2 cups semi-sweet or bittersweet chocolate chips\n1 cup chopped pecans (optional)\n1 cup sweetened, shredded coconut (optional)\n3 cups rolled oats (old fashioned or quick oats, do not use steel cut or instant)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the oven and the baking sheets. Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Butter two large cookie sheets, or line them with silicone mats or parchment paper.\n2 Brown the butter: Place sticks of butter in a thick-bottomed medium sized stainless steel saucepan or other pan with a light, reflective interior. Otherwise you won\'t be able to see the butter browning.\nHeat on medium. Melt the butter, whisking so that the butter melts evenly.\nContinue to cook the butter. As it cooks, the butter will foam up, and then the foam will subside. Whisk frequently to check underneath the bubbly surface.\nAt some point, browned bits will form at the bottom of the pan and the butter will begin to smell nutty. Watch carefully\xe2\x80\x94it\'s easy for the butter to go from browned to burnt.\nWhen the browned bits begin to form, remove the pan from the heat. Pour the melted butter, with the browned bits, into a glass or metal bowl. Allow to cool a bit while you prepare the other ingredients.\n3 Mix the dry ingredients: Vigorously whisk together the flour, salt, baking soda, nutmeg, and cinnamon together in a large bowl.\n4 Make the dough: Place the browned butter (along with the browned bits) in the bowl of a stand mixer. Add the brown and white sugar. Beat on medium-high until smooth, about 3 minutes.\nAdd the eggs and vanilla. Beat for 3 more minutes on medium speed until smooth and light.\n5 Stir in flour mixture and some water: Using a wooden spoon, stir the flour mixture into the batter.\nStir in 2 tablespoons of water (note that if you are using jumbo eggs, and not large eggs as the recipe calls for, you will probably not need this much extra liquid.)\n6 Stir in chocolate chips and oats: Stir in the chocolate chips, and the pecans and shredded coconut (if using). Stir in the rolled oats.\nUp to this point you can make the dough up to a day and a half ahead and store in the refrigerator.\n7 Spoon cookie dough onto lined cookie sheets: Spoon out heaping tablespoons of cookie dough and lay them on lined cookie sheets. Make sure you have about 2" of space between each cookie, as they will flatten a little and spread on the cookie sheet as they bake.\n8 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 10 minutes, or until they are just brown around the edges, but still soft in the center. They will firm up as they cool. (If you want them crispier, you can bake them from 12 to 14 minutes, but 10 minutes will yield a more chewy cookie.)\n9 Cool: Take the cookies out of the oven and let them cool for two or three minutes on the hot baking sheet. Then, using a metal spatula, carefully transfer the still-hot cookies to a wire rack to cool.\nThey will continue to be soft until completely cooled. Once completely cooled, store in an airtight container for 3 to 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nHow to Make Brown Butter\nCook time: 5 minutes\nINGREDIENTS\nUnsalted butter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Melt the butter: Heat a thick-bottomed skillet on medium heat. Add the butter (if you slice it, it will melt more evenly) whisking frequently. Continue to cook the butter.\n2 Watch for brown specs and nutty aroma: Once melted the butter will foam up a bit, then subside. Watch carefully as lightly browned specks begin to form at the bottom of the pan. Smell the butter; it should have a nutty aroma.\n3 Remove from heat and pour into a bowl to stop the butter from cooking further and perhaps burning.\nIt's pretty easy to overcook browned butter and go from brown to burnt. If the butter starts to blacken, I suggest dumping it and starting over (something I've had to do on occasion), unless you want beurre noir which has a different taste than nutty brown butter.\nIf you want to make sage brown butter sauce, add some fresh sage leaves to the butter once it has melted. Allow the butter to brown and remove from heat.\nUse browned butter immediately or store covered in the refrigerator for future use.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nButternut Squash with Brown Butter and Thyme Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 3 to 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 pounds butternut squash, peeled, seeds removed, flesh diced into 1/2-inch pieces (about 4 cups)\n3 tablespoons butter\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh thyme (or 1 teaspoon of dried)\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the butter: Heat a large skillet on medium heat. Add the butter, whisking frequently. Once melted the butter will foam up a bit, then subside. Honey-colored browned milk solids will begin to form. The butter should have a wonderful nutty aroma.\nRemove from heat. Add the thyme, whisking continuously. If using fresh thyme, the mixture will foam up a bit.\n(Note that it doesn't take much time to go from browned butter to burnt butter. You will want to remove the pan from the heat element and place it on a cool surface to help stop the cooking of the butter. If the butter burns, I recommend dumping it and starting over, something I've had to do on occasion when not paying close attention.)\n2 Brown the cubed squash in the butter: Add the cubed butternut squash pieces to the pan and return the pan to the burner, heating to medium high.\nUse a wooden or metal spoon to stir the squash pieces so they are all well coated with the butter thyme mixture.\nSprinkle generously with salt and pepper.\nSpread the squash pieces out in an even layer and let cook, without stirring, so that they brown a bit on one side (several minutes). Stir and spread the pieces out again and let cook without stirring so more sides get browned.\n3 Lower the heat, cover and cook: Reduce the heat to low, cover the pan, and let cook until the squash is tender, 10 to 20 minutes, depending on how big you cut the pieces.\nAdd more salt and pepper to taste, sprinkle with a bit more chopped fresh thyme before serving.\nHello!
