I like to use either a cast iron or stainless steel skillet -- nonstick and enameled cast iron cookware usually aren't meant to be used above 500\xc2\xbaF, so they aren\xe2\x80\x99t broiler safe.\nWhen the oil is shimmering, sear the chicken cutlets for 3 minutes on one side, just so they get a little bit of color.\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s ok if they are not cooked through, since they will finish cooking in the oven.\n4 Flip and season the cutlets: Flip the cutlets over, then spoon on the bruschetta topping and sprinkle with the mozzarella and Parmesan cheese. Let them cook in the pan for 1 1/2 to 2 minutes.\n5 Broil the chicken: Place the skillet under the broiler. Broil until the cheese is bubbly and brown and the chicken is cooked through, about 3 minutes.\nCheck for doneness by cutting into one of the cutlets to see if it\xe2\x80\x99s opaque in the center, or by checking the temperature of one of the cutlets with an instant-read thermometer (the chicken should be 165\xc2\xbaF or higher in the center).\nAt this point, your chicken should be ready, but if you used cutlets that were thicker than 1/4-inch you may have to return it to the stovetop to cook for another 1-3 minutes.\n5 Serve: Sprinkle the parsley on top of the chicken and serve the cutlets hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nRoasted Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, rinsed, ends trimmed, and rough outer leaves of larger sprouts removed\n1 tablespoon minced garlic (about 3 cloves)\n1 teaspoon lemon juice (can sub apple cider vinegar)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1/4 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Prep the Brussels sprouts: Place the trimmed Brussels sprouts in a large bowl. Toss with garlic and lemon juice. Toss the sprouts with olive oil to coat them well.\nSpread the Brussels sprouts out in a large cast iron frying pan or roasting pan in a single layer with plenty of space between them. Sprinkle generously with salt (at least half a teaspoon) and a few turns of black pepper.\n3 Roast in oven: Put the sprouts in oven on the top rack, roast for 25-30 minutes, stirring the sprouts about halfway through the cooking.\nAdjust the timing depending on the size of the sprouts and your particular oven. When the sprouts are ready, they should be nicely browned and some of the outside leaves crunchy. The interior should be cooked through, so that the sprouts are easily pierced with a fork.\nIf the sprouts look like they are getting too browned (they should be well browned, not burnt), move them to a lower rack or lower the heat.\nIf after cooking for 30 minutes the sprouts aren't browned enough, put them under the broiler (or increase the heat to 500\xc2\xb0F) for 5 minutes.\n4 Sprinkle with Parmesan: Toss with Parmesan (if using) and add more salt to taste to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nBrussels Sprouts Gratin Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 6 to 8\nThe best way to trim the brussels sprouts is to slice of 1/4-inch from the bottom stem end with a paring knife. This will make it easier to peel off any outer tough leaves. Then when cutting the brussels sprouts in half, place them cut-side down on the cutting board to help stabilize them.\nYou can easily make this dish vegetarian by leaving out the pancetta in step 2. Just add an additional tablespoon of butter in step 3.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds Brussels sprouts, trimmed of outer leaves and sliced in half\nSalt\n2 ounces pancetta, diced\n1 tablespoon butter\n3 shallots, peeled, halved, and sliced\n2 tablespoons all purpose flour\n1 3/4 cup whole milk\nScant pinch of freshly ground nutmeg\nThyme leaves from 2 sprigs of thyme or 1/2 teaspoon dry thyme\n4 ounces of grated Gruyere cheese, divided 3 ounces and 1 ounce\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch the Brussels sprouts: Heat a large pot of salted water, 4 quarts of water, 1 tablespoon salt. Blanch the halved Brussels sprouts for 3 to 4 minutes, until just barely tender. Remove from pot, drain, rinse with cold water to stop the cooking, set aside.\n2 Brown the pancetta and render the fat: Place diced pancetta in a large pot on medium low heat. Cook until most of the fat is rendered, about 8 to 10 minutes. Remove the pancetta from the pan, set aside, leaving the rendered fat in the pan.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 shallots: Add butter to the pot and melt on medium heat. Add the shallots and gently cook until softened, about 4 to 5 minutes.\n4 Make roux: Add the flour to the butter shallot mixture to make a roux, whisk for 1 to 2 minutes.\nSlowly add the milk while stirring with a wooden spoon until the roux is incorporated into the milk.\nCook over medium low heat for several minutes, stirring, until the sauce thickens and coats the back of your spoon. Add fresh thyme and sprinkle with nutmeg.\n5 Add cheese, then half of the pancetta to white sauce: Add 3 ounces of grated Gruyere cheese into the white sauce and stir until the cheese is melted and incorporated into the sauce. Add half of  the cooked pancetta back to the sauce. Taste and add more salt if necessary.\n6 Add Brussels sprouts, transfer to gratin dish, sprinkle with pancetta, more cheese, bake: Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Butter an 8"x12" gratin dish or casserole . Add the Brussels sprouts into the cheese sauce. Transfer the cheesy Brussels sprouts into the casserole or gratin dish. Sprinkle with the remaining pancetta and the remaining 1 ounce of grated Gruyere cheese.\nBake for 25 minutes until top is lightly browned and bubbly. Remove from oven and let sit for 10 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nRoasted Brussels Sprouts with Pomegranate-Balsamic Glaze Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 6 servings\nThe pomegranate-balsamic glaze can be made ahead and will keep in the refrigerator for up to a month.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the glaze:\n1 cup pomegranate juice\n2/3 cup balsamic vinegar\n2 tablespoons brown sugar\nFor the Brussels sprouts:\n1 1/2 pounds Brussels sprouts\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 to 2/3 cup pomegranate arils\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the glaze: Combine the pomegranate juice, balsamic vinegar, and brown sugar in a saucepan and bring to boil over medium heat. Reduce the heat to medium-low and let the liquid simmer for 25 to 30 minutes, until reduced to a syrupy glaze that coats the spoon. Stir occasionally. You should have about 2/3 cup of pomegranate balsamic glaze when done. (Once cool, store the glaze in the refrigerator for up to a month.)\n2 Preheat oven to 375F. Move the oven racks to the upper third and lower third positions. Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.\n3 Roast the Brussels sprouts: Trim the ends of the Brussels sprouts and slice them in half. Chop very large sprouts into quarters. Toss with the olive oil and a good pinch of salt. Divide the sprouts between 2 baking sheets and roast for 20 to 25 minutes, stirring halfway through.\n4 Toss the sprouts with the glaze: Let the Brussels sprouts cool for a few minutes before tossing them with 2 to 3 tablespoons of the pomegranate balsamic reduction and the pomegranate arils. Taste and add more glaze if you like. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBalsamic Roasted Brussels Sprouts and Shallots Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds Brussels sprouts, tough outer leaves removed, base trimmed, sprouts cut in half\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nSeveral large shallots, peeled and thickly sliced, about a cup\n4 cloves garlic, peeled, sliced in half\n2 tablespoons plus 2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar\nSalt\nPepper\n3/4 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves or 1/4 teaspoon dried thyme\n1/2 cup walnuts, toasted (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 shallots in olive oil: Heat the olive oil in an oven-safe saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the shallots, spread them out in an even layer, lower the heat to medium low, and let them cook for 6 to 8 minutes, until softened and lightly browned.\n2 Add Brussels sprouts, garlic, balsamic: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Add the Brussels sprouts and the garlic to the shallots. Cook for 5 to 6 minutes more, until the sprouts begin to brown.\nDrizzle with 2 tablespoons of balsamic vinegar. Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Toss to coat.\n3 Bake in oven: Place in oven, uncovered. Roast at 425\xc2\xb0F for 15 to 20 minutes, until cooked through and caramelized on the edges.\n4 Sprinkle with balsamic, thyme, walnuts, salt, pepper: Remove from oven. Sprinkle with remaining 2 teaspoons of balsamic vinegar, the thyme, and toasted walnuts (if using). Stir to combine. Add more salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBrussels Sprouts with Bacon and Chestnuts Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 6-8 as a side\nChestnuts are delicious, but a major pain to roast and shell (have you ever exploded chestnuts all over your kitchen? I have). Canned (jarred more like it) chestnuts actually work better in recipes than the kind you roast and peel yourself. The texture and moisture content is more consistent. So, we suggest using canned roasted chestnuts for this recipe. You can of course roast and shell your own if you prefer.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts\n1/3 pound thick-sliced bacon or slab bacon, cut into 1/4-inch pieces or batons\n1 red onion, chopped\n20-25 canned roasted chestnuts, quartered or roughly chopped\n1/4 cup chicken stock\nSalt and pepper to taste\nLemon wedges to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the Brussels sprouts: Cut the Brussels sprouts in half and slice thinly, starting at the top of the sprout and working back toward the stem. Discard the hard tip of the stem side.\n2 Cook the bacon: Cut the bacon into pieces about 1/4 inch wide and put them in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium heat.\nWhen the bacon is browned, remove with a slotted spoon and set aside.\n3 Cook the onions in bacon fat, add back the bacon:  Remove all but 1 tablespoon of the bacon fat (do not put down the drain, see how to render bacon fat). Turn up the heat to high, add the red onions. Cook until the onions begin to brown, add back the bacon.\n5 Add chestnuts, Brussels sprouts, stock: Add the chestnuts and Brussels sprouts to the saut\xc3\xa9 pan with the bacon and onions. Add the chicken stock and toss to combine. Stir in about 1 teaspoon of salt, more or less to taste. Cook over high heat for 3-4 minutes. Add pepper to taste.\nServe hot with lemon wedges. Squeeze a little lemon juice over the sprouts right before you eat them.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nBrussels Sprouts with Toasted Almonds Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb fresh brussels sprouts, trimmed of ragged or old-looking outer leaves\n4-6 Tbsp butter\n1/2 onion, chopped\nSalt and Pepper\n1 teaspoon lemon juice or 1 Tbsp Meyer lemon juice, fresh squeezed\n1/4 cup toasted slivered almonds\nMETHOD\n1 Parboil the brussels sprouts: Bring 2 quarts of salted water (1 Tbsp of salt) to a rolling boil. Add the brussels sprouts and parboil them for 3 minutes or until just tender. (You could also steam them if you prefer.) They should be almost cooked all the way through (split one in half to test).\nRemove the sprouts with a slotted spoon to a bowl of ice water for a minute to shock the brussels sprouts and help them retain their bright green color.\nRemove them from the ice water and cut the sprouts into halves.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, then brussels sprouts: Heat 2-3 Tbsp of butter in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the chopped onions and cook until translucent, about 4-5 minutes.\nAdd 2-3 Tbsp more of butter and the brussels sprouts halves. Increase the heat to medium high and cook for several more minutes. Salt and pepper to taste, while the brussels sprouts are cooking.\nDo not overcook! Overcooked brussels sprouts are bitter and are the main reason why some people don't like them.\n3 Stir in lemon juice, add toasted almonds: Remove the pan from the heat, stir in the lemon juice and half of the toasted almonds. Add salt and pepper to taste. Place in serving dish and garnish with the rest of the toasted almonds.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nHoney Chipotle Roasted Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 4 servings\nThis recipe is easily doubled and while leftovers are okay when you reheat this, the sprouts are best right out of the oven while they are still crispy on the edges.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\n2 chipotle peppers, from a can of chipotles in adobo\n1/4 cup honey\n1 tablespoon adobo sauce, from chipotle can\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Prepare the sprouts: Cut Brussels sprouts in half through the end and toss with olive oil, salt, and pepper. Spread out sprouts on an even layer on a baking sheet. Roast for 15 minutes.\n3 Prepare the honey-chipotle sauce: Using a small knife, split chipotle peppers in half and remove seeds. Then mince the peppers and add to a small bowl with honey and one tablespoon of adobo sauce from the can.\n4 Finish the sprouts: Remove the sprouts from the oven and stir to ensure even cooking, then spread them again into an even single layer on the baking sheet. Toss with the honey chipotle mixture, but reserve a few tablespoons for finishing the sprouts. Return to oven and bake for another 10 minutes.\n5 Serve! Drizzle with the remaining few tablespoons of sauce, and serve sprouts while warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nShaved Brussels Sprouts with Lemon Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, tough or wilted outer leaves peeled off and discarded\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\n2  extra virgin olive oil\n1 garlic clove, minced\n1 tablespoon mustard seeds\n2 tablespoons dry white wine (or Vermouth)\n2 teaspoons lemon zest\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Thinly slice the brussels sprouts and toss with lemon juice: Put the lemon juice in a large bowl. Peel off any large wilted outer leaves from the brussels sprouts and cut off the bottoms and discard.\nCut the sprouts in half lengthwise. Then thinly slice the sprouts crosswise. As you slice the sprouts, put the slices into the bowl with the lemon juice. Toss them to separate the leaves and coat with a little of the lemon juice.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 shredded brussels sprouts with garlic and mustard seeds: Heat the oil over high heat in a large skillet. When the skillet is hot, add the brussels sprouts, garlic, mustard seeds.\nSaut\xc3\xa9 them until the shaved sprouts are just lightly wilted and cooked, but still green and firm, about 3 to 4 minutes.\n3 Finish with white wine, salt, pepper, lemon zest: Add the wine to the pan. Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Saut\xc3\xa9 a minute more.\nRemove from heat and sprinkle with lemon zest. Add more salt and pepper to taste.\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nMaple Glazed Roasted Delicata Squash and Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large delicata squash (about 1 1/4 pound)\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, trimmed of ragged outer leaves and stem\n3 large shallots, peeled, cut lengthwise in half or thirds\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n3 tablespoons pure maple syrup (divided 2 tbsp and 1 tbsp)\n1 tablespoon apple cider vinegar\n1 teaspoon Kosher salt (plus more to taste)\n1/4 cup fresh pomegranate arils\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Seed and slice the squash: Cut the delicata squash in half crosswise, and then in half again lengthwise. Use a metal spoon to scrape out the seeds and strings. Cut the squash into half rounds, about 1/2-inch thick.\n2 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n3 Sprinkle vegetables with olive oil, maple syrup, vinegar, salt: Place the squash, brussels sprouts, and shallots into a large bowl and toss with 2 Tbsp olive oil. Sprinkle on 2 Tbsp of maple syrup and one Tbsp of cider vinegar, and toss to coat. Sprinkle with 1 teaspoon of kosher salt.\n4 Spread out on baking sheet and roast: Spread a little olive oil over the bottom of a large baking sheet. Arrange the squash, brussels sprouts and shallots on the baking sheet in a single layer.\nRoast at 400\xc2\xb0F for 30 to 35 minutes, turning the vegetables over after the first 20 minutes. The squash should be lightly browned and the brussels sprouts well browned.\n5 Toss with pomegranate arils and maple syrup to serve: Remove from oven to a serving dish. Gently toss with fresh pomegranate arils and drizzle with the remaining 1 Tbsp maple syrup.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGolden Beets and Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Serves 3-4\nThis recipe can easily be scaled up to serve more people.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 medium sized golden beets\n10 Brussels sprouts, trimmed of rough outer leaves and cut in half\n2 teaspoons salt\n1 shallot, peeled and sliced\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 teaspoons fresh thyme, chopped\n2 tablespoons almond slivers, toasted\nSalt and freshly ground pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Boil or roast the beets: The beets take the longest to cook so start them first. Either boil them in water in a small saucepan for 45 minutes (or how ever long it takes to get them tender), or wrap them in foil and roast them in the oven at 350\xc2\xb0F for an hour fifteen minutes or until done.\nRoasting will give you better flavor, but takes longer and uses a lot more energy (unless you are already cooking something in the oven).\nWhen done, set the beets aside to cool for 10 minutes, then peel and chop them into 1 x 1/2 inch chunks.\n2 Toast the slivered almonds: While beets are cooking toast your almond slivers if you are starting with raw almonds. Just heat a skillet to medium high heat and put in the almonds. Stir frequently with a spatula. When the almonds begin to brown, remove from pan into a small bowl. Let cool, set aside.\n3 Blanch the Brussels sprouts: Also while the beets are cooking, prepare the Brussels sprouts. Bring 1 1/2 quarts of salted water (2 teaspoons salt) in a medium saucepan to a boil. Add the Brussels sprouts to the water and blanch them for 2-3 minutes. They should be almost all the way cooked through.\nDrain and rinse with cold water to stop the cooking. Set aside.\n4 Cook the shallots, add beets and Brussels sprouts: In a medium sized skillet heat 1 Tbsp olive oil on medium heat. Add the shallot slices and cook until translucent, a few minutes.\nAdd another tablespoon of olive oil and raise the heat to medium high. Add the sprouts and beets to the pan, along with the thyme and mix well. Salt and pepper to taste.\nCook for 1 minute more, stirring. Remove from heat and serve. Can serve warm or at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHoisin Glazed Brussels Sprouts Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 3-4 as a side dish\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, rinsed, any older outer leaves discarded, stems trimmed slightly, sprouts sliced in half through the stem end\n1 Tbsp peanut oil, or other vegetable oil\n1/2 large onion, sliced thinly root to tip\n2 teaspoons minced ginger\n1 garlic clove, minced, about 1 teaspoon\n1 Tbsp seasoned rice vinegar\n2 teaspoons soy sauce\n3 Tbsp hoisin sauce\n1 teaspoon dark sesame oil\nSalt to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Whisk together the seasoned rice vinegar, soy sauce, and hoisin sauce in a small bowl, set aside.\n2 Pre-steam the brussels sprouts: Place a steamer rack in a medium pot, add an inch of water. Heat the water to a boil, then add the brussels sprouts to the pot. Cover the pot and steam the brussels sprouts for 5 minutes.\nRemove the sprouts from the pot and lay them out on a baking sheet to cool while you cook the onions in the next step.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: Heat the peanut oil in a wok or large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over high heat on your most powerful burner until the surface of the oil shimmers. Add the sliced onions and toss to coat with the oil.\nSear over high heat until the edges of the onion slices begin to brown, about 4-5 minutes.\n4 Add the ginger, garlic and brussels sprouts to the pan and toss to combine. Stir-fry for 2 minutes, or until the brussels sprouts begin to brown.\n5 Add the rice vinegar, soy sauce and hoisin sauce mixture to the sprouts and toss to combine. Stir-fry for a minute or two (watch the sides of the pan and turn off the heat if you see any of the sauce scorch on the side of the pan).\nDrizzle with sesame oil and add salt to taste. Serve at once.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHoney-Mustard Sheet Pan Pork Chops Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts, halved or quartered, depending on the size (about 4 cups prepared)\n2 medium sweet potatoes, cut into 1/2-inch cubes (about 3 cups chopped)\n10 sprigs fresh thyme\n2 tablespoons vegetable oil\n1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\n2 cloves garlic, grated or finely minced\n2 tablespoons Dijon mustard\n2 tablespoons honey\nFour 1-inch thick center-cut loin pork chops (about 2 1/2 pounds)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 400\xcb\x9aF.\n2 Toss the Brussels sprouts, sweet potatoes, thyme, oil, salt, and pepper together on a rimmed sheet pan. Make sure the vegetables are all evenly coated with oil.\n3 In a small bowl, mix together the garlic, mustard, and honey.\n4 Brush the pork chops with honey-mustard: Nestle the pork chops between the vegetables on the sheet pan. Brush both sides of the pork chops with half of the honey mustard sauce (reserve the remaining) and sprinkle with some salt and pepper.\n5 Bake the pork chops: Bake in the oven for 10 minutes. Brush both sides of the pork chops with the remaining honey-mustard sauce. Cook another 10 to 15 minutes, until the meat is cooked through and has reached an internal temperature of 145\xcb\x9aF.\n6 Serve: Divide the vegetables and pork chops between places and serve while hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nBrussels Sprouts with Black Bean Garlic Sauce Recipe\nYield: Serves 4\nYou can find black bean garlic sauce in the Asian aisle of most grocery stores. I use the Lee Kum Kee brand and love it.\nIf you're up to it some chopped, cooked bacon is equally tasty when added to this dish.\nNote that the sauce is pretty salty, so no additional salt is needed.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil, grapeseed oil, or safflower oil\nDash of chili pepper flakes\n25 Brussels sprouts\n1 1/2 tablespoons of black bean garlic sauce\nground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the Brussels sprouts: Wash the Brussels sprouts well. Trim the stems and discard any of the loose leaves. Quarter them lengthwise.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the Brussels sprouts: Place the oil and chili flakes into a large skillet and place over medium-high heat.\nAdd the Brussels sprouts to the pan and cook for about 3-5 minutes or until the sprouts begin to brown a bit. They may absorb all the oil, if they do just add another 1/2 tablespoon of oil.\n3 Add the black bean garlic sauce and stir until all the Brussels sprouts are well coated.\nAdd a pinch of ground black pepper (the sauce is already salty so you probably won't need any salt).\nCook for about 30 more seconds. Take off heat and serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBuckwheat Pancakes Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 14 to 15 4-inch pancakes, serves 2-3\nThe egg is optional, we\'ve made the pancakes both ways, with egg and without. With egg results in just a little more structure to the pancake. To make gluten-free buckwheat pancakes, substitute the all-purpose flour with buckwheat flour.\nDon\'t have buttermilk? You can substitute using 2 Tablespoons of white vinegar stirred into enough regular milk to make 2 cups. (After you stir in the vinegar, let the mixture sit for 5 minutes.) Or you can mix together 1 1/2 cups of plain yogurt and 1/2 cup of milk.\nINGREDIENTS\nVegetable oil for coating the pan\n3/4 cup (100g or 3.5 oz) buckwheat flour\n3/4 cup (100g or 3.5 oz) all-purpose flour (can sub with buckwheat flour for a 100% gluten-free buckwheat pancake if you wish)\n3 Tbsp sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n3 Tbsp unsalted butter, melted\n1 egg (optional)\n2 cups (475 ml) buttermilk\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Pre-heat skillet: Heat a well-seasoned griddle, cast iron skillet, or stick-free pan on medium heat. The pan or griddle should be ready for the batter as soon as it is mixed.\n2 Make pancake batter: Whisk together the dry ingredients\xe2\x80\x94the flours, sugar, salt, baking soda\xe2\x80\x94in a large bowl.\nIn Pour the melted butter over the dry ingredients and start stirring.\nBeat the egg with a fork and stir it into half of the buttermilk. Add the buttermilk/egg mixture to the dry ingredients, then slowly add in the rest of the buttermilk as needed to get to the right consistency for your batter (you may not need all of the buttermilk, depending on what type of buttermilk you are using and the brand of flour).\nStir only until everything is combined. Do not over-mix! A few lumps are fine.\n3 Ladle batter onto hot pan: Put a small amount (a half teaspoon) of vegetable oil on the pan or griddle and spread it around with a paper towel to coat.\nLadle the batter onto the hot surface to the desired size, about 4-5 inches wide. (A 1/4 cup measure will ladle about a 4-inch pancake.) Reduce the heat to medium-low. Allow the pancake to cook for 2-3 minutes on this first side.\n4 Flip pancakes over to other side: Watch for bubbles on the surface of the pancake. When air bubbles start to rise to the surface at the center of the pancake, flip the pancake. Cook for another 1-2 minutes, or until nicely browned.\n5 Keep finished pancakes warm: Keep your pancakes warm on a rack in the oven set on "warm," or stack them on a plate and cover with a towel as you make more. Spread more oil on the pan as needed between batches of pancakes.\nServe with butter and maple syrup.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nBuckwheat Waffles Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 8 to 12 waffles, serves 4 to 5\nThe fluffiness of these waffles is greatly enhanced by whipping the egg whites and folding them into the waffle batter. The whipped egg whites also help to provide structure for the waffles. You can skip this step, but the result will be a little more dense.\nWhen whipping egg whites it's important that everything that touches the egg whites is very clean. Even the smallest amount of fat, butter, or egg yolk can interfere with the whip-ability (is that a word?) of the egg whites. So make sure you separate the eggs carefully, and remove any specks of egg yolk that may have wandered into the whites (it's easiest to do that with a large piece of egg shell).\nYou can substitute the plain yogurt and milk combination with buttermilk.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups buckwheat flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1 teaspoon baking soda\nPinch of salt\nPinch of cinnamon\n2 eggs, separated, plus 2 additional egg whites for extra lightness\n2 Tbsp sugar\n1 cup milk (low fat or regular)\n1/4 cup water\n1 cup plain yogurt\n1/2 cup (1 stick) butter, melted\nExtra pats of butter for serving\nHeated maple syrup for serving\nBerries for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Turn on waffle maker, whisk dry ingredients: Turn on your waffle maker, with the setting on medium. In a large bowl, whisk together the buckwheat flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon.\n2 Beat egg whites: Place the egg whites in a medium bowl and beat with a hand mixer or egg beater. Sprinkle in the sugar as you beat the egg whites.  Beat egg whites until you have soft peaks.\n3 In a medium bowl, whisk together the egg yolks, the melted butter, yogurt, milk, and water.\n4 Combine wet and dry ingredients: Pour the yogurt/milk/butter/egg mixture into the buckwheat flour mixture and stir until just combined. It's okay if it's a little lumpy.\n5 Fold in egg whites: Stir a third of the beaten egg whites into the batter until completely incorporated. Gently fold the remaining beaten egg whites into the batter until just combined, and there are no streaks of egg whites. Be gentle so that you do not deflate the egg whites too much.\n6 Make the waffles: When your waffle maker is ready, working in batches, pour or spoon the batter into the wells, until they almost come to the edge. You will know if you've over-filled it because the batter will spill out of the waffle maker. No harm done, but it's a little messy.\nI like to grease the inside of my waffle maker with a little butter, to help make it easy to remove the waffles.\nCook until the waffle maker indicator indicates that the waffles are ready, or wait until steam stops rising out of the waffle maker. Gently pull the waffles out with a fork.\nAs you make the batches, the batter may thicken while it sits. If you want, thin it out a bit with some water.\nGetting the right balance of doneness is key here. Lightly browned means the waffles will be fluffy, but not crisp. Dark brown means the waffles may be crispy, but a little dry inside. It depends on your preference and your waffle maker. You may need to experiment with a few test waffles to see what works best for you.\n7 Serve: Serve with pads of butter, warmed maple syrup, and fresh berries.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nMozzarella and Basil Stuffed Tomatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 8 stuffed tomato cups, 4 servings\nIf preparing gluten-free, use gluten-free bread or bread crumbs.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 medium tomatoes with firm, fleshy walls, 2 1/2 inches wide\n1 cup shredded mozzarella cheese\n1/3 cup grated parmesan cheese, divided\n1/4 cup packed fresh basil, chopped, plus more for garnish\n1 slice of bread (enough to make 1/4 cup breadcrumbs)\n1 tablespoon melted salted butter\n1 teaspoon minced garlic\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon pepper\nOlive oil for drizzling\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the soft breadcrumbs: To make the 1/4 cup soft breadcrumbs, remove the crust from 1 slice of bread (preferably stale) and either pulse in a small food processor or shred with a fork until the bread resembles fine, sand-like crumbs.\n3 Prepare the tomatoes: Slice the tomatoes in half horizontally around the equator and use a spoon to scoop out the flesh. Be careful not to puncture the walls of the tomato, but if you do, the filling will plug the hole. Place empty tomato halves in a casserole dish and season with salt and pepper.\nUsing your hands or a spoon, separate the seeds from the scooped out tomato flesh and transfer the flesh to a cutting board. Discard the seeds and the tomato water. Chop the flesh and set aside for the stuffing.\n4 Make the stuffing: In a medium bowl, add the mozzarella cheese, 1/4 cup of the parmesan cheese, basil, breadcrumbs, butter, garlic, salt, and pepper and stir to thoroughly combine.\n5 Bake: Using two spoons, fill the tomato halves with the stuffing. Sprinkle filled tomatoes with the remaining parmesan cheese and drizzle with olive oil. Bake for 15 minutes, or until tomatoes are tender, then broil on high for 1 minute until the filling begins to bubble and brown.\n6 Serve: Garnish with a few torn basil leaves and serve hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nMozzarella and Basil Stuffed Tomatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 8 stuffed tomato cups, 4 servings\nIf preparing gluten-free, use gluten-free bread or bread crumbs.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 medium tomatoes with firm, fleshy walls, 2 1/2 inches wide\n1 cup shredded mozzarella cheese\n1/3 cup grated parmesan cheese, divided\n1/4 cup packed fresh basil, chopped, plus more for garnish\n1 slice of bread (enough to make 1/4 cup breadcrumbs)\n1 tablespoon melted salted butter\n1 teaspoon minced garlic\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon pepper\nOlive oil for drizzling\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the soft breadcrumbs: To make the 1/4 cup soft breadcrumbs, remove the crust from 1 slice of bread (preferably stale) and either pulse in a small food processor or shred with a fork until the bread resembles fine, sand-like crumbs.\n3 Prepare the tomatoes: Slice the tomatoes in half horizontally around the equator and use a spoon to scoop out the flesh. Be careful not to puncture the walls of the tomato, but if you do, the filling will plug the hole. Place empty tomato halves in a casserole dish and season with salt and pepper.\nUsing your hands or a spoon, separate the seeds from the scooped out tomato flesh and transfer the flesh to a cutting board. Discard the seeds and the tomato water. Chop the flesh and set aside for the stuffing.\n4 Make the stuffing: In a medium bowl, add the mozzarella cheese, 1/4 cup of the parmesan cheese, basil, breadcrumbs, butter, garlic, salt, and pepper and stir to thoroughly combine.\n5 Bake: Using two spoons, fill the tomato halves with the stuffing. Sprinkle filled tomatoes with the remaining parmesan cheese and drizzle with olive oil. Bake for 15 minutes, or until tomatoes are tender, then broil on high for 1 minute until the filling begins to bubble and brown.\n6 Serve: Garnish with a few torn basil leaves and serve hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nGluten-Free Banana Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Makes one 8x4 loaf\nMake sure you\xe2\x80\x99re using soft, overripe bananas that are anywhere from freckly to completely brown all over. When mashing, I like to leave some lumps in, similar to chunky applesauce.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cup mashed overripe bananas, from 3-4 bananas\n1/3 cup unsalted butter, melted\n3/4 cup granulated sugar\n1 large egg, beaten\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 1/2 cups gluten-free all purpose flour\n3/4 teaspoon baking soda\n3/4 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nSpecial equipment:\n8x4 inch loaf pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Prepare the loaf pan: Grease an 8x4-inch loaf pan generously with cooking spray.\n3 Mix the wet ingredients: In a large mixing bowl, add mashed bananas and stir in melted butter, sugar, egg, and vanilla.\n4 Mix the dry ingredients and combine: In a smaller bowl, add flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt. Whisk to combine. Add the flour mixture to the larger bowl with the wet ingredients and stir until fully combined. (Note that it will be slightly lumpy because of the pieces of mashed banana.)\n5 Bake: Pour batter into the prepared loaf pan, scraping the bowl to assist. Bake for 50 minutes to 1 hour, or until a tester comes out clean.\n6 Serve: Cool on a rack at least 15 minutes before removing the loaf from the pan. Cool completely before slicing and serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBrothy Clams with Chorizo, Tomatoes, and Grilled Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the clams:\n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil\n1 large yellow onion, chopped\n4 cloves garlic, minced\n2 1/2 ounces (3/4 cup) Spanish chorizo, skin (casing) removed and cut into thin slices\n2 medium tomatoes, chopped\n1/2 teaspoon dried crushed red pepper (optional)\n1 cup dry white wine\n1 1/2 cups water\n3 1/2 pounds littleneck clams\n1 tablespoon salted butter\n1/3 cup roughly chopped parsley\nFor the bread:\n1 loaf crusty bread, such as sourdough levain, baguette, Italian, or ciabatta\nOlive oil\nSalt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sort the clams: Throw out clams that are cracked or broken. If any clams are slightly open, tap them on the counter. If they don\xe2\x80\x99t close, throw them out.\n2 Prep the clams: If you harvested the clams yourself or bought them from a small purveyor, soak them in cool, salted water covered with a dish towel for 30 minutes to purge them of sand. Rinse clams in the sink under cool water, rubbing off any dirt with your thumbs.\n3 Make the broth: Heat the olive oil in a large pot or Dutch oven set over medium heat. Add the onion and saut\xc3\xa9 until tender and translucent, about 2 minutes. Add the garlic and chorizo and saut\xc3\xa9 for a few minutes more to infuse the vegetables with smoky flavor.\nAdd the tomatoes, crushed red pepper, white wine, and water, and raise the heat so the liquid boils gently. Cook a few minutes more to soften the tomatoes and allow the flavors to develop.\n4 Cook the clams: Add the clams, cover with a lid, and simmer until the clams open, about 10 minutes. Break the butter into pieces and add to the pan, stir, and scatter with parsley. Turn off the heat.\n5 Toast the bread: While the clams cook, cut several thick slices of bread (one or two slices per person is a good place to start), brush lightly with olive oil, and sprinkle with salt. Toast on a hot grill or under a broiler. This should only take minute or two. When finished set aside to serve with clams.\n6 Serve: Spoon clams and broth in shallow bowls with a slice of bread on the side.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nChickpea Salad Sandwich Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: 2 sandwiches\nINGREDIENTS\n1 can (15 ounces) chickpeas, rinsed and drained\n2 stalks celery, diced\n2 tablespoons capers, rinsed and drained\n3 tablespoons mayonnaise\n2 tablespoons lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1/8 teaspoon salt\n2 pinches of black pepper\n4 slices sandwich bread\n1/2 avocado\n2 tablespoons roasted almonds, coarsely chopped\n2 to 4 tomato slices\nHandful of watercress or other greens, such as lettuce, arugula, or spinach\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Mash the chickpeas: In a medium bowl with a potato masher, coarsely mash the chickpeas.\n2 Make the filling: Add the celery, capers, mayonnaise, lemon juice, and mustard to the bowl. Taste and add a pinch each of salt and pepper.\n3 Assemble the sandwiches: Set 2 pieces of sandwich bread on a cutting board. On one slice of bread, mash 1/4 avocado. Sprinkle lightly with salt and pepper.\nTop with a spoonful of the chickpea salad and sprinkle with 1 tablespoon of the almonds. Add a tomato slice or two, greens of your choice, and top with the second slice of bread. Repeat to make the second sandwich.\n5 Enjoy: Slice the sandwich in half or leave it whole and serve with chips or a salad.\nLeftovers! You may have extra chickpea salad depending on the size of your bread. Enjoy it the next day in a salad, with crackers or on a single slice of bread for a snack.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nHow to Steam Hard Boiled Eggs\nCook time: 15 minutes\nThe steaming time will vary depending on the size of your eggs, how cold your eggs are to begin with, the altitude of your location, how vigorous the water is boiling, if your eggs are in a single layer or are stacked, and how soft or firm you like your hard cooked eggs. So you may need to experiment to find the right timing for your situation.\nA steamer basket is convenient, but not necessary.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare pot and steamer basket:  If you are using a steamer basket, fill a saucepan with as much water as needed to reach the bottom of the steamer basket (about 1 inch or so).\nIf you are not using a steamer basket, just fill the bottom of a saucepan with 1/2 inch of water.\n2 Heat water to boiling, add eggs to pot: Heat the water on high heat until it is boiling and producing steam.\nTurn off the heat and gently place the eggs at the bottom of the steamer basket or the bottom of the pan.\nTurn the heat back on again to medium high, and cover the pot.\nThis method works best if the eggs are in a single layer, but you can double them up as well, you'll just need to add more time to the steaming time.\n3 Set your timer and steam the eggs: Set your timer for 6 minutes for soft boiled, 10 minutes for hard boiled with a still translucent and bright yolk, or 12-15 minutes for cooked-through hard boiled.\nIf you have doubled up the eggs in the pan and they are not in a single layer, you may need to add a couple minutes or so to the cooking time for hard boiled.\nThe size large eggs used in these photos were cooked to my satisfaction after 15 minutes when I cooked 6 in a single layer, and 17 minutes when I cooked 12 in the pan.\nNote that many things will influence the steaming time, including altitude and the size of the particular eggs you are using. I recommend removing one egg a couple minutes before you think it should be done, rinsing it with cold water, and breaking it open to see if it is done enough for you.\n4 Remove eggs to a bowl of icy cold water: Remove eggs with a spoon to a bowl of cold water or ice water, or run cold water directly into the pan to cover the eggs and quickly cool them down.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nEasy Shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s Pie Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 to 2 pounds potatoes (about 3 large potatoes), peeled and quartered\n8 Tablespoons (1 stick) butter\n1 medium onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n1-2 cups vegetables\xe2\x80\x94diced carrots, corn, peas\n1 1/2 lbs ground round beef\n1/2 cup beef broth\n1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce\nSalt, pepper, other seasonings of choice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Boil the potatoes: Place the peeled and quartered potatoes in medium sized pot. Cover with at least an inch of cold water. Add a teaspoon of salt. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook until tender (about 20 minutes).\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 vegetables: While the potatoes are cooking, melt 4 tablespoons of the butter in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the chopped onions and cook until tender, about 6 to 10 minutes.\nIf you are including vegetables, add them according to their cooking time. Carrots should be cooked with the onions, because they take as long to cook as the onions do.\nIf you are including peas or corn, add them toward the end of the cooking of the onions, or after the meat starts to cook, as they take very little cooking time.\n3 Add the ground beef, then Worcestershire sauce and broth: Add ground beef to the pan with the onions and vegetables. Cook until no longer pink. Season with salt and pepper.\nAdd the Worcestershire sauce and beef broth. Bring the broth to a simmer and reduce heat to low. Cook uncovered for 10 minutes, adding more beef broth if necessary to keep the meat from drying out.\n4 Mash the cooked potatoes: When the potatoes are done cooking (a fork can easily pierce), remove them from the pot and place them in a bowl with the remaining 4 Tbsp of butter. Mash with a fork or potato masher, and season with salt and pepper to taste.\n5 Layer the meat mixture and mashed potatoes in a casserole dish: Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Spread the beef, onions, and vegetables (if using) in an even layer in a large baking dish (9x13 casserole).\nSpread the mashed potatoes over the top of the ground beef. Rough up the surface of the mashed potatoes with a fork so there are peaks that will get well browned. You can even use a fork to make creative designs in the mashed potatoes.\n6 Bake in oven: Place in a 400\xc2\xb0F oven and cook until browned and bubbling, about 30 minutes. If necessary, broil for the last few minutes to help the surface of the mashed potatoes brown.\n(Be careful when broiling using Pyrex or glass dishes, they have been known to shatter under the high heat of the broiler. It's not a worry if you are using a ceramic or metal casserole dish.)\nSuggested variations:\nPut a layer of creamed corn between the ground beef and the mashed potatoes.\nSprinkle grated cheddar cheese over the top of the mashed potatoes before baking.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCheesy Potato Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup butter, plus more for the casserole dish\n1 yellow onion, diced\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour\n3 cups vegetable or chicken stock\n2 cups grated cheddar cheese\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n30 ounces frozen hash browns\nDAD ADD: Fried Serrano Rings:\n3 serranos, sliced\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nCoarse salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prepare the casserole dish: Preheat oven to 400\xcb\x9aF. Lightly butter or grease a 9x13 baking dish.\n2 Make the cheese sauce: In a medium pot, melt 1/4 cup butter over medium heat. Add diced onion and cook for 3-4 minutes until onions turn translucent but not browned. Then add minced garlic and cook for 30 seconds.\nStir in flour and continue to cook for a minute or two until the flour turns a tan color. Slowly whisk in stock and bring sauce to a slight simmer. The sauce will thicken as it heats. Once the sauce is thick like gravy, stir in the cheddar cheese and season with salt and pepper. Remove from heat.\n3 Combine the potatoes and the sauce: In a large bowl add the frozen hash browns and pour the sauce over the hash browns. Stir together well to combine and transfer to the prepared baking dish. Smooth the top.\n4 Bake the casserole: Place the casserole in the center rack of your oven and bake for 45 minutes at 400\xcb\x9aF. Then turn on the broiler and broil for 5 minutes on high to crisp up the top of the casserole. If your casserole dish is not broiler-safe, then turn the oven up to 500\xcb\x9aF and bake for 3 more minutes.\n5 Serve: Let the casserole cool slightly but serve while warm.\n6 Make the Crispy Serrano Rings (Optional DAD ADD): Slice serrano peppers into thin coins. Heat a few tablespoons of olive oil over medium heat in a small skillet. Once it is hot, add serrano coins and cook for 2-3 minutes until they start to brown. Remove the coins from the skillet and let drain on a paper towel. Season with a pinch of salt.\nLEFTOVERS!\nLeftovers keep in the fridge for 5 days. Reheat in the microwave until warmed through.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nMom\xe2\x80\x99s Turkey Soup Recipe\nThe amounts shown are a guideline. Improvise at will depending on the ingredients you have on hand and how much soup you are making.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the stock:\n1 turkey carcass, leftover from carving a whole turkey, including any leftover drippings or giblets (not the liver) if you have them\nCold water\n1 medium to large yellow onion, quartered or cut into thick wedges\n1 to 2 carrots, roughly chopped (can include tops)\nSeveral sprigs of fresh parsley\n1 to 2 sprigs of thyme, or a teaspoon of dried thyme\n1 bay leaf\n1 celery rib (roughly chopped) and some celery tops\n5 to 10 peppercorns\nSalt\nPepper\nFor the soup:\n3 to 4 quarts of the turkey stock you just made\n1 to 1 1/2 cups each, chopped carrots, onion, and celery\nA few sprigs of fresh parsley, leaves chopped (about 2 to 4 Tbsp)\nA couple cloves garlic, minced\n2 teaspoons of poultry seasoning (more to taste) or a combination of ground sage, thyme, marjoram, and/or a bouillon cube\n2 to 4 cups of leftover chopped or shredded cooked turkey meat (don't use any of the meat from making the stock, the goodness will have been cooked out of it by then)\nSalt and pepper to taste\n4 to 8 ounces of egg noodles OR  1/2 to 1 cup dry rice (optional, skip egg noodles for gluten-free version)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nMaking the Turkey Stock\n1 Remove all the usable turkey meat from the turkey carcass to save for making sandwiches later or for adding to the soup once the stock is made.\n2 Put turkey carcass, vegetables, drippings in large pot, cover with water: If you are working with a large turkey carcass, you may want to break up the bones a bit so they fit better in the pot. Place the turkey carcass, neck (if you haven't cooked it with the turkey), leftover skin and bones from dinner, into a large stock pot (at least 8 quart or 12 quart depending on the size of the turkey), and cover with COLD water by an inch.\nAdd any drippings that weren't used to make gravy, and any giblets (not the liver) that haven't been used already. Add thickly sliced onion, some chopped carrots, celery and celery tops, parsley, thyme, a bay leaf, and some peppercorns to the pot.\n3 Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, skim foam: Bring to a boil on high heat and then lower the heat to keep the stock to a bare simmer. Skim off any foamy crud that may float to the surface of the stock.\n(Note in the photo that even though the stock is at a bare simmer, it looks like it is boiling because of the foam that is beginning to come to the surface.)\n4 Add salt and pepper to the pot, about 1 teaspoon of salt, 1/2 teaspoon of ground black pepper. It sort of depends on how big your turkey is. You can always add salt to the soup later.\n5 Cook for at least 4 hours, partially uncovered, occasionally skimming off any foam that comes to the surface.\n6 Strain the stock: After 4 hours of a low simmer, use tongs, a spider ladle, or a large slotted spoon to remove the bones and vegetables from the pot. Then strain the stock through a fine mesh sieve or strainer.\nIf you have a strainer but it isn't a fine mesh strainer, you can line it with cheesecloth or with several layers of dampened paper towels and strain the stock through that.\n7 Reduce the stock: If making stock for future use in soup you may want to reduce the stock by cooking it longer, uncovered, to make it more concentrated and easier to store.\n(We usually do this step at a rolling boil, and reduce the stock by at least half. When you boil stock it will make it cloudy, but the taste is great so we don't care. If you want to reduce stock and keep it relatively clear, you'll need to do that slowly and a bare simmer, and it will take much longer.)\nMakes 3 to 4 quarts or more of stock, depending on the size of the turkey carcass, and how much water you added to cover it.\nMaking the Turkey Soup\nPrepare the turkey soup much as you would a chicken soup.\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 carrots, onions, celery in a large pot: In a large soup pot, heat some butter or olive oil (or turkey fat rendered from the stock) on medium high heat. Add chopped carrots, onions, and celery in equal parts (about a cup each). Cook until the onions are softened, about 10 minutes.\n2 Add garlic, stock, parsley, seasonings: Add a couple cloves of garlic, chopped, and cook for a minute more, until the garlic is fragrant. Then add the stock to the pot. Add some parsley and seasoning\xe2\x80\x94salt, pepper, poultry seasoning, sage, thyme, marjoram, and/or a bouillon cube.\n3 Bring to a simmer and cook until the vegetables are cooked through (5 to 10 min).\n4 Add turkey meat, noodles: Add noodles, rice, or even leftover mashed potatoes (skip all of these if you are cooking low-carb). If adding noodles, cook for 4 minutes. If adding rice, cook for 15 minutes.\nTake some of the remaining turkey meat you reserved earlier, shred it into bite sized pieces and add it to the soup. Cook for 1 more minute to warm the turkey meat.\nYou may also want to add some chopped tomatoes, either fresh or canned. Add salt and pepper to taste. Sometimes a dash or two of Tabasco gives the soup a nice little kick.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nHow to Make Chicken Stock\nYield: About 2 to 3 quarts of stock\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nMETHOD 1: LEFTOVER CHICKEN BONES\nLeftover bones and skin from a large cooked or raw chicken carcass (or two rotisserie chickens)\nCelery tops and 1 large celery rib, cut into 2-inch segments\nOnion, 1 large onion, quartered (no need to peel)\nCarrot, cut into 2-inch segments\nParsley, 1 bunch\nSalt\nPepper\n1 Put the leftover bones and skin from a chicken carcass into a large stock pot. Add vegetables like celery, onion, carrots, parsley.\nCover with water. Add salt and pepper, about a teaspoon of salt, 1/4 tsp of pepper.\n2 Bring to a boil and immediately reduce heat to bring the stock to barely a simmer. Simmer partially covered at least 4 hours, occasionally skimming off any foam that comes to the surface.\n3 Remove the bones and vegetables with a slotted spoon or spider ladle, and strain the stock through a fine mesh sieve.\n4 If making stock for future use in soup you may want to reduce the stock by simmering an hour or two longer to make it more concentrated and easier to store.\nMETHOD 2: CHICKEN STOCK WITH RAW CHICKEN BACKS, WINGS, AND/OR LEGS\n1 Tbsp olive oil\n4 to 5 lbs of chicken backs, wings, and/or legs, skin-on, trimmed of excess fat, that have been hacked with a cleaver into 2-inch pieces (you can ask your butcher to prepare the chicken pieces this way)\n1 large yellow onion, quartered (no need to peel)\n1 large carrot, cut into 2-inch segments\nCelery tops and 1 large celery rib, cut into 2-inch segments\n1 bunch of parsley\nLeek or green onion greens (if you have them)\n1 bay leaf\n6 quarts of cold water\n1 Tbsp salt\n1 Coat the bottom of a large stock pot (12 quart), with olive oil. Place half of the chicken pieces, skin side down in the bottom of the pot. Heat on medium high, and let cook until the the chicken is browned. Add the rest of the chicken pieces and stir the pot, cooking and occasionally stirring until the chicken is no longer pink.\n2 Add the onion, carrot, celery, parsley, leek greens (if using), and bay leaf to the pot. Cover with 6 quarts of cold water.\n3 Bring to a boil on high heat and reduce to a low simmer. If scum rises to the surface of the pot (this usually happens in the first half hour of cooking), skim off with a large metal spoon. Let simmer at a low simmer, uncovered, for 4 to 6 hours.\n4 Use a large metal spoons with holes in it (or a "spider ladle") to ladle out the cooked chicken and vegetables. (These aren\'t really good to eat, by the way, because after 4 hours of cooking, most of the flavor and nutrients have been cooked out of them and are now in the stock.) Discard.\n5 Use a large sieve lined with dampened cheesecloth or a dampened paper towel (or if using a very fine mesh sieve no need to line), and place over a large bowl or another large pot. Pour the stock through the sieve into the bowl or pot to strain out any remaining solids.\n6 Either pour into jars at this point, or if you want, what we like to do is to boil the stock on high heat for 1 hour, to reduce it by about half. This way you are storing concentrated stock, which takes less room in the freezer or refrigerator. When you are ready, pour into jars.\nIf you are freezing, you may want to ladle off some of the excess fat on the surface. (The fat helps preserve the stock in the fridge, but doesn\'t help it in the freezer.) If freezing, leave at least 1-inch head space, allowing enough room for the liquid stock to expand as it freezes solid. (Otherwise, the expanding ice stock will break the jar.)\nLet the stock cool completely before refrigerating or freezing. Stock should last a week or so in the fridge, and several months in the freezer.\nMETHOD 3: QUICK CHICKEN STOCK\n4 lbs of chicken backs, wings, and/or legs that have been hacked with a cleaver into 2-inch pieces. You can ask your butcher to prepare the chicken pieces this way.\n1 large yellow onion, chopped\nOlive oil\n2 quarts of boiling water\n2 teaspoons of salt\n2 bay leaves\n1 Heat 1 Tbsp of olive oil in a large stock pot. Add one chopped onion. Saut\xc3\xa9 until softened and slightly colored - 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer to a large bowl.\n\n\n2 Add half of the chicken pieces to the pot. Saut\xc3\xa9 until no longer pink, about 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer cooked chicken to bowl with onions. Saut\xc3\xa9 the rest of the chicken the same way. Return onion and chicken pieces to the pot. Reduce heat to low, cover, and cook until chicken releases its juices, about 20 minutes.\n3 While the chicken pieces are cooking, fill a large tea kettle with 2 quarts of water, bring to a boil.\n4 After the chicken pieces have been cooking for 20 minutes, raise the heat level to high, add the 2 quarts of boiling water, 2 teaspoons of salt, 2 bay leaves. Return to a low simmer, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan with a wooden spoon, then cover and barely simmer for about 20 minutes.\n5 Strain stock through cheesecloth or paper towel-lined large sieve, and discard solids. (It helps to remove the big pieces of bone with a slotted spoon first.)\nPour into jars and cool completely before refrigerating or freezing. Stock will last a week or so in the refrigerator or frozen for several months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nLoaf Pan Lasagna for Two Recipe Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: 2-3 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n2 Italian chicken sausages (about 1/2 pound)\n1 can (28 ounces) whole, peeled tomatoes\n1 clove garlic, thinly sliced\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon sugar\n1 large egg\n1 cup ricotta cheese\n1/3 cup finely grated Parmesan\nPinch ground nutmeg\nPinch ground black pepper\nOil or oil spray (for the loaf pan)\n4 no-boil lasagna noodles\n1/2 cup shredded mozzarella\nFor garnish:\nChopped parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the sausage: In a medium skillet over medium-high heat, add 1 tablespoon of the oil. Either slice the sausage into rounds or remove the casing from the sausage by slicing lengthwise down the side and cook it like ground sausage.\nWhen the oil shimmers, add the sausage to the pan, and cook for about 6 minutes or until browned. Use a cooking utensil to break the sausage up as you cook it. Transfer to a plate.\n2 Snip the tomatoes: Open the can of tomatoes and use a large pair of scissors to snip and break them up in the can into chunky pieces. You will mash them a little more in the skillet.\n3 Make the sauce: In the same skillet you used to brown the sausage, heat 1 tablespoon oil over medium heat. Add the sliced garlic and oregano. Cook for 30 seconds, or until the garlic sizzles. Add the tomatoes with their juices, salt, and sugar. Bring to a simmer and cook for 2 to 3 minutes or until the sauce is hot.\nUse a potato masher to break up the tomatoes into smaller pieces (this is easiest to do when tomatoes soften in the heat). You are aiming for a chunky sauce.\nAdd the sausage back to the pan and cook for 10 minutes. Taste, and add more salt and sugar, if you like.\n4 Make the ricotta mixture: Meanwhile, in a small bowl, stir the egg, ricotta, Parmesan, nutmeg, and pepper together.\n5 Preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Brush or spray a 4x8-inch loaf pan with oil.\n6 Assemble the lasagna: In the bottom of the loaf pan, ladle about 1/2 cup tomato-sausage sauce. Top with 1 noodle. Spread with 1/2 cup sauce, and then spread 1/3 mounded cup of the ricotta mixture over it.\nPlace a second noodle on top of the sauce. Spread 1/3 mounded cup ricotta mixture over it, and top with 1/2 cup tomato-sausage sauce.\nPlace a third noodle on top of the sauce. Spread with remaining ricotta and spoon 1/2 cup tomato-sausage sauce over it, using up all of the remaining sausage pieces in this layer.\nPlace a fourth noodle on top of the sauce and spoon the remaining sauce on top. Sprinkle with the mozzarella.\n6 Bake the lasagna: Place the loaf pan on a baking sheet. Fold a large piece of foil in half and fold it in half again. Make a tent over the loaf pan (so it does not stick to the cheese.) Bake for 25 minutes.\nRemove the pan from the oven and remove the foil tent. Check to see if the lasagna is uneven or if it peaks in the middle. If it\xe2\x80\x99s uneven, use the back of a spoon to press the top layer lightly to make it level in the loaf pan and submerge the noodles in the sauce.\nTurn the oven down to 375\xc2\xb0F. Return lasagna to the oven and continue to bake for 15 minutes, or until the sauce bubbles and the cheese is golden brown. (If you like stretchy rather than browned cheese, check after 10 minutes.)\n7 To serve: Allow the lasagna to rest for 10 minutes before serving. Sprinkle with chopped parsley, if you like.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nMozzarella and Basil Stuffed Tomatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 8 stuffed tomato cups, 4 servings\nIf preparing gluten-free, use gluten-free bread or bread crumbs.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 medium tomatoes with firm, fleshy walls, 2 1/2 inches wide\n1 cup shredded mozzarella cheese\n1/3 cup grated parmesan cheese, divided\n1/4 cup packed fresh basil, chopped, plus more for garnish\n1 slice of bread (enough to make 1/4 cup breadcrumbs)\n1 tablespoon melted salted butter\n1 teaspoon minced garlic\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon pepper\nOlive oil for drizzling\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the soft breadcrumbs: To make the 1/4 cup soft breadcrumbs, remove the crust from 1 slice of bread (preferably stale) and either pulse in a small food processor or shred with a fork until the bread resembles fine, sand-like crumbs.\n3 Prepare the tomatoes: Slice the tomatoes in half horizontally around the equator and use a spoon to scoop out the flesh. Be careful not to puncture the walls of the tomato, but if you do, the filling will plug the hole. Place empty tomato halves in a casserole dish and season with salt and pepper.\nUsing your hands or a spoon, separate the seeds from the scooped out tomato flesh and transfer the flesh to a cutting board. Discard the seeds and the tomato water. Chop the flesh and set aside for the stuffing.\n4 Make the stuffing: In a medium bowl, add the mozzarella cheese, 1/4 cup of the parmesan cheese, basil, breadcrumbs, butter, garlic, salt, and pepper and stir to thoroughly combine.\n5 Bake: Using two spoons, fill the tomato halves with the stuffing. Sprinkle filled tomatoes with the remaining parmesan cheese and drizzle with olive oil. Bake for 15 minutes, or until tomatoes are tender, then broil on high for 1 minute until the filling begins to bubble and brown.\n6 Serve: Garnish with a few torn basil leaves and serve hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHow to Make an Omelette\nPrep time: 1 minuteCook time: 5 minutesYield: 1 omelette\nINGREDIENTS\n2 large eggs\n1 tablespoon unsalted butter\n2 tablespoons grated cheese, any kind\n3 to 4 cherry tomatoes, cut in half and sprinkled lightly with salt\n2 tablespoons chopped basil, parsley, or herb of your choice\nSpecial equipment:\n8-inch nonstick skillet\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the eggs:  In a bowl, beat the eggs with a fork.\n2 Melt the butter: In an 8-inch nonstick skillet over medium-low heat, melt the butter.\n3 Add the eggs and cook the omelette: Add the eggs to the skillet and cook without stirring until the edges begin to set. With a silicone spatula, push the edges toward the center of the pan and tilt the pan so the uncooked eggs move to the edge.\nRepeat until the eggs are somewhat set but still a little soft in the center, about 6 minutes.\n4 Fill the omelette: Place the cheese, tomatoes, and herbs in a line down the center of the omelette and cook for about 1 minute longer, or until the eggs are mostly set but still a little soft in the center.\n5 Fold and plate the omelette: Slide the spatula around one side of the omelette at the edge to loosen it. Slip it under the eggs, and use it to carefully fold the omelette in half. Slide the spatula under the folded omelette to loosen it from the pan. Tilt the pan over a plate and use the spatula to nudge it onto the plate. Voila!\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nSouthern Cornbread Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 8 servings\nWhite cornmeal is used in most Southern cornbreads, but we could not find any here in California, so we used yellow cornmeal. If you can find white cornmeal, by all means use it.\nThe egg is optional, though without it the cornbread will be very crumbly.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon bacon drippings\n2 cups cornmeal OR 1 1/2 cups cornmeal and 1/2 cup flour\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 tablespoon sugar (optional)\n1 large egg (optional)\n1 1/4 cups buttermilk\n6 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat pan with bacon drippings: Put the bacon drippings in a 9 or 10-inch well-seasoned cast iron skillet and put the skillet into the oven. Then preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F with the skillet inside. (If you don't have an iron skillet, you can use an uncovered Dutch oven or a metal cake pan.)\n2 Make the batter: Whisk together all the dry ingredients (cornmeal, baking soda, salt, sugar if using) in a large bowl. In another bowl, beat the egg (if using) and buttermilk until combined, then mix that into the bowl of dry ingredients. Stir in the melted butter.\n3 Pour batter into hot skillet and bake: When the oven is hot, take out the skillet (carefully, as the handle will be hot!). Add the cornbread batter and make sure it is evenly distributed in the skillet.\nBake at 400\xc2\xb0F for about 20 minutes, or until the edges are beginning to brown and a toothpick inserted in the center of the bread comes out clean.\n4 Rest bread in skillet, then serve: Let the bread rest for 10 to 30 minutes in the skillet before cutting it into wedges and serving.\nTo store, let the cornbread cool, then remove from pan and wrap in plastic wrap or transfer to an airtight container. Store at room temp for 2 to 3 days\nTo avoid burning your hand because you've forgotten the pan is hot, I recommend placing a pot holder on the pan's handle while the cornbread is resting, or cooling the handle down a bit with an ice cube.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nPasta with Tuna and Capers in White Wine Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 2\nYou can easily dress up this recipe with a few more ingredients - chopped garlic added at the end of the onion cooking, chopped tomatoes and/or olives in with the tuna, lemon zest to serve, etc.\nINGREDIENTS\nSalt\n4 ounces bow tie (farfalle), linguini, or spaghetti pasta\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil (plus more)\n1/2 medium onion, chopped\nPinch chili pepper flakes\n1 (6-ounce) can tuna packed in olive oil, drained\n1 tablespoon capers\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 cup dry white wine\n2 tablespoons chopped flat leaf parsley\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the pasta: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt (1 1/2 teaspoons for every quart of water), return to a boil. Add the pasta and cook according to package directions until cooked through, but still firm (al dente).\n2 Cook the onions and chili pepper flakes: While the water is coming to a boil and the pasta is cooking, prepare the rest of the recipe. In a large, wide saut\xc3\xa9 pan, heat a couple tablespoons of olive oil on medium heat. Add the chopped onion and chili pepper flakes and cook until translucent, about 5 minutes or so.\n3 Mix in the canned tuna, the capers, and the salt. Add the wine, bring to a simmer then lower the heat to low. Cook for 10 minutes or longer, while the pasta is cooking. If the mixture begins to dry out, add a little more wine.\n4 Add the drained pasta to the tuna mixture: When the pasta is ready, drain it and add it in to the pan with the tuna. Toss to mix.\nDrizzle on a bit more olive oil over it all, then add the chopped parsley and a few grinds of black pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nHow to Make a Grilled Cheese Sandwich\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: 1 sandwich\nINGREDIENTS\n3 ounces (about 2/3 to 1 cup) shredded cheddar, swiss, jack, or fontina cheese\n2 slices sandwich bread, preferably 1/2-inch thick\n2 teaspoons mayonnaise or butter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the pan and grate the cheese: Put a heavy-bottomed medium skillet over medium-low to medium heat (everyone\xe2\x80\x99s stove is a little different). As the skillet heats, grate the cheese. If you are using more than one kind of cheese, toss them together in a bowl until nicely combined.\n2 Mayo or butter the bread: Spread one side of each slice of bread evenly with mayonnaise or butter. Lay the slices butter-side-down in the preheated skillet.\n3 Add the cheese and let it melt: Distribute the cheese evenly over both slices of bread. If you have a lid for your skillet, put it on; this will help the cheese melt more evenly.\nNow, stay put! The second you walk away is the second your sandwich will burn. Look for the cheese to begin melting. The time it takes will depend on your stove, your skillet, and the cheese you are using. Lower-moisture cheeses like aged cheddar will take longer to melt. It could take 2 minutes, or up to 5 minutes. You don\xe2\x80\x99t want the cheese to be totally melted\xe2\x80\x94just halfway melted.\n4 Close the sandwich and finish grilling: (If you want to add a filling, like sliced tomato, add it now.) Close the sandwich and continue grilling, flipping the sandwich with a turner as needed, until both sides are golden brown, another 2-3 minutes per side.\nUsually, the second side takes less time than the first. Press down on the sandwich gently but firmly with your turner to compact it a little, but don\xe2\x80\x99t smoosh it. You may need to turn the heat down to medium-low to keep the bread from charring.\nPeek in the sandwich to see if the cheese is fully melted. If the bread is grilled to your liking but the cheese needs more time, turn the heat down and grill it a few minutes longer.\n5 Serve the sandwich: Cut the sandwich the way you like best (I like cutting on the diagonal, creating four pointy corners to dip in tomato soup) and let it cool a minute or so before eating, unless you like burning your mouth on molten cheese. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nHam and Potato Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6\nYou can either make this soup using leftover ham and a ham bone or you can use a meaty ham shank. If you use a ham bone, you'll add the chopped ham at the end of cooking. If you are using a ham shank, after the soup cooks with the ham shank, you'll need to remove it, cut away the meat, chop the meat, and return it to the soup.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 1/2 cups chopped onion\n3/4 cup chopped parsnips or carrots\n3/4 cup chopped celery\n1 minced garlic clove\n1 meaty ham bone from a ham, or a meaty ham shank\n6 cups low sodium chicken stock\n2 bay leaves\n2 sprigs thyme\n2 pounds Russet potatoes, peeled, and cut into 3/4-inch cubes\n1 1/2 cups cubed ham (if using a ham bone), 3/4-inch dice\n1/2 teaspoon ground pepper\n1/4 cup whipping cream\nSalt to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook onions, parsnips or carrots, celery, garlic in olive oil: Heat olive oil in a large, thick-bottomed pot or Dutch oven on medium high heat.\nAdd the onions, parsnips or carrots, celery, and saut\xc3\xa9 for 7 to 8 minutes. Add the garlic and cook for a minute more.\n2 Add ham bone or shank, stock, bay leaves, thyme: Add the ham bone or ham shank to the pot. Add 6 cups of stock. Add bay leaves and thyme. Bring to a boil, lower the heat to maintain a simmer. Cover and simmer for 45 minutes.\n3 Add potatoes: Add the potatoes and simmer for 15 more minutes, until they are cooked through.\n4 Remove ham bone or shank, pur\xc3\xa9e half the soup: Remove the ham bone or ham shank from the soup. Pur\xc3\xa9e half of the soup so that some of the potatoes get pur\xc3\xa9ed to give the soup body, and there are still whole chunks of potatoes for texture.\n5 Add chopped ham: If using a ham shank, cut away the meat and chop into 3/4-inch cubes. Add the chopped ham and black pepper to the soup.\n6 Stir in the cream. Taste for salt and pepper and add more if needed.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nHow to Cook Rice on the Stovetop\nCook time: 20-25 minutesYield: 4 servings, or about 4 cups fluffed, cooked rice\nThis recipe is for regular long-grain white rice. Quick-cooking, parboiled, and converted rice will have different cooking times and may call for different amounts of liquid.\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t want to rinse the rice, increase the amount of liquid to 2 cups.\nYou can safely double this recipe in the same size saucepan.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup long-grain white rice\n1 3/4 cup water\n1/4 teaspoon salt, optional\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Rinse the rice: Put the rice in a wire mesh sieve or strainer and rinse it under cold water for about 30 seconds, or until the water runs clear. Swish it around to get the excess water off.\n2 Combine the rice and liquid: In a medium saucepan (about 2 quarts), combine the rice and water. Add the salt, if using.\n3 Cover and bring to a boil: Put on the lid. Turn the heat to medium-high and bring the rice to a boil. The liquid can quickly boil over and make a big mess, so watch the pot for steam, or listen for the lid making jiggling sounds.\n4 Turn down the heat and set the timer: Once the rice comes to a boil, set a timer for 10 minutes. Reduce the heat to medium-low, or as low as it can go while still maintaining a very gentle simmer (look for wisps of steam around the lid). It\xe2\x80\x99s okay to take off the lid a few times to check on the progress of the rice but try to keep it to a minimum.\n6 Turn off the burner and let the rice steam: Turn off the heat. Let the rice sit with the lid on for 10 minutes so it can steam. Even though the pot is not on the heat, this is part of your cooking time. It\xe2\x80\x99s what makes the rice nice and fluffy, like restaurant rice.\n7 Fluff and serve: Use a fork or spoon to fluff the rice before serving it.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nClassic Baked Chicken\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 4\nEven if you intend to eat the baked chicken without its skin, leave the skin on for baking because it prevents the chicken pieces from drying out while they bake.\nIf you bought a whole chicken to start with, the chicken may have come with the neck and gizzards (often in paper in the cavity of the chicken). Use the chicken back and these giblets to make stock for gravy. Chop up the back a little, and put the back, gizzard, and neck into a small saucepan and cover with water by a half inch or so. Bring to a simmer and let simmer while your chicken is baking. Then strain and use the stock for making a richly flavored gravy.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 3 to 4 pound chicken, cut into 8 parts (2 breasts, 2 thighs, 2 legs, 2 wings), excluding the back\nExtra virgin olive oil\nKosher salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1/2 cup low sodium chicken stock (see Recipe Note) or white wine for the gravy (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Trim and salt the chicken: Trim the chicken pieces of excess fat. Pat the chicken pieces dry with a paper towel. Sprinkle all sides with salt. Let the chicken pieces sit for 15 to 20 minutes to take the chill off.\n2 Preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F (205\xc2\xb0C).\n3 Prep the chicken: Pat the chicken pieces dry with a paper towel. Rub olive oil over the chicken pieces and on the bottom of the roasting pan.\nSprinkle the chicken pieces all over with black pepper and a little more salt.\nArrange the chicken pieces in the pan so that all the pieces are skin-side up, and the largest pieces (the breasts) are in the center of the pan.\nDon't crowd the pan; allow room in between the pieces.\n4 Bake the chicken: Bake (uncovered) in the oven for 30 minutes at 400\xc2\xb0F (205\xc2\xb0C). This initial high heat will help brown the chicken.\nThen lower the heat to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) and bake for and additional 10-30 minutes more until the juices run clear (not pink) when poked with a sharp knife or the internal temperature of the chicken breasts is 165\xc2\xb0F (74\xc2\xb0C), and of the thighs is 170\xc2\xb0F (77\xc2\xb0C) when tested with a meat thermometer.\nIf the chicken isn't browning well enough, place the chicken under the broiler for the last 5 minutes of cooking, until browned sufficiently.\n5 Let it rest: Remove from oven and transfer the chicken to a serving dish.
