b"Print\nHawaiian Pork Burger Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4\nFor those without a grill, you can easily make these burgers on a cast iron pan or grill pan on the stovetop.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound ground pork\n1/4 cup minced green onion\n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger\n1/8 teaspoon ground allspice\n1/8 teaspoon salt (more to taste, but be careful, the BBQ sauce is salty, as is the ham)\nPinch black pepper\n4 pineapple rings, fresh or canned\n1/4 cup your favorite barbecue sauce\n4 burger buns\n4 large lettuce leaves (use leafy lettuce)\n1/4 pound thinly sliced ham\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make burger mixture: Use your (clean) hands to mix the ground pork, green onion, allspice, salt, pepper and ground ginger together in a large bowl until just combined. Don't knead the mixture too much or the burgers will be tough.\n2 Form patties: Gently form 4 equal patties, with a slight indentation in the middle (the burgers will contract as they cook, the indentation helps keep the burgers from bulging in the middle too much).\nIf you want, you can separate the patties with wax paper and store them for a few hours in the fridge before grilling.\n3 Grill the patties: Prepare your grill for medium high, direct heat. Scrape down the grill grates and coat with vegetable oil.\nPlace the pork patties on the hot grill and paint the top with barbecue sauce.\nCover the grill and cook for 5-7 minutes. Flip the burgers and paint with more barbecue sauce.\n4 Grill pineapple rings: After you've flipped the burgers, lay the pineapple rings down on a hot part of the grill. Cook the burgers for another 5 to 7 minutes, until cooked through.\nCook the pineapple rings for 3-5 minutes, or until you have nice grill marks on one side. Flip the pineapple and grill another 1-2 minutes.\nRemove the pineapple and burgers from the grill and let them rest 5 minutes.\n5 Toast burger buns on grill: While the meat is resting, toast the burger buns on the hot grill until the edges brown nicely, about 1-2 minutes.\n6 Assemble the burgers: To construct the burger, lay some lettuce on the bun, add the burger patty and paint with a little more barbecue sauce. Top with the ham, then the pineapple, then the other bun.\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nTuna Burgers with Dill Olive Mayo Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 18 minutesYield: 6 burgers\nThese tuna patties taste as good on a bed of lettuce as they do on a toasted hamburger bun.\nFor the spice mix, I use Zatarain\xe2\x80\x99s Creole Seasoning, but you could use Old Bay Seasoning instead.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the dill olive mayo:\n1/3 cup mayonnaise\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh dill or 1 teaspoon dried dill\n1 tablespoon sliced green olives, minced\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon Creole seasoning\nFor the tuna burgers:\n1 large egg\n1/4 cup of mayonnaise\n2 (5-ounce) cans tuna in water, drained\n3/4 cup unseasoned Panko bread crumbs\n2 cloves garlic, minced or microplaned\n1/2 cup corn (frozen or fresh)\n1/2 cup finely grated carrot\n1/4 cup minced red bell pepper\n1/4 cup minced yellow onion\n3/4 teaspoon Creole seasoning\n3 tablespoons olive oil (stove top method) or cooking spray to bake\nFor the topping:\nSliced red onion (optional)\nLettuce (optional)\nHamburger buns\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dill olive mayo: In a small bowl, combine the mayonnaise, dill, olives, lemon juice, and Creole seasoning. Cover and place in refrigerator until the tuna burgers are ready to be served.\n2 Make the tuna mix: In a small bowl, use a fork to combine the egg and mayonnaise. Add the tuna and stir to combine. In a separate, medium bowl combine panko, garlic, corn, carrot, red pepper, yellow onion, and Creole seasoning.\nAdd the mayonnaise and tuna mixture to the panko mixture. Stir until well combined.\n3 Shape the patties: Use a 1/3 cup measuring cup to measure out a heaping scoop of tuna mixture and form into 6 patties.\n4 Cook the patties in the oven or on the stovetop:\nTo make in the oven: Place a large cast iron skillet in your oven, then preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. When it reaches the desired temperature, remove skillet from the oven with oven mitts. You want the skillet good and hot, which will help sear the burgers.\nSpray the inside of the skillet and both sides of the tuna burgers with cooking spray; it helps mimic that crisp edge you get when you actually fry something. Add the burgers to the skillet and return it to the oven. Bake for about 7 minutes or until the bottoms of the burgers are golden brown and crispy.\nFlip the burgers and cook until the other side is golden. This should take about 7 to 9 additional minutes.\nTo make this on the stovetop: Heat 3 tablespoons of oil in a large skillet over medium heat. When the oil begins to shimmer, add the tuna burgers to the skillet and cook on each side for about 3 to 4 minutes, until the surface is golden brown and crispy. Drain on a paper towel.\nServe on toasted hamburger buns with the dill olive mayonnaise, sliced red onion, and lettuce.\nMake-ahead instructions: Feel free to shape the patties up to 24 hours in advance. Cover with plastic wrap and keep in the fridge until ready to use. Reheat previously cooked patties by heating a teaspoon of oil in a pan over medium heat. When the oil begins to shimmer, add the patties. Flip them once and cook until they are warmed through\xe2\x80\x94about 5 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nArugula Salad with Tomatoes, Corn, and Burrata Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the dressing\n2 tablespoons red wine vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nPinch of black pepper\n6 tablespoons olive oil\nFor the salad\n4 ears corn\n2 large handfuls baby arugula\n2 large tomatoes, sliced\n1 pint mixed cherry tomatoes, halved\nAbout 8 large basil leaves, torn into pieces\n1 (8-ounce) ball burrata\nFreshly ground black pepper\nCrusty bread, for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together the vinegar, salt, and pepper. Gradually whisk in the olive oil.\n2 Cook the corn: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the corn and cook for 2 minutes. Drain and rinse with cold water.\nTo cut the kernels from the cob, hold one of the cobs upright in the center of a bundt pan (or a mixing bowl with an overturned ramekin in the middle). With a knife, cut the kernels from the cob in a downward motion, letting the kernels collect in the well of the bundt pan.\nRepeat with all the cobs. For more details on this method, read this post.\n3 Toss the corn and arugula: In a medium bowl, toss the arugula and corn with 2 tablespoons of the dressing. (Reserve the remaining dressing for drizzling over the salad.)\n4 Plate the salad: Divide the arugula and corn between 4 salad plates. Gently cut the burrata into four quarters, and transfer to the salad plates.\nTop the salads with the sliced tomatoes, cherry tomatoes, and torn basil leaves. Sprinkle with more dressing and a few grindings of black pepper, and serve with crusty bread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nFreezer Breakfast Burritos with Sausage, Eggs and Salsa Verde Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 8 large burritos\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound sweet pork sausage\n2 to 3 medium Yukon potatoes, diced (about 3 cups; no need to peel them)\n1 green pepper, diced\n1 medium yellow onion, diced\n8 ounces mild or sharp cheddar cheese, grated\n1 tablespoon butter\n8 large eggs\nSalt and pepper\n1 cup salsa verde, homemade or store-bought\n8 large burrito-sized flour tortillas\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the sausage: In a large skillet over medium heat, cook the pork sausage. Break it up as it cooks until it\xe2\x80\x99s browned evenly. Transfer the cooked pork to a bowl.\n2 Cook the vegetables: Add the potatoes to the skillet used to cook the pork and cook until they are tender and browned in spots, 8 to 10 minutes, stirring regularly. Any fat left over from the pork should be enough to cook the potatoes in, but if the skillet is very dry, add a drizzle of olive oil.\nAdd the diced peppers and onions  and continue to cook until the veggies soften, another few minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Remove the skillet from heat.\n3 Scramble the eggs: In a separate nonstick skillet over low heat, add the butter. Whisk together the eggs in a medium bowl. Once the butter has melted, add eggs and cook until scrambled and set, but not completely dry. Remove from heat and set aside. (You can do this at the same time the vegetables are cooking if you want to multitask!)\n4 Assemble the burritos: Once your fillings are cooled slightly (it\xe2\x80\x99s okay if they are still a bit warm, as long as they're not steaming), lay out a large flour tortilla on a clean surface.\nAdd about 1/8 of the pork sausage, 1/8 of the potato filling, 1/8 of the cheddar cheese, and 1/8 of the eggs. It\xe2\x80\x99s okay to eyeball the amounts, but you should have enough of each filling to make eight burritos. Top with about two tablespoons of salsa verde.\n  5 Roll the burritos: Fold the sides over the filling and then roll the tortilla into a tight burrito. Immediately roll the burrito in foil. Repeat with all burritos.\n6 Freeze the burritos: Transfer the foil-wrapped burritos to a large, freezer-safe, resealable plastic bag and freeze. Burritos will store well in the freezer for up to three months.\nEven if you plan to eat your burritos the same week you make them, we still recommend freezing the burritos until you're ready to eat them. This preserves them better than in the fridge and prevents the burrito from becoming overly soggy.\n7 Reheat the burritos: Unwrap burrito from foil and microwave on high for 4 to 5 minutes, turning once halfway through. At that point the burrito will be hot and you could eat it as is. Serve with extra salsa verde, if desired.\nAs a bonus step, which I love: place the reheated burrito in a small nonstick skillet over medium heat and let the tortilla crisp up for 2 to 3 minutes per side. If you loathe any hint of sogginess in your burritos, this will eliminate the problem!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nIndian Butter Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 30 minutesMarinating time: 30 minutes minimum, 8 hours maximumYield: 4 servings\nIf you have trouble finding the spices, you can substitute paprika for the Kashmiri Lal Mirch and skip the Kasuri Methi.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken and marinade:\n1 pound boneless, skinless chicken thighs, cut into roughly 1-inch cubes\n1/4 cup full-fat plain yogurt\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 tablespoon ginger garlic paste\n1 teaspoon dried coriander\n1 teaspoon Kashmiri Lal Mirch\n1 teaspoon cumin\nSalt to taste\nFor the sauce:\n8 to 10 whole almonds\n8 to 10 whole cashews\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, divided\n1 tablespoon ginger garlic paste\n1 teaspoon sugar\n1 (15-ounce) can canned diced tomatoes\n2 tablespoons dried coriander\n1 1/2 teaspoons ground Garam Masala\n1/2 teaspoon ground Kashmiri Lal Mirch\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 cup water\n1/4 cup heavy cream\n1/2 tablespoon Kasuri Methi\nTo serve:\nCooked rice, roti, or naan bread\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: Bring the chicken and the rest of the marinade ingredients together in a large bowl. Using your hands, massage the marinade into the chicken.\nCover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 1 hour, or up to overnight.\n2 Soak cashews and almonds in water for at least an hour to (or up to overnight) before preparing the rest of the recipe.\n3 Cook the chicken: Heat a skillet or grill pan over medium-high heat. Drizzle a teaspoon of oil to the pan.\nWorking in batches, remove chicken from the marinade and grill them on the pan for 3 to 5 minutes on each side, until the chicken is cooked through (clear juice runs out of it when you cut into it). Do not crowd the pan.\nOnce cooked, transfer the chicken into a separate dish. Cover and set aside for later.\n4 Start making the sauce: Melt 1 1/2 tablespoons of the butter in a medium sized Dutch oven or a skillet on medium low heat. As soon as the butter melts, add the ginger garlic paste followed by sugar. Saut\xc3\xa9 for 1 to 2 minutes.\nStir in the tomato and cook for 8 to 10 minutes on medium high heat, until all the extra liquid is cooked off. The sauce should be a loose, paste-like consistency.\nAdd coriander, garam masala, Kashmiri Lal Mirch, and salt. Stir and cook on medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes. Turn off the heat.\n5 Puree the sauce with the nuts: Transfer the paste to a blender or the bowl of a food processor. Add the soaked cashews and almonds. Blend into a smooth paste.\n6 Finish the dish: Return the paste to the cooking pan over medium heat. Add the water to the paste and stir to make a smooth sauce.\nAs the sauce begins to boil, add the grilled chicken and heavy cream. Stir well. Cover the pan and simmer for 5 minutes.\n7 Rest the butter chicken: Turn off the heat and uncover the pan. Stir in the remaining 1/2 tablespoon butter and the kasuri methi. Cover again, and let the dish rest for 8 to 10 minutes so the flavor of kasuri methi can marry into the butter chicken.\n8 Serve: Serve the butter with a side of steamed basmati rice, roti, or naan. Leftovers will keep refrigerated, covered, for five days.\nYou can freeze this dish in an airtight covered container or a zip-top bag for a month. Thaw and reheat in a saucepan over medium-low heat to retain the texture.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nHow to Make Brown Butter\nCook time: 5 minutes\nINGREDIENTS\nUnsalted butter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Melt the butter: Heat a thick-bottomed skillet on medium heat. Add the butter (if you slice it, it will melt more evenly) whisking frequently. Continue to cook the butter.\n2 Watch for brown specs and nutty aroma: Once melted the butter will foam up a bit, then subside. Watch carefully as lightly browned specks begin to form at the bottom of the pan. Smell the butter; it should have a nutty aroma.\n3 Remove from heat and pour into a bowl to stop the butter from cooking further and perhaps burning.\nIt's pretty easy to overcook browned butter and go from brown to burnt. If the butter starts to blacken, I suggest dumping it and starting over (something I've had to do on occasion), unless you want beurre noir which has a different taste than nutty brown butter.\nIf you want to make sage brown butter sauce, add some fresh sage leaves to the butter once it has melted. Allow the butter to brown and remove from heat.\nUse browned butter immediately or store covered in the refrigerator for future use.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nEasy Buttered Noodles Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 8 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 pound egg noodles\n2 Tbsp butter\n2 Tbsp grated Parmesan cheese\n1 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the noodles: Heat 2 quarts of water with 1 Tbsp kosher salt in a large pot on high heat until boiling. Add the egg noodles. Cook for 5 minutes. Reserve 1/4 cup of the pasta cooking liquid and drain the noodles.\n2 Add butter, cheese, parsley: Place the drained hot noodles in a large bowl. Add the butter and Parmesan and stir until the butter has melted. Stir in a tablespoon or two of the pasta cooking water. Stir in the chopped parsley. Add salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nTip: How to Soften Butter Quickly\nPrep time: 2 minutes\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Put the stick of butter between two large pieces of wax paper.\n2 Using a rolling pin, press down on the butter.\n3 Roll it out they way you would roll out a pie crust.\n4 When the butter is about 1/8 to 1/4-inch thick, lift off the wax paper and peel away the butter (before it gets too soft to peel).\nVoil\xc3\xa0! Softened butter, ready for beating.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nLemon-Garlic Butter Sauce for Seafood Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes a little more than 1 1/2 cups\nUse whole milk or cream with water. Do not use low-fat milk or the sauce may curdle.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup clam juice (can substitute chicken stock)\n1/2 cup dry sherry\n1/2 cup whole milk (OR 3 Tbsp cream with 5 Tbsp water)\n1 Tbsp minced garlic\n1 Tbsp minced shallots\n1 bay leaf\n1 Tbsp unsalted butter\n1 Tbsp flour\n1/2 pound (2 sticks) unsalted butter\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon white pepper\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Simmer and reduce the liquids, with garlic, shallots, and bay leaf: Place first six ingredients (clam juice, sherry, whole milk, garlic, shallots, bay leaf) in a small saucepan.\nHeat on medium high heat and let simmer until the liquids have reduced by about half.\n2 Make a roux: In a separate saucepan (1-qt minimum) prepare the roux. Heat one tablespoon of butter in the saucepan on medium heat until it is foamy.\nSprinkle in the flour, stirring a couple of minutes with a metal whisk until well mixed (tan, but not browned).\n3 Slowly add liquid mixture to roux: Slowly add the reduced mixture to the roux, stirring quickly to incorporate. When you first add some of the mixture, the roux will bubble up. Just keep adding the mixture and keep whisking to incorporate.\n4 Slowly incorporate butter, 2 Tbsp at a time: Lower the heat to low. Remove the bay leaf. Slowly whisk in the butter, 2 tablespoons at a time. Let the butter tablespoons fully melt and be incorporated into the sauce before adding more tablespoons.\n5 Stir in lemon juice, salt, and white pepper. Add some more clam stock or water if the sauce is too thick.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSimple Soft Sugar Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: 24 cookies\nLeave these cookies plain, frost them after cooling, or dress them up with colored sparkling sugars sprinkled over top before baking.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup (225 g, or 2 sticks) unsalted butter at room temperature\n1 cup (200 g) granulated white sugar\n1/4 cup (55 g) packed light brown sugar\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n1 large egg\n2 1/4 cups (315 g) all-purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nTo finish:\n1/2 cup (100 g) granulated white sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven: Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F (190\xc2\xb0C). Line a baking sheet with a silicon baking mat or parchment paper.\n2 Beat the butter and sugar: Place butter, both sugars and vanilla extract in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. Beat the ingredients together until the butter is light, fluffy and clings to the side of the bowl.\n3 Add the egg and beat to incorporate. Scrape down the sides of the bowl with a spatula.\n4 Add the flour, baking powder and salt. Mix on low speed until the dry ingredients are mostly absorbed, then increase the speed until fully incorporated.\n5 Chill the dough: Chill in the fridge for at least one hour or overnight.\n6 Shape the cookies: Pinch off a lump of dough. Roll it between the palms of your hands to form a ball roughly 1 1/2 inches in diameter, about the size of a pingpong ball. Roll the dough in the granulated white sugar and place on the baking sheet. Repeat, spacing the cookies about 2 inches apart.\n7 Press the cookies into disks: Use the flat bottom of a glass to press down and form thick disks about 2 inches wide. Sprinkle some extra sugar on each disk\n8 Bake the cookies: Bake at 375\xc2\xb0F (190\xc2\xb0C) 11 to 13 minutes, or until the edges of the cookies are starting to turn golden brown. Let cool for 10 minutes on the baking sheet before moving cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.\nStore in an airtight container for up to 3 days at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nOrange & Vanilla Hot Buttered Rum Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: 4 drinks\nGood-quality dark rum really is key here. You don\xe2\x80\x99t have to pay a lot of money for good bottle; just avoid anything in a plastic jug. (I find Mount Gay is a flavorful and affordable option.)\nThe compound butter will keep for several weeks in an airtight container in the fridge, and the flavors will only get more intense over time. I often make a large batch a few days in advance of a party so it\xe2\x80\x99s at its most fragrant.\nScale this recipe up for larger crowds.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the orange-vanilla butter:\n8 tablespoons (1 stick) unsalted butter, room temperature\n1/2 cup packed dark brown sugar\n1 tablespoon orange zest\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract (or the seeds from 1/2 vanilla bean pod)\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/4 teaspoon ground ginger\n1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg\nPinch ground cloves\nPinch salt\nTo serve:\n6 ounces dark rum\n3 cups near-boiling hot water\nCinnamon sticks for garnish (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the compound butter: In a stand mixer with a beater attachment or using a hand mixer, beat together the butter, brown sugar, orange zest, vanilla, spices, and salt until light and fluffy. (If making ahead, transfer the butter to an airtight container and refrigerate until needed.)\n2 Make the hot buttered rums: Divide the butter between four mugs (3 to 4 tablespoons per mug). Add 1 1/2 ounces of rum per mug and then top with hot water. Stir together until the butter and sugar melt. Garnish with cinnamon sticks and enjoy while hot!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nCilantro Lime Compound Butter Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutes\nINGREDIENTS\n8 Tbsp unsalted butter, room temperature (slightly softened)\n1/4 cup finely chopped cilantro, packed\n1 Tbsp fresh squeezed lime juice\n1/2 teaspoon lime zest (optional)\n1 teaspoon salt\nMETHOD\n1 Mix together the chopped cilantro, lime juice, lime zest, and salt in a medium bowl.\n2 Smash the softened butter into the cilantro lime mixture and mix it until the cilantro is well distributed.\n3 To save the butter for later, wrap it up in plastic wrap in the shape of a log and refrigerate until stiff. To use, just unwrap and slice from the butter log.\nServe with corn-on-the-cob or over your favorite fill-in-the-blank.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. b"Save It Print\nAlaska Rockfish with Turmeric Cauliflower Steaks and Curry Butter Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: 4 servings\nThis recipe fits within the American Institute for Cancer Research's recommendations for a cancer preventative diet.\nHaving trouble finding rockfish? Cod makes a great substitute.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cauliflower:\n1 large (at least 3 pounds) or 2 small heads cauliflower\n4 tablespoons olive oil\nSalt and pepper, to taste\n1 1/4 teaspoons ground turmeric\n1 teaspoon coriander seeds, coarsely crushed with a rolling pin or mortar\n1 lemon, sliced into wedges\nFor the butter:\n1 lemon\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter, at room temperature\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh ginger\n1 teaspoon curry powder\n1 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest\n1/8 teaspoon salt\nPinch of black pepper\nFor the fish:\n4 (6-ounce) Alaska rockfish fillets\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n2 scallions, finely sliced, including some of the green part (for garnish)\n2 tablespoons chopped parsley\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xbaF. Spray or brush a rimmed baking sheet with olive oil.\n2 Slice the cauliflower into steaks: Remove all the outer leaves from the cauliflower and stand it upright on your cutting board (trim the bottom of the stem as needed to keep the cauliflower stable).\nWith a large knife, cut it into 3/4-inch thick slices. You will have some \xe2\x80\x9cscraps\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94slices or florets of cauliflower that are not attached to the core and fall apart, but you should get at least 4 slices that are intact.\n3 Roast the cauliflower: Brush both side of the steaks with oil, and toss the \xe2\x80\x9cscraps\xe2\x80\x9d with a little oil as well. Arrange them on the baking sheet, and sprinkle generously with salt and pepper, followed by the turmeric and coriander. Squeeze the lemon wedges over top.\nRoast for 25 to 30 minutes, or until golden and tender when you insert the tip of a knife into the steak. Remove from the oven and set aside.\n4 Lower the oven temperature down to 400\xc2\xbaF.\n5 Make the lemon-curry butter while the cauliflower bakes: Remove about 1 teaspoon of zest from the lemon and squeeze about 1 1/2 tablespoons of juice. In a food processor, process the butter, lemon zest and juice, ginger, curry powder, 1/8 teaspoon salt and a pinch of black pepper until combined. Scrape down the bowl once or twice as needed. Transfer to a bowl.\n6 Cook the fish: Line a baking sheet with foil and lightly brush with oil or spray with olive oil spray. Set the fillets on the baking sheet. Brush with 2 tablespoons of olive oil and sprinkle generously with salt and pepper.\nBake in the oven at 400\xc2\xbaF for 6 to 8 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and opaque.\nRemove from the oven, cover loosely with foil, and let the fish rest for 5 minutes.\n7 To serve: The cauliflower can be served warm or room temperature; return it to the oven for a few minutes to rewarm, if desired. Transfer the cauliflower to a large platter. Set the fillets on top and dot each fillet with the curry butter. Sprinkle with chopped scallions and parsley and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nApricot Hamantaschen Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hour, 30 minutesCook time: 12 minutesChill time: 12-72 hoursYield: 26-36 cookies\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the apricot filling:\n1-1/4 cups (7 ounces) dried apricots, preferably Turkish\n2 tablespoons honey\nFor the dough:\n2 cups (262 grams) all-purpose flour\n3/4 cup (156 grams) sugar\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter or margarine, chilled\n1 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest\n1 teaspoon finely grated orange zest\n1 large egg, lightly beaten\nSpecial equipment:\nFood processor\nBox grater\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the filling: Put the apricots in a small saucepan and add enough water to cover. Put on the lid, bring to a boil, reduce the heat, and simmer until the fruit is tender, about 10-15 minutes.\nRemove the apricots from the saucepan with a slotted spoon and place in a food processor. Reserve the cooking water.\nAdd the honey and 1 tablespoon of the cooking water to the food processor, and puree until very smooth, scraping down the sides of the food processor from time to time. If the fruit is too thick for the machine to puree it, add 1 to 2 more tablespoons of cooking water.\nScrape the filling into a container, let it cool, cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate overnight or up to 3 days before baking.\n2 Make the dough: Lay a large sheet of plastic wrap on the counter.\nIn a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Using the large holes of a box grater, grate the margarine or butter into the bowl (work quickly so the butter does not melt). Add the lemon and orange zest.\nWork the grated butter into the flour with a pastry cutter or your fingertips until the mixture resembles coarse cornmeal. Add the egg and knead with your hands for a minute or 2, until the dough is smooth and no longer crumbly.\nLay the dough on the plastic wrap, press into a flat rectangle, and wrap tightly. Chill in the refrigerator overnight, or up to 3 days.\n3 Heat the oven and prepare the baking sheets: Preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F and position racks in the upper and lower thirds of the oven. Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Take the dough out of the refrigerator and let it come to temperature for 10 minutes.\n4 Roll out the dough Lightly flour your countertop. Cut the dough in half; return one half to the refrigerator.\nDust both sides of the dough lightly with flour. Roll out to an even 1/8-inch thickness. Use a dry pastry brush or your hands to brush off the excess flour. Using a 3-inch biscuit or cookie cutter or a drinking glass, cut the dough into rounds.\nPlace the rounds on the baking sheets as you go. Once your first sheet is filled, pop it in the fridge so the cookies keep their shape while you work on the second baking sheet. Save and refrigerate the dough scraps.\nRepeat with remaining half of dough, then re-roll scraps and get as many rounds as you can out of them. (You\xe2\x80\x99ll have anywhere between 26 to 36 rounds).\n5 Fill the cookies: Transfer the chilled filling to a piping bag or a zip-top sandwich bag with the corner snipped off.\nWorking with one baking sheet at a time, pipe a circle of filling (about 1-1/2 teaspoons) on the center of each dough round. (You will likely have extra filling. Store it in the refrigerator and use it to spread on toast or stir into yogurt.)\n6 Shape the cookies: Start by folding one edge over. Fold the second edge over so one corner overlaps the other and forms a 60-degree angle. Fold the third edge over, creating the three distinct corners of a triangle. The first few cookies you shape might not be perfect, but you\xe2\x80\x99ll get the hang of it quickly. There is no need to press, pinch or seal the edges.\n7 Bake the cookies: Arrange the cookies so they are about 2 inches apart (they should all fit on two baking sheets). Bake and set your timer for 6 minutes.\nWhen the timer goes off, rotate the sheets front to back and top to bottom. Reset the timer, and bake the cookies for an additional 5 to 10 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown. Total baking time will be 12 to 16 minutes.\n8 Cool the cookies: Cool the cookies on sheets for 2 minutes, then transfer to cooling racks with a metal spatula. You may serve the cookies warm, but they are best at room temperature.\nThe cookies are crispiest on the day you bake them, but they will last up to 3 days in a tightly covered container.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHomemade Flour Tortillas\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesRest time: 30 minutesYield: 8 (7-inch) tortillas\nHomemade tortillas can become brittle after storing them. To make them pliable again just wrap them in a cloth and heat them in the microwave or in a skillet for 10-20 seconds.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups all-purpose flour\n3/4 teaspoon fine table salt\n3 tablespoons unsalted butter, vegetable shortening, or vegetable oil, at room temperature\n1/2 cup plus 1 tablespoon hot water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Mix the dough: You can mix the dough by hand or in a stand mixer. I\xe2\x80\x99ve provided instructions for both methods below. Choose the one that works best for you.\nTo mix the dough by hand: In a bowl, stir the flour and salt until blended. Add the shortening, butter, or oil and mix with your fingers until the fat is incorporated in small bits. Add the water and mix with your hands until blended. If the dough seems stiff and dry, add a little more water, 1 tablespoon at a time. On a lightly floured work surface, knead for a few minutes, or until the dough is smooth.\nTo mix the dough with a stand mixer: In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, mix the flour and salt on low speed. If using shortening or butter, add it in pieces to the flour and mix on low speed until it is blended. If using oil, stream it into the flour until blended.\nWith the mixer on low speed, slowly stream in the hot water, mixing until it forms a dough. If the dough seems stiff and dry, add a little more water, 1 tablespoon at a time. Turn the mixer to medium-low and mix for about 2 minutes, or until the dough is smooth and supple.\n2 Roughly form the tortillas: Sprinkle a large plate or small baking sheet with flour. On a lightly floured work surface, roll the dough into a cylinder about 6-8 inches long. Cut it into four equal pieces and cut each piece in half, to make eight pieces that are all about the same size.\nRoll the pieces into balls and flatten them into disks. You aren\xe2\x80\x99t rolling them out just yet. Just getting the basic shape in place. They need to rest before the final roll. Place them on the plate, cover with plastic wrap, and allow to rest at room temperature for 30 minutes.\n3 Roll the tortillas: Lightly flour the work surface and the rolling pin. Start from the center of each disk and roll outward from the center towards the edge and then back towards you. Turn the disk 45 degrees and repeat. Keep rolling back and forth, turning, and flipping the circle of dough over from time to time, until the tortilla is about 7-inches in diameter.\nContinue to roll the tortillas, stacking them between layers of parchment or waxed paper until they are all rolled. Let rest while you heat the pan.\n4 Cook the tortillas: Heat a cast iron pan, griddle, or another skillet over medium heat until hot. Line a plate with a clean dishtowel or napkin.\nPlace one tortilla on the hot pan and cook for about 30 seconds. Air bubbles will appear on the surface and they should have light brown spots on the bottom. Adjust the heat \xe2\x80\x93 you may need to lower it \xe2\x80\x93 so the tortillas cook gently without burning.\nTurn them over and cook for another 20 to 30 seconds on the other side. The tortilla should look puffed up and opaque. If the tortilla needs a little longer, flip for a third time and cook and additional 10 or 12 seconds.\nWhen finished with a tortilla, place it on the dishtowel-lined plate and cover it.\nContinue to cook, stack, and cover the remaining tortillas. (No need to sandwich cooked tortillas between layers of paper.)\n5 Steam the tortillas: If you are eating them right away, wrap them in a cloth napkin and let them steam for 5 to 10 minutes.\nIf you are planning to store them to reheat later, turn a plastic zip-top bag inside out. Place the hot stack of tortillas in the bag, close the bag without sealing it, and let cool.\nWhen cool, remove the tortillas, turn the bag right side out, and slip the stack inside the bag and seal it. The droplets of steam will now be on the outside of the bag and you can pat them dry with a dishtowel.\n6 Store the tortillas: Store the well-sealed bag in the refrigerator for up to four days, or freeze for up to two months.\n7 Reheat the tortillas: Just before serving, heat a skillet or griddle over medium heat. Place each tortilla on the hot pan, and cook for 10 to 12 seconds on each side, or until hot. You can also reheat them in a microwave for 15 to 20 seconds.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nEasy Vanilla Buttercream Frosting\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: 4 cups\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup (227g) unsalted butter, room temperature\n4 cups (460g) powdered sugar\n2-4 tablespoons heavy whipping cream\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract\nPinch of kosher salt\nSpecial equipment:\nStand mixer with a whisk attachment, or hand mixer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Beat the butter: In the bowl of a stand mixer (or a large mixing bowl and a hand mixer) beat the butter until creamy.\n2 Add the sugar and a little cream: Add 2 cups of powdered sugar and 1 tablespoon of heavy cream. Mix on low until the powdered sugar is incorporated into the butter, scrape down the sides, then turn up the mixer to high and beat for 1 minute. Scrape down the bowl and repeat the process with the remaining 2 cups of powdered sugar and another 1 tablespoon of cream.\n3 Add the extract and salt: Add the vanilla and salt and beat to combine. If the buttercream seems too stiff, beat in an additional 1-2 tablespoons of cream at a time. You want it to hold a peak, but be soft enough to spread with little effort.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nMini Garlic Butter Pretzels Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesRise time: 1 hourYield: 16 mini pretzels\nFor a darker color on the pretzels, brush them with an egg wash prior to baking.\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4 cup warm water (100-105\xcb\x9aF)\n1 teaspoon sugar\n2 1/4 teaspoons or one packet (7 grams) of active dry yeast\n2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n6 cups water\n2 tablespoons baking soda\nFor the garlic butter sauce:\n6 tablespoons unsalted butter\n4 cloves garlic, chopped\nCoarse salt\nFresh parsley, garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Activate the yeast: In a small bowl, stir together warm water, sugar, and yeast. Let sit for 5 minutes so yeast can activate. It should be bubbling. (If not, your yeast is old and should be replaced.)\n2 Make the pretzel dough: In a large bowl, stir together flour and salt. Pour in yeast mixture and stir to form a dough. Knead the dough for 6-7 minutes in the bowl until it\xe2\x80\x99s smooth and no longer sticky. If the dough is really sticky, add more flour by the 1/4 cup.\nWhen dough is smooth, transfer to a clean bowl. Cover loosely with a towel or plastic wrap and place in a warm area to rise. Let dough rise for 60 minutes or until the dough at least doubles in size.\n3 Boil a pot of water: Fill a large pot with 6 cups of boiling water and 2 tablespoons baking soda. Bring to a boil. Get out two baking sheets. Line one with parchment paper. Place a wire-rimmed rack on top of the other.\n4 Preheat the oven to 400\xcb\x9aF.\n5 Shape the mini pretzels and boil: After the dough has risen, divide it into quarters and then each quarter into four pieces to make 16 small dough balls. Working with one dough ball at a time, roll the dough out into a thin strand about 12-14 inches long. Form a pretzel by twisting two ends together to form a loop and then folding the ends back up.\nWhen your pretzel is formed, dunk it in the pot of boiling water. Wait until the pretzel floats (maybe 10 seconds) and then remove with a slotted spoon and place on the wire rack over a baking sheet. Let drain. Once all the pretzels have been boiled, move them to the lined baking sheet.\n6 Bake the pretzels: When all the pretzels are shaped, boiled, and placed on the baking sheet, transfer to the oven and bake for 10-12 minutes until they start to brown.\n7 Toss with the garlic butter sauce, then bake for 3-4 more minutes: In a small saucepan, melt butter with garlic over low heat. Once combined, remove from heat to avoid burning butter.\nWhen pretzels come out of the oven, add them to a large bowl and toss with garlic butter mixture. Return to baking sheet, spooning any leftover sauce over each pretzel. Sprinkle pretzels lightly with coarse salt, then return pretzels to oven and bake a second time for 3-4 minutes.\n8 Let cool and serve: Remove pretzels and let cool. Garnish finished pretzels with fresh parsley.\nPretzels are best served slightly warm. Store pretzels in an airtight container on the counter for 1-2 days or in the fridge for up to a week. Reheat in a low 300\xcb\x9aF oven until warmed through, 3-4 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nButter Pecan Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 1 dozen cookies\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4 cup pecans, chopped\n1/2 cup (1 stick, 112 g) unsalted butter, room temperature\n1/3 cup (70 g) sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/8 teaspoon salt\n1 cup (140 g) all-purpose flour\nMETHOD\n1 Make cookie dough: With an electric mixer, beat the butter for about a minute. Add 1/3 cup sugar and beat until light, about 1 minute more. Beat in vanilla, salt, and flour, scraping down sides of bowl, just until dough comes together. Fold in pecans.\n2 Roll into balls: Separate dough into 12 pieces; squeeze dough to shape into balls. Place, 3 inches apart, on a baking sheet.\n3 Gently flatten with the bottom of a glass (reshape sides if necessary).\n4 Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) until golden brown, rotating sheet halfway through, about 15 minutes. Cool cookies on a wire rack.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nButter Pecan Ice Cream Recipe\nYield: Makes 1 1/2 quarts\nINGREDIENTS\nIce cream base:\n6 large egg yolks\n6 Tbsp unsalted butter\n1 cup brown sugar\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n2 cups heavy cream\n2 cups whole milk\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nPecans:\n1 cup pecans\n1 Tbsp unsalted butter\nPinch of salt\nSpecial equipment:\nIce cream maker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Whisk egg yolks: In a medium sized heat-safe bowl (metal, ceramic, or glass), whisk together the egg yolks until well blended. Set aside.\n2 Set cream in bowl over ice, with a sieve on top: Pour the cream into a metal bowl set in a larger bowl of ice and set a medium-mesh sieve on top. Set aside.\n3 Brown the butter, add brown sugar and salt: In a medium thick-bottomed saucepan on medium heat, melt the butter cook it, stirring constantly, until it just begins to brown.\nAdd the brown sugar and salt. Stir until the sugar completely melts.\n4 Add milk slowly, dissolve sugar: Slowly add the milk, stirring to incorporate. It will foam up initially, so make sure you are using a pan with high enough sides. Heat until all of the sugar is completely dissolved. Do not let boil or the mixture may curdle.\n5 Temper the eggs: Whisk in hand, slowly pour half of the milk and sugar mixture into the eggs, whisking constantly to incorporate.\nThen add the warmed egg mixture back into the saucepan with the remaining milk sugar mixture.\n6 Stir until custard base thickens: Stir the mixture constantly over medium heat with a wooden or heatproof rubber spatula, scraping the bottom as you stir, until the mixture thickens and coats the spatula, about 5-7 minutes.\n7 Pour the custard through the sieve and stir it into the cream. Add vanilla and stir until cool over the ice bath.\n8 Chill mixture thoroughly in the refrigerator.\n9 Toast the pecans: While the mixture is chilling, preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Melt 1 Tbsp of butter. Toss with pecans and a pinch of salt.\nSpread pecans out on a rimmed baking sheet and bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 10 minutes, until the pecans are lightly toasted. Set aside to cool.\nOnce cool, roughly chop the pecans and set aside.\n10 Process in your ice cream maker: Once the ice cream mixture is thoroughly chilled, process in your ice cream maker according to the manufacturer's instructions.\n11 Fold in chopped toasted pecans: Once the ice cream has been formed in the ice cream maker, it will be fairly soft. Fold in the chopped pecans.\n12 Freeze: Put in an airtight plastic container and place in the freezer for at least an hour, preferably several hours.\nIf it has been frozen for more than a day, you may need to let it sit at room temperature for a few minutes to soften it before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nEasy Blender Hollandaise Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: Makes about 1 cup of sauce, good for about 4-6 servings.\nINGREDIENTS\n10 tablespoons unsalted butter (if using salted butter, skip the added salt)\n3 egg yolks (see how to separate eggs)\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon cayenne (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Melt the butter: Melt the butter slowly in a small pot. Try not to let it boil\xe2\x80\x94you want the moisture in the butter to remain there and not steam away.\n2 Blend egg yolks, lemon juice, salt, until lightened in color: Add the egg yolks, lemon juice, salt and cayenne (if using) into your blender. Blend the egg yolk mixture at a medium to medium high speed until it lightens in color, about 20-30 seconds.\nThe friction generated by the blender blades will heat the yolks a bit. The blending action will also introduce a little air into them, making your hollandaise a bit lighter.\n3 Lower blender setting, slowly drizzle in melted butter: Once the yolks have lightened in color, turn the blender down to its lowest setting (if you only have one speed on your blender it will still work), and drizzle in the hot melted butter slowly, while the blender is going.\nContinue to blend for another couple seconds after the butter is all incorporated.\n4 Adjust salt and lemon juice to taste: Turn off the blender and taste the sauce. It should be buttery, lemony and just lightly salty. If it is not salty or lemony enough, you can add a little lemon juice or salt to taste.\nIf you want a thinner consistency, add a little warm water. Pulse briefly to incorporate the ingredients one more time.\nStore until needed in a warm spot, e.g. next to the stovetop. Use within an hour or so.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nLemon-Garlic Butter Sauce for Seafood Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes a little more than 1 1/2 cups\nUse whole milk or cream with water. Do not use low-fat milk or the sauce may curdle.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup clam juice (can substitute chicken stock)\n1/2 cup dry sherry\n1/2 cup whole milk (OR 3 Tbsp cream with 5 Tbsp water)\n1 Tbsp minced garlic\n1 Tbsp minced shallots\n1 bay leaf\n1 Tbsp unsalted butter\n1 Tbsp flour\n1/2 pound (2 sticks) unsalted butter\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon white pepper\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Simmer and reduce the liquids, with garlic, shallots, and bay leaf: Place first six ingredients (clam juice, sherry, whole milk, garlic, shallots, bay leaf) in a small saucepan.\nHeat on medium high heat and let simmer until the liquids have reduced by about half.\n2 Make a roux: In a separate saucepan (1-qt minimum) prepare the roux. Heat one tablespoon of butter in the saucepan on medium heat until it is foamy.\nSprinkle in the flour, stirring a couple of minutes with a metal whisk until well mixed (tan, but not browned).\n3 Slowly add liquid mixture to roux: Slowly add the reduced mixture to the roux, stirring quickly to incorporate. When you first add some of the mixture, the roux will bubble up. Just keep adding the mixture and keep whisking to incorporate.\n4 Slowly incorporate butter, 2 Tbsp at a time: Lower the heat to low. Remove the bay leaf. Slowly whisk in the butter, 2 tablespoons at a time. Let the butter tablespoons fully melt and be incorporated into the sauce before adding more tablespoons.\n5 Stir in lemon juice, salt, and white pepper. Add some more clam stock or water if the sauce is too thick.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nOrange Butter Sauce (Beurre Blanc) for Seafood Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes about 1 cup\nYou'll need one large orange or two smallish oranges to have enough juice for this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 oranges\n1/2 cup (120 ml) white wine\n2 teaspoons minced shallots\n1/2 pound (2 sticks, 225 g) cold, unsalted butter\nSalt and white pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make a syrup with orange zest, orange juice, wine, and shallots:  Zest half of one orange (about 2 teaspoons) and juice the two oranges (about 3/4 cup).\nPut the juice, zest, wine and shallots in a sauce pan on medium high heat.\nCook until it is syrupy and almost gone.\n2 Slowly whisk in butter: On low heat, whisk in the butter continuously and vigorously, 1 tablespoon at a time.\nButter is the only emulsifier for this sauce, and if you slowly add it, continuously stirring, the sauce will achieve a silky smooth texture. Do not let the sauce boil!\n3 Add salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nRicotta Stuffed Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 whole roasting chicken, 4 to 5 lbs.\nStuffing:\n12 oz. ricotta cheese\n1/3 cup grated Parmesan cheese\n1 egg\n2 teaspoons chopped fresh basil (or 1 teaspoon dried)\n1 teaspoon chopped fresh tarragon (or 1/2 teaspoon dried)\n2 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley\n1 large clove garlic, minced\nRub:\nSalt\nExtra virgin olive oil\n1 teaspoon chopped fresh basil (or 1/2 teaspoon dried)\n1/2 teaspoon chopped fresh tarragon (or 1/4 teaspoon dried)\n1/4 teaspoon paprika\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Butterfly the chicken: Rinse chicken and pat dry with paper towels. Butterfly the chicken by using poultry shears or a knife to cut along one side of the backbone. Cut along the other side and remove the backbone and tail. (See our guide to how to spatchcock or butterfly a chicken.)\nSpread the chicken open, skin side up. Press down on the chicken with the palms of your hands (or pound with your fists) to flatten the chicken. Fold the wings under the chicken.\n2 Make ricotta Parmesan herb mixture: In a medium bowl, mix the ricotta, Parmesan cheese, egg, parsley, garlic, 2 teaspoons of chopped basil, and 1 teaspoon of chopped tarragon.\n3 Stuff ricotta mixture under chicken skin: Using a sharp paring knife and your fingers, loosen skin over top of chicken and drumsticks starting at neck edge. Work with your fingers and hand to press under the chicken skin to separate the chicken skin from the chicken breasts, thighs, and drumsticks. Be gentle, the skin can easily tear.\nCarefully spoon cheese mixture under skin of chicken, pressing with your fingers to distribute evenly over the chicken and drumsticks.\n4 Season chicken: Brush chicken lightly with oil; sprinkle with 1/2 teaspoon basil, 1/2 teaspoon tarragon, paprika, and a generous amount of salt.\n5a Cook chicken using an oven: Preheat oven to 500\xc2\xb0F. Place chicken, skin side up, on a rack in a roasting pan. Place in oven and immediately turn the heat down to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n5b OR Cook chicken using a grill: Prepare grill for medium indirect heat. If using a gas grill, heat all burners on high until the grill is hot, then turn off the middle burner.\nIf using a charcoal grill, bank the coals to one side of the grill and place a large aluminum drip pan underneath the grate on the side without coals, adding a couple cups of water to the drip pan so that the drippings don't burn.\nPlace the chicken, skin side up, on the cooking grate, away from the side with coals if you are using a charcoal grill, or above the middle burner if you are using gas.\nAlternatively, you can lay the chicken out on a rack in a disposable aluminum roasting pan and place the roasting pan on the cooking grate (this tip works well with gas grills, I haven't tried it with the charcoal one yet). Cover the grill.\n6 Roast the chicken for an hour or until the juices run clear from the thigh when pierced with a fork. (Chicken should have an internal temperature of 165\xc2\xb0F when tested with a meat thermometer.) If the skin browns before the chicken is cooked through, cover it loosely with foil.\n7 Let rest: Transfer chicken to a cutting board; let stand 10 minutes. Cut into quarters to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nHow to Spatchcock (Butterfly) a Chicken\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 4 or more servings, depending on the size of the bird\nThis method will work with any size bird, even turkeys.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 whole chicken\nSpecial equipment:\nKitchen shears\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Lay the chicken breast side down on a cutting surface. You should be looking down at the chicken's backbone.\n2 Using kitchen shears, cut out the backbone. You can start from the top of the chicken or the bottom. Cut slightly to one side of the backbone, so that you're cutting through rib bones and not the backbone itself.\nIf it feels very difficult to cut through the bones, try repositioning your scissors slightly further away from the backbone.\nCut all the way up one side of the backbone and then all the way up the other. Remove the backbone and set it aside.\n3 Use your hands to open up the bird slightly, then flip it breast side up. Now the breast of the chicken should be facing up. Fold the legs so they are facing inward and the majority of the meat is facing up.\n4 Flatten the chicken: Use the palm of your hand and press down firmly over the breast bone.\nThe aim is to flatten the chicken so the breast meat and the thighs are at roughly the same level. You will likely hear some crunching (though it's ok if you don't). You can also pick up the chicken and use your hands if that feels more comfortable.\n5 Tuck the wings under (optional): The tips of the tiny, thin wings tend to cook quickly and burn during cooking. Tuck them behind the body of the chicken to help slow down their cooking and keep the tips protected.\n5 Roast or grill the chicken. If roasting, place the chicken in a roasting pan, rub it all over with olive oil, and sprinkle with salt and pepper. Roast at 450\xc2\xb0F for 35 to 45 minutes, until the chicken registers at least 165\xc2\xb0F in both the thighs and the breast.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nSpatchcocked Grilled Chicken with Orange and Ginger Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesMarinating time: 2 hours to overnightYield: 4 to 6 servings\nAsk your butcher to spatchcock the chicken for you, or do it yourself following the directions in Step 1 of the recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken:\n1 (4-pound) chicken\nSalt and pepper, to taste\nOil, for the grill \nFor the marinade:\n1 orange, zest and juice (about 1/2 tablespoon zest and 1/3 cup juice)\n1 lemon, juiced (about 2 tablespoons)\n3 tablespoons finely chopped fresh ginger\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 tablespoon honey\n1 tablespoon whole coriander seeds, crushed (or 1/2 teaspoon ground coriander)\n2 teaspoons paprika\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n  Special equipment:\nKitchen shears\nCharcoal grill or gas grill\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Spatchcock the chicken (if not already spatchcocked at the butcher): With kitchen shears or a sharp knife, cut along each side of the backbone (cutting through the rib bones) and remove it. Save it for stock, if you like.\nTurn the chicken over so it is lying breast side up on the cutting board. Press firmly on the breastbone to flatten it.\nPat the chicken dry, and sprinkle with salt and pepper on both sides. Place it in a baking dish.\n2 Make the marinade: In a small bowl, stir together the orange zest, orange juice, lemon juice, ginger, olive oil, honey, coriander, paprika and salt. Pour the marinade over the chicken, turning to coat.\nCover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or up to overnight, turning occasionally in the marinade.\n3 Prepare a gas or charcoal grill: If using a gas grill, set one side to high temperature and the other side to low temperature. Heat the grill to at least 450F.\nIf using a charcoal grill, prepare a two-level fire. Arrange two-thirds of the charcoal on one side of the grill and spread the remaining one-third on the other side.\nWhen your gas or charcoal grill is hot, use tongs to oil the grill grates with a small folded piece of paper towel dipped in oil.\n4 Grill the chicken: Set the chicken on the cool side of the grill with the skin side up and legs facing the hot side. Cover with the lid and cook for 20 minutes.\nRotate the chicken, still skin-side up, so that the breast side is closer to the hot side. Continue to cook for another 10 to 20 minutes, or until an instant read thermometer registers at least 165F when inserted into both the thigh and breast.\n(Exact cooking time will depend on the heat of your grill and the size of the bird, so always double-check the internal temperature.)\n5 Crisp the skin: Once the chicken has cooked through, carefully flip the chicken over onto the hot side of the grill. Cook for an additional 1 to 3 minutes, or until the skin is brown and crisp.\n6 Let the chicken rest: Transfer the chicken to a cutting board and let rest for 10 minutes. Cut into pieces and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nHow to Make Gluten-Free Biscuits Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesChilling time: 30 minutesYield: 10 (2 1/2-inch) biscuits\nYou can also bring this dough together in the food processor (with gentle pulses) and by hand (soak your hands in cold water; the butter should be even colder), but we have found that using the stand mixer works quickly and requires the least amount of manual interference with cold butter. And this is what you want for flaky biscuits!\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups (about 300 g) gluten-free flour mix, preferably Bob\xe2\x80\x99s Red Mill 1-to-1 Gluten-Free Baking Blend or another flour blend with xanthan gum\n1 tablespoon baking powder\n3/4 teaspoon baking soda\n2 tablespoons sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup (8 tablespoons) very cold butter, cut into tablespoons and then cut in half, plus more to grease the pan\n3/4 to 1 cup cup cold buttermilk\n1 tablespoon melted unsalted butter\nSpecial equipment:\n9-inch cast iron skillet, or 8x8 baking dish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine dry ingredients: Mix flour, baking powder, baking soda, sugar, and salt in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. \n2 Add the butter: On the low speed, let the mixer break up the butter into smaller pieces; this should take about a minute. Stop the mixer and check; you still want visible pieces of butter about the size of marbles or even a little bigger. They will look like they are starting to flatten.\nThis dough is not a situation where we say the flour and butter should look like \xe2\x80\x9cthe consistency of small peas.\xe2\x80\x9d If some of the pieces haven't flattened, just press them between your fingertips to break them up a little bit\xe2\x80\x94dime-sized pieces are fine.\n3 Add the buttermilk: Remove the bowl from the stand mixer and add 2 tablespoons of buttermilk. Using a fork, quickly mix the buttermilk into the flour to hydrate it.\nThen, slowly mix in a scant 3/4 cup of buttermilk and combine with a fork until no streaks of flour remain. If the dough seems dry, add additional buttermilk a tablespoon at a time and incorporate before adding more. You don't want a wet dough.\n4 Gather the dough into a ball: On a floured surface, turn out the dough, which will look like a crumbly mess. It will come together when you begin to shape it into a ball. If for some reason (ambient humidity, variations in buttermilk thickness) the dough feels dry, add a couple of tablespoons of buttermilk to hydrate those dry bits.\n5 Fold the dough like a letter: Lightly press the dough (or roll it with a floured rolling pin) into a thick rectangular shape, about 4 inches by 6 inches. Fold one of the short ends of the dough toward the middle, and then the other, like a letter.\nRotate the dough 1/4 turn and roll it out, and fold it again into thirds. Repeat this process one more time, then wrap the dough in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 1/2 hour to an hour. (This process creates flaky layers; if you skip it, your biscuits will bake flat, like hockey pucks.) \n6 Prep the oven and pan: Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xb0F and prep a 9- or 10-inch cast iron pan or an 8x8 glass baking dish with either spray oil or grease with butter.\n7 Roll and cut out the biscuits: Remove the dough from the fridge and, using a rolling pin, gently roll it out to a rectangle about 6 inches by 9 inches and one inch thick. Using a 2 1/2-inch biscuit cutter that\xe2\x80\x99s been lightly floured (this dough can be sticky), cut out about 6 biscuits by pressing the cutter straight down into the dough; if you twist them when you remove them, you\xe2\x80\x99ll stunt their rise!\nReroll the scraps, reflouring the biscuit cutter if needed, and make more biscuits until all the dough is used up.\nTransfer to the pan. You will have to nestle them close to each other, and that\xe2\x80\x99s okay. You want them touching in order for them to rise better. Brush the tops with the melted butter.\n8 Bake: Bake the biscuits for 20 to 25 minutes until the tops look lightly brown around the edges. Check frequently to avoid burning.\n9 Cool and serve: Remove from the oven and brush the tops with melted butter. Let the biscuits cool in the pan for about 5 to 10 minutes before removing from the pan to a wire rack to cool completely. Try to wait the seemingly impossible 10 minutes before you eat one. They will continue to cook a little, firm up a little while cooling, and not burn your mouth. It\xe2\x80\x99s all worth the wait.\nThese biscuits are best eaten warm out of the oven, but they do okay reheated in a toaster or low oven (300\xc2\xb0F) for up to 2 days. They get dried out pretty fast.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nBiscuits and Gravy Recipe\nCook time: 35 minutesYield: Makes 10 to 12 servings\nI recommend preparing the biscuits first (not baking them), getting the gravy started, and then baking the biscuits while the gravy is thickening up. That way you can stir the gravy frequently which is hard to do when your hands are covered with flour and dough.\nIf you don't have self-rising flour, you can substitute using a ratio of 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 1/4 teaspoon baking powder, plus 1/8 teaspoon of salt, for every cup of self-rising flour.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the Buttermilk Biscuits:\n2 1/2 cups self-rising flour (plus extra for flouring your surface)\n2 tsp sugar (optional)\n1/2 tsp kosher salt\n4 Tbsp vegetable shortening (see Baking Tips below)\n4 Tbsp butter, cut into cubes, chilled\n1 cup chilled buttermilk, plus 1-2 Tbsp more, if needed\n1 Tbsp melted butter (optional, to brush on top of biscuits after baking)\nFor the Sausage Gravy:\n1 lb sage-flavored pork sausage\n1/4 cup finely chopped white or yellow onion\n6 tbsp all purpose flour\n4 cups whole milk\n1/2 tsp poultry seasoning\n1/4 tsp ground nutmeg\n1/4 tsp salt\n1-2 dashes of Worcestershire sauce\n1-2 dashes of Tabasco sauce, cayenne pepper, or other hot sauce\n1-2 Tbsp butter or bacon grease (if needed)\nMETHOD\nTO MAKE THE BUTTERMILK BISCUITS:\nBaking Tips: 1) Spoon the flour into your measuring cup, and level it off with the back side of a knife. If you scoop the flour, it will pack into the measuring cup, yielding too much flour, 2) Instead of 4 Tbsp each of butter and shortening, feel free to use 8 Tbsp of shortening or butter, or any combination up to 8 Tbsp.\n1 Preheat oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. Prepare a floured surface for shaping the dough and have an un-greased baking sheet ready (lined with Silpat sheets if you have them).\n2 Whisk together flour, sugar and salt in a medium-sized bowl.\n3 Using a fork or a pastry blender cut in the shortening and butter. Work quickly, you don\xe2\x80\x99t want the fats to melt \xe2\x80\x93 the key to fluffy biscuits is minimal handling. The mixture should be crumbly.\n4 Make a well in the flour mixture, and pour in the buttermilk. Stir with a spoon and blend just until the liquid is absorbed and the dough comes away from the sides of the bowl \xe2\x80\x93 add 1-2 tbsp more buttermilk if the dough is dry. Do not over mix; the dough will be tacky, neither wet nor dry.\n5 Fold and shape dough: With lightly floured hands, turn out the dough onto a lightly-floured surface and gently fold it over on itself 2 or 3 times. Shape into a 3/4\xe2\x80\x9d thick round. If you use a rolling pin, be sure to flour it first to keep the dough from sticking to the pin.\n6 Cut out biscuits: Using a 2-inch biscuit cutter, cut out the biscuits pressing straight down (avoid the temptation to twist the cutter as twisting keeps the biscuits from rising). Dip the cutter in flour between cuttings to keep the dough from sticking to the cutter.\nPlace biscuits on the baking sheet so that they just touch (for crunchy sides, leave space in between). Reshape scrap dough and continue cutting. Remember to handle the dough as little as possible.\n(At this point you can start on making the sausage gravy below, and put the biscuits in the oven right before adding the milk in the last gravy step.)\n7 Bake: Bake at 450\xc2\xb0F for 15-18 minutes or until lightly golden brown on top. Turn the baking sheet around halfway through baking.\n8 Brush with butter: (Optional) Brush the tops of the biscuits with melted butter.\nTO MAKE THE SAUSAGE GRAVY:\n1 Brown the sausage, stir in onions: Preheat a 4-quart saucepan over medium high heat (put a few drops of water in the pan \xe2\x80\x93 when they evaporate, you know the pan is ready). Crumble the sausage into the pan and let it brown for a minute or two, then turn down to medium heat.\nContinue cooking, breaking up the sausage into smaller pieces, until no pink remains. Stir in the onions and cook until they are transparent.\n2 Adjust fat, add flour, brown the flour: Remove sausage with a slotted spatula or spoon, leaving the drippings in the pan. If less than 3 tbsp of drippings remain, add enough butter (or bacon grease) to equal about 3 tbsp of drippings.\nAdd the cooked sausage back to the pan on medium heat, and sprinkle the flour over the sausage.\nStir in the flour and cook for about 6-8 minutes, until the mixture starts bubbling and turns slightly golden brown.\n3 Add seasonings: Stir in poultry seasoning, nutmeg, Worcestershire sauce, Tabasco sauce and salt \xe2\x80\x93 cook for 1 minute to deepen the flavors.\n4 Add the milk, and cook until thickened: Slowly add the milk and cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until thickened (about 15 minutes). Be patient, it will thicken!\nTO SERVE THE BISCUITS AND GRAVY:\nTo serve, break a biscuit in half and put it in a bowl or on a plate. Spoon a generous portion of sausage gravy over the biscuit half and top with the other biscuit half.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nBoston Brown Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nDo your best to find the rye flour. It adds a lot to the flavor of the finished bread.\nINGREDIENTS\nButter for greasing loaf pans or coffee cans\n1/2 cup (heaping) all-purpose flour\n1/2 cup (heaping) rye flour\n1/2 cup (heaping) finely ground corn meal (must be finely ground)\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon allspice\n1/2 cup molasses (any kind)\n1 cup buttermilk\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract (optional)\n1/2 cup raisins (optional)\nOne metal 6-inch tall by 4-inch diameter coffee can, or a 4x8 loaf pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare for either stovetop or oven methods: You can either make the bread on the stovetop with a coffee can, or you can make it in the oven with a coffee can or loaf pan.\nStovetop: If you are using the stovetop method, set the steamer rack inside a tall stockpot and fill the pot with enough water to come 1/3 of the way up the sides of your coffee can. Turn the burner on to medium as you work.\nOven: If you are using the oven method, preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F and bring a large pot of water to a boil.\n2 Grease pan: Grease a coffee can or small loaf pan with butter.\n3 Mix dry ingredients:  In a large bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, rye flour, corn meal, baking powder and soda, salt and allspice. Add the raisins if using.\n4 Mix wet ingredients, combine with dry: In another bowl, mix together the buttermilk and vanilla extract if using. Whisk in the molasses.\nPour the wet ingredients into the dry and stir well with a spoon.\n5 Pour batter into can or pan, cover with foil: Pour the batter into the coffee can or loaf pan taking care that the batter not reach higher than 2/3 up the sides of the container.\nCover the loaf pan or coffee can tightly with foil.\n6 Prepare steam environment on stovetop or oven:\nStovetop: If you are using the stovetop method, set the can in the pot on the steamer rack. Make sure there is enough water in the pot to come up 1/3 of the way up the sides of your coffee can or loaf pan. Cover the pot and turn the heat to high.\nOven: If you are using the oven method, find a high-sided roasting pan that can hold the coffee can or loaf pan. Pour the boiling water into the roasting pan until it reaches one third up the side of the coffee can or loaf pan. Put the roasting pan into the 325\xc2\xb0F oven.\n7 Steam the bread: Steam the bread on the stovetop or in the oven for at least 2 hours and 15 minutes.\nCheck to see if the bread is done by inserting a toothpick into it. If the toothpick comes out clean, you're ready. If not, re-cover the pan and cook for up to another 45 minutes.\n8 Allow bread to cool: Remove from the stovetop or oven and let cool for 10 minutes before putting on a rack. Let the bread cool for 1 hour before turning out of the container.\nSlice and eat plain, or toast in a little butter in a frying pan.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nClassic Buttermilk Waffles Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 6 Belgian-sized waffles, or 12 regular waffles\nFor extra-crispy waffles, replace half of the buttermilk with whole milk and reduce the baking soda to 1/2 teaspoon.\nLet your waffle iron fully heat before using or your waffles might not cook evenly.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups (280g) all-purpose flour\n2 tablespoons sugar\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 cups buttermilk, well-shaken\n1/4 cup (1/2 stick) unsalted butter, melted\n2 large eggs\n1/4 cup melted butter for the waffle iron, optional\nSpecial equipment:\nWaffle iron\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Warm the oven to 250F. Set a wire metal cooling rack on top of a baking sheet and place in the oven. (You can also toast waffles directly on the oven rack, if you prefer.)\n2 Whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.\n3 Whisk together the buttermilk and butter. Whisk in the eggs.\n4 Stir the buttermilk mixture into the flour. Continue gently stirring just until you see no more streaks of dry flour.\n5 Rest the batter while your waffle iron warms: Cover the batter with a clean kitchen towel and let it rest for at least five minutes while you warm the waffle iron. The waffle iron is ready when a drop of water sizzles on contact with the griddle.\n6 Make the waffles: Brush the waffle iron with melted butter, if you like. This helps give your waffles a golden color and prevents sticking, but isn't crucial for the recipe. Scoop 1/3 to 1/2 cup of batter into each grid of the waffle iron and cook until golden, according to your waffle iron's instructions.\n7 Transfer the cooked waffles to the oven: When the waffles are done, transfer them to the cooling rack on the baking sheet in the oven. Place them in one single layer so that they crisp evenly on top and bottom, and so steam isn't trapped between layers. Let them toast for 5 to 10 minutes.\n8 Cook the remaining waffles: Transfer each batch of waffles to the oven as they are ready. Waffles that have been toasting for a few minutes can now be stacked to make room for the following batches.\n9 Serve the waffles: Serve the waffles as soon as all batches are made and crisped. Let leftover waffles cool completely, then store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to a week, or freeze for up to 3 months. Reheat briefly in the toaster until warmed and crisped.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nHomemade Buttermilk Ranch Dressing Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: Makes about 1 1/2 cups\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup buttermilk\n1/2 cup mayonnaise\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\n1/8 teaspoon paprika\n1/4 teaspoon mustard powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper\n1 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley\n1 teaspoon chopped fresh chives\n1/4 teaspoon of dry dill (or a teaspoon chopped fresh)\nMETHOD\nIn a medium bowl, stir together the buttermilk and mayonnaise until fully mixed. Add in the other ingredients, adjusting for taste.\nKeeps for a week, covered in the fridge.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nJeweled Rice Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 6-8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the salad:\n1 1/2 cups wild rice\n8 cups water\n1 1/4 teaspoons salt, divided\n1 half butternut squash, peeled (about 1 pound), cut into 3/4-inch cubes\n3 tablespoons Filippo Berio Delicato Extra Virgin Olive Oil, divided\n1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/3 cup blanched slivered almonds\n1/3 cup shelled pistachios\n1/2 red onion, finely chopped\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon ground coriander seed\n1/2 teaspoon ground turmeric\n1/8 teaspoon ground cloves\n1/3 cup dried cranberries\n1/3 cup golden raisins\n1/3 cup finely diced apricots\nFinely grated zest of 1 orange\n1/2 cup pomegranate seeds (from about 1/2 pomegranate)\n1 handful of torn mint leaves\nFor the dressing:\n1/3 cup freshly squeezed orange juice\n2 tablespoons white wine vinegar\n1 teaspoon honey\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/3 cup Filippo Berio Delicato Extra Virgin Olive Oil\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the rice: In a large pot, bring 8 cups water and 1 teaspoon of the salt to a boil. Add the rice, return the water to a boil, and immediately reduce the heat to a gentle simmer. Simmer for 45 minutes, or until the rice is tender.\nDrain in a sieve or fine-mesh colander. Transfer to a large bowl.\n2 Roast the squash: Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xbaF. On a rimmed baking sheet, mound the squash in the center. Sprinkle with 2 tablespoons of the olive oil, remaining 1/4 teaspoon salt, and pepper. Toss to coat the squash, massaging the olive oil into the cubes to coat them.\nSpread in one layer and roast for 20 to 25 minutes, or until tender. Remove and cool on the baking sheet.\n 3 Toast the nuts: In a medium skillet over medium heat, toast the almonds and pistachios until the almonds are golden and the nuts are fragrant, about 4 minutes. Transfer to a plate. \n4 Cook the onions and bloom the spices: Add the remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil to the skillet. Over medium heat, cook the onions, stirring occasionally, for 4 to 5 minutes or until softened. Add the ground cinnamon, ground coriander, turmeric, and ground cloves. Stir for 30 seconds.\nFold in the cranberries, raisins, and apricots and remove from heat.\n 5 Make the dressing: In a small bowl, combine the orange juice, vinegar, honey, salt, and pepper. Whisk in the olive oil until emulsified. Taste and add more salt or pepper, as desired.\n6 Assemble the salad: Add the squash, toasted nuts, onions, spices, dried fruits, and orange zest to the bowl of rice. Toss with half the dressing (you will have more than you need). Taste and add more salt, pepper, or dressing as desired.\n 7 Serve: Mound the rice on a platter or in a serving bowl, and garnish with the pomegranate seeds and mint leaves. Serve at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nButternut Squash Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nIf you finely chop (1/2-inch) the butternut squash, apple, carrot, celery, and onion, they'll cook more quickly.\nAdd a smoky flavor to the soup by sprinkling in some smoked paprika. Make the soup a little more creamy by swirling in some sour cream (after you remove the soup from heat).\nButternut squashes come in various sizes. Your ratio of chopped butternut squash to chopped apple should be 3 to 1.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the soup:\n1 medium yellow onion, chopped (about 1 cup)\n1 celery rib, chopped (about 3/4 cup)\n1 carrot, chopped (about 3/4 cup)\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1 butternut squash, peeled and chopped (6 to 8 cups), seeds discarded (see How to Peel and Cut a Butternut Squash)\n1 large tart green apple, peeled, cored, chopped (squash to apple ratio should be 3:1)\n3 cups chicken stock or broth (or vegetable broth)\n1 cup water\nPinches of nutmeg, cinnamon, cayenne, salt and pepper\nFor the garnish (optional):\nFresh parsley, chopped\nChives, chopped\nDash of smoked paprika\nSour cream\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onion, carrot, celery in butter: Heat a large thick-bottomed pot on medium-high heat. Melt the butter in the pot and let it foam up and recede. Add the onion, carrot, and celery and saut\xc3\xa9 for 5 minutes. Lower the heat if the vegetables begin to brown.\n2 Cook the soup: Add the butternut squash, apple, broth, and water. Bring to boil. Reduce to a simmer, cover, and simmer for 30 minutes or so, until the squash and carrots have softened.\n3 Pur\xc3\xa9e the soup: Use an immersion blender to pur\xc3\xa9e the soup, or work in batches and pur\xc3\xa9e the soup in a stand blender.\n4 Add seasonings: Add pinches of nutmeg, cinnamon, and cayenne. Add salt and pepper to taste.\nGarnish with chopped fresh parsley or chives and, if you want, a dollop of sour cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nHow to Peel and Cut a Butternut Squash\nPrep time: 10 minutes\nKeep squash pieces as stable as possible while cutting. A rubber mallet can help, if you have one, to gently push the knife through difficult thick spots. Using a very sharp vegetable peeler, one with a carbon steel blade, will help with the peeling.\nBy the way, it helps to microwave a butternut squash (whole) for 30 seconds or so first, before peeling.
