This will help soften the peel just enough to make it a bit easier to peel.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne butternut squash, 1 1/2 to 3 pounds\nA sharp, heavy, chef's knife\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Slice off the ends: Using a heavy, sharpened chef's knife, cut off about 1/4-inch from the bottom of the squash in an even slice. Then cut off 1/4-inch from the stem end.\n2 Peel with a vegetable peeler: Holding the squash in one hand, use a sharp vegetable peeler in the other hand to peel off the outer layer of the squash. You can also secure the squash standing upright and peel it in downward strokes with the peeler.\n3 Cut the squash in half: Stand the peeled squash upright on a cutting board. It shouldn't wobble, you want the squash to be stable. (If it is wobbly, make another cut at the bottom to even it out.) Make one long cut, down the middle from the top to bottom, with a heavy chef's knife.\nSome squashes can be pretty hard; to help with the cutting you can use a rubber mallet to gently tap on the ends of the knife to help push the knife down through the squash.\n4 Scrape out the seeds: Use a metal spoon to scrape out the seeds and the stringy pulp from the squash cavity. (If you want, you can prepare the seeds like toasted pumpkin seeds.)\n5 Cut squash halves into slices: Lay the squash halves, cut side down on the cutting board for stability. Working section at a time, cut the squash into slices, lengthwise, the desired width of your squash pieces. Some recipes call for 1/2-inch slices or cubes, some for 1-inch or greater.\n6 Stack and slice, then make crosswise cuts into cubes: If you are cubing the squash, lay the slices down (you can stack a few at a time) and make another set of lengthwise cuts. Then make crosswise cuts to make cubes.\nOne 1 1/2 pound butternut squash will yield approximately 4 cups of 1/2-inch cubed squash.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCurried Squash and Pear Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n6 cups cubed butternut squash (about 1 1/2 pounds)\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 teaspoon butter\n1 medium onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n2 1/2 teaspoons yellow curry powder\n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger\nPinch of nutmeg\n2 cups peeled, chopped Bartlett pear (about 1 pound, 3 pears)\n1 1/2  cups water\n1 cup pear nectar\n4 cups chicken or vegetable stock (use veg stock for vegetarian option)\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper\n1/4 cup heavy whipping cream\n1 small Bartlett pear, cored and thinly sliced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the butternut squash: Heat 2 Tbsp olive oil and 1 teaspoon butter in a large, thick-bottomed pot on high heat. Add half of the cubed butternut squash. Toss to coat with the oil. Let cook until lightly browned on several sides.\nRemove with a slotted spoon to a bowl. Repeat with the remaining butternut squash. Remove to a bowl.\n2 Cook the onions and spices: Add 1 tablespoon of olive oil to the pot. Add the chopped onion. Lower the heat to medium and cook for a few minutes to soften.\nThen add the curry powder, ground ginger, and nutmeg. Cook for a few minutes more.\n3 Add the chopped pear, and toss to coat. Cook for a minute more.\n4 Add water, stock, pear nectar, salt, pepper, then simmer: Add the browned butternut squash to the onion pear mixture. Add the water, stock, pear nectar, salt, and pepper. Bring to a boil on high heat; partially cover, reduce heat, and simmer 30 minutes.\n5 Pur\xc3\xa9e: Pur\xc3\xa9e using a stick blender or if using a standing blender, pur\xc3\xa9e a third of the soup at a time.\nIf the soup is too thick for you, add a little water to thin it. If it is too thin for you, bring it to a boil and let it boil down a bit.\n6 Add cream: Turn off heat. Stir in 1/4 cup of cream.\nLadle soup into bowls, and garnish with pear slices.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nButternut Squash with Brown Butter and Thyme Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 3 to 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 pounds butternut squash, peeled, seeds removed, flesh diced into 1/2-inch pieces (about 4 cups)\n3 tablespoons butter\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh thyme (or 1 teaspoon of dried)\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the butter: Heat a large skillet on medium heat. Add the butter, whisking frequently. Once melted the butter will foam up a bit, then subside. Honey-colored browned milk solids will begin to form. The butter should have a wonderful nutty aroma.\nRemove from heat. Add the thyme, whisking continuously. If using fresh thyme, the mixture will foam up a bit.\n(Note that it doesn't take much time to go from browned butter to burnt butter. You will want to remove the pan from the heat element and place it on a cool surface to help stop the cooking of the butter. If the butter burns, I recommend dumping it and starting over, something I've had to do on occasion when not paying close attention.)\n2 Brown the cubed squash in the butter: Add the cubed butternut squash pieces to the pan and return the pan to the burner, heating to medium high.\nUse a wooden or metal spoon to stir the squash pieces so they are all well coated with the butter thyme mixture.\nSprinkle generously with salt and pepper.\nSpread the squash pieces out in an even layer and let cook, without stirring, so that they brown a bit on one side (several minutes). Stir and spread the pieces out again and let cook without stirring so more sides get browned.\n3 Lower the heat, cover and cook: Reduce the heat to low, cover the pan, and let cook until the squash is tender, 10 to 20 minutes, depending on how big you cut the pieces.\nAdd more salt and pepper to taste, sprinkle with a bit more chopped fresh thyme before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nCurried Butternut Squash Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4 to 6\nIt's easier to peel a butternut squash if you microwave it whole for 30 seconds first. That short amount of time helps soften the peel just enough to make it easier to work with.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 2-pound butternut squash, peeled, seeded, diced into 1/2-inch to 3/4-inch cubes, yielding about 6 cups of cubed squash (see how to cut and peel a butternut squash)\nExtra virgin olive oil\n1 teaspoon butter\nSalt\n1 large yellow onion, chopped\n2 teaspoons yellow curry powder\n1 teaspoon whole mustard seeds (if you substitute ground mustard, only use 1/4 teaspoon)\nA dash of ground cumin\n1 tablespoon minced fresh ginger\n4 cups chicken stock\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup sour cream (can substitute plain yogurt)\n1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro (can substitute parsley)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the cubed squash: Heat a tablespoon of olive oil in a large, thick-bottomed stock pot on medium heat. Add a dab of butter to the olive oil.\nWorking in two batches so as not to crowd the pan, add the cubed butternut squash to the pan. Toss to coat all sides with oil. Sprinkle a little salt over the squash. Then spread out in an even layer and let cook, stirring only occasionally, so that the edges and sides get lightly browned.\nYou may need to adjust the heat up to ensure browning, or down to prevent burning or drying out. Add more oil and butter for the additional batches. Remove from pan and set aside.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions, spices, ginger: Heat another tablespoon of olive oil in the pot, on medium heat. Add the chopped onions and cook, stirring now and then, until softened. Add the curry powder, mustard seeds, cumin, and fresh ginger, and cook for a minute or so longer. Use a flat bottomed wooden or metal spatula to scrape up any browned bits.\n3 Add the squash, stock, salt, then simmer: Return the butternut squash to the pot. Add the chicken stock and a teaspoon of salt. Increase the heat to bring to a simmer, then lower the heat to maintain a low simmer, cover the pot. Cook for 40 minutes until squash is completely tender.\n4 Pur\xc3\xa9e the soup: Use an immersion blender (or a stand up blender in which case work in batches) to blend the soup smooth. Add more salt to taste if needed.\n5 Serve with sour cream and cilantro: Serve in individual bowls with a dollop of sour cream and some chopped cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nHow to Cook a Whole Butternut Squash in the Pressure Cooker\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutes\nINGREDIENTS\n1 medium (2 1/2 to 3 pound) butternut squash\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart Instant Pot or other pressure cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the squash for steaming: Lay the squash on its side on a cutting board \xe2\x80\x94 you can hold onto it with a kitchen towel for extra stability. Slice off the stem, then cut the squash in half through the middle, where the thinner neck meets the larger bottom. Cut each section in half again, then scoop out the seeds.\n2 Pressure-steam the squash: Place a wire metal trivet in your electric pressure cooker and pour in 1 1/2 cups of water. Arrange the pieces of squash on top of the trivet in a single layer. It\xe2\x80\x99s fine if they overlap a bit.\nSecure the lid on your pressure cooker, and make sure the pressure release valve is set to its sealing position. Select the \xe2\x80\x9cSteam\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d setting, and set the cooking time to 7 minutes at high pressure. (If you\xe2\x80\x99re using a stovetop pressure cooker, steam the squash at high pressure for 6 minutes.)\nThe pot will take about 10 minutes to come up to pressure, and then the cooking program will begin.\n3 Remove the squash from the pressure cooker and cool: At the end of cooking, move the pressure release valve to its venting position. When the pressure has fully released, open the pot.\nIf, after 7 minutes, the squash is not as tender as you'd like, add another 1/2 cup of water to the Instant Pot, lock on the lid, and set the pressure cooking time for another 2 minutes. If necessary, keep cooking under pressure in increments of 2 minutes until tender. You may need up to 12 minutes total pressure cooking time. Some butternut squash cook faster than others.\nUse a pair of tongs to transfer the squash to a cutting board to cool.\n4 Scoop the squash from the skin: When it's cool enough to handle, use a big spoon to scoop the squash from the outer skin. At this point, it's ready to be added to any recipe calling for cooked squash.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nButternut Squash Apple Cranberry Bake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large butternut squash, peeled and cut into 1-inch cubes\n2 large tart cooking apples (like Granny Smith), peeled and cut into 1/2-inch thick slices\n1/2 cup fresh or frozen cranberries\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n1/4 cup (half a stick) butter\n1 Tbsp flour\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg or mace\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven and prepare baking dish: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Lightly butter the sides and bottom of a 7x11-inch baking dish.\n2 Mix together the flour, brown sugar, salt, and nutmeg in a small bowl.\n3 Layer squash, apples, cranberries, and topping in baking dish: Put a layer of cut butternut squash on the bottom of the baking dish. Place apples on top and then sprinkle with cranberries. Sprinkle everything with the flour brown sugar mixture. Dot with butter.\n4 Bake: Bake 50-60 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F until cooked through and lightly browned.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nRoasted Butternut Squash Kale Saut\xc3\xa9 Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 4\nTime saver: while the squash is roasting, prep the other ingredients.\nTo make ahead, roast the cubed squash and prep the ingredients, then do a quick saut\xc3\xa9 before serving.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups 3/4-inch cubes of butternut squash (from about 1 3/4 pound whole small butternut squash)\n1 teaspoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 teaspoon balsamic vinegar\n1/4 teaspoon salt\nSprinkling of black pepper\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 large red onion, quartered and sliced (about 2 cups of sliced red onions)\n3 cloves garlic, minced (about 1 Tbsp)\n1 teaspoon balsamic vinegar\n6 cups thinly (3/4-inch) sliced kale (center ribs removed) (from about 1 bunch of kale)\n1/3 cup dried sweetened cranberries\n1/2 cup slightly broken up pecans\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast cubed butternut squash: Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Place cubed butternut squash in a bowl and toss with olive oil, balsamic vinegar, salt and pepper. Spread out onto a lined baking sheet. Roast in oven for 25 minutes or until the squash is cooked through and browned on the edges.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and garlic: 15 minutes into roasting the butternut squash, start on the onions. Heat olive oil on medium high heat in a thick-bottomed 4 to 5 quart pot. Add the sliced red onion and toss to coat. Let cook for 7 to 8 minutes until softened. Add the garlic and cook a minute more.\n3 Add balsamic and kale: Add the balsamic vinegar and the shredded kale. Stir until the kale is mixed well with the onions (it helps to use tongs to turn over the kale). Let cook for a minute or two until the kale is just wilted (don't overcook).\n4 Add roasted squash, dried cranberries, pecans: Then stir in the roasted butternut squash, the dried sweetened cranberries, and pecans. Add salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nPressure Cooker Butternut Squash Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 6 to 8 servings (makes about 8 cups)\nINGREDIENTS\n1 medium (2 1/2 to 3 pound) butternut squash\n1 1/2 cups water\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1 medium yellow onion, chopped small\n1 celery rib, chopped small\n1 medium carrot, chopped small\n1 large (8-ounce) Granny Smith or other tart apple, peeled, cored, and diced small\n1 quart chicken or vegetable stock\n1 pinch each of nutmeg, cinnamon, cayenne, salt and pepper\nTo serve:\nChopped chives\nPlain yogurt\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart Instant Pot or other pressure cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the squash for steaming: Lay the squash on its side on a cutting board \xe2\x80\x94 you can hold onto it with a kitchen towel for extra stability. Slice off the stem, then cut the squash in half through the middle, where the thinner neck meets the larger bottom. Cut each section in half again, then scoop out the seeds.\n2 Pressure-steam the squash: Place a wire metal trivet in your electric pressure cooker (6-quart or larger) and pour in 1 1/2 cups of water. Arrange the pieces of squash on top of the trivet in a single layer. It\xe2\x80\x99s fine if they overlap a bit.\nSecure the lid on your pressure cooker, and make sure the pressure release valve is set to its sealing position. Select the \xe2\x80\x9cSteam\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d setting, and set the cooking time to 7 minutes at high pressure. (If you\xe2\x80\x99re using a stovetop pressure cooker, steam the squash at high pressure for 6 minutes.)\nThe pot will take about 10 minutes to come up to pressure, and then the cooking program will begin.\nWhen it\xe2\x80\x99s finished cooking, move the pressure release valve to its venting position. When the pressure has fully released, open the pot and use a pair of tongs to transfer the squash to a cutting board to cool.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the other ingredients and add the broth: Remove the inner pot from the pressure cooker housing, remove the trivet, and pour out the water. Return the inner pot to your pressure cooker.\nReset the cooking program on your pressure cooker, and select the highest \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d setting. Melt the butter in the pot.\nWhen the butter is melted and bubbling, add the onion, celery, carrot, and apple. Saut\xc3\xa9 until the onions are translucent, about five minutes.\nPour in the broth and let it come to a simmer.\n4 Scoop the squash from the skin and add it back to the pot: While you're waiting for the broth to come up to a simmer, use a big spoon to scoop the squash from the outer skin. Add the squash to the pot (it's ok if the broth isn't simmering quite yet).\n5 Simmer the soup: Let the soup simmer until the apples and other vegetables are soft, 5 to 7 minutes or so.\n6 Puree the soup, season, and serve: Use an immersion blender or a traditional blender to process the soup until it is smooth. (If using a traditional blender, puree in batches with the top slightly loosened. Use a dishtowel to hold down the lid while blending.)\nStir in the spices and taste, adding more salt if needed. Ladle the soup into bowls and serve it with a dollop of yogurt and chives sprinkled on top.\nThis soup will keep for about a week in the fridge, or frozen for up to 3 months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nRoasted Butternut Squash, Radicchio, and Onion Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 6-8 as a side dish\nButternut squash can be tricky to cut. Check out our How to Peel and Cut a Butternut Squash for a step-by-step how-to.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 medium butternut squash (about 2 pounds), peeled and cut into chunks\n1 large onion, peeled and cut into wedges through the root\n1 head radicchio, cut into wedges through the root\nExtra virgin olive oil\nSalt and black pepper\n1/2 cup pine nuts\n1/4 cup chopped parsley\nGrated parmesan or pecorino cheese to taste, about 1/4 cup to 1/3 cup\nBalsamic vinegar to taste, about a tablespoon\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast the vegetables: Preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Toss the squash chunks, onion and radicchio wedges in olive oil and salt them well.\nArrange in one layer on baking sheets (you may need two) and put in the oven.\nRoast the vegetables until their edges are nicely caramelized, turning the radicchio and onion wedges over about halfway through the roasting.\nThe radicchio, onion, and squash will roast at different speeds. So periodically you'll have to remove the finished vegetables and let the others remain in the oven to finish roasting. As a guideline, roast the radicchio for about 25 minutes, turning halfway.\nRoast the onions about 35 minutes, again, turning halfway. Roast the squash pieces for 45 minutes, but do not turn.\nIn all cases do not remove from the oven until you see browning on the edges.\n2 Toast the pine nuts: While the vegetables are roasting, toast the pine nuts.  Heat a small pan on medium high heat.  Add the pine nuts in a single layer. Cook until lightly toasted. Remove from heat to a bowl to keep the nuts from burning.\n3 Chop roasted radicchio and onions: Once all the vegetables are cool enough to handle, roughly chop the radicchio and onion into manageable pieces.\n4 Toss with pine nuts, parsley, balsamic, black pepper: Place the radicchio, onion, and butternut squash in a large serving bowl. Add the pine nuts and parsley. Add black pepper to taste. Drizzle with balsamic vinegar. Stir gently to combine, taking care not to squish the soft roasted squash.\nTo serve, sprinkle with some grated Parmesan or pecorino cheese.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nButternut Squash with Walnuts and Vanilla Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4\nWe're using butternut squash for this dish, but you could easily use kabocha squash instead, or any firm, easy-to-peel, winter squash.\nYou can either boil or roast the squash, directions are given for both methods.\nRecipe can be easily doubled.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 butternut squash, about 2 pounds, peeled, seeds removed, flesh cut into 1-inch cubes (see how to cut and peel a butternut squash)\n3 bay leaves (if boiling the squash)\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil (if roasting the squash)\nSalt\n1 heaping cup of walnuts (can substitute pecans or pine nuts)\n2 to 3 tablespoons butter\n2 teaspoons grated ginger\n1 to 2 teaspoons vanilla extract\nLemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon dried thyme\nBlack pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast or boil the cubed squash: \nIf roasting: Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Coat the cubed squash with a little olive oil and spread out onto a baking tray. Sprinkle with salt and roast until the cubes begin to brown, about 20 minutes. Remove from oven.\nIf boiling: Put 4 cups of water into a medium-sized pot and add the bay leaves. Bring to a simmer. Add the squash to the pot. Boil, covered for 10 minutes. Drain.\n2 Toast the walnuts: Heat a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat and toast the walnuts. Stir frequently or they will burn. Once they they start to brown, and you can smell the aroma of toasted walnuts, remove from heat.\n3 Melt the butter: Melt the butter in the pan with the walnuts over medium-high heat. Toss the walnuts to coat with butter, then add the squash. Toss them to coat with butter.\n4 Add the grated ginger, vanilla extract, black pepper, a little salt and dried thyme and toss once more. Turn off the heat and squeeze some lemon juice over everything. Taste for salt and lemon and add more to taste.\nIf you want this to be a bit more luxurious, mix in another tablespoon of butter or two before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nButternut Squash Risotto Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nWe are serving this with chopped chives, but you could also crisp up a few fresh sage leaves in simmering butter, then crumble them into the risotto.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 cups (1.4 liters) chicken broth (use vegetable broth for vegetarian option, and gluten-free stock for gluten-free version)\n5 Tbsp (70g) unsalted butter, divided into 4 Tbsp (56g) and 1 Tbsp (14g)\n1 small onion, finely chopped (1 cup)\n2 cups (240g) butternut squash, peeled, and finely diced (1/4-1/2 inch)\n2 cups (400g) arborio rice (can substitute medium grained white rice, but arborio is preferred)\n1 cup (236 ml) dry white wine (such as Sauvignon Blanc)\n3/4 cup (1.5 oz, 40g) freshly grated Parmesan cheese, divided\n2 tablespoons chopped chives or garlic chives\nSalt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat broth in medium sized saucepan and keep warm over low heat.\n2 Cook onion and squash in butter: Melt 4 Tbsp of butter in a large saucepan; add onion and butternut squash. Cook over medium heat until onion is translucent, about 5 minutes.\n3 Add rice: Add arborio rice to onion and squash. Cook 1 to 2 minutes.\n4 Add wine: Add the wine and cook, stirring constantly until wine has been absorbed by the rice or evaporated.\n5 Start adding broth a ladle at a time, allowing rice to absorb broth: Add a few ladles of broth, just enough to barely cover rice. Cook over medium heat until broth has been absorbed.\nContinue cooking, stirring rice enough to keep it from sticking to the pan, adding a little bit of broth at a time, cooking and stirring until the liquid is absorbed, and the rice is tender but still firm to the bite, about 15 to 20 minutes.\n6 During the last minutes of cooking, add remaining tablespoon of butter, 1/2 cup Parmesan, and chives. At this point the rice should have a creamy consistency. Add salt to taste. (The amount of salt you add will depend on how salty your broth was to begin with. I usually add at least a teaspoon of salt, sometimes more.)\nServe with remaining grated Parmesan.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nPasta with Butternut Squash Parmesan Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4-6\nThis butternut pasta sauce will work with any pasta, but spaghetti is an especially good pairing.\nBe careful when you cut the squash, winter squash are hard! The best way to do it safely is to slice a bit off of both ends so that you can stand the squash upright without it rolling. Then cut down the middle. See how to cut and peel a butternut squash for visuals, though note for this recipe you do not want to peel the squash before roasting.\nIt also helps if you have a microwave, to microwave the whole squash for a minute before cutting into it. This will lightly soften the outside of the squash, making it easier to cut it.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 butternut squash weighing about 2 1/2 pounds\n1 pound pasta\n1 tablespoon of extra virgin olive oil\n1/3 cup of chopped shallots or onions\n1/4 cup of packed, freshly grated Parmesan cheese\n1/3 cup sour cream or Greek yogurt\n1/8 teaspoon of grated nutmeg\n1 tablespoon of chopped parsley, for garnish\n1 teaspoon salt (more to taste)\nPepper to taste\nWater as needed to thin the sauce, about 1 cup\nMETHOD\n1 Bake the butternut squash: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Cut the butternut squash lengthwise in half and scoop out the guts and seeds and discard them (or save the seeds and toast them).\nPour 1/4 cup of water into a baking dish and place the butternut squash halves cut side down.\nBake for 40 minutes or until a fork easily pierces the squash. Allow to cool for 10 minutes.\nScoop out the squash flesh from the skins and put into a blender. Discard the skins.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the shallots in the olive oil over medium heat in a small skillet until just beginning to brown, about 2-3 minutes.\n3 Pur\xc3\xa9e in blender: Add the shallots to the blender. Add 1 cup water, the parmesan, 1 teaspoons salt and 1/8 teaspoon nutmeg and blend until smooth. Taste and add more salt if needed. If the sauce is too thick, thin it with a little more water.\n4 Add sour cream and heat until warm: Pour the sauce into a small pot set over low heat. Mix in the sour cream and warm it through. Do not let the sauce boil.\n5 Cook pasta in boiling salted water: Fill a pot with water and salt (1 tablespoon of salt for every 2 quarts of water). Set over high heat to bring to a hard boil. Add the pasta and cook at a hard boil, uncovered until al dente.\n6 Mix cooked pasta with sauce: When the pasta is ready, drain and put it into a bowl. Mix with a little of the sauce and serve. Add a dollop of additional sauce and some parsley right when you bring it to the table.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nHarvest Salad with Miso-Maple Roasted Butternut Squash Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 4 servings\nYellow, white or any mellow variety of miso will work for this dish. I used chickpea miso because it's both mellow and soy-free.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the squash:\n1 small butternut squash (about 2 pounds), peeled, seeded and cubed into 1/2 inch chunks\n2 tablespoons yellow or white miso\n1 tablespoon maple syrup\n3 tablespoons olive oil, divided\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon pepper\nFor the dressing:\n1 1/2 tablespoons red wine vinegar\n1 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1 tablespoon maple syrup\n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil\nSalt and pepper to taste\nFor the salad:\n4 cups arugula\n1 cup cooked whole grains, like oat groats or wild rice\n1 crisp apple, cored and diced\n1/4 cup dried cranberries\n1/4 cup pepitas (green pumpkin seeds)\nArils of one pomegranate (about 1/2 cup)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast the squash: Preheat oven to 425F. Lightly brush two baking sheets with about 1 tablespoon of olive oil.\nIn a large bowl, whisk together miso, maple syrup, the rest of the oil, salt, and pepper. Add butternut squash cubes, and toss to coat.\nSpread squash out onto baking sheets with plenty of room between pieces. Bake for 25 minutes or until golden brown and crispy at the edges. For more caramelization, turn the squash at the 15-minute mark.\n2 Make the dressing: Mix together all ingredients in a small jar and shake well to emulsify.\n3 Assemble the salad: Toss the roasted squash (hot, warm, or cool), the dressing, and the remaining salad ingredients together in a large salad bowl. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nPasta with Butternut Squash, Bacon, and Brown Butter Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound butternut squash, cut into 1/2-inch cubes (about 4 cups)\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 teaspoon Morton\xe2\x80\x99s kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon freshly cracked black pepper\n1 pound pasta, such as penne, rigatoni, or other short-shaped pasta\n8 ounces bacon (7 to 8 slices, depending on how thickly they are cut)\n1/4 cup sliced shallots\n1 stick unsalted butter (4 ounces/8 tablespoons)\n4 to 5 sage leaves\n1/4 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast the squash: Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. On a rimmed baking sheet, combine the squash with olive oil, salt, and pepper on a rimmed baking sheet, and toss to coat.\nRoast for 20 minutes, tossing half way through to evenly brown. When it\xe2\x80\x99s ready, the squash will be soft and some of the edges will have browned.\n2 Cook the pasta: Meanwhile, bring a large pot of salted water to boil and cook the pasta to al dente, or according to package directions. Drain well and set aside.\n3 Fry the bacon: In a large, deep skillet (I used cast iron), put the bacon in a cold pan and cook over medium heat until crispy. Remove from the skillet and drain on paper towels.\n4 Cook the shallots: Place the skillet back on the stove, but with the heat turned off. Drain all but about 2 tablespoons of the bacon grease.\nAdd the shallots and cook in the residual heat from the skillet; this helps prevent the shallots from burning. If they don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be cooking fast enough, turn the heat to medium-low and cook for just a couple of minutes until they start to soften and become aromatic. Transfer the cooked shallots to a large bowl.\n  5 Combine the bacon, shallots, squash and pasta: After the bacon cools, cut it into small pieces using kitchen scissors (or using a chef's knife), and combine with the shallots in a large bowl\xe2\x80\x94or you can use the stockpot you cooked the pasta in (I like to do this if it's just me and the boys).\nAdd the pasta and toss to combine. When the squash comes out of the oven, add the squash to this bowl and toss gently together.\n  6 Brown the butter: In a small saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Stir it constantly and keep an eye on it so it does not burn. (See here for full instructions on how to brown butter.) It will start to crackle, foam, and smell nutty. The color will deepen to a caramel/amber hue.\nAround when the butter stops foaming\xe2\x80\x94or at least it starts to subside\xe2\x80\x94and the butter turns slightly brown, add the sage leaves.\nRemove the saucepan from the heat as soon as the sage leaves start to curl. Pour the butter and the sage leaves into the bowl with the rest of the ingredients.\n  7 Combine all ingredients and serve: Toss everything gently together with a wooden spoon. Taste and add salt and/or pepper if needed. Serve immediately with freshly grated cheese over the top.\nIf you are feeling extra decadent, add a chunk of unsalted butter or a splash of extra virgin olive oil on top when you toss, or some of the reserved bacon grease.\nLeftovers keep for about 2 to 3 days and reheat fairly well. I like to add a bit of olive oil or water to the pot when I reheat it over low heat. (I try to avoid microwaving leftover pasta because it just makes it gummy.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nRoasted Eggplant and Butternut Squash with Tahini-Yogurt Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesSalting time: 30 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the sauce:\n1/2 cup whole-milk or low-fat plain yogurt\n2 tablespoons tahini paste\n2 tablespoons lemon juice\nFor the eggplant:\n2 medium eggplants (1 1/2 pounds total)\n2 teaspoons salt\n5 tablespoons olive oil\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/2 peeled, seeded butternut squash, and cut into 1/2-inch slices (about 1 pound)\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon pepper\n1/4 red onion, thinly sliced\n3 tablespoons white wine vinegar\n1 jalapeno or other small green chili pepper, cored, seeded, and thinly sliced\n1/2 cup whole parsley leaves\nTo serve:\nRice pilaf, made with 1 cup rice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the yogurt-tahini sauce: In a bowl, whisk the yogurt, tahini, and lemon juice until smooth. Taste for seasoning and add salt and pepper, if you like.\n2 Prep and salt the eggplant: Cut the eggplant in half lengthwise. Use the tip of a paring knife to score the cut sides in a cross-hatch pattern about 1/2 inch deep.\nSprinkle with salt and set the eggplant on a large rimmed baking sheet, cut side up, for 30 minutes. You\xe2\x80\x99ll see liquid coming out of the cuts.\nAfter 30 minutes are up, rinse the eggplant and pat dry with paper towels. Use the towels to wipe the baking sheet.\n3 Roast the eggplant and squash: Heat the oven to 450 degrees F. Set the eggplant halves on the baking sheet cut sides up. Brush with 3 tablespoons of the olive oil and sprinkle with cumin. Arrange the sliced butternut in the spaces between the halves, and sprinkle with 1 tablespoon of the olive oil and salt.\nRoast the eggplant and butternut for 35 to 40 minutes, or until the eggplant is golden brown, the squash is browned on the bottom, and both are tender when pierced with a skewer. If the eggplant isn\xe2\x80\x99t browned, remove the butternut from the baking sheet and continue cooking the eggplant for 5 more minutes.\nKeep the eggplant warm covered loosely with foil on the top of the stove while you finish the vegetable topping.\n4 Make the vegetable topping: In a large bowl, combine the red onion, vinegar, and a pinch of salt. Let them sit for 5 minutes to mellow the onion. With a large spoon, stir in the remaining 2 tablespoons oil.\nTransfer the roasted butternut to a cutting board and cut into 1/2-inch pieces. Fold the butternut, jalapeno, and parsley into the bowl with the onions. Taste for seasoning and add more salt and pepper, if you like.\n5 Plate and serve: Scoop the pilaf on a serving platter, or divide between 4 plates. Add the eggplant halves and top with the butternut mixture. Drizzle with yogurt sauce and serve the remaining sauce separately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\n7-Layer Magic Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 24 bars\nThese bars are so rich and sweet, you can cut them into 24 small bars and still feel satisfied.\nI like to add a sprinkle of flaky Maldon salt on top to add some crunch and help cut the sweet richness. The salt is totally non-traditional, though, so omit if you want that nostalgic, ultra-sweet Magic Bar experience.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups (225 g) graham cracker crumbs\n1/2 cup (115 g / 1 stick) melted unsalted butter\n14 ounces (396 g / 1 can) sweetened condensed milk\n1 cup (185 g) semi-sweet chocolate chips\n1 cup (185 g) butterscotch chips\n1 cup (115 g) chopped pecans\n1 cup (105 g) shredded sweetened coconut\n1 teaspoon flaky sea salt (like Maldon), optional\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 350F. Spray a 9 x 13-inch baking pan with cooking oil then line it with parchment paper.\n2 Make the graham cracker crust: Place the graham cracker crumbs and the melted butter in a bowl. Toss with a fork until the crumbs are moist and hold together when squeezed with your hand.\nDump the crumbs in the middle of the pan and then press them into an even layer with your fingers or the back of a flat-bottomed cup.\n3 Pour the sweetened condensed milk over the graham cracker crust. Spread to edges of the pan with a spatula.\n4 Layer on the rest of the toppings: In this order, sprinkle the chocolate chips, butterscotch chips, pecans, and then sweetened coconut over the top of the condensed milk.\nGently press the ingredients down with your palm so they stick to the condensed milk.\n5 Bake in the oven for 30 to 35 minutes. Bake until the edges of the bars turn golden-brown and start to pull away slightly from the sides of the pan. Remove from the oven and sprinkle with the sea salt (if using).\n6 Cool completely before lifting the bars out of the pan using the parchment paper. (Stick them in the fridge for a few hours or overnight if needed to help firm up.) Cut into 24 pieces and store in an airtight container with wax paper or parchment paper between layers.\nThe flavor of the bars is even better the day after baking. Bars stored at room temperature will be fairly soft and are best eaten within 3 to 5 days. For firm and chewy bars, store in the fridge for up to a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nHow to Make Butterscotch Sauce\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutes\nINGREDIENTS\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1 cup of tightly packed dark brown sugar\n\xc2\xbe cup heavy whipping cream (not ultra-pasteurized)\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nButterscotch sauce takes about a half an hour to make, from start to finish.\n1 Have everything ready to go: First, before you begin, make sure you have everything ready to go - the cream and the brown sugar next to the pan, measured and waiting. Making butterscotch is a fast process that cannot wait for hunting around for ingredients.\n2 Melt butter, add brown sugar: In a heavy bottomed stainless steel 2 quart saucepan, melt butter over low to medium heat. Just before butter is melted, add all dark brown sugar at once and stir with wooden spoon until sugar is uniformly wet.\n3 Stir infrequently: Stir infrequently until mixture goes from looking grainy to molten lava. Make sure to get into the corners of your pot, and watch closely to notice how the mixture changes. It will take about 3 to 5 minutes.\n4 Note the texture: Right before you add the cream, the caramelizing brown sugar will begin to look and feel more like liquid and less like thick wet sand.\n5 Add the cream, let boil: At this point add all the cream at once and replace your spoon with a whisk. Lower heat a little and whisk cream into mixture.\nWhen liquid is uniform, turn heat back to medium and whisk every few minutes for a total of 10 minutes or until it registers 225\xc2\xb0F on a digital or candy thermometer.\n6 Let rest, then transfer to storage vehicle to cool: After liquid has been boiling on the stove for its 10 minutes, turn heat off and let rest for a minute or two before transferring into a heatproof storage vessel. (I prefer a stainless steel or glass bowl.) Cool to room temperature.\n7 Taste, add salt and vanilla extract to taste: When butterscotch liquid is room temperature, take a small taste. It's important to know what cooked brown sugar and butter tastes like, and what happens when transforming that flat sweetness into real butterscotch flavor.\nWhisk in half the salt and vanilla extract. Taste again. Add more salt and vanilla extract until the marvelous taste of real butterscotch is achieved.\nButterscotch makes a fantastic topping for ice cream.\nChill butterscotch sauce in a non-reactive container with a tightly fitting lid only after sauce has chilled completely. It will keep for one month refrigerated, that is if you can keep from eating it all the moment it has cooled down and been seasoned to your liking.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nButterscotch Cookies Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 13 minutesYield: Makes 4 dozen small cookies\nDo not use fine grain table salt (aka: iodized salt) as the flavor will be way off and unpleasant.\nINGREDIENTS\n12 tablespoons unsalted butter, cut into tablespoon sized slices\n1 3/4 cups packed dark brown sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 large egg\n1 egg yolk\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract\n2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/4 teaspoon baking powder\nSugar dredging mixture:\n1/4 cup packed dark brown sugar\n2 tablespoons white granulated sugar\nSprinkling salt:\nFleur de sel, Maldon, sea salt, or Kosher salt for sprinkling (See Recipe Note)\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F and line baking sheets with parchment paper.\n2 Whisk the dry ingredients: Vigorously whisk together the flour, baking soda, and baking powder and set aside. Mix together the brown sugar white sugar dredging mixture in another bowl and set aside.\n3 Brown the butter: Place 10 tablespoons of butter into a thick-bottomed skillet over medium heat. The butter will foam a bit before subsiding. Once the butter takes on a tan color and begins to smell nutty take it off of the heat. Add the other two tablespoons of butter and mix it in until it melts. (See tutorial on how to brown butter.)\n4 Make the cookie dough: Pour the brown butter into a mixing bowl fitted with a paddle attachment. Add the brown sugar and salt and mix. Add the egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract and mix together, scraping down the sides and bottom of the bowl at least once.\nAdd the flour mixture in three increments being sure to scrape down the sides and bottom once or twice. Mix just until the flour is incorporated. The dough will be very thick.\n5 Shape the cookies: Take 1/2 to full tablespoon-sized pieces of dough (you can make them a bit bigger or smaller to your liking, just make sure the pieces of dough are all the same size) and gently roll them into ball shapes.\nDredge them in the sugar dredging mixture until well-coated.\nPlace on the baking sheet and sprinkle with a little bit of the sprinkling salt (be reserved with the salt as very little goes a long way).\n6 Bake the cookies: Bake at 375\xc2\xb0F for 10-12 minutes or until the edges have browned a bit. Be careful not to over-bake.\n8 Cool and serve: Allow to cool on the sheet for one minute before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely. Tastes best with a glass of milk for dipping. Cookies will keep in an airtight container for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nButterscotch Pudding Recipe\nYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1 1/2 cups dark brown sugar\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 1/4 cup heavy whipping cream\n3/4 cup whole milk\n3 egg yolks\n1 1/2 tablespoons vanilla extract\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven, heat water, prepare ramekins: Preheat oven to 325\xc2\xb0F and set a kettle of water to boil. Set four ramekins or oven-safe bowls out and a large baking dish.\n2 Make butterscotch base with butter, sugar, salt, cream and milk: In a saucepan melt the butter. Once melted add the brown sugar and salt, stir until well combined.\nAdd the cream and milk to the sugar mixture. Heat until steamy and tiny, pinprick-sized bubbles begin to show around the side of the pot and the ingredients are combined (about 170\xc2\xb0F to 180\xc2\xb0F). You do not want it to boil or even simmer as this will cause scalding or curdling of the milk. Remove from heat immediately.\n3 Temper the egg yolks: Slowly, in a thin stream, pour the heated sugar-dairy mixture into the egg yolks, whisking constantly so that the egg yolks are tempered by the warm mixture, but not cooked by it.\n4 Add vanilla and strain mixture through sieve: Stir in the vanilla extract. Pour through a fine mesh sieve to catch any cooked bits of egg.\n5 Pour mixture into ramekins, prepare water bath: Ladle the mixture evenly into the ramekins. Place ramekins in a heavy bottomed pan and pour the hot water into the pan until the water rises halfway up the sides of the ramekins.\nLightly tent the entire pan (not each individual ramekin) with some vented foil. The foil can simply be crimped on two opposite sides, it shouldn't be airtight.\n6 Bake: Bake at 325\xc2\xb0F for 45-50 minutes. Be sure to rotate the pan half way through cooking. If you shake them they will have a jell-o-like wobble. It should not ripple or move like a liquid when you shake it. Don't worry as they will set up after they cool. Chill in the fridge for a few hours before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nCorned Beef and Cabbage Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nCorned beef is cured in a salt mixture, so it can be very salty, depending on the source. We recommend first bringing the corned beef to a boil in plain water, and discarding the water, (repeat for less salt), before proceeding with the baked version.\nINGREDIENTS\nCorned Beef (baked)\n3 pounds corned beef (in package)\n10 whole cloves\n1/4 cup hot sweet honey mustard\n2 tablespoons brown sugar\nCorned Beef (boiled)\n3 pounds corned beef (in package, including spice packet)\nCabbage (saut\xc3\xa9ed)\nExtra virgin olive oil and butter\n1 medium yellow onion, chopped\n1 cloves garlic, minced\n1 large head of cabbage, sliced into 3/8-inch to 1/2-inch wide slices\nSalt\nCabbage (boiled)\n1 large head of cabbage, sliced into 3/8-inch to 1/2-inch wide slices\nAdditional vegetables such as a couple carrots (cut to 1 inch pieces) or several new potatoes (quartered)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nCorned Beef (Baked)\n1 Lightly boil to remove excess salt: Take the corned beef from the package and discard the spice packet. Note that one side of the roast should have a layer of fat, the other side should have distinct lines indicating the grain of the beef.\nCorned beef can be very salty, especially when baked. To remove some of the salt before cooking, place it in a pot fat side up. Cover with water, bring to a boil, and discard the water. Repeat to remove even more salt.\n2 Top with cloves, honey mustard, brown sugar: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Lay the corned beef, fat side up, on a large piece of heavy duty, wide, aluminum foil (you may have to get creative with the way you wrap the beef if your foil isn't wide enough).\nInsert the cloves into the top of the slab of corned beef, evenly spaced. Spread the top with the hot sweet honey mustard. Sprinkle brown sugar over the top.\n3 Wrap in foil and bake: Wrap the corned beef with foil in a way that allows for a little space on top between the corned beef and the foil, and creates a container to catch the juices. Place foil-wrapped corned beef in a shallow roasting pan and bake for 2 hours at 350\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Add more honey mustard, broil: Open the foil wrapping, spread a little more honey mustard over the top of the corned beef, and broil it for 2-3 minutes, until the top is bubbly and lightly browned.\n5 Slice: Let rest for 5 to 10 minutes, then place on cutting board. Pull out and discard the cloves.\nLift the corned beef up to see which direction the grain of the meat is.  Then cut the meat at a diagonal, across the grain of the meat, into 1/2-inch thick slices.\nServe immediately.\nCorned Beef (Boiled)\n1 Place corned beef in a large (6 to 8 quart) pot. Cover the beef with an inch water. Add the contents of the spice packet to the water. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to a simmer.\nSimmer for 2-3 hours, until the corned beef is fork tender. Remove from pot to a cutting board. (Reserve cooking liquid for boiling cabbage, if you plan to boil and not saut\xc3\xa9 the cabbage.)\nCut slices across the grain, into 1/2-inch thick slices. Serve.\nCabbage (Saut\xc3\xa9ed)\n1 Heat 2 Tbsp olive oil (enough to well coat the pan) on medium high to high heat in a large, wide pot (8-quart if available) or large, high-sided saut\xc3\xa9 pan. Add chopped onions, cook for a couple of minutes, then add garlic.\n2 Add a third of the sliced cabbage to the pan. Sprinkle with a little salt and stir to coat with oil and mix with onions.\nSpread out the cabbage evenly over the bottom of the pan and do not stir until it starts to brown. If the heat is high enough, this should happen quickly. The trick is to have the burner hot enough to easily brown the cabbage, but not so hot that it easily burns.\nWhen the bottom of the cabbage is nicely browned, use a metal spatula to lift it up and flip it, scraping the browned bits as you go.\n3 Once the cabbage in the pan has browned on a couple of flips, add another third of the cabbage to the pan. Mix well, then spread out the cabbage and repeat. Add a bit of butter to the pan for flavor, and to keep the cabbage from sticking too much to the pan. Once this batch has cooked down a bit and browned, add the remaining third of the cabbage and repeat.\nServe with the corned beef. Serve with boiled new potatoes. Can be made ahead and reheated.\nCabbage (Boiled)\n1 Once you have removed the corned beef from the pot, add the cabbage and any other vegetables (carrots, new potatoes) to the pot. Taste the liquid. If it is too salty, add more water to the pot. Raise the heat until the liquid is simmering well. Simmer until the cabbage and any other vegetables are cooked through, 15-30 minutes.\nPlace vegetables in a serving bowl, add a little of the cooking liquid to the bowl.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nNew England Boiled Dinner Recipe\nCook time: 4 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nCorned beef can be pretty salty, so if you are making boiled dinner with corned beef you may want to put it in a pot, cover with cold water, bring to a boil, and then discard the water before starting the recipe. If the broth ends up being too salty, you can serve just the meat and vegetables, without the broth, or add water to the broth to dilute it.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 pounds corned beef brisket or plain beef brisket\n15 peppercorns\n8 whole cloves\n1 bay leaf\nSalt, if using plain brisket\n2 medium sized turnips, peeled and quartered\n4 red new potatoes, peeled and quartered\n3 large carrots, cut into thirds and the thickest pieces quartered lengthwise\n1 small head cabbage, cut into fourths\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Put corned beef in a pot, cover with water, add seasonings, simmer: Put the brisket in a 5 or 6 quart Dutch oven and cover with an inch of water.\nIf you are using corned beef brisket and it does not come already packed in seasoning, add peppercorns, cloves, and a bay leaf to the pot.\nIf using plain brisket, add a teaspoon of salt for every quart of water.\nBring to a simmer and then cover, lower the heat until it is barely simmering. Keep at a low simmer for four hours or until the meat is tender (a fork goes through easily).\n2 Remove meat, add vegetables, simmer: Remove the meat and set aside, keeping the meat warm. Add the vegetables to the pot. Check the broth for taste. If it is too salty, add a little more water to taste.\nRaise the temperature and bring the soup to a high simmer. Cook at a high simmer until done, about 15-30 minutes longer, depending on the size of the cut of your vegetables.\n\n3 Slice meat across the grain: Slice the meat in thin slices across the grain. You may find it easier to slice if you first cut the roast in half along the same direction as the grain of the meat. Then slice smaller lengths across the grain.\n\nServe in bowls, a few pieces of meat in each, add some of the vegetables and some broth. Serve with horseradish or mustard or both.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nPolish Hunter\xe2\x80\x99s Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 40 minutesCook time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 10 to 12\nI used beer as the liquid, although lots of people use red wine. If you are making the tomato-based version, skip the beer and use the can of tomato sauce. If you cannot drink alcohol, use some beef stock.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 ounce dried porcini or other wild mushrooms\n2 Tbsp bacon fat or vegetable oil\n2 pounds pork shoulder\n1 large onion, chopped\n1 head cabbage (regular, not savoy or red), chopped\n1 1/2 pounds mixed fresh mushrooms\n1-2 pounds kielbasa or other smoked sausage\n1 smoked ham hock\n1 pound fresh Polish sausage (optional)\n1 25-ounce jar of fresh sauerkraut (we recommend Bubbies, which you may be able to find in the refrigerated section of your local supermarket)\n1 bottle of pilsner or lager beer\n1 Tbsp juniper berries (optional)\n1 Tbsp black peppercorns\n1 Tbsp caraway seeds\n2 Tbsp dried marjoram\nSalt\n20 prunes, sliced in half (optional)\n2 Tbsp tomato paste (optional)\n1 15-ounce can tomato sauce (optional)\n1-2 Tbsp mustard or horseradish (optional)\nMETHOD\n1 Pour hot tap water over the dried mushrooms and submerge them for 20-40 minutes, or until soft. Grind or crush the juniper berries and black peppercorns roughly; you don\xe2\x80\x99t want a powder. Cut the pork shoulder into large chunks, about 2 inches. Cut the sausages into similar-sized chunks. Drain the sauerkraut and set aside. Clean off any dirt from the mushrooms and cut them into large pieces; leave small ones whole.\n2 Heat the bacon fat or vegetable oil in a large lidded pot for a minute or two. Working in batches if necessary, brown the pork shoulder over medium-high heat. Do not crowd the pan. Set the browned meat aside.\n3 Put the onion and fresh cabbage into the pot and saut\xc3\xa9 for a few minutes, stirring often, until the cabbage is soft. Sprinkle a little salt over them. The vegetables will give off plenty of water, and when they do, use a wooden spoon to scrape any browned bits off the bottom of the pot. If you are making the tomato-based version, add the tomato paste here. Once the pot is clean and the cabbage and onions soft, remove from the pot and set aside with the pork shoulder.\n4 Add the mushrooms and cook them without any additional oil, stirring often, until they release their water. Once they do, sprinkle a little salt on the mushrooms. When the water is nearly all gone, add back the pork shoulder, the cabbage-and-onion mixture, and then everything else except the prunes. Add the beer, if using, or the tomato sauce if you're making the tomato-based version. Stir well to combine.\n5 You should not have enough liquid to submerge everything. That\xe2\x80\x99s good: Bigos is a \xe2\x80\x9cdry\xe2\x80\x9d stew, and besides, the ingredients will give off more liquid as they cook. Bring everything to a simmer, cover the pot and cook gently for at least 2 hours.\n6 Bigos is better the longer it cooks, but you can eat it once the ham hock falls apart. Check at 2 hours, and then every 30 minutes after that. When the hock is tender, fish it out and pull off the meat and fat from the bones Discard the bones and the fat, then chop the meat roughly and return to the pot. Add the prunes and cook until they are tender, at least 30 more minutes.\nBigos is best served simply, with rye bread and a beer. If you want a little kick, add the mustard or horseradish right before you eat it. Bigos improves with age, too, which is why this recipe makes so much: Your leftovers will be even better than the stew was on the first day.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nSweet and Sour German Red Cabbage Recipe\nPrep time: 7 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 3-4\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 large red cabbage, sliced 1/4-inch thick\n2 tablespoon butter\n2 tablespoon sugar\n1/4 cup balsamic vinegar\nKosher salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the cabbage: Melt the butter in a large pot over medium heat. Add the thinly sliced red cabbage and toss to coat with the butter. Saut\xc3\xa9 until slightly wilted, about 5 minutes.\n2 Add seasonings and simmer: Sprinkle sugar over the cabbage and toss to coat evenly. Add the balsamic vinegar to the pot. Bring to a simmer, then reduce the heat to medium low.\nCover and simmer until the cabbage is completely tender, stirring often, about 30 minutes total. Season to taste with salt and pepper.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nItalian Sausage and Cabbage Stew Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8 to 10\nWe use savoy cabbage for this recipe, but you could use regular cabbage, or even collard greens or dinosaur kale. If you want to make this stew vegetarian, leave out the sausage and double the beans.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 pound sweet Italian sausage, bulk, or removed from casings\n1 large yellow onion, half sliced and half minced\n2 garlic cloves, minced\n1 1/2 cups white wine\n1 15-ounce can of white beans (cannellini, Great Northern, or Navy), drained\n1 quart vegetable or chicken stock\n1 quart water\n1 teaspoon salt, more to taste\n1 large (2-pound) savoy cabbage, quartered, then sliced into 1/4-inch thick slices\n2 bay leaves\n1 cup chopped parsley, loosely packed\n1/2 cup to a cup of freshly grated Parmesan or pecorino cheese for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the sausage: Heat the olive oil on medium heat in a large (8-quart), thick-bottomed pot. Add the sausage, breaking it up into pieces as you put it into the pot in a single layer.\nWhen the sausage has cooked on all sides, remove it with a slotted spoon and set aside.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, garlic: Add the minced onion (save the sliced onion for later) and saut\xc3\xa9 for 3-4 minutes, stirring often.\nOnce the onions give up some of their water, use a wooden spoon to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pot.\nAdd the minced garlic and cook for another 1-2 minutes.\n3 Add wine, beans, boil, lower heat to simmer: Add the white wine and the beans and bring to a rolling boil. Reduce to a simmer. Cover and cook for 10 minutes. If you want, for a thicker base, use an immersion blender to blend some (or all) of the beans and onions.\n4 Add water, stock, salt, cabbage, sliced onion, bay leaves, sausage, then simmer: Add the water, stock, salt, cabbage, sliced onion half, bay leaves and browned sausage. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to a simmer. Cover and simmer for 10 minutes, then uncover and continue cooking until the cabbage is tender, about another 10-20 minutes.\nTo serve, sprinkle on chopped parsley and grated cheese.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBraised Red Cabbage with Chestnuts Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 strips thick-cut bacon (about 3 ounces) cut crosswise into 1/4-inch strips\n1 medium onion, thinly sliced\n1 red cabbage head, about 2 pounds, quartered, tough core removed, quarters sliced into 1/4-inch thick slices\n1 large green tart apple\n1/2 cup apple cider vinegar\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n6 tablespoons sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt, more to taste\nFreshly ground pepper\n8 ounces canned or jarred roasted chestnuts (NOT water chestnuts), roughly chopped\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the bacon: Cook the bacon batons slowly in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan (with cover) on medium low heat until most of the fat has rendered out, and the bacon is lightly browned, not crisp.\n2 Add onions: Add the sliced onions, increase the heat of the pan to medium high and cook, stirring often, until the onions have softened and lightly browned.\n3 Add cabbage, apples, vinegars, sugar: While the onions are cooking, peel the apple and cut it into 1/2-inch thick pieces. Once the onions are ready, add the sliced cabbage, chopped apple, cider vinegar, balsamic vinegar, and sugar. Carefully toss to combine. Bring to a simmer, cover the pan, lower the heat, and simmer until the cabbage is cooked through and soft, about 40 minutes.\n4 Add chestnuts: Uncover the pan. Add the chopped roasted chestnuts. Add salt and pepper to taste. Increase the heat to boil off excess moisture for a few minutes.\nServe hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nPork Chops with Braised Cabbage Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nWe used large, bone-in pork chops for this recipe, but any style pork chop\xe2\x80\x94thick or thin, bone-in or boneless\xe2\x80\x94will work.\nThe ultimate cooking time may depend on if you are using pork chops taken directly from the fridge or chops that have been allowed to come closer to room temperature before cooking. Thin chops you can take directly from the refrigerator. Thick chops should probably sit out for a bit before cooking.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 teaspoons bacon fat, butter or extra virgin olive oil\n1 large onion, sliced 1/4-inch, about 2 cups\n1/2 head of cabbage, sliced 1/4-inch wide slices\nSalt\n1/4 teaspoon celery seed\n1 teaspoon caraway seed\n1/2 cup stock (chicken, beef, or vegetable) or water\n1 tablespoon mustard, preferably Dijon\n1 tablespoon malt or cider vinegar\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1 tablespoon bacon fat or extra virgin olive oil\n4 pork chops\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions and cabbage: Heat the bacon fat (or butter or olive oil) in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat.\nAdd the onion and saut\xc3\xa9, stirring only occasionally, until the edges of the onions begin to brown, about 5 minutes. Sprinkle salt over the onions as they cook.\nAdd the sliced cabbage and toss to combine. Cook for a minute or two, then add the celery seed, caraway, and stock. Cover and reduce the heat to low. Cook, covered for 10 minutes.\n2 Stir in mustard and vinegar: After 10 minutes, remove from heat, but leave the cover on the pan. Wait another 5 minutes, then uncover the pan and mix in the mustard and vinegar. Add salt and black pepper to taste.\n3 Cook the pork chops in a separate pan: As soon as you cover the cabbage pan in step 1, heat a tablespoon of bacon fat or oil in a cast iron frying pan on medium high heat. Pat the pork chops dry with paper towels. Sprinkle them with salt and lay them in the pan, working in batches if necessary as to not crowd the pan.\nTip: Place the chops in the pan so that the thickest, boniest parts are near the center of the pan where they get the most heat.\nAs soon as the chops are nicely browned on one side, about 2 minutes or so, flip them and sear them on the other side. If your pork chops are less than 3/4-inch thick, and you are using a cast iron pan, once the chops are seared on the second side, remove the pan from heat and let the chops sit in the hot pan until cooked through (you can use the finger test to check for the doneness of the meat). If you are not using a cast iron pan, just remove the pan from heat and cover the pan for a few minutes until the chops are done.\nIf your chops are thicker than 3/4-inch, and you are using a cast iron pan, remove the pan from heat and cover it, letting the chops finish cooking for about 5 minutes. If not using a cast iron pan, keep the chops covered on low heat for another 5 minutes after searing.\n4 Let chops rest, serve with cabbage: Remove the chops from the pan and let rest for 5 minutes. Serve alongside the cabbage.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nNapa Cabbage Picnic Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nThe dressing recipe makes a little more than you will likely need. So, use about 1/2 of it to start, and add more to taste when you dress the salad.\nThis salad recipes scales easily for a potluck or picnic.\nRecipe adapted from one in Sunset Magazine, July 2004\nINGREDIENTS\n1/3 cup slivered almonds\n4 cups (1/2 pound) coarsely shredded Napa cabbage\n6 ounces snow peas, sliced into half-inch slices on the diagonal\n2/3 cup thinly sliced radishes\n2/3 cup thinly sliced green onions (including greens)\n2/3 cup lightly packed chopped cilantro\nDressing ingredients:\n1 tablespoon plus 1 1/2 teaspoons rice vinegar (seasoned or unseasoned)\n1 tablespoon sugar\n1 tablespoon soy sauce\n1/2 clove peeled and minced garlic (about 1/2 teaspoon)\n1/4 teaspoon toasted sesame oil\n1/4 teaspoon ground ginger\n1/8 teaspoon cayenne powder\n1/2 cup mayonnaise\nMETHOD\n1 Toast the almonds: Toast the almond slivers in a dry nonstick or cast-iron skillet on medium high, stirring frequently until browned. Set aside.\n2 Assemble the salad ingredients: Combine cabbage, snow peas, radishes, green onions, cilantro in a large bowl. Can make this step a day or two ahead.\n3 Make the dressing: In a separate bowl, whisk together the rice vinegar, sugar, soy sauce, garlic, sesame oil, ginger, and cayenne until sugar has dissolved. Whisk in the mayonnaise.\n4 Toss the salad with dressing: When ready to serve, gently combine the dressing and almonds with the cabbage mixture.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nPot Sticker Stir-Fry Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 6 servings\nMichelle says, "The thing I love most about pot stickers is the umami-rich filling of pork, cabbage, and mushrooms. In fact, when I was a kid, there were times when I felt the urge to just empty the dumpling skins of their stuffing and tuck into a big bowl of pot sticker filling. Sadly, this sort of...creativity wasn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly encouraged at the dinner table. But now that I\xe2\x80\x99m an old bag, I do whatever I want\xe2\x80\x94which explains the existence of this recipe."\nRecipe reprinted with permission from Ready or Not!: 150+ Make-Ahead, Make-Over, and Make-Now Recipes by Nom Nom Paleo (Andrews McMeel Publishing, 2017). Copyright \xc2\xa9 2017 Michelle Tam & Henry Fong.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon ghee\n2 medium carrots, peeled and finely diced\n2 shallots, minced\n1/4 pound shiitake mushrooms, stemmed and thinly sliced\nKosher salt\n4 garlic cloves, minced\n1 tablespoon finely grated ginger\n2 pounds ground pork\n1 small Napa cabbage, cut in half and thinly sliced crosswise\n2 tablespoons coconut aminos\n2 teaspoon rice vinegar\n1 teaspoon fish sauce\n2 teaspoons toasted sesame oil\n3 scallions, thinly sliced\nButter lettuce leaves, to serve (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n12-inch skillet or large wok\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the vegetables: In a 12-inch (or larger) skillet over medium heat, melt the ghee. Once it\xe2\x80\x99s hot, toss in the carrots, shallots, and mushrooms.\nAdd a sprinkle of salt, and saut\xc3\xa9 for 3 to 5 minutes or until the shallots are soft and the \xe2\x80\x99shrooms are pliable.\nToss in the garlic and ginger, and stir for 30 seconds or until fragrant.\n2 Add the ground pork and cook: Add the pork along with another sprinkle of salt, and break up the meat with a spatula or wooden spoon.\nCrank up the heat to medium-high, and cook for about 5 minutes or until the pork is no longer pink.\n3 Transfer the cooked pork with a slotted spoon to another platter. Leave the cooking liquid in the pan.\n4 Cook the cabbage: Throw the cabbage into the pan with another sprinkle of salt, and saut\xc3\xa9 for 3 to 5 minutes or until wilted.\n5 Combine everything back in the skillet and season: Lower the heat to medium, and add the ground pork back into the skillet. Stir to combine.\nSeason with coconut aminos, rice vinegar, and fish sauce. Taste and adjust with more seasoning if needed.\n6 Serve and eat: Remove the skillet from the heat. Finish with a drizzle of sesame oil and a generous sprinkle of scallions. Serve the stir-fry on its own, or with butter lettuce to make lettuce cups (i.e. paleo "tacos"!).\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nSkillet Pork Chops with Cabbage Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n4 thick bone-in center-cut pork loin chops (2 1/2 pounds total)\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon pepper\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1 yellow onion, thinly sliced\n1 clove garlic, chopped\n1/2 large head green cabbage, cored and very thinly sliced with a mandoline or chef\xe2\x80\x99s knife\n1 apple (any kind), peeled, cored, and cut into bite-sized chunks\n1 teaspoon caraway seeds, optional\n3 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\nSpecial equipment:\nMandoline (optional)\n10-inch oven-safe skillet\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Sear the pork chops: Sprinkle the pork all over with 1/2 teaspoon of the salt and 1/4 teaspoon of the pepper. Heat a 10-inch oven-safe skillet over medium-high heat for 1 minute. Add 2 tablespoons of the oil and when it is hot, add the pork chops in one layer.\nSear for 3 minutes without disturbing. Turn and cook 2 minutes more. Transfer to a plate or bowl.\n3 Cook the cabbage: Add the remaining 1 tablespoon oil to the pan over medium heat. Add the onion, garlic, and cabbage, along with the remaining 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Cook for about 3 minutes, stirring until the cabbage is completely coated with oil.\nContinue cooking, stirring occasionally, for 15 minutes. Add the apples, caraway seeds (if using), and 2 tablespoons of the parsley. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 10 minutes more, or until the cabbage is very tender and wilted.\n4 Finish cooking the pork chops: Set the pork chops on the cabbage and tip any juices from the bowl into the pan with the cabbage.\nTransfer to the oven. Cook the pork for 10 to 15 minutes, without turning the chops, or until a meat thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the meat registers at least 145\xc2\xb0F. Exact cooking time will depend on the thickness of your pork chops.\n5 Serve: Carefully remove the skillet from the oven (the handle will be very hot). Let the meat and cabbage sit for 5 minutes. Sprinkle with the remaining 1 tablespoon parsley. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nButtered Cabbage with Caraway Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 2-pound head of green cabbage\n4 Tbsp butter\n1 teaspoon caraway seeds\n1/2 teaspoon celery seeds\nSalt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Put water on to boil: Heat a large (8-quart) pot of well salted water to a boil.\n2 Prep the cabbage: While the water is heating, prepare the cabbage. Peel away and discard and discolored or old outer leaves. Cut the head of cabbage into quarters, through the core, and cut away and discard the core. Use your hands to tear the cabbage into large (about 1 to 2 inch) pieces. (Or use a knife.)\n3 Boil leaves for 90 seconds: Once the water is at a rolling boil, add the torn cabbage leaves to the water. Submerge the leaves in the hot water. Cook for 90 seconds, then drain the pot of its water. Return the cabbage leaves to the pot.\n4 Melt butter, toss with cabbage, caraway, celery seeds, salt: Stir 4 tablespoons of butter into the cabbage. The cabbage and the pan are both hot, so the butter should melt quickly in the pan.\nIf you are using unsalted butter, you will want to add more salt to the cabbage. Start with half a teaspoon and add more if needed.\nSprinkle with caraway seeds, celery seeds, and black pepper, and toss to combine.\nServe immediately. Great with pork, veal, or frankfurters.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'

If you are using unsweetened rice vinegar, to get the right balance of acidity and sweet, sprinkle a little sugar over the salad and toss.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups thinly sliced cabbage (about 1/3 to 1/2 cabbage)\n1 carrot, grated\n2 radishes, thinly sliced\n1 green onion, thinly sliced\n1/4 cup (packed) fresh cilantro, chopped\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 tablespoon seasoned rice vinegar (or plain rice vinegar with added sugar to taste)\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Assemble the salad: Place the thinly sliced cabbage, grated carrot, radish slices, sliced green onions, and cilantro in a large serving bowl.\n2 Toss with dressing and serve: Right before serving, sprinkle with olive oil, rice vinegar, salt and pepper, and toss to coat.\nServe immediately.\nHello!
