b'Save It Print\nCabbage and Kale Slaw with Caraway Ranch Dressing Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nDressing Ingredients:\n1 tablespoon minced shallots\n2 teaspoons Dijon mustard (whole grain or smooth)\n2 Tbsp champagne vinegar (or white wine vinegar)\n6 tablespoons buttermilk\n2/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1 teaspoon caraway seeds\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nPinch of white pepper (can sub black pepper)\n  Salad Ingredients:\n4 cups thinly sliced green cabbage (about 1/2 a large head)\n1 cup thinly sliced red onion\n1 cup, packed, thinly sliced curly or lacinato kale (center tough stems removed before slicing the leaves)\nMETHOD\n1 Heat and grind caraway seeds: Heat a small saut\xc3\xa9 pan on high heat. Add the caraway seeds to the pan. Stir the seeds in the pan and heat them until they are warm and fragrant, then remove from pan. Do not brown them. Grind them with a mortar and pestle or mince them up finely with a sharp knife.\n2 Make dressing: Add the shallots, mustard, and vinegar into a bowl, whisk to combine. Whisk in the buttermilk. Slowly dribble in the olive oil, whisking to create an emulsion. (You can also put everything into a jar, close the jar and shake vigorously to create an emulsion.) Whisk in the caraway seeds, salt, and pepper.\n3 Assemble salad: Place the thinly sliced cabbage, red onion, and kale into a large serving bowl. Sprinkle with dressing and toss to combine 10 to 15 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nRoasted Cabbage with Bacon Gremolata Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: 4 to 6 servings\nFrom Andrea Bemis:\n"This is one of our favorite winter side dishes, and we get rave re\xc2\xadviews each time we serve it for company. I\'ve brought back the bacon gremolata yet again because it pairs so nicely with the roasted cabbage. I hope you and your guests find as much joy and pleasure in this simple recipe as we do."\nAdapted from Dishing Up the Dirt by Andrea Bemis, copyright \xc2\xa9 2017. Published by Harper Wave, an imprint of Harper Collins Publishers.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cabbage:\n1 medium-sized head of cabbage (about 1 1/2 pounds)\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nFor the bacon gremolata:\n3/4 cup roasted unsalted almonds\n4 strips (about 1/4 pound) good-quality thick-cut bacon\n3 tablespoons minced fresh parsley\n1 teaspoon freshly grated lemon zest\nPinch of kosher salt\nTo serve:\nFreshly grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 400F. Arrange two oven racks in the upper and lower third of the oven.\n2 Slice the cabbage: Peel off one or two of the thin, limp outer layers of the cabbage. Trim the stem so that it is flush with the bottom of the cabbage (if it isn\'t already).\nSet the cabbage upright and slice into 1-inch thick slices. Don\'t worry if a few of the outer layers unfurl or fall away.\n3 Brush the cabbage slices with olive oil: Use a pastry brush to cover both sides of the cabbage slices with olive oil, or use your fingers to rub the oil in. Season both sides with a little salt and pepper.\n4 Roast the cabbage: Arrange the cabbage slices in a single layer on a baking sheet. Roast on the lower oven rack for 35 to 45 minutes, flipping the slices halfway through cooking.\nWhen done, both sides should be seared an even golden-brown with crispy edges and the center of the slices should be tender.\n5 While the cabbage is roasting, prepare the bacon gremolata. If using unroasted almonds, arrange them on another sheet pan and roast in the upper part of the oven for about 10 minutes, until toasted and fragrant. Remove from the oven, cool briefly, then finely chop using a chef\'s knife (or pulse a few times in a food processor, but be careful not to over process or you\'ll make almond butter!)\nCook the bacon in a skillet over medium heat until very crispy. Transfer to a plate lined with paper towels to drain. When cool, roughly chop.\nCombine the chopped almonds, chopped bacon, minced parsley, lemon zest, and a pinch of kosher salt in a small mixing bowl. Toss to combine and set aside. (This bacon gremolata can be prepared ahead and kept refrigerated in an airtight container for about a week.)\n6 To serve: As soon as the cabbage slices are done roasting, transfer to a serving platter or individual plates. Sprinkle with a few spoonfuls of bacon gremolata and grated Parmesan cheese. Serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nSlow Cooker Corned Beef and Cabbage Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 8 hoursYield: 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n3 to 3 1/2 pounds cured corned beef, with spice packet\n1 medium white onion, quartered\n2 cloves garlic, peeled and left whole\n3 cups of water\n1 1/2 pounds new red potatoes, washed and chopped into 2-inch chunks\n1 medium (about 1 1/4 pounds) green cabbage, cut into sixths\n4 large carrots, peeled and cut into 2-inch slices\nWhole grain mustard, for topping\nSpecial equipment:\nSlow Cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the corned beef: After removing the corned beef from the bag, rinse it under cold water to rid it of any remaining brine. Then place the brisket into your slow cooker, fat side up. Sprinkle the contents of the spice packet over the brisket and add the onion and garlic. Pour the water over the brisket and cook on low for 8 hours (or on high for 4 hours).\n2 Add the vegetables: With 2 hours of cook time remaining (or 1 hour if cooking on high), carefully remove the corned beef from the slow cooker to a plate. Add the cut potatoes to the bottom, then return the brisket to the slow cooker. Nestle the cabbage pieces and carrots around the beef and cover. Continue to cook the corned beef for 2 hours if you're cooking on low (or 1 hour if on high).\n3 Slice and serve: Once the potatoes are fork tender and a piece of brisket easily flakes off when pierced with a fork, carefully remove the corned beef from the slow cooker to a cutting board, using a pair of tongs. Slice the brisket 1/4- to 1/2-inch thick, against the grain.\nTransfer to a serving platter and arrange the cabbage, carrots, and potatoes around it. You can also return the corned beef slices to the slow cooker to keep warm and serve directly from the pot.\nTop with whole grain mustard, if desired.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nClassic Corned Beef and Cabbage Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 4 hoursYield: 6 servings\nCorned beef often comes with a spice packet. For this version, I discard the packaged spices, and instead make my own blend for a more flavorful, satisfying brisket.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the corned beef\n1 flat-cut corned beef brisket (about 4 pounds)\n1/4 teaspoon mustard seed\n1/4 teaspoon coriander seed\n1/8 teaspoon whole cloves\n1/8 teaspoon whole peppercorns\n2 to 3 bay leaves\n1 large onion, peeled and quartered\n6 Yukon gold potatoes (about 1 pound), halved, or quartered, if large\n1 small head of cabbage (about 1 3/4 pounds), outer tough leaves removed and cut into 6 wedges\n12 slender carrots (about 1 pound), peeled and left whole\n2 teaspoons kosher salt\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley (for garnish)\nDijon or grainy mustard (for serving)\nFor the horseradish sauce (Optional)\n1 cup sour cream\n3 tablespoons whole milk\n1 tablespoon lemon juice, or more, to taste\n1 tablespoon prepared horseradish in brine, or more, to taste\n1/2 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the horseradish sauce (optional): In a bowl, stir the sour cream and milk together until blended. Stir in the lemon juice, horseradish, and mustard. Add the salt, pepper, and parsley, and taste. Add more horseradish or lemon juice, if you like. Cover and set in the refrigerator until ready to serve.\n2 Preheat the oven: Preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xbaF.\n3 Prepare the meat for braising: Discard the spice packet that came with the beef. In a Dutch oven or other large, heavy-bottomed pot, place the brisket, mustard seed, coriander seed, cloves, peppercorns, bay leaves, and onion quarters. Add enough cold water to just cover the meat.\n4 Braise the meat: Over medium heat on the stovetop, bring the water to a boil. Cover the pot and place in the oven for 3 1/2 hours, or until the beef is very tender when pierced with a fork. Remove the meat from the broth with tongs and transfer it to a shallow baking dish or baking sheet.\n5 Brown the meat: Increase the oven temperature to 425\xc2\xb0F. Place the corned beef in the oven with a ladle of stock, and bake for 10 to 15 minutes, or until the top browns. Transfer the meat to a cutting board, cover with foil to keep warm, and let rest while you cook the vegetables. Turn off the oven.\n6 Strain the stock, cook the vegetables, and slice the meat: In a fine mesh strainer, strain the stock and return it to the pot. Add the salt. With a ladle, skim the fat that rises to the top. Bring it to a boil.\nAdd the potatoes and adjust the heat to a simmer. Cook for 5 minutes. Add the cabbage wedges and carrots, cover and bring to a simmer again. Cook for 15 to 20 minutes, or until the potatoes, carrots, and cabbage are tender.\nTransfer them to a deep platter, cover with foil, and keep them warm in the turned-off oven.\n7 Slice and serve the corned beef: Slice the beef across the grain into 1/4-inch thick slices. Transfer them to the platter with the vegetables, and spoon a few ladles of stock over the meat and vegetables. Sprinkle with chopped parsley. Serve with mustard and/or horseradish sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nChicken Cacciatore (Hunter Style Chicken) Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nThis recipe calls for added wine, which is traditional. It does add to the flavor. If you have a dietary restriction that prohibits wine, just omit.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 4 pound chicken, cut into serving pieces, trimmed of excess fat (or 3 1/2 to 4 pounds of chicken thighs, bone in, skin on)\nSalt\n2 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 medium onion, thinly sliced root to tip, about 1 1/2 cups\n1 red or green bell pepper, seeded, sliced into 1/4-inch wide slices\n8 ounces cremini mushrooms, thickly sliced\n2 garlic cloves, thinly sliced\n1/3 cup white or red wine\n2 1/2 to 3 cups peeled and chopped, firm ripe tomatoes, with their juices,  or 1 28 ounce can of plum tomatoes in their juice\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1 teaspoon dry thyme (or 2 teaspoons fresh, chopped)\n1 teaspoon dry oregano (or 2 teaspoons fresh, chopped)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the chicken: Rinse chicken and pat dry. Season the chicken pieces on all sides with salt. Heat olive oil in a large skillet on medium heat.\nWorking in batches so that you don't crowd the pan, place the chicken pieces skin side down in the pan.  Cook until nicely browned, about 5 minutes, then turn over and lightly brown the other side.\nRemove chicken to a bowl, set aside. Drain off all but 2 tablespoons of the rendered fat. If you have less than 2 Tbsp of fat in the pan, add more olive oil until you have about that much oil coating the pan.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions, bell peppers, mushrooms, garlic: Add the sliced onions, bell peppers, and mushrooms to the pan. Increase the heat to medium high.\nCook until the onions are translucent, and the mushrooms have given up most of their moisture, stirring frequently, about 10 minutes.\nAdd the garlic to the pan and cook a minute more.\n3 Deglaze pan with wine, add tomatoes, spices: Add the wine and scrape up any browned bits at the bottom of the pan. Simmer until the wine is reduced by half. Add the tomatoes.\nStir in the pepper, thyme, oregano, and about a teaspoon of salt. Test and taste to adjust. Simmer uncovered for another 5 minutes.\n4 Add chicken back to pan, partially cover, cook until tender: Place the chicken pieces on top of the tomatoes and onions, skin side up. Lower the heat and cover the skillet with the lid slightly ajar.\nCook the chicken on a low simmer, turning and basting from time to time. Cook until the thighs are tender, about 30 to 40 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nRabbit Cacciatore Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 4-5\nWhole rabbit is much more difficult to part out than a whole chicken. If you can, have your butcher cut it for you.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 2 1/4 pound rabbit, cut into 6 to 8 pieces\nSalt and freshly ground pepper\n3 tablespoons fresh thyme leaves (or 1 Tbsp dried)\n1 teaspoon fresh rosemary leaves (or 1/2 teaspoon dried)\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour (Wondra flour works great)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 cup chopped onion\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n2/3 cup chopped mushrooms\n3 cups of chopped, very ripe tomatoes (or canned plum tomatoes)\n2 red bell peppers, seeded, cut into 1-inch cubes\n1 bay leaf\n16 salt-cured olives, black or green, pitted\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nBefore you start, cut the rabbit into pieces, or have your butcher do it for you. Hank Shaw has an excellent guide here: How to Cut up a Rabbit.\n1 Brown the rabbit pieces: Sprinkle the rabbit pieces generously with salt and pepper. Rub half of the thyme leaves into the pieces, then sprinkle with flour to lightly coat.\nHeat olive oil in a large skillet on medium high. Place the rabbit pieces in the pan in a single layer. Do not stir.\nCook for 2-3 minutes on one side until lightly browned, then turn the pieces and brown on the other side for a minute or two more. Remove the rabbit pieces to a dish to set aside.\n2 Add onions, then garlic, bell pepper, mushrooms, rosemary, thyme: Reduce the heat to medium. Add onions to the pan, cook for 1 minute. Then add garlic, bell pepper, and mushrooms, cook for a couple minutes more. Add the rosemary and the remaining thyme.\n3 Add the rabbit back into the pan. Cover with chopped tomatoes and bay leaf.\nReduce heat to medium low; cover the pan and cook for 35 minutes.\n4 Uncover the pan, add the olives.\n5 Boil off excess liquid: Increase heat to high and cook for several minutes to boil off excess moisture and reduce the sauce.\nWhen the liquid has reduced by half, check the seasoning, add salt or pepper to taste, remove from heat and serve.\nServe with rice, pasta, or potatoes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHow to Cut and Prepare Prickly Pears\nINGREDIENTS\n1 prickly pear\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Slice both ends of the prickly pear off. Discard them.\n2 Make one long vertical slice down the body of the prickly pear.\n3 Slip your finger into the slice and grab a hold of the skin.\n4 Peel back the skin: Begin to peel back the thick fleshy skin that\'s wrapped around the prickly pear. Discard the skin. You\'ll be left with the prickly pear itself.\nThe flesh is studded with tons of little edible seeds, if you like them, feel free to just chop the prickly pear up and eat, seeds and all.\n5 Extract the juice: To extract the prickly pear juice, place the "husked" prickly pears into a blender or food processor and pulse until liquefied.\nPlace the juice into a fine mesh sieve and push out the juice into a pitcher or bowl. Discard the remaining pulp and seeds.\nUse the juice as you like. Depending on the size of the prickly pears, 6 to 12 prickly pears will get you about 1 cup of juice. It\'s great mixed in with some fresh lemonade, just use equal parts of prickly pear juice to lemonade.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nNopalitos with Tomatoes and Onions Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 3 to 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound nopalitos, nopales prickly pear cactus paddles that have been stripped of spines, cleaned, and chopped\nExtra virgin olive oil\n2 large cloves garlic, minced\n1/2 red onion, roughly chopped\n1 jalape\xc3\xb1o pepper, stem and seeds removed, chopped\n1 medium tomato, roughly chopped\nSalt and pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, garlic, jalape\xc3\xb1o: Heat a tablespoon of olive oil (enough to coat the bottom of the pan) in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add red onion, garlic, and jalape\xc3\xb1o. Cook for a minute, stirring occasionally.\n2 Add the nopalitos, then the tomatoes: Add the nopalitos. Cook for several more minutes. Then add the chopped tomato.\nContinue to cook until all vegetables are cooked through. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve immediately.\nHello! b'Save It Print\nNopalitos Cactus Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 6\nIf using canned nopalitos, just drain them and mix them in with the tomatoes and the rest of the ingredients. No need to cook them as they are already cooked.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound (450 g) fresh chopped nopalitos\n1 pound cherry tomatoes, quartered (about 3 cups)\n1 cup chopped red radishes\n1 cup finely chopped red onion\n3 tablespoons lime juice\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/2 cup chopped cilantro\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch and rinse nopalitos: Bring a medium pot of salted water to a boil. Add the nopalitos, return to a rolling boil and cook for 1 minute. Strain through a fine mesh sieve. Rinse with water for 1 minute.\n2 Toss with remaining ingredients: Place rinsed and drained nopalitos in a bowl with the chopped tomatoes, radishes, and onion. Toss with lime juice, olive oil, salt, and pepper. Fold in cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCactus and Corn Salsa Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 3 cups\nIf your farmers market doesn\xe2\x80\x99t sell cactus, you can find it in most Latin grocery stores in the produce aisle, either whole or already prepped and chopped.\nYou can also buy it in a jar in the Mexican food aisle of your grocery store, but fresh paddles taste far better. You\xe2\x80\x99ll want fresh paddles for this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 nopales cactus paddles, spikes removed*\n2 green tomatoes, cored and cut in half\n1/2 large, white onion, peeled and cut into 4 chunks\n2 jalape\xc3\xb1o chiles, red or green, more or less to taste\n1 teaspoon extra virgin olive oil plus more to grease baking sheet\n1 cup frozen corn**\n1 cup cilantro, stems removed\n1 garlic clove, peeled\nJuice from 1/2 a lime, about 1 tablespoon\n2 tablespoons tequila, optional\n1 teaspoon dried Mexican oregano\nSalt to taste\nTortilla chips, to serve\n*This recipe is designed for the whole paddles, but you may be able to make it with bagged cut cactus for nopalitos if that's all that is available in the market. Just arrange them close together on the roasting pan while you roast the vegetables so they don't dry out.\n**You can also use freshly cooked corn or grilled corn, stripped from the cob. In this case, skip the corn roasting in step 2, and just add to the salsa in the last step.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep cactus paddles: Heat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Working with a large sharp knife with a fairly straight edge, scrape off any remaining prickles or nubs on the cactus paddles.\nCut the paddles crosswise into 1-inch thick strips. Lightly grease a baking sheet with olive oil.\n2 Roast the cactus paddles, onion and jalape\xc3\xb1os in oven: Place cactus, green tomatoes, white onion and jalape\xc3\xb1os on the baking sheet in preheated 425\xc2\xb0F oven for 12 minutes. The cactus should still be slightly crisp when pierced with a fork.\n3 Roast the corn kernels: Heat a cast iron or stick-free skillet with 1 teaspoon olive oil over medium heat on the stove top. When the pan is heated, add frozen corn and spread out in an even layer. Do not stir the corn. Allow it to roast in the hot pan for about 2 to 3 minutes.\nThe corn should become browned and roasted. You can check by gently flipping a few pieces with the corner of a spatula.\nWhen corn is browned, stir and roast for another 2 to 3 minutes. Remove from heat. Place corn in a small bowl and set aside.\n4 Pulse in a food processor: Place the oven roasted vegetables in a food processor with the cilantro, garlic, lime juice, tequila, oregano and salt. Pulse until nearly smooth, about 30 seconds.\n(Be careful when you remove the lid on the food processor\xe2\x80\x94the heat released from the peppers will zoom up your nose and down your throat, so don\xe2\x80\x99t stand directly over the open food processor.)\n5 Stir in the roasted corn: Pour the salsa into a serving dish. Stir the roasted corn into the finished salsa. Allow to rest in the fridge for 30 minutes to 1 hour. Serve with tortilla chips.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nRemoulade Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: Makes about 1 1/2 cups\nIf you don't have any pickle juice on hand, use a little lemon juice or vinegar.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/4 cups mayonnaise\n1/4 cup mustard (Creole mustard if possible)\n1 Tbsp sweet paprika\n1-2 teaspoons Cajun or Creole seasoning\n2 teaspoons prepared horseradish\n1 teaspoon pickle juice (dill or sweet, your preference)\n1 teaspoon hot sauce (preferably Tabasco)\n1 large clove garlic, minced and smashed\nMETHOD\nMix all the ingredients together in a medium bowl. The remoulade is better if left for a few hours to let the flavors meld. Keep refrigerated.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nShrimp Gumbo with Andouille Sausage Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nIf you are not familiar with fil\xc3\xa9 (fee-lay), it is a powder made from dried sassafras leaves. It is a powerful thickener, but must be added at the end of cooking or it will form slimy, ropey strands in the gumbo. Fil\xc3\xa9 is available in many supermarkets (we found ours at Whole Foods), or online.\nNote that you can make your own shellfish stock with the shells from the shrimp. Put the shrimp shells and tail tips in a pot and cover with 2 quarts of water.  Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and simmer uncovered for an hour. Strain and use in this recipe for the stock. Diluted bottle clam juice will also work as shellfish stock in this recipe. Read more here.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup peanut oil, or other vegetable oil\n1/2 cup all-purpose flour\n1 green bell pepper, chopped\n1 medium onion, chopped\n3 celery stalks, chopped\n4 garlic cloves, minced\n1 tablespoons Cajun seasoning\n1 quart shellfish or chicken stock, plus 1 cup water (see Recipe Note)\n2 teaspoons Worcestershire sauce\n8-12 ounces smoked andouille sausage, cut into 1/4-inch thick rounds\n2 pounds shrimp, peeled and deveined\nSalt and pepper to taste\n3-5 green onions, white and green parts, chopped\nFil\xc3\xa9 powder (optional)\nHot sauce (such as Tabasco) to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the roux. Heat the peanut oil in a large, thick-bottomed pot, such as a Dutch oven, on medium high heat, for a minute or two. Whisk in the flour and lower the heat to medium. Stir almost constantly, making sure to scrape the bottom of the pan as you stir.\nLet the roux cook until it is the color of peanut butter, then lower the heat to medium low. Keep cooking and stirring (careful, you want the flour to cook, not burn!) until the roux is the color of an old penny, about 20-30 minutes total time.\n2 Stir in the vegetables: Mix in the "holy trinity" of green pepper, onion and celery and increase the heat to medium-high. Cook, stirring often, for 5 minutes.\nAdd the garlic and cook another 2 minutes. Stir in the Cajun seasoning.\n3 Slowly add stock, then simmer: In a separate pot, heat the stock and water until steamy. Slowly add the steamy stock and water to the bell pepper onion roux mixture, stirring constantly while you do so.\nBring the gumbo to a simmer and add the Worcestershire sauce and salt to taste. Simmer gently for 30 minutes.\nIf you find that the roux has broken a bit and oil is pooling on the surface of the gumbo, whisk in about another 1/2 to 1 cup of water. This will often "fix" it.\n4 Stir in the andouille sausage and cook for 5 minutes (andouille sausage is already cooked, so you just need to heat it).\n5 Add the shrimp, return to a simmer and cook another 5 minutes, until the shrimp has just cooked through. Add salt and black pepper to taste.\n6 Serve: Serve with white rice, garnished with green onions. To eat, sprinkle with fil\xc3\xa9 powder and hot sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nShrimp Po Boy Sandwich Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 4 large sandwiches\nIf you cant get peanut oil, use any other vegetable oil or lard. And if you don't feel like making remoulade, smear the top of the bread with mayo and the bottom with mustard.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound medium shrimp, shelled, deveined and with tails removed\n3/4 cup fine cornmeal\n3/4 cup flour\n1 Tbsp Cajun seasoning\n1 teaspoon salt\n2 eggs, beaten\nPeanut oil for frying\n1/2 head iceberg lettuce, shredded\n2-3 tomatoes, sliced about 1/4 inch thick\n4 small French sandwich rolls\nRemoulade\n1/4 cup mustard, preferably Creole mustard\n1 1/4 cups mayo\n2 teaspoons prepared horseradish\n1 teaspoon pickle juice or vinegar\n1 teaspoon hot sauce (Crystal, Tabasco, etc)\n1 large garlic clove, minced and smashed\n1 Tbsp sweet paprika\n1-2 teaspoons Cajun seasoning\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the remoulade sauce: If you are making your own remoulade, mix all the ingredients together in a bowl and set aside for 30 minutes or so; you don't have to wait that long, but the sauce will be better over time.\n2 Heat oil in pan: Pour enough peanut oil in a large frying pan to come up about 1/4 inch, and set the pan over medium-high heat until a small amount of flour sizzles immediately when you drop some in.\n3 Dredge shrimp: Mix the cornmeal, flour, Cajun seasoning and salt in a large bowl. Working with a few at a time, dredge the shrimp in the egg, then in the cornmeal-flour mixture.\n4 Fry shrimp: Shake off any excess breading and fry the shrimp until golden on both sides, about 2 minutes total. Set the fried shrimp aside on paper towels to drain.\n5 Assemble sandwiches: To assemble the sandwiches, slice the sandwich loaves almost all the way through and smear remoulade on both the top and bottom.\nLay down a layer of shredded lettuce on the bottom of the sandwich, then arrange the shrimp on top.\nLay 3-4 slices of tomato on the shrimp and press the top of the bread down on the bottom, compressing the sandwich a little.\nServe at once with hot sauce and a beer.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nChicken Gumbo with Andouille Sausage Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 10-12\nI include a recipe for my own Cajun spice blend, but you can use a commercial spice blend if you want.\nA word on the andouille sausage: try your best to find it. We've found it in regular supermarkets, and it comes fresh or smoked. Either is good. It can be spicy, however, so if you are sensitive to spicy foods, lower the amount of cayenne in the recipe and use a mild Italian sausage.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/3 pound bacon, diced\n2-3 pounds chicken thighs, skin on\nSalt\n1-2 pounds andouille sausage\n1/2 cup peanut or other vegetable oil\n1 cup flour\n2 green peppers, diced\n4 celery stalks, diced\n1 large onion, diced\n4 garlic cloves, minced\n2 tablespoons tomato paste\n1 quart chicken stock\n1 quart water\n1/2 to 1 pound okra, sliced into discs\n3 green onions, chopped\n1/2 cup fresh parsley, chopped\nCajun spice mix\n1 teaspoon black pepper\n1/2 to 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1 teaspoon celery seed\n2 Tbsp sweet paprika\n1 Tbsp garlic powder\n1 Tbsp dried thyme\n1 Tbsp dried oregano\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the bacon: Cook the diced bacon until crispy in a large stew pot set over medium heat. Remove the bacon and set aside; you'll add it back in when you serve your gumbo.\n2 Brown the chicken in the bacon fat: Once the bacon is cooked, set the chicken thighs skin side down in the bacon fat to crisp. Salt the meat side, which will be facing up in the pot.\nCook the chicken, without moving, for at least 4-5 minutes before trying to turn the chicken over.\nBrown the other side of the chicken thighs. Incidentally, you start with skin side down to render some fat, which you will need for the roux.\n3 Brown the sausages: Remove the browned chicken thighs and set aside. Brown the sausages in the fat, remove and set aside.\n4 Make the roux: If you want, measure how much fat is in the pot; it should be about 1/2 cup. Or, do what I do and add 1/2 cup peanut oil to the pot. Let this heat up a minute or two, then stir in 1 cup flour. Stir this almost constantly for the first few minutes, then every couple minutes or so thereafter.\nLower the heat to medium-low and cook this roux until it turns dark. How dark? I like my roux the color of coffee with just a tiny bit of cream.\nYou can go all the way to chocolate brown, but be careful! If you burn your roux you will need to start over and make it again. This whole process can take 30 minutes.\n5 Heat chicken stock: While you are stirring and cooking the roux, bring the chicken stock and water to a boil in a separate pot.\n6 Add onion, bell pepper, celery to roux, add garlic, then tomato paste: Add to the roux the onion, green pepper and celery and mix well. Let this cook, stirring often, for about 5 minutes.\nAdd the garlic, stir again and cook for another 2 minutes. Mix in the tomato paste.\n7 Ladle hot stock into the gumbo, stir in some spice: Using a large ladle, add the hot chicken stock to the gumbo. It will sizzle and seize up as the roux absorbs the liquid.\nKeep adding more stock, stirring all the time and scraping the bottom of the pot, to incorporate all the stock and all the roux.\nYou might not need all 2 quarts, but add enough to make the gumbo slightly more watery than you want it to be at the end\xe2\x80\x94remember you are going to cook this down for several hours.\nStir in half the Cajun spice mix, taste the gumbo, and add more if you want.\n8 Lower the heat, add the chicken, simmer: Lower the heat to medium-low and add back the chicken thighs. Now you can either eat the skin while it's still crispy, or toss it into the gumbo and chop it fine later. I tend to do half-and-half.\nSimmer this gently, stirring from time to time, until the meat wants to fall off the bones of the chicken, about 90 minutes. Remove the chicken and let it cool a bit.\n9 Add sausage, okra, chicken meat: While the chicken is cooling, cut the andouille sausage into thick discs and drop them in the gumbo.\nAdd the okra.\nPick the chicken meat from the bones and chop it roughly. Add it back to the gumbo.\nAt this point you can cook the gumbo for another hour, or up to several more hours, depending on how cooked down you want the final stew to be.\n10 Add green onions, parsley, bacon to serve: When you are ready to eat, add the green onions, parsley and bacon and stir well. Serve over rice, or with good French bread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nRed Beans and Rice Recipe\nYield: Serves 8\nIf you have access to ham hocks and not shanks, you may want to make up the difference in meat (hocks have much less meat) with sausage. Just take 1/2 pound of Andouille sausage, slice, brown first before adding to the beans with the ham shanks.\nIf you do not eat pork, you might try making this with smoked turkey sausage, in which case I would replace some of the water with chicken stock.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb dry small red beans\n1 1/2 to 2 lbs meaty ham shanks\n4 cups water\n4 cloves garlic, minced\n1 large onion, chopped (about 2 cups)\n1 1/2 cups chopped celery\n1 cup chopped green bell pepper\n1 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce\n2 teaspoons of Cajun or Creole seasoning (Tony Chachere's or Zatarains) or to taste*\nTabasco sauce**\nSalt and pepper to taste\nCooked white rice (from about 3 cups raw rice)\n*If you don't have access to packaged seasoning, just skip it and add some thyme (fresh or dried), a bay leaf (in with the beans and shanks in step 2), and a little paprika\n**We used a combo of Chipotle Tabasco sauce and regular Tabasco, could also use cayenne pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Soak the beans: Place dried beans in a large bowl and cover them with cold water by a couple of inches. Let soak for 8 hours or overnight. (You can quick soak them by putting them in a bowl and pouring boiling water over them, covering them by 2 inches, then letting them soak for two hours.) Drain.\n2 Cook beans with ham, garlic, onion, water: Place beans, ham shanks, garlic, chopped onion, and water in a large (8-quart) pot and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer and cover, simmer for 1 1/2 hours or until beans are tender.\n3 Remove ham shanks, separate meat from bones: Remove ham shanks from the pot to a dish. Let cool slightly then shred the meat away from the bones. Return the meat back to the pot.\n4 Add vegetables, seasonings, cook until thick: Add the celery, bell peppers, Worcestershire and seasonings. Cover and cook for another hour or until the mixture gets thick.\nSeason to taste with Tabasco sauce, salt and pepper.\nServe over rice.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nCajun Chicken Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nWhile this recipe calls for poaching raw chicken breasts, you could easily just use leftover cooked chicken.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound skinless, boneless chicken breasts\nSalt\n1/2 cup mayonnaise\n2 Tbsp mustard\n1 Tbsp cider vinegar\n2 teaspoons paprika\n1 teaspoon Cajun or Creole seasoning\n1 teaspoon prepared horseradish\n2 hard-boiled eggs, chopped\n1/2 cup chopped celery\n1/2 cup chopped green pepper\n1/4 cup chopped green onion\nTabasco or other hot sauce to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Poach the chicken: Set a 2-quart pot of well salted water over high heat. As the water heats to a boil, cut the chicken breasts into large (2 1/2-inch) chunks. When the water boils, add the chicken. Return to a simmer, then turn off the heat, and cover the pot. Let sit for 15 minutes (time it) or more while you prepare everything else.\n2 Make the dressing, mix in the eggs and vegetables: In a large bowl, mix the mayo, mustard, vinegar, paprika, Cajun seasoning and horseradish together. Mix in the eggs, celery, green pepper, green onion.\n3 Dice chicken, mix with salad: Using a slotted spoon, remove the chicken from the poaching water* and dice it. Mix it in with the remaining ingredients. Add salt and hot sauce to taste. Chill before serving.\nServe over butter lettuce or between two pieces of bread for a sandwich.\n*The resulting poaching liquid is a light, salted chicken broth. You can save it and pour it into a cup and drink it as a light soup if you want.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nSlow Cooker Cajun-Spiced Stuffed Peppers Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 4 hoursYield: 5 to 6 servings\nLook for Cajun seasoning in the spice section at the grocery store. It is typically a mix of paprika, cayenne, garlic, cumin, oregano, and a few other dried spices.\nBe sure to buy bell peppers that are shaped like big cups and can stand upright on their own.\nYou can also cook these peppers in the oven: Put them in a baking dish, cover with foil, and bake at 400F for 50 to 60 minutes. Slice one pepper open to make sure the beef has cooked through.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound (450g) lean ground beef\n1 1/2 (225g) cups cooked brown rice\n1 1/4 cups (150g) diced yellow onions\n1 1/4 (115g) cups shredded mozzarella cheese\n3/4 cup (80g) corn kernels (fresh or frozen)\n1 1/2 teaspoons Cajun seasoning\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1 teaspoon sea salt\n1/2 teaspoon paprika\n5 to 6 large bell peppers\nSpecial Equipment:\n4- to 6-quart slow cooker, though any size will work as long as the peppers will stand upright\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Mix the filling: In a large bowl, mix the ground beef, cooked rice, onions, 3/4 cup of the mozzarella cheese, corn, Cajun seasoning, oregano, sea salt and paprika together. The beef can be a bit difficult to break apart in the beginning. Using a fork can help. Set filling aside (or cover and refrigerate for up to 24 hours).\n2 Prepare the peppers: Slice off the tops of the bell peppers. You don\xe2\x80\x99t need to cut off a lot; just enough to get the stem off. Remove the seeds and membrane from the insides of the peppers. The peppers should look like little cups that are ready for stuffing.\n3 Stuff each pepper with beef and rice filling. Carefully place each stuffed pepper into the slow cooker. Cover the pot.\n(The stuffed peppers can also be covered and refrigerated for up to 24 hours before cooking.)\n4 Set the slow cooker on low and cook for 4 to 5 hours. The peppers are done when the meat is cooked through. About 10 minutes before the peppers are done, sprinkle the remaining cheese on top of the peppers and close the lid.\n5 Drain excess liquid and serve: Carefully remove peppers from the slow cooker. Some of your peppers may have filled with some liquid. That\xe2\x80\x99s perfectly normal. I like to gently tip the peppers over to drain the excess liquid before serving. Be careful when doing this, as the peppers may still be quite hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nCajun Turkey Pot Pie Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hour, 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nYou can make the turkey pot pie either in individual ramekins or in one large casserole dish.\nINGREDIENTS\nFilling:\n5 Tbsp peanut oil or unsalted butter\n3 celery stalks, chopped\n1 1/2 cups chopped yellow or white onion\n1 large green pepper, chopped\n1-2 jalapeno peppers, chopped\n4 garlic cloves, minced\n3 cups diced, cooked turkey meat\n2 Tbsp Cajun seasoning*\nSalt\n1/3 cup all-purpose flour\n2 1/2 cups turkey or chicken stock\n1 cup dark beer (brown ale or Guinness)\n1 cup diced tomatoes\nPie Crust:\n1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) chilled unsalted butter, diced into 1/2-inch cubes\n3 to 4 Tbsp chilled ice water\nEgg Wash:\n1 egg yolk\n1 Tbsp cream\n*If you can't find Cajun seasoning in your local market, you can make your own with 3/4 teaspoon each of salt, pepper, dried oregano, dried thyme, and 1 1/2 teaspoons each of paprika, garlic powder, and onion powder.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the pie crust dough: Pulse the flour and salt together in a food processor. Add the chilled butter cubes to the food processor and pulse 5 times. The dough should resemble a coarse cornmeal, with some pea-sized pieces of butter.\nSlowly add the chilled water (make sure there are no small ice cube bits), just a tablespoon at a time, pulsing once after each addition, until the dough just sticks together when you press some between your fingers.\n \n  Empty the food processor, placing the dough mixture on a clean surface. Use the heel of your palm to shmoosh the dough mixture onto the table surface a few times. This action will help flatten and spread the butter between layers of flour, so that the resulting dough will be flaky.\nOnce you've done this a few (5 or 6) times, use your hands to mold the dough into a disk. Sprinkle the disk with a little flour, wrap it in plastic wrap, and let it chill for an hour, or up to 2 days, before rolling out.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, celery, green pepper, jalape\xc3\xb1o: Heat the oil over medium-high heat and saut\xc3\xa9 the onion, celery, green pepper and jalape\xc3\xb1o, stirring often, until they are soft, about 6-8 minutes.\n3 Add the garlic, turkey meat, Cajun seasoning, and salt. Mix well and cook another 1 minute, stirring once or twice.\n4 Finish making the filling: Bring the stock and beer to a boil in a small pot. Sprinkle the flour over the turkey and veggies and mix well. Cook for 4-5 minutes, stirring often and making sure no flour burns on the bottom of the pan.\nSlowly pour in the hot stock-beer mixture, stirring. It will seize up at first, then, as you pour in more stock and stir, will form a silky sauce for the turkey.\nAdd the tomatoes and cook until the mixture thickens, about 3-5 minutes.\nPour the filling into a 2-quart casserole or, if you wish, into individual ramekins.\n5 Prepare the crust: Roll dough out on a lightly floured surface to a little less than a quarter-inch thick. If you are using a casserole, roll into a sheet a little larger than the dish.\nIf you are using ramekins (use 10 ounce ramekins), cut the dough into 6 rounds that are slightly larger than the circumference of the ramekins.\n6 Top the filling with the crust dough: Lay the dough onto the filling. Fold the excess dough under itself and use the tines of a fork to press the dough against the edge of the ramekins. Cut a 1-inch vent into each individual pie, or several if you are making a casserole.\n7 Brush with egg wash: Whisk together in a small bowl the egg yolk and cream for an egg wash. Use a pastry brush to paint the egg wash over the crust. This will help the crust brown nicely.\n8 Bake: Bake at 400\xc2\xb0F for 25 minutes, or until the pastry is golden and the filling is bubbling. Let cool for at least 5 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nPerfect Cheesecake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 40 minutesChilling time: 4 hours or overnightYield: Makes 16 servings\nRecipe adapted from Dorie Greenspan's Baking: From My Home to Yours. Published with permission from author.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n1 3/4 cups (230g) of Graham cracker crumbs (from about 15 Graham crackers)\n2 Tbsp sugar\nPinch salt\n4 Tbsp plus 1 teaspoon (60g) unsalted butter (if using salted butter, omit the pinch of salt), melted\nFor the filling:\n2 pounds cream cheese (900g), room temperature\n1 1/3 cup granulated sugar (270g)\nPinch of salt\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n4 large eggs\n2/3 cup sour cream (160 ml)\n2/3 cup heavy whipping cream (160 ml)\nFor the sour cream topping:\n2 cups sour cream (475 ml)\n1/3 cup powdered sugar (35g)\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nFor the raspberry sauce:\n12 ounces (340g) fresh raspberries\n1/2 cup granulated sugar (100g)\n1/2 cup water (120 ml)\nSpecial equipment:\n9-inch, 2 3/4-inch high springform pan\nHeavy-duty, 18-inch wide aluminum foil\nA large, high-sided roasting pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nPREPARE THE CRUST\n1 Process graham crackers, mix with sugar, salt, butter: Pulse the graham crackers in a food processor or blender until finely ground. Put in a large bowl, and stir in the sugar and salt. Stir in the melted butter.\nPreheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C), with rack in lower third of oven.\n2 Press the graham cracker crumbs into the bottom of the springform pan: Gently press down on the crumbs using your fingers, until the crumbs are a nice even layer at the bottom of the pan, with maybe just a slight rise along the inside edges of the pan.\n3 Bake the crust: Place the pan on a baking sheet and bake at 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) for 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and let cool. While the crust is cooling, you can skip ahead and start on the filling. Wait until the crust has cooled to wrap the pan in foil in the next step.\n4 Triple wrap pan in heavy duty foil: Prepare the springform pan so that no water leaks into it while cooking. Place a large 18-inch by 18-inch square of heavy duty aluminum foil on a flat surface.\nPlace the springform pan in the middle of the foil. Gently fold up the sides of the foil around the pan. Make sure to do this gently so that you don't create any holes in the foil.\nIf there are any holes, water will get into the pan and ruin the crust.\nPress the foil around the edges of the pan. Place a second large square of foil underneath the pan, and repeat, gently folding up the sides of the foil around the pan and pressing the foil against the pan.\nTo be triply safe, repeat with a third layer of heavy duty foil. Gently crimp the top of the foil sheets around the top edge of the pan.\nMAKE THE CHEESECAKE\n1 Beat cream cheese, then sugar: Cut the cream cheese into chunks and place in the bowl of an electric mixer, with the paddle attachment. Mix on medium speed for 4 minutes until smooth, soft and creamy. Add the sugar, beat for 4 minutes more.\n2 Add salt, vanilla, then eggs, then sour cream: Add the salt and vanilla, beating after each addition. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating for one minute after each addition. Add the sour cream, beat until incorporated.\n3 Add the heavy cream, beat until incorporated. Remember to scrape down the sides of the mixer bowl, and scrape up any thicker bits of cream cheese that have stuck to the bottom of the mixer that paddle attachment has failed to incorporate.\n4 Prepare pan and boiling water: Place the foil-wrapped springform pan in a large, high-sided roasting pan. Prepare 2 quarts of boiling water.\nHeat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C).\n5 Pour filling into pan: Pour the cream cheese filling into the springform pan, over the graham cracker bottom layer. Smooth the top with a rubber spatula.\n6 Place in oven: Place the roasting pan with the springform pan in it, in the oven, on the lower rack.\n7 Carefully pour the hot water into the roasting pan (without touching the hot oven), to create a water bath for the cheesecake, pouring until the water reaches halfway up the side of the springform pan, about 1 1/4 inches. (Alternatively you can add the water before putting the pan in the oven, whichever is easier for you.)\n8 Bake at 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C) for 1 1/2 hours.\n9 Turn off the heat of the oven. Crack open the oven door 1-inch, and let the cake cool in the oven, as the oven cools, for another hour. This gentle cooling will help prevent the cheesecake surface from cracking.\n10 Chill 4 hours: Cover the top of the cheesecake with foil, so that it doesn't actually touch the cheesecake. Chill in the refrigerator for a minimum of 4 hours, or overnight.\nFINISH AND SERVE THE CHEESECAKE\n1 Prepare the sour cream topping: Place sour cream in a medium sized bowl, stir in the powdered sugar and vanilla, until smooth. Chill until you are ready to serve the cake.\nNote that this recipe produces enough sour cream topping for a thick topping and some extra to spoon over individual pieces of cheesecake, if desired. If you would like a thinner layer of topping and no extra, reduce the sour cream topping ingredients in half.\n2 Prepare the raspberry sauce: Place raspberries, sugar, and water in a small saucepan. Use a potato masher to mash the raspberries. Heat on medium, whisking, about 5 minutes, until the sauce begins to thicken. Remove from heat. Let cool.\n3 Prepare the cheesecake to serve: Remove the cake from the refrigerator. Remove the foil from the sides of the pan, and place the cake on your cake serving dish. Run the side of a blunt knife between the edge of the cake and the pan.\nDorie recommends, and we've done with success, that you use a hair dryer to heat the sides of the pan to make it easier to remove. Open the springform latch and gently open the pan and lift up the sides.\nSpread the top with the sour cream mixture. Serve plain or drizzle individual slices with raspberry sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nHow to Make Classic Tiramisu\nPrep time: 45 minutesChilling time: 8 to 24 hoursYield: About 9 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n6 large egg yolks\n1 cup (200 grams) sugar, divided\n3 ounces (6 tablespoons) dark rum, divided\n1 1/2 cups (12 oz) mascarpone cheese, cold from the fridge\n1 cup heavy whipping cream, cold from the fridge\n1 cup boiling water\n1 tablespoon instant espresso powder\n1 (7-ounce) package ladyfingers\nCocoa powder for dusting the top\nSpecial equipment:\n8x8-inch baking dish\nSaucepan and heatproof bowl, or a double-boiler\nBalloon whisk\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the dish: Lightly oil an 8x8 inch baking dish.\n2 Whisk the yolks and sugar to make the zabaglione: Set a large heatproof bowl over a pan of simmering water to create a double boiler (the bowl should rest on the rim of the pan and the bottom should not touch the surface of the water).\nWhisk together the egg yolks and 3/4 cup of the sugar in the bowl. Continue whisking until the sugar has dissolved, the mixture has increased slightly in volume, and it looks light yellow color. Not sure? Rub a little of the mixture between two fingers (it will be warm, but not too hot to touch) \xe2\x80\x93 it should feel smooth and silky; if you feel any sugar granules, keep whisking.\n3 Add in the rum: Gradually whisk in 2 ounces (4 tablespoons) of the rum and continue whisking rapidly over the double boiler for about 10 minutes, until the mixture is thick, foamy, and very pale yellow. (You can also use a hand mixer for this step, if you prefer.)\nRemove the bowl from the double boiler and set aside until cooled to at least 90F or room temperature.\n4 Whip the mascarpone and cream: You can use either a hand mixer or a stand mixer with a whisk attachment for this step. If using a stand mixer, be very attentive and do not walk away while the mascarpone is whipping. Stand mixers are so powerful, that it's easy to overwhip, which causes the mascarpone to separate. You have a little more wiggle room with a hand mixer.\nWith a hand mixer or in the bowl of a stand mixer with a whisk attachment, beat the mascarpone on medium speed for 15 to 30 seconds, until it smooths out and softens. Be careful not to over-beat or else the mascarpone will separate and become grainy.\nWith the mixer still on medium speed, gradually add the cream in a thin, slow stream until it's all incorporated. This should take 1 to 2 minutes. Stop the mixer and scrape down the bowl. Continue beating with the mixer on medium-high speed for another 30 to 60 seconds, until the mixture holds firm, not-quite-stiff peaks.\n5 Mix the whipped cream and the zabaglione: Fold 1/3 of the whipped cream into the zabaglione to lighten it, then fold in the remaining whipped cream.\n6 Make the coffee dipping liquid for the ladyfingers: In a wide, shallow dish, whisk the remaining 1/4 cup sugar with the remaining 1 ounce (2 tablespoons) of rum, the boiling water, and the espresso powder. Stir to dissolve the sugar and espresso.\n7 Assemble the tiramisu: Dunk one ladyfinger at a time in the espresso liquid, turning it so that all sides are evenly moistened \xe2\x80\x93 a quick dunk is all you need; any more and the ladyfingers start to disintegrate. Arrange the dunked ladyfingers in rows on the bottom of the baking dish.\nOnce you finish the layer, spread 1/2 of the mascarpone mixture over the top. Repeat dunking and arranging a second layer, and spread the remaining mascarpone over top.\n8 Chill the tiramisu: Cover the tiramisu and refrigerate for at least 8 hours or up to 24 hours to give the tiramisu time to firm up and for the ladyfingers to soften.\n9 Serve: Dust with cocoa before serving. Serve in wedges directly from the pan. Leftovers will keep for about 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nFlourless Lemon Almond Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 8\nIt helps to separate the eggs first, while they are cold, and then let them sit to come to room temperature as you prep the other ingredients.  Eggs are easier to separate when cold, and they perform better as leavening agents when at room temperature.\nWhen whipping egg whites, make sure your equipment is perfectly clean. Any fat (or even bits of egg yolk in the whites) can keep the egg whites from properly whipping up.\nIf almond flour is not available at your market, you can grind up blanched, slivered almonds in a food processor until very finely ground.  I would start with a little more than 1 1/3 cups. Our local Whole Foods carries a Bob's Red Mill brand of finely ground blanched almond flour which is what we used for this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 eggs (large), separated into 4 egg yolks and 4 egg whites, room temperature (see how to separate eggs)\n2 Tbsp lemon zest, packed\n1/2 cup (100 g) white sugar, divided 1/4 cup (50 g) and 1/4 cup (50 g)\n1 1/2 cup lightly scooped (144 g) finely ground blanched almond flour\n1 teaspoon baking powder (make sure your baking powder is fresh!)\n1/4 teaspoon ground cardamom\n1 teaspoon white or cider vinegar\nPinch of salt\nPowdered sugar for sprinkling\nSpecial equipment:\n8 or 9-inch springform pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven, prepare pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175 \xc2\xb0C).  Place a round of parchment paper on the bottom of a 8 or 9-inch springform pan, and grease it and the sides of the pan with butter or cooking spray.\n2 Beat egg yolks, lemon zest, 1/4 cup sugar: In a large bowl, beat together with a wooden spoon the egg yolks, lemon zest, and 1/4 cup sugar until smooth.\n3 Whisk almond flour, baking powder, cardamom, beat into egg yolk mixture: In a separate bowl, whisk together the almond flour, ground cardamom, and baking powder. Add the flour mixture to the egg yolk mixture and beat until well combined. The mixture should resemble a thick paste.\n4 Whip egg whites to soft peaks: With an electric mixer with a very clean bowl and clean whisk attachment, beat the egg whites, starting on low speed and gradually increasing the speed.\nWhen bubbles start to form, add a pinch of salt and the teaspoon of vinegar (both the salt and the vinegar will help the beaten egg whites maintain better structure, as will the sugar in the next step).\nAs the egg whites begin to increase in volume, sprinkle in the remaining 1/4 cup of sugar, a little at a time, as you continue to beat the egg whites. Beat until soft peaks form.\n5 Fold beaten egg whites into almond mixture: Stir a third to a half of the beaten egg whites into the almond mixture to loosen it and make it lighter.\nThen gently fold the remaining whipped egg whites into the batter, a large scoopful at a time.\n6 Scoop batter into pan, bake: Gently scoop the batter into the prepared springform pan and place in the oven. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F (175 \xc2\xb0C) for 30 minutes.\nRemove from the oven and let cool. Run a sharp knife around the edge of the cake helping it to separate from the side of the pan.\nRelease the springform pan sides, and gently move the cake (on parchment) to a cake serving plate. Sprinkle with a little powdered sugar before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nTexas Sheet Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 36 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cake:\n2 cups (8.8 ounces) all-purpose flour\n2 cups (14 ounces) granulated sugar\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (8 ounces) unsalted butter\n1 cup water\n1/4 cup (1 ounce) natural unsweetened cocoa powder\n1/2 cup buttermilk\n2 large eggs\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\nFor the frosting:\n3/4 cup (6 ounces) unsalted butter\n5 tablespoons natural cocoa powder\n1/2 cup milk, whole or 2 percent\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nPinch of kosher salt\n3 cups (15 ounces) powdered sugar, sifted\n1 cup chopped pecans (4.5 ounces)\nSpecial equipment:\nHalf-sheet pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prep the pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Spray or butter a half-sheet pan (13x18 inches) and line the bottom with parchment.\n2 Combine the dry ingredients: Whisk the flour, sugar, and salt together in a large mixing bowl.\n3 Make the batter: In a saucepan over medium-low heat, combine the butter, water, and cocoa powder. Whisk until melted and smooth, and then bring to a simmer. Once simmering, remove from the heat.\nUsing a whisk or electric mixer, beat the hot cocoa mixture into the dry ingredients until combined. Beat in the buttermilk, eggs, and vanilla, followed by the baking soda, until combined.\n  4 Bake the cake: Spread the batter into the prepared pan and bake for 25 to 28 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.\nRemove from the oven and set the pan on a wire rack to cool briefly, about 5 to 10 minutes, while you make the frosting.\n5 Frost the cake: As soon as the cake is done baking and on the cooling rack, combine the butter, cocoa, and milk for the frosting together in a saucepan and bring to a boil. Remove from the heat and stir in the salt and vanilla. Beat in the powdered sugar with an electric mixer or by hand.\nPour the hot frosting over the still-warm cake and spread evenly. Sprinkle the top with chopped pecans or other topping.\nAllow to set, then serve immediately or cool completely and cover to serve later. You can also wrap the cake well in foil or plastic wrap and freeze.\n   Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nCranberry Upside Down Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Serves 8 to 10\nBaking times will vary, depending on the brand of flour, size of pan, thickness of sour cream. The batter should be gloppy, not runny, so add a little more flour to get to gloppy if your batter is too thin.\nSome readers have needed to cook this cake longer than the baking times indicated, so definitely test before turning out!\nINGREDIENTS\nTopping\n3/4 cup firmly packed brown sugar\n4 Tbsp (1/4 cup or 1/2 stick) unsalted butter\n12 ounces fresh or frozen cranberries\nCake\n1 3/4 cups all purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger\n1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon\nScant pinch ground cloves\n1/2 cup (1 stick) butter, room temp (plus more for buttering the pan)\n1 1/2 cups white granulated sugar\n3 large eggs\n1 Tbsp orange zest\n1/2 cup sour cream (or greek yogurt)\n1/4 cup of milk\nEquipment\nA 9-inch cake pan with at least 2-inch high sides\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Butter a 9-inch cake pan: Generously butter the bottom and sides of a 9-inch diameter cake pan.\n2 Make caramel topping with brown sugar and butter: In a small saucepan, place the 1/4 cup of butter and the 3/4 cups of packed brown sugar. On medium high heat, stir the sugar as the butter melts. Once the butter is melted and mixed in well with the sugar, stop stirring and let the mixture simmer for 15 seconds or so.\n3 Pour brown sugar mixture into cake pan and top with cranberries: Pour the brown sugar butter mixture into the prepared cake pan. Spread the cranberries on top of the sugar butter mixture.\n4 Whisk together flour, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, ginger, cloves: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. In a medium bowl vigorously whisk together the flour, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, ground ginger, and ground cloves.\n5 Beat butter, add sugar, add eggs, stir in zest: In a separate bowl, use an electric mixer to beat the butter until light. Add the sugar and beat together the sugar and butter until fluffy.\nAdd the eggs one at a time, beating after each addition. Stir in the orange zest.\n6 Alternate adding sour flour mixture and sour cream, then add milk: Mix a third of the dry ingredients into the mixture. Beat in half of the sour cream. Mix in another third of the dry ingredients.  Mix in the remaining sour cream. Beat in the remaining dry ingredients and then the milk.\n7 Pour batter into cake pan and bake: Pour batter over the cranberries in the cake pan, and smooth the surface.\nPlace in the preheated oven and lower the heat from 350\xc2\xb0F to 325\xc2\xb0F. Bake until a tester comes out with just a few moist crumbs, and pressing down on the surface bounces back, 55 minutes to an hour.\n8 Cool cake in pan, run knife around edge, turn over onto a serving plate: Cool cake in the pan on a rack for 10 minutes.\nRun a blunt knife around the inside rim of the cake pan to loosen the cake from the sides of the pan. Then turn the cake out onto a platter.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nChocolate Peppermint Swiss Roll Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 20 minutesCooling and Chilling time: 1 1/2 to 2 hoursYield: 10 to 12 servings\nFor this recipe, you\'ll need a clean kitchen towel on hand. Cocoa powder and cake crumbs can stain, so make sure it\'s one you won\'t mind getting dirty.\nOnce the ganache is added, the cake is best served the day it is made (the ganache won\'t look as pretty the second day). Leftover cake that doesn\'t get devoured can be stored, covered, in the fridge for several days.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the Chocolate Sponge Cake:\n1/3 cup all-purpose flour\n1/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder, plus extra for rolling the cake\n1/8 teaspoon kosher salt\n6 large eggs\n2/3 cup sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted and cooled (but still liquid)\nFor the Peppermint Whipped Cream:\n1 1/4 cups heavy whipping cream\n2 tablespoons sugar\n1 teaspoon peppermint extract\nFor the Ganache and Peppermint Topping:\n1/2 cup heavy cream\n4 ounces bittersweet chocolate, chopped, divided\n1 teaspoon light corn syrup\n1/4 cup crushed peppermint candies or candy canes\nSpecial Equipment:\nStandard half-sheet pan or baking sheet with a rim (approximately 13x17)\nOffset spatula\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 450F. Position a baking rack in the center of the oven.\n2 Prepare the baking sheet: Spray a 13 x 17-inch rimmed baking sheet with cooking spray, line bottom with parchment paper, then spray again and dust with cocoa powder, tapping out any excess. Set aside.\n3 Sift together the flour, cocoa powder, and salt for the cake. Set aside.\n4 Warm the eggs and sugar: Make a double boiler by filling a medium saucepan with 2 inches of water, and brining the water to a gentle simmer over medium heat. Combine the eggs, sugar, and vanilla extract in the bowl of a stand mixer, or another large heatproof bowl, and set this bowl over the simmering water. The bowl should be larger than the pan and sit above the surface of the simmering water.\nBegin whisking the eggs, sugar, and vanilla extract with a sturdy whisk. Continue whisking until the sugar has dissolved and the egg mixture is pale and warm to the touch. Remove from heat.\n5 Beat the egg mixture until tripled in volume: Using a stand mixer with a whisk attachment or a hand mixer, beat egg mixture on high speed until mixture is very pale , has a shiny gloss, and has nearly tripled in volume. This will take 5 to 10 minutes depending your mixer.\n6 Fold the flour and cocoa mixture into the egg mixture in two batches: Sprinkle half of the flour and cocoa mixture over the surface of the eggs, and gently fold until just barely combined. Sprinkle the remaining flour and cocoa mixture over the top and fold until you see no more dry streaks and the mixture looks uniform.\n7 Drizzle the melted, cooled butter into the batter. Stir to combine.\n8 Working quickly, spoon mixture out onto prepared baking sheet. Use an offset spatula to spread batter out evenly.\n9 Bake for 6 to 7 minutes, or until cake has pulled away from sides and is springy to the touch. Cool cake 2 for 3 minutes, but no longer.\n10 While the cake is baking, prepare the kitchen towel for rolling: Find a clean kitchen towel that is larger than your baking sheet (or use two, overlapping). Dust it all over with cocoa powder.\n11 Roll the cake in the kitchen towel: With swift, confident motions, run a knife along the outside edge of the cake pan. Set the pan on its side, and then flip face down onto the dusted towel. Carefully lift the pan up and away, and peel away parchment.\nFold an edge of towel over one of the shorter sides of the cake, and gently roll the cake up. Set rolled cake on a wire rack and cool completely, an hour or longer.\n12 Make the whipped cream filling: Whip the heavy cream until is billowy, then add the sugar and peppermint extract. Continue whipping until the cream just barely holds firm peaks; be careful not to overwhip.\n13 Fill the cake with whipped cream: Gently unroll cake on a clean surface. Spread the whipped cream filling evenly over the cake, leaving a 1-inch border on all sides. Roll the cake back up again (this time without the towel!). If any whipped cream squeezes out as you roll, spoon it up and add it back in.\n14 Chill the cake: Wrap cake roll in parchment, then plastic wrap, and set in fridge to chill at least 30 minutes to set, or as long as overnight.\n15 When ready to finish the cake, make the ganache: Make a double boiler by filling a medium saucepan with 2 inches of water, and bringing the water to a gentle simmer over medium heat. Set a larger bowl on top of the saucepan, over the water.\nAdd the heavy cream, two-thirds of the chopped chocolate, and a pinch salt to the bowl. Stir until melted. Remove the bowl from heat, and stir in remaining chocolate and corn syrup.\n16 Drizzle the cake with ganache: Unwrap the chilled cake and set it on a platter seem-side down. Slip two pieces of parchment on either side of the "log" to catch the drips. Drizzle the prepared ganache over roll until roll is completely covered. Remove the parchment paper "drip catchers." Scatter the peppermint candy bits on the top.\n17 Chill and serve: Set the cake in the fridge and chill 20 minutes. Slice and serve!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nPumpkin Cheesecake Recipe\nYield: Makes 16 servings\nYou can make your own pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e by cutting a sugar pumpkin in half, scooping out the seeds, placing the pumpkin halves cut-side down in a roasting pan with a 1/4 inch of water in it, and cooking it in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for an hour, until soft. Scoop out the flesh and pur\xc3\xa9e it in a blender or food processor. Strain out excess water.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n1 cup pecans\n1/2 cup all-purpose flour\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n1/2 cup graham cracker crumbs (approximately 4 graham crackers)\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened\n1 egg yolk\nFor the filling:\n2 15-ounce cans pumpkin puree (see Recipe Note)\n3 tablespoons all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger\n1/4 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg\n1/4 teaspoon ground allspice\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n2 tablespoons vanilla extract\n2 tablespoons bourbon or other whiskey\n5 large eggs\n4 8-ounce packages cream cheese, room temperature\n2 cups (1 pound) brown sugar\nSpecial equipment:\n1 9-inch diameter, 3-inch tall springform pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make graham cracker pecan crust: Pulse pecans, flour, brown sugar, and graham cracker crumbs in a food processor. Add butter and egg yolk. Pulse until mixture is homogenous. Press into bottom of 9\xe2\x80\x9d springform pan and bake for 10 minutes at 375\xc2\xb0F. Remove from oven and let cool.\n2 Drain or strain any liquid from pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e. Take pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e and place on several layers of paper towels. Cover with several layers of paper towels and use your hands to gently squeeze out liquid from the pur\xc3\xa9e.\nNote that you will probably go through a lot of paper towels (can use tea towels too). Two 15-ounce cans of pur\xc3\xa9ed pumpkin should yield a little more than 2 cups of pur\xc3\xa9e, with the excess moisture removed. You want exactly 2 cups of the pur\xc3\xa9e.\n3 Mix spices with pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e, bourbon, eggs: Whisk together the flour, cinnamon, ground ginger, grated nutmeg, and allspice in a medium bowl. With a wooden spoon (no need for a mixer for this step), mix in the salt, pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e, vanilla, and bourbon. Beat in the eggs, one at a time.\n4 Mix cream cheese with brown sugar, add pumpkin mixture: In a large bowl, (helps to use a mixer for this step) combine the cream cheese and the brown sugar until fully creamed and smooth (no lumps). Gradually add the pumpkin mixture until fully incorporated. Bring a kettle of water to a boil.\n5 Line pan with 3 layers of thick foil: Place crust-baked springform pan in the middle of three layers of large sheets of heavy duty aluminum foil (to help prevent water-bath moisture from leaking into the pan). Fold the aluminum foil up the sides of the pan and trim. (You can also use a turkey roasting bag instead of the foil to keep the water out.)\n6 Pour filling into pan: Place the aluminum wrapped pan in a large roasting pan (large enough so that there is room on all sides). Pour the pumpkin cream cheese mixture into the springform pan.\n7 Pour hot water into roasting pan to create water bath: Place the roasting pan containing the springform pan in a 325\xc2\xb0F oven on the middle rack. Pour boiling water into the pan so that it comes halfway up the side of the springform pan.\n8 Cook for 1 1/2 hours. Turn off the oven heat and prop the oven door open. Let the cheesecake sit in the oven, cooling for another hour. Then remove from oven and let come to room temperature. Once it has cooled down, chill for several hours in the refrigerator, preferably overnight.\n9 When ready to serve, gently remove the cake from the springform pan.\nTo do this well, I recommend a tip by Dorie Greenspan in her book Baking: From My Home to Yours. To help ensure that the cake doesn't stick to the springform side as you unlock it, first run a blunt knife around the cake and then warm the sides of the pan with a hair dryer. Then carefully unlock the springform and lift off the sides.\nServe cheesecake with caramel sauce, candied pecans, and whipped cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nPersimmon Pudding Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups of ripe Hachiya persimmon pulp\n1/2 cup sugar\n4 eggs\n1/2 cup butter (1 stick), melted\n3/4 cups milk\n1 teaspoon vanilla\n1 1/2 cups flour\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg\n1 teaspoon ground ginger\n1 teaspoon ground allspice\n1 cup chopped nuts - pecans or walnuts\nWhipping cream\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. In a large bowl, mix the persimmon pulp, sugar, eggs, butter, milk and vanilla.\n2 In a separate bowl vigorously whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and spices.\n3 Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, a third at a time, fully incorporating after each addition. Add the chopped nuts.\n4 Bake in an 8-inch square glass pan, buttered, at 400\xc2\xb0F until done (about 50 minutes).\nTop with a dollop of whipped cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBanana Sheet Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 30 pieces\nHere's a tip, leave the cream cheese and butter for the frosting out while you make the banana cake, that way they will be softened by the time the cake is cooled and ready to frost. This banana cake is on the sweet side (it is a cake after all).\nIf you are trying to cut sugars, you may want to experiment dropping the sugar in the cake mixture by a half cup and cutting the amount of frosting in half.\nINGREDIENTS\nCake\n2 cups all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n1 teaspoon cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter\n1 cup white granulated sugar\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n2 eggs\nThe scraped insides of one vanilla bean, or 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract\n1 cup of mashed ripe bananas (2 large or 3 medium bananas)\n1/2 cup full fat sour cream\nFrosting\n6 ounces cream cheese, room temp\n4 Tbsp (1/4 cup) unsalted butter, room temp\n2 cups powdered sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) . In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt.\n2 Beat together in a mixer the butter and sugars. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Mix in the vanilla and mashed bananas.\n3 Mix in half of the flour mixture, then the sour cream, then the other half of the flour mixture.\n4 Spread batter evenly in a greased 10x15 baking pan. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) for 20 minutes, or until nicely browned and the surface bounces back when you press it with your finger. Cool completely before frosting.\n5 To make the frosting, mix all of the ingredients together with an electric mixer. If too stiff to spread, add a teaspoon or two of water. Spread the frosting evenly over the cake and slice to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nGrandma\xe2\x80\x99s Zucchini Cake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Makes about 20 pieces.\nThe frosting amount assumes that you are going to keep the cake in the pan and only frost the top. If you plan on removing the cake from the pan and frosting the sides, you'll want to up the frosting amounts.\nINGREDIENTS\nCake:\n2 cups flour\n2 teaspoons cinnamon (can sub 1 teaspoon with other spices such as allspice and nutmeg, go easy on the cloves though)\n2 teaspoons baking soda\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon baking powder\n3 eggs\n2 cups white, granulated sugar\n1 cup vegetable oil\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon grated lemon zest (optional, my addition)\n2 cups (from about 3-4 regular sized zucchini) grated un-peeled zucchini (place grated zucchini in a sieve and press out some of the excess moisture before measuring)\n1 cup chopped walnuts or pecans (my grandmother recommends black walnuts)\n1/2 cup golden raisins (optional)\nFrosting:\n3 ounces cream cheese, softened to room temperature (Philadelphia cream cheese recommended)\n1/4 cup butter, room temperature\n1 1/2 to 2 cups of powdered sugar\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Butter a 9x12 or 9x13 baking pan (I used a pyrex pan).\n2 In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, cinnamon, baking soda, salt, and baking powder. Set aside.\n3 In a mixer, beat the 3 eggs on high speed until frothy. Lower the speed and beat in the sugar, vegetable oil, vanilla, and lemon zest (if using). Stir in the flour mixture, a third at a time. Stir in the zucchini and chopped nuts and/or raisins.\n4 Pour mixture into a 9x12 or 9x13 baking pan. Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 40 to 45 minutes. (My grandmother's notes say you can also bake in an angel food pan for 1 hour.) Remove from oven and let cool completely before frosting. (While the cake is cooling, let the frosting's cream cheese and butter sit at room temperature to soften.)\n5 To make the frosting, beat together the cream cheese and butter. Add the powdered sugar and beat until smooth.\nFrost the cake and serve. Store covered with aluminum foil.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nGerman Chocolate Snack Cake With Coconut-Pecan Frosting Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 10 to 12 servings (1 9x13 cake)\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cake:\n2 cups (280 grams) all-purpose flour\n1/4 cup (21 grams) unsweetened cocoa powder\n1 teaspoon baking powder\n1/2 teaspoon baking soda\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup boiling water\n4 ounces unsweetened baking chocolate\n1/2 teaspoon espresso powder, optional (for deeper chocolate flavor)\n2 cups (400 grams) granulated sugar\n4 large eggs\n1 cup canola oil\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\nFor the coconut pecan frosting:\n3 large egg yolks\n8 ounces evaporated milk\n1 1/2 cups (323 grams) lightly packed brown sugar\n4 ounces (113 grams, 1 stick) unsalted butter\n1 teaspoon vanilla\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 1/2 cups sweetened, shredded coconut\n1 1/2 cups chopped pecans\nSpecial equipment:\n9x13-inch baking dish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the oven and pan: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan.\n2 Combine the dry ingredients: Sift the flour, cocoa, baking powder, soda, and salt into a large mixing bowl.\n3 Make the batter: In a measuring cup combine the boiling water, chocolate, and espresso. Cover and let the hot water melt the chocolate, about 10 minutes, and whisk until smooth. Check the water with your finger; it's fine if it's still a little warm, but it should no longer be hot to the touch.\nIn a separate bowl (or in your measuring cup, if it's large enough), combine chocolate-water with the sugar, eggs, oil, and vanilla extract. Whisk to combine.\nPour the chocolate mixture into the flour mixture and beat, using a stand mixer or a hand mixer, until just combined. Stop periodically and scrape the bottom of the bowl.\n4 Bake the cake: Spread the batter into the pan and bake for 25 to 35 minutes or until the top springs back to the touch, the sides of the cake have pulled slightly away from the pan, and a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.\nLeave the cake in the pan, and set it on a wire rack to cool completely before frosting, about 45 minutes.\n5 Make the frosting: Whisk together the egg yolks, evaporated milk, and brown sugar in a saucepan. Add the butter and warm over medium-high heat, stirring constantly until the mixture thickens, about 10 minutes. Remove from the heat and stir in the vanilla and salt, followed by the coconut and pecans.\nThe frosting should be thick, creamy, and nubbly with coconut and pecans.\n6 Finish the cake: Cool the frosting to room temperature and spread generously onto the cake. Serve the cake from the pan.\nThe cake can be made a few days ahead, but wait to top it with the coconut-pecan frosting until before serving. This cake is best served the same day it's frosted.
