b'Save It Print\nTuna and Tomato Pasta Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nTuna packed in olive oil is highly recommended for this recipe. If all you have is tuna packed in water, you can try draining it and then adding olive oil to the can, and letting it soak in the olive oil in the fridge for several hours, but you will get the best results if you start with tuna packed in oil.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1 28-ounce can of tomatoes, whole or crushed\nSalt\n1 pound pasta shells\n1/2 cup ricotta cheese\n1 6-ounce can tuna packed in olive oil\n1/4 cup fresh basil, chopped or torn\nA generous 1/2 cup grated parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Simmer tomatoes with butter 30 min: Melt the butter in a medium pot on medium heat and add the can of tomatoes, including the juice. If you are using whole canned tomatoes (or fresh ones) crush them with your (clean) fingers as you put them in the pot. Simmer gently, partially covered, for 30 minutes.\n2 Cook pasta: While the sauce is cooking, heat a large pot of well salted water to a strong boil. Add the shell pasta to the boiling water and cook at a vigorous boil, uncovered, until al dente, cooked through but still a bit firm to the bite, which is usually whatever the time specified on the pasta package minus about 2 minutes. Drain and set aside.\n3 Combine tuna, tomato sauce, ricotta, pasta, basil: Pour off the excess oil from the tuna can and stir the tuna into the tomato sauce. Add the ricotta cheese, and add salt to taste. Turn off the heat. Mix the sauce with the pasta in a large bowl. Mix in the basil.\n4 Put into casserole, top with parmesan, broil: Pour the pasta into a 2 to 3-quart casserole dish and top with the parmesan cheese. Put under a hot broiler for 4-6 minutes, until the cheese is melted and lightly browned. Serve hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nMediterranean Tuna Pasta Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n2 5-ounce cans of albacore tuna (preferably packed in olive oil), drained*\n1 tomato, cored, cut in half crosswise and squeezed of excess juice, chopped (about 1 cup)\n1/4 cup pitted, kalamata olives, coarsely chopped\n1/4 cup chopped red onion\n2 Tbsp chopped parsley\n1 Tbsp capers, coarsely chopped\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\n2 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil (more if you are using tuna packed in water)\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nPinch of freshly ground black pepper\n3/4 pound fusilli pasta, dry\n1 cup grated Mozzarella cheese\n*If you are using a good quality brand of canned tuna, packed in good quality olive oil, there is no need to drain. The oil is highly flavored. If you question the quality of the olive oil, drain it, and add back the same amount of your own good quality olive oil (about 2 Tbsp, listed in the ingredients).\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Put pasta water on to boil: Heat 2 quarts of salted water (1 Tbsp kosher salt), to a boil. While heating the pasta water, prep  the ingredients.\n2 Stir drained tuna with tomato, olives, onion, parsley, capers, lemon juice, olive oil, salt, pepper: Place drained tuna in a medium bowl. Stir with a fork to break up the largest chunks of tuna. Add the tomato, olives, red onion, parsley, capers, lemon juice, olive oil, salt and pepper. Stir to combine.\n3 Boil pasta until al dente: When the pasta water comes to a boil, add the pasta and boil, uncovered, on a rolling boil until al dente (cooked through, but still a little firm to the bite). Reserve 1/4 cup of the pasta water.\n4 Add pasta to tuna mixture, sprinkle with Mozz: Drain the pasta and immediately add the pasta to the tuna mixture.\nSprinkle with the grated Mozzarella cheese and stir until everything is well combined. If the pasta seems a little dry, add some of the reserved pasta water and/or some more olive oil.\nServe warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nTuna Pasta with Tomato and Olives Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4\nPrep the ingredients while the pasta water is heating. If you are subbing onions for the shallots, mince them and let them cook a few minutes before adding the garlic and red pepper flakes.\nIf you are using water-packed, not oil-packed tuna, add a couple more tablespoons of olive oil to the sauce. You may also want to add a minced anchovy.\nINGREDIENTS\n12 ounces short pasta (shells, macaroni, rigatoni)\nSalt for pasta water\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil (plus 2 Tbsp if you are using tuna packed in water)\n1/4 cup chopped shallots (can sub onion)\n2  teaspoons minced garlic\n1/2 teaspoon red pepper flakes\n2 5-ounce cans tuna packed in olive oil, drained\n1 14-ounce can crushed tomatoes\n1/4 cup chopped kalamata olives\n1 teaspoon capers\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n1/4 teaspoon salt (more to taste)\n1/4 cup shredded Parmesan\n1 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Bring pasta water to a boil: Bring 4 quarts of salted water to a boil (add 1 Tbsp salt for every 2 quarts of water). While the water is heating, prep the ingredients and start the sauce.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 shallots, garlic, red pepper flakes: Heat 3 Tbsp of olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Once the oil is hot, add the chopped shallots, minced garlic, and red pepper flakes at the same time to the pan. Let cook for about 30 seconds.\n3 Add drained canned tuna: Drain the canned tuna and add it to the pan. If you are using tuna packed in water and not olive oil, add 2 or 3 more Tbsp of olive oil to the pan.\nBreak up any chunks of tuna with a fork or wooden spoon. Let simmer for a minute.\n4 Add tomatoes, olives, capers, salt, pepper: Stir in the crushed tomatoes, olives, capers, salt, and pepper.\nBring to a simmer and reduce heat to the lowest setting to gently cook while you cook the pasta.\n5 Cook pasta: Add dry pasta to the pot of boiling salted water. Cook uncovered at a vigorous full boil until al dente\xe2\x80\x94cooked, but still a little firm to the bite, about 13-14 minutes.\nBefore draining, remove a cup of the pasta water and set aside.\n6 Stir cooked pasta into sauce: Drain the pasta and stir into the sauce. Toss with grated Parmesan and chopped fresh parsley. If the pasta seems a little dry after a few minutes, add back in some of the reserved pasta water.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nTuna Macaroni Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4\nTuna packed in olive oil is more flavorful than tuna packed in water. If you can find it packed in oil, use that but don't drain it. If you have tuna packed in water, drain it, and add 2 to 3 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the pasta:\n1 cup uncooked elbow macaroni\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 quart water\nFor the salad:\n1/2 cup chopped green onion, including green onion greens\n1 cup chopped red, orange, or yellow bell pepper\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\n2 (5-ounce) cans tuna, packed in olive oil (if it's packed in water, drain and add 2 to 3 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil)\n2 stalks celery, chopped (about 1 cup)\n2 tablespoons lemon juice\n1/4-1/3 a head lettuce (preferably iceberg lettuce), sliced first and roughly chopped into 2 inch long strips\n1/4 cup mayonnaise (more to taste)\n1/2 teaspoon sweet Hungarian paprika\nFresh ground pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the macaroni: In a saucepan, add 1 cup of elbow macaroni to 1 quart of boiling water with an added teaspoon of salt. Cook at a rolling boil uncovered for about 10 minutes until the macaroni is just a little more cooked than al dente.\nRemove from heat, drain, and rinse with cold water.\n2 Prep the salad ingredients: While the macaroni is cooking, assemble the other ingredients. In a large bowl mix the green onion, bell peppers, parsley, tuna, celery and lemon.\n3 Combine the salad ingredients: Add the cooked and drained macaroni. Fold in the mayonnaise until well mixed. Add the paprika. Add fresh ground pepper to taste. (At this point you can make ahead and chill.)\n4 Serve: Fold in the lettuce gently and serve. The salad does not make good leftovers as the lettuce will eventually get soggy.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nPasta with Tuna and Arugula Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nWhile you are heating the pasta water, prep the ingredients.\nThis recipe requires tuna canned in olive oil. Tuna canned in water just doesn't work well with this recipe. If water canned tuna is your only option, drain it, and soak it in half a cup of good quality olive oil for an hour first.\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4 pound (12 ounces) dried fettuccine, spaghetti or linguine\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n1/8 teaspoon hot red pepper flakes (more to taste)\n2 6-ounce cans tuna packed in olive oil, drained\nSalt\n5 to 8 ounces baby arugula\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook pasta: Bring a large pot of salted water (1 Tbsp salt for every 2 quarts of water) to a rolling boil. Add the pasta, return to a rolling boil, and boil uncovered until the pasta is al dente, cooked, but still a little firm to the bite.\n2 Cook garlic and red pepper flakes in olive oil; add tuna, salt: While the pasta is cooking, heat the olive oil in a large skillet on medium-low heat. Add the garlic and hot pepper flakes and cook until garlic is fragrant.\nAdd the tuna and shred it into fine flakes with a fork. Season with salt. Keep warm over low heat.\n3 Set aside a cup of pasta water: Just before the pasta is ready, set aside 1 cup of boiling water. You'll need this to add back to the pasta dish to keep it from getting too dry.\n4 Combine pasta with tuna mixture, arugula, and some pasta water: Drain the pasta and depending on the size of your pan, either add it to the skillet with the tuna, or return the pasta to the pasta pot and add the tuna mixture to the pasta.\nAdd the arugula and use tongs to toss together with the pasta and tuna. Add some of the hot reserved pasta water to help loosen the pasta.\nThe arugula will wilt as you toss the pasta and tuna with it. Add more pasta water as needed.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nTuna Burgers with Dill Olive Mayo Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 18 minutesYield: 6 burgers\nThese tuna patties taste as good on a bed of lettuce as they do on a toasted hamburger bun.\nFor the spice mix, I use Zatarain\xe2\x80\x99s Creole Seasoning, but you could use Old Bay Seasoning instead.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the dill olive mayo:\n1/3 cup mayonnaise\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh dill or 1 teaspoon dried dill\n1 tablespoon sliced green olives, minced\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\n1/2 teaspoon Creole seasoning\nFor the tuna burgers:\n1 large egg\n1/4 cup of mayonnaise\n2 (5-ounce) cans tuna in water, drained\n3/4 cup unseasoned Panko bread crumbs\n2 cloves garlic, minced or microplaned\n1/2 cup corn (frozen or fresh)\n1/2 cup finely grated carrot\n1/4 cup minced red bell pepper\n1/4 cup minced yellow onion\n3/4 teaspoon Creole seasoning\n3 tablespoons olive oil (stove top method) or cooking spray to bake\nFor the topping:\nSliced red onion (optional)\nLettuce (optional)\nHamburger buns\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dill olive mayo: In a small bowl, combine the mayonnaise, dill, olives, lemon juice, and Creole seasoning. Cover and place in refrigerator until the tuna burgers are ready to be served.\n2 Make the tuna mix: In a small bowl, use a fork to combine the egg and mayonnaise. Add the tuna and stir to combine. In a separate, medium bowl combine panko, garlic, corn, carrot, red pepper, yellow onion, and Creole seasoning.\nAdd the mayonnaise and tuna mixture to the panko mixture. Stir until well combined.\n3 Shape the patties: Use a 1/3 cup measuring cup to measure out a heaping scoop of tuna mixture and form into 6 patties.\n4 Cook the patties in the oven or on the stovetop:\nTo make in the oven: Place a large cast iron skillet in your oven, then preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. When it reaches the desired temperature, remove skillet from the oven with oven mitts. You want the skillet good and hot, which will help sear the burgers.\nSpray the inside of the skillet and both sides of the tuna burgers with cooking spray; it helps mimic that crisp edge you get when you actually fry something. Add the burgers to the skillet and return it to the oven. Bake for about 7 minutes or until the bottoms of the burgers are golden brown and crispy.\nFlip the burgers and cook until the other side is golden. This should take about 7 to 9 additional minutes.\nTo make this on the stovetop: Heat 3 tablespoons of oil in a large skillet over medium heat. When the oil begins to shimmer, add the tuna burgers to the skillet and cook on each side for about 3 to 4 minutes, until the surface is golden brown and crispy. Drain on a paper towel.\nServe on toasted hamburger buns with the dill olive mayonnaise, sliced red onion, and lettuce.\nMake-ahead instructions: Feel free to shape the patties up to 24 hours in advance. Cover with plastic wrap and keep in the fridge until ready to use. Reheat previously cooked patties by heating a teaspoon of oil in a pan over medium heat. When the oil begins to shimmer, add the patties. Flip them once and cook until they are warmed through\xe2\x80\x94about 5 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nPan Bagnat (French Tuna Sandwich) Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesPressing time: 20 minutes\nInstead of a baguette, you can also make this sandwich with one 8-inch round crusty loaf.\nIf you want to make the sandwiches a day in advance, store them in the refrigerator overnight before slicing and bring them to room temperature before eating. For extra fun, wrap each sandwich in parchment and tie with string.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 small red onion, thinly sliced\n2 hardboiled eggs, sliced\n2 anchovy fillets, finely chopped\n2 (5-ounce) cans oil-packed tuna fish\n1/4 cup pitted Nicoise or Kalamata  olives\n1 to 2 tablespoon red wine vinegar\n2 10-inch baguettes, or 1 full-sized baguette, cut in half (see Recipe Note)\n1 garlic clove, peeled\n1/4 cup olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon pepper\n2 tomatoes, sliced\n12 large basil leaves\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak the onions: Place the onion slices in a bowl and cover with cold water. Let them soak for at least 10 minutes or up to 30 minutes at room temperature, while you prepare the sandwiches.\n2 Make the sandwich filling: In a bowl, combine the tuna, its oil, anchovies, olives and 2 teaspoons of red wine vinegar. Stir gently to keep from mashing the tuna chunks.\n3 Prepare the bread: Slice the baguettes along their length to separate the top from the bottom. Remove some of the soft crumb inside the top and bottom of the bread to make room for the filling.\nRub the insides with the garlic clove. Brush with olive oil and sprinkle with vinegar, salt, and pepper.\n4 Fill the sandwiches: Distribute the tuna mixture evenly in the bottoms of the baguettes. Top with the red onion, eggs slices, tomatoes and basil. Drizzle with more olive oil, and sprinkle on salt and pepper.\nTop the sandwiches with the tops of the baguettes, and wrap each tightly in plastic wrap.\n  5 Press the sandwiches: Place the wrapped sandwiches side-by-side on the counter and set a cutting board on top. Place a heavy pot or skillet on top, and place a few canned goods inside to weight it down even more.\nPress the sandwiches for 10 minutes, turn them over, and continue to press for another 10 minutes on the other side.\n6 Slice and store the sandwiches: With the sandwiches still wrapped in plastic, use a serrated knife to cut them into individual servings.\nThe sandwiches are ready to eat now, or they can be packed into a picnic basket or lunch box and eaten within about two hours from now. The sandwiches taste best at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nClassic Tuna Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: 2 servings\nThis recipe serves two, but it\xe2\x80\x99s easy enough to double or even triple to serve larger families.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 (5-ounce) can tuna packed in water\n1 rib celery, diced\n3 tablespoons mayonnaise\n1 teaspoon finely chopped red onion\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\nPinch of salt\nPinch of black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Drain the tuna: Open the can and hold it over the sink. Tilt the can and press on the lid to allow the water in the can to drain.\n2 Mix the tuna salad: In a bowl, break the tuna up with a fork. Add the celery, mayonnaise, onion, lemon juice, salt, and pepper. Stir to combine. Taste and adjust seasoning to your liking. Chill or use immediately.\n3 To serve: Spoon tuna salad onto slices of bread to make a sandwich, scoop onto crackers for a snack, or serve it atop a bed of salad greens.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nThree Bean Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 8\nPrep the onion first. Soak the chopped onion in a small bowl of water to take the edge off the onion while you prep the other ingredients.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the salad:\n1 (15-ounce) can cannellini beans, rinsed and drained\n1 (15-ounce) can kidney beans, rinsed and drained\n1 (15-ounce) can garbanzo beans, rinsed and drained\n1/2 red onion, finely chopped (about 3/4 cup), soaked in water to take the edge off the onion\n2 celery stalks, finely chopped (about 1 cup)\n1 cup loosely packed, fresh, finely chopped flat-leaf parsley\n1 teaspoon fresh finely chopped rosemary\nFor the dressing:\n1/3 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/4 cup granulated sugar (more or less to taste)\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the salad: In a large bowl, mix the 3 different types of beans, the celery, onion (drained of soaking water), parsley, and rosemary.\n2 Make the dressing: In a separate small bowl, whisk together the vinegar, sugar, olive oil, salt, and pepper. Add the dressing to the beans. Toss to coat.\n3 Chill and Serve: Transfer the salad to the refrigerator for several hours, to allow the beans to soak up the flavor of the dressing. Let come to close to room temperature to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHow To Make Fast, No-Soak Beans in the Instant Pot\nCook time: 30 minutesYield: about 5 cups cooked beans\nDon\'t skip the olive oil. This helps reduce foam during cooking, which could clog the pressure valve on the pressure cooker.\nIf cooking red kidney beans, I recommend boiling the beans for about 10 minutes first to break down the lectins.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dried beans (see below for cooking times for specific beans)\n8 cups water\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 to 2 teaspoons salt\n2 o 3 cloves peeled garlic, optional\n1 bay leaf, optional\nSpecial equipment:\n6- to 8-quart pressure cooker (I use a 6-quart Instant Pot)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine all ingredients in the pressure cooker. Do not fill the pressure cooker more than half full.\n2 Secure the lid. Make sure the pressure regulator valve is closed. (On an Instant Pot, this means it will be set to the the "sealing" position.)\n3 Cook the beans: Here are the cooking times for unsoaked beans in the Instant Pot. Cooking times will be similar for other electric pressure cookers; cooking time will be slightly less for stovetop pressure cookers. Double-check the manual that came with your pressure cooker for more exact cooking times:\nBlack beans: 20 to 25 minutes\nBlack-eyed peas : 20 to 25 minutes\nGreat Northern beans: 25 to 30 minutes\nNavy beans: 25 to 30 minutes\nPinto beans: 25 to 30 minutes\nCannellini beans: 35 to 40 minutes\nChickpeas (garbanzo beans): 35 to 40 minutes\nRed kidney beans: 25-30 minutes (boil for 10 minutes before pressure cooking)\nCook beans at high pressure for the time recommended above. The pressure cooker will take 15 to 20 minutes to come to full pressure before cooking begins.\n4 Let the pressure release: Once cooking is complete, you can let the pressure release naturally on its own, which takes about 20 to 30 minutes, or you can do a "quick release" by opening the pressure valve on the top of the pressure cooker. If doing a rapid release, be careful because the bean liquid sometimes foams into the valve.\nI recommend letting the pressure release naturally for as long as you\'re able before the beans are needed. This helps the beans retain their shape and avoids the bean liquid foaming.\nWhat to do if your beans aren\'t quite done: Put the lid back on the pressure cooker and make sure the release valve is set back to "sealing." Cook at high pressure for another 5 to 10 minutes (depending on if you think your beans need just a little more time or a little more time to finish). The pot will quickly come back up to pressure because the contents are already hot. Check your beans after the extra cooking time and continue cooking for longer if needed.\n5 Using and storing your beans: The beans can be strained and used right away, or cooled and stored in their cooking liquid. They will keep for up to a week refrigerated or up to 3 months in the freezer.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nEasy Tuscan Bean Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 servings\nIf eating gluten-free, use gluten-free bread for the Parmesan toasts, or replace the toasts with another gluten-free side dish.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the soup:\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n2 medium carrots, thickly sliced\n1 large onion, coarsely chopped\n1 stalk celery, coarsely chopped\n1 clove garlic, finely chopped\n3 sprigs fresh oregano\n1/4 teaspoon salt\nBlack pepper, to taste\n2 (15 -ounce) cans cannellini beans or other small white beans, drained and rinsed\n5 cups chicken stock or vegetable stock\n4 cups baby kale or baby spinach, stems removed if tough\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh oregano, for garnish\nOlive oil, to serve\nExtra grated Parmesan, to serve\nFor the parmesan toasts:\n1/2 baguette, thinly sliced\nOlive oil\n1/2 cup grated Parmesan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the vegetables: In a soup pot, heat the olive oil. When it is hot, add the carrots, onion, celery, garlic, fresh oregano sprigs, salt, and pepper. Cook, stirring often, for 10 minutes until the vegetables look softened and the onions turn translucent.\n2 Prepare the beans: On a plate, mash 1/2 cup of the beans with a fork or potato masher. Add them to the vegetables in the pot. Cook, stirring, for 2 minutes.\n3 Simmer the soup: Add the remaining beans to the pot and stir well. Stir in the chicken stock and bring to a boil. Lower the heat, partially cover with the lid placed askew, and simmer for 20 minutes, or until the carrots are tender and the liquid is flavorful.\nDiscard the oregano sprigs; the leaves will have fallen into the soup. Add additional salt and pepper to taste.\n4 While the soup simmers, make the Parmesan toasts: Toast the bread until lightly golden on both sides. While the toast is still hot from the toaster, sprinkle with olive oil and cheese. If you have a toaster oven, return them to the toaster for 1 minute to melt the cheese; otherwise, arrange the toasts in a skillet over medium heat, cover, and warm for about 1 minute or until the cheese has melted.\n5 Add the greens to the soup: Add the kale or spinach to the pot and simmering for another 2 minutes, or just until the greens wilt.\n 6 Serve the soup: Ladle the soup into bowls, sprinkle with oregano and more olive oil, if you like. Serve with Parmesan toasts and extra Parmesan for sprinkling.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nQuick and Easy White Bean Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: Serves 4\nYou can easily double or quadruple the recipe to serve a larger group.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 14.5-ounce can white beans, drained but not rinsed\n2 tablespoons chopped red onion\nA squeeze of lemon juice\n2 teaspoons wine vinegar (red or white)\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon dry Herbs de Provence (crumbled) OR 1 teaspoon of some combination of finely chopped rosemary, tarragon, thyme, and lavender\nSalt and freshly ground pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Let the onion marinate in lemon juice: After you chop up the onion, squeeze a little lemon juice over it and let it sit while prepping the other ingredients. According to my mother, this will take the edge off the onion.\n2 Combine all ingredients into a serving dish. You can serve right away if you want, but if you chill for a few hours, the flavors will come together better.\nLasts a couple of days in the refrigerator.\nHello! b'Save It Print\nWhite Bean and Tuna Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup of chopped red onions or shallots\nThe zest and juice of 1 lemon or 2 limes (can sub a tablespoon or two of cider vinegar)\n2 five to six ounce cans of tuna packed in olive oil\n2 15-ounce cans of cannellini or Great Northern white beans, rinsed and drained\n1/2 cup (loosely packed) of chopped parsley or arugula, or 2 tablespoons thinly sliced mint\nA few splashes of Tabasco sauce, or 1 minced Serrano chile or 1 teaspoon red chile flakes\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nSalt and more extra virgin olive oil to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Sprinkle some of the lemon juice over the chopped onions while you prepare the other ingredients. This will take some of the oniony edge off the onions.\n2 Combine ingredients in a bowl: Drain the oil from the tuna and put the tuna into a large bowl. Add the beans to the tuna and gently stir to combine.\nAdd the onions, herbs, black pepper, lemon zest and lemon juice and mix to combine. Add Tabasco or chili to taste.\nIf the salad needs more acid, add a little more lemon juice. If the salad seems a little dry, add a little bit of extra virgin olive oil. Add salt to taste.\n3 Chill before serving. This salad will last several days in the fridge, tightly covered.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBaked Beans in Tomato Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 2 hours, 45 minutesYield: Serves 8-10 as a side\nIf you want to save time, you can used canned beans instead of dry. Use 3 or 4 15-ounce cans, drained and rinsed and proceed to step 3. If you want a vegetarian version, skip the bacon, increase the olive oil, and use vegetable stock.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dry cannellini, borlotti or Great Northern beans\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1/4 pound bacon or pancetta, roughly chopped\n1/2 medium onion, chopped\n4 garlic cloves, chopped\n1 tablespoon fresh sage, minced (can sub fresh rosemary)\n1/2 to 1 teaspoon chile flakes (depending on how spicy you want it)\n2 tablespoons honey\n1/4 cup tomato paste\n1 15-ounce can crushed tomatoes or tomato sauce\n2 cups beef or chicken stock (use gluten-free stock for gluten-free version)\nSalt\n1/2 cup chopped fresh parsley\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak the beans in water: Pre-soak the beans, either by covering with two inches of water and soaking overnight, or by pouring boiling water over them and soaking them for an hour.\n2 Drain beans, cover with water, cook until tender: Drain the beans and put them in a medium-sized pot and cover with 2 inches of water. Bring to a simmer, cover, reduce the heat to a low simmer and cook until the beans are just soft enough to eat, about 1 hour, give or take 15 minutes or so, depending on how old the beans are (older beans will take longer to cook).\n3 Cook bacon or pancetta: Preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F. In a 3 or 4 quart heavy-bottomed, oven-proof, lidded pot such as a Dutch oven, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the bacon or pancetta and cook slowly until lightly browned and crispy.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions: Add the chopped onions and increase the heat to medium-high. Cook, stirring often, until the onions begin to brown. Use a wooden spoon to scrape any browned bits off the bottom of the pot.\n5 Add garlic, chili flakes, sage, then add tomatoes and stock: Add the garlic, chile flakes and sage and cook for 1-2 minutes, then add the honey and tomato paste. Stir well to combine.\nAdd the tomatoes or tomato sauce and the stock. Bring to a simmer. Taste for salt and add some if needed.\n6 Add the beans, cover, cook in oven: Drain the beans and add them to the pot. Stir well.\nCover the pot and cook in a 325\xc2\xb0F oven for 1 hour and 15 minutes.\nIf still a bit wet, remove the cover and cook for 15 minutes more.\nNote that the cooking time will depend on several things, the most important being how thoroughly the beans were cooked to begin with when they were simmered.\nIf the beans are still a bit hard when they go in the oven, it may take several hours to soften them, once the tomato and honey have been added.\n7 Stir in parsley and balsamic vinegar: Right before serving, gently stir in the chopped parsley and balsamic vinegar. Taste for salt, add more if needed to taste.\nServe either hot or at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHow to Cook Dried Beans Recipe\nCooking time: 45 minutes to 3 hours, depending on the type of beanYield: About 6 cups cooked beans\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dried beans, such as chickpeas, great northern, cannellini, navy, or black beans\nWater\n4 teaspoons kosher salt, divided\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sort through the beans: Pull out and discard any small stones or wrinkled or broken beans.\n2 Soak the beans (optional): Place the beans in bowl. Cover with 2 to 3 inches of water. Cover and leave on the countertop until you are ready to cook them the following day. Drain the water. Rinse the beans.\nAlternatively, you can quick-soak your beans or skip soaking altogether; see above for a breakdown of these options.\n3 Cook the beans: In a large pot set over medium high heat, add the beans (either soaked or unsoaked) and cover them with water until it reaches about 3 inches above the beans.\nBring the beans up to a boil, then reduce the heat to gentle simmer. Leave the pot uncovered and cook.\n4 Salt the beans: After about 40 minutes, check a bean to taste it. If it\xe2\x80\x99s firm, but tender, add 4 teaspoons of salt. Give the pot a gentle stir.\nContinue cooking until the beans are creamy, but intact, about another 20 to 50 minutes.\nNote: Total cooking time will vary based on the type of bean, the age, and whether you soaked or not. See total cooking time estimates in the headnotes above.\n5 Store or serve: If serving immediately, drain the beans through a fine mesh sieve and place them in a bowl. Season as desired (see headnotes for suggestions) and serve.\nIf storing, allow the beans to cool completely in their liquid, and then store in their broth in the fridge for up to 4 days, or freeze for up to three months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nWhite Beans and Sausage Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesSoaking and Cooking Beans from Scratch time: 6 hoursYield: Serves 4-8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound dried cannellini beans\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n4-5 fresh sage leaves\n2 cloves garlic, crushed\n3 teaspoons kosher salt\n4 black peppercorns\nOR\n4 15-ounce cans cannellini beans\n  5 tablespoons extra olive oil\n1 1/2 pounds sweet Italian sausage\n4 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed\n3-4 canned plum tomatoes, chopped\nPinch red pepper flakes\n1 cup tomato pur\xc3\xa9e\nSalt (about 2 teaspoons) and freshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nPreparing dry beans if using:\n1 Rinse and soak the beans: Rinse the dry beans under cold running water, removing any stones you may find. Place the beans in a large pot and cover with at least a couple of inches with cold water. Soak for at least 4 hours. (To do a quick soak, you can pour boiling water over the beans and cover by a couple of inches, and just soak for one hour instead of four.)\n2 Cook beans with aromatics: Drain the beans. Return the beans to the pot and add 3 quarts of water to the pot. Add 2 Tbsp olive oil, the sage leaves, 2 cloves crushed garlic, 3 teaspoons kosher salt, and the peppercorns. Cover, bring to a simmer on medium heat, and simmer beans for one hour. Lower the heat so that the beans are barely simmering. Cook for an additional 1-2 hours, or until beans are just tender. Note that the fresher the beans the shorter the cooking time, the older the beans the longer the cooking time. Remove from heat and let cool in cooking liquid. Set aside 1/2 cup of the cooking liquid, drain the rest from the beans.\nPreparing canned beans if using:\nTaste the liquid in the cans of beans. If it tastes good (and it should), drain the beans and reserve 1/2 a cup of the bean liquid. If the liquid doesn't taste good (which may happen if the can has been sitting around too long), discard the liquid and use 1/2 cup of water instead of the bean liquid in the next step.\nPreparing the beans and sausage:\n3 Cook the sausage: Heat one tablespoon of olive oil in a large, heavy-bottomed skillet over medium heat. Remove sausages from their casings (if the sausage has come in casings), and cook in the skillet until lightly browned, about 3-4 minutes.\n4 Add the reserved bean cooking (or can) liquid, 4 Tbsp olive oil, garlic, chopped tomatoes, and red pepper flakes, stirring occasionally until slightly thickened, about 5 minutes.\n5 Add the reserved beans and tomato pur\xc3\xa9e. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Simmer a few minutes longer, stirring gently, until sausage is cooked through and the sauce has thickened. Be careful not to break up the beans.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nShrimp, Arugula, White Bean, Cherry Tomato Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIt always helps to brine the shrimp before cooking. An extra step, but worth it if you have the time!\nTo brine the shrimp, mix together 4 cups water, 1/4 cup kosher salt (or 3 Tbsp table or sea salt), 1/4 cup white sugar until the salt and sugar have dissolved. Add one cup of ice and the shrimp. After 30 minutes (time it!) remove the shrimp and give them a quick rinse.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound 16-20 count shelled and deveined shrimp\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 15-ounce cans cannellini white beans, rinsed and drained\n1 cup cherry tomatoes, halved or quartered\n1/2 cup finely diced red onion\n3/4 teaspoon grated lemon zest\n3 handfuls baby arugula leaves\nDressing:\n3 tablespoons red wine vinegar\n1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2 cloves minced garlic\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the shrimp: Heat a large cast iron skillet or griddle on high heat. Add 2 Tbsp of olive oil to coat the pan. When the oil is hot, working in batches of half of the shrimp at a time, add the shrimp and saut\xc3\xa9 a minute on each side to sear. (You can also grill the shrimp if you prefer.)\nWhen the shrimp are barely cooked through, remove from the pan and set aside to cool. (The shrimp will continue to cook for a little bit after you remove them from the pan, and you don't want overcooked rubbery shrimp.)\n2 Assemble the salad: Put the drained beans, cut cherry tomatoes, diced onion, lemon zest, and arugula leaves into a large bowl. Fold in the shrimp.\n3 Make the dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together the red wine vinegar, olive oil, garlic, salt and pepper.\nGently fold the dressing into the salad and serve!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nWhite Bean Soup with Ham, Pumpkin, and Chard Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 5-6\nThis recipe calls for a sugar pumpkin (the kind you use to make pies). You can easily substitute the same quantity of butternut squash or almost any winter squash.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 cups chopped yellow onion\n3 bay leaves\n2 stalks of celery, chopped\n4 cloves garlic, peeled and minced\nOne 2 pound whole sugar pumpkin, halved, seeds scooped out, flesh peeled, and cut into 1-inch chunks (resulting in 3 1/2 cups or 1 pound of chunks)\n1/2  pound ham hock\n8 cups chicken stock\n1 15-ounce can of whole peeled tomatoes, drained OR 1 large fresh, ripe tomato, peeled and chopped\n6 sprigs of thyme, tied with string (or 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme)\n2 15-ounce cans of cannellini white beans, rinsed and drained, or homemade\n4 large Swiss chard leaves (can substitute kale), center rib removed, leaves roughly chopped\nFreshly ground black pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, bay leaves, celery, garlic: Heat the olive oil on medium heat in a large, thick-bottomed pot (5 to 6 quart). Add the onion and the bay leaves and cook for 2 to 3 minutes, until slightly softened. Add the chopped celery, cook for 2 to 3 more minutes. Add the minced garlic and cook for a minute more.\n2 Add pumpkin, ham hock, stock, tomatoes, thyme: Add the chopped pumpkin and the ham hock to the pot. Add the chicken stock, tomatoes, and thyme. Increase heat to bring to a simmer. Reduce heat to maintain a simmer, uncovered. Let simmer for an hour and a half.\n3 Remove ham hock, add white beans, chard: Remove the ham hock from the soup pot, to a plate to let cool enough to handle.  Add the white beans and cook for 15 minutes. Add the chopped chard, simmer until chard is wilted, a few minutes more.\n4 Strip ham from bone, chop, return to soup: Strip the meat from the ham hock, chop it, and return to the pot. Add 1 to 2 cups of water to the soup to thin it to your preference. Remove the bay leaves before serving.\nAdd freshly ground black pepper and adjust seasonings to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nWhite Bean and Cherry Tomato Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 15-ounce cans of white beans, such as Great Northern or cannellini beans, drained and rinsed\n1 pint cherry or plum tomatoes, halved\n1/3 cup coarsely chopped parsley\nDressing ingredients:\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n3 cloves garlic, peeled and smashed\n1 3-inch sprig of fresh rosemary\n3 anchovy fillets, coarsely chopped (omit for vegetarian option)\n1/4 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese\n3/4 teaspoon Kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground pepper\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1/4 cup of lemon juice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Infuse rosemary in olive oil: Place the garlic and sprig of rosemary in the olive oil in a small saucepan. Heat the oil on medium until the rosemary begins to sizzle.\nRemove the pan from the heat and let sit for 20 minutes, allowing the rosemary and garlic to infuse in the oil.\n2 Make the dressing: Remove rosemary sprig from the oil, discard. Remove the garlic from the oil, reserving the oil.\nAdd the garlic, anchovies (omit for vegetarian option), Parmesan cheese, salt, pepper, lemon zest, and lemon juice to a food processor or mini chopper. Pulse until smooth.\n3 Mix dressing with beans: In a medium bowl, gently mix the garlic Parmesan lemon mixture in with the beans until the beans are well coated.\nLet the beans sit for a few minutes so they absorb some of the dressing.\n4 Gently mix in the reserved olive oil, tomatoes, and parsley.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nCreamy Tomato and White Bean Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 6 servings\nWhen it's fresh and in season, basil makes a nice alternative to the rosemary in this recipe.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the soup:\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 large onion, chopped\n2 medium cloves garlic, thinly sliced\n3 pounds ripe plum (Roma) tomatoes, cut into 1-inch pieces (or 2 (28-ounce) cans whole tomatoes and their juices, crushed in a bowl)\n1 15-ounce can cannellini beans, drained and rinsed, or homemade\n1 sprig fresh rosemary\n1 1/2 cups water, plus more as needed\n1/2 cup freshly grated Parmesan\n1 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste\n1/8 teaspoon black pepper, plus more to taste\nFor the garnish:\n12 cherry tomatoes, sliced or quartered\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 teaspoon red wine vinegar\nSalt and pepper, to taste\n12 basil leaves, thinly sliced\nSpecial Equipment:\nBlender or immersion blender\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the onion and garlic: Heat the oil in a soup pot over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 6 to 8 minutes, or until softened.\n2 Add the tomatoes and beans: Add the fresh or canned tomatoes, rosemary, beans, 1 1/2 cups of water, salt, and pepper to the pot. Bring to a simmer and cook, uncovered, for 20 minutes, or until the tomatoes are very soft. Remove the rosemary sprig. Stir in the Parmesan.\n3 Puree the soup: In 2- to 3-cup batches, puree the soup in a blender until smooth, or use an immersion blender. (Warning! The soup is hot! To puree hot liquid in a blender, only fill it 1/3 full. Cover the lid with a folded dishtowel and hold it down with your hand. Start on low speed, and increase the speed gradually.)\nTransfer the soup to a pot and stir in enough additional water to bring the soup to your desired consistency (up to 2 1/2 cups of water). Taste and add salt and pepper, if you like. Reheat over low heat until hot.\n4 Make the garnish: In a bowl, stir together the tomatoes, oil, vinegar, salt, and pepper. Just before serving, stir in the basil.\n5 Serve the soup: Ladle the soup into bowls, and top each bowl with the fresh tomato garnish.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nCreamy Tortellini Soup with Sausage and Spinach Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 55 minutesYield: 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 teaspoon olive oil\n1 pound mild Italian sausage, removed from casings if purchased in links\n1 large yellow onion, diced\n8 ounces mushrooms, diced\n1 teaspoon salt, divided\n2 large carrots, diced\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n2 quarts chicken stock\n1 pound fresh or frozen cheese tortellini\n10 ounces baby spinach, kale, chard, or other green (torn into the size of baby spinach, if necessary)\n1 15-ounce can cannellini beans\n2 teaspoons cider vinegar\n1/2 cup heavy cream or whole milk\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the sausage: Warm a teaspoon of oil in a large soup pot over medium-high heat, and add the sausage. Cook the sausage until completely browned, breaking it up into crumbles as it cooks. When browned, remove the sausage from the pan with a slotted spoon and set aside.\n2 Cook the vegetables: Drain all but a tablespoon of fat from the pan (add more oil if you don\xe2\x80\x99t have quite a tablespoon). Add the onions and a half teaspoon of salt, and cook until the onions are translucent and beginning to brown, about 5 minutes.\nAdd the mushrooms and another half teaspoon of salt. Cook until the mushrooms have released all their moisture and are cooked through, another 5 minutes. Add the carrots and cook until they look softened around the edges, another 2-3 minutes. Stir in the garlic and cook until fragrant, 30 seconds.\n3 Bring the soup to a simmer and add the tortellini: Pour a cup of chicken stock into the pot and scrape any browned bits from the bottom of the pot. Return the sausage to the pot and add the remaining stock. Bring to a rapid simmer over high heat, then reduce the heat to a medium.\nAdd the tortellini and cook according to package instructions.\n4 Puree the beans: In a medium sized bowl, add the drained beans, 1/2 cup water, and apple cider vinegar. Puree using an immersion blender (or you can do this in a food processor or countertop blender).\n5 Finish the soup: When the tortellini is done, add the greens and stir until wilted. Stir in the pureed beans and heavy cream (or milk). Taste and add salt, pepper, or another splash of cider vinegar as needed to perk up the flavors. Serve.\nLEFTOVERS! This leftover soup will keep for about 5 days in the fridge and is best reheated gently over low heat on the stovetop or in the microwave. The tortellini will gradually soften, the longer the leftovers sit.\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99d like to freeze any portion of the soup, cook the tortellini separately and freeze the soup without it. When ready to serve, cook more tortellini in boiling water and add to each bowl when serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBread and Butter Pickles Recipe\nPrep time: 4 hours, 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes about 5 pint jars\nStart with the freshest pickling cucumbers you can find; your pickles are only going to be as good as the produce you start with. The fresher the cucumbers are, the crispier your pickles will be.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 lbs pickling cucumbers (fresh from the market)\n1/4 cup pickling salt (can use Kosher salt as a substitute, regular table salt has additives in it that will turn the pickles dark and muddy the color of the pickle juice)\n1 pound white or yellow onions, thinly sliced\n1 1/4 cup white distilled vinegar (5% acidity)\n1 cup apple cider vinegar (5% acidity)\n2 1/4 cups sugar\nPickling spices:\n1 tablespoon mustard seeds\n1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes\n3/4 teaspoon celery seeds\n1 inch cinnamon stick\n6 allspice berries plus a pinch of ground allspice\n6 whole cloves plus a pinch of ground cloves\n1/2 teaspoon turmeric\nSpecial equipment:\nIf you are planning to store pickles outside of refrigerator, you will need the following canning equipment:\n5 pint-sized canning jars, clean, unused lids, metal screw bands for the lids (see Canning jars and lids)\n1 16-qt canning pot with rack\nJar lifters or tongs\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Rinse and slice the cucumbers: Carefully rinse the cucumbers, scrubbing away any dirt that may have stuck to the ribs. Slice off 1/8-inch from the ends and discard. Slice the cucumbers in 1/4-inch thick slices, place in a large bowl.\n2 Salt, chill, and drain the cucumber slices: Add the sliced onions and all of the pickling salt. Stir in so that the salt is well distributed among the cucumber slices. Cover with a clean tea towel (thin towel, not terry cloth). Cover with a couple of inches of ice.\nPut in the refrigerator and let chill for 4 hours. Discard ice. Rinse the cucumber and onion slices thoroughly, drain. Rinse and drain again.\n3 Sterilize the jars: If you are planning to store your pickles outside of the refrigerator for any length of time, you will need to sterilize your jars before canning, and heat the filled jars in a hot water bath after canning.\nIf you are planning to eat the pickles right away and store them the whole time in the refrigerator, you can skip the water bath step. It's still a good idea to sterilize the jars first, you can do that by running them through the dishwasher, or placing them in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\nTo sterilize the jars for canning, place empty jars on a metal rack in a large, 16-qt canning pot. (Jars must rest on a rack in the pot, not on the bottom of the pot). Fill with warm water and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to warm to keep the jars hot and ready for canning.\nRemove with tongs or jar lifters one by one as you can the cucumbers.\nSterilize the lids by bringing a pot of water to a boil and pouring water over a bowl containing the lids.\n4 Make pickling syrup: In a 4 qt or 6 qt pot, place the vinegar, sugar, and all of the pickling spices. (Do NOT add salt.) Bring to a boil. Once the sugar has dissolved, add the sliced cucumbers and onions. Bring to a boil again. As soon as the sugar vinegar solution begins boiling again, use a slotted spoon to start packing the hot jars with the cucumbers and onions.\n5 Pack jars, add pickling syrup: Pack jars to an inch from the rim with the cucumbers and onions. Then pour hot vinegar sugar syrup over them to a half inch from the rim.\nWipe the rim clean with a paper towel. Place a sterilized lid on the jar. Secure with a metal screw band.\n6 Process in hot water bath: If you are planning to store pickles outside of refrigerator, you will want to process the filled jars in a hot water bath.\nReturn filled jars to the same canning pot with its already hot water. Water level needs to be at least one inch above the top of the cans.\nBring to a boil and let boil hard for 15 minutes, or 20 minutes for altitudes of 1001 to 6,000 feet. Over 6,000 feet, boil for 25 minutes. Remove jars from pot.\nLet cool down to room temperature. Jars should make a popping sound as their lids seal. If a lid doesn't properly seal, do not store the jar outside of the refrigerator.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nCanned Tomato Salsa Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Makes about 5 pints\nBefore starting, prepare your workspace so that it is clean and uncluttered. If you don\'t want to roast your own green chiles, you can sub with about two 7-ounce cans of green chiles, chopped.\nThis recipe uses specific amounts of ingredients, balancing the non-acidic ingredients with the amount of added acid needed to make the recipe safe. Do not increase the amount of green chiles beyond 1 1/2 cups, or decrease the amount of tomatoes less than 7 cups.\nINGREDIENTS\n5 pounds of tomatoes\n1 pound large Anaheim green chiles (5-6 chiles)\n3 jalape\xc3\xb1o chilies, seeded and stems removed, chopped\n1 1/2 cups chopped onion\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n1 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/2 cup loosely packed fresh chopped cilantro (including stems)\n2 teaspoons dried oregano\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\n2 teaspoons salt\n1 to 2 tablespoons sugar or more (to taste, depending on how sweet your tomatoes are)\nSpecial equipment:\n5 to 6 pint-sized canning jars, with rings and new lids\nA very large stockpot or canning pot (16-qt)\nA flat steamer rack on which to place the filled jar for the water bath canning, so that they don\'t touch the bottom of the pan and crack from excess heat\nOptional but recommended:\nJar lifter canning tongs to make it easy to lift the jars in and out of boiling water\nRubber or latex coated gardening gloves to make it easier on your hands for handling hot jars\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sterilize jars and lids in water bath: Place steamer rack in the bottom of a large (16-qt) stock pot or canning pot. Place new or clean mason jars on the rack. Fill the jars with water and fill the pot with just enough water to come to the top of the jars. Heat water to a simmer. Simmer for 10 minutes. (Keep the jars warm while preparing the salsa.)\nHave a kettle half filled with water ready to boil, to use to sterilize the jar lids a few minutes before canning.\n2 Roast chile peppers: Roast the Anaheim green chile peppers until blackened all over. The best way to do this is directly over a gas flame on the stovetop (see how to roast chiles over a gas flame.) If you don\'t have a gas cooktop you can broil the chiles, or blister them on a grill.\nNote that it is not essential that the chile peppers be cooked through, only that the outer tough skin is blistered and blackened. This is what will help with flavor. Also it will make it easy to peel the chiles.\nJust put the chiles near a heat source until blistered and blackened, and turn them so that they get blackened on all sides.\nThen place the chiles in a brown paper bag (or in a covered bowl), close the bag and let the chiles steam in their own heat for a few minutes.\nThen gently rub off the outer skin and discard. Cut away the stems and remove the seeds and any prominent veins.\nChop up the chiles and set aside; you should have 1 cup of chopped chiles. Do not use more than 1 1/2 cups of chopped chiles.\n3 Prepare the tomatoes: You want the tomatoes peeled, and there are several ways of doing that. Blanching them is easiest; grilling or broiling will result in more flavor.\nTo blanch them, score the ends of the tomatoes and place them in boiling water for a minute.\nIf you are going to grill or broil the tomatoes, I recommend coring them first. Grilling is best with whole plum tomatoes; grill them on high direct heat until blackened in parts and the peels are cracked.\nBroiling works with any sized tomato. Just cut them in half and place the cut side down on a rimmed baking sheet or roasting pan. Broil until the peels are blackened in parts.\nRemove the tomatoes (from water, grill or broiler) and let cool to the touch. Remove and discard the peels. Cut away any cores if you haven\'t done so already. Chop the tomatoes taking care to save any juices that may come out of them.\nStarting with 5 pounds of tomatoes you should end up with about 8 cups of chopped tomatoes and juices. (You must use at least 7 cups of tomatoes.) Place them in a bowl and set aside.\n4 Simmer all ingredients in a large pot: Put all of the ingredients into a large (8-qt) stainless steel pot. (Do not use aluminum or the acidity of the sauce will cause the aluminum to leach into the sauce.)\nBring to a boil, reduce to a simmer. Cook uncovered for about 10 minutes.\n5 Sterilize jar lids: While the salsa is cooking, place the jar lids in a bowl and cover with boiling water to sterilize.\n6 Blend salsa if you want it to be more smooth: If you want your salsa to be more smooth than chunky, use an immersion blender to pulse it a few times, or working in batches ladle about half of it into a blender and pur\xc3\xa9e.\n7 Adjust seasonings: If too acidic to taste, add more sugar to balance the vinegar! If too sweet, add a bit more vinegar.\n8 Ladle salsa into canning jars and seal: Ladle salsa into canning jars, leaving 1/2-inch head space. Wipe the rims with a clean, dampened paper towel so that there is no residual food on the rims.\nPlace canning lids on the jars. Screw on the lid rings. Do not over-tighten or you may not get a good seal. Air does need to escape from the jars during the next step, the water bath.\n9 Boil in a water bath: Place the filled and lidded jars back onto the rack in the large stock-pot of hot water you used to sterilize the jars in step one. You may need to remove some of the water from the pot to prevent it from overfilling.\nCover the jars with at least 1-inch of water. Bring to a rolling boil and process for 15 minutes (20 minutes for altitudes 1000 to 6000 ft, 25 minutes above 6000 ft). Then turn off heat and let the jars sit in the hot water for 5 minutes.\n10 Let jars cool, lids should pop: Remove jars from the water bath and let sit on a counter for several hours until completely cool. The lids should "pop" as the cooling salsa creates a vacuum under the lid and the jars are sealed.\nIf a lid has not sealed, either replace the lid and reprocess in a water bath for another 15 minutes, or store in the refrigerator and use within the next few days.\nRemember to label the cans with the date processed. (I use a Sharpie on the lid.) Canned salsa should be eaten within a year.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nEscabeche (Pickled Jalape\xc3\xb1os) Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes about 4 to 5 pint jars\nRecipe adapted from Diana Kennedy's The Essential Cuisines of Mexico.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound jalape\xc3\xb1o (and/or serrano if you wish) chile peppers\n1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2-3 medium white or yellow onions, thickly sliced\n2-3 medium carrots, peeled and thickly sliced\nFlorets from half a small cauliflower (optional)\n1 head garlic, cloves separated but not peeled\n4 cups apple cider vinegar\n2 tablespoons Kosher salt or sea salt\n2 bay leaves\n1/2 teaspoon dried oregano\n4 sprigs fresh marjoram (can sub fresh oregano) or 1/4 teaspoon dried\n4 sprigs fresh thyme or 1/4 teaspoon dried\n1 tablespoon sugar\nSpecial equipment:\n4 - 5 pint-size canning jars\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the chiles: Wash the chiles, leaving the stems intact. Cut a cross in the tip end of each chile so that the vinegar will be able to penetrate the chiles.\n2 Fry the vegetables in olive oil: Heat olive oil in a large, deep skillet. Add the chiles, onions, carrots, cauliflower if using, and garlic. Fry over medium heat for about 10 minutes, turning them over occasionally.\n3 Boil with vinegar and seasonings: Add the vinegar, salt, bay leaves, dried oregano, marjoram, thyme, and sugar and bring to a boil. Lower the heat and simmer for 10 minutes.\nMake sure the chiles are entirely cooked through before canning. You will know they are cooked when they are no longer vibrant green, but a dull, olive green.\n4 Pack  the jars: Pack 4 to 5 pint-sized sterilized jars with the chiles and vegetables. Top with the vinegar cooking liquid and seal.\n5 Process in a hot water bath for 10 minutes.\nOnce opened, can keep for one to two months in the refrigerator.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nEscabeche (Pickled Jalape\xc3\xb1os) Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes about 4 to 5 pint jars\nRecipe adapted from Diana Kennedy's The Essential Cuisines of Mexico.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound jalape\xc3\xb1o (and/or serrano if you wish) chile peppers\n1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2-3 medium white or yellow onions, thickly sliced\n2-3 medium carrots, peeled and thickly sliced\nFlorets from half a small cauliflower (optional)\n1 head garlic, cloves separated but not peeled\n4 cups apple cider vinegar\n2 tablespoons Kosher salt or sea salt\n2 bay leaves\n1/2 teaspoon dried oregano\n4 sprigs fresh marjoram (can sub fresh oregano) or 1/4 teaspoon dried\n4 sprigs fresh thyme or 1/4 teaspoon dried\n1 tablespoon sugar\nSpecial equipment:\n4 - 5 pint-size canning jars\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the chiles: Wash the chiles, leaving the stems intact. Cut a cross in the tip end of each chile so that the vinegar will be able to penetrate the chiles.\n2 Fry the vegetables in olive oil: Heat olive oil in a large, deep skillet. Add the chiles, onions, carrots, cauliflower if using, and garlic. Fry over medium heat for about 10 minutes, turning them over occasionally.\n3 Boil with vinegar and seasonings: Add the vinegar, salt, bay leaves, dried oregano, marjoram, thyme, and sugar and bring to a boil. Lower the heat and simmer for 10 minutes.\nMake sure the chiles are entirely cooked through before canning. You will know they are cooked when they are no longer vibrant green, but a dull, olive green.\n4 Pack  the jars: Pack 4 to 5 pint-sized sterilized jars with the chiles and vegetables. Top with the vinegar cooking liquid and seal.\n5 Process in a hot water bath for 10 minutes.\nOnce opened, can keep for one to two months in the refrigerator.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nHow to Make Easy Refrigerator Pickles\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 minutesPickling time: 24 hoursYield: 2 pint jars of pickles\nYou can use this method to make pickle spears as well! They\'ll need to pickle for 2 to 3 days in the fridge before they\'re ready.\nAs is, the recipe makes a fairly sweet pickle. You can cut the sugar in half for a more sour and tart pickle, if desired.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Kirby or other small cucumbers\n1 small sweet yellow onion\n1 cup apple cider vinegar\n1 cup water\n1/4 cup granulated sugar\n1 tablespoon kosher salt\n1 1/2 teaspoons pickling spice, homemade or store-bought\nSpecial equipment:\n2 wide-mouth pint canning jars\nCanning jar lids, plastic or metal\nMandoline, or sharp knife\nCanning funnel (helpful, but not essential)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Wash and dry the jars and cucumbers: Wash 2 wide-mouth pint jars and their lids in hot, soapy water. Set them aside to dry.\nRinse the cucumbers well under cold water, pat them dry, and then set them on a towel to dry completely.\n2 Slice the cucumbers and onion, then pack them in the jars: With a sharp knife or a mandoline slicer, slice the cucumbers and onion into slices 1/8- to 1/4-inch thick.\nFirmly pack the cucumbers and onions into the jars, fitting in as many as you can without smashing the vegetables. Leave 1/2-inch or so of headspace at the top of the jars.\n3 Make the brine: In a small saucepan over medium-high heat, bring the vinegar, water, sugar, salt, and pickling spice up to a simmer. Stir occasionally and continue simmering until the sugar and salt are dissolved.\n4 Pour the brine over the vegetables: If you have a canning funnel, use it here to make it easier to fill the jars. Carefully pour or ladle the hot brine into each jar, filling the jars until the cucumbers and onions are covered. It\'s ok if a few small pieces poke out the top.\n5 Cool and refrigerate for 24 hours: Screw on the lids, then let the jars cool to room temperature (about an hour). The cucumbers will start off bright green, but will become darker and more "pickle-colored" as they cool.\nPlace them in the refrigerator. Wait at least 24 hours before eating the pickles in order to let the flavors develop. Use them within one month.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBread and Butter Pickles Recipe\nPrep time: 4 hours, 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes about 5 pint jars\nStart with the freshest pickling cucumbers you can find; your pickles are only going to be as good as the produce you start with. The fresher the cucumbers are, the crispier your pickles will be.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 lbs pickling cucumbers (fresh from the market)\n1/4 cup pickling salt (can use Kosher salt as a substitute, regular table salt has additives in it that will turn the pickles dark and muddy the color of the pickle juice)\n1 pound white or yellow onions, thinly sliced\n1 1/4 cup white distilled vinegar (5% acidity)\n1 cup apple cider vinegar (5% acidity)\n2 1/4 cups sugar\nPickling spices:\n1 tablespoon mustard seeds\n1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes\n3/4 teaspoon celery seeds\n1 inch cinnamon stick\n6 allspice berries plus a pinch of ground allspice\n6 whole cloves plus a pinch of ground cloves\n1/2 teaspoon turmeric\nSpecial equipment:\nIf you are planning to store pickles outside of refrigerator, you will need the following canning equipment:\n5 pint-sized canning jars, clean, unused lids, metal screw bands for the lids (see Canning jars and lids)\n1 16-qt canning pot with rack\nJar lifters or tongs\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Rinse and slice the cucumbers: Carefully rinse the cucumbers, scrubbing away any dirt that may have stuck to the ribs. Slice off 1/8-inch from the ends and discard. Slice the cucumbers in 1/4-inch thick slices, place in a large bowl.\n2 Salt, chill, and drain the cucumber slices: Add the sliced onions and all of the pickling salt. Stir in so that the salt is well distributed among the cucumber slices. Cover with a clean tea towel (thin towel, not terry cloth). Cover with a couple of inches of ice.\nPut in the refrigerator and let chill for 4 hours. Discard ice. Rinse the cucumber and onion slices thoroughly, drain. Rinse and drain again.\n3 Sterilize the jars: If you are planning to store your pickles outside of the refrigerator for any length of time, you will need to sterilize your jars before canning, and heat the filled jars in a hot water bath after canning.\nIf you are planning to eat the pickles right away and store them the whole time in the refrigerator, you can skip the water bath step. It's still a good idea to sterilize the jars first, you can do that by running them through the dishwasher, or placing them in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\nTo sterilize the jars for canning, place empty jars on a metal rack in a large, 16-qt canning pot. (Jars must rest on a rack in the pot, not on the bottom of the pot). Fill with warm water and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to warm to keep the jars hot and ready for canning.\nRemove with tongs or jar lifters one by one as you can the cucumbers.\nSterilize the lids by bringing a pot of water to a boil and pouring water over a bowl containing the lids.\n4 Make pickling syrup: In a 4 qt or 6 qt pot, place the vinegar, sugar, and all of the pickling spices. (Do NOT add salt.) Bring to a boil. Once the sugar has dissolved, add the sliced cucumbers and onions. Bring to a boil again. As soon as the sugar vinegar solution begins boiling again, use a slotted spoon to start packing the hot jars with the cucumbers and onions.\n5 Pack jars, add pickling syrup: Pack jars to an inch from the rim with the cucumbers and onions. Then pour hot vinegar sugar syrup over them to a half inch from the rim.\nWipe the rim clean with a paper towel. Place a sterilized lid on the jar. Secure with a metal screw band.\n6 Process in hot water bath: If you are planning to store pickles outside of refrigerator, you will want to process the filled jars in a hot water bath.\nReturn filled jars to the same canning pot with its already hot water. Water level needs to be at least one inch above the top of the cans.\nBring to a boil and let boil hard for 15 minutes, or 20 minutes for altitudes of 1001 to 6,000 feet. Over 6,000 feet, boil for 25 minutes. Remove jars from pot.\nLet cool down to room temperature. Jars should make a popping sound as their lids seal. If a lid doesn't properly seal, do not store the jar outside of the refrigerator.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nCanned Tomato Salsa Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Makes about 5 pints\nBefore starting, prepare your workspace so that it is clean and uncluttered. If you don\'t want to roast your own green chiles, you can sub with about two 7-ounce cans of green chiles, chopped.\nThis recipe uses specific amounts of ingredients, balancing the non-acidic ingredients with the amount of added acid needed to make the recipe safe. Do not increase the amount of green chiles beyond 1 1/2 cups, or decrease the amount of tomatoes less than 7 cups.\nINGREDIENTS\n5 pounds of tomatoes\n1 pound large Anaheim green chiles (5-6 chiles)\n3 jalape\xc3\xb1o chilies, seeded and stems removed, chopped\n1 1/2 cups chopped onion\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n1 cup apple cider vinegar\n1/2 cup loosely packed fresh chopped cilantro (including stems)\n2 teaspoons dried oregano\n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin\n2 teaspoons salt\n1 to 2 tablespoons sugar or more (to taste, depending on how sweet your tomatoes are)\nSpecial equipment:\n5 to 6 pint-sized canning jars, with rings and new lids\nA very large stockpot or canning pot (16-qt)\nA flat steamer rack on which to place the filled jar for the water bath canning, so that they don\'t touch the bottom of the pan and crack from excess heat\nOptional but recommended:\nJar lifter canning tongs to make it easy to lift the jars in and out of boiling water\nRubber or latex coated gardening gloves to make it easier on your hands for handling hot jars\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sterilize jars and lids in water bath: Place steamer rack in the bottom of a large (16-qt) stock pot or canning pot. Place new or clean mason jars on the rack. Fill the jars with water and fill the pot with just enough water to come to the top of the jars. Heat water to a simmer. Simmer for 10 minutes. (Keep the jars warm while preparing the salsa.)\nHave a kettle half filled with water ready to boil, to use to sterilize the jar lids a few minutes before canning.\n2 Roast chile peppers: Roast the Anaheim green chile peppers until blackened all over. The best way to do this is directly over a gas flame on the stovetop (see how to roast chiles over a gas flame.) If you don\'t have a gas cooktop you can broil the chiles, or blister them on a grill.\nNote that it is not essential that the chile peppers be cooked through, only that the outer tough skin is blistered and blackened. This is what will help with flavor. Also it will make it easy to peel the chiles.\nJust put the chiles near a heat source until blistered and blackened, and turn them so that they get blackened on all sides.\nThen place the chiles in a brown paper bag (or in a covered bowl), close the bag and let the chiles steam in their own heat for a few minutes.\nThen gently rub off the outer skin and discard. Cut away the stems and remove the seeds and any prominent veins.\nChop up the chiles and set aside; you should have 1 cup of chopped chiles. Do not use more than 1 1/2 cups of chopped chiles.\n3 Prepare the tomatoes: You want the tomatoes peeled, and there are several ways of doing that. Blanching them is easiest; grilling or broiling will result in more flavor.\nTo blanch them, score the ends of the tomatoes and place them in boiling water for a minute.\nIf you are going to grill or broil the tomatoes, I recommend coring them first. Grilling is best with whole plum tomatoes; grill them on high direct heat until blackened in parts and the peels are cracked.\nBroiling works with any sized tomato. Just cut them in half and place the cut side down on a rimmed baking sheet or roasting pan. Broil until the peels are blackened in parts.\nRemove the tomatoes (from water, grill or broiler) and let cool to the touch. Remove and discard the peels. Cut away any cores if you haven\'t done so already. Chop the tomatoes taking care to save any juices that may come out of them.\nStarting with 5 pounds of tomatoes you should end up with about 8 cups of chopped tomatoes and juices. (You must use at least 7 cups of tomatoes.) Place them in a bowl and set aside.\n4 Simmer all ingredients in a large pot: Put all of the ingredients into a large (8-qt) stainless steel pot. (Do not use aluminum or the acidity of the sauce will cause the aluminum to leach into the sauce.)\nBring to a boil, reduce to a simmer. Cook uncovered for about 10 minutes.\n5 Sterilize jar lids: While the salsa is cooking, place the jar lids in a bowl and cover with boiling water to sterilize.\n6 Blend salsa if you want it to be more smooth: If you want your salsa to be more smooth than chunky, use an immersion blender to pulse it a few times, or working in batches ladle about half of it into a blender and pur\xc3\xa9e.\n7 Adjust seasonings: If too acidic to taste, add more sugar to balance the vinegar! If too sweet, add a bit more vinegar.\n8 Ladle salsa into canning jars and seal: Ladle salsa into canning jars, leaving 1/2-inch head space. Wipe the rims with a clean, dampened paper towel so that there is no residual food on the rims.\nPlace canning lids on the jars. Screw on the lid rings. Do not over-tighten or you may not get a good seal. Air does need to escape from the jars during the next step, the water bath.\n9 Boil in a water bath: Place the filled and lidded jars back onto the rack in the large stock-pot of hot water you used to sterilize the jars in step one. You may need to remove some of the water from the pot to prevent it from overfilling.\nCover the jars with at least 1-inch of water. Bring to a rolling boil and process for 15 minutes (20 minutes for altitudes 1000 to 6000 ft, 25 minutes above 6000 ft). Then turn off heat and let the jars sit in the hot water for 5 minutes.\n10 Let jars cool, lids should pop: Remove jars from the water bath and let sit on a counter for several hours until completely cool. The lids should "pop" as the cooling salsa creates a vacuum under the lid and the jars are sealed.\nIf a lid has not sealed, either replace the lid and reprocess in a water bath for another 15 minutes, or store in the refrigerator and use within the next few days.\nRemember to label the cans with the date processed. (I use a Sharpie on the lid.) Canned salsa should be eaten within a year.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nMeyer Lemon Marmalade Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes 6-8 half-pint (8-ounce) jars\nThis recipe calls for Meyer lemons, a hybrid of a regular lemon and an orange, that is thinner skinned and sweeter than a regular lemon. You cannot substitute regular lemons for Meyer lemons in this recipe.\nThe proportion of lemon segments to water to sugar is 1:1:1. So if you don\'t have a kitchen scale and don\'t weigh your lemons to begin with, as you proceed through this recipe keep in mind these proportions. Your 2 1/2 lbs of lemons should yield 6 cups of chopped lemon. 6 cups of chopped lemon will be cooked first with 6 cups of water, and then later 6 cups of sugar are added.\nYou can also do this recipe with 4 cups of chopped lemons, 4 cups of water, and 4 cups of sugar. Do not double the recipe.\nDo not reduce the sugar (if you want a reduced sugar recipe, use a different recipe); the sugar is needed for the jelly to set.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 lbs of Meyer lemons (about 9 lemons)\n6 cups water\n6 cups granulated sugar\nSpecial equipment:\n1 wide 6 or 8-quart pan (Stainless steel or copper with stainless steel lining, not aluminum which will leach)\nA sharp chef\'s knife\nA candy thermometer or instant-read thermometer (I use a thermapen or thermopop)\n6 half-pint (8-oz) canning jars\nCheesecloth, enough to double over and form a bag to hold the seeds for making pectin, or a Muslin jelly bag\nAdditional Equipment Recommended:\nFlexible plastic cutting board surface (to curl up to catch the lemon juice from the lemons to add to the fruit)\nDisposable latex or non-latex gloves to protect your hands from the acid from the lemons\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nPREPARING THE FRUIT\n1 Scrub the lemons clean. Discard any that are moldy or damaged.\n2 Prepare the lemons: Cut 1/4 inch off from the ends of the lemons. Working one at a time, stand a lemon on end. Cut the lemon in half lengthwise. Cut each lemon half into several segments, lengthwise.\nAs you cut the lemons into segments, if you can, pull off any exposed membranes. Just get the ones that are easy to get to, ignore the rest. When you\'ve cut down to the final segment, cut away the pithy core. Remove all seeds from the segments. Reserve the seeds and any removed membrane or pith. You will need them to make pectin.\nCut each lemon segment crosswise into even pieces to make little triangles of lemon peel and pulp.\n3 Put seeds, membranes, pith into cheesecloth or muslin bag: Put all of the seeds, membranes and pith you removed from the lemons into a bag fashioned out of two layers of cheesecloth or a muslin jelly bag.\n  FIRST STAGE OF COOKING\n4 Place the lemon segments and water into a large, wide pot.\n5 Secure pectin bag: Place the pectin bag in the pot with the fruit pulp and secure to the pot handle.\n6 Boil until peels are soft: Bring mixture to a strong boil on high heat. Let boil, uncovered, for about 25-35 minutes, until the peels are soft and cooked through. (If too much of the water evaporates from the boil and the peels start sticking to the bottom of the pan, add a little more water back in.)\nTest one of the lemon peel pieces by eating it. It should be very soft. If it is still chewy, keep cooking until soft.\nRemove from heat.\n7 Remove the pectin bag, place the pectin bag in a bowl and let cool until it is comfortable to touch.\nADD THE PECTIN AND SUGAR\n8 Squeeze pectin from pectin bag: Once your pectin bag has cooled to the point you can handle it, if you want, squeeze it like play-doh to extract any extra pectin. This is not necessary but will help ensure a good set. (I like to wear latex-type gloves for this part.) You should be able to get a teaspoon or two more from the bag. It has the consistency of sour cream. Return this pectin to the pan with the lemon mixture.\n9 Add sugar: Measure out your sugar and add it to the pan with the lemon mixture.\n  SECOND STAGE OF COOKING\n10 Boil and check temperature: Heat the jelly mixture on medium high and bring it to a rapid boil, stirring occasionally, making sure nothing is sticking to the bottom of the pan.\nAfter the jelly first comes to a boil, it will foam up considerably. this is why you need need to use a large pot, and make sure you pay attention and keep your eyes on the whole process. Stir with a wooden spoon to bring the foam back down. If it gets too high, lower the temperature to keep it from overflowing the pot.\nSecure a candy thermometer to the side of the pan, or check the jelly temperature with an instant read thermometer. The marmalade may take anywhere from 20 to 35 minutes or so to be ready to pour out. After about 15 minutes, start checking the temperature frequently.\n11 Test to see if the marmalade is at set point: There are two ways to test that the marmalade is ready to pour out into jars: the mixture reaching a temperature of 218-220\xc2\xb0F (6-8\xc2\xb0F above the boiling point at your altitude) OR putting a bit of it on a chilled plate "wrinkling up" when you push it with your finger tip. I steer off of the wrinkle test. If the sample of jelly wrinkles, it\'s ready. I use a thermometer just to help me gauge when to do the wrinkle test.\nFor the wrinkle test, place a small plate into the freezer. As the jelly temperature reaches 217\xc2\xb0F, start testing it by placing a small amount of the hot jelly on the chilled plate. If the jelly spreads out and thins immediately, it isn\'t ready. If it holds its shape a bit, like an egg yolk, that\'s a good sign. Push up against it with your finger tip. If the jelly sample wrinkles at all, it is time to take the jelly off the heat and pour it out into jars.\nWhen you use a candy thermometer or an insta-read thermometer to test the temperature of your mixture, make sure the probe is NOT touching the bottom of the pan. Make sure that the indentation on the probe (with modern candy thermometers this is about an inch and a half from the bottom of the probe) is actually surrounded by the mixture.
