This may mean that you have to tilt the pan to one side, to cover the probe sufficiently to get a good reading.\n  CANNING\n12 Sterilize canning jars: While the marmalade is in its second cooking stage, rinse out your canning jars, dry them, and place them, without lids, in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven. They should be in the oven at least 10 minutes before using them. This not only sterilizes the jars, but it helps to keep them from cracking from the temperature differential when you add the hot jelly mixture to them.\n13 Sterilize lids: As the time approaches for the marmalade to be done, boil some water in a tea pot. Put the jar lids in a glass or ceramic bowl and pour the boiling water over them to sterilize.\n14 Ladle marmalade into sterilized jars: Once the jelly has reached 218-220\xc2\xb0F or its "wrinkly" stage, remove the jelly pot from the heat. Carefully ladle the jelly into the jars, leaving 1/4 inch head space at the top of the jars for a vacuum seal.\n15 Clean rims, secure with lids and jar ring: Wipe the rim clean with a clean, wet paper towel. Place the lid on the jar, securing with a jar ring. Work quickly.\n16 Allow jars to cool and seal: Allow the jars to sit overnight. You will hear them make a popping sound as a vacuum seal is created.\nEven if the jelly is not firm as it goes into the jar (it shouldn\'t be), it should firm up as it cools.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nPomegranate Jelly Recipe\nYield: Makes 6 to 7 eight-ounce jars\nThe process of canning jelly is specific to what fruit you are canning, the type of pectin you are using - whether natural, liquid, powder - and the ratio of juice to sugar to pectin.\nIf you plan to store your jelly on a shelf, and not in the refrigerator, you need special canning equipment to ensure against spoilage.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups pomegranate juice\n1/4 cup lemon juice\n1 package SureJell powdered pectin*\n5 cups white cane sugar\n*If using MCP pectin, use 3 cups of pomegranate juice, 4 cups sugar, 1/4 cup lemon juice for one package of pectin\nSpecial equipment:\n6-7 Eight ounce canning jars\nFine mesh strainer\nSteaming rack for water bath\nMETHOD\n1 Make the Juice: There are two basic ways to make pomegranate juice from fresh pomegranates.\nThe first way is to cut open a pomegranate and submerge it in a large bowl filled with water. Remove the seeds underwater; they will sink to the bottom while the white membrane holding them together will float. Discard the peel and membranes.\nStrain the seeds and put them in a blender. Cover the blender. Pulse the blender only a few times so that the seeds are broken up. Place a mesh strainer over a bowl and pour the seed mixture through the strainer. Use a rubber spatula to help press the pulp against the strainer as to extract as much juice as possible.\nThe second way to juice a pomegranate is to use a juice press. I have an old fashioned press that I use. I wash the pomegranate and cut it into quarters or halves, depending on how big the pomegranate is.\nI then crush the sections with a press and strain the juice through a mesh strainer. I have found that this method takes half the time or less of the first method, but the flavor can be a little more bitter because you are squeezing the peel as well.\n2 Prepare canning jars: Seep the clean, empty canning jars in boiling water for several minutes. Boil a few cups of water in a separate kettle and pour over the lids in a small bowl to sterilize.\n3 Bring pomegranate juice, lemon juice, and pectin to a rolling boil: Measure pomegranate juice and lemon juice in a 6-quart pan. Add pectin, stir and place over high heat. Bring to a boil, stirring constantly to prevent scorching.\n4 Add sugar: When you reach a full rolling boil that cannot be stirred down, and add sugar. Return to a boil and boil hard for exactly 2 minutes. Remove from heat. Let stand for a minute and skim off foam.\n5 Fill jars: Fill jars to 1/2" of the top. Wipe rims clean. Screw on 2-piece lids.\n6 Water bath:  It helps to take this step if you plan to keep the jelly unrefrigerated. A water bath will give you a tighter seal.\nPlace the jelly jars, not touching, on a rack in a tall pot of boiling water. The water should cover the top of the jars by at least an inch. Boil for 5 minutes and then remove from the water.\nLet the jars cool. Check seals, the lids should be sucked down (you\'ll hear a popping noise as the jelly cools).\nOnce the jars reach room temperature, put them in the refrigerator for a few hours to complete the jellying. Lasts about 3 weeks once opened.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSeville Orange Marmalade Recipe\nYield: Makes 5-6 8-ounce jars\nIt\'s best to make just one batch at a time of this marmalade. I do not recommend experimenting with a double batch until you are comfortable making single batches.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 pounds (1.36 kg) of seville or bitter oranges (6 to 12 oranges, depending on the size of the oranges)\n6 to 8 cups water\n2 lemons - 1 regular lemon and 1 Meyer lemon\n5 to 6 cups white granulated sugar (or more to taste)\nSpecial equipment:\n1 wide 6 to 8-quart pan (stainless steel or copper with stainless steel lining, do not use aluminum which will leach, hard anodized aluminum is okay)\nA citrus juicer (an electric one will make the process easier, but you can use a hand juicer)\nA sharp chef\'s knife\nAn instant read digital thermometer or a candy thermometer\nA large (8 cup) measuring cup pourer\n6 to 8 8-oz canning jars\nA muslin jelly bag (for the pectin), or a large (18" diameter) round piece of muslin, or several pieces of cheesecloth that you can tie up into a bag\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nPREPARING THE FRUIT\n1 Scrub the oranges clean. Discard any that are damaged or soft.\n2 Cut the oranges in half and juice them. As you juice the oranges, save the seeds. Put the seeds into a separate bowl and set them aside. You will use the seeds to make natural pectin for the marmalade\n3 Cut the peels into narrow strips: Taking a clean juiced orange half rind, use a spoon to dig out segment membranes still attached to the inside. Put a few of these in with the seeds (segment membranes will also provide pectin).\nUse a sharp chef\'s knife to thinly julienne the peel. Once you julienne all of the oranges put the cut peels and the juice in a large (8-cup Pyrex works great) measuring cup.\n4 Juice the regular lemon and add this juice to the orange peels and juice. Save the seeds for making pectin.\n5 Prep the Meyer lemon: Cut the Meyer lemon in eighths, lengthwise. Remove the seeds and as much of the inner membranes as you can easily remove. Cut the lemon segments crosswise into triangular pieces. (See the steps in the Meyer lemon marmalade recipe for photo descriptions.)\nAdd the cut Meyer lemon to the measuring cup with the oranges.\nAdd the Meyer lemon seeds to the Seville orange seeds and membranes.\nYou should have 5 to 6 cups combined, of citrus peels and juices.\n6 Put seeds into cheesecloth or muslin bag: Put the citrus seeds and membranes into 4 layers of cheesecloth, tied up tightly with string, or into a muslin jelly bag. (I made a "pectin bag" which I use for making marmalade, by sewing up piece of plain muslin cloth into a bag with a drawstring at the end.)\nFIRST STAGE OF COOKING\n1 Put orange mixture into pot, add water: Place the orange and lemon juices and cut peels into a large, wide (6 to 8-quart) thick-bottomed pot.\nAdd 6 cups of water. (At this point you can soak overnight if you want. It will help the peels cook faster.)\n2 Secure pectin bag: Place the cheesecloth or muslin bag containing the citrus seeds and pulp into the pot, submerging it in the liquid, and secure the string at the other end to the pot handle.\nAs the mixture cooks, the pectin from the seeds and membranes will be extracted into the mixture.\n3 Boil until the peels are soft: Bring mixture to a boil. Let boil, uncovered, for 30 minutes (or longer), or until the peels are completely soft and cooked through.\nDepending on your particular fruit, it may take more time, and more water, to get to the point where the peels are soft. Once you add sugar to the mixture in the next step, the peels will firm up with the sugar, so it\'s very important that the peels in this first stage of cooking are completely soft.\nTest the orange peels as you go. Take a bite, if the peel is at all firm to the bite, it needs more cooking.\nIf the water has boiled down and the mixture starts to stick to the bottom of the pot, add more water, a cup at a time.\nWhen the peels are soft, remove from heat.\n4 Remove the pectin bag and place it in a bowl to let cool until it is comfortable to touch.\nMEASURE THE FRUIT AND ADD SUGAR AND PECTIN\n1 Measure the mixture: Pour out the mixture from the pot into a large measuring cup. Measure how much of the mixture you have. Depending on how hard of a boil and how long the cooking time, you could have anywhere from 4 to 5 cups. Return the mixture back to the pan.\n2 Add sugar: Add to the mixture 7/8 cup of sugar for every cup of mixture. So, if you measured 4 cups of mixture, add in 3 1/2 cups of sugar. Once the sugar has dissolved, taste the mixture. Add more sugar depending on how sweet you want your marmalade to be.\nNote that the jelly mixture will reduce further, intensifying both the flavor and the sweetness of the jelly. I typically use 4 cups of sugar for every 4 cups of fruit mixture, which produces a rather tart marmalade. Feel free to use more!\n3 Squeeze pectin from pectin bag: Once your pectin bag has cooled to the point you can handle it, squeeze it like play-doh to extract extra pectin. Grasp a tangerine size portion of the bag and squeeze, pulling the bag away from you with one hand as you hold firmly with the other hand. Work your way around the bag.\n"Milk" the pectin until you have released about a tablespoon of pectin. The pectin has the consistency of sour cream. Add it to the orange mixture.\nSECOND STAGE OF COOKING\n1 Boil and check temperature: Heat the jelly mixture on medium high and bring it to a rapid boil, stirring occasionally, making sure nothing is sticking to the bottom of the pan. Secure a candy thermometer to the side of the pan.\nThe marmalade may take anywhere from 15 to 30 minutes or so to set. After about 10 minutes, start checking it frequently.\n2 Test to see if the marmalade is at setting point: Once the mixture reaches a temperature of 218\xc2\xb0F it is close to the set point. It should set between 218\xc2\xb0F and 222\xc2\xb0F (or 6 to 10\xc2\xb0F above the boiling point at your altitude).\nYou can tell if the mixture has reached its set point by putting a small amount of the jelly liquid on a chilled plate, and looking for signs of it wrinkling when you push it with your finger tip.\nWhile thermometers aren\'t always accurate, the wrinkle test works. If the jelly wrinkles on a cold plate, it\'s ready.\nPut several small plates into the freezer to chill. As the marmalade temperature reaches 218\xc2\xb0F, start testing it by placing a small amount of the hot jelly on a chilled plate. If the jelly spreads out and thins immediately, it isn\'t ready. If it holds its shape a bit, that\'s a good sign. Let it cool on the plate for a few seconds.\nPush up against it with your finger tip. If the jelly sample wrinkles at all, it is time to take the jelly off the heat.\nIf it wrinkles even just a little, it\'s ready\nWhen you use a candy thermometer to test the temperature of your mixture, make sure the probe is NOT touching the bottom of the pan. Make sure the indentation on the probe (with modern candy thermometers this is about an inch and a half from the bottom of the probe) is actually surrounded by the mixture. You may have to tilt the pan to one side, to cover the probe sufficiently to get a good reading.\nOvercooking a marmalade will result in a caramelized flavor or tough orange peels in your marmalade.\nCANNING THE MARMALADE\n1 Sterilize the canning jars: There are several ways to sterilize your jars for canning. You can run them through a short cycle on your dishwasher.\nYou can place them in a large pot (12 quart) of water on top of a steaming rack (so they don\'t touch the bottom of the pan), and bring the water to a boil for 10 minutes.\nOr you can rinse out the jars, dry them, and place them, without lids, in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\n2 Sterilize the lids: As the time approaches for the marmalade to be done, boil some water in a tea pot. Put the jar lids in a glass or ceramic bowl and pour the boiling water over them to sterilize.\n3 Ladle jam into sterilized jars: Once the jelly has reached its set point, remove the jelly pot from the heat. Let the jelly sit in the pot for a couple minutes (that will help keep the peels from floating in the jars).\nCarefully pour or ladle the marmalade into the jars, one at a time, leaving 1/4 inch head space at the top of the jars for a vacuum seal.\n4 Clean rims, secure with lids and jar ring: Wipe the rim clean with a clean, wet paper towel. Place the lid on the jar, securing with a jar ring. Work quickly.\n5 Process in water bath (optional): If you want, you can process the jars in a hot water bath for 5 minutes to help get a better seal and to help prevent mold. If you used boiling water in an earlier step to sterilize the jars, you can just keep the same set-up for the water bath. You want to make sure there is a rack at the bottom of the pot so that the jars aren\'t actually resting on the bottom of the pot.\n6 Allowing the jars to seal: Once you have sealed the jars with a lid and ring, and have water bathed (or not) the jars, let them sit on your kitchen counter. As the marmalade cools, you\'ll hear a popping noise as a vacuum is created in the headspace of the jars, pulling the lids down.\nSometimes the marmalade orange peels float to the top of the jar, so to help keep that from happening, turn the jars upside down for half an hour at a time. Keep turning every 30 minutes or so until the marmalade seems stable and the peels are well distributed through the marmalade.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nMeyer Lemon Marmalade Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes 6-8 half-pint (8-ounce) jars\nThis recipe calls for Meyer lemons, a hybrid of a regular lemon and an orange, that is thinner skinned and sweeter than a regular lemon. You cannot substitute regular lemons for Meyer lemons in this recipe.\nThe proportion of lemon segments to water to sugar is 1:1:1. So if you don\'t have a kitchen scale and don\'t weigh your lemons to begin with, as you proceed through this recipe keep in mind these proportions. Your 2 1/2 lbs of lemons should yield 6 cups of chopped lemon. 6 cups of chopped lemon will be cooked first with 6 cups of water, and then later 6 cups of sugar are added.\nYou can also do this recipe with 4 cups of chopped lemons, 4 cups of water, and 4 cups of sugar. Do not double the recipe.\nDo not reduce the sugar (if you want a reduced sugar recipe, use a different recipe); the sugar is needed for the jelly to set.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 lbs of Meyer lemons (about 9 lemons)\n6 cups water\n6 cups granulated sugar\nSpecial equipment:\n1 wide 6 or 8-quart pan (Stainless steel or copper with stainless steel lining, not aluminum which will leach)\nA sharp chef\'s knife\nA candy thermometer or instant-read thermometer (I use a thermapen or thermopop)\n6 half-pint (8-oz) canning jars\nCheesecloth, enough to double over and form a bag to hold the seeds for making pectin, or a Muslin jelly bag\nAdditional Equipment Recommended:\nFlexible plastic cutting board surface (to curl up to catch the lemon juice from the lemons to add to the fruit)\nDisposable latex or non-latex gloves to protect your hands from the acid from the lemons\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nPREPARING THE FRUIT\n1 Scrub the lemons clean. Discard any that are moldy or damaged.\n2 Prepare the lemons: Cut 1/4 inch off from the ends of the lemons. Working one at a time, stand a lemon on end. Cut the lemon in half lengthwise. Cut each lemon half into several segments, lengthwise.\nAs you cut the lemons into segments, if you can, pull off any exposed membranes. Just get the ones that are easy to get to, ignore the rest. When you\'ve cut down to the final segment, cut away the pithy core. Remove all seeds from the segments. Reserve the seeds and any removed membrane or pith. You will need them to make pectin.\nCut each lemon segment crosswise into even pieces to make little triangles of lemon peel and pulp.\n3 Put seeds, membranes, pith into cheesecloth or muslin bag: Put all of the seeds, membranes and pith you removed from the lemons into a bag fashioned out of two layers of cheesecloth or a muslin jelly bag.\n  FIRST STAGE OF COOKING\n4 Place the lemon segments and water into a large, wide pot.\n5 Secure pectin bag: Place the pectin bag in the pot with the fruit pulp and secure to the pot handle.\n6 Boil until peels are soft: Bring mixture to a strong boil on high heat. Let boil, uncovered, for about 25-35 minutes, until the peels are soft and cooked through. (If too much of the water evaporates from the boil and the peels start sticking to the bottom of the pan, add a little more water back in.)\nTest one of the lemon peel pieces by eating it. It should be very soft. If it is still chewy, keep cooking until soft.\nRemove from heat.\n7 Remove the pectin bag, place the pectin bag in a bowl and let cool until it is comfortable to touch.\nADD THE PECTIN AND SUGAR\n8 Squeeze pectin from pectin bag: Once your pectin bag has cooled to the point you can handle it, if you want, squeeze it like play-doh to extract any extra pectin. This is not necessary but will help ensure a good set. (I like to wear latex-type gloves for this part.) You should be able to get a teaspoon or two more from the bag. It has the consistency of sour cream. Return this pectin to the pan with the lemon mixture.\n9 Add sugar: Measure out your sugar and add it to the pan with the lemon mixture.\n  SECOND STAGE OF COOKING\n10 Boil and check temperature: Heat the jelly mixture on medium high and bring it to a rapid boil, stirring occasionally, making sure nothing is sticking to the bottom of the pan.\nAfter the jelly first comes to a boil, it will foam up considerably. this is why you need need to use a large pot, and make sure you pay attention and keep your eyes on the whole process. Stir with a wooden spoon to bring the foam back down. If it gets too high, lower the temperature to keep it from overflowing the pot.\nSecure a candy thermometer to the side of the pan, or check the jelly temperature with an instant read thermometer. The marmalade may take anywhere from 20 to 35 minutes or so to be ready to pour out. After about 15 minutes, start checking the temperature frequently.\n11 Test to see if the marmalade is at set point: There are two ways to test that the marmalade is ready to pour out into jars: the mixture reaching a temperature of 218-220\xc2\xb0F (6-8\xc2\xb0F above the boiling point at your altitude) OR putting a bit of it on a chilled plate "wrinkling up" when you push it with your finger tip. I steer off of the wrinkle test. If the sample of jelly wrinkles, it\'s ready. I use a thermometer just to help me gauge when to do the wrinkle test.\nFor the wrinkle test, place a small plate into the freezer. As the jelly temperature reaches 217\xc2\xb0F, start testing it by placing a small amount of the hot jelly on the chilled plate. If the jelly spreads out and thins immediately, it isn\'t ready. If it holds its shape a bit, like an egg yolk, that\'s a good sign. Push up against it with your finger tip. If the jelly sample wrinkles at all, it is time to take the jelly off the heat and pour it out into jars.\nWhen you use a candy thermometer or an insta-read thermometer to test the temperature of your mixture, make sure the probe is NOT touching the bottom of the pan. Make sure that the indentation on the probe (with modern candy thermometers this is about an inch and a half from the bottom of the probe) is actually surrounded by the mixture. This may mean that you have to tilt the pan to one side, to cover the probe sufficiently to get a good reading.\n  CANNING\n12 Sterilize canning jars: While the marmalade is in its second cooking stage, rinse out your canning jars, dry them, and place them, without lids, in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven. They should be in the oven at least 10 minutes before using them. This not only sterilizes the jars, but it helps to keep them from cracking from the temperature differential when you add the hot jelly mixture to them.\n13 Sterilize lids: As the time approaches for the marmalade to be done, boil some water in a tea pot. Put the jar lids in a glass or ceramic bowl and pour the boiling water over them to sterilize.\n14 Ladle marmalade into sterilized jars: Once the jelly has reached 218-220\xc2\xb0F or its "wrinkly" stage, remove the jelly pot from the heat. Carefully ladle the jelly into the jars, leaving 1/4 inch head space at the top of the jars for a vacuum seal.\n15 Clean rims, secure with lids and jar ring: Wipe the rim clean with a clean, wet paper towel. Place the lid on the jar, securing with a jar ring. Work quickly.\n16 Allow jars to cool and seal: Allow the jars to sit overnight. You will hear them make a popping sound as a vacuum seal is created.\nEven if the jelly is not firm as it goes into the jar (it shouldn\'t be), it should firm up as it cools.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nEscabeche (Pickled Jalape\xc3\xb1os) Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes about 4 to 5 pint jars\nRecipe adapted from Diana Kennedy's The Essential Cuisines of Mexico.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound jalape\xc3\xb1o (and/or serrano if you wish) chile peppers\n1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2-3 medium white or yellow onions, thickly sliced\n2-3 medium carrots, peeled and thickly sliced\nFlorets from half a small cauliflower (optional)\n1 head garlic, cloves separated but not peeled\n4 cups apple cider vinegar\n2 tablespoons Kosher salt or sea salt\n2 bay leaves\n1/2 teaspoon dried oregano\n4 sprigs fresh marjoram (can sub fresh oregano) or 1/4 teaspoon dried\n4 sprigs fresh thyme or 1/4 teaspoon dried\n1 tablespoon sugar\nSpecial equipment:\n4 - 5 pint-size canning jars\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the chiles: Wash the chiles, leaving the stems intact. Cut a cross in the tip end of each chile so that the vinegar will be able to penetrate the chiles.\n2 Fry the vegetables in olive oil: Heat olive oil in a large, deep skillet. Add the chiles, onions, carrots, cauliflower if using, and garlic. Fry over medium heat for about 10 minutes, turning them over occasionally.\n3 Boil with vinegar and seasonings: Add the vinegar, salt, bay leaves, dried oregano, marjoram, thyme, and sugar and bring to a boil. Lower the heat and simmer for 10 minutes.\nMake sure the chiles are entirely cooked through before canning. You will know they are cooked when they are no longer vibrant green, but a dull, olive green.\n4 Pack  the jars: Pack 4 to 5 pint-sized sterilized jars with the chiles and vegetables. Top with the vinegar cooking liquid and seal.\n5 Process in a hot water bath for 10 minutes.\nOnce opened, can keep for one to two months in the refrigerator.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBasic Pickling Spice Blend Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: about 1/2 cup (enough for about 16 pints of pickles)\nUse as many or as few of the spices below to created your own signature spice blend. I recommend using mustard seeds, black peppercorns or red pepper flakes, and at least one of the sweet spices (allspice, cinnamon, or cloves), and then as many of the other spices as you like.\nAll spices are whole spices. Do not substitute ground spices.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cinnamon stick (or 1 tablespoon cinnamon chunks)\n2 bay leaves\n2 tablespoons yellow mustard seeds\n2 tablespoons coriander seeds\n1 tablespoon black peppercorns\n1 tablespoon dill seeds\n1 teaspoon allspice berries\n1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes\n1 teaspoon dried minced ginger (optional)\n8 whole cloves\nMETHOD\n1 Crush the cinnamon and bay leaves: In a mortar and pestle or electric spice grinder, break down the cinnamon stick into small (about 1/4-inch) pieces. Transfer to a small bowl, then repeat with the bay leaves, crushing them into small pieces of about the same size. Transfer them to the bowl as well.\n2 Mix up the spice blend: Stir in the rest of the spices. Use a small funnel to transfer the mixture to a spice jar, or use it right away. The spices will keep in a tightly-lidded jar for up to 1 year.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nJalapeno Pepper Jelly Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 20 minutesMash straining time: Several hoursYield: Makes 4-5 half-pint jars of jelly\nTart green apples have more pectin in them than sweet apples, so use tart green apples for this recipe, earlier in the season the better. This is especially true if you are not also using cranberries, as cranberries have their own natural pectin as well.\nJalape\xc3\xb1o jelly can be pretty "hot" if you have included a lot of the seeds in your cooking. The jelly is great served on crackers with cream cheese because the fat molecules in the cream cheese absorb the hot capsaicin of the jalape\xc3\xb1os, reducing the heat, but leaving the flavor of the chiles. This is also why sour cream tastes so good with spicy Mexican food.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 lbs of tart apples (e.g. Granny Smith), unpeeled, chopped into big pieces, including the cores\n6 jalape\xc3\xb1o chili peppers, sliced in half lengthwise, the seeds and ribs removed from 3 of them (for mildly hot jelly. If you want a hotter jelly leave the seeds and ribs in all of them.)\n1 green bell pepper (or red if you want the color), seeds and ribs removed, chopped\n1 cup cranberries (optional but recommended, will help with color and with setting)\n3 cups water\n3 cups white vinegar\n3 1/2 cups sugar (7/8 cup for each cup of juice)\nSpecial equipment:\nOne 6-quart pan (Stainless steel or copper with stainless steel)\nA digital thermometer\nA large fine mesh sieve (or several layers of cheesecloth, or a muslin cloth jelly bag)\n4-5 half-pint canning jars\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Boil and mash the apples, jalape\xc3\xb1os, bell pepper, and cranberries: Combine the apple pieces, apple cores (needed for their pectin content), jalape\xc3\xb1os, bell pepper, cranberries (if using), water and vinegar in a large pot.\nBring to a boil and then reduce heat to medium-low, simmering for about 20 minutes, or until the apples, cranberries, and peppers are soft. Stir occasionally to make sure nothing is sticking to the bottom of the pan where it might burn.\nUse a potato masher to mash up the apple pieces to the consistency of slightly runny apple sauce. If the mash is too thick, add more water.\n2 Strain through a fine mesh sieve or cheesecloth: Spoon the mash into a fine mesh sieve, muslin cloth, or a couple layers of cheesecloth, suspended over a large bowl. Leave to strain for several hours (even overnight).\nIf you want a clear jelly, do not squeeze or force through the mesh. Just let it drip. If you want a fuller flavor jelly and don\'t mind that the result won\'t be clear, you can force some of the pulp through the mesh.\nIf your pulp is too thick, and nothing is coming out, you can add an extra 1/2 cup or cup of water to it. You want to end up with about 4 cups of juice.\n3 Add sugar to juice, heat to dissolve: Measure the juice, then pour into a large, wide, thick-bottomed pot. Add the sugar (7/8 a cup for each cup of juice). Heat gently, stirring to make sure the sugar gets dissolved and doesn\'t stick to the bottom of the pan and burn.\n4 Boil until setting point: Bring to a boil. Cook for 10-15 minutes, using a spoon to skim off the surface scum.\nContinue to boil until a digital thermometer shows that the temperature has reached 220-222\xc2\xb0F (8-10\xc2\xb0F above the boiling point at your altitude).\nAdditional time needed for cooking can be anywhere from 10 minutes to an hour or longer, depending on the amount of water, sugar, and apple pectin in the mix.\n\nLeft: Jelly is too runny. Right: Jelly is wrinkling when pushed, which means it\'s ready.\nA thermometer reading isn\'t always the most reliable indicator of whether or not a jelly is done. Another way to test is put a half teaspoonful of the jelly on a chilled (in the freezer) plate. Allow the jelly to cool a few seconds, then push it with your fingertip. If it wrinkles up, it\'s ready.\n5 Can in jars: Pour jelly into sterilized jars* to within 1/4" from the top and seal.\nMakes approx. 4 half-pint jars.\nServe with cream cheese on crackers.\n*There are several ways to sterilize your jars for canning jelly. You can run them through a short cycle on your dishwasher. You can place them in a large pot (12 quart) of water on top of a steaming rack (so they don\'t touch the bottom of the pan), and bring the water to a boil for 10 minutes. Or you can rinse out the jars, dry them, and place them, without lids, in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nMarinated Roasted Red Bell Peppers Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 40 minutesWater bath time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 3 pint jars\nRecipe adapted from Eugenia Bone\'s fabulous canning book Well-Preserved and a marinated pepper recipe from University of Minnesota.\nUser water bath method instructions if canning for shelf storage, otherwise just use clean jars and lids and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 weeks.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 pounds firm, fresh, clean red bell peppers\n1 cup bottled lemon juice*\n2 cups white vinegar (5%)\n1 cup extra virgin olive oil + additional for roasting the peppers\n2 cloves garlic, quartered\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n3 pint canning jars\n*Bottle lemon juice has a consistent level of acidity which you need for this canning recipe.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare water bath and mason jars if canning: If you are canning for shelf storage (and not just chilling in the refrigerator), place a steaming rack at the bottom of a large (12-qt) pot, add the empty mason jars that you will be using for canning.\nFill the pot with enough water to cover the jars and bring to a boil. It takes a while to get a large pot of water to boil, so while the water is heating, proceed with the recipe.\n2a Blacken Peppers, Broiler Method Position rack in oven so that the top surface of bell peppers placed in the oven will be 4-5 inches from the broiler heat element. Rub the surface of the peppers with a little olive oil (this will help them blister faster).\nPreheat broiler on high. Place peppers either directly on the top oven rack, with a pan to catch the drippings on a rack beneath, or place on a aluminum-foil or Silpat lined broiler pan (a cookie sheet will warp).\nAs the surface of the peppers blister and blacken, turn them with tongs so that they will blacken on all sides.\n2b Blacken Peppers, Stovetop Method If you have a gas range (or grill) you can place the peppers directly on the range top so that the flames lick the peppers. Work carefully so that as soon as one section of a pepper is blackened, you turn it to work on a fresh side.\nIf you have an electric stove, heat a cast iron pan on high and place the peppers in the pan, allowing the peel to blister and blacken, turning so that all sides get blackened.\n3 Remove blackened peel: When the peppers are all well blistered and blackened, place in a non-reactive bowl and cover. (The steam from the hot peppers will help dislodge the skins.)\nOnce the peppers have cooled enough to handle, work with them one by one over a plate, gently peel off the blackened skins.\nCut the peppers in half and remove and discard the seed pods, stems and all seeds.\n4 Heat lemon juice, white vinegar, olive oil, garlic, and salt, in a saucepan until boiling.\n5 Sterilize the lids: If canning for shelf storage, remove some boiling water from the pot of boiling water in step one and place into a bowl. Put the lids in that bowl.\n6 Distribute peppers and vinegar mixture in jars: Use tongs or a jar lifter to remove mason jars from the boiling water in step 1 (if canning). Distribute the peppers evenly among the jars. Pour the hot vinegar mixture over the peppers to cover (try to make sure some garlic gets in each jar).\nLeave 1/2-inch head space on the jars. Wipe the rims with a clean, dampened paper towel. Place on lids and rings (do not tighten rings too tight).\nAt this point you can store in the refrigerator for several weeks. If you want longer storage, or shelf storage, proceed.\n7 Water bath for canning: Place filled jars in boiling water on a rack (from step 1). (Helps to use tongs and wear thick rubber gloves). Water should cover jars by at least an inch. Boil for 15 minutes.\nLet cool in pot for several minutes, remove. Let cool completely. You should hear the jars "pop" as the lids seal.\nIf a jar does not seal, store it in the refrigerator and use up within a few weeks. Otherwise the jars should last a year.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHow to Make Easy Refrigerator Pickles\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 minutesPickling time: 24 hoursYield: 2 pint jars of pickles\nYou can use this method to make pickle spears as well! They\'ll need to pickle for 2 to 3 days in the fridge before they\'re ready.\nAs is, the recipe makes a fairly sweet pickle. You can cut the sugar in half for a more sour and tart pickle, if desired.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Kirby or other small cucumbers\n1 small sweet yellow onion\n1 cup apple cider vinegar\n1 cup water\n1/4 cup granulated sugar\n1 tablespoon kosher salt\n1 1/2 teaspoons pickling spice, homemade or store-bought\nSpecial equipment:\n2 wide-mouth pint canning jars\nCanning jar lids, plastic or metal\nMandoline, or sharp knife\nCanning funnel (helpful, but not essential)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Wash and dry the jars and cucumbers: Wash 2 wide-mouth pint jars and their lids in hot, soapy water. Set them aside to dry.\nRinse the cucumbers well under cold water, pat them dry, and then set them on a towel to dry completely.\n2 Slice the cucumbers and onion, then pack them in the jars: With a sharp knife or a mandoline slicer, slice the cucumbers and onion into slices 1/8- to 1/4-inch thick.\nFirmly pack the cucumbers and onions into the jars, fitting in as many as you can without smashing the vegetables. Leave 1/2-inch or so of headspace at the top of the jars.\n3 Make the brine: In a small saucepan over medium-high heat, bring the vinegar, water, sugar, salt, and pickling spice up to a simmer. Stir occasionally and continue simmering until the sugar and salt are dissolved.\n4 Pour the brine over the vegetables: If you have a canning funnel, use it here to make it easier to fill the jars. Carefully pour or ladle the hot brine into each jar, filling the jars until the cucumbers and onions are covered. It\'s ok if a few small pieces poke out the top.\n5 Cool and refrigerate for 24 hours: Screw on the lids, then let the jars cool to room temperature (about an hour). The cucumbers will start off bright green, but will become darker and more "pickle-colored" as they cool.\nPlace them in the refrigerator. Wait at least 24 hours before eating the pickles in order to let the flavors develop. Use them within one month.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nGreen Tomato Chutney Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Makes 6 8-ounce jars, or 3 pint jars\nThese instructions include instructions for canning the green tomato chutney. If you plan on storing in the refrigerator and using up within a few months, you can skip the sterilization and canning steps (steps 1 and 4).\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 pounds firm green tomatoes, about 7 cups, cored and chopped\n1 1/4 cups brown sugar, packed\n1 cup chopped red onion\n1 cup golden raisins\n1 cup cider vinegar\n2 Tbsp chopped candied ginger\n1 Tbsp mustard seeds\n1 teaspoon chili pepper flakes\n1 teaspoon fennel seeds\n1 teaspoon of salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground allspice\n1/8 teaspoon ground cloves\n1 cinnamon stick\nPinch of ground nutmeg\nSpecial equipment:\n3 pint jars or 6 8-ounce jars for canning\nSteamer rack\nJar lifter (helpful for lifting jars out of boiling water)\nLarge 16-quart pot\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sterilize the jars and lids: Place a steamer rack in a large (16 quart) pot, and place the jars on the rack. Fill the jars and the pot with water up to the rim of the jars.\nIf you don't have a rack you can place a clean dish towel at the base of the pot. You want to prevent the glass jars from touching the bottom of the pot which can get quite hot and cause the glass to crack.\nPut the burner on high and heat until a rolling boil. Boil for 10 minutes. To sterilize the lids, place them in a bowl and pour boiling water over them.\n2 Put all ingredients into a large pot and cook them 45 minutes: Place all of the ingredients in a medium sized (about 4 qt) thick-bottomed pot.\nBring to a boil and reduce to a simmer. Cover and cook for 45 minutes. Taste and adjust seasonings.\n3 Scoop chutney into jars: Remove the jars from the pot of hot water (reserving the water if you plan to can for shelf storage.). Scoop the green tomato chutney into the jars, filling them to 1/4 of an inch from the rim.\nWipe the rims with a clean wet paper towel. Place sterilized lids on the jars. Secure with canning rings.\n4 Process filled jars in a water bath: Place the filled jars back on the steamer rack in the pot of hot water. Make sure the jars are covered with an inch of water.\nBring to a boil and process for 15 minutes, or 20 minutes if you are at altitudes between 1000 and 6000 feet.\nRemove the jars from the pot and place on a dish towel spread out on your counter. Allow the jars to cool completely.\nThe jar lids should make a popping sound as they seal. If a lid doesn't seal for some reason, store the jar in the refrigerator.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nMicrowave Strawberry Jam Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesMacerating time: 30 minutesYield: 1 1/2 cups of jam\nThe best strawberries for making strawberry jam are those that are firm and not soft, overly ripe, or too sweet.\nYou can sub 1/2 cup of the strawberries for 1/2 cup of chopped orange segments for more orange flavor. Just don't use more than 2 1/2 cups of fruit or your bowl may overflow in the microwave.\nYou can swap out some of the lemon juice with balsamic vinegar.\nA tiny pinch of finely ground black pepper added in step 1 can add some zing to the jam.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 cups hulled and quartered strawberries (from about 1 pound)\n2 teaspoons orange zest\n2 Tbsp lemon juice\n1/2 cup sugar (can reduce to 1/4 cup if you would like your jam less sweet)\nSpecial equipment:\nAn 8-cup Pyrex measuring cup OR a large microwave safe bowl (no metal)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toss berries with orange zest, lemon juice, sugar: Place the quartered strawberries, orange zest, lemon juice, and sugar in a large microwave-safe bowl (at least 10 cup capacity) or 8-cup Pyrex measuring cup.\nGently toss to combine so that the strawberries are well coated with the sugar. Let sit for 30 minutes at room temp to macerate.\n2 Microwave in 5 min intervals: Place bowl with strawberries on a plate (to catch possible overflow) in your microwave oven. Cook on high for intervals of 5 minutes each, gently stirring after each 5 minute interval.\nIn my 1650 Watt microwave, I use 3 intervals of 5 minutes each for a total of 15 minutes. If you have a lower powered microwave, you may need to cook longer, or if you have a higher powered microwave, you may need less time.\nPay attention so that the mixture doesn't overflow. If it bubbles up too much and begins to overflow, put the mixture in a larger (microwave safe) bowl and continue.\nThe jam mixture will be ready when the liquid in it thickens slightly and gets syrupy. Because it is hot, it will not be thick like regular jam. As it cools it should thicken.\n3 Pour into jar, let cool, then chill: Pour the hot jam into a jar. Let cool to room temperature then store in the refrigerator.\nIf the jam is too loose and watery even after it has chilled, it may need to be microwaved for several minutes longer.\nIf you want your jam to be shelf stable, use the full amount of recommended sugar (1/2 cup), use sterilized jars and lids, and leave 1/4 inch headspace from the top of the jar. Otherwise, store in the refrigerator, or freeze (leaving an inch headspace in the jar to account for the expansion of the liquid as it freezes into ice).\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nEasy Microwave Fig Jam Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes one pint, or two 8-ounce jars\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups diced fresh figs (6-10 figs, depending on the size of the figs)\n1/2 cup seeded, peeled orange, diced\n1 1/2 cups of sugar (reduce if you want, though it won't set as well)\n1 1/2 teaspoons grated orange peel\n3 Tbsp lemon juice\n1/4 teaspoon ground ginger\n1/4 teaspoon ground cloves\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon butter\nSpecial equipment:\n2 (8-ounce) canning jars\n2-quart (8-cup) pyrex measuring cup or large microwave-proof bowl\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Macerate fruit in sugar: Place the ingredients in a large ceramic or glass bowl or casserole (we use a 2-quart pyrex measuring cup), stir to combine, let sit for 30 minutes for the fruit to macerate in the sugar.\n2 Cook in microwave: Place in microwave. You will cook the fruit mixture on the high setting for approximately 15 minutes.\nAs soon as the mixture starts to boil, after about 6 to 8 minutes, stop the cooking and stir. Continue cooking and stir every few minutes.\nAt about 13 minutes the mixture should start to get viscous. If you spoon out a bit on to a small plate that has been in the freezer, you can push the mixture around a bit with your finger tip to see how thick it is.\nIf it is runny, cook it a couple minutes more. You can also check by seeing how the jam runs off of a spoon. If it seems to firm up a bit as it drips, it's done.\nIf you use a large pyrex measuring cup as we have done here, you can see that you start with close to 3 cups of liquid. You want to boil it down to 2 cups.\n3 Pour into jars: Pour out the jam into jars, leaving 1/4-inch of headroom from the top of the jars. If you want to keep your jam in a cupboard, then use sterilized jars (heat them in the oven at 200\xc2\xb0F for 10 minutes). If you plan to eat up quickly and will keep them in the refrigerator, regular clean jars will do.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nJalape\xc3\xb1o Bread and Butter Pickles Recipe\nPrep time: 4 hours, 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 2 quarts\nI highly recommend that you wear protective gloves while cutting and de-seeding the jalape\xc3\xb1os. If you don't have gloves, you can protect your hands with plastic baggies. If you must handle the cut peppers with your bare hands, rub a little vegetable oil over your hands first. The oil will provide your pores with some protection.\nWash your hands thoroughly with warm soapy water after handling the peppers. Do not touch your eyes for several hours.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds jalape\xc3\xb1o chile peppers\n1 pound white or yellow onions, thinly sliced\n1/4 cup pickling salt (can use Kosher salt or sea salt as a substitute, regular table salt has additives in it that will darken your pickles and make the color of the pickle juice muddy)\n1 1/4 cup white distilled vinegar\n1 cup apple cider vinegar\n2 1/4 cups sugar\n1 tablespoon mustard seeds\n1 star anise\n1 cardamom pod\n3/4 teaspoon celery seeds\n1 inch cinnamon stick\n6 whole cloves\n1/2 teaspoon turmeric\nSpecial equipment:\n2 clean 1-quart canning jars, or 4 pint jars\nMETHOD\n1 Prep the jalape\xc3\xb1os: Cut the stem end off of the jalape\xc3\xb1os. Then cut them in half lengthwise. Remove and discard the seeds and the ribs.\n2 Salt peppers and onions, cover with ice, chill: Place the peppers in a large bowl. Add the onions and stir in the pickling salt so that it is well distributed. Cover the peppers with a clean, thin towel. Put ice over the towel and place the bowl in the refrigerator to chill for at 4 hours.\n3 Rinse and drain the peppers and onions: After the jalape\xc3\xb1os and onions have been chilling for 4 hours, rinse the salt off of the peppers and onions. Drain, and rinse and drain again.\n4 Make pickling solution: In a 4 or 6 quart pot, put the vinegar, sugar, and spices. Bring to a boil to dissolve the sugar.\n5 Boil peppers and onions in pickling solution: Add the peppers and onions to the pot with the pickling solution. Bring to a boil again.\n6 Pack jars with peppers and onions: Watch the jalape\xc3\xb1o peppers. As soon as they are all cooked through (you can tell because their color changes from a vibrant to a more dull green), start packing your canning jars with the peppers and onions, using a slotted spoon to remove them from the pan.\nPack the jars evenly with the peppers and onions, up to about an inch from the top of the jars.\nThen pour the sugary vinegar mixture over the peppers, until it covers them.\n7 Seal and chill: Cover the jars and let cool to room temperature before chilling in the refrigerator.\nIf you are planning to store outside of the refrigerator or for an extended period of time, use canning jars. Sterilize your jars and lids first. Wipe the rims of the jars after you pack them with pickles. Process in a water bath for 10 minutes. For specific canning instructions, see more detailed instructions on our bread and butter pickle recipe post.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nApricot Riesling Jam Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Makes four 8 oz. jars\nMost of the alcohol cooks out and leaves a delightful flavor that I encourage you try, but if you don\'t want to use wine, just substitute with water. This recipe can be easily doubled; if doubling, use an 8-quart pot.\nINGREDIENTS\n5 cups of chopped apricots, pits discarded*\n2 + 3/4 cups of sugar\n1/3 cup of Riesling (or Gew\xc3\xbcrztraminer)\n5 tablespoons of lemon juice\nMETHOD\n1 Place a couple small plates in the freezer, these will be used to test the jam later.\n2 Bring apricots, sugar, wine, lemon juice to a boil: Place the apricots, sugar, wine, and lemon juice in a large (at least 4-qt), thick-bottomed, stainless steel pot and bring to a boil over medium-high heat.\n3 Skim the foam, gently stir: The mixture will boil and rise in volume. Skim off the pale yellow foam that forms at the top and discard. The boil will subside to larger bubbles, but still bubble vigorously. Be sure to begin gently stirring the jam frequently to prevent it from sticking to the bottom.\n4 Test jam on cold plate: After about 25 minutes begin testing the jam by placing a small amount on a cold plate. Allow 30 seconds to pass and then run your finger through it to see what the cooled consistency will be. Boil for a few minutes longer if desired for a thicker jam.\n5 Ladle into jars: Ladle into hot, sterilized canning jars** and seal leaving 1/4 inch of head space. Before applying the lids, sterilize the lids by placing them in a bowl and pouring boiling water over them. Wipe the rims of the jars clean before applying the lids.\nWill keep for up to a year.\n* If you want, you can use a few of the kernels from the pits to give your jam a slight almond-y flavor. Roast the pits at 350 for about 10 minutes. Take them and crack them open with a hammer (do outside on concrete), and extract the kernel. Roast the "nuts" for a couple of minutes. Pop one or two in each sterilized jar when you pour the jam in.\n** To sterilize the jars, rinse out clean Mason jars, dry them, and place them, without lids, upright in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nPlum Conserve Jam Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes 5 to 6 pints\nINGREDIENTS\n7 cups seeded, chopped tart plums (about 3 pounds)\n4 cups sugar\n1 navel orange, thinly sliced, including rind\n1 lemon, thinly sliced, including rind, seeds removed\n3 1/2 cups raisins\n1 cup chopped walnuts\nSpecial equipment:\n6 pint-sized mason jars\n1 large 6 to 8-quart sized pan (Stainless steel, do not use aluminum which will leach)\nA ladle or pour cup for transferring the conserve from the pan to the jars\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare jars for canning: Prepare jars for canning in any of the following ways: You can run them through a short cycle on your dishwasher.\nYou can place them in a large pot (12 quart) of water on top of a steaming rack (so they don't touch the bottom of the pan), and bring the water to a boil for 10 minutes.\nOr you can rinse out the jars, dry them, and place them, without lids, in a 200\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes.\n2 Put plums, sugar, orange, lemon, and raisins into a large 6 or 8-quart pan. Heat until boiling. Gently boil for 20 to 25 minutes, stirring frequently, or until the mixture starts to thicken slightly.\nIf you want, use kitchen shears to cut some of the longer citrus rinds.\nStir in walnuts.\n3 Carefully ladle the conserve into the jars, one at a time, leaving 1/4 inch head space at the top of the jars for a vacuum seal.\nWipe the rim clean with a clean, wet paper towel. Place the lid on the jar, securing with a jar ring.\nAllow the jars to sit overnight. You will hear them make a popping sound as a vacuum seal is created.\nHello!
