b"Save It Print\nMelon Sorbet Recipe\nPrep time: 50 minutesChilling time: 3 hoursYield: Each recipe makes approximately 1 quart.\nMuskmelon, Canary melon, or any other type of melon can be used in these recipes. Watermelons may work too, but I haven't tested it with these recipes.\nINGREDIENTS\nCantaloupe Sorbet\n5 cups of diced cantaloupe (about 2 1/2 - 3 pounds)\n2/3 cup of sugar\n1/2 cup of water\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n2 tablespoons of light corn syrup\n1/4 cup of lemon or lime juice\nPinch of salt\nHoneydew Sorbet\n5 cups of diced honeydew (about 2 1/2 - 3 pounds)\n1/2 cup of mint leaves, well packed\n2/3 cup of sugar\n1/2 cup of water\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n2 tablespoons of light corn syrup\n1 tablespoon of lemon juice\nPinch of salt\nMETHOD\n1 Prep the melons: Cut the melons open and scoop out the strings and seeds and discard them. Carefully cut off the rind and discard that as well. Cut up each melon and one at a time, pur\xc3\xa9e in a blender or food processor until smooth and soupy. Set each pur\xc3\xa9ed melon aside in a separate bowl.\n2 Make simple syrup: Make a simple syrup by placing the sugar, water, and lemon zest in a saucepan over medium-high heat. Heat until the sugar has melted and the mixture has come to boil.\nRemove from heat. Add the mint (if using) and let sit for 10 minutes. Strain out the lemon zest (and mint if using).\n3 Stir together the simple syrup, citrus juice, corn syrup, salt, and the pur\xc3\xa9ed melon. Chill, covered with plastic wrap. Chill for several hours or overnight.\n4 Process in an ice cream machine via the manufacturer's instructions. The sorbet will have a soft texture right out of the ice cream maker. If you would like a firmer consistency, transfer the sorbet to an airtight container and place in a freezer for an hour or two. Once frozen, you may need to let it sit for a few minutes at room temperature to soften before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nEggplant Caponata Pasta Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n2 medium eggplants (1 1/2 to 2 pounds total)\n1/2 red onion, cut into 1-inch pieces\n4 tablespoons olive oil\n1 clove garlic, finely chopped\n1 stalk celery, finely chopped\n1 28-ounce can whole tomatoes (I like an imported variety like San Marzano)\n1/2 cup golden raisins\n1/4 cup red wine vinegar, or more to taste\n2 tablespoons capers\n1/4 teaspoon sugar\n3/4 pound pasta shells, orecchiette, or any other curly pasta shape\n1/2 cup grated fresh Parmesan\n1/2 cup mixed green and black olives, pitted and coarsely chopped\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the eggplant: Turn on the broiler and slide a rack 10-inches below the broiling element. Trim the stem and bottom from the eggplant and cut it into 1-inch pieces. Combine the eggplant and onion in a bowl and toss with salt, pepper, and 2 tablespoons of the olive oil.\n2 Broil the eggplant: Spread the eggplant and onions on a large rimmed baking sheet. Broil for 5 to 6 minutes, turning once, or until the eggplant begins to char at the edges.\n3 Roast the eggplant until tender: Place the eggplant and onion in the middle of the oven and turn the oven temperature to 450F. Continue roasting for 20 minutes, turning several times, or until the eggplant and onion are tender.\n4 Prepare the tomato sauce: In a large pot (big enough to hold the eggplant later), heat the remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil over medium-high heat. Add the garlic and celery and cook, stirring, for 1 minute.\nCrush the whole tomatoes in a bowl using your hands or a potato masher until you have small, bite-sized pieces. Add both the tomatoes and the roasted eggplant mixture into the pan with the garlic and celery. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat, cover the pan, and simmer for 5 minutes.\n5 Stir the raisins, vinegar, capers, and sugar into the sauce. Continue cooking for 5 minutes, or until the eggplant is very soft. Taste for seasoning and add more salt and vinegar, if you like.\n6 Cook the pasta: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the pasta and let it cook, stirring once or twice, for 8 minutes, or until it is tender but still has some bite. Before you drain the pasta, use a heatproof measuring cup to scoop out roughly 1 cup of the water; set aside. Drain the pasta and return it to its cooking pot. Sprinkle with olive oil and toss gently.\n7 Combine the pasta and sauce: Pour the eggplant sauce over the pasta, then add 1/2 cup of the pasta cooking water.. Place over low heat and stir until the sauce begins to coat the pasta. Add enough of the remaining cooking water to make a saucy mixture. Taste for seasoning and add more salt and vinegar, if you like.\n8 Serve the pasta: Spoon the pasta and sauce into 4 shallow bowls. Sprinkle with Parmesan, olives, and parsley.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSheet Pan Chicken with Roasted Eggplant Caponata Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nThe eggplant is even better if you salt it the night before and let it drain overnight!\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the roasted eggplant caponata:\n1 large eggplant (about 2 pounds), cut in 1/2-inch cubes\n1/2 tablespoon salt\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon honey or sugar\n1 pint mixed cherry tomatoes, halved\n2 celery stalks, finely diced\n1/2 cup sliced green olives\n2 tablespoons capers\n1/4 cup parsley, finely chopped\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n1/4 cup toasted pine nuts\nAdditional chopped parsley, to garnish\nFor the chicken thighs:\n2 to 2 1/2 pounds chicken thighs, skin-on and bone-in\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/2 tablespoon sweet paprika\n1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper (optional)\n1 teaspoon fennel seed (optional)\n1/4 teaspoon pepper\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the eggplant: In a large bowl, combine diced eggplant with 1/2 tablespoon salt. Place the eggplant in a colander set inside a large bowl. Strain at least 15 minutes or up to 24 hours. The longer you strain the eggplant, the crispier it will get.\nWhen ready to roast, press the eggplant firmly to squeeze out moisture.\n2 Place a large baking sheet on a middle rack in the oven and preheat to 450\xc2\xbaF for 15 to 20 minutes.\n3 Prepare the chicken: In a shallow bowl, combine chicken with paprika, red pepper, fennel, salt, pepper, and one tablespoon olive oil and toss to coat.\nThe chicken can also be prepared, covered, and refrigerated overnight.\n4 Roast the eggplant and chicken: When you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to cook, toss the eggplant with 2 tablespoons olive oil. Working quickly, pull the baking sheet from the oven and place chicken skin side down. Add the eggplant in a single layer around the chicken.\nReturn the hot pan to the oven and immediately lower the heat to 425\xc2\xbaF. Roast for 15 minutes. Flip the chicken skin side up, and roast another 15 minutes, or until the thighs are cooked through and register 165\xc2\xbaF with an instant-read thermometer.\n5 Prepare the rest of the caponata: In a large bowl, whisk together the balsamic and the honey or sugar. Add the cherry tomatoes, celery, green olives, capers, parsley, and garlic. Toss to combine well.\n6 Finish and serve: When chicken is ready, transfer it to a plate and rest for 10 minutes.\nAdd the roasted eggplant and the pan juices to the bowl with the cherry tomato mixture, and stir well. Taste and add salt and pepper as needed. Mix pine nuts into the caponata just before serving so they retain their crunch.\nServe the chicken thighs and top with the caponata. Sprinkle with extra parsley.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nChristmas Crack Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: About 35 pieces\nFeel free to add 1/2 cup of chopped nuts or coconut flakes on top once you\xe2\x80\x99ve poured the melted chocolate.\nYou can use darker chocolate with higher percentages of cacao, but these chocolates sometimes become brittle and separate from the cracker layer.\nWe recommend cooling this candy overnight in the fridge since cooling in the freezer can cause the chocolate layer and the cracker layer to separate when you "crack" the candy. If you need to freeze, let the crackers warm up for about 10 minutes before cracking.\nINGREDIENTS\n28 to 35 saltine crackers (about one sleeve, enough to line your tray)\n1 cup (220 g) packed dark brown sugar\n1 cup (225 g or 2 sticks) unsalted butter\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n2 cups (10 to 12 ounces) semi-sweet chocolate\nSpecial equipment:\nJelly roll pan (10x15-inches)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 400F. Line a 10x15-inch jelly roll pan with nonstick aluminum foil (preferred) or regular heavy duty foil, making sure that the foil completely covers the bottom and sides of the pan. If using regular foil, spray lightly with baking spray. Line the saltine crackers in a single layer on the bottom.\n2 Make the caramel sauce: Place the brown sugar, butter and salt in a medium sized saucepan. Cook on medium heat, stirring frequently, until the butter melts. Continue to cook, stirring occasionally, for another 3 to 5 minutes, just until the mixture comes to a boil and starts to darken. Remove from heat and stir in the vanilla extract.\n(Note: You\'re not actually making true caramel here, so you don\'t need to be as precise or worry about the temperature of the caramel. Just make sure it comes to a boil and wait for it to darken slightly, then continue.)\n3 Pour the hot brown sugar mixture over the saltine crackers. Spread to evenly coat the crackers.\n4 Move the pan to the oven and bake for 5 minutes. The caramel will be hot and bubbly.\n5 Melt the chocolate: Place the chocolate in a microwave-safe bowl. Cook it in the microwave in 30-second intervals at full power, stirring between each cook time, until the chocolate has melted.\n6 Pour the chocolate over the baked crackers: Once the crackers are done baking, remove from oven and allow to cool for 1 minute, until the caramel is no longer bubbling. Then pour the melted chocolate over the crackers. Use a spatula to spread the chocolate evenly over the top.\n7 Cool the crackers overnight: Let the crackers cool to room temperature then move to the refrigerator and cool over night.\n8 "Crack" the crackers: The crackers will form a single sheet once cool. Remove from pan and gently peel the foil away, being careful not to tear the foil. (If any bits of foil tear and get stuck in the caramel, break those bits away and discard.) Cut the candy into snack-sized pieces using a chefs knife (you can use your hands, too, but I find it easier with a knife).\nStore in an airtight container in the refrigerator for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nHow to Make Butterscotch Sauce\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutes\nINGREDIENTS\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter\n1 cup of tightly packed dark brown sugar\n\xc2\xbe cup heavy whipping cream (not ultra-pasteurized)\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nButterscotch sauce takes about a half an hour to make, from start to finish.\n1 Have everything ready to go: First, before you begin, make sure you have everything ready to go - the cream and the brown sugar next to the pan, measured and waiting. Making butterscotch is a fast process that cannot wait for hunting around for ingredients.\n2 Melt butter, add brown sugar: In a heavy bottomed stainless steel 2 quart saucepan, melt butter over low to medium heat. Just before butter is melted, add all dark brown sugar at once and stir with wooden spoon until sugar is uniformly wet.\n3 Stir infrequently: Stir infrequently until mixture goes from looking grainy to molten lava. Make sure to get into the corners of your pot, and watch closely to notice how the mixture changes. It will take about 3 to 5 minutes.\n4 Note the texture: Right before you add the cream, the caramelizing brown sugar will begin to look and feel more like liquid and less like thick wet sand.\n5 Add the cream, let boil: At this point add all the cream at once and replace your spoon with a whisk. Lower heat a little and whisk cream into mixture.\nWhen liquid is uniform, turn heat back to medium and whisk every few minutes for a total of 10 minutes or until it registers 225\xc2\xb0F on a digital or candy thermometer.\n6 Let rest, then transfer to storage vehicle to cool: After liquid has been boiling on the stove for its 10 minutes, turn heat off and let rest for a minute or two before transferring into a heatproof storage vessel. (I prefer a stainless steel or glass bowl.) Cool to room temperature.\n7 Taste, add salt and vanilla extract to taste: When butterscotch liquid is room temperature, take a small taste. It's important to know what cooked brown sugar and butter tastes like, and what happens when transforming that flat sweetness into real butterscotch flavor.\nWhisk in half the salt and vanilla extract. Taste again. Add more salt and vanilla extract until the marvelous taste of real butterscotch is achieved.\nButterscotch makes a fantastic topping for ice cream.\nChill butterscotch sauce in a non-reactive container with a tightly fitting lid only after sauce has chilled completely. It will keep for one month refrigerated, that is if you can keep from eating it all the moment it has cooled down and been seasoned to your liking.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nCaramel Walnuts Recipe\nCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 2 cups candied walnuts\nINGREDIENTS\n1/3 cup sour cream\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 Tbsp milk\n3/4 cup sugar\n2 cups of walnut halves\n1 teaspoon of vanilla extract\nMETHOD\n1 Make the caramel base: In a small, thick-bottomed saucepan, mix together and heat the sour cream, salt, milk, and sugar. Heat until the temperature reads 240\xc2\xb0F on a candy thermometer or digital thermometer, stirring occasionally.\n2 Add walnuts, vanilla: Add the walnuts and a teaspoon of vanilla. Stir until the walnuts are creamy.\n3 Remove from pan and separate: Remove pan from heat and spread the walnuts out on parchment paper or Silpat. Separate using 2 forks if necessary. Let cool to harden.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nCaramel Apple Monkey Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 2 hours, 30 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 12 to 15 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the dough:\n1 1/4 cups (237 mL) whole milk, warmed (not hot)\n2 teaspoons active dry or instant yeast\n1/4 cup (50 grams) sugar, divided\n4 cups (560 grams) all-purpose flour\n1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt\n3 tablespoons (42 grams) unsalted butter, melted\nFor the apples:\n1 tablespoon (14 grams) unsalted butter\n1 medium sweet-tart apple, peeled and diced (about 1 1/2 cups; I used honeycrisp)\n1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon\nPinch kosher salt\nFor the caramel sauce:\n1 cup (200 grams) sugar\n1/2 cup + 2 tablespoons (118 mL) apple cider, divided\n2 tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 tablespoons heavy cream\nTo assemble:\n1/2 cup (56 grams) unsalted butter\n1 cup (200 grams) sugar\n1 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon\nSpecial equipment:\nBundt pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dough: Whisk the warmed milk with the yeast and 2 tablespoons of the sugar in a measuring cup. Set it to the side to become foamy.\nIn the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the dough hook, whisk together the remaining sugar, flour, salt, 3 tablespoons of melted butter. Add the yeast-milk mixture. Mix on low speed until a shaggy dough forms, then turn the mixer up to medium-low and knead for 10 minutes (set a timer!). When done, the dough should form a ball and spring back when you poke it.\n2 Let the dough rise for one hour, or overnight: Gather the dough into a ball with your hands and place into a greased bowl. Cover well with plastic wrap. Let the dough rise on the counter for 1 hour, until doubled in size, or place in the fridge to rise overnight. (The dough may not quite double in size if you\'re refrigerating overnight, but it should look risen and puffed.)\n3 Make the apples while the dough rises (or before assembling, if you\'ve chilled the dough overnight): Melt the butter for the apples in a medium skillet. Add the diced apples, cinnamon, and a pinch of salt. Cook over medium heat for about five minutes until the apples are just tender. Remove from the heat and set aside to cool. (The apples can be made up to a day ahead and kept refrigerated.)\n4 Make the caramel sauce: In a large saucepan, combine the sugar and 1/2 cup of the apple cider, and stir over low heat until the sugar has dissolved. Once the sugar has dissolved, stop stirring, increase the heat to medium-low, and bring the mixture to a boil.\nContinue to boil (without stirring!) until the sugar turns a deep golden caramel color, 320F to 330F. Remove from the heat and stir in the butter, followed by the salt, cream, and remaining 2 tablespoons of cider. Whisk until smooth. (Caramel sauce can be cooled and refrigerated for several days; warm briefly in the microwave or on the stovetop, until it\'s a "drizzle" consistency, before assembling.)\n5 Assemble the monkey bread: Grease a bundt pan well and set aside. Melt the butter needed for assembly. In a separate bowl, mix together the sugar and cinnamon.\nTear off walnut- or golf ball-sized pieces of dough and roll into balls between your hands, They don\xe2\x80\x99t have to be uniform! Dip each dough ball into the melted butter, roll in cinnamon sugar, and place in the bottom of the prepared bundt until there is a good layer on the bottom of the pan (using up about half the dough).\nSpoon all of the apples over the dough, followed by a third of the caramel sauce. Continue rolling the remaining dough and layering in the pan. Drizzle another third of the caramel sauce over the top. (Save the rest of the caramel sauce for serving).\n6 Let the monkey bread rise for 30 to 60 minutes: Cover the monkey bread with plastic wrap. Room temperature dough will take about 30 minutes to rise; dough that\'s cold from the fridge will take 30 to 60 minutes. Let the monkey bread rise until the top looks slightly puffed and pillowy.\n7 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n8 Bake the monkey bread: Uncover the bundt pan and transfer to a sheet pan (to catch butter drips!). Place in the oven and bake for 30 to 35 minutes. When done, the top should have risen slightly over the top of the pan and the bread should be a deep golden brown.\n9 Cool and serve! Cool the monkey bread in the bundt pan on a wire rack for 15 minutes. Place a serving plate over the pan, and using oven mitts, flip the pan over to unmold the monkey bread onto the plate.\nDrizzle with the remaining caramel sauce and serve. Be careful, the bread will still be hot!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nCaramelized Pecan Tart Recipe\nYield: Serves 8 to 10\nINGREDIENTS\nCrust:\n1 cup all purpose flour\n1 Tbsp white granulated sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 cup chilled butter (4 ounces, 1 stick), cut into cubes\n1 Tbsp ice water\nFilling:\n1/2 cup unsalted butter, softened\n1 1/2 cups dark brown sugar\n1 large egg\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\nPinch of salt\n2 cups of whole pecans\n Equipment needed:\nOne 9-inch by 1-inch tart pan with a removable bottom\nFood processor to make the tart dough\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dough. Combine in a food processor the flour, sugar, and salt. Pulse to blend. Add the cubed butter and pulse until you have pea-sized pieces of butter. Add 1 Tbsp ice water and pulse until the dough starts to come together into a ball. Turn the dough out onto a clean surface and form into a ball with your hands. Flatten into a disc form, wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes.\n2 Form the crust. Press the dough into the center of the tart pan and work it with your fingers and the palm of your hand so that it spreads to the edges and up the sides of the tart pan. Lay a large piece of aluminum foil into the pan on top of the dough and press it into the dough so that it helps the dough keep its shape in the pan. Then place the pan into the freezer for 30 minutes.\n3 Blind bake the crust. Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. After 30 minutes, remove the pan from the freezer and gently remove the foil from the dough. Place the pan on top of a sheet of foil (to catch drippings) on top of a baking sheet. Prick the bottom of the tart dough with the tines of a fork in several places and place the tart pan in the oven. Bake for 15 -20 minutes, or until the dough is lightly browned. Remove from oven and let sit at room temperature to cool.\n4 Make the filling. Put the butter, brown sugar, egg, and salt in a large bowl. Stir until well combined. Then gently stir in the pecans. Pour the filling into the pre-baked, cooled tart shell.\n5 Bake the tart. Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Place the tart on a foil lined pan and bake for about 25 minutes until lightly browned and slightly puffy all over. Remove from oven and let cool to touch. Then while the tart is still slightly warm, gently remove the outer ring of the tart pan, leaving the tart on the metal tart pan bottom. Let cool all the way before cutting to serve.\nServe with whipped cream. Use a sharp chef's knife to cut the tart. You have to cut through pecans, so make strong, swift cuts.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nSpicy Caramel Popcorn Clusters Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup roasted peanuts\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon chili powder\n1/2 teaspoon sugar\n1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1/3 cup popcorn\n3 tablespoons canola oil\n1/2 cup unsalted butter\n1 cup brown sugar\n1/2 cup light corn syrup\n1/2 teaspoon baking powder\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Get everything ready: Add roasted peanuts to a large bowl (you'll add the popcorn later). In a separate, small bowl, mix together the spice mixture (salt, chili powder, sugar, and cayenne). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and set it aside.\n2 Pop the popcorn: Add canola oil to a large pot over medium heat. Add one kernel of popcorn to the pot and cover the lid. When that kernel pops, it means your oil is at the right temperature.\nRemove the single kernel and pour in all the popcorn. Off the heat, cover the pot and wait 30 seconds to bring all the kernels up to temperature. Return the pot to heat and shake vigorously while the popcorn pops to prevent burning.\nWhen the popping slows to a few seconds between pops, remove from heat and pour into the large bowl with the peanuts. There may be some unpopped kernels, but that\xe2\x80\x99s better than burned popcorn.\nFor more detailed instructions on how to pop popcorn, see HERE\n3 Make the caramel: Melt the butter in a medium pot over medium heat. Add the brown sugar and corn syrup and stir well to combine. Cook over medium heat for 6 to 8 minutes until the mixture thickens and coats the back of a rubber spatula.\nAdd half of the spice mixture to the caramel sauce along with the baking powder. Stir well to combine.\n4 Coat the popcorn with caramel: Immediately after making the caramel (don't let it get cold), pour it into the popcorn and peanut mixture. Work quickly and stir to combine and coat popcorn.\n5 Cool the popcorn: Spread popcorn out on the baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Use a rubber spatula to press the popcorn down into an even layer. Sprinkle popcorn with the remaining spice mixture.\nWhen the popcorn has cooled slightly, you can shape the popcorn into balls if you want, but I prefer it in freeform clusters. These popcorn clusters keep perfectly at room temperature in an airtight container for a few days, or probably up to a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nHow to Caramelize Onions\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutes\nQuantities depend on how much caramelized onions you wish to make. In this example, 5 large raw onions yielded about 2 cups caramelized onions.\nINGREDIENTS\nSeveral medium or large onions, yellow, white, or red\nExtra virgin olive oil\nButter (optional)\nSalt\nSugar (optional)\nBalsamic vinegar (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cut the onions root to tip: Slice 1/2-inch off the stem ends of the onions and the roots off of the root end. Place the onions cut side down on the cutting board. Cut them in half through the root end. Peel back the peels from the onions.\nLay the onions cut side down and make angled cuts into each onion, aimed at the center, cutting almost all the way, but not completely through the root end.  Make the cuts to your desired level of thickness.\nThe root end will help hold the onion together as you cut it, making it easier to cut. Then cut a V in the root end to cut out the tough root holding the slices together.\n2 Heat olive oil and butter, add onion slices: Use a wide, thick-bottomed saut\xc3\xa9 pan for maximum pan contact with the onions. Coat the bottom of the pan with olive oil, or a mixture of olive oil and butter (about 1 teaspoon per onion). Heat the pan on medium high heat until the oil is shimmering. Add the onion slices and stir to coat the onions with the oil. Spread the onions out evenly over the pan and let cook, stirring occasionally.\nDepending on how strong your stovetop burner is you may need to reduce the heat to medium or medium low to prevent the onions from burning or drying out.\nAfter 10 minutes, sprinkle some salt over the onions, and if you want, you can add some sugar to help with the caramelization process. (I add only about a teaspoon of sugar for 5 onions, you can add more.) One trick to keeping the onions from drying out as they cook is to add a little water to the pan.\n3 Cook, stirring every few minutes: Let cook for 30 minutes to an hour more, stirring every few minutes. As soon as the onions start sticking to the pan, let them stick a little and brown, but then stir them before they burn.\nThe trick is to leave them alone enough to brown (if you stir them too often, they won't brown), but not so long so that they burn. After the first 20 to 30 minutes you may want to lower the stove temperature a little, and add a little more oil, if you find the onions are verging on burning.\nA metal spatula will help you scrape up the browned bits from the bottom of the pan as the caramelization proceeds. As the onions cook down, you may find you need to scrape the pan every minute, instead of every few minutes.\nContinue to cook and scrape, cook and scrape, until the onions are a rich, browned color. At the end of the cooking process you might want to add a little balsamic vinegar or wine to help deglaze the pan and bring some additional flavor to the onions.\nStore refrigerated for several days in an air-tight container.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nFrench Onion Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 10 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nMuch of the success of this soup depends on the stock that you are using, and stock varies tremendously in its taste. Depending on your stock, you may need to bump up the flavor with some beef bouillon (we recommend "Better than Bouillon brand").\nTaste the soup before putting it in the oven, and if it needs more seasoning, don\'t be afraid to add more!\nINGREDIENTS\n6 large red or yellow onions (about 3 pounds), peeled and thinly sliced root to stem (see How to Slice an Onion), about 10 cups of sliced onions total\n4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 tablespoons butter\n1 teaspoon of sugar\nSalt\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n8 cups of beef stock, chicken stock, or a combination of the two (traditionally the soup is made with beef stock)\n1/2 cup of dry vermouth or dry white wine\n2 bay leaves\n1 tablespoon (loose) of fresh thyme (can also use a few sprigs of fresh thyme) OR 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme (more to taste)\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n2 tablespoons brandy (optional)\n8 slices French bread or baguette cut 1-inch thick\n1 1/2 cups of grated Swiss Gruyere and a sprinkling of Parmesan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Caramelize the onions: In a 5 to 6 quart thick-bottomed pot, heat 3 tablespoons of olive oil on medium heat. Add the onions and toss to coat with the olive oil.\nCook the onions, stirring often, until they have softened, about 15 to 20 minutes.\nIncrease the heat to medium high. Add the remaining tablespoon of olive oil and the butter and cook, stirring often, until the onions start to brown, about 15 more minutes.\nThen sprinkle with sugar (to help with the caramelization) and 1 teaspoon of salt and continue to cook until the onions are well browned, about 10 to 15 more minutes.\nAdd the minced garlic and cook for a minute more.\n2 Deglaze the pot with vermouth: Add the vermouth to the pot and scrape up the browned bits on the bottom and sides of the pot, deglazing the pot as you go.\n3 Add stock and seasonings: Add the stock, bay leaves, and thyme. Bring to a simmer, cover the pot and lower the heat to maintain a low simmer. Cook for about 30 minutes.\nSeason to taste with more salt and add freshly ground black pepper. Discard the bay leaves. Add brandy if using.\n4 Toast French bread slices: While the soup is simmering, line a sheet pan with parchment paper or foil and preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xb0F with a rack in the upper third of the oven.\nBrush both sides of the French bread or baguette slices lightly with olive oil (you\'ll end up using about a tablespoon and a half of olive oil for this).\nPut in the oven and toast until lightly browned, about 5 to 7 minutes. Remove from oven.\nTurn the toasts over and sprinkle with the grated Gruyere cheese and Parmesan. Return to oven when it\'s close to serving time and bake until the cheese is bubbly and lightly browned.\n5 Serve: To serve, ladle soup into a bowl and transfer one cheesy toast onto the top of each bowl of soup.\nAlternatively, you can use individual oven-proof bowls or one large casserole dish. Ladle the soup into the bowls or casserole dish. Cover with the toast and sprinkle with cheese. Put into the broiler for 10 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0 F, or until the cheese bubbles and is slightly browned.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nCaramelized Onion Quiche Recipe\nYield: Serves 6-8\nNote that although this recipe calls for making a pie crust from scratch, you can easily use an already prepared frozen pie crust. Just pre-bake it using the directions that follow.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 recipe pie dough (see P\xc3\xa2te Bris\xc3\xa9e recipe)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2-3 large red onions (about one pound total), French-cut (see below)\nSalt and freshly ground pepper\n2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar\n3/4 cup milk\n1/4 cup heavy cream\n3 large eggs\nPinch nutmeg\n6 ounces Gruy\xc3\xa8re cheese, grated (1 1/2 cups)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nSLICING ONIONS STEM TO ROOT\nTo caramelize onions, you\'ll want to slice them lengthwise, or from stem end to root end. That way the onions will hold their shape better during the long cooking involved in caramelizing. (See How to Slice an Onion for more details.)\n1 First, use a sharp knife, get a firm grip on the onion, and slice off the stem end of the onion, by about a 1/2 inch. Cut about 1/8th of an inch from the root end, cutting off the roots, but leaving the core intact. Then place the onion root side up on the board to stabilize it, and cut it in half, straight through the root end.\n\n2 Peel back the papery skin of the onions. If you want, to keep your cutting area clean, cut off the roots with the skins, but cut only enough to cut off the messy roots. Keep the root end intact. It will make it easier to slice the onion.\n\n3 With an onion half cut-side down on the board to stabilize it, make angled cuts into the onion, from stem end to root end, cutting to, but not through the root end. Work your way around the arc of the onion, aiming your knife\'s blade toward the center of the onion.\n4 Make a "V" cut in the root end of the onion to cut out the tough root end, to release the onion slices.\nPRE-BAKE THE CRUST\n1 Make a frozen tart crust: If you are making your own crust (instead of using an already prepared frozen crust), roll out your dough on a lightly floured surface, into a 12-inch circle. Fit into a 9-by-1 1/2-inch round tart pan (or 9-inch pie dish), pressing dough into corners, extending the edges extra high to allow for shrinkage. Transfer to freezer to chill for 30 minutes.\n2 Line frozen crust with foil and pie weights: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line pastry with aluminum foil, pressing into the corners and edges, allowing extra foil on the sides (they\'ll be your handles when you remove the foil).\nFill at least two-thirds with baking weights\xe2\x80\x94dried beans, rice, copper pennies, or ceramic or metal pie weights.\n3 Bake with weights: Bake first for 15 minutes, remove from oven and let cool a few minutes. Carefully remove aluminum foil and weights.\n4 Remove weights and bake again: Poke the bottom of the pie pan with the tines of a fork and return to oven and bake an additional 10 minutes or until lightly golden. (Fork holes are for any air to escape.) Transfer to a wire rack to cool while making filling.\n  CARAMELIZING THE ONIONS AND PREPARING THE QUICHE\nThe onions will take about an hour to cook on the stovetop before they are ready to go into the quiche. So timing-wise, if you are making the entire quiche from scratch, it makes sense to get started on the onions once you\'ve put the crust into the freezer to chill before pre-baking.\n1 Caramelize the onions: Heat 2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil in a large, heavy-bottomed saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the onions and sprinkle a little salt over them. Cook, stirring occasionally for 10 minutes, until the onions have softened and are translucent. Reduce the heat to medium low and cook for an additional 40 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions are well browned. (See How to Caramelize Onions for more details.)\nAdd 2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar and cook for 10 minutes more, until onions are completely caramelized. Remove from heat.\n2 Assemble the quiche: Place tart pan on a baking sheet to catch any run-off there might be. Sprinkle half the cheese evenly over the bottom of the crust. Spread onions over the cheese and then top with remaining cheese.\nIn a medium bowl, whisk together milk, cream, and eggs. Season with nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Pour over the tart.\n3 Bake the quiche: Transfer to the 350\xc2\xb0F oven, and bake until just set in the center, 30 to 35 minutes. Cool on a wire rack for about 10-15 minutes before slicing.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCaramelized Onion Tart with Gorgonzola and Brie Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Makes 9 to 12 appetizer sized pieces.\nTarragon is a summer herb, if you can't find any, you may crush a few fennel seeds (maybe half a teaspoon) and sprinkle over the tart. Or top with fresh chopped fennel fronds, after the tart has been taken out of the oven.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n4 cups of sliced onions, sliced root-to-top into 1/4-inch thick slices (about 2-3 med onions)\n1 tablespoon brown sugar\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon pepper\n8 oz frozen puff pastry (defrosted a couple hours in the fridge)\n2 oz chilled Brie cheese, rind removed and diced\n2 oz Gorgonzola or other blue cheese, diced\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh tarragon\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Caramelize the onions: Heat oil in a large deep pan on medium-high heat. Add onions and cook for about 10 minutes or until wilted and starting to brown. Add sugar, vinegar, salt and pepper.\nReduce heat and cook gently, uncovered for 20-25 minutes or until richly caramelized. Add a little water if the onions look like they are starting to dry out. Cool.\n2 Roll pastry into a 10-to-14-inch rectangle (or whatever shape you want). Place pastry on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Prick with a fork at a couple inch increments to prevent the pastry from forming big bubbles while baking.\n3 Spread onions over pastry, all the way to the edges of the pastry. Dot with cheese. Sprinkle with tarragon. Refrigerate if not baking immediately.\n4 Bake in a preheated oven at 400\xc2\xb0F for 18-20 minutes or until cheese has melted and pastry is crispy. Cool for 5 minutes. Cut into wedges or squares and enjoy!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nCaramelized Fennel and Onions Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n2 large onions, halved then sliced lengthwise (root to tip) in 1/4-inch thick slices\n2 large fennel bulbs, sliced into 1/4-inch thick slices\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1 Tbsp butter\nSalt\n1/4 cup grated Parmesan\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\nMETHOD\n1 Cook fennel and onions in olive oil and butter: Heat olive oil and butter in a large, uncovered, wide pan on medium high heat. Add the sliced fennel and onions and stir to coat. Stir occasionally.\nAfter about 10 minutes, sprinkle the onions and fennel with salt. Lower the temperature to medium.\nYou want to strike a balance between allowing the pan to get hot enough so that some caramelization (when the natural sugars in the onion and fennel start to brown) and keeping the pot from getting so hot that the onions and fennel dry out.\nIf it becomes an issue, you can add a couple tablespoons of water to the pan to help the onions and fennel to keep from drying out too much.\n2 Scrape up browned bits: Stir occasionally, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan. Note that the browned bits are the tastiest parts.\nCook for another 30 minutes to an hour, depending on how much of a hurry you're in, and how caramelized you want your mixture to be. The longer you cook, the more caramelized and browned.\nTaste test along the way to see if the cooking has been sufficient for your taste.\nBy the way, the onions and fennel will have plenty of flavor without having to be completely cooked down and browned all over.\n3 Toss with Parmesan, parsley, lemon: When ready to serve, remove from heat and toss in the freshly grated Parmesan cheese, the chopped parsley, lemon zest and lemon juice. Taste and add more lemon juice if necessary.\nServe alone as a side to chicken or seafood, or on crackers or thinly sliced toasted baguette for a crostini. You can also use it as a filling for a rustic tart.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCaramelized Onion Dip Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Makes about 2 1/2 cups of dip\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n4 cups chopped yellow onions (from about 2-3 onions)\n1 teaspoon brown sugar\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n1 cup sour cream\n1/2 cup mayonnaise\n1/4 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce\n1/4 teaspoon garlic powder\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Caramelize the onions: Heat olive oil in a large, thick-bottomed deep pot (I used a 5-quart Dutch oven) on medium high heat. Add the chopped onions and cook until translucent and starting to color, about 10 minutes.\nIf at any point during the cooking of the onions they start to dry out, add a tablespoon of water to the pot.\nStir in the brown sugar, balsamic, salt, and pepper. Lower the heat and cook gently, uncovered, for about 25 to 30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions are nicely caramelized.\nThen set aside. (You can caramelize the onions up to 2 days ahead and chill until you make the dip.) Let cool a bit before adding to the other ingredients.\n2 Combine with remaining ingredients: In a medium bowl, mix together the sour cream and mayonnaise (a rubber spatula works well for this). Stir in the caramelized onions. Sprinkle with garlic salt and stir to incorporate. Stir in the Worcestershire sauce.\nChill until ready to serve. Serve with potato chips.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nRoasted New Potatoes with Caramelized Onions and Truffle Oil Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound small, new potatoes, scrubbed, quartered\n1 large yellow onion, peeled, thinly sliced\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\nKosher salt and freshly ground black pepper\nSeveral shakes of white truffle oil, about 1/2 teaspoon\n  METHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Toss potatoes and onions with olive oil, salt, pepper: Put onions and potatoes in a sturdy roasting pan. Pour olive oil over them and toss well to coat. Liberally sprinkle salt and pepper over the potatoes and onions. Spread the potatoes out so they are in a single layer in the pan.\n3 Roast: Place in oven. Roast at 400\xc2\xb0F for 40 minutes or until the potatoes are lightly browned and cooked through.\n4 Sprinkle with truffle oil: Place potatoes and onions in a serving dish. Sprinkle well with truffle oil. Toss to coat.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nRustic Onion Tart Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 40 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 recipe for butter sour cream pastry dough* or 1 packaged, flat pie crust (Trader Joe's has one in their frozen section)\n3 medium sized red and/or yellow onions (enough for 5 to 8 cups, sliced)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 tablespoon butter\nSalt\n1 teaspoon balsamic vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon fresh thyme, chopped, or 1/4 teaspoon dried thyme\n3/4 cup (not packed) roughly grated Gruy\xc3\xa8re Swiss cheese\n*Sour cream pastry dough:\n1 1/4 cup (160 g) all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon salt\n5 ounces of butter (1 1/4 sticks, 10 Tbsp, 137g), cubed\n1/4 cup sour cream\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the dough: If you are making a crust from scratch, prepare the dough and let it chill in the refrigerator while you are cooking the onions.\nTo prepare the dough, whisk the flour and salt together in a large bowl. Cut the butter into the flour with your hands or with a pastry cutter, until the mixture resembles a coarse meal.\nAdd the sour cream and use a fork to incorporate it into the dough. Gather the dough into a ball and shape it into a disk. Wrap it with plastic wrap and chill for at least an hour.\n2 Peel and slice the onions, lengthwise from stem to root. (See How to Slice an Onion)\n3 Caramelize the onions: Heat olive oil and butter in a large, heavy-bottomed saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Once the butter has melted, add the onions and sprinkle a little salt over them.\nCook, stirring occasionally for 10 minutes, until the onions have softened and are translucent.\nReduce the heat to medium low and cook for an additional 40 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions are well browned.\nAdd balsamic vinegar and cook for 10 minutes more, until onions are completely caramelized. Remove from heat.\n4 Roll out the dough: Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. Remove the dough from the refrigerator and let stand for 5 minutes before rolling it out.\nRoll out the dough on a lightly floured surface to a 13-inch diameter. Transfer the crust dough to a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper.\n5 Layer the cheese and onions onto the dough: Place all but a couple tablespoons of the cheese in the center of the dough. Spread to within 1 1/2 inches from the edges. Add the caramelized onions, layering them on top of the cheese. Sprinkle with thyme.\n6 Pleat the edges: Fold the edges of the crust dough over so that a small circle of onion is still showing in the centre of the tart. Sprinkle the remaining cheese over the top of the tart.\n7 Bake: Place in the oven on the middle rack. Bake for 10 minutes at 450\xc2\xb0F. Reduce the heat to 350\xc2\xb0F and bake for an additional 20-25 minutes, until the crust is golden brown.\nRemove from oven and let sit for 10 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nPurple Potatoes with Caramelized Onions and Shiitake Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 3 to 4\nINGREDIENTS\n3 slices of thick style bacon\n1/2 pound new purple potatoes sliced in half and then in small wedges\n1 small yellow onion, thinly sliced lengthwise\n4 medium sized shiitake mushrooms, thinly sliced\nExtra virgin olive oil\nKosher Salt\nFreshly cracked pepper\n1 pinch red pepper flakes\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh tarragon\n1 tablespoon chopped capers\n1/2 tablespoons unsalted butter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Start caramelizing the onions: In a small saut\xc3\xa9 pan heat one tablespoon of olive oil over a low heat. Add the sliced onions in one even layer, after five minutes add 1/2 tablespoon of butter, stir and add a pinch of kosher salt.\nWhile rendering your bacon and cooking your mushrooms in the next steps, make sure to stir the onions every few minutes and remove once they are evenly browned. This should take around 30 minutes, remove from heat when finished and reserve.\n2 Cook the bacon: While the onions are slowly cooking slice the bacon in small batonettes (1/8-inch crosswise strips) on your cutting board. Heat up a larger saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium and when your pan is hot add the sliced bacon.\nSlowly saut\xc3\xa9 the bacon until slightly crispy and remove from the pan onto a paper towel-lined plate, reserve for later.\n3 Cook mushrooms in rendered bacon fat: Julienne the shiitake mushrooms and then add them to the pan which now has the rendered bacon fat.\nAdd a pinch of salt and fresh cracked pepper to the Shiitake mushrooms, don\xe2\x80\x99t shake the pan but let the mushrooms brown evenly on one side.\nOnce browned, flip the mushrooms delicately and remove from pan onto a smaller plate, reserve.\n4 Brown the purple potatoes: Add 2 Tablespoons of olive oil in the pan and add the evenly sliced potatoes to the hot pan in a single layer; make sure not to crowd the pan. Add a pinch of red pepper flakes and a good pinch of salt to the potatoes.\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t move the pan, this is very important so that the potatoes can evenly brown.\nAfter 3-5 minutes, when they are browned flip potatoes and brown the other side, turn down the heat to medium low to evenly cook the potatoes.\n5 Add capers, onions, mushrooms, bacon: Once the potatoes are thoroughly cooked, add the capers and let crisp up for a minute. Then combine the caramelized onions, mushrooms, and bacon to the large saut\xc3\xa9 pan with the browned potatoes.\nRe-warm over low heat. When hot, turn the heat off and garnish with a sprinkle of fresh picked tarragon.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nMaple-Glazed Chicken with Caramelized Onions and Pears Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 4 servings\nIf you don't have an oven-safe skillet, transfer the cooked onions and pears to a baking dish in Step 4, place the chicken on top, and bake.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 skinless, boneless chicken breasts (1 1/2 to 2 pounds total)\n1 teaspoon salt, divided, plus more to taste\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper, divided, plus more to taste\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n2 tablespoons butter\n1 large Spanish or yellow onion, halved and thinly sliced\n2 large ripe firm-fleshed pears (like Bartlett), or 3 smaller pears\n2 tablespoons maple syrup\n1 tablespoon Dijon mustard\n3 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\nSpecial equipment:\n1 large cast iron skillet, or other oven-safe skillet\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the chicken: Heat the oven at 450\xc2\xb0F. Sprinkle the chicken with 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper.\nHeat the olive oil in the skillet over medium-high heat. When it is hot, add the chicken and cook without disturbing for 3 to 5 minutes, until the underside is golden. Turn and cook the other sides for 3 to 5 minutes more, until the other side is golden. Transfer chicken to a large plate.\n2 Cook the onion: Melt the butter in the skillet over medium heat. Add the onion, 1/2 teaspoon of salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Cook, stirring often, for 8 minutes, or until the onion starts to brown.\n3 Prep and cook the pears: While the onions cook, peel and core the pears. Cut into quarters (large pears can be cut into 6 pieces.)\nMove the onions to the center of the pan. Add the pears, cut sides down, around the edge. Cook for 4 minutes or until the pears brown on the bottom. Stir the onions occasionally.\nTurn the pears and cook the other cut sides for 3 minutes more. Stir the onions occasionally.\n4 Return the chicken to the skillet and glaze: Gently stir the pears and onions together and flatten them slightly to create a bed for the chicken. Place the chicken on top of the pears and onions. Tip in any pan juices from the plate into the skillet.\nIn a small bowl, stir together the maple syrup and mustard. Spread the glaze over the chicken breasts with a spoon.\n5 Bake the chicken: Transfer the skillet to the oven and cook for 20 to 25 minutes, or until the glaze is browned, the pears are tender when pierced, and the chicken is cooked through. A meat thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the breasts should register 165\xc2\xb0F.\n6 Serve the chicken: Divide the pears and onions between plates, add a chicken breast, and sprinkle with parsley.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nCaramelized Onion English Muffin Pizzas Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes 12 English muffin pizzas\nINGREDIENTS\n6 English muffin halves\n1 cup grated Mozzarella cheese, packed\n1 tablespoon butter\n1 medium onion, thinly sliced\n3/4 cup diced ham\nA pinch of chopped fresh sage\n1/4 teaspoon stoneground mustard\nOptional: A few slices of fresh tomato\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat oven to 425\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Cook the onions and ham: Melt butter in a medium skillet on medium high heat. Add the onions and cook until translucent, about 5 minutes. Add the diced ham, cook 5 minutes more. Mix in the sage and mustard. Remove from heat.\n3 Assemble the muffin pizzas: Put muffin halves, open side up on a sturdy baking pan. Distribute the cheese evenly, sprinkling over the muffin halves. Put the onion ham mixture on top of the cheese. If you want to use tomato slices, layer them between the cheese and onion mixture.\n4 Bake: Bake at 425\xc2\xb0F for 8-9 minutes, until the muffins and toppings are nicely browned, but not burnt. b'Print\nInstant Pot French Onion Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 5 minutesYield: 6 (1-cup) servings\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t have broiler-safe bowls, you can toast the cheesy bread separately, then add one slice to each bowl of soup just before serving.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the soup:\n1/4 cup unsalted butter or vegetable oil\n2 1/2 to 3 pounds yellow or red onions, halved, peeled, and sliced 1/4-inch thick\n1 tablespoon brown sugar\n1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt\n1/4 cup dry sherry or vermouth\n4 cups low sodium beef broth\n1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/4 teaspoon dried thyme leaves or 1 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves\n1 bay leaf\nFor the toasts:\n6 (1-inch thick) slices of a baguette\n1 1/4 teaspoons Dijon mustard\n1 cup grated Gruyere cheese\nFreshly ground black pepper\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart Instant Pot or pressure cooker\n4 broiler-safe crock bowls\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Set the cooking time: Select the high saut\xc3\xa9 setting on your pressure cooker. If it\xe2\x80\x99s an Instant Pot or similar model, the timer should default to a cooking time of 30 minutes. You will use every minute of this to saut\xc3\xa9 the onions.\n2 Add the fat and caramelize the onions: Add the butter or oil to the pressure cooker. Once the butter has melted or the oil shimmers, about 2 minutes, add the onions, sugar, and salt and stir with a wooden spoon, separating the onion layers and coating the slices with the fat.\nCover the pot with a tempered glass lid or other 9-inch pot lid and let the onions cook, without stirring, for 10 minutes.\n3 Uncover the pot and continue cooking the onions: Uncover the pot. At this point the onions should be softened, but not brown, and there should be some liquid at the bottom of the pot.\nWhile wearing an oven mitt, hold the rim of the inner pot in place, and stir the onions vigorously. Be careful not to splash hot liquid on yourself.\nContinue to stir the onions vigorously every 2 minutes, making sure to nudge loose any fond or brown bits from the bottom of the pot as it develops with your spoon. Do this until the saut\xc3\xa9 cooking program has ended after 30 minutes and the pot turns off automatically.\nAt this point, the onions should be caramelized and golden brown.\n3 Deglaze the pot and cook the soup under pressure: While the pot is off but still hot and the onions are sizzling, add the sherry. Use a wooden spoon to thoroughly scrape any remaining fond from the pot bottom.\nStir in the broth, Worcestershire, thyme, bay leaf, and pepper. Secure the pressure cooker lid in its sealing position, then select the manual setting, and set the time for 5 minutes at high pressure.\n(The pot will take about 10 minutes to come up to pressure before the cooking program begins.)\n4 Release the pressure and prepare to serve: When the cooking program ends, let the pressure release naturally for at least 15 minutes, then move the pressure release valve to "venting" to release any remaining steam.\nAt this point, the soup will stay hot on the \xe2\x80\x9ckeep warm\xe2\x80\x9d setting for up to 10 hours, until you are ready to serve it.\nWhen you are ready to serve the soup, discard the bay leaf. Taste the soup for seasoning, adding salt and/or pepper if needed.\n5 Make the toasts and finish the soup: Preheat the broiler on your oven and line a baking sheet with aluminum foil. Place broiler-safe serving bowls on the baking sheet, then ladle the soup into the bowls, filling them to about 1/2-inch from the top.\nSpread the baguette slices very sparingly with Dijon mustard (1/4 teaspoon per slice), then place the baguette slices on top of the bowls of soup.\nHeap a pile of the Gruyere cheese onto each baguette slice. Grind one or two grinds of black pepper on top of each slice. Broil for 3-5 minutes, or until the cheese is bubbly and beginning to brown.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nCaraway Soda Bread Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Makes one loaf\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour (1 pound)\n1 Tbsp sugar\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n2 teaspoons caraway seeds\n4 Tbsp butter (1/2 stick) room temp\n1 1/2 cups buttermilk*\n*If necessary, you can substitute buttermilk with a half cup of plain yogurt mixed in with a cup of plain milk and a tablespoon of white vinegar.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, salt, baking soda, and caraway seeds.\n2 Using your fingers (or a fork) work the butter into the flour until the mixture resembles a coarse meal.\n3 Make a well in the center of the flour. Pour the buttermilk into the center and using either your hands or a wooden spoon, fold the flour over the buttermilk and gently mix until just combined.\nThe dough should be neither too wet or too dry, so if it is a little too dry to work with, add a little more buttermilk. If too wet, add a little more flour. Roughly shape into a ball and place on a floured surface. Knead just a few times to shape it into a round loaf. Do not over-knead or the bread will be tough.\n4 Place dough loaf onto a lightly greased baking sheet (or cast iron pan). Make 1 1/2-inch deep cuts, forming a cross, from side to side on the loaf. The scoring helps the heat get to the center of the loaf while cooking.\n5 Place in oven, cook for 15 minutes at 450\xc2\xb0F, then lower the heat to 400\xc2\xb0F and cook for 25 more minutes. One way to test for doneness is to take it out of the oven, turn it over and knock on the bottom. If it sounds hollow, it's done. You can also use a skewer inserted into the center.\nLet bread sit on the baking sheet for 5-10 minutes to cool. Then remove it to a rack to cool a little bit longer. I think the bread is best when it is still warm and just baked. Quick breads like this, which rely on baking soda for leavening, are generally best eaten soon after they're baked.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nPork Chops with Braised Cabbage Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nWe used large, bone-in pork chops for this recipe, but any style pork chop\xe2\x80\x94thick or thin, bone-in or boneless\xe2\x80\x94will work.\nThe ultimate cooking time may depend on if you are using pork chops taken directly from the fridge or chops that have been allowed to come closer to room temperature before cooking. Thin chops you can take directly from the refrigerator. Thick chops should probably sit out for a bit before cooking.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 teaspoons bacon fat, butter or extra virgin olive oil\n1 large onion, sliced 1/4-inch, about 2 cups\n1/2 head of cabbage, sliced 1/4-inch wide slices\nSalt\n1/4 teaspoon celery seed\n1 teaspoon caraway seed\n1/2 cup stock (chicken, beef, or vegetable) or water\n1 tablespoon mustard, preferably Dijon\n1 tablespoon malt or cider vinegar\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1 tablespoon bacon fat or extra virgin olive oil\n4 pork chops\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions and cabbage: Heat the bacon fat (or butter or olive oil) in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat.\nAdd the onion and saut\xc3\xa9, stirring only occasionally, until the edges of the onions begin to brown, about 5 minutes. Sprinkle salt over the onions as they cook.\nAdd the sliced cabbage and toss to combine. Cook for a minute or two, then add the celery seed, caraway, and stock. Cover and reduce the heat to low. Cook, covered for 10 minutes.\n2 Stir in mustard and vinegar: After 10 minutes, remove from heat, but leave the cover on the pan. Wait another 5 minutes, then uncover the pan and mix in the mustard and vinegar. Add salt and black pepper to taste.\n3 Cook the pork chops in a separate pan: As soon as you cover the cabbage pan in step 1, heat a tablespoon of bacon fat or oil in a cast iron frying pan on medium high heat. Pat the pork chops dry with paper towels. Sprinkle them with salt and lay them in the pan, working in batches if necessary as to not crowd the pan.\nTip: Place the chops in the pan so that the thickest, boniest parts are near the center of the pan where they get the most heat.\nAs soon as the chops are nicely browned on one side, about 2 minutes or so, flip them and sear them on the other side. If your pork chops are less than 3/4-inch thick, and you are using a cast iron pan, once the chops are seared on the second side, remove the pan from heat and let the chops sit in the hot pan until cooked through (you can use the finger test to check for the doneness of the meat). If you are not using a cast iron pan, just remove the pan from heat and cover the pan for a few minutes until the chops are done.\nIf your chops are thicker than 3/4-inch, and you are using a cast iron pan, remove the pan from heat and cover it, letting the chops finish cooking for about 5 minutes. If not using a cast iron pan, keep the chops covered on low heat for another 5 minutes after searing.\n4 Let chops rest, serve with cabbage: Remove the chops from the pan and let rest for 5 minutes. Serve alongside the cabbage.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nButtered Cabbage with Caraway Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 2-pound head of green cabbage\n4 Tbsp butter\n1 teaspoon caraway seeds\n1/2 teaspoon celery seeds\nSalt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Put water on to boil: Heat a large (8-quart) pot of well salted water to a boil.\n2 Prep the cabbage: While the water is heating, prepare the cabbage. Peel away and discard and discolored or old outer leaves. Cut the head of cabbage into quarters, through the core, and cut away and discard the core. Use your hands to tear the cabbage into large (about 1 to 2 inch) pieces. (Or use a knife.)\n3 Boil leaves for 90 seconds: Once the water is at a rolling boil, add the torn cabbage leaves to the water. Submerge the leaves in the hot water. Cook for 90 seconds, then drain the pot of its water. Return the cabbage leaves to the pot.\n4 Melt butter, toss with cabbage, caraway, celery seeds, salt: Stir 4 tablespoons of butter into the cabbage. The cabbage and the pan are both hot, so the butter should melt quickly in the pan.\nIf you are using unsalted butter, you will want to add more salt to the cabbage. Start with half a teaspoon and add more if needed.\nSprinkle with caraway seeds, celery seeds, and black pepper, and toss to combine.\nServe immediately. Great with pork, veal, or frankfurters.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nCabbage and Kale Slaw with Caraway Ranch Dressing Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nDressing Ingredients:\n1 tablespoon minced shallots\n2 teaspoons Dijon mustard (whole grain or smooth)\n2 Tbsp champagne vinegar (or white wine vinegar)\n6 tablespoons buttermilk\n2/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1 teaspoon caraway seeds\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nPinch of white pepper (can sub black pepper)\n  Salad Ingredients:\n4 cups thinly sliced green cabbage (about 1/2 a large head)\n1 cup thinly sliced red onion\n1 cup, packed, thinly sliced curly or lacinato kale (center tough stems removed before slicing the leaves)\nMETHOD\n1 Heat and grind caraway seeds: Heat a small saut\xc3\xa9 pan on high heat. Add the caraway seeds to the pan. Stir the seeds in the pan and heat them until they are warm and fragrant, then remove from pan. Do not brown them. Grind them with a mortar and pestle or mince them up finely with a sharp knife.\n2 Make dressing: Add the shallots, mustard, and vinegar into a bowl, whisk to combine. Whisk in the buttermilk. Slowly dribble in the olive oil, whisking to create an emulsion. (You can also put everything into a jar, close the jar and shake vigorously to create an emulsion.) Whisk in the caraway seeds, salt, and pepper.\n3 Assemble salad: Place the thinly sliced cabbage, red onion, and kale into a large serving bowl. Sprinkle with dressing and toss to combine 10 to 15 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSaut\xc3\xa9ed Chard and Onions with Caraway Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nFeel free to use spinach or kale instead of chard.  Spinach will cook very quickly.  Kale may take longer to wilt.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 large onions, sliced 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch wide slices, root to stem\nSalt\n1 pound chard, center ribs removed, leaves roughly chopped\n1 tablespoon honey\n1 teaspoon caraway seeds\n1/4 teaspoon celery seed\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n2 teaspoons sherry or red wine vinegar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions: Heat the olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over high heat until the oil is almost smoking. Add the onions and toss to coat with oil. Saut\xc3\xa9 for 10-12 minutes stirring often, until the onions are soft and browned on the edges. Sprinkle with salt while the onions are cooking.\n2 Add chard, once wilted add honey and seasonings: Add the chard to the onions and mix well with tongs.\nOnce the chard wilts, 2 to 4 minutes, add the honey, caraway seeds, celery seeds, and black pepper. Toss well to combine and cook for another 2-3 minutes, stirring often.\nAdd the vinegar right before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected.
