b'Save It Print\nSpaghetti Pasta Carbonara Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nThis recipe uses raw eggs, which are essentially cooked by tossing with hot pasta. They are not cooked to the point of scrambled though, just enough to thicken the eggs into a sauce.\nThe garlic is optional. It is not usually included in pasta carbonara, but it tastes great so we\'ve included it. By the way, "guanciale", or pork jowl, is traditionally used in this dish, so if you can get it, by all means use it.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil or unsalted butter\n1/2 pound pancetta or thick cut bacon, diced\n1-2 garlic cloves, minced, about 1 teaspoon (optional)\n3-4 whole eggs\n1 cup grated parmesan or pecorino cheese\n1 pound spaghetti pasta (or bucatini or fettuccine)\nSalt and black pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat pasta water: Put a large pot of salted water on to boil (1 Tbsp salt for every 2 quarts of water.)\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 pancetta/bacon and garlic: While the water is coming to a boil, heat the olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium heat. Add the bacon or pancetta and cook slowly until crispy.\nAdd the garlic (if using) and cook another minute, then turn off the heat and put the pancetta and garlic into a large bowl.\n3 Beat eggs and half of the cheese: In a small bowl, beat the eggs and mix in about half of the cheese.\n4 Cook pasta: Once the water has reached a rolling boil, add the dry pasta, and cook, uncovered, at a rolling boil.\n5 Toss pasta with pancetta/bacon: When the pasta is al dente (still a little firm, not mushy), use tongs to move it to the bowl with the bacon and garlic. Let it be dripping wet. Reserve some of the pasta water.\nMove the pasta from the pot to the bowl quickly, as you want the pasta to be hot. It\'s the heat of the pasta that will heat the eggs sufficiently to create a creamy sauce.\nToss everything to combine, allowing the pasta to cool just enough so that it doesn\'t make the eggs curdle when you mix them in. (That\'s the tricky part.)\n6 Add the beaten egg mixture: Add the beaten eggs with cheese and toss quickly to combine once more. Add salt to taste. Add some pasta water back to the pasta to keep it from drying out.\nServe at once with the rest of the parmesan and freshly ground black pepper.\nIf you want, sprinkle with a little fresh chopped parsley.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nZucchini Pasta Carbonara Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4\nThis recipe uses thinly sliced prosciutto, which works well with the more delicate flavor of the summer squash. But you could also use pancetta (diced), bacon (thin strips), or even thinly sliced ham.\n* To slice the basil leaves, chiffonade them by stacking basil leaves on top of each other, roll them up into a cigar shape, starting at one end and working your way down the "cigar" take thin slices from the end.\nINGREDIENTS\nSalt\n3/4 pound egg noodles\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 teaspoon butter\n1/4 pound prosciutto, thinly sliced\n1 yellow onion, chopped\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n3-4 summer squash, yielding 4 cups chopped squash\nSalt and pepper\n4 eggs\n1 cup grated Parmesan cheese (plus more for topping)\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1/2 cup basil leaves, sliced thin*\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the pasta cooking water: To cook the pasta, bring a large pot of water to a boil. Salt the water (one tablespoon of salt for 2 quarts of water).\n2 Brown the prosciutto: As the water for the pasta is heating, prep your vegetables and heat olive oil and butter on medium high in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan.\nWorking in batches, lay pieces of sliced prosciutto down in the pan. Fry gently on both sides until just lightly browned (no more than a minute, more likely 30 seconds each side, the prosciutto is very thin), remove from pan with tongs or a slotted spoon to a paper towel-lined plate to drain.\nOnce cool, tear into bite-sized pieces. Reserve oil in the pan.\n3 Add the pasta to the boiling water to cook: Add pasta to boiling salted water. The pasta should take about 10-12 minutes to cook until al dente (cooked but still a bit firm), which is just about the right amount of time you\'ll need to cook the vegetables. Cook with a rolling boil, uncovered.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, garlic, summer squash: While the pasta is cooking, add the onions, garlic, and summer squash to the saut\xc3\xa9 pan that you had used to cook the prosciutto. The heat should be medium high.\nStir the vegetables so that they are all coated with oil from the pan, then spread them out in the pan, generously salt and pepper them. Cook until they are just lightly browned, stirring only occasionally. Remove from heat.\n5 Beat the eggs, add Parmesan and lemon zest: In a medium bowl, beat the eggs and mix in the grated Parmesan and lemon zest.\n6 Add cooked pasta to vegetables, stir in egg mixture: When the pasta is ready, reserve 1/2 cup of the cooking liquid, then drain the pasta. Add the pasta to the squash and onions (or add the veggies to the pasta, depending on the size of your pans).\nPour the egg, Parmesan, lemon zest mixture over the pasta mixture and quickly stir in with a wooden spoon. The heat from the pasta will sufficiently cook the eggs.\nAdd a little of the reserved pasta cooking water if it looks a little dry. Stir in the prosciutto and basil.\nGarnish with more basil and grated Parmesan.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nSwedish Coffee Bread (Tea Ring) Recipe\nYield: Makes 2 wreaths\nIt's best to start with whole cardamom pods - peel the pods (helps to crush them first) to release the seeds. Crush the seeds with a mortar and pestle or use a rolling pin to grind them.\nINGREDIENTS\nBread:\n1 cup whole milk\n1/2 cup (100g) white sugar\n1/2 cup (4 oz) butter\n2-pkg active yeast dissolved in 1/4 cup warm water\nAbout 4 cups (560g) all-purpose flour\n1 large egg\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon ground cardamom\nFilling:\n2 tablespoons melted butter\n1/4 cup (54g)  brown sugar, packed\n1 tablespoon white sugar\n2 teaspoons cinnamon\n1 cup golden raisins (optional)\n1/2 cup slivered almonds (optional)\n1/4 cup almond paste (optional)\nEgg glaze:\n2 egg yolks\n2 tablespoon cream\nSugar glaze:\n1 cup (115g) powdered sugar\n1 tablespoon water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nMake the Dough:\n1 Put milk into a small saucepan and heat on medium heat until steamy (but not boiling). Remove from heat. Stir in the butter and sugar until the butter has melted and the sugar dissolved. Pour into a mixing bowl. Mix in yeast mixture and egg.\n2 Mix in salt and cardamom. Slowly add in 2 cups of the flour. After the first two cups of flour gradually add more flour until a soft dough starts to form a ball and pull away from the sides of the bowl.\n3 Turn out onto a floured surface and knead dough for 7 to 10 minutes until smooth, OR use a dough hook in a stand-up mixer and knead the dough that way for 7 to 10 minutes, adding more flour as needed to keep the dough from being too sticky. Note that the dough should remain soft, so take care not to add too much flour.\nLet the Dough Rise:\n4 Place the dough in an oiled bowl, covered with a clean tea-towel or with plastic wrap. Let rise for an hour or until the dough has doubled in size.\nAt this point you can make a simple braided bread if you want (2 loaves), by punching the dough down, dividing the dough in half, and then dividing each half into three equal parts, rolling the dough pieces into ropes, braiding them, and tucking the ends under.\nOr you can get more fancy, which is what we've done here, with a filling, and forming the dough into a wreath shape. The following directions are for the wreath form.\nMake the Wreath Form:\n5 Press the dough down to deflate it a bit. Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. Take one part (saving the other for wreath number 2) and use your fingers to spread it into a 8-inch by 16-inch rectangle on a lightly floured, clean, flat surface.\nIf you are having difficulty getting the dough to keep its shape, just do what you can and let it sit for 5 minutes before trying again. Like pizza dough, the dough needs time to relax while you are forming it.\nBrush the dough with melted butter, leaving at least a half inch border on the edges so the dough will stick together when rolled. Mix together the brown and white sugar and the cinnamon and sprinkle the dough with half of the mixture (saving the other half for the second batch of dough).\nSprinkle on more fillings, as you like, such as raisins, slivered almonds, or almond paste. You could even sprinkle on some cream cheese for a creamier filling.\n6 Carefully roll the dough up lengthwise, with the seam on the bottom. Carefully transfer to a greased baking sheet. Form a circle with the dough on the baking sheet, connecting the ends together.\n7 Using scissors, cut most of the way through the dough, cutting on a slant. Work your way around the dough circle. After each cut, pull out the dough segment either to the right or to the left, alternating as you go around the circle. The dough circle will look like a wreath when you are done.\nRepeat steps 5, 7, and 8 with the rest of the dough, to form a second wreath.\nThe Second Rise:\n8 Cover lightly with plastic wrap and set in a warm area for a second rise. Let rise for about 40 minutes to an hour; the dough should again puff up in size.\nBake:\n9 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Whisk together the egg yolks and cream. Use a pastry brush to brush over the dough. Bake in the oven for 25-30 minutes. After the first 15 minutes of baking, if the top is getting well browned, tent with some aluminum foil.\n10 Remove from oven and let cool completely. Whisk together powdered sugar and water to create a final glaze (optional). Add more water if the glaze is too thick to drizzle, add more powdered sugar if the glaze is too runny. Drizzle the glaze in a back and forth motion over the pastry.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nCardamom Citrus Fruit Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large ruby pink grapefruit\n3 navel oranges or a combination of naval oranges, blood oranges, mandarin oranges and/or tangerines\n1/4 cup honey\n2 Tbsp fresh lime or lemon juice\n1/4 teaspoon ground cardamon\nMETHOD\n1 Prep the fruit: Peel the fruit. Cut away the membranes of the individual segments with a sharp knife. Collect the peeled segments in a bowl.\n2 Make the dressing: Drain off any excess juice from the fruit into a small saucepan.\nAdd the lime juice, honey, and cardamom to the saucepan.\nBring to a boil and reduce heat to low. Simmer for 10 minutes and then remove from heat and let cool to room temp.\n3 Combine: Pour over fruit mixture and gently fold in so that all the fruit is coated. Let stand for 15 minutes or chill until ready to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nCardamom Honey Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesMarinating time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIf a recipe calls for ground cardamom, it is best to start with whole pods. Break open the pods to release the tiny brown and black cardamom seeds. Use a spice grinder or mortar and pestle to grind the seeds.\nINGREDIENTS\nMarinade\n4 tablespoons honey\n2 tablespoons sherry\n1 teaspoon cardamom seeds, ground\n1 teaspoon peppercorns, ground\nChicken\n4 chicken breasts, skin-on, bone-in (cut in half if large), or one whole chicken, cut into parts\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 lemon, thinly sliced\nSalt and pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Marinate the chicken: Warm the honey slightly (in microwave or on stovetop), stir in the sherry, cardamom and peppercorns.\nPlace marinade and chicken in a large bowl, coat chicken with marinade. Cover with plastic wrap and let sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.\n2 Preheat oven to 390\xc2\xb0F (200\xc2\xb0C).\n3 Sear the chicken pieces: Heat olive oil in a large frying pan at medium heat. Sear the chicken for 20 to 30 seconds, skin side down, until golden. Watch carefully, since the chicken skin goes from browned to charred quickly.\n4 Bake in oven: Place lemon slices in a roasting pan. Lay the chicken pieces on top. Brush with the marinade. Season generously with salt and pepper. Cover loosely with foil.\nPlace in the oven and bake for 25 minutes. Remove foil and continue to bake for 10 to 15 minutes longer or until a thermometer registers 165\xc2\xb0F (75\xc2\xb0C) when inserted into the thickest part of the chicken.\nCheck often. If the chicken starts to get too dark (this can happen when using honey), tent with foil.\n5 Let rest: Remove from oven and let rest for 10 minutes before serving. Pour out drippings from the pan into a gravy boat for gravy.\n6 Serve with rice, mashed potatoes, or couscous.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nPork Roast with Cardamom Mushroom Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesBrining the roast time: 23 hoursYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\nBrine:\n3/4 cup coarse kosher salt\n3/4 cup sugar\n1 gallon cold water\n1 tablespoon pepper\nRoast:\n1 1/2 cups chopped onion (about 2 medium sized onions), divided into 3 x 1/2 cups\n6 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 1/4 teaspoons ground cardamom, divided, 2 and 1/4 teaspoons\n1 large garlic clove\n1 4-pound center-cut boneless pork loin roast\nSalt and pepper\n1 1/2 pounds mushrooms, sliced\n2 cups chicken broth, divided, 1 cup and 1 cup\n1/2 cup whipping cream\n1 tablespoons all purpose flour\n1 tablespoons butter, room temperature\nMETHOD\n1 Brine the pork roast: Whisk together the salt, sugar, and water until the salt and sugar have completely dissolved. Add the pepper.\nSubmerge pork in the brine solution and chill for 1 to 2 days. Note that thick, gallon-sized freezer bag is great for brining; if you use one, you probably only need half as much brine solution. Even if you are using a bag, place in a bowl just in case the bag leaks.\nRinse the roast thoroughly of the brine solution before cooking, pat dry.\n2 Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n3 Make onion garlic cardamom rub: Pur\xc3\xa9e 1/2 cup chopped onion, 2 Tbsp olive oil, 2 teaspoons ground cardamom, and garlic in a food processor or blender.\n4 Rub roast with onion pur\xc3\xa9e, surround with mushrooms and onions in roasting pan: Toss remaining 1 cup of chopped onion with mushrooms and 4 Tbsp olive oil in a bowl. Place pork roast in the center of the roasting pan. Sprinkle the roast with salt and pepper. Rub roast with onion garlic pur\xc3\xa9e. Surround the roast with mushrooms and onions.\n5 Roast pork, remove mushrooms, add broth and water: Roast pork 1 hour at 350\xc2\xb0F. Remove from oven after one hour and remove the mushrooms, placing them into a large saucepan.\nAdd 1 cup broth and 1/2 cup water to roasting pan.\nReturn roast to oven and roast pork until thermometer inserted into thickest part registers 140\xc2\xb0F-145\xc2\xb0F, about 15-20 minutes longer. Transfer pork to platter; tent with foil.\n6 Make mushroom cream sauce with pan drippings: Scrape the drippings from the roasting pan into the pan with the mushrooms. Add the cream, remaining cup of broth, and 1/4 teaspoon cardamom to pan; bring to boil. Blend flour and butter in small cup; mix into mushroom sauce.\nCook the sauce, stirring often, until reduced enough to coat spoon. Season sauce with salt and pepper; serve with pork.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nEasy Black Beans and Rice Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup uncooked white rice\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 small onion, chopped\n1/2 green bell pepper, thinly sliced\n1/2 red bell pepper, thinly sliced (for added flavor you can substitute roasted red bell peppers or some chopped pimentos)\n3 cloves minced garlic\n2 16-ounce cans of black beans, rinsed and drained\n2 tablespoons white vinegar\nA few dashes of Tabasco or 1/4 teaspoon cayenne powder\n1 teaspoon dried oregano OR 1 heaping tablespoon chopped fresh oregano\nSalt and pepper to taste\nOptional Lime wedges and cilantro for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the rice: Cook rice according to package instructions. White rice usually takes 15 minutes to cook once the water is simmering, and 10 minutes to sit.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, bell peppers, garlic: Heat oil in a large skillet on medium high. Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and bell peppers for 3-4 minutes, until just beginning to soften, then add garlic and saut\xc3\xa9 a minute more.\n3 Add beans, vinegar, Tabasco, then simmer: Add the black beans, vinegar and Tabasco or cayenne. Bring vinegar to a simmer, reduce heat, cover and simmer for 5 minutes.\n4 Stir in rice and oregano. Add salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. b"Save It Print\nJamaican Goat Curry Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 3 hoursYield: Serve 8-12\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup vegetable oil\n6-8 Tbsp curry powder\n1 Tbsp allspice (see step 1)\n3 pounds goat (can use lamb or beef if you can't find goat)\nSalt\n2 onions, chopped\n1-2 habanero or Scotch bonnet peppers, seeded and chopped\nA 2-inch piece of ginger, peeled and minced\n1 head of garlic, peeled and chopped\n1-2 15-ounce cans coconut milk\n1 15-ounce can of tomato sauce or crushed tomatoes\n1 Tbsp dried thyme\n3-4 cups water\n5 Yukon gold potatoes, peeled and cut into 1-inch chunks\nMETHOD\n1 Make the curry powder: If you can find Jamaican curry powder, definitely use it. If not, use regular curry powder and add the allspice to it. You will need at least 6 tablespoons of spices for this stew, and you can kick it up to 8-9 depending on how spicy you like it.\n2 Cut and salt the goat meat: Cut the meat into large chunks, maybe 2-3 inches across. If you have bones, you can use them, too. Salt everything well and set aside to come to room temperature for about 30 minutes.\n3 Heat the curry powder in oil: Heat the oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Mix in 2 tablespoons of the curry powder and heat until fragrant.\n4 Brown meat in curried oil: Pat the meat dry and brown well in the curried oil. Do this in batches and don\xe2\x80\x99t overcrowd the pot. It will take a while to do this, maybe 30 minutes or so. Set the browned meat aside in a bowl. (When all the meat is browned, if you have bones, add them and brown them, too.)\n5 Cook onions, habanero, ginger, garlic: Add the onions and habanero to the pot and saut\xc3\xa9, stirring from time to time, until the onions just start to brown, about 5 minutes. Sprinkle some salt over them as they cook. Add the ginger and garlic, mix well and saut\xc3\xa9 for another 1-2 minutes.\nPut the meat (and bones, if using) back into the pot, along with any juices left in the bowl. Mix well.\n6 Add coconut milk, tomatoes, curry powder, water, thyme, then simmer: Pour in the coconut milk and tomatoes and 5 tablespoons of the curry powder. Stir to combine. If you are using 2 cans of coconut milk, add 3 cups of water. If you\xe2\x80\x99re only using 1 can, add 4 cups of water. Add the thyme.\nBring to a simmer and let it cook until the meat is falling-apart tender, which will take at least 2 hours. Longer if you have a mature goat.\n7 Add potatoes: Once the meat is close to being done \xe2\x80\x93 tender but not falling apart yet \xe2\x80\x93 Add the potatoes and mix in. The stew is done when the potatoes are. Taste for salt and add some if it needs it.\n8 Skim fat: You might need to skim off the layer of fat at the top of the curry before serving. Do this with a large, shallow spoon, skimming into a bowl. Also, be sure to remove any bones before you serve the curry.\nThe stew is better the day after, or even several days after, the day you make it.\nServe with Jamaican rice and peas, a coconut rice with kidney beans.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nSalsa Verde Carnitas Recipe\nCook time: 3 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 6\nIf you have time, lightly toast the whole cumin and coriander seeds first, in a small skillet on medium high heat.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 1/2 pounds pork shoulder, trimmed of excess fat (not all the fat, just the glaring excess fat), cut into large (3 to 4 inch) chunks\n2 cups tomatillo salsa verde, bottled or homemade\n1 1/2 cups chopped onion\n3 cups chicken stock\n2 teaspoons whole cumin seeds\n2 teaspoons coriander seeds\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1 bunch cilantro, roughly chopped, stems and tender leaves\nSalt\n12 to 16 corn tortillas, heated and softened\n1/4 head of cabbage, very thinly sliced\n1 teaspoon seasoned rice vinegar (if you only have unseasoned, add 1/4 teaspoon of sugar to it)\nSalt and pepper\n1 avocado, peeled, seeded, and chopped\n1/2 cup crumbled Cotija Mexican farmer's cheese, or some grated Monterey Jack cheese\nCrema fresca, crema Mexican, or sour cream\nChopped cilantro leaves for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Simmer pork with salsa verde, onion, stock, spices until tender: Put the pork, salsa verde, chopped onion, chicken stock, cumin seeds, coriander seeds, and oregano in a large, thick-bottomed pot, and heat on high heat. Bring to a boil, and reduce heat to a low simmer. Cover and simmer until meat pulls away easily with a fork, about 3 hours.\n2 Shred meat with two forks, then broil: Preheat oven broiler. Remove meat from the pot and put into a roasting pan. With 2 forks, tear the meat into large shreds, spreading them out in an even layer in the roasting pan. Put pan on the top rack of the oven. Broil for 5 to 10 minutes until edges and some parts are brown and crispy.\n3 Skim fat, reduce the salsa verde sauce: While the meat is browning in the oven, skim the fat from the liquid in the large pot. (Discard but do not put the fat down the drain or you will clog your pipes.)\nHeat the pot on high and vigorously boil the remaining liquid, stirring, until reduced to 2 1/2 cups, several minutes.\n4 Return meat to sauce, stir in cilantro: Return the meat to the pot with the liquid. Stir in chopped cilantro. Season with salt.\nServe with heated and softened corn tortillas (20 seconds each in the microwave spread out over a paper towel will heat and softened packaged tortillas sufficiently), diced avocado, crumbed Cotija or grated Monterey jack cheese, sour cream (or crema fresca), and seasoned cabbage slaw.\nSeasoned Cabbage Slaw\nPlace thinly sliced cabbage in a medium sized bowl. Sprinkle with seasoned rice vinegar, salt and pepper. You can substitute white vinegar or apple cider vinegar for the rice vinegar, if you do, sprinkle on some sugar to help balance the acidity of the vinegar. Toss. Adjust seasonings. Let sit for 10 minutes for the cabbage to absorb some of the dressing.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nCarrot Ginger Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4-5\nI think this soup works best when it is pur\xc3\xa9ed until perfectly smooth. This is best achieved using an upright blender. If you use an immersion blender, just keep working at it until the soup is as smooth as you can make it.\nWe use chicken stock in this recipe, but you can easily use vegetable stock for a vegetarian option.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons butter\n1 1/2 pounds carrots (6-7 large carrots), peeled and sliced thin\n2 cups chopped white or yellow onion\nSalt\n1 teaspoon minced ginger\n2 cups chicken stock or vegetable stock\n2 cups water\n3 large strips of zest from an orange\nChopped chives, parsley, dill or fennel for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and carrots: Melt the butter in a soup pot over medium heat and cook the onions and carrots, stirring occasionally, until the onions soften, about 5 to 8 minutes. Do not let the onions or carrots brown. Sprinkle a teaspoon of salt over the carrots and onions as they cook.\n2 Add stock and water, ginger, and strips of orange zest. Bring to a simmer, cover, and cook until the carrots soften, about 20 minutes.\n3 Remove the strips of orange zest! It's easy to forget this step, and if you forget and pur\xc3\xa9e the soup with the strips of zest still in it, the soup may be too bitter for your taste.\n4 Pur\xc3\xa9e soup: Pur\xc3\xa9e the soup with a stick blender, or working in small batches, pour the soup into a blender and pur\xc3\xa9e until completely smooth. Only fill the blender bowl a third full with the hot liquid and keep one hand pressing down on the cap of the blender to keep it from popping off.\nAdd more salt to taste.  (You will need more salt if you are using homemade unsalted stock or unsalted butter.)\nGarnish with chopped chives, parsley, or fennel fronds.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nVietnamese Daikon and Carrot Pickles Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesYield: Makes approximately 5 pints\nTraditionally served in Vietnamese street sandwiches called Banh Mi. These pickles would be great with anything that would typically be served with coleslaw or sauerkraut, like hot dogs, or barbecued pork, or even with salad or wrapped into a spring roll. Or just eat them straight.\nFor a lower glycemic option, you can substitute the 1 cup of sugar with 3/4 cup of agave syrup.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds carrots (about 5 medium sized carrots), peeled\n2 pounds of daikon radishes (about 2 large daikon), peeled\n1 cup plus 4 teaspoons of sugar\n2 teaspoons salt\n2 1/2 cups white vinegar\n2 cups warm water (warm enough to easily dissolve sugar\nSpecial equipment:\nAbout 5 pint jars\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Julienne the carrots and the daikon radishes: Cut them first crosswise into 2 1/2 inch long segments. Then cut 1/4-inch thick slices lengthwise. Stack the slices and cut them again into 1/4-inch thick batons.\n2 Massage with salt and sugar: Place the carrots and daikon radishes in a large bowl. Sprinkle with 4 teaspoons of sugar and 2 teaspoons of salt. Use your clean hands to toss the carrots and daikon with the salt and sugar until well coated.\nContinue to mix the carrots and daikon with your hands until they begin to soften, about 3 minutes. They are ready once you can bend a piece of daikon all the way over without it breaking.\n3 Rinse: Transfer the carrots and daikon to a colander, rinse with cool water and drain well.\n4 Make vinegar sugar mixture: In a bowl (a 8 cup pyrex measuring cup works great for this) mix together one cup of sugar, the white vinegar and the warm water, until the sugar dissolves.\n5 Pour vinegar mixture over carrots and daikon in jars: Prepare clean jars. Pack the daikon and carrots tightly into the jars. Pour over the pickling liquid to cover. Seal. Refrigerate.\nThe pickles should sit at least overnight before eating; their flavor will improve with time. They should last 4 to 6 weeks in the refrigerator.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCider Vinaigrette Roasted Root Vegetables Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nIf your root vegetables are competing with a roast for the oven for a holiday meal, just make them ahead, and put them in the oven to warm them up again while the roast rests before serving.\nWe are using parsnips, golden beets, carrots, and yams for this recipe, but you could use any of your favorite root vegetables.\nThis recipe makes enough for 6 to 8 people and requires two roasting pans. You can easily cut the recipe in half.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup cider vinegar\n1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil\n3 tablespoons dark brown sugar\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\nFreshly grated black pepper to taste\n4 medium golden beets, peeled, thickly sliced\n4 medium carrots, peeled, sliced lengthwise into 1 to 2 inch long pieces\n3 medium garnet yams, sliced lengthwise into 1 to 2 inch long pieces\n4 medium parsnips, peeled, sliced lengthwise into 1 to 2 inch long pieces, any tough woody core removed\n1 large red onion, thickly sliced\n3/4 teaspoon thyme, dry or fresh\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toss vegetables with vinegar, oil, sugar, salt, pepper: Preheat the oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. In a large bowl (enough room for all the vegetables) mix together the cider vinegar, olive oil, brown sugar, salt and pepper. Add the vegetables\xe2\x80\x94the beets, carrots, yams, parsnips, onion\xe2\x80\x94to the bowl and toss to combine.\n2 Spread vegetables out into two lined sheet pans: Line two large roasting pans or sturdy rimmed baking sheets with aluminum foil. Spread the root vegetables out over the pans in a single layer, with some space in between so that the vegetables don't crowd each other too much and the hot oven air can circulate around the vegetables. (You'll get better browning that way.) Pour the remaining vinaigrette over the root vegetables in the pans.\n3 Roast the vegetables: Place vegetables in the oven and roast at 450\xc2\xb0F for 35 to 40 minutes, turning the pans (and swapping bottom and top rack positions), half-way through the cooking. Cook until the vegetables are well browned and caramelized around the edges.\n4 Sprinkle with thyme: Remove from oven and gently loosen the root vegetables from the foil with a wooden spoon. Sprinkle with thyme. Add more salt and pepper to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nRoasted Baby Carrots Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 pounds of 5 inch long young carrots, rinsed and scrubbed clean, patted dry, carrot greens cut to 1 inch above top of carrot\n1 medium red onion, halved lengthwise (root to top) then cut into 8-12 wedges (see How to Slice an Onion)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n1 tablespoon fresh chopped rosemary\n2 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed\nSalt\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Line a roasting pan with aluminum foil.\n2 Arrange vegetables on pan, coat with olive oil, salt, pepper: Place the carrots, red onion wedges, and crushed garlic cloves on the pan and sprinkle with chopped rosemary. Drizzle with olive oil and toss to combine so that the carrots and onions are lightly coated. Sprinkle with salt and pepper.\n3 Roast: Roast at 400\xc2\xb0F for 30 to 40 minutes until well browned and caramelized around the edges.\nRemove from pan and place in a serving dish to serve.\nHello! b'Print\nCarrot Cake Cupcakes Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 24 cupcakes\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup (100 g) chopped walnuts\n1 pound (450 g) carrots (about 3 1/2 cups, grated)\n3 large eggs\n1/2 cup (120 ml) of buttermilk (or add a teaspoon of lemon juice to regular milk and allow to stand for 10 minutes)\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n2 cups (400 g) sugar\n1 cup (240 ml) vegetable oil\n1 tablespoon orange zest\n3 cups (400 g) all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon baking soda\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground cardamom\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\nCream Cheese Frosting:\n1 cup unsalted butter, softened\n16 ounces Philadelphia cream cheese\n2 cups powdered sugar, sifted\nMETHOD\n1 Toast the walnuts: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Toast the walnuts in the oven for 5 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside to cool.\n2 Line 2 standard (12-well) cupcake pans with cupcake liners.\n3 Mix wet ingredients and carrots: Place the buttermilk, oil, sugar, eggs, vanilla extract, and orange zest together in a bowl and whisk thoroughly. Then stir in the grated carrots.\n4 Mix dry ingredients: In another bowl whisk the flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt, cardamom, and cinnamon.\n5 Fold dry ingredients into wet, add walnuts: Fold the flour mixture into the carrot mixture, being sure not to over-mix. Fold in the toasted walnuts until evenly incorporated.\n6 Bake: Scoop the batter into cupcake papers, filling them about 1/2 to 3/4 full. Bake for 19-21 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F, rotating the pan after the first 15 minutes of baking.\nCool for 5 minutes before taking the cupcakes out of the cupcake tin and allowing them to fully cool on a wire rack.\n7 Make the frosting: Beat the cream cheese and butter on medium speed until well combined. Sift in the powdered sugar and mix. Spread or pipe onto cooled cupcakes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'

Cover and refrigerate until ready to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nMoroccan Grated Carrot and Beet Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nWe always have fresh mint growing in yard somewhere, which is why I like tossing it into salads. If you don't have easy access to fresh mint for this recipe, just skip it.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups of grated carrots (from about 3 carrots)\n1 cup of grated fresh beets (from about 1 medium sized peeled beet)\n1/2 cup golden raisins\n1/2 teaspoon paprika (sweet, not hot)\n1/4 teaspoon ground cumin\n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon\nSmall pinch of salt\nSmall pinch of cayenne\n2 Tbsp lemon juice\n2 teaspoons honey\n2 Tbsp sliced fresh mint leaves\nMETHOD\n1 Rinse the grated beets, combine with carrots and raisins: Place the grated carrots in a medium sized serving bowl.\nPlace the grated beets into a sieve and briefly rinse with cold water. This will rinse away a little of the excess beet juice that may otherwise color the whole salad beet red.  Pat dry with a paper towel.\nThen add to the bowl with the carrots.  Add the raisins.  Stir to gently combine.\n2 Make the dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together the paprika, cumin, cinnamon, salt, and cayenne. Then add the lemon juice and honey and whisk until smooth.\n3 Dress the carrots and beets, let sit for an hour: Drizzle over the the carrots and beets, then gently fold until the carrots and beets are lightly coated.  Let sit for an hour before serving, either chilled or at room temperature, for the dressing to seep into the carrots and beets.\n4 Stir in sliced mint before serving: Right before serving, stir in a couple tablespoons of sliced fresh mint leaves. Garnish with fresh mint.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"

b'Save It Print\nWinter Root Vegetable Slaw Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4-6 as a side dish\nThe choice of root vegetables here works well, but you are free to mix and match. Just be sure to not have too many sweet vegetables like carrots and parsnips, or too many sharp ones, like radishes or turnips.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon sugar\n1/4 cup sherry or red wine vinegar\n1 cup chopped parsley, loosely packed\n2/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2 large carrots (choose different colored carrots if you can find them)\n2 medium parsnips\n1 small celery root\n2 black radishes or 1/2 daikon radish\nMETHOD\n1 Make the vinaigrette: Put the mustard, salt, sugar, vinegar and parsley in a blender and process until combined, about 30 seconds. Scrape down the sides of the blender, cover and process at its slowest setting.\nDrizzle in the olive oil slowly. When it is all in, move the blender to its highest setting and puree for about 90 seconds.\n2 Shred the root vegetables: Peel all the vegetables except for the radishes, if you are using black ones. The slivers of black in the salad look cool, so I leave them in.\nUsing a vegetable peeler or a coarse grater, slice shreds off the vegetables into a bowl. Try to keep the shreds roughly the same length if you can.\n3 Toss shredded vegetables with vinaigrette: To finish, toss some of the vinaigrette with the shredded vegetables and let stand in the fridge for at least 20 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSlow Cooker Honey-Dijon Glazed Carrots Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesSlow Cooker Time time: 4 to 6 hoursYield: 6 servings\nDoubling this recipe: A double batch is best cooked in a larger (7-quart) slow cooker. If cooking in a smaller slow cooker, stir the carrots every so often so they cook evenly. No changes are needed to the cooking time.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 pounds carrots, peeled and cut 1/2-inch thick on a bias\n1 1/4 cup water\n2 teaspoons kosher salt, divided\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted\n1/4 cup honey\n1/4 cup Dijon mustard\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh sage\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\nSpecial equipment:\nSlow cooker, 3 1/2 quart or larger \nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Slow cook the carrots: Place the carrots into your slow cooker. Add the water and 1 teaspoon of kosher salt. Cover and cook the carrots on low for 4 to 6 hours, or until tender when pierced with a fork.\nDrain the water from the carrots and return them to the slow cooker.\n2 Add the glaze: In a separate bowl, whisk together the remaining salt, butter, honey, Dijon mustard, sage, and black pepper until they are blended well.\nPour the honey-Dijon mustard glaze over the carrots. Toss the carrots in the glaze to coat evenly. Season with more salt and pepper to taste.\n3 Serve: Reduce the slow cooker\xe2\x80\x99s temperature to warm. The carrots are now ready to serve, or you can cover them and hold on warm anywhere from 1 to 2 hours.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nClassic Corned Beef and Cabbage Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 4 hoursYield: 6 servings\nCorned beef often comes with a spice packet. For this version, I discard the packaged spices, and instead make my own blend for a more flavorful, satisfying brisket.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the corned beef\n1 flat-cut corned beef brisket (about 4 pounds)\n1/4 teaspoon mustard seed\n1/4 teaspoon coriander seed\n1/8 teaspoon whole cloves\n1/8 teaspoon whole peppercorns\n2 to 3 bay leaves\n1 large onion, peeled and quartered\n6 Yukon gold potatoes (about 1 pound), halved, or quartered, if large\n1 small head of cabbage (about 1 3/4 pounds), outer tough leaves removed and cut into 6 wedges\n12 slender carrots (about 1 pound), peeled and left whole\n2 teaspoons kosher salt\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley (for garnish)\nDijon or grainy mustard (for serving)\nFor the horseradish sauce (Optional)\n1 cup sour cream\n3 tablespoons whole milk\n1 tablespoon lemon juice, or more, to taste\n1 tablespoon prepared horseradish in brine, or more, to taste\n1/2 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the horseradish sauce (optional): In a bowl, stir the sour cream and milk together until blended. Stir in the lemon juice, horseradish, and mustard. Add the salt, pepper, and parsley, and taste. Add more horseradish or lemon juice, if you like. Cover and set in the refrigerator until ready to serve.\n2 Preheat the oven: Preheat the oven to 325\xc2\xbaF.\n3 Prepare the meat for braising: Discard the spice packet that came with the beef. In a Dutch oven or other large, heavy-bottomed pot, place the brisket, mustard seed, coriander seed, cloves, peppercorns, bay leaves, and onion quarters. Add enough cold water to just cover the meat.\n4 Braise the meat: Over medium heat on the stovetop, bring the water to a boil. Cover the pot and place in the oven for 3 1/2 hours, or until the beef is very tender when pierced with a fork. Remove the meat from the broth with tongs and transfer it to a shallow baking dish or baking sheet.\n5 Brown the meat: Increase the oven temperature to 425\xc2\xb0F. Place the corned beef in the oven with a ladle of stock, and bake for 10 to 15 minutes, or until the top browns. Transfer the meat to a cutting board, cover with foil to keep warm, and let rest while you cook the vegetables. Turn off the oven.\n6 Strain the stock, cook the vegetables, and slice the meat: In a fine mesh strainer, strain the stock and return it to the pot. Add the salt. With a ladle, skim the fat that rises to the top. Bring it to a boil.\nAdd the potatoes and adjust the heat to a simmer. Cook for 5 minutes. Add the cabbage wedges and carrots, cover and bring to a simmer again. Cook for 15 to 20 minutes, or until the potatoes, carrots, and cabbage are tender.\nTransfer them to a deep platter, cover with foil, and keep them warm in the turned-off oven.\n7 Slice and serve the corned beef: Slice the beef across the grain into 1/4-inch thick slices. Transfer them to the platter with the vegetables, and spoon a few ladles of stock over the meat and vegetables. Sprinkle with chopped parsley. Serve with mustard and/or horseradish sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSkillet Chicken Thighs with Potatoes, Carrots, and Greens Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 4-6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n8 (3 pounds) bone-in, skin-on, chicken thighs\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon pepper\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 1/2 pounds (about 4 medium) Yukon Gold potatoes, cut into 1-inch chunks\n12 ounces baby carrots\n3 whole, unpeeled cloves garlic, smashed with the flat of a knife to break the skin\n1 bunch Swiss chard\n1 1/2 cups chicken stock\n1 tablespoon Dijon mustard\nFinely grated zest of 1 lemon\n1/2 teaspoon dried thyme\nJuice of 1/2 lemon\n1/4 cup chopped parsley\nSpecial equipment:\nLarge (12- to 13-inch) oven-proof skillet or Dutch oven\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven: Preheat the oven to 400\xcb\x9aF.\n2 Trim and season the chicken thighs: With scissors or a sharp knife, cut off excess flaps of skin and fat from the thighs. Sprinkle with salt and pepper on both sides.\n3 Prep the chard stalks and leaves: Tear or cut the stalks from the leaves. Cut the stalks into 1-inch pieces. Slice the leaves into 2-inch-wide strips. Keep the stalks and leaves separate.\n4 Brown the chicken and par-cook the potatoes and carrots: In a large (12- to 13-inch) ovenproof skillet set over medium-high heat, add the oil. Once the oil shimmers, add the chicken with the skin side down. Cook on the skin side only for about 5 minutes without disturbing it, or until the skin lightly browns.\nTransfer to a plate. (If the chicken doesn\xe2\x80\x99t fit in one skillet, cook in batches or use two smaller skillets and divide the ingredients between them.)\nAdd the potatoes and carrots to the skillet and cook for 5 minutes, or until they brown lightly.\n5 Prep the braising liquid: In a bowl or measuring cup, whisk the chicken stock, mustard, and lemon zest to combine.\n6 Braise the chicken: Add the chard stalks, smashed garlic and braising liquid to the skillet with the vegetables. Set the chicken pieces on top and sprinkle with the thyme.\n7 Transfer to the oven: Transfer the pan to the oven. Roast, uncovered, for 30 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and the vegetables are tender. Remove the pan from the oven.\n8 Add the chard leaves: Transfer the chicken thighs to a plate. Taste the broth and add more salt, if you like. Set the skillet over high heat and bring the liquid to a boil. Stir the chard leaves into the skillet and cook for 2 to 3 minutes, or just until wilted. Remove the garlic cloves.\n9 Serve: Set the chicken on top of the vegetables. Squeeze the lemon over the chicken and sprinkle with the parsley. Serve from the skillet, or transfer to a large serving platter. Serve as is, or with a salad.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nHow to Make Creamy Vegan Cashew \xe2\x80\x9cCheese\xe2\x80\x9d Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesSoaking time: 4 to 8 hoursYield: About 1 cup\nIf you have a Vitamix, you only need to soak the cashews for about 30 minutes before blending.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup raw, unsalted cashews\n3/4 cup to 1 cup water\n2 teaspoons lemon juice\n1/4 teaspoon sea salt\nSpecial equipment:\nBlender\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Soak the cashews: Place the cashews in a bowl and cover with about 2 inches of warm water. Soak for at least 4 hours, up to 8 hours.\n2 Make the cashew cream: When ready to make the cashew cream, drain and rinse the cashews. Place them in a blender along with 3/4 cup fresh water, lemon juice, and the salt.\nPuree, adding more water as needed, until you achieve a smooth, pourable sauce.\nUse it immediately, or transfer to an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to five days. You can also freeze it for up to three months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBaby Bok Choy with Cashews Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 5 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil\n1 cup chopped green onions, including green ends\n3 cloves garlic, chopped\n1 pound baby bok choy, rinsed, larger leaves separated from base, base trimmed but still present, holding the smaller leaves together\n1/2 teaspoon dark sesame oil\nSalt\n1/2 cup chopped, roasted, salted cashews\nMETHOD\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, garlic, bok choy: Heat olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add onions, then garlic, then bok choy. Sprinkle with sesame oil and salt.\n2 Cover, and let the baby bok choy cook down for approximately 3 minutes. (Like spinach, when cooked, the bok choy will wilt a bit.)\n3 Remove cover. Lower heat to low. b"Save It Print\nSpicy Garlic Cashew Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 4\nTaste the jalape\xc3\xb1os first, before using. Jalape\xc3\xb1os vary in heat and sometimes you need more, sometimes less to get the desired heat level. If you want to take it up a notch in heat, leave in more of the seeds.\nUse gloves when handling jalape\xc3\xb1os (or a plastic sandwich bag), or coat your hands with a little oil first, before cutting the peppers, and then wash hands with warm soap and water after.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup roasted (salted or unsalted) cashew nuts\n6 Tbsp roughly chopped cilantro (leaves and stems)\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n4 garlic cloves, roughly chopped\n2 tablespoons soy sauce (use gluten-free for gluten-free version)\n2 teaspoons brown sugar\n1 to 2 jalape\xc3\xb1o peppers, stems and most seeds discarded, roughly chopped\n1 Tbsp lime juice, plus lime wedges for garnish\nKosher salt and freshly ground black pepper\n3 pounds bone-in, skin-on chicken thighs\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the spicy cashew paste: In a food processor or blender, add the cashews, cilantro, olive oil, garlic, soy sauce, brown sugar, jalape\xc3\xb1o, lime juice, and 2 tablespoons of water.\nPulse or blend until the mixture is a smooth paste. Add salt and pepper to taste.\nReserve a third of the marinade for serving with the chicken. Use the rest for coating the chicken.\n2 Coat chicken with the cashew paste: Sprinkle the chicken thighs all over with salt and pepper. Coat the chicken pieces with the marinade.\nAt this point if you want, you can make ahead, and chill for several hours or overnight until ready to cook. Bring to room temperature before cooking.\n3 Grill or broil the chicken: Preheat broiler or prepare grill (or grill pan) for medium direct heat.\nBroil or grill chicken, turning frequently, until golden and crisp and a meat thermometer reads 165\xc2\xb0F when inserted into the thickest part of the thigh (not touching a bone), or when the juices run clear (not pink) when cut into with a knife.\nThis will take about 25 to 35 minutes for a grill on medium heat, or about 10-20 minutes under a broiler, depending on how far the chicken is from the heat.\nNote that as you turn the pieces, some of the coating will fall off. It's to be expected, so don't worry if and when this happens.\nServe with lime wedges, reserved marinade, and cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nEasy Cashew Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesMarinating time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nYou can whip this up pretty quickly if you first start with the marinade, then chop the vegetables and cook the cashews while the chicken is marinating.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken:\n4 skinless, boneless chicken breasts (about 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 pounds total), cut into 1-inch cubes\n3/4 cup peanut oil or other vegetable oil\n3 tablespoons chili powder\n1/2 cup tamari (or soy sauce; use wheat-free tamari or soy sauce if you need to cook gluten-free)\n1/2 cup honey\n2 cups raw cashews\n3 cups roughly chopped onions (about 2 medium large onions)\n3 cups roughly chopped mushrooms\nFor garnish, optional:\n1 to 2 teaspoons minced fresh ginger\n1/4 cup chopped scallions or green onions, green parts only\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: Place the cubed chicken in a medium bowl. Add the oil. Add the tamari until the marinade turns dark brown (about 2 tablespoons per breast). Sprinkle the chili powder over the chicken pieces while stirring, so that each piece of chicken gets well coated with the chili powder and marinade.\nStir in the honey, about 2 tablespoons for each breast. Add chopped ginger if using. Marinate for 1/2 hour to several hours, the longer the better.\n2 Toast the cashews: Heat a skillet on medium high heat. Spread the cashews in a single layer over the bottom of the pan. Stir until lightly browned, remove from heat.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 the chicken: Heat a large skillet on medium high heat. Working in batches if needed so you don't crowd the pan, use tongs to remove the chicken pieces from the marinade and place them in the pan, reserving the extra marinade.\nSaut\xc3\xa9 the chicken pieces until just cooked through, remove from the pan and set aside.\nPlace any extra marinade back in the pan and simmer for several minutes (to kill any bacteria). Pour off all but 1 tablespoon of the marinade into a separate bowl and reserve.\n4 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and mushrooms: In the same pan, saut\xc3\xa9 the onions on medium high to high heat for several minutes.\nAdd mushrooms and continue to saut\xc3\xa9 until onions are translucent and mushrooms are cooked, several minutes more. Add some reserved marinade to the pan if necessary.\n5 Combine all the ingredients. Add the chicken and cashews back to the pan with the mushrooms and onions. Stir to combine.\n6 Serve: Stir in onion greens (if using) right before serving. Serve over rice. This will keep for about 5 days in the refrigerator, covered.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nSaut\xc3\xa9ed Kale with Toasted Cashews Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup to 3/4 cup unsalted, roasted cashews, roughly chopped\n4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil, divided\n1/2 yellow onion, sliced\n1/2 teaspoon red pepper flakes\n1 bunch kale, rinsed, tough midrib removed, roughly chopped\n1 tablespoon lemon juice, plus more to taste\nSalt\nMETHOD\n1 Toast the cashews: In a large, shallow saut\xc3\xa9 pan, heat on medium high. Add the cashews and spread out in an even layer. Toast, stirring occasionally until lightly browned here and there, and you smell the aroma of the toasted cashews. Remove from the pan to a bowl.\n2 Cook the onions: Add a couple tablespoons of olive oil to the pan. Heat on medium. Add the onions and cook until translucent, about 5 minutes.\n3 Add the kale and red pepper flakes: Increase the heat to high/medium high. Add a couple tablespoons more of olive oil to the pan. Add the red pepper flakes. Add the roughly chopped kale. Use tongs to turn the kale leaves over so that they are all coated with olive oil.\nCook just a couple minutes, turning the leaves over often, until they are just beginning to wilt.\n4 Sprinkle on lemon juice and salt. Remove from heat. Stir in the cashews.\nTaste and add more salt and lemon juice to taste.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. b"Save It Print\nZucchini Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Makes 6-8 portions\nINGREDIENTS\n6-8 eggs\n1 cup ricotta cheese (about 245 g)\n1 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese (130 g)\n1/4 teaspoon Tabasco sauce or other hot chili sauce\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n3 cups grated zucchini (from 2-3 fresh zucchinis, about 390 g)\n1 1/2 cups chopped plum tomatoes (from 4-5 fresh tomatoes, about 370 g),\n1/2 cup sliced fresh basil (from about 20 leaves)*\n4 cups cubed day-old bread (from about 4 slices, rustic French or Italian bread works best)\nExtra virgin olive oil\n*Chiffonade basil by stacking a few leaves on top of each other, roll them up like a cigar, slice thin, starting at one end of the cigar and working your way down.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the egg cheese base: In a large bowl beat the eggs. Add the ricotta and beat until smooth. Mix in the grated Parmesan cheese, Tabasco, salt and pepper.\n2 Prep the vegetables and bread, add to egg mixture: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). Prepare the vegetables and bread. Once you chop the tomatoes, squeeze excess moisture out of them by pressing them in a sieve, or wrapping in paper towels and squeezing. Add the tomatoes, basil, and zucchini to the egg mixture.\nMoisten the bread cubes with a little water then squeeze out any excess moisture using paper towels. Mix the bread cubes into the egg mixture.\n3 Bake: Coat the bottom and sides of a 9x13 baking dish generously with olive oil. Pour the egg vegetable mixture into the baking pan and even it out in the pan. Place in the middle rack of the oven.\nBake for 30 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). The casserole should puff up and brown lightly. If it hasn't browned enough after 30 minutes at that temp, increase the heat to 425\xc2\xb0F (220\xc2\xb0C) and cook for 5-10 minutes further.\nRemove from oven and let cool on a rack for 10 minutes before cutting into squares to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nEasy Breakfast Casserole with Prosciutto Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 6 to 8\nYou can make and bake this savory strata all in one fell swoop, or assemble and refrigerate it the night before (but leave the cheese off until morning). Pull it out of the fridge 30 minutes before baking; add the cheese, and pop it into the oven.\nIf you have vegetarians at your table, feel free to skip the prosciutto and add one teaspoon of smoked paprika instead.\nThe strata holds up well as a leftover, so enjoy it for breakfast the next day, or pack up a slice for your desk lunch.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil\n1 medium yellow onion, chopped\n2 big handfuls tender greens, such as arugula, dandelion greens, baby kale, or spinach (tough stems removed)\n1 1/2 cups asparagus, cut into 3/4-inch pieces\n1 teaspoon kosher salt, divided\n3 ounces thinly sliced prosciutto\n2 packed cups cubed crusty bread, such as levain, baguette, or Italian bread (slightly stale is ok)\n8 large eggs\n1 cup low fat cottage cheese\n1 cup 2% milk (or whatever kind you have in the fridge)\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1 1/2 cups (3 oz) grated cheddar, divided\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the vegetables: Add oil to a 12-inch ovenproof skillet set over medium heat. I use cast iron, but any ovenproof skillet will do.\nAdd the onion and saut\xc3\xa9 until tender, about 5 minutes. Add the greens, asparagus, and 1/2 teaspoon salt and saut\xc3\xa9 until the greens wilt, about 2 minutes. Remove from heat.\n3 Add the prosciutto and bread: Tear the prosciutto slices into smaller pieces and distribute over the vegetables. Add the bread and stir everything together. Leave that to cool while you whisk the eggs.\n4 Whisk the eggs: In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs, cottage cheese, milk, the remaining 3/4 teaspoon salt, and several generous grinds of black pepper. Add 1/2 cup of the cheese and stir again. Pour the eggs over the vegetables and scatter the remaining cheese on top.\n5 Bake the casserole: Place the casserole in the oven and bake until it is just set with no obvious liquid remaining, about 35 minutes. It should be a little jiggly. Keep in mind that it will continue to cook a bit once it\xe2\x80\x99s out of the oven.\n6 Serve: Cool for 10 minutes. Cut into wedges and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nMexican Lasagna Recipe\nPrep time: 45 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 8\nCorn tortillas come in different varieties. The sturdy yellow corn tortillas will have more flavor, and hold up better in this casserole, but they do require "softening" or cooking in a little oil before layering. If you use tender white corn tortillas, you may not need to soften them.\nINGREDIENTS\nExtra virgin olive oil\n1 1/4 pounds ground beef or ground turkey\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 tablespoon chili powder\n1 tablespoon ground cumin\n1 tablespoon ground coriander seeds\n1/4 teaspoon cayenne\n1 14-oz can refried pinto beans (or you can make your own refried beans)\n2 medium onions, chopped (about 2 1/2 cups)\n1 red bell pepper, stem and seeds removed, chopped (about 1 cup)\n3 garlic cloves, peeled and minced\n1 28-oz can crushed or diced tomatoes, preferably "Fire Roasted"\n1 7-oz can diced green Anaheim chiles\n1/2 teaspoon dried oregano\n12 (6-inch) corn tortillas (choose sturdy tortillas mad with yellow corn)\n2 cups coarsely grated Monterey Jack cheese (about 8 oz)\n2 cups coarsely grated mild cheddar cheese (about 8 oz)\nTo serve:\nSour cream\nAvocado\nCilantro\nIceberg lettuce\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brown the ground beef: Heat 2 tablespoons olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan or cast iron frying pan on medium high heat. Add the ground meat, breaking it up as you add it.\nSprinkle with salt. Sprinkle on the chile powder, cayenne, cumin, and coriander. Increase the heat to high. Add another 2 tablespoons of olive oil.\nDo not stir the meat unnecessarily. Allow the meat to brown on one side, and then stir it so the other side can be browned.\nAs soon as the meat is browned, remove the pan from the burner. The meat will continue to cook in the heat of the pan.\nOnce you are sure that the meat is cooked through, use a slotted spoon to remove the meat from the pan to a bowl. Set aside.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, bell peppers, garlic, add tomatoes, chiles, oregano: Add another tablespoon of olive oil to the empty pan used to cook the meat and set over medium heat.\nAdd the onions and chopped bell peppers. Cook until onions have softened, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic, cook for an additional 1 minute.\nAdd the diced tomatoes, green chiles and oregano. Bring to a simmer. Simmer gently for 15-20 minutes while you prepare the tortillas.\n3 Cook the tortillas: While the sauce is simmering, soften the tortillas by frying them in a little oil. In a 9-inch skillet, heat 1/2 cup olive oil on medium high heat until it is sizzling hot, but not smoking.\nCook the tortillas one at a time, for 5 seconds on each side, so that they soften, but don\'t get crisp.\nRemove the tortillas with a metal spatula or tongs and place on a plate lined with paper towels to soak up the excess oil.\n4 Preheat oven: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F and lightly oil a 9x13-inch glass or ceramic baking dish.\n5 Assemble the casserole: In baking dish, arrange 4 tortillas in one layer, overlapping slightly (tortillas will not cover bottom completely).\n(If you don\'t have time to pre-soften the tortillas, coat the bottom of the pan with some olive oil and spread a little sauce over the bottom before adding the tortillas.)\nSpread half of bean mixture evenly over tortillas in dish and top with half of meat mixture. Sprinkle one third cheese over the meat and spread half of the sauce over the cheese.\nRepeat layering of tortillas, beans, meat, cheese, and sauce and top with remaining 4 tortillas. Sprinkle remaining cheese over tortillas.\n6 Bake: Bake casserole on the middle rack in the oven at 350\xc2\xb0F for 35 minutes, until the casserole is heated through and the cheese is completely melted and bubbling.\n7 Cool and serve: Let the casserole stand for 10-15 minutes before serving.\nServe with sour cream, chopped avocado, chopped cilantro, and thinly sliced iceberg lettuce on which has been sprinkled vinegar and salt.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nCheesy Potato Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup butter, plus more for the casserole dish\n1 yellow onion, diced\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour\n3 cups vegetable or chicken stock\n2 cups grated cheddar cheese\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n30 ounces frozen hash browns\nDAD ADD: Fried Serrano Rings:\n3 serranos, sliced\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nCoarse salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prepare the casserole dish: Preheat oven to 400\xcb\x9aF. Lightly butter or grease a 9x13 baking dish.\n2 Make the cheese sauce: In a medium pot, melt 1/4 cup butter over medium heat. Add diced onion and cook for 3-4 minutes until onions turn translucent but not browned. Then add minced garlic and cook for 30 seconds.\nStir in flour and continue to cook for a minute or two until the flour turns a tan color. Slowly whisk in stock and bring sauce to a slight simmer. The sauce will thicken as it heats. Once the sauce is thick like gravy, stir in the cheddar cheese and season with salt and pepper. Remove from heat.\n3 Combine the potatoes and the sauce: In a large bowl add the frozen hash browns and pour the sauce over the hash browns. Stir together well to combine and transfer to the prepared baking dish. Smooth the top.\n4 Bake the casserole: Place the casserole in the center rack of your oven and bake for 45 minutes at 400\xcb\x9aF. Then turn on the broiler and broil for 5 minutes on high to crisp up the top of the casserole. If your casserole dish is not broiler-safe, then turn the oven up to 500\xcb\x9aF and bake for 3 more minutes.\n5 Serve: Let the casserole cool slightly but serve while warm.\n6 Make the Crispy Serrano Rings (Optional DAD ADD): Slice serrano peppers into thin coins. Heat a few tablespoons of olive oil over medium heat in a small skillet. Once it is hot, add serrano coins and cook for 2-3 minutes until they start to brown. Remove the coins from the skillet and let drain on a paper towel. Season with a pinch of salt.\nLEFTOVERS!\nLeftovers keep in the fridge for 5 days. Reheat in the microwave until warmed through.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nReuben Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 6-8\nINGREDIENTS\n8 slices (9 ounces) seeded sliced rye bread\n8 ounces cream cheese, room temperature\n1 1/2 pounds sliced pastrami or corned beef (from the deli or homemade)\n8 ounces sliced Swiss cheese\n22 ounces (2 3/4 cups) sauerkraut, drained\n1 1/2 cups Thousand Island dressing\n2 teaspoons caraway seeds\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nButter for the baking dish\nSpecial equipment:\n9x13-inch baking pan\nFood processor\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the pan and heat the oven: Butter a 9x13 baking dish and preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Cube and crumb the bread: Take 6 slices of the bread and cut them into 1-inch cubes. Ultimately, you need enough bread to cover the bottom of your baking dish. If you're bread isn't pre-sliced, you might need more to do this.\nTake the remaining 2 slices of bread and pulse in a food processor until fine crumbs are formed.\n3 Chop the meat and the cheese: Chop the pastrami (or corned beef if you\xe2\x80\x99re using) into bite sized pieces. I do this by stacking it and cutting the meat first in strips, then I cut across the strips to form rough squares. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need to be perfect. It\xe2\x80\x99s a casserole.\nStack the cheese slices one on top of the other, then cut it in strips, and then cut across the strips into squares.\n4 Make the filling: In a large bowl, add the cream cheese and smoosh it with a spoon or spatula to soften and break it up a bit. Add the meat, Swiss cheese, sauerkraut, thousand island dressing, caraway seeds, and salt. Stir to combine, making sure you fully incorporate the cream cheese.\n5 Layer the casserole: Place the cubed bread on the bottom of your 9x13 baking dish (slice and add more cubes if needed to make a full layer). Then spoon the filling over the top of the bread. Spread it out as evenly as possible. Sprinkle the breadcrumbs over the top.\n6 Bake the casserole: Place the casserole in the oven and bake for 40-45 minutes until the crumbs are toasted and the casserole is heated through.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nEasy Shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s Pie Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 to 2 pounds potatoes (about 3 large potatoes), peeled and quartered\n8 Tablespoons (1 stick) butter\n1 medium onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n1-2 cups vegetables\xe2\x80\x94diced carrots, corn, peas\n1 1/2 lbs ground round beef\n1/2 cup beef broth\n1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce\nSalt, pepper, other seasonings of choice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Boil the potatoes: Place the peeled and quartered potatoes in medium sized pot. Cover with at least an inch of cold water. Add a teaspoon of salt. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook until tender (about 20 minutes).\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 vegetables: While the potatoes are cooking, melt 4 tablespoons of the butter in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the chopped onions and cook until tender, about 6 to 10 minutes.\nIf you are including vegetables, add them according to their cooking time. Carrots should be cooked with the onions, because they take as long to cook as the onions do.\nIf you are including peas or corn, add them toward the end of the cooking of the onions, or after the meat starts to cook, as they take very little cooking time.\n3 Add the ground beef, then Worcestershire sauce and broth: Add ground beef to the pan with the onions and vegetables. Cook until no longer pink. Season with salt and pepper.\nAdd the Worcestershire sauce and beef broth. Bring the broth to a simmer and reduce heat to low. Cook uncovered for 10 minutes, adding more beef broth if necessary to keep the meat from drying out.\n4 Mash the cooked potatoes: When the potatoes are done cooking (a fork can easily pierce), remove them from the pot and place them in a bowl with the remaining 4 Tbsp of butter. Mash with a fork or potato masher, and season with salt and pepper to taste.\n5 Layer the meat mixture and mashed potatoes in a casserole dish: Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Spread the beef, onions, and vegetables (if using) in an even layer in a large baking dish (9x13 casserole).\nSpread the mashed potatoes over the top of the ground beef. Rough up the surface of the mashed potatoes with a fork so there are peaks that will get well browned. You can even use a fork to make creative designs in the mashed potatoes.\n6 Bake in oven: Place in a 400\xc2\xb0F oven and cook until browned and bubbling, about 30 minutes. If necessary, broil for the last few minutes to help the surface of the mashed potatoes brown.\n(Be careful when broiling using Pyrex or glass dishes, they have been known to shatter under the high heat of the broiler. It's not a worry if you are using a ceramic or metal casserole dish.)\nSuggested variations:\nPut a layer of creamed corn between the ground beef and the mashed potatoes.\nSprinkle grated cheddar cheese over the top of the mashed potatoes before baking.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nCheesy Potato Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup butter, plus more for the casserole dish\n1 yellow onion, diced\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour\n3 cups vegetable or chicken stock\n2 cups grated cheddar cheese\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n30 ounces frozen hash browns\nDAD ADD: Fried Serrano Rings:\n3 serranos, sliced\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nCoarse salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prepare the casserole dish: Preheat oven to 400\xcb\x9aF. Then add minced garlic and cook for 30 seconds.\nStir in flour and continue to cook for a minute or two until the flour turns a tan color. Slowly whisk in stock and bring sauce to a slight simmer. Heat a few tablespoons of olive oil over medium heat in a small skillet. Once it is hot, add serrano coins and cook for 2-3 minutes until they start to brown. b'Print\nSweet Potato Casserole with Marshmallows Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 8 to 10 servings\nTo make ahead: Prepare the recipe through Step 4, then cover the casserole with plastic wrap and refrigerate for up to 3 days. Bake for 45 to 50 minutes, or until hot all the way through. Top with marshmallows and bake for a few more minutes until the marshmallows have melted.\nINGREDIENTS\n8 sweet potatoes (about 4 pounds)\n1/4 cup plus 1 tablespoon unsalted butter, softened at room temperature\nFinely grated zest of 1 orange\n1/2 cup fresh-squeezed orange juice\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon pepper\n4 cups large marshmallows (about 12 ounces), cut in half with scissors\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Roast the sweet potatoes: Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xbaF. Line a baking sheet with parchment and spray it with vegetable oil spray.\nScrub clean and dry the sweet potatoes. Slice them in half lengthwise.\nPlace the potato halves, cut side down, on the baking sheet. Prick each in several places with a fork and bake for 40 to 45 minutes, or until soft. Remove and let rest until potatoes are cool enough to handle.\n2 Lower the oven temperature to 375\xc2\xbaF. Butter or coat with cooking spray a 3-quart or 9-x13-inch baking dish.\n3 Remove the sweet potato skins: As soon as the potatoes are cool enough to handle, pull off the skins and discard. Transfer the inner flesh to the bowl of a stand mixer bowl fitted with the paddle attachment, or a large bowl.\n4 Mash the potatoes: Add 1/4 cup of the butter, orange zest, orange juice, salt and pepper. Mix on low speed in the stand mixer until the potatoes are creamy, but not necessarily perfectly smooth. Taste and add more salt and pepper, if you like. Transfer the potatoes to the buttered baking dish.\nAlternatively, mash with a potato masher and beat until creamy with a wooden spoon, then transfer to the baking dish.\n4 Bake the casserole: Dot the top of the casserole with the remaining 1 tablespoon of butter. Cover loosely with foil and bake for 30 to 35 minutes, or until hot.\n5 Add the marshmallows: Place the marshmallows close together in a random pattern over the potatoes. Return the casserole to the oven and bake for 5 to 7 minutes, or until the marshmallows melt and brown.\n6 Serve: Cool the casserole briefly and serve while hot. Leftovers can be refrigerated for up to 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nLoaf Pan Lasagna for Two Recipe Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: 2-3 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n2 Italian chicken sausages (about 1/2 pound)\n1 can (28 ounces) whole, peeled tomatoes\n1 clove garlic, thinly sliced\n1 teaspoon dried oregano\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon sugar\n1 large egg\n1 cup ricotta cheese\n1/3 cup finely grated Parmesan\nPinch ground nutmeg\nPinch ground black pepper\nOil or oil spray (for the loaf pan)\n4 no-boil lasagna noodles\n1/2 cup shredded mozzarella\nFor garnish:\nChopped parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the sausage: In a medium skillet over medium-high heat, add 1 tablespoon of the oil. Either slice the sausage into rounds or remove the casing from the sausage by slicing lengthwise down the side and cook it like ground sausage.\nWhen the oil shimmers, add the sausage to the pan, and cook for about 6 minutes or until browned. Use a cooking utensil to break the sausage up as you cook it. Transfer to a plate.\n2 Snip the tomatoes: Open the can of tomatoes and use a large pair of scissors to snip and break them up in the can into chunky pieces. You will mash them a little more in the skillet.\n3 Make the sauce: In the same skillet you used to brown the sausage, heat 1 tablespoon oil over medium heat. Add the sliced garlic and oregano. Cook for 30 seconds, or until the garlic sizzles. Add the tomatoes with their juices, salt, and sugar. Bring to a simmer and cook for 2 to 3 minutes or until the sauce is hot.\nUse a potato masher to break up the tomatoes into smaller pieces (this is easiest to do when tomatoes soften in the heat). You are aiming for a chunky sauce.\nAdd the sausage back to the pan and cook for 10 minutes. Taste, and add more salt and sugar, if you like.\n4 Make the ricotta mixture: Meanwhile, in a small bowl, stir the egg, ricotta, Parmesan, nutmeg, and pepper together.\n5 Preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Brush or spray a 4x8-inch loaf pan with oil.\n6 Assemble the lasagna: In the bottom of the loaf pan, ladle about 1/2 cup tomato-sausage sauce. Top with 1 noodle. Spread with 1/2 cup sauce, and then spread 1/3 mounded cup of the ricotta mixture over it.\nPlace a second noodle on top of the sauce. Spread 1/3 mounded cup ricotta mixture over it, and top with 1/2 cup tomato-sausage sauce.\nPlace a third noodle on top of the sauce. Spread with remaining ricotta and spoon 1/2 cup tomato-sausage sauce over it, using up all of the remaining sausage pieces in this layer.\nPlace a fourth noodle on top of the sauce and spoon the remaining sauce on top. Sprinkle with the mozzarella.\n6 Bake the lasagna: Place the loaf pan on a baking sheet. Fold a large piece of foil in half and fold it in half again. Make a tent over the loaf pan (so it does not stick to the cheese.) Bake for 25 minutes.\nRemove the pan from the oven and remove the foil tent. Check to see if the lasagna is uneven or if it peaks in the middle. If it\xe2\x80\x99s uneven, use the back of a spoon to press the top layer lightly to make it level in the loaf pan and submerge the noodles in the sauce.\nTurn the oven down to 375\xc2\xb0F. Return lasagna to the oven and continue to bake for 15 minutes, or until the sauce bubbles and the cheese is golden brown. (If you like stretchy rather than browned cheese, check after 10 minutes.)\n7 To serve: Allow the lasagna to rest for 10 minutes before serving. Sprinkle with chopped parsley, if you like.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nEggplant Parmesan Recipe\nYield: Serves 8\nFirst cut the eggplant and salt the eggplant rounds. Then prep the rest of the ingredients while the eggplant rounds are releasing their moisture.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/4 pounds (about 2 large) eggplants\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n  1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 clove minced garlic (about 1 teaspoon)\n1 28-oz can whole peeled tomatoes (preferably San Marzano), tomatoes diced, reserve juices\n1/2 cup finely chopped fresh basil\nKosher salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n  1 1/2 cups breadcrumbs\n1 1/4 cups shredded Parmesan cheese, divided\n3/4 cup flour\n4 eggs, beaten (more if needed)\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil (plus more to oil the sheet pans)\n1 1/2 pounds fresh mozzarella, sliced into 1/4-inch slices\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Slice and salt eggplant, let drain: Slice the eggplants into 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch thick rounds. Lay the eggplant slices out on a rack over a rimmed sheet pan (or on several layers of paper towels).\nSprinkle both sides of the eggplant rounds lightly with salt. Let the eggplant rounds sit and release moisture for 2 hours.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 garlic, add tomatoes, simmer, add salt, pepper, basil: Heat 1 Tbsp olive oil in a 4-quart saucepan on medium heat. Add the minced garlic and gently cook for 1 minute or until fragrant.\nAdd the tomatoes and their juices, breaking up the tomatoes as you add them to the pot. Increase heat to bring to a simmer, lower heat to maintain a very low simmer for 15 minutes, uncovered. Add salt and pepper to taste. Add the minced basil and remove from heat.\n3 Make breadcrumb Parmesan mixture, set up bowls for dredging with flour, egg, breadcrumbs: Combine 1 1/2 cups of breadcrumbs with 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, and place in a shallow bowl or rimmed dish.\nSet up your station so that you have flour in one shallow bowl, beaten eggs in another bowl, and the breadcrumb cheese mixture in another, in that order.\n4 Dredge eggplant rounds in flour, egg, breadcrumbs, top with olive oil: Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Spread a tablespoon of olive oil each over the bottom of two rimmed baking sheet pans. Pat dry the eggplant slices with paper towels.\nWorking one at a time dredge the eggplant slices first in the flour, then dip in the beaten eggs, and then dredge in the breadcrumb parmesan cheese mixture.\nPlace on oiled sheet pan. Drizzle a little oil over the top of each breaded eggplant round.\n5 Bake eggplant rounds: Place breaded prepared eggplant slices in the oven. Cook for 18 to 20 minutes at 425\xc2\xb0F, turning the slices over at the half-way point, until they are nicely browned. Remove from oven, and let cool to touch.\n6 Layer sauce, eggplant rounds, cheeses in casserole dish: Spread 1/2 cup of the tomato sauce over the bottom of a 9x13-inch casserole dish. Place a third of the eggplant rounds in a single layer covering the sauce on the bottom of the pan.\n  Layer half of the sliced mozzarella on top of the eggplant rounds.
