Set aside 20 minutes to marinate, until crisp-tender.\n4 Finish the salad: To the bowl with the vegetables, add the olive oil, cooked bulgur, parsley, scallions, and sherry vinegar. Stir to combine. Taste and add salt, lemon juice, or olive oil as needed.\n5 Let stand 30 minutes before serving: Cover and let mixture marinate at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before serving to give the flavors time to combine. (If marinating longer, set in the fridge.)\nSalad will keep well covered in the fridge for 3 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nCauliflower Gratin Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 6\nINGREDIENTS\n1 head cauliflower, cored, broken into bite-sized florets (see How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n2 medium-small leeks, cleaned, halved lengthwise, sliced into 1/4-in thick slices, white and light green parts only, about 2 cups\n2 Tbsp butter\n2 Tbsp all purpose flour\n1 1/3 cups milk\n4 ounces Gruyere cheese, grated\n1 teaspoon minced fresh thyme or 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme\n1/8 teaspoon grated nutmeg\n1 teaspoon salt\nPepper\nTopping:\n1 1/2 cups fresh breadcrumbs (3 slices of sandwich bread or rustic bread, pulsed in a food processor)\n1 Tbsp butter\n1/4 teaspoon salt\nPepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the leeks: Melt butter on medium heat in a medium sized saucepan. Add the sliced leeks and gently cook until completely softened, about 8 to 10 minutes.\n2 Lightly steam the cauliflower: While the leeks are cooking, place cauliflower florets in a steamer basket in a saucepan over an inch of water. Bring water to a boil, cover, and steam the cauliflower for 3 to 4 minutes.\nThe steaming should just take the rawness out of the cauliflower, but not cook it so much that it is tender. You want the cauliflower at this stage to be al dente. Remove strainer and cauliflower from hot pan and set aside.\n3 Make roux with butter, leeks, flour, add milk: Add 2 Tbsp of flour to the leeks and butter. Stir and let cook for a minute or two. Slowly add the milk, stirring as you add it to break up any lumps. Bring to a low simmer and continue to stir as the sauce thickens.\n4 Stir in cheese, thyme, nutmeg, salt: Once the sauce is thick enough to coat the back of a spoon, stir in 3 ounces of the shredded cheese (reserving the rest of the cheese for the topping), the thyme, nutmeg, and salt.\n5 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n6 Pour sauce over cauliflower in gratin dish: Spread a teaspoon of butter over the insides of a 2-quart gratin dish. Place the lightly steamed cauliflower florets in an even layer in the dish. Pour the leek and cheese sauce over the cauliflower. Top with remaining cheese.\n7 Bake at 400\xc2\xb0F for 25 minutes.\n8 Toast breadcrumbs: While the gratin is baking, melt 1 Tbsp of butter in a small saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium high heat. Add the fresh breadcrumbs and toast in the melted butter for 4 to 5 minutes, until lightly browned. Sprinkle with 1/4 teaspoon of salt, and a sprinkling of pepper. Remove from heat.\n9 Top gratin with toasted breadcrumbs and bake: After the gratin has baked for 25 minutes, remove it from the oven. Sprinkle toasted breadcrumbs over the top and return to the oven. Bake for 5 more minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCauliflower Mashed \xe2\x80\x9cPotatoes\xe2\x80\x9d with Brown Butter Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nCauliflowers vary in size. If you are working with a cauliflower that is larger or smaller than 1 1/4 pounds, increase or decrease the amount of butter and sour cream to add.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large cauliflower (about 1 1/4 pound or 565 g), core removed, cut into large florets (see How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n1 cup (235 ml) water\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n2 tablespoons butter\n4 tablespoons (60 ml) sour cream\nChopped chives, green onions, and/or parsley for garnish\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Steam/boil the cauliflower: Place 1 cup water in a medium saucepan. Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Add the cauliflower florets.\nBring to a boil on high heat. Lower the heat to a simmer.\nCover and let the cauliflower cook for 10-14 minutes, until very tender.\n2 Brown the butter: While the cauliflower is cooking, melt the butter in a small saucepan (easier to use a stainless steel pan so that you can see the browning occur) on medium heat.\nOnce the butter melts, it will begin to foam up a bit. When the foam subsides, look for amber colored bits forming at the bottom of the pan.\nWhen the butter begins to brown, smell it. It will have a lovely nutty aroma.\nWhen you can see lots of flecks of browned bits, and the melted butter smells wonderful, remove it from the heat and pour into a bowl (glass or metal).\nButter can quickly go from browned to burnt, so keep an eye on it and work quickly when the butter starts to brown! (See our more detailed instructions on How to Brown Butter.)\n3 Strain the cooked cauliflower: When the cauliflower is cooked through and tender enough to mash with a fork, strain out all but a tablespoon or two of the remaining water.\n4 Mash with a potato masher and stir in the brown butter and sour cream. (Make sure to scrape in all the browned bits from the butter; that's where the flavor is!)\n5 Pur\xc3\xa9e to desired consistency: Use an immersion blender or a standing blender and blend the mashed potatoes to as smooth a consistency as you would like. Or just mash more with a potato masher if you like a chunky consistency.\nAdd salt and pepper to taste. Top with chopped chives, green onions, or parsley to serve.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nSimple Cauliflower Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\nFlorets from one head of cauliflower (See How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n1 quart of water\nSalt\nUnsalted butter\nChives\nExtra virgin olive oil\nMETHOD\n1 Cook cauliflower florets in salted water: Bring 1 quart of water to a rolling boil in a medium-sized pot. Add 2 teaspoons of salt to the water.\nAdd the cauliflower florets, and cook until cooked through, about 4 minutes. Use a slotted spoon to remove florets to a bowl. Reserve cooking water.\n2 Pur\xc3\xa9e cooked cauliflower: Working in batches, fill a blender half-way with cooked cauliflower, add enough cooking water to the blender bowl so that it comes up a quarter of the way. Pur\xc3\xa9e until smooth. You want the consistency to be that of soup, so if you need to add more water, do so.\n3 Add salt and butter: or each blender batch, add salt and butter to taste (about 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and about a tablespoon or more of butter for each blender batch). Since you are using only lightly salted cooking water for a base, not stock, you will need to salt this more than you would otherwise.\n4 Serve: Serve immediately into bowls. Drizzle olive oil over the top and sprinkle with chopped chives.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nHow to Cut and Core Cauliflower\nINGREDIENTS\nOne head of cauliflower\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Pull leaves off base of cauliflower.\n2 Cut cauliflower in half from the top of the crown through the stem.\n3 Lay the cauliflower halves cut side down on the cutting board and cut them vertically again.\n4 Lay the cauliflower quarter on the cutting board and angle the knife so that it cuts out the core. Repeat with remaining quarters of cauliflower.\n5 Pull apart the cauliflower florets.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nPasta with Cauliflower, Tomato, and Parmesan Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4\nVariations to this recipe include adding some toasted pinenuts or walnuts, a few raisins, and or some saffron.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup fresh breadcrumbs*\n6 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil, divided 2 and 4 Tbsp\n1 onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n2 tablespoons anchovies packed in oil, minced (about 6 anchovies)\n1 large head of cauliflower, core removed and discarded, florets coarsely chopped (see How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n5 cloves of garlic, minced\n1/2 teaspoon of crushed red pepper flakes (more or less to taste)\nSalt and freshly ground black pepper\n3 tablespoons tomato paste\n1/2 pound small elbow macaroni\n1 15-ounce can of whole tomatoes, chopped, or diced tomatoes, including juice\n1/4 cup chopped Italian parsley\n1/2 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese\n* To make breadcrumbs, chop up about 3 slices of day old bread. Pulse in blender or food processor until you have small crumbs.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toast breadcrumbs: Toast crumbs in a little olive oil in a large skillet on medium high heat until lightly browned. Remove crumbs from skillet and set aside.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions with garlic and anchovies: Heat 2 Tbsp olive oil in the skillet on medium low heat. Add the onions, garlic, and anchovies.\nCrush the anchovies with the back of a spoon so that they smear well over the onions. Cook for 5 minutes, until the onions are soft. Remove the onions from the pan and set aside.\nWhile you are cooking the onions, put a large pot of salted water (1 Tbsp salt for 2 quarts of water) for the pasta on the stove to boil.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 cauliflower florets: Heat 4 Tbsp olive oil in the skillet on medium high heat. Add the cauliflower, stir infrequently, allowing the cauliflower edges to brown. Cook until the cauliflower florets are lightly browned, 3-5 minutes. Add red pepper flakes to the pan, and salt and pepper to taste.\n4 Add tomato paste, tomatoes, onion mixture: Dissolve tomato paste in 1/2 cup of water. Lower the heat to low. Add the tomato paste, tomatoes, onion, garlic, and anchovies, stir to combine well.\nCook, uncovered, on low heat, until the cauliflower is tender.\n5 Cook pasta, add to cauliflower mixture: Cook the pasta, uncovered, in salted boiling water until just al dente, according to the pasta package's cooking directions. Drain the pasta from the cooking water and add the cooked pasta to the cauliflower mixture.\nStir in about half of the parsley, breadcrumbs, and Parmesan (leave the rest for garnish on top).\nMakes great leftovers as the flavors have more time to blend.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nCauliflower Pasta Bake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: 6 to 8 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the pasta:\n1 large head cauliflower\n3 tablespoons olive oil\n1 medium yellow onion\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/2 pound pasta, such as shells, pipe rigate, or rigatoni\n1/2 cup (1 1/2 ounces) finely grated Parmesan\n1 cup milk, whole or 2%\nZest from one lemon (about 1 tablespoon zest)\n2 tablespoons chopped thyme leaves\n3 cups (8 ounces) grated Gouda\nFor the cracker topping:\n14 (1 small sleeve) Ritz crackers, or similar buttery crackers\n2 tablespoons finely grated Parmesan\n2 tablespoons melted butter\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\nSpecial equipment:\n3-quart or 4-quart baking dish (a 9x13 baking dish works great)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xbaF. Place one rack in the top third of the oven and one rack in the lower third.\n2 Prepare the cauliflower and the onions: Trim away the outer leaves and cut the cauliflower into slices roughly 1/4-inch thick. Some smaller florets will fall away; this is fine.\nSpread the cauliflower slices and any florets that have fallen off on a rimmed baking sheet. Drizzle with 2 tablespoons of the oil. Using your hands, rub the oil into the cauliflower, coating both sides. Sprinkle with 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper.\nRoughly chop the onion. On a second baking sheet or in an ovenproof skillet, toss the onions with the remaining 1 tablespoon of the oil and sprinkle with 1/4 teaspoon salt.\n(Roasting the cauliflower and onions on separate pans will give them more space and help them roast better.)\n3 Roast the cauliflower and onions: Place the cauliflower on the lower rack of the oven and the onions on the top rack. Roast for 25 to 30 minutes, until both are tender and golden. Flip the cauliflower once during roasting; stir the onions occasionally. Remove the onions from the oven if they finish before the cauliflower or start to burn.\nLet the vegetables cool slightly in their pans. Break the cauliflower into smaller florets.\n4 Lower the oven temperature to 375\xc2\xbaF for baking the pasta.\n5 While the vegetables roast, cook the pasta: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the pasta to the boiling water and cook for 8 to 10 minutes, or until al dente (do not overcook or the pasta will become mushy after baking). Scoop out and reserve 1 cup of the pasta cooking water.\nDrain the pasta in a colander.\n6 Assemble the casserole: Return the drained pasta to the pot and immediately stir in 1/2 cup of Parmesan while the pasta is still hot. Once the cheese has melted and absorbed into the pasta a little, stir in the milk.\nAdd the roasted cauliflower and onion, lemon zest, thyme and Gouda, and stir well. Taste and add more salt and pepper, if you like. If the mixture seems dry, add a little pasta cooking water, a tablespoon at a time.\nTransfer to a 3- or 4-quart baking dish.\n7 Top with the crispy cracker crumbs: Place the crackers in a zip-top bag and crush with a rolling pin until coarsely crumbled.\nIn a bowl, mix the crushed crackers with 2 tablespoons Parmesan, the melted butter and parsley. Sprinkle this evenly over the pasta.\n8 Bake the pasta: Bake for 35 to 40 minutes, or until the pasta is hot and the top is golden.\n9 Cool briefly and serve. Leftovers can be refrigerated for up to 5 days and reheated in a microwave or a warm oven.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nTurmeric Cauliflower Curry Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 head cauliflower (about 1 3/4 pounds)\n3 medium Yukon gold potatoes (about 1 1/4 pounds)\n1 1/2 cups water\n1 medium onion, coarsely chopped\n1 poblano chili pepper, seeded and coarsely chopped\n1 2-inch piece fresh ginger, sliced\n1 teaspoon ground turmeric\n2 teaspoons garam masala\n1/2 teaspoon salt, or to taste\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 cup frozen green peas\n12 cherry tomatoes, halved\n1 cup plain yogurt\n3 tablespoons chopped fresh cilantro\n2 limes, quartered, for garnish\nSpecial equipment:\nBlender or food processor\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.\n2 While waiting for the water to boil, prepare the cauliflower and potatoes: Cut the potatoes into 1 1/2-inch cubes. To prepare the cauliflower, use a chef's knife to cut a deep cross into the base of the cauliflower. Place your thumbs into the crevice and pull the head apart into 4 quarters Stand each quarter upright, and slice off and discard the core and outer leaves. Break or cut the cauliflower into bite-size florets.\n3 Cook the potatoes and cauliflower: Carefully transfer the potatoes into the boiling water and cook for 4 minutes. Add the cauliflower and cook for 10 minutes longer, or until the vegetables are tender. (Total cooking time is 14 to 15 minutes) Drain into a colander.\n3 Make the curry sauce: In a blender or food processor, combine the water, onion, chili pepper, ginger, turmeric, garam masala, and salt. Puree until smooth.\n4 Cook the curry sauce: Warm the olive oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the sauce and cook for 2 minutes. Stir in the cooked cauliflower and potatoes. Taste and add more salt and garam masala, if you like.\n5 Finish the dish: Stir the peas and tomatoes into the pot. Heat for 2 to 3 minutes, or until hot. Just before serving, stir in the yogurt and reheat gently (do not let it boil, or the yogurt may curdle.)\nTransfer to a serving dish and sprinkle with cilantro. Serve with lime wedges.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Print\nCream Of Celeriac Soup with Brussels Sprouts Chips Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 8 as a starter, 6 as a main course\nEditor's Note: Celeriac, or celery root, is the large, bulbous root of a particular type of celery plant. It has a flavor similar to celery, but more intense and earthy. Look for it near the other root vegetables in the produce section at the grocery store.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the Brussels sprouts chips:\n10 brussels sprouts\n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil\n1/8 teaspoon natural salt, plus more to taste\nFor the soup:\n2 tablespoons grapeseed oil or extra-virgin olive oil\n2 cups diced yellow onion\n2 teaspoons minced garlic (from 2 whole cloves)\n1 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste\n1 medium head cauliflower, cut into florets (See How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n3 cups peeled and diced celeriac (from 1 large root)\n8 cups vegetable broth, plus more as needed\n1/4 cup blanched slivered almonds\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, plus more to taste\nSpecial equipment:\nBlender\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the Brussels sprouts chips: Heat the oven to 350F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone liner.\nSlice the bottom tip of each sprout, and peel off the outer leaves. Trim off a bit more of the bottom, and peel off the next layer of leaves. Continue this process until you've removed all of the leaves.\nToss the leaves with the olive oil and salt, and spread them out in a single layer on the baking sheet. Roast for about 10 minutes, until the leaves are browned and crisp.\nSet aside until needed.\n2 While the Brussels sprouts are roasting, start the soup: In a large saucepan, warm the oil over medium heat and saute\xcc\x81 the onion, garlic, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt for about 5 minutes, until the onions are soft and translucent. Add the cauliflower and celeriac, and saute\xcc\x81 for another minute.\n3 Add the broth and simmer: Add the vegetable broth and 1/2 teaspoon of the salt, increase the heat to high, and bring just to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium-high and simmer for 20 to 30 minutes, until the cauliflower and celeriac are just tender.\n4 Remove the saucepan from the heat and stir in the almonds: Allow the soup to cool slightly for 10 minutes. (This gives the nuts time to soften.)\n5 Puree the soup: Pour the soup into your blender in batches and puree on high for 30 to 60 seconds, until smooth and creamy. Return the soup to the saucepan and warm it over low heat. Stir in the remaining 1\xe2\x81\x844 teaspoon the salt, and add the pepper. Season with additional salt and pepper, to taste.\n6 To serve: Ladle portions of the soup into bowls, and top with the Brussels sprouts chips.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nCauliflower Pasta with Bacon and Parmesan Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n3 to 4 ounces thick-cut sliced bacon, cut into half inch pieces\nExtra virgin olive oil\n1/2 cup panko bread crumbs\n3/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 Tbsp fresh chopped parsley\n1 teaspoon fresh thyme or 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme\n2 cups thinly sliced red onion (1 large red onion)\n1 Tbsp minced garlic (about 3 cloves)\n4 cups small bite-sized cauliflower florets (see How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n1/2 pound cavatappi, gemelli, or fusilli dry pasta\n2 teaspoons grated lemon zest\n1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Bring salted water for pasta to a boil: Place a large pot of salted water (2 quarts of water, 1 Tbsp salt), on to the stove to boil. While the water is heating, continue with the recipe.\n2 Cook the bacon: Place the bacon pieces in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Cook until lightly browned and much of the fat rendered, about 5-6 minutes. Remove the bacon from the pan to a bowl, retaining the fat in the pan.\n3 Brown the panko: While the bacon in step 2 is rendering, brown the panko in a separate skillet on medium high heat, stirring occasionally. When most of the panko is browned, remove from heat and place in a bowl. Stir in 2 tablespoons of olive oil, 3/4 teaspoon salt, 1/8 teaspoon of pepper, the parsley and thyme. Set aside.\n4 Cook the onions and garlic: Increase the heat to medium high. You'll want about a tablespoon to a tablespoon and a half of fat in the pan. If your bacon has not yielded that much fat, then add some olive oil to the pan. Add the sliced red onion. Cook until lightly browned, about 4 to 5 minutes. Add the garlic and cook an minute more.\nRemove the onions and garlic from the pan, adding them to the bowl with the bacon.\n5 Saut\xc3\xa9 the cauliflower: Add 2 more tablespoons of olive oil to the pan and heat on high heat. Add the cauliflower florets and toss to coat with the olive oil. Brown on high heat for 5 minutes, and then lower the heat, cover, and cook for 5 more minutes, or until the cauliflower florets are cooked through and tender.\n6 Cook the pasta: About the same time that you start cooking the cauliflower, add the pasta to the boiling pasta water. Cook the pasta at a rolling boil for 8 to 10 minutes, until cooked through, but still a little firm to the bite, al dente. Reserve 1 cup of the pasta water and drain the pasta.\n7 Combine bacon, onions, cauliflower, pasta, lemon zest, Parmesan: Add the bacon and onions into the pan with the cauliflower. Stir in the pasta, lemon zest, grated Parmesan. Drizzle in another tablespoon of olive oil.\nSprinkle with some of the reserved pasta water to loosen the pasta and cauliflower if it seems a bit dry. Serve topped with toasted seasoned breadcrumbs.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nCauliflower Pur\xc3\xa9e Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 head cauliflower, stem trimmed of leaves, florets roughly chopped (see How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n1 cup chicken stock, vegetable stock (for vegetarian option), or salted water (if cooking gluten-free, use water or gluten-free stock)\n3 Tbsp of sour cream\n1 Tbsp butter\nSalt and pepper\nMETHOD\n1 Boil cauliflower: Place roughly chopped cauliflower in a medium saucepan, add stock. Bring to a boil and reduce heat to a simmer. Cover and cook until the cauliflower is tender, about 10 minutes.\n2 Pur\xc3\xa9e cooked cauliflower in blender: Place the cooked cauliflower in a blender. Add a tablespoon or two of the cooking liquid and pulse until smooth, about 15 to 20 seconds.\nAdd the sour cream and butter, and blend 5 to 10 seconds more. Season to taste with salt and pepper.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nCream of Celery Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 5\nTaste the raw celery you plan to use in this soup. The celery should be fresh and good on its own, not old or bitter. If you have a particularly tough or bitter bunch of celery, please don't use it in this soup, find another use for it.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons butter, divided into 2 Tbsp and 1 Tbsp\n1 cup chopped onion\n1 1/2 cups sliced leeks, white and light green parts only\n1 large bunch or 2 small bunches celery (5 cups chopped for the soup, 1 1/2 cups diced for the topping)\n2 cloves garlic, minced\n2 bay leaves\n4 cups chicken stock\n1/2 teaspoon to 1 1/2 teaspoons of salt, to taste\n1/4 to 1/3 cup of cream\nFreshly ground black pepper to taste\nFresh chopped chives or parsley for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions, leeks, 5 cups chopped celery: Melt 2 tablespoons butter in a thick-bottomed 4 to 5 quart pot on medium heat. Add the diced onion, the leeks, and 5 cups of the chopped celery.\nCook on medium heat for 10 minutes until softened. Add the minced garlic and cook for a minute more.\n2 Add stock, bay leaves, salt, then simmer: Add the chicken stock and bay leaves to the pot. Taste for salt and add salt. (If you are using unsalted butter and unsalted stock, you will need to add more salt than you expect, if not, maybe just a little salt will be needed.)\nIncrease heat to bring to a boil, reduce heat to low and cover to maintain a simmer. Simmer for 15 minutes.\n3 Braise remaining celery to soften: While the soup is simmering, prepare the extra celery that will be added later to the soup. In a separate small saut\xc3\xa9 pan, melt 1 tablespoon of butter on medium heat. Add 1 1/2 cups diced celery to the butter.\nLadle 1/2 cup of the simmering stock from the soup pot into the saut\xc3\xa9 pan. Simmer on low for 5 or 6 minutes to soften the celery. Set aside.\n4 Pur\xc3\xa9e soup: Remove the soup pot from heat, let cool slightly. Remove and discard the bay leaves. Working in batches, pur\xc3\xa9e the soup in a blender, filling the blender no more than a third full at a time (keep your hand on the lid so the hot liquid doesn't explode). Return the pur\xc3\xa9ed soup to the pot.\n5 Stir in the cream and the braised diced celery.\nTaste for salt and add more if needed. Sprinkle with freshly ground black pepper and chopped chives or parsley to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nCelery, Blue Cheese and Hazelnut Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4-8\nTo save time, start by roasting the hazelnuts. While they roast, you can prep all the other ingredients. Celery bunches come in different sizes, so the amounts here are a little inexact. Just make sure you have enough blue cheese so that you get a little with every bite of the celery.\nINGREDIENTS\n6 ounces good quality blue cheese\n3/4 cup hazelnuts\n1 tablespoon butter\n3 tablespoons maple Syrup\nPinch of cayenne\nSalt\n2-3 bunches of celery, tops removed\n12-15 pitted dates (can sub with a handful of dried cranberries or cherries)\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil (or hazelnut oil if you happen to have it)\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n4 teaspoons lemon juice (if using Meyer lemons, use 2 Tbsp)\nFreshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Remove cheese from refrigerator to come to room temperature.\n2 Roast hazelnuts: Place hazelnuts on a rimmed baking sheet in a 300\xc2\xb0F oven for 30 minutes.\n3 Prep celery and dates: While the nuts are roasting, prepare the other ingredients. Use a vegetable peeler to peel away the tough outer strings of the stalks of celery. Slice the celery stalks on the diagonal into 1/4-inch thick slices.\nSlice the dates lengthwise first in half, then slice the halves lengthwise into 3 or four pieces. If the dates are on the large size, you may want to slice them in half widthwise first. You want to end up with pieces that are about an inch long and a 1/4 inch wide.\n4 Rub outer skin off hazelnuts: Once the hazelnuts have roasted for half an hour, remove them from the oven, let cool for a few minutes. Then rub the hazelnuts together inside of a clean dish towel to remove as much of the outer dark skin as you can.\n5 Glaze hazelnuts: Melt butter in a small skillet. Add a pinch of cayenne and salt. Add the roasted hazelnuts to the pan and toast them on medium low heat for a few minutes, continuously stirring.\nWhen the hazelnuts are hot, turn off the heat and add maple syrup to the pan. Stir to coat the hazelnuts in the maple syrup.\nLet glazed nuts sit in the pan to cool. Later you will scrape them loose with a wooden spoon and serve atop the salad.\n6 Prepare the salad dressing: In a small jar, mix together the olive oil, lemon zest, and lemon juice. Add salt and black pepper to taste. Shake to combine.\n7 Assemble salad: Layer a shallow platter or dish first with the sliced celery, then dates, then crumble the blue cheese over it and sprinkle with glazed hazelnuts. Right before serving, pour dressing over top.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nClassic Tuna Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesYield: 2 servings\nThis recipe serves two, but it\xe2\x80\x99s easy enough to double or even triple to serve larger families.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 (5-ounce) can tuna packed in water\n1 rib celery, diced\n3 tablespoons mayonnaise\n1 teaspoon finely chopped red onion\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\nPinch of salt\nPinch of black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Drain the tuna: Open the can and hold it over the sink. Tilt the can and press on the lid to allow the water in the can to drain.\n2 Mix the tuna salad: In a bowl, break the tuna up with a fork. Add the celery, mayonnaise, onion, lemon juice, salt, and pepper. Stir to combine. Taste and adjust seasoning to your liking. Chill or use immediately.\n3 To serve: Spoon tuna salad onto slices of bread to make a sandwich, scoop onto crackers for a snack, or serve it atop a bed of salad greens.\nHello! b'Print\nCelery Root Mash Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4-6 as a side dish\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds celery root\n1/2 cup milk or cream\n3 tablespoons unsalted butter\nSalt to taste\nChopped celery root leaves, for garnish (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Bring a large pot of salted water to a simmer (1 Tbsp of salt for every 2 quarts of water).\n2 Peel and cube the celery root, boil until soft: While the water is coming to a boil, peel the celery roots with a knife. Cut the celery roots into 1-inch pieces.\nBoil for 25-30 minutes, until soft.\n3 Drain the pot, steam the celery root: Drain the pot, return the celery roots to the pot to the stovetop on low. Cover and let the celery roots steam for a minute or two, shaking the pan a bit to prevent sticking.\n4 Add the milk or cream, butter and a generous pinch of salt and mash with a potato masher until it is as smooth as you like it. Add salt to taste and garnish with the celery root leaves, if using.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nBeef and Barley Stew with Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 30 minutesYield: Serves 8-10\nIf you can't find celery root, you can substitute turnips, rutabagas or potatoes. Just be sure to adjust your cooking times\xe2\x80\x94potatoes cook faster than celery root. Save time in the prep work by prepping the onions and mushrooms while the beef is browning.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp unsalted butter\n2-3 pounds beef chuck, cut into chunks\nSalt\n3 cups chopped onions\n1 pound button or cremini mushrooms, quartered if small or 1/4-inch sliced\n1 quart beef or chicken broth\n3 cups water\n2 teaspoons dried marjoram\n1 cup pearl barley\n1 cup roughly chopped carrot\n3 cups celery root, peeled and chopped into 3/4-inch to 1-inch chunks\nBlack pepper\nAbout 1/2 cup sour cream (around 1 Tbsp sour cream per serving)\nDill for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sear the beef: In a large, thick-bottomed pot, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add enough pieces of the beef to sear in the pot without crowding.\nYou will need to brown the meat in several batches. Salt the beef as it cooks, and set aside browned pieces in a bowl.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 the onions: When all the beef has browned, add the onions. As the onions release some of their water, use a wooden spoon to scrape any browned bits off the bottom of the pot.\nSprinkle a little salt over the onions as they cook. Lower the heat to medium and cook the onions until they begin to brown, 5-6 minutes.\n3 Add the mushrooms: When the onions have lightly browned, mix in the mushrooms and increase the heat to high. Cook the mushrooms until they release their water, about 2-3 minutes.\n3 Add back beef, add marjoram, stock, water, then simmer: Add the beef back to the pot and sprinkle with marjoram.\nAdd 1 cup of the stock and use the wooden spoon to scrape any browned bits off the bottom of the pot. Add the rest of the stock and water and bring to a simmer.\nCover the pot, lower the heat to low and simmer very gently for 1 hour.\n4 Add barley, celery root, carrots, continue to simmer: Add the barley, celery root and carrots, stir well and recover the pot. Simmer gently until the barley and celery root are tender, between 40 minutes and an hour.\n5 Serve with sour cream and dill: Ladle servings into bowls, then top with a dollop of sour cream and a few sprigs of dill. Grind a little black pepper over right before you serve. To eat, stir in the sour cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nRabbit Braised in Belgian Ale Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nMany markets carry whole frozen rabbits. Call ahead to have your butcher defrost and cut rabbit into parts. Otherwise, defrost by by placing into a large bowl of cool water. Once thawed, cut into parts (see these instructions). Try to remove any stray little bones at the edges of some of the cuts of rabbit.\nThe dish works best with a Belgian ale. If not available, try Newcastle brown ale or Anchor Steam ale, or O-Doule amber ale if you need to avoid alcohol. Do not attempt this recipe with a hoppy beer.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 2 1/2 to 3 pound rabbit, cut into 6 to 7 serving pieces (2 front legs, 2 back legs, the loin cut into 2 to 3 pieces), plus ribs and flap meat\nSalt\n1/2 cup all purpose flour for dredging\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 tablespoons butter\n2 medium onions, sliced stem to root (about 2 1/2 cups sliced)\n4-6 whole cloves of garlic, peeled\n6 sprigs of fresh thyme, tied together with kitchen string (or 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme)\n1 1/2 cups of Belgian ale, such as Chimay or Ommengang\n1/2 cup of chicken stock\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1 celery root, peeled and diced\n2 teaspoons whole grained mustard\n2 teaspoons brown sugar\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Sprinkle rabbit pieces with salt: Place rabbit pieces on a platter, sprinkle both sides with kosher salt. Let sit for 30 minutes to an hour.\n2 Dredge rabbit with flour, brown in butter: Place flour on plate. Dredge rabbit pieces in flour.\nHeat oil and butter in a large  Dutch oven on medium heat (large enough to fit rabbit pieces in a single layer). Once the butter is melted and foamy, add the rabbit pieces in a single layer to the pot.\nBrown on one side without stirring for 5 to 6 minutes. Then turn the pieces over and brown on the other side. Remove to a plate.\n3 Brown the onions, add garlic and thyme: Add the sliced onions to the pot, and cook, stirring occasionally, until lightly brown, scraping up and browned rabbit bits from the bottom of the pot. Add garlic cloves and thyme, cook until onions are soft and the garlic quite fragrant.\n4 Add ale, then stock, salt, pepper: Increase the heat to high and add the Belgian ale. Let it simmer for a minute or two, then add the stock. Add a half teaspoon of salt and the freshly ground black pepper.\n5 Add celery root, rabbit, then simmer: Place the diced celery root over the onions in a single layer. Place the browned rabbit pieces over the  celery root. Bring to a simmer. Cover and reduce heat to maintain a very low simmer. Cook for 45 minutes, or until the rabbit is just cooked through and tender.\n6 Reduce sauce: Remove rabbit pieces from the pot and keep warm on a platter. Increase the heat to high and reduce the liquid by one third. Then, reduce the heat to low, stir in the mustard and sugar. Taste and add more salt and pepper in needed.\n7 Return meat to sauce in pot: Slice the flap meat pieces of the rabbit into strips and return to the pot. Strip away any available meat from the back and chest parts and return meat to the pot. Add the serving pieces to the pot. Cover and let rewarm for a minute.\n8 Serve: Sprinkle with chopped parsley to serve. Serve with crusty bread, egg noodles, or rice pilaf, along with some Belgian ale.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCelery Root Fennel Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nThe one challenge of making celery root soup is peeling the celery roots, which with their nobby-ness can be difficult. Use a sharp chef's knife to cut off the ends of the root. Then stand the root upright on a cutting board and use downward slices to cut the remaining peel off the the root. Then cut the roots in half, place the halves cut side down on the cutting board, and thinly slice them.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp butter\n2 cups thinly sliced onions (sliced across the grain)\n4 cloves garlic, sliced\n2 medium fennel bulbs, thinly sliced\n2 medium celery roots (about 1 1/2 pounds), peeled and thinly sliced (See TheKitchn's guide to peeling celery root)\n1 medium russet potato, peeled and thinly sliced\n2 bay leaves\n7 cups chicken stock\n2 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt (less or more to taste)\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\n1/4 cup whipping cream\nFennel fronds for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Cook onions: Melt butter in a large (6-8 quart) thick-bottomed pot on medium high heat. Stir in the onions and cook until softened, about 4 to 5 minutes.\n2 Add the garlic and the sliced fennel, lower the heat to medium and cook for 10 to 12 minutes or until softened.\n3 Add the sliced celery root, sliced potato, 2 bay leaves, stock and salt. Increase heat to high, bring to a simmer, reduce heat to low, and maintain a simmer, partially covered for another 10 to 12 minutes, until all of the vegetables are soft enough to pur\xc3\xa9e.\n4 Pur\xc3\xa9e the soup: Either working in batches with a standing blender (do not fill blender bowl more than a third full at a time), or with an immersion blender, pur\xc3\xa9e the soup until smooth. (Note that an immersion blender will take several minutes longer than a standing blender to pur\xc3\xa9e the soup to smoothness.)\n5 Stir in cream and black pepper. Adjust salt to taste. Garnish with fennel fronds.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nCelery Root Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesChill time: 1 hour\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup mayonnaise\n2 Tbsp Dijon mustard\n1 Tbsp fresh lemon juice\n2 Tbsp chopped parsley\n1 lb celery root - quartered, peeled, and coarsely grated just before mixing\n1/2 tart green apple, peeled, cored, julienned\nSalt and freshly ground pepper\nMETHOD\nCombine the mayonnaise, mustard, lemon juice and parsley in a medium-sized bowl. Fold in the celery root and apple and season with salt and pepper. Cover and refrigerate until chilled, at least 1 hour.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nCream Of Celeriac Soup with Brussels Sprouts Chips Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 8 as a starter, 6 as a main course\nEditor's Note: Celeriac, or celery root, is the large, bulbous root of a particular type of celery plant. It has a flavor similar to celery, but more intense and earthy. Look for it near the other root vegetables in the produce section at the grocery store.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the Brussels sprouts chips:\n10 brussels sprouts\n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil\n1/8 teaspoon natural salt, plus more to taste\nFor the soup:\n2 tablespoons grapeseed oil or extra-virgin olive oil\n2 cups diced yellow onion\n2 teaspoons minced garlic (from 2 whole cloves)\n1 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste\n1 medium head cauliflower, cut into florets (See How to Cut and Core Cauliflower)\n3 cups peeled and diced celeriac (from 1 large root)\n8 cups vegetable broth, plus more as needed\n1/4 cup blanched slivered almonds\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, plus more to taste\nSpecial equipment:\nBlender\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the Brussels sprouts chips: Heat the oven to 350F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone liner.\nSlice the bottom tip of each sprout, and peel off the outer leaves. Trim off a bit more of the bottom, and peel off the next layer of leaves. Continue this process until you've removed all of the leaves.\nToss the leaves with the olive oil and salt, and spread them out in a single layer on the baking sheet. Roast for about 10 minutes, until the leaves are browned and crisp.\nSet aside until needed.\n2 While the Brussels sprouts are roasting, start the soup: In a large saucepan, warm the oil over medium heat and saute\xcc\x81 the onion, garlic, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt for about 5 minutes, until the onions are soft and translucent. Add the cauliflower and celeriac, and saute\xcc\x81 for another minute.\n3 Add the broth and simmer: Add the vegetable broth and 1/2 teaspoon of the salt, increase the heat to high, and bring just to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium-high and simmer for 20 to 30 minutes, until the cauliflower and celeriac are just tender.\n4 Remove the saucepan from the heat and stir in the almonds: Allow the soup to cool slightly for 10 minutes. (This gives the nuts time to soften.)\n5 Puree the soup: Pour the soup into your blender in batches and puree on high for 30 to 60 seconds, until smooth and creamy. Return the soup to the saucepan and warm it over low heat. Stir in the remaining 1\xe2\x81\x844 teaspoon the salt, and add the pepper. Season with additional salt and pepper, to taste.\n6 To serve: Ladle portions of the soup into bowls, and top with the Brussels sprouts chips.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nWinter Root Vegetable Slaw Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 4-6 as a side dish\nThe choice of root vegetables here works well, but you are free to mix and match. Just be sure to not have too many sweet vegetables like carrots and parsnips, or too many sharp ones, like radishes or turnips.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 teaspoon Dijon mustard\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon sugar\n1/4 cup sherry or red wine vinegar\n1 cup chopped parsley, loosely packed\n2/3 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2 large carrots (choose different colored carrots if you can find them)\n2 medium parsnips\n1 small celery root\n2 black radishes or 1/2 daikon radish\nMETHOD\n1 Make the vinaigrette: Put the mustard, salt, sugar, vinegar and parsley in a blender and process until combined, about 30 seconds. Scrape down the sides of the blender, cover and process at its slowest setting.\nDrizzle in the olive oil slowly. When it is all in, move the blender to its highest setting and puree for about 90 seconds.\n2 Shred the root vegetables: Peel all the vegetables except for the radishes, if you are using black ones. The slivers of black in the salad look cool, so I leave them in.\nUsing a vegetable peeler or a coarse grater, slice shreds off the vegetables into a bowl. Try to keep the shreds roughly the same length if you can.\n3 Toss shredded vegetables with vinaigrette: To finish, toss some of the vinaigrette with the shredded vegetables and let stand in the fridge for at least 20 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBraised Lamb Shanks with Celery Root and Rosemary Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 20 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 lamb shanks (3 to 3 1/2 pounds total), trimmed of excess fat\nSalt\n1 medium onion, chopped (about 1 1/2 cups)\n8 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed\n2 sprigs rosemary\n2 sprigs fresh thyme\n2 bay leaves\n1 cup chicken stock\n2 large celery roots (about 3 pounds total)\n1/2 head of green cabbage\n1 tablespoon balsamic vinegar\nFreshly ground black pepper\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Salt the lamb shanks: Sprinkle shanks with salt and let sit while you prep the ingredients.\n2 Brown the shanks: Heat oil in a large (6 quart), thick-bottomed pot on medium high heat. Pat shanks dry with paper towels, add them to the pot and sear to brown on all sides.\nWhen sufficiently browned, remove shanks to a bowl, set aside.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and garlic: Add chopped onions to the pot and cook until translucent and beginning to color, about 5 minutes. Add garlic cloves and cook a minute more.\n4 Add rosemary, thyme, bay, shanks, stock, then simmer: Place sprigs of rosemary, thyme, the bay leaves on top of the onions.\nPlace the seared lamb shanks on top. Sprinkle with a teaspoon of salt. Add the chicken stock. Bring the stock to a simmer, lower the heat to the lowest setting to maintain a simmer, and cover. Let simmer for 1 hour.\n5 Prep celery root and cabbage: While the shanks are cooking prepare the celery root and cabbage. Cut off the knobby end of the celery root. Place the celery root cut side down on cutting board to stabilize it. Use a strong knife to cut away the outside peel. Once peeled, cut the celery root into 1 1/2-inch cubes.\nCore the cabbage and slice the cabbage into 1 1/2-inch thick slices.\n5 Add celery root and cabbage to pot: After an hour, remove the shanks from the pot. Add the sliced cabbage and chunks of celery root. Sprinkle with balsamic vinegar.\nReturn the shanks to the pot, nestling them in the celery root and cabbage.\n6 Simmer until celery root is cooked and shanks are tender: Increase heat to return the pot to a simmer, lower the heat to maintain a simmer, cover and cook for another 45 minutes to an hour, until the celery root is cooked through and the shanks are tender.\n7 Cut meat away from bones, chop, return meat to pot: Remove the shanks from the pot. Cut the meat away from the bones. Roughly chop the meat and return to the pot.\nAdd salt and pepper to taste. Sprinkle with parsley to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nCeviche with Avocado and Grilled Corn Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 15 minutesMarinating time: 30 minutesYield: 6 to 8 as an appetizer\nAlthough "cooking" fish in this way changes its texture and flavor, it\'s still essentially raw from a food safety standpoint. Therefore, it is extremely important to find a fishmonger you trust and who will sell you high quality fresh fish.\nServe ceviche with thick-cut tortilla chips, as you would salsa, or eat it on its own as a salad.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 whole ears corn\n4 to 6 limes, juiced (3/4 to 1 cup of juice)\n1/4 red onion, very thinly sliced\n1 pound firm white fish, cut into 1/2-inch pieces (I used halibut)\n2 medium ripe avocados, diced\n1 cup loosely packed cilantro leaves, chopped\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nThick-cut tortilla chips, to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the corn: Fill a large pot with about an inch of water. Place a steamer basket in bottom of pot and layer corn on top. Cover tightly and cook on high for 10 minutes.\nWhen cool enough to handle, shuck the corn.\nIf desired, brush the corn with oil and cook on a hot grill (or under a broiler set to high) for a couple of minutes on each side until the corn starts to caramelize and get crunchy in spots.\nAllow to cool (you can carry on with making the ceviche). When it\xe2\x80\x99s cool enough to handle, slice the corn off the cob. The corn can be prepared up to a day in advance.\n2 Make and marinate the ceviche: In a large bowl, mix together the lime juice, red onion, and salt. Add the fish and stir so the fish is evenly coated with lime juice.\nCover and refrigerate for 15 to 30 minutes, until the fish is firm and opaque. Stir occasionally as you think about it. Start tasting the fish after 15 minutes, and continue until it is as firm as you like it.\nOnce it has reached your preferred firmness, it\'s best to serve the ceviche right away. (Ceviche left for too long will eventually become mushy and unappealing.)\n3 Serve: When ready to serve, mix in the diced avocado, corn kernels, and chopped cilantro. No need to strain, before serving, though if it seems like there\'s a lot of liquid, serve with a slotted spoon.\nServe immediately with thick cut tortilla chips.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nCreamy Chai-Spiced Vegan Rice Pudding Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 50 minutesChill time: 3 hoursYield: 6 servings\nFor an extra-tight seal while steaming the rice, cover the pot with tin foil and then place the lid.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the rice:\n1 1/2 cups water\n1 (3-inch) cinnamon stick\n1 whole star anise\n1 cup jasmine rice\nFor the pudding:\n1 1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon, plus more to garnish\n1 teaspoon ground ginger\n3/4 teaspoon ground cardamom\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\nPinch ground black pepper\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n3 (13 1/2-ounce) cans full fat unsweetened coconut milk, divided\n1 cup packed brown sugar\nToasted coconut flakes, to garnish, optional\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the rice: In a 4-quart pot, combine the water, cinnamon stick, and star anise, and bring the water to a boil over medium-high heat. Add the rice and reduce the heat to low. Cover the pot and steam it until it is no longer crunchy, about 15 minutes.\n2 Make the spice blend: In a small bowl, combine the spices. Add the vanilla extract and 1/4 cup of the coconut milk to the spices, and whisk to create a smooth paste. This prevents the spices from clumping together when you add them to the steamed rice.\n3 Combine the rice and coconut milk: Once the rice has finished cooking, add 4 cups of the coconut milk and the spice paste to the pot. Scrape the bottom of the pot to loosen any rice that may be stuck.\n4 Simmer the rice pudding: Bring the mixture to a gentle simmer over low heat, uncovered, and cook without stirring for 15 minutes. The surface of the rice pudding should develop small bubbles; if large, rapidly moving bubbles break the surface of the milk, lower the temperature. Don\xe2\x80\x99t stir it because you don\xe2\x80\x99t want the rice to break up. A skin will form on the surface, but that's fine!\nAfter 15 minutes, add the brown sugar and stir the pudding (also stir any any skin that's formed). When you scrape the bottom of the pot, it will sound like rustling paper. Simmer for another 20 minutes, stirring frequently, or until the pudding has thickened to the consistency of mayonnaise.\n5 Transfer to a shallow dish and chill: Remove the cinnamon stick and star anise from the pudding and discard. Transfer the pudding to a shallow dish (like a pie plate or casserole dish) and refrigerate uncovered until cold, at least 3 hours, up to overnight.\n6 Finish with coconut milk and cinnamon: Just prior to serving, stir in the remaining coconut milk. Spoon the pudding into individual serving dishes and garnish with a sprinkle of ground cinnamon and toasted coconut flakes.\nStore any leftovers in a covered container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nBoozy Chai-Spiced Apple Cider Punch Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: 7 cups or approximately 10 servings, enough to fill an average-sized pitcher\nThis punch is on the tart side. To make it sweeter, start with two tablespoons honey or simple syrup and add more until you reach your desired sweetness.\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re trying to fill a large punch bowl or countertop drink dispenser, I recommend doubling or even tripling the recipe.\nThe punch can be made a day or so ahead of time and kept it in the fridge until needed. Hold off on garnishing until you're ready to serve since the apples can get a bit dodgy.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 bags chai tea or 3 teaspoons loose chai (I like Republic of Tea)\n1 1/2 cups water\n2 cups brandy\n1 1/2 cups apple cider\n3/4 cups fresh squeezed lemon juice\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\nHoney or simple syrup, as needed\nLemon wheels or clove-studded apple slices, for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Make the tea: Add 2 tea bags or 3 teaspoons loose chai tea to 1 1/2 cups of water. Steep for 5 minutes. Let cool to room temperature.\n2 Combine all ingredients: Add the cooled brewed tea, brandy, apple cider, lemon juice, and vanilla extract to a pitcher. Add several handfuls of ice cubes or one large ice mold. Stir, and then garnish with lemon wheels and apple slices studded with cloves.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nChampagne Chocolate Truffles Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesChill time: at least 8 hoursYield: 24 truffles\nChampagne from a freshly-opened bottle or flat, day-old champagne will both work well for this recipe.\nYou can also substitute dark beer, like porter or stout, in place of the beer. If you\'d like to swap out the champagne for liquor, use half the amount called for.\nEdible gold leaf isn\xe2\x80\x99t tough to work with and I buy mine from Amazon. I like the loose sheets sold by Barnabas Blattgold the best.\nINGREDIENTS\n20 ounces chopped dark chocolate or quality dark chocolate chips\n8 ounces (1 cup) heavy cream\nPinch of salt\n1/3 cup champagne or sparkling wine (sparkling or flat, either is fine)\n3 to 4 tablespoons cocoa powder, sifted\nEdible gold leaf, optional\nSpecial equipment:\n8-inch loaf pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the pan: Lightly butter an 8-inch loaf pan and line with a sling of parchment paper, leaving a few inches of overhang on two sides. The butter will help the parchment paper stick to the pan without slipping.\n2 Make the chocolate: Combine the chocolate, cream, and a pinch of salt in a heatproof bowl and set it over a pan of simmering water. Make sure the water does not touch the bottom of the bowl. Stir the mixture over the heat until just melted and smooth.\nRemove from the heat and whisk in the champagne.\n3 Chill the chocolate block: Scrape the chocolate into the prepared loaf pan with a spatula and smooth the surface. Chill in the refrigerator for at least 8 hours or up to 24 hours, until set firmly (there will still be some slight give, which is good).\n4 Slice the truffles: Warm a knife in hot water, dry it off, and then run it around the rim of the pan to loosen the chocolate block. Lift out the block using the parchment sling.\nTrim the ends of the truffle to square them off if you want. (And save the trimmings for yourself!) Cut the block in half through the middle to make two squares. Cut each square into thirds and then cut into fourth to make cubes. As needed to prevent sticking, wipe down your knife, dip it again in warm water, and wipe dry.\n5 Coat the truffles with cocoa. Place the sifted cocoa powder in a bowl. Carefully toss each cube cocoa powder. If you want to apply gold leaf, make sure to leave one of the sides clear so the leaf has something to stick to.\n6 Apply the gold leaf (optional): Avoid touching the gold leaf with your fingers at it will stick to whatever it touches. Use a very dry, very clean paint brush to apply it to the truffles. Lightly brush or dab the surface of the gold leaf with your paint brush to "grab" some of the gold leaf, and then dab it on the surface of the truffle. The leaf should adhere to the truffle and slip off of the brush.\nRepeat until all the truffles have a little gold leaf on top.\n7 Serving and storing: If serving the same day, arrange the truffles on a plate and store in the fridge until serving. Take them out of the fridge a little bit before serving to take the chill off. Truffles can also be stored in an airtight container for up to 3 days.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nChampagne Sorbet Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesChilling and churning time: 3 hoursYield: Makes about 1 quart\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups sparkling wine or champagne\n1 cup white granulated sugar\n1 Tbsp light corn syrup\n1 teaspoon of lemon and or grapefruit zest\n1 1/2 cups fresh grapefruit juice\n1/4 cup fresh squeezed lemon juice (Meyer if you have access to them)\nMETHOD\n1 Boil champagne, sugar, corn syrup, zest: Put champagne, sugar, corn syrup, and zest into a saucepan. Bring to a vigorous boil so that the sugar completely dissolves, remove from heat.\n2 Strain: Strain into a stainless steel bowl (will help cool down faster), add the grapefruit juice and lemon juice.\n3 Chill: Chill completely. To do this, either place bowl in a larger bowl half-filled with ice water, and stir until champagne solution is completely cold, refreshing the ice in the outer bowl if necessary.\nOr you can cover with plastic wrap and chill in your refrigerator overnight.\nI put the bowl in the ice compartment of our freezer for a couple hours, because it fits, chills quickly, and is far enough away from the other food in the freezer.\n4 Process in ice cream maker: Process the mixture in your ice cream maker (Amazon sells a good one) according to the ice cream maker directions.\n5 Freeze until firm: Transfer mixture to a storage container and freezer in your freezer until firm, at least 6 hours.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nChampagne Mushroom Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Makes about 2 cups\nEven though this recipe is called "Champagne" sauce, you can use any dry sparkling wine. If using alcohol is not an option, you can try using sparkling cider, just remember the sauce will taste sweeter then.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 ounce dried porcini mushrooms (other dried mushrooms will work if dried porcini are not available)\n1 cup chicken or vegetable stock\n2 cups Champagne or other sparkling wine\n1/3 cup shallots, minced\nUnsalted butter, 1/4 cup to add to the sparkling wine, 3 Tbsp for the roux\n3 Tbsp all-purpose flour\nSalt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Rehydrate dried mushrooms: Add the stock and dried mushrooms into a medium sized pot. Cover and bring to a boil, then reduce heat to its lowest setting.\n2 Reduce champagne with shallots, whisk in butter: In separate medium sized pot, add the sparkling wine and shallots. Bring to a rolling boil, and boil until the wine has reduced to 3/4 of a cup.\nTurn off the heat and wait until the wine stops simmering, then whisk in 1/4 cup of butter, a little at a time.\n3 Make roux with butter and flour: Heat 3 Tbsp butter in a saucepan over medium-high heat. When the butter stops foaming, add the flour and stir well to combine. Stirring often, cook this roux for 5 minutes, or until it turns the color of coffee-with-cream.\n4 Slowly add hot stock to roux: Working with two hands, slowly add the hot stock (along with the mushrooms) to the roux. It will sputter and spit at first, but keep pouring in the stock and stirring. It will turn into a silky sauce.\n5 Whisk in butter shallot champagne mixture, pour through sieve: To finish, turn the heat off and whisk in the butter-shallot-sparkling wine mixture.\nPour the mixture through a fine mesh sieve into a bowl, to strain out the mushroom and shallots. Add salt to taste and keep warm until you need it.\nDo not let it boil or the sauce may separate.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'

Throw in a few cubes of ice and shake until the shaker forms a frost. Strain into a Champagne flute or coupe.\n2 Add Champagne: Top with Champagne and enjoy!\nHello! b'Save It Print\nWatermelon Ros\xc3\xa9 Mimosa Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesYield: 4 cocktails\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the watermelon juice:\n10 ounces watermelon cubes\nFor the watermelon mimosa:\n16 ounces sparkling ros\xc3\xa9\n8 ounces watermelon juice\n2 ounces Meyer lemon juice, freshly squeezed or Limoncello, optional\nTo garnish:\nWatermelon wedges for garnish\nMETHOD\n1 Make the watermelon juice: Into a blender or food processor, add the watermelon cubes. b'Print\nTurkey Mushroom Risotto Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Serves 4\nYou must use risotto rice for this recipe or it will not work. These rices\xe2\x80\x94Arborio, Carnaroli or Vialone Nano\xe2\x80\x94contain special starches that slough off when you stir the rice, creating a creamy sauce without any added cream. You can use chicken stock instead of turkey stock, but note that the turkey stock is what gives this risotto its turkey flavor.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp butter\n1 large shallot, chopped\n1/3 pound chanterelles or other fresh mushrooms, chopped\n2 garlic cloves, chopped\n1 Tbsp fresh sage, chopped\n1 1/2 cups Arborio, Carnaroli, Vialone Nano, or other risotto rice\nSalt\n3 cups turkey stock\n2 ounces Chevre or other fresh goat cheese\nBlack pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Simmer turkey stock and water: Bring the turkey stock, plus an additional 2 cups of water, to a simmer.\n2 Cook shallots and mushrooms: Heat the butter in a medium-sized pot over medium-high heat for 1-2 minutes, until it begins to brown. Add the shallots and mushrooms and toss to combine. Salt them well and saut\xc3\xa9 until the shallots are translucent, about 3 minutes.\n3 Add the garlic, sage and rice and stir well. Saut\xc3\xa9 for another 1-2 minutes, stirring often.\n4 Start adding stock: Add 1 cup of the simmering stock. Stirring constantly, let the stock evaporate before adding another 1/2 cup. Repeat, stirring almost constantly, until the rice is al dente, cooked through but still a little firm. This will take about 20-30 minutes.\n5 When the rice is al dente, add the goat cheese and stir well to combine. Add the black pepper and stir again. Serve at once.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nSaut\xc3\xa9ed Swiss Chard with Shiitake Mushrooms Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4.\nI have tried cooking the tougher ribs (chopped) separately in a little butter and adding them back to the greens. Not a big fan of this approach. Better to save the ribs for another recipe, use them for making vegetable stock, or compost them.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp unsalted butter\n6 ounces of shiitake mushrooms, sliced 1/4-inch thick\n1/4 teaspoon Kosher salt\n2 large bunches of Swiss chard (about 1 1/2 pounds total), rinsed, patted dry, large ribs removed, leaves roughly chopped\nSprinkling of grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 mushrooms in butter: In a large stick-free saut\xc3\xa9 pan melt the butter on medium-high heat. Stir in the sliced mushrooms. Sprinkle with salt (skip added salt if using salted butter).\n2 Add chopped chard: Once the mushrooms are beginning to brown and have given off some water, add the chopped chard leaves to the pan and toss with the mushrooms. (You may have to stagger in the adding of the chard leaves, as not to overwhelm the pan.)\nOnce the chard leaves have wilted, remove from heat and cover the pan. Let the chard leaves steam in their residual heat for a couple minutes.\n3 Sprinkle with Parmesan: Place chard and mushrooms in a serving dish. Sprinkle generously with grated Parmesan cheese.\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nChayote with Tomato and Green Chile Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound chayotes\n6 ounces of roasted tomatoes (can use canned fire roasted tomatoes, or roast whole tomatoes on stovetop or under broiler until skin begins to blacken, do not remove skin but process whole)\n1 clove garlic, chopped\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 tablespoons chopped onion\n1 large green Anaheim chile (stem and seeds removed and discarded), chopped\nPinch red chile pepper flakes\n1/4 cup water\nSalt to taste\n1/4 cup roughly chopped cilantro\n1/4 cup finely grated Monterey Jack cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Peel and cut the chayotes: The peel is tough and inedible when cooked, so peel the chayotes completely. (This may take a little doing, as the folds in the chayotes can make it difficult.) Cut the chayotes into 1/4-inch wide, 2 inch long julienned strips, including the core.\n2 Pur\xc3\xa9e the roasted tomatoes and the garlic in a blender, set aside.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions and green chiles, add tomato and chili flakes: Heat oil in a large skillet on medium heat. Add the chopped onion and green chiles. Cook on medium heat until just soft, about 3-4 minutes.\nAdd the tomato mixture, red chile flakes, and continue to cook 3 minutes more.\n5 Add chayote, water, salt: Add the chayote, water, and salt to taste. Cover and cook, stirring occasionally for 15 minutes.\nAdd the chopped cilantro and cook for 5 minutes more. The chayote should be just tender, moist but not watery.\n5 Serve: Sprinkle with grated cheese to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. b'Save It Print\nCheesy Potato Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup butter, plus more for the casserole dish\n1 yellow onion, diced\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour\n3 cups vegetable or chicken stock\n2 cups grated cheddar cheese\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n30 ounces frozen hash browns\nDAD ADD: Fried Serrano Rings:\n3 serranos, sliced\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nCoarse salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven and prepare the casserole dish: Preheat oven to 400\xcb\x9aF. Lightly butter or grease a 9x13 baking dish.\n2 Make the cheese sauce: In a medium pot, melt 1/4 cup butter over medium heat. Add diced onion and cook for 3-4 minutes until onions turn translucent but not browned. Then add minced garlic and cook for 30 seconds.\nStir in flour and continue to cook for a minute or two until the flour turns a tan color. Slowly whisk in stock and bring sauce to a slight simmer. The sauce will thicken as it heats. Once the sauce is thick like gravy, stir in the cheddar cheese and season with salt and pepper. Remove from heat.\n3 Combine the potatoes and the sauce: In a large bowl add the frozen hash browns and pour the sauce over the hash browns. Stir together well to combine and transfer to the prepared baking dish. Smooth the top.\n4 Bake the casserole: Place the casserole in the center rack of your oven and bake for 45 minutes at 400\xcb\x9aF. Then turn on the broiler and broil for 5 minutes on high to crisp up the top of the casserole. If your casserole dish is not broiler-safe, then turn the oven up to 500\xcb\x9aF and bake for 3 more minutes.\n5 Serve: Let the casserole cool slightly but serve while warm.\n6 Make the Crispy Serrano Rings (Optional DAD ADD): Slice serrano peppers into thin coins. Heat a few tablespoons of olive oil over medium heat in a small skillet. Once it is hot, add serrano coins and cook for 2-3 minutes until they start to brown. Remove the coins from the skillet and let drain on a paper towel. Season with a pinch of salt.\nLEFTOVERS!\nLeftovers keep in the fridge for 5 days. Reheat in the microwave until warmed through.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBroccoli Cheddar Bites Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes 24 broccoli bites\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large bunch of broccoli florets\n2 eggs, lightly beaten\n1/2 cup, packed, torn fresh bread (no crust)\n1/4 cup grated onion\n1/4 cup mayonnaise\n1 cup (4 ounces, 114 g), packed, grated sharp cheddar cheese\n1 1/2 teaspoons lemon zest\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Steam and chop the broccoli: Place 1 inch of water in a pot with a steamer basket. Bring to a boil. Add the broccoli florets. Steam the broccoli florets for 5 minutes, until just tender. Rinse with cold water to stop the cooking.\nFinely chop the steamed broccoli florets. You should have 2 to 2 1/2 cups.\n  2 Make filling: Place the beaten eggs and the torn bread in a large bowl. Mix until the bread is completely moistened.\nAdd the grated onion, mayonnaise, cheese, lemon zest, salt and pepper. Stir in the minced broccoli.\n3 Distribute broccoli mixture in mini muffin pan wells:  Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Coat the wells of 2 mini muffin pans (1 dozen wells each) with olive oil (so the bites don't stick). Distribute the broccoli mixture in the muffin wells.\n4 Bake: Bake at 350\xc2\xb0F for 25 minutes until cooked through and lightly browned on top.\nIf you don't have mini muffin pans, you can cook the bites freeform. Just grease a baking sheet and spoon large dollops of the mixture onto the pan. Baking time is the same.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected.
