b"Save It Print\nBroccoli Cheddar Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large head or two small heads broccoli (a little more than 1 pound), chopped into florets and stems\n1/4 cup unsalted butter\n1/2 white onion, chopped\n1 small carrot, peeled and grated\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour\n1 quart vegetable stock\n2 cups whole milk\n8 ounces cheddar cheese, grated\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon fresh black pepper\nBread, for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch the broccoli: Bring a large pot of water to a boil and add a few big pinches of salt. Add broccoli stalks and blanch for 2 to 3 minutes until they are bright green and fork tender, but still slightly crispy.\nDrain broccoli. Scoop out and set aside about 1 cup of the florets for the topping.\n2 Cook the onions and carrots: Wipe out the pot, place over medium heat, and melt the butter. Once melted, add the onions and carrots, and cook until veggies soften, 4 to 5 minutes, stirring regularly.\n3 Cook the soup: Stir in the all-purpose flour. The flour will form a paste with the veggies. Cook for a minute or two to coat the vegetables, and then start to slowly pour in vegetable stock. Stir constantly as you pour in the stock to avoid lumps.\nOnce all the stock is added, bring soup up to a low simmer. Add milk and the blanched broccoli (except what you're saving for the topping). Simmer for about 10 minutes over low heat.\n4 Puree the soup: Blend with an immersion blender, or let the soup cool until no longer steaming and blend in batches in a blender. (If using a blender, be careful to let the soup cool a bit and do not overfill the blender to avoid splattered hot soup!)\n5 Season to taste and serve: Add the grated cheese, salt, and pepper to the pureed soup and stir over low heat until the cheese has melted. Taste soup and season with additional salt and pepper to your liking.\nLadle the soup into bowls and garnish with some reserved broccoli and extra cheese on top. Serve with bread.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nCheesy Zucchini Bites Recipe\nPrep time: 35 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Makes 24 mini muffin zucchini bites\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds of zucchini, grated (large holes of a box grater)\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 cup mayonnaise\n3 eggs\n3/4 cup diced fresh bread (without crust)\n1/2 cup minced green onions (including green parts)\n2 cloves garlic, minced, about 2 teaspoons\n1 1/2 teaspoons grated lemon zest\n1/4 teaspoon minced fresh rosemary\n1/2 cup grated cheddar cheese\n1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\n2 teaspoons of olive oil to coat mini muffin tins\nSpecial equipment:\n2 12-well mini-muffin tins\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Salt and drain the zucchini: Toss the grated zucchini with 1/2 teaspoon of salt and place in a colander to drain (in a sink or over a bowl). Let drain for 30 minutes to an hour.\nAfter at least 30 minutes, use your (clean) hands to press and squeeze the grated zucchini against the colander to release more moisture.\nThen use double layered sturdy paper towels or a clean tea towel to wrap up the zucchini and squeeze out even more moisture.\n2 Whisk together the mayo and eggs, then whisk in the bread, green onions, garlic, zest, rosemary, cheeses, pepper: While the zucchini is draining in step 1, whisk together in a large bowl the mayonnaise and eggs until smooth.\nThen add the bread, green onions, garlic, lemon zest, rosemary, grated cheddar, Parmesan, and black pepper. Let that sit while the zucchini is draining so that the bread breaks down in the mixture.\n3 Prepare pans, preheat oven: Grease the wells of 2 mini-muffin tins with olive oil. Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Stir zucchini into batter, spoon into mini-muffin tins: Stir the drained, squeezed zucchini into the egg mixture until evenly distributed. Spoon the mixture into the wells of the mini-muffin tins, about a heaping tablespoon each.\n5 Bake for 25 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F.\n6 Cool and release zucchini bites from pan: Let cool for 5 minutes, then run a knife around the edges of the zucchini bites to loosen them from the pan. Remove from the pan to a rack to cool further.\nEat warm or cool to room temp, then chill or freeze to reheat later.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nLoaded Baked Potatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n6-8 strips bacon\n6 medium-large russet potatoes, scrubbed well\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 pound fresh broccoli, cut into florets (or use frozen)\n8 ounces grated sharp cheddar cheese\nTo serve:\nSour cream\nFresh chives\nDad Add: Quick Home Fries (serves 2):\n1 baked potato, diced\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon seasoned salt\nEggs, for serving\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the bacon: Line a baking sheet with foil, then top with a wire baking rack (cookie cooling rack). Lay the bacon strips on the wire rack perpendicular to the wires, making sure the bacon pieces don\xe2\x80\x99t overlap.\n2 Bake the bacon and scrub the potatoes: Place the bacon in a cold oven and set the temperature to 375\xc2\xb0F. Bake for 15-20 minutes. Check the bacon around the 18-minute mark. Some types of bacon cook faster than others. (See How to Make Bacon in the Oven for full details.)\nWhile the bacon bakes, scrub potatoes well and then stab each potato about 10 times with a fork to prevent the possibility of a potato exploding in the oven. (It can happen!)\nRemove the bacon from the oven; transfer to a paper towel-lined plate.\n3 Bake the potatoes: Increase the heat to 400\xcb\x9aF. Place potatoes on a baking sheet, drizzle well with olive oil, and sprinkle with coarse salt. Bake potatoes for about an hour until the skins are shriveled slightly and the potatoes are very tender. (See How to Bake a Potato for more details.)\n4 Blanch the broccoli: While the potatoes bake, cook your broccoli. Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add a big pinch of salt to the water to season it. Add broccoli to the water and boil for 3 minutes until the broccoli is just tender, but not mushy at all.\nDrain broccoli once it is tender and set aside for assembly. We will warm everything up once the potatoes are assembled at the end.\n5 Open the potatoes: Once your potatoes are baked, let them cool slightly so you can handle them. Cut each potato down the center, being careful not to cut all the way through. Then cut two perpendicular cuts near the end of each potato; this will allow you to open each potato up easier. I like to use a small paring knife to slice up the interior of the potato, making it easier to unfold and stuff.\n5 Stuff the potatoes: Sprinkle some cheese over the potato. I like a lot of cheese, but feel free to use as much or as little as you\xe2\x80\x99d like. Top with about 1/2 cup of cooked broccoli and 1 piece of crumbled bacon. Sprinkle the broccoli with more cheese and more broccoli or bacon depending on the size of the potato and the size of your appetite!\n6 Reheat the potatoes: Place the stuffed potato back in the oven for 5-10 minutes to really melt the cheese and warm the fillings.\n7 Serve: Top the warm potatoes with sour cream and chives and serve.\nLeftovers: Store any extra potatoes before filling them. Leftover potatoes can be used within a week for baked potatoes, loaded potatoes, or quick Dad Add home fries!\n8 How to Make Dad Add Home Fries: Cut a leftover potato into about 1/4-inch cubes. Into a medium skillet set over medium heat, add the olive oil. When the oil starts to shimmer, add the potato cubes and seasoned salt. Cook for 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes are crispy and browned on the edges. Remove from skillet and serve with eggs.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nMozzarella and Basil Stuffed Tomatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 8 stuffed tomato cups, 4 servings\nIf preparing gluten-free, use gluten-free bread or bread crumbs.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 medium tomatoes with firm, fleshy walls, 2 1/2 inches wide\n1 cup shredded mozzarella cheese\n1/3 cup grated parmesan cheese, divided\n1/4 cup packed fresh basil, chopped, plus more for garnish\n1 slice of bread (enough to make 1/4 cup breadcrumbs)\n1 tablespoon melted salted butter\n1 teaspoon minced garlic\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon pepper\nOlive oil for drizzling\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the soft breadcrumbs: To make the 1/4 cup soft breadcrumbs, remove the crust from 1 slice of bread (preferably stale) and either pulse in a small food processor or shred with a fork until the bread resembles fine, sand-like crumbs.\n3 Prepare the tomatoes: Slice the tomatoes in half horizontally around the equator and use a spoon to scoop out the flesh. Be careful not to puncture the walls of the tomato, but if you do, the filling will plug the hole. Place empty tomato halves in a casserole dish and season with salt and pepper.\nUsing your hands or a spoon, separate the seeds from the scooped out tomato flesh and transfer the flesh to a cutting board. Discard the seeds and the tomato water. Chop the flesh and set aside for the stuffing.\n4 Make the stuffing: In a medium bowl, add the mozzarella cheese, 1/4 cup of the parmesan cheese, basil, breadcrumbs, butter, garlic, salt, and pepper and stir to thoroughly combine.\n5 Bake: Using two spoons, fill the tomato halves with the stuffing. Sprinkle filled tomatoes with the remaining parmesan cheese and drizzle with olive oil. Bake for 15 minutes, or until tomatoes are tender, then broil on high for 1 minute until the filling begins to bubble and brown.\n6 Serve: Garnish with a few torn basil leaves and serve hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nZucchini Breakfast Casserole Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: Makes 6-8 portions\nINGREDIENTS\n6-8 eggs\n1 cup ricotta cheese (about 245 g)\n1 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese (130 g)\n1/4 teaspoon Tabasco sauce or other hot chili sauce\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n3 cups grated zucchini (from 2-3 fresh zucchinis, about 390 g)\n1 1/2 cups chopped plum tomatoes (from 4-5 fresh tomatoes, about 370 g),\n1/2 cup sliced fresh basil (from about 20 leaves)*\n4 cups cubed day-old bread (from about 4 slices, rustic French or Italian bread works best)\nExtra virgin olive oil\n*Chiffonade basil by stacking a few leaves on top of each other, roll them up like a cigar, slice thin, starting at one end of the cigar and working your way down.\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the egg cheese base: In a large bowl beat the eggs. Add the ricotta and beat until smooth. Mix in the grated Parmesan cheese, Tabasco, salt and pepper.\n2 Prep the vegetables and bread, add to egg mixture: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). Prepare the vegetables and bread. Once you chop the tomatoes, squeeze excess moisture out of them by pressing them in a sieve, or wrapping in paper towels and squeezing. Add the tomatoes, basil, and zucchini to the egg mixture.\nMoisten the bread cubes with a little water then squeeze out any excess moisture using paper towels. Mix the bread cubes into the egg mixture.\n3 Bake: Coat the bottom and sides of a 9x13 baking dish generously with olive oil. Pour the egg vegetable mixture into the baking pan and even it out in the pan. Place in the middle rack of the oven.\nBake for 30 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C). The casserole should puff up and brown lightly. If it hasn't browned enough after 30 minutes at that temp, increase the heat to 425\xc2\xb0F (220\xc2\xb0C) and cook for 5-10 minutes further.\nRemove from oven and let cool on a rack for 10 minutes before cutting into squares to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nMozzarella and Basil Stuffed Tomatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Makes 8 stuffed tomato cups, 4 servings\nIf preparing gluten-free, use gluten-free bread or bread crumbs.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 medium tomatoes with firm, fleshy walls, 2 1/2 inches wide\n1 cup shredded mozzarella cheese\n1/3 cup grated parmesan cheese, divided\n1/4 cup packed fresh basil, chopped, plus more for garnish\n1 slice of bread (enough to make 1/4 cup breadcrumbs)\n1 tablespoon melted salted butter\n1 teaspoon minced garlic\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/8 teaspoon pepper\nOlive oil for drizzling\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 400\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the soft breadcrumbs: To make the 1/4 cup soft breadcrumbs, remove the crust from 1 slice of bread (preferably stale) and either pulse in a small food processor or shred with a fork until the bread resembles fine, sand-like crumbs.\n3 Prepare the tomatoes: Slice the tomatoes in half horizontally around the equator and use a spoon to scoop out the flesh. Be careful not to puncture the walls of the tomato, but if you do, the filling will plug the hole. Place empty tomato halves in a casserole dish and season with salt and pepper.\nUsing your hands or a spoon, separate the seeds from the scooped out tomato flesh and transfer the flesh to a cutting board. Discard the seeds and the tomato water. Chop the flesh and set aside for the stuffing.\n4 Make the stuffing: In a medium bowl, add the mozzarella cheese, 1/4 cup of the parmesan cheese, basil, breadcrumbs, butter, garlic, salt, and pepper and stir to thoroughly combine.\n5 Bake: Using two spoons, fill the tomato halves with the stuffing. Sprinkle filled tomatoes with the remaining parmesan cheese and drizzle with olive oil. Bake for 15 minutes, or until tomatoes are tender, then broil on high for 1 minute until the filling begins to bubble and brown.\n6 Serve: Garnish with a few torn basil leaves and serve hot.\nHello! b"Save It Print\nPerfect Cheesecake Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 2 hours, 40 minutesChilling time: 4 hours or overnightYield: Makes 16 servings\nRecipe adapted from Dorie Greenspan's Baking: From My Home to Yours. Published with permission from author.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n1 3/4 cups (230g) of Graham cracker crumbs (from about 15 Graham crackers)\n2 Tbsp sugar\nPinch salt\n4 Tbsp plus 1 teaspoon (60g) unsalted butter (if using salted butter, omit the pinch of salt), melted\nFor the filling:\n2 pounds cream cheese (900g), room temperature\n1 1/3 cup granulated sugar (270g)\nPinch of salt\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n4 large eggs\n2/3 cup sour cream (160 ml)\n2/3 cup heavy whipping cream (160 ml)\nFor the sour cream topping:\n2 cups sour cream (475 ml)\n1/3 cup powdered sugar (35g)\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nFor the raspberry sauce:\n12 ounces (340g) fresh raspberries\n1/2 cup granulated sugar (100g)\n1/2 cup water (120 ml)\nSpecial equipment:\n9-inch, 2 3/4-inch high springform pan\nHeavy-duty, 18-inch wide aluminum foil\nA large, high-sided roasting pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nPREPARE THE CRUST\n1 Process graham crackers, mix with sugar, salt, butter: Pulse the graham crackers in a food processor or blender until finely ground. Put in a large bowl, and stir in the sugar and salt. Stir in the melted butter.\nPreheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C), with rack in lower third of oven.\n2 Press the graham cracker crumbs into the bottom of the springform pan: Gently press down on the crumbs using your fingers, until the crumbs are a nice even layer at the bottom of the pan, with maybe just a slight rise along the inside edges of the pan.\n3 Bake the crust: Place the pan on a baking sheet and bake at 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) for 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and let cool. While the crust is cooling, you can skip ahead and start on the filling. Wait until the crust has cooled to wrap the pan in foil in the next step.\n4 Triple wrap pan in heavy duty foil: Prepare the springform pan so that no water leaks into it while cooking. Place a large 18-inch by 18-inch square of heavy duty aluminum foil on a flat surface.\nPlace the springform pan in the middle of the foil. Gently fold up the sides of the foil around the pan. Make sure to do this gently so that you don't create any holes in the foil.\nIf there are any holes, water will get into the pan and ruin the crust.\nPress the foil around the edges of the pan. Place a second large square of foil underneath the pan, and repeat, gently folding up the sides of the foil around the pan and pressing the foil against the pan.\nTo be triply safe, repeat with a third layer of heavy duty foil. Gently crimp the top of the foil sheets around the top edge of the pan.\nMAKE THE CHEESECAKE\n1 Beat cream cheese, then sugar: Cut the cream cheese into chunks and place in the bowl of an electric mixer, with the paddle attachment. Mix on medium speed for 4 minutes until smooth, soft and creamy. Add the sugar, beat for 4 minutes more.\n2 Add salt, vanilla, then eggs, then sour cream: Add the salt and vanilla, beating after each addition. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating for one minute after each addition. Add the sour cream, beat until incorporated.\n3 Add the heavy cream, beat until incorporated. Remember to scrape down the sides of the mixer bowl, and scrape up any thicker bits of cream cheese that have stuck to the bottom of the mixer that paddle attachment has failed to incorporate.\n4 Prepare pan and boiling water: Place the foil-wrapped springform pan in a large, high-sided roasting pan. Prepare 2 quarts of boiling water.\nHeat the oven to 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C).\n5 Pour filling into pan: Pour the cream cheese filling into the springform pan, over the graham cracker bottom layer. Smooth the top with a rubber spatula.\n6 Place in oven: Place the roasting pan with the springform pan in it, in the oven, on the lower rack.\n7 Carefully pour the hot water into the roasting pan (without touching the hot oven), to create a water bath for the cheesecake, pouring until the water reaches halfway up the side of the springform pan, about 1 1/4 inches. (Alternatively you can add the water before putting the pan in the oven, whichever is easier for you.)\n8 Bake at 325\xc2\xb0F (160\xc2\xb0C) for 1 1/2 hours.\n9 Turn off the heat of the oven. Crack open the oven door 1-inch, and let the cake cool in the oven, as the oven cools, for another hour. This gentle cooling will help prevent the cheesecake surface from cracking.\n10 Chill 4 hours: Cover the top of the cheesecake with foil, so that it doesn't actually touch the cheesecake. Chill in the refrigerator for a minimum of 4 hours, or overnight.\nFINISH AND SERVE THE CHEESECAKE\n1 Prepare the sour cream topping: Place sour cream in a medium sized bowl, stir in the powdered sugar and vanilla, until smooth. Chill until you are ready to serve the cake.\nNote that this recipe produces enough sour cream topping for a thick topping and some extra to spoon over individual pieces of cheesecake, if desired. If you would like a thinner layer of topping and no extra, reduce the sour cream topping ingredients in half.\n2 Prepare the raspberry sauce: Place raspberries, sugar, and water in a small saucepan. Use a potato masher to mash the raspberries. Heat on medium, whisking, about 5 minutes, until the sauce begins to thicken. Remove from heat. Let cool.\n3 Prepare the cheesecake to serve: Remove the cake from the refrigerator. Remove the foil from the sides of the pan, and place the cake on your cake serving dish. Run the side of a blunt knife between the edge of the cake and the pan.\nDorie recommends, and we've done with success, that you use a hair dryer to heat the sides of the pan to make it easier to remove. Open the springform latch and gently open the pan and lift up the sides.\nSpread the top with the sour cream mixture. Serve plain or drizzle individual slices with raspberry sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nLemon Cheesecake Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 1 hourChill Time time: 8 hoursYield: 12-16 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the gingersnap crust:\n7 ounces (198g) crisp gingersnap cookies (or graham crackers)\n4 tablespoons (57g) unsalted butter, melted\n3 tablespoons sugar\nPinch of kosher salt\nFor the cheesecake batter:\n2 pounds cream cheese, softened\n1 cup (200g) sugar\n1 packed tablespoon lemon zest (from 1-2 fresh lemons)\n4 large eggs\n1 cup (227g) sour cream\nPinch of kosher salt\nTo serve:\nPrepared lemon curd, store-bought or homemade\nSpecial equipment:\n10-inch springform pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the oven and baking sheet: Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. On a baking sheet place a sheet of aluminum foil large enough to wrap around the outside of the springform pan. Set it aside.\n2 Make the crust: To make the crust, place the cookies into the bowl of a food processor and process until you get fine, even crumbs. Mix the cookie crumbs with the melted butter, sugar, and kosher salt until you get the consistency of wet sand, and the mixture clumps together when squeezed in the palm of your hand.\nPress the crust mixture into the bottom of a 10-inch springform pan in an even layer. You can either keep the crust layer only on the bottom, or on the bottom and pressed up against the sides. It is totally up to you!\nBake for 15 minutes. Remove from the oven and set on a cooling rack while you prepare the cheesecake filling.\n3 Reduce the heat and create a steam bath: Turn the oven down to 325\xc2\xb0F. Place a 9x13-inch baking dish on the lower rack of the oven and fill with boiling water; this will create a steamy environment for the cheesecake to bake.\n4 Make the batter: In the bowl of a stand mixer (or using a mixing bowl and hand mixer) beat the cream cheese until smooth and creamy, scraping the sides of the bowl a few times so there are no lumps of firm cream cheese. Beat in the sugar, lemon zest, and salt, then scrape down the sides.\nBeat in the eggs one at a time, mixing until each egg is combined and scraping down the sides and bottom of the bowl after each addition. Resist the urge to whip the mixture too much; just beat in each egg until mixed well\xe2\x80\x94over-beating can pull too much air into the batter, resulting in a cracked cheesecake.\n5 Add the sour cream and spread the filling over the crust: On low speed, beat in the sour cream until just combined. Spread the cheesecake filling into the pre-baked crust.\n6 Bake the cheesecake: Put the cheesecake onto the foil-lined baking sheet. Press the foil up and around the outside of the springform pan.\nPlace the baking sheet with the cheesecake on it, on the center rack of the oven, above the pan of hot water, for 1 hour or until the cheesecake appears set and dry on top but still jiggles in the center like Jello.\n7 Allow the cheesecake to cool slowly: Turn off the oven and allow the cheesecake to cool for 60 minutes with the oven door closed.\nCrack open the oven door (place a wooden spoon between the door and the frame of the oven to keep it just cracked) and allow the cheesecake to cool for an additional 45 minutes before removing from the oven to cool on a baking rack, until it reaches room temperature.\nThe cheesecake may have domed slightly while baking but should deflate to a flat top with a small ridge around the edge, as it slowly cools.\nRemove the foil once the cheesecake has cooled to room temperature (anytime after the cheesecake has pulled away from the edges of the pan and it's cool enough to handle).\n8 Transfer to the refrigerator: Once the cheesecake is at room temperature, transfer it to the refrigerator to chill for at least 6 hours before serving.\n9 Top with lemon curd and serve: To create the petal pattern as shown in the photos, pipe or dollop small blobs of curd in a ring around the perimeter of the cheesecake, leaving about 1/2-inch border.\nUsing an offset spatula or the back of a teaspoon, gently smash and drag the blobs toward the center of the cheesecake. If you have leftover lemon curd, serve the rest when you slice the cheesecake.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nNo-Bake Cheesecake Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesChilling time: 1 hourYield: 8 to 12 servings\nBe sure to let the cream cheese warm at room temperature until very soft before making the cheesecake, at least 2 hours. If you forget, you can speed up the process by placing the wrapped packages of cream cheese in a bowl of warm water.\nI use an actual vanilla bean in this cheesecake because I think it adds a rounder and more complex flavor than extract, plus I like the way the specks look in the finished cheesecake.\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a vanilla bean, feel free to add an additional 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract to the cheesecake (a total of 4 teaspoons).\nThe gelatin in this recipe helps firm up the cheesecake and make it easy to slice without the need for commercial whipped cream (which already has stabilizers) or sweetened condensed milk (which can make the cheesecake too sweet).\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n8 ounces (225 g) store-bought graham crackers (about 14 rectangular crackers)\n6 tablespoons (85 g or 3/4 stick) unsalted butter, melted\nFor the cheesecake filling:\n1 tablespoon (1 1/2 packages) powdered gelatin\n1/4 cup cold water\n16 ounces (455 g or 2 bricks) cream cheese, at room temperature\n1 1/2 cup (175 g) powdered sugar\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n1 vanilla bean\n2 cups cold heavy cream\nFor the strawberry sauce (optional):\n1 pound (455 g) fresh or frozen hulled and sliced strawberries\n2/3 cups (135 g) granulated white sugar\n2 teaspoons cornstarch\n2 teaspoons cold water\n1 teaspoon balsamic vinegar (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\n9-inch springform pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the crust: Lightly coat a 9-inch round springform pan with cooking spray. Break the graham crackers into a few large pieces and place them in a food processor. Process into crumbs. Drizzle in the melted butter and process until the crumbs start to clump together. Dump the buttery crumbs into the prepared pan and press into a thick crust over the bottom of the pan using the bottom of a glass.\n2 Dissolve the gelatin: Sprinkle the gelatin over the cold water in a microwave-safe bowl or glass measuring cup. Stir to moisten - it should look like applesauce. Set aside for 5 minutes to soften. Once softened, microwave the gelatin for 20 to 30 seconds, until the gelatin is dissolved and liquid. Set aside to cool.\n3 Prepare the cheesecake base: Place the cream cheese in the bowl of a stand mixer and sift the powdered sugar over top. Mix on low speed with the paddle attachment until the sugar is begins to mix into the cream cheese, and then raise the mixer speed to medium and mix until the sugar is fully incorporated and the cream cheese looks fluffy and creamy, like frosting.\nScrape down the sides of the bowl and add the vanilla extract. Split the vanilla bean lengthwise and scrape out the seeds with the edge of a butter knife. Add the seeds to the cheesecake batter, and reserve the vanilla pod for another use. Mix for an additional 15 seconds or until the vanilla extract and seeds have been blended in. Scrape down the sides of the bowl and the beater.\n4 Switch to a whisk attachment and add the cream. Mix on low speed until the cream is incorporated, then raise the speed to medium. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl. Continue to mix, slowly increasing the speed to high, until soft peaks form (peaks that slowly bend over at the tips).\n5 Reduce the speed to medium and slowly drizzle the warm gelatin into the bowl. If your gelatin has cooled too much and started to gel, warm it in the microwave for another 5 to 10 seconds until liquidy again before adding mixing it into the filling. Once all the gelatin has been added, return the mixer speed to high and beat until the mixture forms firm peaks (peaks that stay firmly upright at the tips).\n6 Spoon the filling into the pan on top of the graham cracker crust. Smooth the top of the cheesecake. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 1 hour or overnight to firm up.\n7 Prepare the strawberry sauce (optional): Place the strawberries and sugar in a large pot. In a small bowl, stir the cornstarch and cold water together until they make a smooth, milky liquid, and then pour over the strawberries. Cook on medium high heat, stirring constantly for about 5 to 7 minutes or until the strawberries have softened and the sauce has thickened.\nRemove from heat and stir in the balsamic vinegar if using. Let cool to room temperature, then spoon over the chilled cheesecake and return to the refrigerator to chill for an additional hour or overnight. (Alternatively, serve the sauce at the table and spoon over individual slices.)\n8 When ready to serve: Run an offset spatula or a thin butterknife around the edge of the cake, then remove the outer ring. Leave it on the pan base, and transfer to a serving platter or cake stand. Top with any toppings you like. Slice and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nPressure Cooker Cheesecake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesChilling time: at least 12 hours or up to 24 hoursYield: 8 slices\nReprinted with permission from The Essential Instant Pot Cookbook by Coco Morante copyright \xc2\xa9 2017. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n8 graham cracker sheets\n1 tablespoon brown sugar\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted\nFor the filling:\n2 (8-ounce) packages cream cheese, at room temperature\n1/4 cup heavy cream\n1/2 cup granulated sugar\n1 tablespoon all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n2 large eggs, at room temperature\n1 large egg yolk, at room temperature\n1/2 cup sour cream\n1 tablespoon powdered sugar\nSpecial equipment:\n7-inch round springform pan\nFood processor\nTrivet\n6-quart Instant Pot, or other electric pressure cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the pan: Line the base of a 7-inch round springform pan with an 8-inch round of parch\xc2\xadment paper. Secure the collar on the springform pan, closing it onto the base so the parchment round is clamped in. Lightly grease the sides of the pan with butter or nonstick cooking spray. (I traced a circle on parchment using the bottom of the springform pan as the guide. This worked great! \xe2\x80\x93Emma)\n2 Make the crust: To make the crust, in a food processor, process the graham crackers into fine crumbs. You should have 3/4 cup. (I recommend measuring out the crumbs as I had slightly more than 3/4 cup. \xe2\x80\x93Emma) Add the brown sugar and melted butter and, using one-second pulses, process the mixture until a uniform, sandy texture forms.\nTransfer the crumb mixture to the prepared pan and press firmly in an even layer onto the bottom and about 1/2 inch up the sides of the pan. Place the pan in the freezer to allow the crust to firm up a bit while you make the filling.\n3 Make the filling: To make the filling, in the now-empty food processor, combine the softened cream cheese, heavy cream, granulated sugar, flour, and vanilla. (I wiped the food processor clean before doing this step. \xe2\x80\x93Emma)\nProcess the mixture in about 5 one-second pulses, just until it becomes a smooth filling, stopping to scrape down the sides of the bowl if necessary.\nAdd the eggs and the egg yolk one at a time, processing for 2 one-second pulses after each addition. Do not overprocess the filling, or you will end up with an overly fluffy cheesecake. Using a spoon or a rubber spatula, gently stir in any remaining streaks of egg yolk. It is fine if a few streaks of egg yolk remain.\nPour the filling into the prepared crust. Tap the pan firmly against the counter\xc2\xadtop a few times to remove any air bubbles in the filling.\n4 Make a sling for the cheesecake: Fold a 20-inch-long sheet of aluminum foil in half lengthwise twice to create a 3-inch-wide strip. Center it underneath the pan to act as a sling for lifting the pan in and out of the Instant Pot.\n5 Assemble everything in the pressure cooker: Pour 1 1/2 cups water into the pot and place the trivet in the pot.\nHolding the ends of the foil sling, lift the cake pan and lower it into the pot. Fold over the ends of the sling so they fit inside the pot.\n6 Pressure cook the cheesecake: Secure the lid and set the Pressure Release to Sealing. Select the Manual setting and set the cooking time for 32 minutes at high pressure. (My Instant Pot took about 8 minutes to come up to pressure before the cooking time actually began. \xe2\x80\x93Emma)\n7 Make the sour cream topping: While the cheesecake is cooking, in a small bowl, whisk together the sour cream and confectioners\xe2\x80\x99 sugar.\n8 Release the pressure naturally and remove the cheesecake from the pot: When the timer goes off, leave the pot on its default Keep Warm setting for 20 minutes, letting the pressure release naturally.\nOpen the pot, taking care not to drip condensation from the lid onto the cheesecake. Wearing heat-resistant mitts, grasp the ends of the foil sling, lift the springform pan out of the Instant Pot, and transfer the cheesecake to a cooling rack.\nUse a paper towel to dab up any moisture that may have settled on the top. (Be sure to dab up any water that pools on the sides too! \xe2\x80\x93 Emma) The cake will be puffed up and jiggle a bit in the center when it comes out of the pot, but it will settle and set up as it cools.\n9 Add the sour cream topping: When the cheesecake has deflated about 1/2 inch, spread the sour cream mixture on top in a smooth, even layer. Let the cheesecake cool on the rack for 1 hour.\n10 Cover and refrigerate for at least 12 hours or for up to 24 hours before unmolding.\n11 Unmold and serve the cheesecake: To serve, unclasp the collar on the pan and lift it off, then use the parchment border to tug the cheesecake off the base of the pan onto a plate, where it can be sliced and served.\n(I ran a thin spatula between the cheesecake and the mold to make sure it released cleanly. You can also clean up any rough edges with the spatula before serving. Also, my leftover cheesecake kept just fine in the fridge for about a week! So good! \xe2\x80\x93Emma)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nPumpkin Cheesecake Recipe\nYield: Makes 16 servings\nYou can make your own pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e by cutting a sugar pumpkin in half, scooping out the seeds, placing the pumpkin halves cut-side down in a roasting pan with a 1/4 inch of water in it, and cooking it in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for an hour, until soft. Scoop out the flesh and pur\xc3\xa9e it in a blender or food processor. Strain out excess water.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n1 cup pecans\n1/2 cup all-purpose flour\n1/2 cup brown sugar\n1/2 cup graham cracker crumbs (approximately 4 graham crackers)\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened\n1 egg yolk\nFor the filling:\n2 15-ounce cans pumpkin puree (see Recipe Note)\n3 tablespoons all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger\n1/4 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg\n1/4 teaspoon ground allspice\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n2 tablespoons vanilla extract\n2 tablespoons bourbon or other whiskey\n5 large eggs\n4 8-ounce packages cream cheese, room temperature\n2 cups (1 pound) brown sugar\nSpecial equipment:\n1 9-inch diameter, 3-inch tall springform pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make graham cracker pecan crust: Pulse pecans, flour, brown sugar, and graham cracker crumbs in a food processor. Add butter and egg yolk. Pulse until mixture is homogenous. Press into bottom of 9\xe2\x80\x9d springform pan and bake for 10 minutes at 375\xc2\xb0F. Remove from oven and let cool.\n2 Drain or strain any liquid from pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e. Take pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e and place on several layers of paper towels. Cover with several layers of paper towels and use your hands to gently squeeze out liquid from the pur\xc3\xa9e.\nNote that you will probably go through a lot of paper towels (can use tea towels too). Two 15-ounce cans of pur\xc3\xa9ed pumpkin should yield a little more than 2 cups of pur\xc3\xa9e, with the excess moisture removed. You want exactly 2 cups of the pur\xc3\xa9e.\n3 Mix spices with pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e, bourbon, eggs: Whisk together the flour, cinnamon, ground ginger, grated nutmeg, and allspice in a medium bowl. With a wooden spoon (no need for a mixer for this step), mix in the salt, pumpkin pur\xc3\xa9e, vanilla, and bourbon. Beat in the eggs, one at a time.\n4 Mix cream cheese with brown sugar, add pumpkin mixture: In a large bowl, (helps to use a mixer for this step) combine the cream cheese and the brown sugar until fully creamed and smooth (no lumps). Gradually add the pumpkin mixture until fully incorporated. Bring a kettle of water to a boil.\n5 Line pan with 3 layers of thick foil: Place crust-baked springform pan in the middle of three layers of large sheets of heavy duty aluminum foil (to help prevent water-bath moisture from leaking into the pan). Fold the aluminum foil up the sides of the pan and trim. (You can also use a turkey roasting bag instead of the foil to keep the water out.)\n6 Pour filling into pan: Place the aluminum wrapped pan in a large roasting pan (large enough so that there is room on all sides). Pour the pumpkin cream cheese mixture into the springform pan.\n7 Pour hot water into roasting pan to create water bath: Place the roasting pan containing the springform pan in a 325\xc2\xb0F oven on the middle rack. Pour boiling water into the pan so that it comes halfway up the side of the springform pan.\n8 Cook for 1 1/2 hours. Turn off the oven heat and prop the oven door open. Let the cheesecake sit in the oven, cooling for another hour. Then remove from oven and let come to room temperature. Once it has cooled down, chill for several hours in the refrigerator, preferably overnight.\n9 When ready to serve, gently remove the cake from the springform pan.\nTo do this well, I recommend a tip by Dorie Greenspan in her book Baking: From My Home to Yours. To help ensure that the cake doesn't stick to the springform side as you unlock it, first run a blunt knife around the cake and then warm the sides of the pan with a hair dryer. Then carefully unlock the springform and lift off the sides.\nServe cheesecake with caramel sauce, candied pecans, and whipped cream.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nSous Vide Cheesecake in Jars Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: 6 8-ounce servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cheesecake:\n2 (8-ounce) packages cream cheese, softened\n2/3 cup sugar\n3 large eggs\n2/3 cup buttermilk\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\nPinch of salt\nFor the topping:\n2 cups chopped fresh or frozen strawberries, hulled and roughly chopped\n2 tablespoons sugar\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\nPinch of salt\n1 cup crumbled graham crackers\nSpecial equipment:\n6 (8-ounce) jars with lids\nCanning jar lifter\n  METHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the water: Fill a pot with water and place your immersion circulator inside. Set the temperature to 176\xc2\xb0F and let the water come up to temperature. Make sure there is enough water in the pot to completely cover the jars.\n2 Beat together the cream cheese, sugar, and eggs: In a stand mixer with the paddle attachment or with a hand mixer, beat together cream cheese and sugar at medium speed until it\xe2\x80\x99s light and fluffy. Then add in the eggs, one at a time, and beat until combined.\n3 Add the buttermilk: Slowly add the buttermilk to the cream cheese mixture, mixing on low until it\xe2\x80\x99s combined. Then add the vanilla and salt, and mix until the cheesecake mixture has no lumps and is an even consistency.\nStop the mixer a couple times and scrape down the sides of the bowl to make sure everything is evenly incorporated.\n4 Fill the jars: Transfer the mixture to a large measuring cup or bowl with a spout. Divide the cheesecake mixture among 6 jars, leaving about 1 1/2 inches of room at the top of each jar. Seal jars tightly with lids and bands, but don\xe2\x80\x99t overtighten them.\n5 Cook the cheesecakes sous vide: Once the water has come to temperature, add the jars and cook for 90 minutes. Then remove the jars carefully and allow to cool. Refrigerate the jars to set the cheesecake completely before serving, although they can be served at room temperature as well.\n6 Make the strawberry topping: Put the strawberries in a small pot over low heat with the sugar, lemon juice, and salt. Bring to a low simmer. Cook for 2 to 3 minutes until the strawberries just start to break down but are still spoonable. You aren\xe2\x80\x99t making jam, so don\xe2\x80\x99t overcook it. Allow topping to cool to room temperature.\n7 Serve the cheesecake: Place a big spoonful of the strawberry topping over each jar along with a few spoonfuls of crumbled graham crackers.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nChocolate Chip Cheesecake Bars Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 25 minutesChilling time: 4 hoursYield: 16 bars\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the cookie crust:\n30 original-size vanilla wafer cookies\n2 tablespoons granulated sugar\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n3 tablespoons (43 g) unsalted butter, melted\n2 tablespoons (10 g) mini chocolate chips\nFor the cheesecake filling:\n16 ounces softened cream cheese\n3 large eggs\n1/2 cup (3 1/2 ounces) granulated sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/4 cup (2 ounces) sour cream\n1/2 cup (3 ounces) mini chocolate chips\n  Special equipment:\nFood processor\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven: Heat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Grease and line an 8x8 baking dish with parchment paper, leaving an overhang of parchment on two sides. This will help you lift the bars out of the pan after they\xe2\x80\x99ve been baked.\n2 Make the crust: Pulse vanilla wafers in a food processor until fine crumbs the size of sand are formed. You should end up with 1 cup of crumbs. Add sugar and salt to the food processor and pulse 5 times to combine. Pour in melted butter and pulse until the mixture starts to clump together, 5-10 seconds. The crust will look like wet sand and stick together when squeezed. Remove blade and use a small rubber spatula to stir in 2 tablespoons mini chocolate chips.\n3 Form the crust to the pan: Dump the cookie crumb mixture into the prepared baking dish. Firmly, press crust into the bottom of the dish in an even layer. You can use the bottom of a measuring cup for this. It should be firm enough to not move when gently touched. Bake for 10 minutes. The crust will be slightly golden brown around the edges.\nRemove from oven to cool on a cooling rack while you make the filling.\nTurn the oven down to 325\xc2\xb0F.\n4 Make the filling: Beat the cream cheese in a mixing bowl (or in the bowl of a stand mixer) until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time until combined, scraping the bowl after each addition.\nBeat in the sugar, followed by the vanilla extract and sour cream, until just combined. Do not overmix. The mixture should be smooth and thick like yogurt.\nTurn off the mixer and fold in the mini chocolate chips with a spatula.\n5 Fill the crust: Spread the cheesecake filling over the prepared crust and rap the pan on the counter a few times to release any bubbles.\n6 Bake the bars: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes or until the filling is just set and slightly jiggly in the center. Turn off the oven, crack open the door (use a wooden spoon wedged between the door to keep it from closing if yours won\xe2\x80\x99t stay open) and cool in the oven for 30 minutes.\n7 Chill the bars: Remove from the oven and cool to room temperature on a rack, about 30 minutes. Transfer to the fridge and chill for at least 3 hours or overnight before serving.\nLeftovers! These bars will keep in a covered container in the fridge for about a week.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nRaspberry Cheesecake in a Mason Jar Recipe\nCook time: 2 hoursCooling and chilling time: 1 hourYield: Makes 4 individual servings\nAs soon as you think you want to make these cheesecakes, take the cream cheese out of the refrigerator to help it soften as it warms to room temperature.\nYou can probably easily double the recipe without having to double the raspberry sauce (it\'s a generous amount).\nINGREDIENTS\n1 12-ounce package frozen raspberries\n3/4 cup sugar, divided 1/2 cup and 1/4 cup\n1/3 cup water\n10 Oreo cookies, without the filling, or 20 chocolate wafer cookies\n2 Tbsp melted butter\n8 ounces cream cheese, room temperature\nPinch salt\n1 egg\n1/3 cup sour cream\nWhipped cream for topping\nFresh raspberries for garnish\n  4 Wide-mouthed 8-ounce mason jars\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the raspberry sauce: Set aside 1/2 a cup of the frozen raspberries from the package. With the remaining raspberries, place them in a medium saucepan. Add 1/2 cup sugar and 1/3 cup of water. Bring to a simmer on medium high heat, then lower the heat to maintain the simmer, and gently cook, whisking frequently, until the raspberries have completely broken down, about 10 minutes.\nIf you want, strain the raspberry sauce through a sieve to remove the seeds, and then return the sauce to the pan and continue to gently simmer until the the sauce is syrupy. Set aside to cool.\n2 Make the Oreo cookie crust: Grind the chocolate cookie wafers (Oreo or other brand) in a food processor, mini chopper, or by placing in a plastic bag and crushing with a rolling pin, until finely ground.\nPlace in a medium bowl and stir in the melted butter. Divide evenly among the mason jars, packing the chocolate "crust" at the bottom of each mason jar in a layer about 1/4 to 1/3-inch thick.\nAt this point you can put in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for 10 minutes to bake the crust in, which will make it easier to pour in the cheesecake filling without it mixing in with the crust. (Or if you don\'t care if the bottom is a little messy, you can skip this part.)\n3 Make the cream cheese filling: In a mixer, beat the cream cheese on medium speed for 4 minutes, until smooth and light. Add 1/4 cup of sugar and beat 4 minutes more. Add a pinch of salt and the egg, and beat another minute.\nAdd the sour cream and beat another minute, until smooth. Add 1/4 cup of the cooled raspberry syrup from step one, and beat until incorporated.\n4 Layer raspberries and filling on top of crusts in mason jars: Place the reserved raspberries on top of the chocolate crusts in the mason jars in a single layer. Pour the raspberry cheesecake filling over the raspberries in the jars.\n5 Bake in water bath: Place in a roasting pan and add about an inch of boiling water to the pan to create a water bath, which will help the cheesecakes cook more evenly. Bake at 325\xc2\xb0F for 40 minutes. Then turn off the heat in the oven and let the cheesecakes continue to gently cook in the residual heat of the oven for another 30 minutes.\n6 Chill and top with whipped cream and raspberry sauce: Remove from oven and let cool to room temp. Chill for at least a half hour before eating. Don\'t worry if there are cracks on the surface of the cheesecakes. Top with the remaining raspberry sauce, whipped cream, and fresh raspberries.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nInstant Pot Pumpkin Cheesecake Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourChilling time: 12 hoursYield: 8 servings\nFor Stovetop Pressure Cookers: Make the crust and filling, then assemble the cheesecake as directed below, placing it on a steam rack. Pour 1 1/2 cups of water into the pressure cooker, lower the cheesecake inside the pot, place the lid on in its sealed position, and cook at high pressure for 27 minutes. Let the pressure release naturally completely before opening the pot, then refrigerate and serve as directed.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n1/4 cup pecans or pecan pieces\n8 graham cracker sheets\n1 tablespoon brown sugar or turbinado sugar\n1 tablespoon unsalted butter, melted and cooled\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the filling:\n12 ounces cream cheese, at room temperature\n1/4 cup heavy cream\n1/2 cup canned pumpkin puree\n1/2 cup brown sugar or turbinado sugar\n1 tablespoon all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n3/4 teaspoon pumpkin pie spice\n2 large eggs plus 1 egg yolk, at room temperature\nFor the whipped cream:\n1 cup heavy cream\n1 tablespoon bourbon\n1 tablespoon powdered sugar\nTo garnish:\nSprinkling of ground cinnamon\n2 tablespoons chopped toasted pecans\nSpecial equipment:\n7-inch round springform pan, or 7-inch by 3-inch push-pan\nFood processor\n6-quart electric pressure cooker, such as the Instant Pot\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the pan: Line the base of a 7-inch round springform pan or 7-inch by 3-inch push-pan with parchment paper. Lightly grease the sides of the pan with butter or nonstick cooking spray.\n2 Toast the pecans: Toast the pecans in a dry skillet over medium heat on the stovetop for 4 to 5 minutes until they become fragrant; watch carefully to avoid burning. Alternatively, toast the pecans in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for about 10 minutes, checking frequently, until toasted and fragrant.\nAllow the nuts to cool.\n3 Process and prepare the crust: In a food processor, process the cooled pecans and graham crackers to fine crumbs. Add the brown sugar, melted butter, and salt. Using 1-second pulses, process until the mixture resembles damp sand.\nTransfer the crumb mixture to the prepared pan and press firmly into an even layer on the bottom and about 1/2 inch up the sides of the pan. Use the bottom of a drinking glass to firmly press the crumbs into the bottom.\nPlace the pan in the freezer to allow the crust to firm up a bit while you make the filling.\n4 Make the filling: In the now-empty food processor, combine the cream cheese, heavy cream, pumpkin puree, brown sugar, flour, vanilla, and pumpkin pie spice. Process the mixture for about five 1-second pulses, just until smooth, stopping to scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed.\nOne at a time, add the eggs and the egg yolk, processing for two 1-second pulses after each addition until just barely combined. Using a rubber spatula, gently stir in any large streaks of egg yolk. It\xe2\x80\x99s fine if a few small streaks remain. (Do not over-process the filling, or the batter may overflow the pan as it cooks and you will end up with an overly fluffy cheesecake, which may crack as it cools.)\n5 Pour the filling into the prepared crust. Remove the crust from the freezer and pour in the filling. Tap the pan firmly against the countertop a few times to remove any air bubbles from the filling. Place the pan on a long-handled silicone steam rack.\nIf you are using a tall push pan, you can cover it with aluminum foil to keep any condensation off of the cheesecake. If using a springform, do not cover.\n6 Pressure cook the cheesecake: Pour 1 1/2 cups water into the Instant Pot. Holding the handles of the steam rack, lower it into the pot.\nSecure the lid and set the Pressure Release to \xe2\x80\x9cSealing.\xe2\x80\x9d Select the Cake, Pressure Cook, or Manual setting and set the cooking time for 32 minutes at high pressure. (The pot will take about 10 minutes to come up to pressure before the cooking program begins.)\n7 Release the pressure and cool: When the cooking program ends, leave the pot on its default \xe2\x80\x9cKeep Warm\xe2\x80\x9d setting for 20 minutes, letting the pressure release naturally.\nAfter 20 minutes, open the pot, taking care not to drip condensation from the lid onto the cheesecake. Wearing heat-resistant mitts, grab the handles of the steam rack, lift it out of the pot, and transfer the cheesecake to a cooling rack.\nIf you have not covered the pan with foil, use a paper towel to dab up any moisture that may have settled on the top. If the pan is covered, remove the foil, taking care not to get burned from the steam.\nThe cake will be puffed up and jiggle a bit in the center when it comes out of the pot, but it will settle and set up as it cools.\n8 Cool and refrigerate the cheesecake: Let the cheesecake cool on the rack for about 1 hour, then cover (or re-cover) and refrigerate for at least 12 hours, or up to 24 hours.\n9 Prepare the whipped cream: The day you plan to serve the cheesecake, make the whipped cream. In a medium bowl or stand mixer, combine the heavy cream, bourbon, and powdered sugar. Using an electric mixer or whisk, beat the mixture vigorously (about 2 minutes on high) until fluffy and just stiff enough to hold its shape. Cover the bowl and refrigerate for up 12 hours.\n10 Serve the cheesecake: If using a springform pan, run a knife around the side of the pan, then unclasp the collar on the pan and lift it off to unmold it. Use the parchment border to tug the cheesecake off the base of the pan and onto a plate.\nIf you\xe2\x80\x99re using a push pan, run a knife around the side of the pan, place a drinking glass under the pan, then gently slide the outside ring of the pan downwards.\nTransfer the cheesecake to a serving plate. Cut into wedges and serve each piece topped with whipped cream, chopped nuts, and a sprinkle of cinnamon.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nBanoffee Cheesecake Recipe\nPrep time: 40 minutesCook time: 1 hourCooling and Chilling time: 16 hoursYield: 12 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the toffee sauce:\n3/4 cup heavy cream\n1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, sliced\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup (197 g) packed light brown sugar\n3 tablespoons dark corn syrup\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\nFor the banoffee cheesecake:\n2 (5-ounce) packages Walker\xe2\x80\x99s shortbread cookies\n1 cup (200 g) granulated sugar, divided\n3 tablespoons melted unsalted butter\n4 (8-ounce) packages cream cheese, at room temperature\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n4 large eggs\n3 ripe bananas, peeled and mashed\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon banana extract\n1/3 cup cornstarch\nTo garnish:\nToffee sauce\nWhipped cream\nDried banana chips\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the toffee sauce: Warm the heavy cream in the microwave for one minute, or on the stovetop over medium heat. The cream should steam, but not boil. Set this aside.\nIn a 4-quart saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Add the salt, brown sugar, and corn syrup. Whisking frequently, heat until the sugar has dissolved and the syrup bubbles gently. This should take anywhere from 3 to 5 minutes.\nTurn the stove off and whisk in the warmed cream\xe2\x80\x94be careful, as the sugar will bubble and steam once the cream is poured in. Add the vanilla extract to the sauce and set the pan back over medium heat.\nCook for another 5 minutes, or until the syrup is thick. Transfer the sauce to a glass jar and store in the refrigerator until ready to use, up to one week in advance.\n2 Prep the oven and the pan: Preheat your oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Wrap a 10-inch springform pan in heavy duty aluminum foil and set aside; be very careful not to tear or puncture the foil.\n3 Make the shortbread crust: Use a food processor to pulse the shortbread cookies into fine crumbs. Add 1/4 cup of granulated sugar and the melted butter to the food processor bowl and pulse until the crumbs hold together.\nSqueeze a handful of crumbs in the palm of your hand. If the mixture doesn\xe2\x80\x99t hold together, add another tablespoon of melted butter, and re-mix.\n4 Pre-bake the crust: Press the shortbread mixture onto the bottom and an inch or so up the sides of the springform pan. Bake the crust for 10 minutes. Remove the pan from the oven and allow it to cool while you prepare the cheesecake filling.\n5 Heat water: While the crust bakes, heat 4 or 5 cups of water to boiling for the water bath.\n6 Prepare the banana cheesecake: In the bowl of a stand mixer with a paddle attachment (or in a large mixing bowl), blend together the cream cheese, the remaining 3/4 cup sugar, and the salt until smooth.\nAdd the eggs, one at a time, to the cream cheese mixture, stopping to scrape down the sides after each addition. Mix on low speed for an additional minute.\nAdd the banana puree and both extracts. Blend on low for another minute. Scrape down the mixing bowl and add the cornstarch. Blend on the lowest speed for 30 seconds, or until no lumps of cornstarch are visible, being careful not to over-mix. \n7 Bake the cheesecake: Pour the batter into the prepared pan and set the foil-wrapped springform pan into a larger pan. Add enough hot water to reach halfway up the sides of the springform pan and carefully place the pan into the oven.\nBake the cheesecake for 55 minutes to an 1 hour, or until the top is a light golden brown and the cheesecake jiggles slightly when shaken. Turn the oven off and open the door a crack to allow the cheesecake to cool in the oven for 30 minutes.\n8 Cool the cheesecake completely: Once the cheesecake has cooled in the oven, carefully take it out of the oven and remove the foil. Cool the cheesecake on the countertop for an hour, then transfer it to the refrigerator to cool completely, at least 12 hours or up to 24 hours.\n9 Decorate the cheesecake: Once the cheesecake is cold, remove the collar from the springform pan. Warm the toffee sauce slightly so that it's pourable but not runny (I set it in a dish of warm water), then drizzle one cup of the toffee sauce over the top of the cheesecake. Use a piping bag to pipe rosettes of whipped cream around the cheesecake and garnish each rosette with a banana chip.\nKeep the cheesecake refrigerated until ready to serve, and be sure to keep leftovers chilled, too.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nTriple Chocolate Cheesecake Recipe\nPrep time: 1 hourCook time: 1 hourChill Time time: 12 hoursYield: Serves 12\nLet the eggs and cream cheese come to room temperature before making this cheesecake. You will also need make this cake 24 hours before you want to serve it to allow adequate time to chill, and frankly, we all need a bit more chill time.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the crust:\n8 chocolate graham crackers, crushed (about 1 1/4 cups)\n1/3 cup (66 g) sugar\n1 tablespoon cocoa powder\nPinch of kosher salt\n4 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted\nFor the filling:\n8 ounces semi-sweet chocolate, chopped\n1/3 cup heavy whipping cream\n4 large eggs, room temperature\n2 teaspoons vanilla extract\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n3 (8 ounce) packages cream cheese, room temperature\n1 1/4 cup (250 g) sugar\n2 tablespoons cocoa powder\nFor the ganache topping:\n3/4 cup heavy whipping cream\n1 tablespoon corn syrup (optional)\nPinch of kosher salt\n8 oz semi-sweet chocolate, finely chopped\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nSpecial equipment:\n9-inch springform pan\nHeavy-duty, extra-long aluminum foil\nRoasting pan\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the crust: In the bowl of a food processor fitted with the metal s-blade attachment, add the graham crackers. Pulse until they are ground fine like sand.\nAdd the sugar, cocoa powder, and salt. Pulse 2 or 3 times until just combined. Pour melted butter around the bowl in a circle, pulse 4 or 5 times combine it. The mixture should clump a little bit, but may still look a little dry.\nDump the mixture into the bottom of your ungreased springform pan. Use your fingers or the underside of a cup to press the mixture into the bottom of the pan, making it as even as possible.\nPlace the crust in the oven and bake for about 8 to 10 minutes. Remove from oven to cool.\n3 Reduce the oven temp and melt the chocolate: Once the crust has baked, reduce the oven to 300\xc2\xb0F.\nIn a medium-sized, heavy-bottom saucepan set over low heat, combine the chopped chocolate and 1/3 cup heavy cream. Stir continuously, for about 10 minutes. Once melted, remove from heat, and set aside. You will fold it into your filling later.\n4 Make the cheesecake filling: In a small bowl or Pyrex measuring cup, gently beat the eggs, vanilla extract, and salt together with a fork. Set it aside.\nUsing a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment (or a hand mixer set to low and a large bowl), add the cream cheese. Beat the cream cheese on low or stir speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl.\nBeat again on low for about 1 minute. With the stand mixer still on low, slowly add the sugar and two tablespoons cocoa powder. Stop the mixer. Scrape down the bottom and sides of the bowl. Beat for another minute or two until light and fluffy.\nWith the mixture still on low, add the egg mixture, 1/3 at a time, scraping down the sides of the bowl after each addition.\nPour the cooled, melted chocolate into the bowl of the stand mixer and (you guessed it!) beat on low for about a minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl. Beat on low again for about 30 seconds, or until the chocolate is fully incorporated. Alternatively, you can fold in the chocolate in using a spatula.\n5 Prepare the water bath and add the filling: Wrap the outside of the your springform pan in 3 layers of aluminum foil. Be careful not to tear or puncture the foil. Bring the foil all the way up the sides. Set it inside a roasting pan or a large Dutch oven.\nPour the filling into springform pan.\nFill the roasting pan with warm water about halfway up the sides of the springform pan. (I usually just heat it in a tea kettle.) Be careful not to splash any water into the cheesecake pan or inside the foil.\n6 Bake the cheesecake: Put the pan in the oven and bake until the cheesecake is just barely set in the center, 55-65 minutes. It will still jiggle slightly, but shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t slosh in the center when moved.\n7 Let it cool, then chill: Remove the roasting pan from the oven. Let the cake cool in the water bath for about an hour. Then remove it from the water bath and transfer it to a cooling rack on the counter for another hour. Finally, keep the cake in the springform pan, and let it chill, uncovered overnight in the fridge.\n8 Make the ganache: Place chopped chocolate in a medium-sized bowl. In a small saucepan set over medium heat, add the heavy cream, corn syrup, and salt. Stir to combine and bring to a simmer.\nPour the heated cream over the chopped chocolate. Don\xe2\x80\x99t stir. Let sit for 5 minutes, then add the vanilla. Use a spatula and stir gently to combine. Let the ganache cool at room temperature for 2 hours. Cover with plastic wrap and keep it in the fridge until you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to serve the cheesecake.\n9 Finish the cake: The ganache is probably too thick to pour. Simply warm it in the microwave for 15-second intervals (or more depending on how powerful your microwave is) until it\xe2\x80\x99s pourable. (Be careful, though \xe2\x80\x93 chocolate can burn quickly in a microwave.) Stir it gently.\nRemove the cheesecake from the springform pan. Pour about half of the ganache over the top, just until it drips down a little on the sides. You probably won\xe2\x80\x99t use all of the ganache. Save the rest to add to hot milk for the most luxurious hot cocoa or freeze it in scoopfuls for when you need a little chocolate fix.\n10 Serve the cake: Serve the cake with sliced strawberries (if you wish), slice, and enjoy!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nSweet Cherry Pie Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourPie chilling before baking time: 30 minutesYield: Makes 8 servings\nWe've used 1/2 cup of sugar for the filling, which results in a pie not overly sweet. You may want to use more or less sugar, depending on how sweet you would like your pie to be, and how sweet your cherries are.\nINGREDIENTS\nPie dough for top and bottom 9 or 10-inch pie (see pie crust recipe)\n5 cups sweet cherries, pitted\n1/2 cup sugar\n1/2 teaspoon almond extract\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n6 tablespoons cornstarch\n2 teaspoons of butter, cut into small pieces\n1 large egg\nCoarse sugar for sprinkling\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the cherry filling: Place the pitted cherries, sugar, almond extract, lemon juice and cornstarch in a large bowl. Toss until the cherries are well coated with the sugar and other ingredients.\n2 Roll out bottom crust: On a lightly floured clean surface, roll out the bottom crust. Form it into a 9- or 10-inch pie pan. Using kitchen scissors, trim the edges so that they extend beyond the edge of the pie pan by 1 inch. Place in the refrigerator while you roll out the top crust.\n3 Roll out top crust: Roll out the top crust to about the same size as the bottom crust. If you want to make a lattice top (it's pretty and it's easy to do) follow these instructions for making a lattice pie crust.\n4 Fill the pie: Use a slotted spoon to lift the cherries out of the bowl and put them in the pie plate. (Leave any excess liquid behind.) Dot with small dabs of butter. Cover with the top crust. Trim the edges. Crimp to seal the edges together.\n5 Score the pie and chill: Score the top crust with several cuts so that the steam can escape while the pie is cooking (unnecessary if you are making a lattice crust). Chill the pie for 30 minutes before cooking.\n6 Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. \n7 Brush with egg wash (optional): In a small bowl, whisk the egg with a tablespoon of water or milk. Use a pastry brush to brush over the top crust. Sprinkle the top with coarse sugar.\n8 Bake: Place the pie on the middle rack, with a baking sheet on the rack below to catch any pie drippings.\nBake for 15 minutes, then reduce the temp to 350\xc2\xb0F and cook for 45 to 55 minutes longer, or until the crust is nicely browned and the filling is thick and bubbly.\n9 Allow to cool completely before serving. Store pie covered with plastic wrap at room temperature for 3 days or in the fridge for up to 5 days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nCherry Hand Pies Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesChill time: 15 minutesYield: 6 hand pies\nBe sure to thaw the puff pastry before using, ideally in the fridge overnight. Puff pastry can also be quickly thawed on the counter top, but keep an eye on it on hot days so that it doesn't become too soft to work with.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound fresh or frozen sweet cherries -- pitted but left whole if fresh, thawed if frozen\n1/3 to 1/2 cup sugar\n1 tablespoon cornstarch\nZest and juice of one lemon\n1 large egg + 1 tablespoon water\n1 17-oz. package puff pastry, thawed\nCoarse decorating sugar (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat oven to 450\xc2\xb0F. Line a baking sheet with parchment and set aside.\n2 Make the cherry filling: In a colander placed over a bowl, combine the cherries, 1/3 cup of sugar, cornstarch, lemon zest, and juice. Stir to combine and then let it sit for 15 minutes. This resting time allows some of the juice to drain out of the fruit and will ensure your filling isn\xe2\x80\x99t too liquidy. Don\xe2\x80\x99t worry. There will still be plenty of cherry juice left!\nTaste after 15 minutes and add additional sugar if needed.\n  3 Unroll and cut the puff pastry: When you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to make the hand pies, unroll one portion of puff pastry and press it out gently to make it even thickness. Cut into 6 even rectangles and place the rectangles on the baking sheet lined with parchment paper.\nCut the second sheet of puff pastry into matching pieces.\n4 Fill the hand pies: Spoon about two tablespoons of cherry filling onto each rectangle on the baking sheet and then top with the rectangles from the second sheet of puff pastry. Using a fork, crimp the edges of the hand pies to seal them. You should get six cherry hand pies out of the recipe.\nCut 2 or 3 slashes on the top of each hand pie with a serrated knife. Whisk together the egg and tablespoon of water and brush over each hand pie. Sprinkle with coarse sugar, if using.\n   5 Briefly freeze the pies: Prior to baking, freeze the hand pies for 15 to 30 minutes to chill the filling so it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t explode while baking.\nPies can also be completely frozen, wrapped tightly in plastic wrap, and stored for up to 3 months before baking.\n6 Bake the pies: Remove the pies from the freezer and put them straight into the oven. Bake for 13 to 15 minutes, rotating the pan once half way through until the hand pies are beautifully browned and puffy.\nIf you are baking completely frozen hand pies, you can move them straight into the oven from the freezer. Add 5 to 6 minutes onto baking time.\n7 Cool and serve, or store. Let the hand pies cool before serving. Once cooled, store leftover hand pies an airtight container in the fridge. They will keep for a few days.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nCherry Ice Cream with Chocolate Chips Recipe\nYield: Makes about one quart\nYou can also try making this ice cream with yogurt instead of cream. Heat the cherries, sugar, salt, and milk first. Then let cool. Add 1 3/4 cup of full-fat yogurt and pur\xc3\xa9e. Everything else is the same except no need to add lemon juice.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups pitted ripe sweet cherries (from about 3/4 lb cherries)\n3/4 cup milk\n1 3/4 cups cream\n1/2 cup sugar\n1 pinch salt\n1 teaspoon lemon juice\n2 Tbsp Amaretto, cherry liqueur, or rum (optional)\n4 ounces bittersweet chocolate, chopped fine, keep in freezer until used\nMETHOD\n1 Heat cherries, milk, 1 cup cream, sugar, salt, then pur\xc3\xa9e: Put cherries, milk, one cup of the cream, sugar, and salt into a medium saucepan. Heat on medium heat until the mixture is steamy, then lower the heat to warm and just let sit for about 15 minutes.\nRemove from heat. Pour mixture into a blender, or use an immersion blender, and carefully pur\xc3\xa9e.\n(Careful because you are dealing with a hot liquid. Make sure you hold the cap down on the top of the blender while pur\xc3\xa9eing.)\n2 Stir in remaining cream and chill: Put mixture into a large bowl. Stir in the remaining 3/4 cup of cream.\nChill for several hours in the refrigerator until completely cold. (Can also place bowl over an ice bath, to speed up the cooling process.)\n3 Stir in lemon juice and Amaretto: Before putting the mixture into your ice cream maker, stir in the lemon juice and the Amaretto or other liqueur if you are using. Note that you can skip the alcohol if you want, but the addition of it will help the ice cream from getting too icy, and the amaretto can add a nice flavor boost to the ice cream.\n4 Churn with your ice cream maker: Churn the ice cream in your ice cream maker according to the manufacturer's instructions.\n5 Fold in chocolate chips and freeze: Once the ice cream has completed churning, the ice cream should be pretty soft. Gently fold in the finely chopped chocolate.\nPut in an airtight container and place in the freezer for at least an hour, preferably several hours.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nSavory Cherry Compote Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: Makes 2 cups, enough to accompany meat dish for 4 to 6 people\nINGREDIENTS\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 tablespoons minced shallots (can sub red onion)\n2 1/2 cups pitted sweet cherries, quartered\n1 cup walnuts, chopped\n1 teaspoon minced fresh rosemary\nSalt and pepper to taste\n1/4 cup Port, red wine, kirsch, cassis, or cherry juice (or water)\n1 tablespoon honey\nSpecial equipment:\nCherry pitter\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the shallots: Heat the olive oil in a pan in a frying pan on medium heat. Add the shallots and cook them until they just begin to color on the edges, about 2-3 minutes. Stir a few times while they\xe2\x80\x99re cooking.\n2 Add the walnuts, rosemary and cherries and stir everything to combine. Turn the heat down to medium and cook until the cherries are soft, about 4-5 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add a little black pepper and taste for salt.\n3 Pour in the Port, wine, kirsch or cassis and the honey, and stir again. Boil this down slowly until the softening cherries and the liquid cook down to a syrupy texture.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nSweet Cherry Cobbler Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: 12 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the filling:\n2 1/2 pounds pitted fresh or frozen sweet cherries\n1/2 cup (70 grams) granulated sugar\n1 tablespoon lemon juice\n1 tablespoon cornstarch (use 1 1/2 tablespoons if using frozen cherries)\n1/8 teaspoon kosher salt\nFor the topping:\n2 cups (250 grams)  all-purpose flour\n2 teaspoons baking powder\n1/4 cup (35 grams) granulated sugar, plus additional for sprinkling over top\n1 tablespoon lemon zest\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n6 tablespoons (85 grams) unsalted butter cut into small pieces\n1 cup whole milk\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\nSpecial equipment:\n9x13 baking pan\nIce cream scoop, optional\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Make the filling: In a large mixing bowl, combine the whole pitted cherries, sugar, lemon juice, cornstarch, and salt, and stir to coat. Spread the cherries into a 9x13 inch baking dish and set aside.\nIf you are using frozen cherries, you can put the dish in the preheating oven to defrost them a bit while you make the cobbler topping.\n3 Make the topping: In a medium mixing bowl, combine the flour, baking powder, sugar, lemon zest, and salt and whisk with a fork. Using your hands or a pastry blender, work the butter into the dry mixture until it becomes coarse, sandy, and well incorporated.\nWhisk the milk and vanilla together in a measuring cup, and using a fork, work the liquid into the dry mixture until you get a thick batter--it should resemble something between biscuit dough and pancake batter.\n   4 Top the cobbler: Using a levered ice cream scoop or a large spoon, drop large scoops of the batter on top of the cherries. Make about 9 mounds of batter over the top of the cherries; they won\xe2\x80\x99t completely cover the cherries but that\xe2\x80\x99s okay. As it bakes, the dough will puff and spread out. Sprinkle about 2 tablespoons of sugar over the top of the batter.\n5 Bake the cobbler: Bake the cobbler in the preheated oven for about 40 minutes, or until the topping is golden brown and the cherry juices are bubbling throughout. (If you are using frozen fruit, expect to bake an additional 15 minutes).\n6 Serve: Serve the cobbler warm with vanilla ice cream. This cobbler is best the day it is made, but leftover servings can be reheated in the microwave for about 1 minute. Store any leftover cobbler in the pan covered with plastic or in an airtight container in the refrigerator.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nCherry Frozen Yogurt Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesChill and Churn time: 1 hour, 30 minutesYield: Makes a little more than 1 quart\nA cherry pitter comes in handy when making dishes with fresh cherries. You can also use a paring knife to cut out the pit.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cups pitted fresh or frozen cherries\n2 Tbsp lemon juice\n3/4 cup sugar (more or less depending on how sweet the cherries and how sweet you want your frozen yogurt to be)\n1/4 cup whole milk (can substitute half-and-half or cream for creamier version)\n1 1/2 cups full fat yogurt (if you are using non or low-fat yogurt, add 2 Tbsp heavy cream)\n2 Tbsp almond liqueuer such as Amaretto (optional)\nSpecial equipment:\nCherry pitter\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the cherries with lemon juice and sugar: Place the pitted cherries, lemon juice, and sugar in a medium saucepan and bring to a simmer, stirring until the sugar is completely dissolved.\nWhile the mixture is heating, use a potato masher to mash up the berries in the pot which will release some of their moisture.\nWhen all of the sugar has dissolved, remove from heat and let cool for 10 minutes.\n2 Place the cherry mixture in a blender and pulse until smooth.\n3 Make and chill yogurt base: Mix cherry pur\xc3\xa9e, milk, and yogurt together in a bowl. Chill in the refrigerator for at least an hour; the longer the mixture chills the better (can chill overnight).\n4 Process in ice cream maker: Right before processing in an ice cream maker, add the almond liqueur if using. The alcohol in the liqueur will help keep the frozen yogurt smooth, but it is not necessary.\nProcess the mixture in your ice cream maker for 25 minutes.\nYou can eat it right away (it will be rather soft) or put it in the freezer for a few hours to harden up a bit.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nApricot Cherry Galette Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 1 hourDough chilling time: 1 hourYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\nCrust:\n1 cup (130 g) all purpose flour\n1 teaspoon sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/2 teaspoon crushed fennel seeds\n4 ounces butter (1 stick, 8 Tbsp, 112 g), cut into cubes\n1/4 cup (57 ml) sour cream\n1 egg, beaten, for egg wash\n1 teaspoon cream for egg wash\nCoarse sugar for sprinkling\nFilling:\n1 pound apricots (about 12 apricots, 450 g), pitted and quartered, skin on, recommend Blenheims\n8 pitted cherries, sliced in half\n1/4 cup (50 g) sugar\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1 teaspoon minute tapioca for thickening (can sub same amount of cornstarch)\n1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the dough: To make the dough, whisk together the flour, sugar, salt, and fennel seeds in a large bowl. Add the butter and work the butter into the flour with your (clean) hands until the mixture resembles crumbs and no piece of butter is bigger than a pea.\nMake a well in the center and add the sour cream. Use a fork to work the flour into sour cream.\nForm the dough into a ball and flatten into a disk. Refrigerate for 1 hour before rolling out.\n2 Toss apricots with sugar, lemon zest, tapioca, vanilla: Put the apricots and cherries into separate bowls. In the bowl with the apricots add the sugar, lemon zest, minute tapioca, and vanilla extract.
