Gently toss to combine.\n3 Roll out the dough: Roll out the dough and transfer to a parchment lined baking sheet.\n4 Arranged apricots and cherries on rolled out dough: Arrange the apricot quarters in a circular pattern in the center of the rolled out pastry dough, leaving a border of 2 1/2 inches from the edge. Dot with cherry halves.\n5 Fold dough edges over: Fold up the edges of the dough round over the outer edge of the fruit.\nIf at this point the dough has become sticky, put chill the pastry for 10 minutes before proceeding.\n6 Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F (190\xc2\xb0C).\n7 Brush egg wash on crust edges, sprinkle with coarse sugar: Whisk together the beaten egg and the cream for the egg wash. Gently apply the egg wash with a pastry brush to outer edge of the crust (note you will only use a little bit of the egg wash). Sprinkle with a little coarse sugar.\n8 Bake: Bake for 40 to 45 minutes, tenting with foil halfway through the baking process if the crust is getting too browned. The galette is done when the filling is bubbly and thickened, and the crust is nicely browned.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nCherry Almond Granola with Vanilla Crumbles Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: 6 cups granola and crumbles\nThe vanilla crumbles are an adaptation of Milk Crumbs developed by Christina Tosi of Momofuko Milk Bar in New York City. The original recipe is in her cookbook.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the vanilla crumbles (makes about 1 cup of crumbles):\n6 tablespoons instant nonfat dry milk (such as Carnation)\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour\n2 tablespoons sugar\n2 tablespoons cornstarch\n1/8 teaspoon salt\n3 tablespoons melted butter\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract, or the 1 vanilla bean, seeded and scraped\nFor the granola:\n3 cups old-fashioned rolled oats, divided\n3 tablespoons oil\n2 tablespoons maple syrup\n1/3 cup brown sugar\n1 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1 teaspoon almond extract\n1/2 teaspoon cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 cup slivered almonds\n3/4 cup dried cherries\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the oven to 250\xc2\xb0F.\n2 Mix the crumbles: Whisk together dry ingredients\xe2\x80\x94the powdered milk through salt\xe2\x80\x94in a bowl. If using vanilla bean add the scraped seeds to the dry ingredients. If using vanilla extract add it to the melted butter.\nSlowly pour the butter over the dry ingredients while tossing with a fork until it forms clumps and all the dry ingredients have been incorporated. It will look like sandy gravel. Your largest pieces should be no larger than the size of a pea.\n3 Bake the crumbles: Scatter the crumbles evenly on a parchment-lined cookie sheet and bake at for 25 minutes until they are dry, but still pale in color. Cool completely on the cookie sheet.\nStore in an airtight container for up to one week, or cool and use stir into granola.\n4 Increase the oven temperature to 325\xc2\xb0F.\n5 Mix the granola: Combine oil, syrup, sugar, extracts, cinnamon, and salt in a medium sized bowl. Stir in oats and almonds making sure they are well coated. (Reserve the dried cherries for adding later.)\n6 Bake the granola: Spread mixture evenly onto a parchment-lined baking sheet. Bake in the oven for 10 min. Stir and bake for 10 more minutes. Stir and bake for 5 to 7 minutes more. The granola should be dry and golden. Remove from oven. Let cool completely.\n7 Finish and store: Once the granola is cool, stir in cherries and vanilla crumbles. Store in an airtight container at room temp for 2 weeks. (Alternatively, store the vanilla crumbles separately at room temperature, covered, for up to two weeks, and the granola will keep for 1 month.)\nServe over your favorite yogurt with sliced bananas and a drizzle of honey.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nGrilled Pork Chops with Cherry Salsa Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIf your cherries are juicy, the salsa will be juicy too. If you want the salsa less juicy, put the finished salsa into a fine-meshed strainer and strain off some of the excess juice.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup chopped red onion\n2 tablespoons lemon juice\n1 1/2 pounds cherries, about 4 cups\n4 pork chops, about 3/4-inch thick\nSalt\nExtra virgin olive oil\n2 Tbsp chopped fresh basil\n1 tablespoon balsamic vinegar\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 heaping teaspoon sugar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Mix onion with lemon juice: Mix the chopped onion with the lemon juice in a small bowl and set aside. The lemon juice will help take the edge off the onions.\n2 Coat the pork chops in olive oil and sprinkle salt over them. Set aside at room temperature.\n3 Pit and de-stem the cherries. A cherry pitter is magical for this task, but if you don't have one, use a small knife. Double check for stray pits, they always seem to find their way into dishes that call for fresh cherries.\n4 Process cherries, onions, basil for salsa: Put the cherries, onions and chopped basil into a food processor. Pulse a few times until you have a chunky salsa, with differing textures of cherry. Alternately, you can chop everything by hand.\n5 Add balsamic vinegar, salt, sugar to salsa: Mix in the balsamic vinegar, the 1/2 teaspoon salt and sugar. Add more of any of these ingredients to taste. Set aside at room temperature. You can make this salsa up to 8 hours in advance.\n6 Grill pork chops: Prepare your grill for high direct heat. Grill the pork chops over high heat with the grill cover closed for 3 minutes. Turn them 45 degrees on the same side to get a pretty cross-hatch pattern, then close the grill cover and cook another 3 minutes.\nTurn the pork chops over, but this time keep the grill cover open and cook for a final 2-3 minutes. Allow to rest for 5-10 minutes before serving.\nServe the pork chops with the cherry salsa.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nPork Chops with Cherry Pan Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the pork chops:\n1 tablespoon vegetable oil\n4 bone-in center-cut pork chops, about 3/4-inch-thick and 8 to 9 ounces each\n2 teaspoons kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/2 teaspoon garlic powder\nFor the herb-cherry pan sauce:\n2 cups pitted halved sweet cherries (fresh or frozen)\n1 teaspoon chopped fresh thyme leaves or 1/2 teaspoon dried\n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup tawny Port wine\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Season the pork chops: Sprinkle the pork chops on both sides with the salt, pepper, and garlic powder.\n2 Cook the pork chops: Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium to medium-high heat.\nAdd the pork chops two at a time, so as to not crowd the pan, and cook until browned on the first side, 4 to 5 minutes. Flip pork chops over and cook on other side for 3 to 4 minutes more.\nTransfer to a tray or platter and cover with foil to keep warm. (You can also put them in a low oven if you wish.) Repeat with the remaining pork chops, adding more oil to the pan if dry.\n3 Make the herb-cherry pan sauce: Add the cherries, thyme, and salt to the pan and cook so they start to release their juices and soften, scraping up the stuck-on bits on the bottom of the pan, 3 to 4 minutes.\nAdd the Port and let simmer until reduced by about half, 10 to 12 minutes. Stir in the butter until emulsified and the sauce is nice and glossy. Taste and adjust with more salt to taste.\n4 Serve: Serve the pork chops with the sauce on the side for diners to spoon on their plates or over their chops. Enjoy!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nTuscan Chicken Pasta Skillet Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 25 minutesMarinating time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the marinade:\n1/4 cup olive oil\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/2 teaspoon dried Italian seasoning\nFor the dinner:\n1 1/2 pounds boneless skinless chicken breasts\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n12 ounces cherry tomatoes (about 2 cups), halved\n1 tablespoon minced garlic\n8 ounces spaghetti\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup quartered marinated artichokes hearts, drained\n1/3 cup Kalamata olives, pitted and sliced\n1/4 cup freshly grated parmesan cheese\n6 basil leaves, thinly sliced\n2 teaspoons chopped fresh parsley (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: In a small bowl, combine 1/4 cup olive oil, 1 teaspoon salt, 1/2 teaspoon pepper, and Italian seasoning. Cut each chicken breast lengthwise to create 4 long, thin pieces. Place chicken in a shallow dish. Pour marinade over the chicken, turn to evenly coat. Let sit for 15 minutes before cooking.\n2 Cook the chicken: Heat a large high-sided skillet or saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat. Add 2 tablespoons of olive oil. Once the oil is hot, add the chicken. Cook until the chicken is golden brown and fully cooked, about 6 to 8 minutes per side.\nTransfer chicken to a cutting board to rest while cooking the pasta.\n3 Cook the pasta: Add tomatoes, garlic, spaghetti, 4 cups water, and 1/2 teaspoon salt to the skillet. Bring to a boil over high heat. Cook and stir frequently, until the pasta is tender and water has mostly evaporated\xe2\x80\x94about 9 to 11 minutes. You want to have a small amount of water in the pan to create a light sauce.\nAdd more water if needed, 1/2 cup at a time for a softer pasta. Turn off the heat.  \n4 Finish and toss: Cut the chicken into 1/4-inch thick slices. Add the artichoke hearts, olives, Parmesan cheese, sliced chicken, and basil. Toss to combine. If you'd like a thicker sauce, you can add 1 or 2 tablespoons of butter. Taste and season with more salt and pepper as desired.\n5 Serve: Garnish pasta with parsley, then divide among plates and serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nItalian Skillet Chicken with Spinach, Tomatoes, and Onions Recipe\nPrep time: 12 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the marinade\n1 1/2 pounds boneless skinless chicken tenders, tenderloin, or thinly sliced chicken breasts\n1 tablespoon dried oregano\n2 1/2 teaspoons dried thyme\n1 1/2 teaspoons Kosher salt\n1 teaspoon dried basil\n1 teaspoon freshly ground pepper\nZest from 1 lemon\n3 tablespoons lemon juice, from about 1 lemon\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nFor the vegetables\n2 teaspoons olive oil\n1 pint cherry tomatoes\n1 medium red onion\n2 large handfuls spinach, about 2 packed cups\n1 teaspoon capers\n1 tablespoon butter\nCrusty bread, to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Label the bag: Use a sharpie to write the date and the title of the recipe on a gallon-sized zip top bag so you can easily find it on SimplyRecipes.com when you want to cook it. Alternatively, write the cooking instructions on the bag.\n2 Combine the ingredients: Roll down the opening of the bag a little just so you don\xe2\x80\x99t accidently get raw chicken juices on the outside of the zip top. Add the chicken, spices, zest,  lemon juice, garlic and olive oil.\nRemove as much air as possible and seal the bag. Smoosh the chicken around so it\xe2\x80\x99s coated in the marinade.\n3 Lay the chicken flat in the freezer and freeze for up to 6 months.\nAlternatively, you could skip the freezer and let it marinade in the fridge for a couple of hours and up to two days, then cook it according to the directions below.\n4 Thaw the chicken before cooking: Take the chicken out of the freezer in the morning before you go to work, and it will be ready to cook by the end of the day.\n5 Prepare the onion: Peel and trim the stem ends of the onion, but leave the stem intact so it can keep the onion layers together. Slice the onion in half. Then slice each half into 5 wedges leaving a little stem with each one.\n6 Cook the chicken: Set a large skillet over medium heat add 2 teaspoons of olive oil. Once the oil shimmers, add chicken and any marinade in the bag. If any chicken is folded up, unfolded it so it lays flat in the pan. Cook the chicken for 2 minutes, then flip it.\n7 Add the vegetables: Add the onion wedges, tomatoes, and capers. Cover with a lid. Let everything simmer together for 12 to 15 minutes. The tomatoes should be soft, and the onions dull in color.\n8 Check the chicken: Check the chicken to see if it\xe2\x80\x99s cooked through by cutting a piece open. If the juices run clear, and you don\xe2\x80\x99t see any pink the chicken is ready. Use a fork to remove the chicken to a plate and tent with foil.\n9 Finish the sauce: Turn the heat up to medium high. Add 1 tablespoon butter to the sauce. Stir it in and let the sauce reduce uncovered for about 2 minutes. Add the spinach stir to coat a couple of times until the spinach has wilted.\n10 To serve: Nestle the chicken back into the pan, and season to taste with salt and pepper.\nBring the skillet to the table. Spoon up chicken, vegetables and sauces into shallow bowls or plates. Serve with crusty bread to sop up the sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nTomato Galette With Parmesan Whole Wheat Crust Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 30 minutesChilling time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nNote: While this pie crust comes together easily in the food processor, using cornmeal and whole wheat flour can be a bit challenging if you're a beginner. If you've never made a pie crust before, you might want to start with a pie crust like this recipe instead to get a feel for the process. (A recipe for a single pie crust can be substituted for this one.)\nUse only the best, freshest, ripest cherry tomatoes for this recipe. It won't be nearly as good with out-of-season grocery store tomatoes. A mix of colors makes the tart especially pretty.\nDon't forget to salt the tomatoes before making the galette so they release some of their juices. Not only does this help keep the crust from getting soggy, but it also adds a lot of flavor to the tomatoes themselves.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the whole wheat crust:\n1 cup (135g) whole wheat flour\n1 cup (120g) all-purpose flour\n1/3 cup (50g) coarse cornmeal\n1/4 cup (20g) shredded Parmesan\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n8 ounces (2 sticks) cold unsalted butter, cut into cubes\n1/2 cup ice water, more as needed\nFor the tomato filling:\n4 cups (about 1 3/4 pounds) cherry tomatoes, halved\nSalt (for the tomatoes)\n1/2 cup (40g) shredded Parmesan\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh thyme leaves\n1 large egg, well beaten with 1 tablespoon water\n1 tablespoon chopped parsley, to garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Chill the crust ingredients: In a bowl, combine the whole-wheat flour, all-purpose flour, cornmeal, Parmesan and salt. Add the butter pieces and toss with your hands to separate and coat them with flour. Place the bowl in the freezer for 30 minutes.\n2 Make the dough: Pour the flour and butter mixture into the bowl of a food processor. Process in 4 to 5 long pulses, or until the butter is cut into small pieces (a few larger pieces are okay.)\nOpen the top of the machine and drizzle the ice water over the flour and butter. Close and pulse in a series of short bursts, until the mixture looks like wet sandy gravel.\nPress a small amount of the dough together in your hand. It should form a clump that holds together firmly and without cracking at the edges. If it feels crumbly or dry, put it back in the food processor, sprinkle the mixture with an additional tablespoon or two of the ice water, and pulse briefly to mix.\nTo mix by hand: Follow step one, and use a pastry cutter or wire whisk to break up the butter into small pieces. Drizzle the ice water over the mixture and toss it together with your hands as if you were tossing a salad. If it still feels dry, add water, one tablespoon at a time. When the dough starts to come together, shape it as directed in the next step.\n3 Shape and chill the dough: Empty the dough onto the countertop. Quickly press the dough together to form a disk about an inch or so thick. Resist the temptation to knead or squish the dough. The idea is to firmly compress all the little bits of dough together into a disk shape without overworking the dough.\nWrap the dough in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes.\n4 Salt the tomatoes: Line a baking sheet with paper towels. Spread the tomatoes on the baking sheet and sprinkle evenly with about a teaspoon of salt. (This might seem like too much at first, but the saltiness mellows out perfectly once the tomatoes have rested for a little while.)\nLet stand while the dough chills (about 30 minutes). The tomatoes will start to release their juices as they sit. Before assembling the galette, blot the tomatoes dry with paper towels until much of the liquid is absorbed.\n5 Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xbaF. Line a baking sheet with parchment.\n6 Roll and fill the galette: On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough into a 15-inch circle. Transfer to the baking sheet (it will drape over the sides, but that\xe2\x80\x99s okay).\nSprinkle the Parmesan for the filling in a rough 11-inch circle over the bottom of the dough, leaving the edges clear. Arrange two-thirds of the tomatoes, cut-side up, over the cheese (reserve the remaining third). Sprinkle with the thyme.\nFold the edges over the tomatoes, pleating as necessary. Brush the edges of the crust with beaten egg.\n7 Bake the galette: Bake for 30 minutes, or until the crust is golden. Scatter the reserved tomatoes over the top of the galette and sprinkle with parsley. Serve warm or at room temperature.\nThis galette is best served the day it is made. Leftovers will keep for several days, refrigerated.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Save It Print\nMake-Ahead Frittata Squares with Spinach, Tomatoes, and Feta Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 9 squares\nINGREDIENTS\nButter (for the baking dish)\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1 pint cherry tomatoes\n1 bunch scallions, thinly sliced\n5 ounces (about 3 1/2 packed cups) baby spinach leaves\n1/2 cup whole milk\n1/2 cup sour cream\n12 large eggs\n3/4 teaspoon salt, divided\n1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1 cup (about 5 ounces) crumbled feta cheese\n3 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley\nSpecial equipment:\n2-quart glass or ceramic baking dish (8x8 square or 7x11 rectangular)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350F. Butter a 2-quart baking dish.\n2 Cook the vegetables: In a large skillet over medium heat, heat the olive oil. Add the tomatoes and cook, stirring often, for 2 minutes, or until just starting to soften but not yet falling apart. Transfer to a separate dish and set aside.\nAdd the the scallions to the pan and cook for about 1 minute, or until softened. Stir in the spinach and 1/4 teaspoon of salt. Cook, stirring often, until the spinach wilts. Remove the pan from the heat and cool for a few minutes.\nStir in the crumbled feta cheese.\n3 Whisk egg mixture: In a large bowl, gradually whisk the milk into the sour cream until smooth. Whisk in the eggs, 1/2 teaspoon of salt and pepper.\n5 Assemble and bake the frittata: Transfer the spinach filling from the pan into the baking dish and pour the egg mixture over top. Scatter the tomatoes on top of the eggs so they peek out, and sprinkle with the parsley.\nBake for 40 to 45 minutes, or until the eggs are set. You can check with a paring knife inserted in the middle; the eggs should be set and no longer be runny.\n6 Serve: Cool the frittata for at least 10 minutes, and cut into 9 servings. Store leftovers in the refrigerator for up to a week, and reheat in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBaked Chicken with Cherry Tomatoes and Garlic Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 4 to 6\nThis dish produces a lot of flavorful liquid. You can use it for dipping crusty toasted bread. Or, you can remove the chicken, tomatoes, and garlic to a serving dish and pour the strained liquid into a small saucepan and boil until reduced to a thicker sauce. You can pour this sauce back over the chicken or pour it over rice or pasta.\nThe recipe calls for bone-in thighs. If you make it with boneless thighs you may need to reduce the cooking time by a few minutes.\nThe recipe calls for skin-on thighs. If you make it with skinless thighs, try to cover the thighs as much as you can with the tomatoes, to help prevent the meat from drying out. If you make it with skinless breasts, do the same, and reduce the cooking time to 25 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 pounds (900 g) bone-in, skin-on chicken thighs, trimmed of excess fat\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n2 cups of cherry tomatoes (a heaping basket or 25 to 30 cherry tomatoes)\n6 whole cloves garlic, peeled\n1 1/2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n1 1/2 teaspoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 sprigs fresh rosemary (or 1/2 teaspoon dry rosemary)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Arrange chicken thighs in casserole dish, sprinkle with salt: Place chicken thighs in a baking dish that allows for a little room between the thighs. Sprinkle both sides of the chicken thighs with salt.\n2 Preheat oven to 375\xc2\xb0F (190\xc2\xb0C).\n3 Prep cherry tomatoes with garlic, vinegar, oil: Cut the cherry tomatoes in half. Place in a bowl with the whole garlic cloves. Sprinkle with balsamic vinegar and olive oil.\n4 Place tomatoes, garlic, rosemary around chicken: Pour the cherry tomatoes over the chicken pieces and arrange so that they are squeezed around the chicken pieces. You want the chicken skins to be exposed so they brown in the oven. Lay sprigs of rosemary over the tomatoes.\n(If you are using dry rosemary instead of fresh sprigs, just mix it in with the tomatoes.)\n5 Bake: Bake, uncovered for 45 minutes, until the chicken is well browned on the top and cooked through. Remove from oven and cool for 5 minutes. Skim the excess chicken fat with a ladle.\nServe with toasted crusty bread, buttered noodles, or rice. (Skip for paleo option, skip bread and noodles for gluten-free versions.)\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nTomato Galette With Parmesan Whole Wheat Crust Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 30 minutesChilling time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nNote: While this pie crust comes together easily in the food processor, using cornmeal and whole wheat flour can be a bit challenging if you're a beginner. If you've never made a pie crust before, you might want to start with a pie crust like this recipe instead to get a feel for the process. (A recipe for a single pie crust can be substituted for this one.)\nUse only the best, freshest, ripest cherry tomatoes for this recipe. It won't be nearly as good with out-of-season grocery store tomatoes. A mix of colors makes the tart especially pretty.\nDon't forget to salt the tomatoes before making the galette so they release some of their juices. Not only does this help keep the crust from getting soggy, but it also adds a lot of flavor to the tomatoes themselves.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the whole wheat crust:\n1 cup (135g) whole wheat flour\n1 cup (120g) all-purpose flour\n1/3 cup (50g) coarse cornmeal\n1/4 cup (20g) shredded Parmesan\n3/4 teaspoon salt\n8 ounces (2 sticks) cold unsalted butter, cut into cubes\n1/2 cup ice water, more as needed\nFor the tomato filling:\n4 cups (about 1 3/4 pounds) cherry tomatoes, halved\nSalt (for the tomatoes)\n1/2 cup (40g) shredded Parmesan\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh thyme leaves\n1 large egg, well beaten with 1 tablespoon water\n1 tablespoon chopped parsley, to garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Chill the crust ingredients: In a bowl, combine the whole-wheat flour, all-purpose flour, cornmeal, Parmesan and salt. Add the butter pieces and toss with your hands to separate and coat them with flour. Place the bowl in the freezer for 30 minutes.\n2 Make the dough: Pour the flour and butter mixture into the bowl of a food processor. Process in 4 to 5 long pulses, or until the butter is cut into small pieces (a few larger pieces are okay.)\nOpen the top of the machine and drizzle the ice water over the flour and butter. Close and pulse in a series of short bursts, until the mixture looks like wet sandy gravel.\nPress a small amount of the dough together in your hand. It should form a clump that holds together firmly and without cracking at the edges. If it feels crumbly or dry, put it back in the food processor, sprinkle the mixture with an additional tablespoon or two of the ice water, and pulse briefly to mix.\nTo mix by hand: Follow step one, and use a pastry cutter or wire whisk to break up the butter into small pieces. Drizzle the ice water over the mixture and toss it together with your hands as if you were tossing a salad. If it still feels dry, add water, one tablespoon at a time. When the dough starts to come together, shape it as directed in the next step.\n3 Shape and chill the dough: Empty the dough onto the countertop. Quickly press the dough together to form a disk about an inch or so thick. Resist the temptation to knead or squish the dough. The idea is to firmly compress all the little bits of dough together into a disk shape without overworking the dough.\nWrap the dough in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes.\n4 Salt the tomatoes: Line a baking sheet with paper towels. Spread the tomatoes on the baking sheet and sprinkle evenly with about a teaspoon of salt. (This might seem like too much at first, but the saltiness mellows out perfectly once the tomatoes have rested for a little while.)\nLet stand while the dough chills (about 30 minutes). The tomatoes will start to release their juices as they sit. Before assembling the galette, blot the tomatoes dry with paper towels until much of the liquid is absorbed.\n5 Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xbaF. Line a baking sheet with parchment.\n6 Roll and fill the galette: On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough into a 15-inch circle. Transfer to the baking sheet (it will drape over the sides, but that\xe2\x80\x99s okay).\nSprinkle the Parmesan for the filling in a rough 11-inch circle over the bottom of the dough, leaving the edges clear. Arrange two-thirds of the tomatoes, cut-side up, over the cheese (reserve the remaining third). Sprinkle with the thyme.\nFold the edges over the tomatoes, pleating as necessary. Brush the edges of the crust with beaten egg.\n7 Bake the galette: Bake for 30 minutes, or until the crust is golden. Scatter the reserved tomatoes over the top of the galette and sprinkle with parsley. Serve warm or at room temperature.\nThis galette is best served the day it is made. Leftovers will keep for several days, refrigerated.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nSpaghetti with Tomatoes, Bacon, and Eggs Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 4\nWhile the water for the pasta and the eggs heats up, cook the bacon, garlic, and tomatoes. Then poach the eggs while the pasta is cooking. It all comes together in about 20 minutes.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons white vinegar, for poaching the eggs\n12 ounces (3/4 box) spaghetti\n6 slices (about 5 ounces) thick cut bacon, cut into 1/2-inch dice\n2 cloves garlic, thinly sliced\n7 to 8 (12 ounces) small (1 1/2-inch) tomatoes, quartered\n4 large eggs\n1/2 cup freshly grated Parmesan\n1/2 cup packed basil leaves, torn into pieces\nFreshly ground black pepper, to taste\nOlive oil, for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Bring two pans of water to a boil: For the pasta, bring a large pot of salted water to a boil (at least 4 quarts of water and 2 tablespoons of salt). For the eggs, fill a wide saucepan with 2 inches of salted water and bring to a boil. Add the vinegar to the saucepan for the eggs.\n2 Cook the bacon, garlic, and tomatoes while the water heats: In a large (12-inch) skillet over medium-high heat, cook the bacon until browned. Transfer to plate.\nAdd the garlic and the tomatoes, and cook, stirring often, for 2 minutes, or just until the garlic turns pale golden and the tomatoes soften slightly. Remove the pan from the heat.\n3 Cook the spaghetti: Add the spaghetti to the large pot of boiling water, and cook for 8 to 9 minutes, or until al dente. Remove 1 cup of the pasta water with a measuring cup.\n4 Poach the eggs while the pasta cooks: Line a tray or plate with a paper towel. Adjust the heat under the saucepan so that the poaching water barely simmers.\nCrack 1 egg into a small bowl or cup and, holding the rim as close to the surface of the water as possible, drop the egg into the water.\nRapidly repeat with the remaining eggs.\nDrag a wooden spoon around the edge of the pot to stir the water and gently release the eggs from the bottom.\nAfter 2 minutes, lift 1 egg from the water with a slotted spoon and test for doneness by pressing on the egg. The white should feel firm and the yolk should still be soft. Return to the water if necessary to complete the cooking. With a slotted spoon, transfer the eggs to the paper towel lined plate to drain the water.\n5 Assemble the pasta: Set the skillet with the garlic and tomatoes back over low heat. With tongs, add the cooked spaghetti. Add the cooked bacon, Parmesan, basil, salt, and pepper and toss together. If the spaghetti looks dry, add some of the reserved pasta water a few tablespoons at a time.\n6 To serve: Divide the spaghetti among 4 plates or shallow bowls and top each with a poached egg. Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle with freshly ground pepper, if you like.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nNopalitos Cactus Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 6\nIf using canned nopalitos, just drain them and mix them in with the tomatoes and the rest of the ingredients. No need to cook them as they are already cooked.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound (450 g) fresh chopped nopalitos\n1 pound cherry tomatoes, quartered (about 3 cups)\n1 cup chopped red radishes\n1 cup finely chopped red onion\n3 tablespoons lime juice\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1/2 cup chopped cilantro\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch and rinse nopalitos: Bring a medium pot of salted water to a boil. Add the nopalitos, return to a rolling boil and cook for 1 minute. Strain through a fine mesh sieve. Rinse with water for 1 minute.\n2 Toss with remaining ingredients: Place rinsed and drained nopalitos in a bowl with the chopped tomatoes, radishes, and onion. Toss with lime juice, olive oil, salt, and pepper. Fold in cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. b"Save It Print\nCherry Tomato Orzo Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 8-10 as a side\nINGREDIENTS\n8 ounces orzo pasta\nSalt\n1 pint red cherry tomatoes, sliced in half\n1 pint yellow cherry tomatoes, sliced in half\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n8 ounces feta cheese, crumbled\n1 large cucumber, peeled and chopped\n2 green onions, thinly sliced\n2 Tbsp minced fresh oregano\nJuice of a lemon\nBlack pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Cook orzo pasta in salted water: Bring a large pot of well salted water to a rolling boil. Add the orzo, stirring it so that it doesn't stick to the bottom of the pan. Cook, uncovered, at a high boil until al dente, cooked through but still a bit firm.\nDrain the pasta (it helps to use a fine mesh sieve for this as the small orzo might pass through holes in a colander), and rinse with cold water to stop the pasta from cooking further.\n2 Toss pasta with olive oil, tomatoes, feta, cucumber, green onions, oregano, lemon juice, pepper: Toss the pasta with the olive oil in a large bowl. At this point you can make ahead and chill until you are ready to serve (or transport to a party).\nToss with the rest of the ingredients, the tomatoes, feta cheese, cucumber, green onions, oregano, lemon juice, and black pepper. The feta is salty so you shouldn't need to add more salt.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. b"Save It Print\nShrimp, Arugula, White Bean, Cherry Tomato Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIt always helps to brine the shrimp before cooking. An extra step, but worth it if you have the time!\nTo brine the shrimp, mix together 4 cups water, 1/4 cup kosher salt (or 3 Tbsp table or sea salt), 1/4 cup white sugar until the salt and sugar have dissolved. Add one cup of ice and the shrimp. After 30 minutes (time it!) remove the shrimp and give them a quick rinse.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound 16-20 count shelled and deveined shrimp\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n2 15-ounce cans cannellini white beans, rinsed and drained\n1 cup cherry tomatoes, halved or quartered\n1/2 cup finely diced red onion\n3/4 teaspoon grated lemon zest\n3 handfuls baby arugula leaves\nDressing:\n3 tablespoons red wine vinegar\n1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil\n2 cloves minced garlic\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the shrimp: Heat a large cast iron skillet or griddle on high heat. Add 2 Tbsp of olive oil to coat the pan. When the oil is hot, working in batches of half of the shrimp at a time, add the shrimp and saut\xc3\xa9 a minute on each side to sear. (You can also grill the shrimp if you prefer.)\nWhen the shrimp are barely cooked through, remove from the pan and set aside to cool. (The shrimp will continue to cook for a little bit after you remove them from the pan, and you don't want overcooked rubbery shrimp.)\n2 Assemble the salad: Put the drained beans, cut cherry tomatoes, diced onion, lemon zest, and arugula leaves into a large bowl. Fold in the shrimp.\n3 Make the dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together the red wine vinegar, olive oil, garlic, salt and pepper.\nGently fold the dressing into the salad and serve!\nHello! b'Save It Print\nWhite Bean and Cherry Tomato Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8\nINGREDIENTS\n1 15-ounce cans of white beans, such as Great Northern or cannellini beans, drained and rinsed\n1 pint cherry or plum tomatoes, halved\n1/3 cup coarsely chopped parsley\nDressing ingredients:\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n3 cloves garlic, peeled and smashed\n1 3-inch sprig of fresh rosemary\n3 anchovy fillets, coarsely chopped (omit for vegetarian option)\n1/4 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese\n3/4 teaspoon Kosher salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground pepper\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\n1/4 cup of lemon juice\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Infuse rosemary in olive oil: Place the garlic and sprig of rosemary in the olive oil in a small saucepan. Heat the oil on medium until the rosemary begins to sizzle.\nRemove the pan from the heat and let sit for 20 minutes, allowing the rosemary and garlic to infuse in the oil.\n2 Make the dressing: Remove rosemary sprig from the oil, discard. Remove the garlic from the oil, reserving the oil.\nAdd the garlic, anchovies (omit for vegetarian option), Parmesan cheese, salt, pepper, lemon zest, and lemon juice to a food processor or mini chopper. Pulse until smooth.\n3 Mix dressing with beans: In a medium bowl, gently mix the garlic Parmesan lemon mixture in with the beans until the beans are well coated.\nLet the beans sit for a few minutes so they absorb some of the dressing.\n4 Gently mix in the reserved olive oil, tomatoes, and parsley.\nHello! b'Save It Print\nAsparagus Artichoke Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: Serve 6-8 as a side dish\nThick asparagus spears are easier than thin to roast or grill without becoming too dry or over-cooked.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large shallot, sliced thin (can sub a few thin slices of red onion or some sliced spring onion)\n2-3 tablespoons lemon juice\n2 pounds thick asparagus, rinsed, tough ends broken off and discarded (or saved for stock)\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil, divided\nSalt\n1 teaspoon garlic powder\n1 pint grape or cherry tomatoes, sliced in half\n1 15-ounce jar of good quality marinated artichoke hearts, quartered or cut in half (depending on the size of the artichokes)\nMETHOD\n1 Soak the sliced shallots in the lemon juice as you get ready to make the rest of the salad.\n2 Roast or Grill the asparagus:\nTo roast the asparagus, preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. Coat the asparagus spears with 1 Tbsp of olive oil, and salt them well. Lay in a single layer in a foil-lined roasting pan, and cook for 8-10 minutes until lightly browned and fork tender.\nTo grill the asparagus, prepare your charcoal or gas grill for high direct heat. Coat the asparagus with 1 Tbsp of olive oil and sprinkle with salt. Grill them until nicely charred and fork tender, between 5 to 10 minutes.\nRemove the asparagus from the oven or grill and cut into bite-sized pieces.\n3 Put the asparagus and all the remaining ingredients into a large bowl and mix to combine. Add as much of the marinating liquid from the jarred artichokes as you like. Serve chilled or at room temperature.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nBalsamic Risotto with Tomatoes and Basil Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 35 minutesYield: Serves 3 to 4\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups of stock (I use homemade vegetable stock or Better Than Bouillon)\n1 Tbsp butter\n1/2 cup chopped shallots\n1 clove garlic, minced\n1 cup (200 g) risotto rice (arborio, carnaroli, or vialone nano)\n1/3 cup dry white wine (I recommend a New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc)\n1/2 cup grated or shredded Parmesan cheese\n1 to 2 Tbsp balsamic vinegar\nWhite pepper\n1/4 teaspoon fresh thyme or a pinch of dried thyme\n1 1/2 cups cherry tomatoes, halved\n4 basil leaves, thinly sliced\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the stock: Bring 4 cups of stock to a low simmer in a small pot. Keep the stock warm while making the risotto.\n2 Cook shallots and garlic: Melt a tablespoon of butter in a wide saucepan on medium heat. Add the chopped shallots and cook until translucent, a couple of minutes.\nAdd the minced garlic and cook until fragrant, a half minute more.\n3 Lightly brown the rice: Add the risotto rice to the pan and toss to coat with the shallots. Increase the heat to medium high and let the rice start to brown.\n4 Add the white wine: Stir in the white wine. The pan will steam up. Let the rice absorb the wine.\n5 Start adding the stock, 1/2 cup at a time: Here is the real process of making risotto. Add the stock, a half cup or ladleful at a time, slowly stirring the rice, and allowing the rice to absorb the stock for a minute or two, before adding another ladleful of stock.\nYou\'ll want to stop adding the stock when the rice is cooked through, but still a little firm to the bite, "al dente". Note that you may not need all of the stock you have heated for this recipe.\n6 Add balsamic, tomatoes, thyme with last 1/2 cup of stock: When it comes time for that last 1/2 cup of stock to add to the risotto, add it, as well as the balsamic vinegar. Balsamic vinegar can vary in its acidity and intensity. So, add 1 tablespoon to start, and add another tablespoon if you want more of the balsamic flavor.\nAdd half of the cherry tomatoes and add the thyme. Let the tomatoes soften with the cooking of the risotto in those last few minutes.\n7 Remove from heat, stir in Parm: When the risotto has reached it\'s "al dente" stage, remove it from heat. Stir in the shredded Parmesan cheese. Sprinkle with pepper.\n8 Serve: Serve with remaining halved fresh cherry tomatoes and thinly sliced basil on top.\n  Hello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nAngel Hair Pasta with Quick Cherry Tomato Sauce Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nIf you're good at multitasking, start the sauce as soon as the pasta goes into the pot so everything comes together at about the same time. If this feels stressful, cook the pasta first and then start the sauce. Either way, dinner is ready fast!\nFor a fancier presentation, if serving this at a dinner party, remove half of the tomatoes before tossing with the pasta. Plate the pasta, then top with the reserved tomatoes.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 1/2 teaspoons salt\n1 pounds angel hair pasta (capellini or capelli d\xe2\x80\x99Angelo), or another thin spaghetti\n4 tablespoons olive oil\n2 pints red and yellow cherry tomatoes\n1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper\n1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper\n2 cloves garlic, very thinly sliced\n1 cup fresh basil leaves, removed from the stems\n1 cup grated Parmesan cheese\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the pasta: Bring a large pot of water with 2 teaspoons of salt to a boil. Add the pasta and stir well until the water returns to a boil.\nCook for 3 to 4 minutes, stirring occasionally, or until the pasta is tender. With a ladle or a heat-proof liquid measuring cup, remove about 1/2 cup of the pasta cooking water and set aside.\nDrain the pasta but do not rinse it; transfer to a bowl. Sprinkle with 1 tablespoon of the oil and toss well.\n2 Prep the tomatoes: Pierce small whole tomatoes with a skewer or the tip of a paring knife. Halve the tomatoes if they\xe2\x80\x99re large.\n3 Make the sauce: In a deep skillet over medium-high heat, heat the remaining 3 tablespoons of oil. Add the cherry tomatoes \xe2\x80\x93 they will splutter \xe2\x80\x93 along with the remaining 1/2 teaspoon salt, red pepper, and black pepper.\nCook, shaking the pan, for 2 to 3 minutes, or until the tomatoes start to collapse and form juices. Add the garlic and continue cooking for 2 minutes more.\n4 Toss the pasta with the sauce: Add the pasta and 1/4 cup of the pasta water to the skillet with the tomato sauce. Toss well.\nAdd more pasta water if needed, a tablespoon at a time, to thin the mixture so the sauce coats the pasta. Add half the basil leaves and toss again.\n5 Serve: Divide the pasta among 4 to 6 large bowls. Add a few basil leaves on top of the pasta and sprinkle generously with Parmesan.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nFattoush Bread Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 10 minutesYield: 4\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the pita chips:\n2 rounds pita bread (8- to 12-inches)\nOlive oil (for toasting the pita)\nSalt and pepper, to taste\nFor the salad:\n4 Persian, pickling, or other small cucumbers, thinly sliced (or 1 English cucumber, trimmed, halved vertically, and thinly sliced)\n4 radishes, trimmed and thinly sliced\n2 large tomatoes, cored and cut into 1-inch pieces\n1/2 pint cherry tomatoes, halved\n1/4 red onion, very thinly sliced\n1/4 cup sliced scallions, white and light green parts\nFor the dressing:\nJuice of 1 lemon, or more to taste\n4 tablespoons olive oil\nLarge handful fresh mint leaves, coarsely chopped\nLarge handful fresh parsley leaves, coarsely chopped\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare pita chips: Set the oven to 375\xc2\xb0F. With kitchen shears, cut the pita round into 1-inch pieces. In a bowl, sprinkle the pita with just enough olive oil so a drop lands on each piece. Toss well. Sprinkle with salt and toss again.\n2 Toast the pita chips: Spread the pieces out on a rimmed baking sheet. It's fine if the pieces overlap or cluster together. Bake for 2 minutes, then toss the chips. Bake another 2 minutes and toss again. Remove any pieces that are starting to look crisp and golden. Continue baking another 1 to 2 minutes until all the pieces are crisp and golden. Set aside to cool.\n3 Prepare the vegetables: In a large bowl combine the cucumbers, radishes, large and cherry tomatoes, scallions, and red onion.\n4 Dress the salad just before serving: Sprinkle the lemon juice, olive oil, salt, and pepper over the vegetables and toss gently but thoroughly. Add the mint and parsley and toss again. Taste for seasoning and add more salt and pepper, if you like. Add the pita chips and toss gently to avoid crushing them. Serve immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nAngel Hair Pasta with Clams, Cherry Tomatoes, and Basil Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 2 to 3\nSave time by prepping the shallots, garlic, tomatoes, and basil while the water for the pasta is heating up.\nINGREDIENTS\n30 cherry tomatoes, sliced in half\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n4 Tbsp chopped fresh basil, divided\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 cup sliced shallots\n2 cloves minced garlic\n2 6-ounce cans chopped clams (and their juices)\n8 ounces capellini or angel hair pasta\nSalt for the pasta water\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Toss cherries with salt and basil: Place sliced cherry tomatoes in a bowl. Toss with 1/4 teaspoon of salt and 2 Tbsp of the chopped fresh basil. Set aside.\n2 Boil salted water, prep shallots and garlic: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil (4 quarts of water, 2 Tbsp salt). While the water is coming to a boil, prep the shallots and garlic and start the sauce.\n3 Make tomato clam sauce: Heat the olive oil in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan on medium heat. Add the sliced shallots and cook until translucent, stirring often. Add the garlic and cook for 30 seconds more.\nAdd the tomatoes and cook for 2 minutes. Add the chopped clams with their juices.\nReduce the heat to low and let simmer at a low temperature while the pasta is cooking in the next step.\n4 Cook the pasta: Once the salted pasta water comes to a rolling boil, add pasta and cook, uncovered at high heat until al dente, no more than 2 minutes.\nDrain the pasta, reserving 1/4 cup of the pasta water. Add the 1/4 cup of pasta water to the sauce in the saut\xc3\xa9 pan.\n5 Combine pasta and sauce: Add the pasta to the cherry tomato mixture and toss to combine. Stir in the remaining 2 Tbsp chopped fresh basil.\nServe immediately.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nFarro Salad with Green Beans, Corn, and Cherry Tomatoes Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: 6 to 8 servings as a side salad\nIf you need to save some time, cook the farro in a separate pot while you are blanching the green beans and corn kernels.\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 pound green beans, trimmed and cut into 1-inch lengths\n2 cups corn kernels, fresh or frozen\n1/2 cup pearled or semi-pearled farro\n3 tablespoons olive oil, or more to taste\n1 bunch scallions, trimmed and chopped\n1 shallot, very thinly sliced\n1/2 pint mixed yellow or red cherry tomatoes, halved or quartered if large\n2 tablespoons white wine vinegar\n2 tablespoons chopped fresh oregano, marjoram, or parsley\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Blanch the green beans: Bring a medium pot of water to a boil. Add a tablespoon of salt and the green beans.\nCook the green beans for 3 minutes or until they are bright green and barely tender. Scoop the beans out with a slotted spoon and transfer to a strainer.\nRinse the beans under cold water until they are cool. Pat dry with paper towels and set aside.\nDo not drain the water; let it come back to a boil over high heat.\n2 Prepare the corn: If using fresh corn kernels, let the pot of water used for the green beans come back to a boil, then blanch the kernels for 1 minute. Drain and rinse with cold water until cool.\nIf using frozen corn, there's no need to blanch; transfer the frozen kernels to a strainer and run under water until the corn is thawed. Spread on a plate, pat dry with paper towels, and set aside.\nDo not drain the water; let it come back to a boil over high heat.\n2 Toast the farro: Toast the farro in a dry cast iron or other heavy skillet, stirring constantly, for 5 minutes or until it smells nutty and toasted.\n3 Cook the farro: Tip the farro into the boiling water \xe2\x80\x93 the grains should sizzle when they hit the water. Let the water return to a boil.\nCook the farro, stirring occasionally, for 12 minutes, or until it is tender but still has some bite.\n2 Drain the farro: Drain the farro into a medium strainer and set the strainer back inside the saucepan. Cover the farro with a clean kitchen towel or paper towel and set the lid on top. (If you don't have a strainer that fits in your pan, follow these instructions.)\nSet aside for 10 minutes to allow the grain to steam.\n3 Season the farro: Transfer the grains to a large bowl. Sprinkle with 1 tablespoon of the olive oil. Taste for seasoning and add more salt, if you like, and pepper.\nCool briefly until no longer piping hot.\n5 Mix the salad: Add the green beans, corn, scallions, shallot, cherry tomatoes, remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil, vinegar, and fresh herbs to the farro. Toss gently.\nTaste for seasoning and add more salt, olive oil, vinegar, or herbs, if you like. This salad is best the day it's made, but leftovers make a great light lunch.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nBrussels Sprouts with Bacon and Chestnuts Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: Serves 6-8 as a side\nChestnuts are delicious, but a major pain to roast and shell (have you ever exploded chestnuts all over your kitchen? I have). Canned (jarred more like it) chestnuts actually work better in recipes than the kind you roast and peel yourself. The texture and moisture content is more consistent. So, we suggest using canned roasted chestnuts for this recipe. You can of course roast and shell your own if you prefer.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound Brussels sprouts\n1/3 pound thick-sliced bacon or slab bacon, cut into 1/4-inch pieces or batons\n1 red onion, chopped\n20-25 canned roasted chestnuts, quartered or roughly chopped\n1/4 cup chicken stock\nSalt and pepper to taste\nLemon wedges to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the Brussels sprouts: Cut the Brussels sprouts in half and slice thinly, starting at the top of the sprout and working back toward the stem. Discard the hard tip of the stem side.\n2 Cook the bacon: Cut the bacon into pieces about 1/4 inch wide and put them in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium heat.\nWhen the bacon is browned, remove with a slotted spoon and set aside.\n3 Cook the onions in bacon fat, add back the bacon:  Remove all but 1 tablespoon of the bacon fat (do not put down the drain, see how to render bacon fat). Turn up the heat to high, add the red onions. Cook until the onions begin to brown, add back the bacon.\n5 Add chestnuts, Brussels sprouts, stock: Add the chestnuts and Brussels sprouts to the saut\xc3\xa9 pan with the bacon and onions. Add the chicken stock and toss to combine. Stir in about 1 teaspoon of salt, more or less to taste. Cook over high heat for 3-4 minutes. Add pepper to taste.\nServe hot with lemon wedges. Squeeze a little lemon juice over the sprouts right before you eat them.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nBraised Red Cabbage with Chestnuts Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 8\nINGREDIENTS\n2 strips thick-cut bacon (about 3 ounces) cut crosswise into 1/4-inch strips\n1 medium onion, thinly sliced\n1 red cabbage head, about 2 pounds, quartered, tough core removed, quarters sliced into 1/4-inch thick slices\n1 large green tart apple\n1/2 cup apple cider vinegar\n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar\n6 tablespoons sugar\n1/2 teaspoon salt, more to taste\nFreshly ground pepper\n8 ounces canned or jarred roasted chestnuts (NOT water chestnuts), roughly chopped\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the bacon: Cook the bacon batons slowly in a large saut\xc3\xa9 pan (with cover) on medium low heat until most of the fat has rendered out, and the bacon is lightly browned, not crisp.\n2 Add onions: Add the sliced onions, increase the heat of the pan to medium high and cook, stirring often, until the onions have softened and lightly browned.\n3 Add cabbage, apples, vinegars, sugar: While the onions are cooking, peel the apple and cut it into 1/2-inch thick pieces. Once the onions are ready, add the sliced cabbage, chopped apple, cider vinegar, balsamic vinegar, and sugar. Carefully toss to combine. Bring to a simmer, cover the pan, lower the heat, and simmer until the cabbage is cooked through and soft, about 40 minutes.\n4 Add chestnuts: Uncover the pan. Add the chopped roasted chestnuts. Add salt and pepper to taste. Increase the heat to boil off excess moisture for a few minutes.\nServe hot.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nSaut\xc3\xa9ed Chestnuts, Onions, and Bacon Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: Serves 6 to 8 as a side\nCastanhas Salteadas com Toucinho Entremeado\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 pound thick-sliced slab bacon or pancetta, cut crosswise into 1/4-inch strips\n1 pound pearl onions, scant 1 inch in diameter\n1 pound peeled, roasted chestnuts (vacuum-packed*, jarred without sugar*, or freshly roasted)\n2 tablespoons honey\nKosher salt and freshly ground black pepper\n1 tablespoon chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley leaves, for garnish\n*Vacuum-packed or jarred are preferred over freshly roasted.\nMETHOD\n1 Cook the bacon: In a large skillet, cook the bacon over medium-low heat, stirring often, until the fat has rendered and the meaty bits start to crisp, about 12 minutes. Transfer to paper towels to drain.\n2 Blanch and peel the onions: Meanwhile, fill a bowl with ice and water and set aside. Bring a medium saucepan of water to a boil. Drop in the onions and blanch for 30 seconds. Scoop them out with a slotted spoon and plop them into the ice water. To peel the onions, snip off the tip and remove the papery outer layers. Set aside the onions.\n3 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions in bacon fat: Raise the heat under the skillet to medium, plonk in the onions, and saut\xc3\xa9 in the bacon fat, stirring occasionally, until spotted with brown and cooked through, 8 to 10 minutes.\n4 Add chestnuts, bacon, honey: Add the chestnuts, cooked bacon, and honey and toss to warm through, being careful not to break the nuts--they're fragile.\nSeason with salt and plenty of pepper and then scoop into a decorate bowl. Sprinkle with the parsley.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nChestnut and Fennel Soup Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourYield: Serves 6-8\nThe recipe works best with packaged cooked chestnuts. However, if those are not available, you can easily prepare chestnuts from scratch if you want. Cut a cross, about 1/8 inch deep and wide enough to go to the edges of one side of the chestnut, into the shells (so steam can escape), place on a baking tray cut side up, and roast for 30-35 minutes at 350\xc2\xb0F. Cool until cool enough to handle, but still warm, and peel off the shells. This soup has a tendency to thicken over time, so dilute it with water as needed.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 tablespoons butter\n1 cup chopped onion (about one medium onion)\n1 cup chopped celery (about 2 large ribs)\n4 cups chopped fennel (about 2 large bulbs)\nSalt\nPepper\n2 good cooking apples (I used fuji. Jonagold, Jonathan, Golden delicious, or Braeburn would be good, do NOT use red delicious), peeled, cored, and chopped\n2 or 3 sprigs fresh thyme (or a teaspoon of dried)\n15 to 16 ounces of peeled roasted chestnuts (jarred is best), chopped (do NOT use water chestnuts)\n4 cups chicken stock (low sodium)\n3 cups water\n1 to 2 tablespoons of Pernod or Ricard pastis (optional)\n2 or 3 tablespoons of sour cream (more or less to taste)\nSprigs of fennel fronds for garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook onion, celery, fennel in butter: Melt butter in a large, thick-bottomed pot (6 to 8 qt) on medium heat. Stir in the chopped onion, celery, and fennel.  Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Cook until the onions are translucent and the fennel and celery softened, about 10 minutes.\n2 Stir in the chopped roasted chestnuts, chopped apples, and thyme. Add the chicken stock and water. Increase the heat to high and bring to a boil, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, covered, for 45 minutes.\n3 Pur\xc3\xa9e the soup: Working in batches, pur\xc3\xa9e in a blender or food processor until completely smooth. Remember to fill the blender bowl no more than halfway, and keep your hand pressing down on the top of the blender lid, or the pressure from blending the hot liquid may cause the soup to splatter everywhere.\n4 Adjust seasoning, add Pernod and/or sour cream: If too thick, add more water to thin to the consistency you desire. Taste and add more salt and pepper if needed. Stir in the Pernod or Pastis if using (or other anise flavored liqueur).\nEither stir in sour cream, or dilute the sour cream and drizzle over the bowls at service.\nServe hot, garnish with fennel fronds.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nGrab-and-Go Oatmeal Chia Cups Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesYield: 1 serving (scale up for more servings)\nThe recipe below is for one single-cup serving. Prepare additional servings in their own jars using the same ratios. You can prepare as many servings as you'll eat within 5 days!\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons old-fashioned rolled oats (gluten-free, if needed)\n1 tablespoon chia seeds\n1/3 cup milk, any kind, including non-dairy\n1/3 cup plain or vanilla yogurt, any kind, including non-dairy\n1 teaspoon honey, maple syrup, or sweetener of your choice, to taste (optional)\n1/4 cup blueberries, sliced strawberries, raspberries, or other chopped fruit of your choice\n1 tablespoon raisins or other dried fruit\n1 tablespoons chopped or sliced almonds, cashews, walnuts or other nut of your choice\nSpecial equipment:\nHalf-pint (8 ounce) canning jar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine the oats, chia seeds, and milk in an 8-ounce or larger jar: Stir to mix the ingredients together. Let stand for 10 minutes to allow the mixture to thicken slightly.\n2 Layer the remaining ingredients on top: Once the chia and milk mixture has thickened slightly, top it with layers of yogurt, honey (if using), berries, raisins and nuts. Cover the jar with a cap and refrigerate until needed, or for up to 5 days.\n3 Enjoy! Eat your breakfast straight from the jar, mixing everything together as you go, or pour the contents into a bowl, if you prefer.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nChia Pudding with Blueberries and Almonds Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesSoaking time: 2 hoursYield: Serves 2 to 3\nThe honey is optional, skip it if you are going vegan, or use maple syrup instead.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cups unsweetened almond milk\n1 cup (divided, 3/4 cup and 1/4 cup) fresh or frozen (defrosted) blueberries\n1/2 cup chia seeds\n2 Tbsp honey (optional)\n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon\n1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract\n1/4 cup toasted slivered or sliced almonds\nMETHOD\n1 Blend together 2 cups almond milk and 3/4 cup blueberries in a blender. Pour out into a bowl or quart-sized mason jar.\n2 Stir in the chia seeds, honey, cinnamon, vanilla extract. (Or just cover and shake if using a jar.) Let sit for 10 minutes, then stir again to  break up any clumping.\n3 Chill for 2 hours or overnight.\n4 When ready to eat, stir again. Top with toasted almonds the remaining blueberries.\nHello! b'Print\nMixed Berry Chia Seed Jam Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 12 minutesYield: 1 to 2 cups jam\nThe blueberries and raspberries break down quite easily. If you want chunks of fruit in the jam, don\xe2\x80\x99t chop the strawberries too finely. Consider halving small strawberries and cutting large strawberries into quarters.\nLook for chia seeds at natural food stores in the baking aisle or with the other nuts and seeds. You can also order them online.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup blueberries\n3/4 cup chopped strawberries (stems removed)\n3/4 cup raspberries\n2 tablespoons sugar, plus more to taste\n2 tablespoons lemon juice (from about 1/2 a lemon), plus more to taste\n1 1/2 tablespoons chia seeds\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Combine the blueberries, strawberries, raspberries, sugar, and lemon juice in a medium saucepan. Give everything a quick stir to distribute the sugar.\n2 Cook the fruits over medium heat for about 10 to 12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the fruit breaks down. The fruit should look like a syrupy, runny sauce. (If you want a smooth jam without chunks, use the back of a wooden spoon or a fork to mash large chunks of fruit.\n3 Remove the saucepan from heat. Mix in the chia seeds and let the jam sit for 10 minutes to thicken. Taste and add additional sugar or lemon juice to taste.\n4 Cool to room temperature, then transfer to a jar and refrigerate. The jam will continue to thicken in the refrigerator. Store for up to 3 to 4 weeks.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nBarbecued Chicken on the Grill Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 45 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nChicken thighs and legs will hold up better to long, slow cooking than will breasts which can more easily dry out. If you barbecue breasts, keep them on the coolest part of the grill (or follow this method).\nThis recipe assumes fairly large chicken pieces (like the main pieces from a 4 to 5 pound whole chicken). If you are working with smaller chicken pieces, they may require a shorter cooking time. If you are cooking wings, they too may be done before the other larger pieces.\nA note about the skin. Even if you do not plan on eating the chicken skin, it\'s still best to barbecue it with it on. The skin will protect the chicken pieces from drying out.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 pounds of your favorite chicken parts (legs, thighs, wings, breasts), skin-on\nSalt\nExtra virgin olive oil or vegetable oil\n1 cup barbecue sauce, store-bought or homemade\nMETHOD\n1 Oil and salt chicken pieces: Coat the chicken pieces with olive oil and sprinkle salt over them on all sides.\n2 Prepare grill: Prepare one side of your grill for high, direct heat. If you are using charcoal or wood, make sure there is a cool side to the grill where there are few to no coals.\n3 Sear chicken on hot side of grill, move to cool side: Lay the chicken pieces skin side down on the hottest side of the grill in order to sear the skin side well. Grill uncovered for 5-10 minutes, depending on how hot the grill is (you do not want the chicken to burn).\nOnce you have a good sear on one side, turn the chicken pieces over and move them to the cooler side of the grill.\nIf you are using a gas grill, maintain the flame on only one side of the grill, and move the chicken pieces to the cooler side, not directly over the flame. Reduce the temp to low or medium low (between 250\xc2\xb0F and 275\xc2\xb0F, no more than 300\xc2\xb0F).\nCover the grill and cook undisturbed for 20-30 minutes.\n4 Turn over and baste with barbecue sauce: Turn the chicken pieces over and baste them with with your favorite barbecue sauce. Cover the grill again and allow to cook for another 15-20 minutes.\nRepeat, turning the chicken pieces over, basting them with sauce, covering, and cooking for another 10-30 minutes.\nNOTE that timing will depend on your grill set-up, the size of your chicken pieces, and how cold your chicken pieces are to start with! If you are grilling smaller pieces of chicken on a charcoal grill, they may be done much earlier. The goal is to maintain a low enough grill temp so that the chicken cooks "low and slow".\n5 Finish with a sear or remove from heat when done: The chicken is done when the internal temperature of the chicken pieces are 160\xc2\xb0F for breasts and 170\xc2\xb0F for thighs, when tested with a meat thermometer.\nOr if you insert the tip of a knife into the middle of the thickest piece and the juices should run clear, the chicken is done.\nIf the chicken isn\'t done, turn the pieces over and continue to cook at a low temperature.\nIf you want, you can finish with a sear on the hot side of the grill. To do this, put the pieces, skin side down, on the hot side of the grill. Allow them to sear and blacken slightly for a minute or two.\n6 Paint with more barbecue sauce to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nTuscan Chicken Pasta Skillet Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 25 minutesMarinating time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the marinade:\n1/4 cup olive oil\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/2 teaspoon dried Italian seasoning\nFor the dinner:\n1 1/2 pounds boneless skinless chicken breasts\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n12 ounces cherry tomatoes (about 2 cups), halved\n1 tablespoon minced garlic\n8 ounces spaghetti\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup quartered marinated artichokes hearts, drained\n1/3 cup Kalamata olives, pitted and sliced\n1/4 cup freshly grated parmesan cheese\n6 basil leaves, thinly sliced\n2 teaspoons chopped fresh parsley (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: In a small bowl, combine 1/4 cup olive oil, 1 teaspoon salt, 1/2 teaspoon pepper, and Italian seasoning. Cut each chicken breast lengthwise to create 4 long, thin pieces. Place chicken in a shallow dish. Pour marinade over the chicken, turn to evenly coat. Let sit for 15 minutes before cooking.\n2 Cook the chicken: Heat a large high-sided skillet or saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat. Add 2 tablespoons of olive oil. Once the oil is hot, add the chicken. Cook until the chicken is golden brown and fully cooked, about 6 to 8 minutes per side.\nTransfer chicken to a cutting board to rest while cooking the pasta.\n3 Cook the pasta: Add tomatoes, garlic, spaghetti, 4 cups water, and 1/2 teaspoon salt to the skillet. Bring to a boil over high heat. Cook and stir frequently, until the pasta is tender and water has mostly evaporated\xe2\x80\x94about 9 to 11 minutes. You want to have a small amount of water in the pan to create a light sauce.\nAdd more water if needed, 1/2 cup at a time for a softer pasta. Turn off the heat.  \n4 Finish and toss: Cut the chicken into 1/4-inch thick slices. Add the artichoke hearts, olives, Parmesan cheese, sliced chicken, and basil. Toss to combine. If you'd like a thicker sauce, you can add 1 or 2 tablespoons of butter. Taste and season with more salt and pepper as desired.\n5 Serve: Garnish pasta with parsley, then divide among plates and serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nGrilled BBQ Chicken Sandwiches Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 8 sandwiches\nINGREDIENTS\nPickle Slaw:\n1/2 cup mayonnaise\n1/4 cup dill pickle juice\n1 tablespoon sugar\n1/2 green cabbage, thin shredded (about 4 cups)\n2 medium carrots, grated (about 1 cup)\n1/4 cup chopped dill pickles\nChicken Filling:\n2 pounds boneless skinless chicken breasts, butterflied\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon black pepper\n1 \xe2\x80\x93 1 1/2 cups Hank\xe2\x80\x99s Kansas City BBQ Sauce or store-bought\n8 hamburger buns\nDAD ADD! Serrano Mayo:\n2-3 grilled serrano peppers, seeds removed\n1 cup mayonnaise\nJuice from 1/2 lime\nPinch of salt\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the slaw: Whisk together mayo, pickle juice, and sugar. Stir in shredded cabbage, carrots, and pickles. Stir together and taste. Season to your liking. Slaw can be made a day or two in advance with no problem.\n\n2 Heat the grill and prepare the chicken: Preheat grill to medium-high heat. To butterfly the chicken, use a sharp knife to slice the chicken horizontally \xe2\x80\x93 leaving the edge connected so you can open the chicken breast \xe2\x80\x93 making it thinner and therefore faster-cooking. Then drizzle with olive oil, salt, and pepper.\nPour 1/2 cup of BBQ sauce into a bowl and set it aside. You will add it to the cooked chicken later.\n3 Grill the chicken and chiles (if using): Add chicken to grill and spoon BBQ sauce over each piece of chicken. You will use 1/3 to 1/2 cup of BBQ sauce for this part of cooking.\nGrill for 5 to 6 minutes on the first side. Flip and add BBQ sauce to the second side. Grill for another 5 to 6 minutes on the second side or until the chicken breasts reach 165\xcb\x9aF. Remove from the grill.\nAs the chicken grills, add 2 to 3 serrano peppers to the grill. Grill them for 2 to 3 minutes per side. Remove and let cool.\nNOTE: If you do not butterfly your chicken breasts, you will need to grill them for 8 to 10 minutes longer than this.\n4 Shred the chicken: When chicken comes off the grill, let it cool briefly and then use two forks to shred or roughly chop the chicken. Stir the 1/2 cup of BBQ sauce you set aside in step 1 into the shredded chicken.\n5 Making the serrano mayo: Split grilled peppers in half and remove seeds. Add to a small food processor with mayo, lime juice, and salt. Pulse until combined.\n6 Make your sandwich: Toast your sandwich buns (if you want to) and smear with serrano mayo if you\xe2\x80\x99re using it. Top with a heap of pickle slaw and shredded BBQ chicken. Serve with chips and pickles on the side.\nLeftover chicken will keep in the fridge for 3 to 4 days or freeze in an airtight container for up to three months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nInstant Pot Paella with Chicken and Sausage Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 40 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nIf using a stovetop pressure cooker, cooking time is the same.\nShort-grain rice is traditional for paella, however it\'s fine to substitute long-grain white rice or quick-cooking brown rice for this recipe. Cooking times are the same.\nNote from the editor: Our original version of this recipe called for one ripe diced tomato or one whole canned tomato (crushed), which adds a more authentic flavor to the paella. However, we received comments that this caused the paella to occasionally burn on the bottom. We\'ve removed the tomatoes from the recipe to ensure a more consistently successful dish, but if you\'d like to experiment with tomatoes on your own, add the tomato after cooking the garlic and cook until most of the liquid has evaporate before adding the onions. Thanks!\nINGREDIENTS\n1 1/2 cups low sodium chicken broth\nBig pinch of saffron threads (roughly equal to 1/4 teaspoon)\n1 cup frozen peas\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n3 cloves garlic, chopped\n1 medium yellow onion, chopped\n1 red bell pepper, chopped\n1 pound (3 to 4) boneless skinless chicken thighs, cut into 1 inch pieces\n6 ounces (about 2 links) chorizo or other spicy sausage, sliced\n1 teaspoon smoked paprika\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 1/2 cups (325 grams) short or medium grain rice\n2 tablespoons chopped parsley\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart Instant Pot or other electric pressure cooker\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Heat the saffron with the chicken broth and defrost the peas: In a small saucepan, heat the broth to a simmer, then and add the peas and saffron. Reduce the heat to low to keep the broth warm and give the saffron a chance to infuse the broth while you get everything else ready.\n(You can also heat the broth in a microwave safe bowl or liquid measuring cup for about three minutes. Add the peas and saffron after microwaving and cover to keep warm until needed.)\n2 Cook the vegetables, chicken, and sausage in the pressure cooker: Select the \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d setting on your electric pressure cooker and add the oil and garlic. Saut\xc3\xa9 until little bubbles of oil form around the garlic and it becomes aromatic, 1 to 2 minutes.\nStir in the onion and bell pepper. Saut\xc3\xa9 until they have softened a little bit, 3 to 4 more minutes. Stir in the paprika and salt, and saut\xc3\xa9 for one more minute.\nAdd the chicken and sausage and stir to combine. Saut\xc3\xa9 for 5 to 6 minutes, until the chicken has turned opaque. It\'s ok if the chicken is still a little pink in the middle.\n3 Scrape the bottom of the pan: Add a splash of the hot broth to the pan and use it to scrape up any browned bits that have developed on the bottom of the pan. These browned bits add a lot of flavor to the dish, so don\'t skip this step. (This also helps prevent the dish from burning on the bottom during cooking!)\n4 Add the remaining ingredients and the broth: Stir in the rice, then pour in the rest of the hot broth with the peas and saffron. Push down any grains of rice from the sides of the pot, making sure that everything is submerged in the cooking liquid.\n5 Pressure cook the paella: Secure the lid on the pressure cooker, and make sure the pressure regulator is in its \xe2\x80\x9cSealing\xe2\x80\x9d position. Cancel the \xe2\x80\x9cSaut\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x9d cooking program, then select the \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cPressure Cook\xe2\x80\x9d program and set the cooking time to 5 minutes at high pressure.\nThe pot will take 5 to 10 minutes to come up to pressure, and then the cooking program will begin counting down.\n6 Release the pressure: When the cooking program ends, let the pressure release naturally for 10 minutes, then release the remaining pressure by moving the pressure regulator to its \xe2\x80\x9cVenting\xe2\x80\x9d position.\n7 Serve: When the pressure has fully released, open the pot. Scoop onto plates, garnish with chopped parsley, and serve it piping hot. Leftovers will keep for about a week.\nYou may get a crust of dark caramelization and crunchy rice at the bottom of the pan -- this is ok! This is called "socarrat" and is traditional for paella. Just mix it in and enjoy!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nClassic Chicken Salad Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesPoaching chicken time: 20 minutesYield: Serves 4\nWe are poaching boneless skinless chicken breasts in salted water for this salad. You could also use any leftover cooked chicken meat, with or without the skin.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the salad:\n1 pound boneless, skinless (raw) chicken breasts, cut into 2 1/2-inch chunks (or 2 to 3 cups cooked chicken meat)\n2 stalks celery, chopped\n1/2 red bell pepper, seeded and chopped\n4 to 6 green olives, pitted and minced\n1/4 cup chopped red onion\n1/2 to 1 whole apple, cored and chopped\n1/3 head iceberg head lettuce, sliced and chopped\nFor the dressing:\n5 tablespoons mayonnaise\n1 tablespoon plum preserves, or any sweet berry preserve (or a lesser amount of honey)\n2 teaspoons fresh squeezed lemon juice\nSalt and pepper to taste\nMETHOD\n1 Poach the chicken (skip if using already cooked chicken): Bring a pot with 2 quarts of well salted water (1 tablespoon salt) to a boil. Add the chicken breast (cut into large chunks) and return the water to a simmer. Then turn off the heat, and cover the pot. Let the chicken sit for 15 minutes (time it) or more while you prepare everything else.\n2 Make the dressing: Prepare the chicken salad dressing in a large bowl. Mix together the mayonnaise, preserves, and lemon juice. Taste for the proper balance of sweetness and acidity. The salad dressing should not be too sweet, nor too sour.\nAdd more preserves or lemon juice until you have reached the balance you want. Add salt and pepper to taste.\n3 Mix in the chopped celery, bell pepper, olives, red onion, and apple.\n4 Dice the chicken, mix with dressing and vegetables: Remove the chicken from the poaching water and dice it. (Or dice already cooked chicken if that is what you are using for this salad.) Mix it in with the dressing and vegetables.\n5 Add lettuce: At this point you can make ahead. When ready to serve, fold in the sliced and chopped iceberg lettuce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nHow to Make Chicken Stock\nYield: About 2 to 3 quarts of stock\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nMETHOD 1: LEFTOVER CHICKEN BONES\nLeftover bones and skin from a large cooked or raw chicken carcass (or two rotisserie chickens)\nCelery tops and 1 large celery rib, cut into 2-inch segments\nOnion, 1 large onion, quartered (no need to peel)\nCarrot, cut into 2-inch segments\nParsley, 1 bunch\nSalt\nPepper\n1 Put the leftover bones and skin from a chicken carcass into a large stock pot. Add vegetables like celery, onion, carrots, parsley.\nCover with water. Add salt and pepper, about a teaspoon of salt, 1/4 tsp of pepper.\n2 Bring to a boil and immediately reduce heat to bring the stock to barely a simmer. Simmer partially covered at least 4 hours, occasionally skimming off any foam that comes to the surface.\n3 Remove the bones and vegetables with a slotted spoon or spider ladle, and strain the stock through a fine mesh sieve.\n4 If making stock for future use in soup you may want to reduce the stock by simmering an hour or two longer to make it more concentrated and easier to store.\nMETHOD 2: CHICKEN STOCK WITH RAW CHICKEN BACKS, WINGS, AND/OR LEGS\n1 Tbsp olive oil\n4 to 5 lbs of chicken backs, wings, and/or legs, skin-on, trimmed of excess fat, that have been hacked with a cleaver into 2-inch pieces (you can ask your butcher to prepare the chicken pieces this way)\n1 large yellow onion, quartered (no need to peel)\n1 large carrot, cut into 2-inch segments\nCelery tops and 1 large celery rib, cut into 2-inch segments\n1 bunch of parsley\nLeek or green onion greens (if you have them)\n1 bay leaf\n6 quarts of cold water\n1 Tbsp salt\n1 Coat the bottom of a large stock pot (12 quart), with olive oil. Place half of the chicken pieces, skin side down in the bottom of the pot. Heat on medium high, and let cook until the the chicken is browned. Add the rest of the chicken pieces and stir the pot, cooking and occasionally stirring until the chicken is no longer pink.\n2 Add the onion, carrot, celery, parsley, leek greens (if using), and bay leaf to the pot. Cover with 6 quarts of cold water.\n3 Bring to a boil on high heat and reduce to a low simmer.
