If scum rises to the surface of the pot (this usually happens in the first half hour of cooking), skim off with a large metal spoon. Let simmer at a low simmer, uncovered, for 4 to 6 hours.\n4 Use a large metal spoons with holes in it (or a "spider ladle") to ladle out the cooked chicken and vegetables. (These aren\'t really good to eat, by the way, because after 4 hours of cooking, most of the flavor and nutrients have been cooked out of them and are now in the stock.) Discard.\n5 Use a large sieve lined with dampened cheesecloth or a dampened paper towel (or if using a very fine mesh sieve no need to line), and place over a large bowl or another large pot. Pour the stock through the sieve into the bowl or pot to strain out any remaining solids.\n6 Either pour into jars at this point, or if you want, what we like to do is to boil the stock on high heat for 1 hour, to reduce it by about half. This way you are storing concentrated stock, which takes less room in the freezer or refrigerator. When you are ready, pour into jars.\nIf you are freezing, you may want to ladle off some of the excess fat on the surface. (The fat helps preserve the stock in the fridge, but doesn\'t help it in the freezer.) If freezing, leave at least 1-inch head space, allowing enough room for the liquid stock to expand as it freezes solid. (Otherwise, the expanding ice stock will break the jar.)\nLet the stock cool completely before refrigerating or freezing. Stock should last a week or so in the fridge, and several months in the freezer.\nMETHOD 3: QUICK CHICKEN STOCK\n4 lbs of chicken backs, wings, and/or legs that have been hacked with a cleaver into 2-inch pieces. You can ask your butcher to prepare the chicken pieces this way.\n1 large yellow onion, chopped\nOlive oil\n2 quarts of boiling water\n2 teaspoons of salt\n2 bay leaves\n1 Heat 1 Tbsp of olive oil in a large stock pot. Add one chopped onion. Saut\xc3\xa9 until softened and slightly colored - 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer to a large bowl.\n\n\n2 Add half of the chicken pieces to the pot. Saut\xc3\xa9 until no longer pink, about 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer cooked chicken to bowl with onions. Saut\xc3\xa9 the rest of the chicken the same way. Return onion and chicken pieces to the pot. Reduce heat to low, cover, and cook until chicken releases its juices, about 20 minutes.\n3 While the chicken pieces are cooking, fill a large tea kettle with 2 quarts of water, bring to a boil.\n4 After the chicken pieces have been cooking for 20 minutes, raise the heat level to high, add the 2 quarts of boiling water, 2 teaspoons of salt, 2 bay leaves. Return to a low simmer, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan with a wooden spoon, then cover and barely simmer for about 20 minutes.\n5 Strain stock through cheesecloth or paper towel-lined large sieve, and discard solids. (It helps to remove the big pieces of bone with a slotted spoon first.)\nPour into jars and cool completely before refrigerating or freezing. Stock will last a week or so in the refrigerator or frozen for several months.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nBarbecued Chicken on the Grill Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 45 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nChicken thighs and legs will hold up better to long, slow cooking than will breasts which can more easily dry out. If you barbecue breasts, keep them on the coolest part of the grill (or follow this method).\nThis recipe assumes fairly large chicken pieces (like the main pieces from a 4 to 5 pound whole chicken). If you are working with smaller chicken pieces, they may require a shorter cooking time. If you are cooking wings, they too may be done before the other larger pieces.\nA note about the skin. Even if you do not plan on eating the chicken skin, it\'s still best to barbecue it with it on. The skin will protect the chicken pieces from drying out.\nINGREDIENTS\n4 pounds of your favorite chicken parts (legs, thighs, wings, breasts), skin-on\nSalt\nExtra virgin olive oil or vegetable oil\n1 cup barbecue sauce, store-bought or homemade\nMETHOD\n1 Oil and salt chicken pieces: Coat the chicken pieces with olive oil and sprinkle salt over them on all sides.\n2 Prepare grill: Prepare one side of your grill for high, direct heat. If you are using charcoal or wood, make sure there is a cool side to the grill where there are few to no coals.\n3 Sear chicken on hot side of grill, move to cool side: Lay the chicken pieces skin side down on the hottest side of the grill in order to sear the skin side well. Grill uncovered for 5-10 minutes, depending on how hot the grill is (you do not want the chicken to burn).\nOnce you have a good sear on one side, turn the chicken pieces over and move them to the cooler side of the grill.\nIf you are using a gas grill, maintain the flame on only one side of the grill, and move the chicken pieces to the cooler side, not directly over the flame. Reduce the temp to low or medium low (between 250\xc2\xb0F and 275\xc2\xb0F, no more than 300\xc2\xb0F).\nCover the grill and cook undisturbed for 20-30 minutes.\n4 Turn over and baste with barbecue sauce: Turn the chicken pieces over and baste them with with your favorite barbecue sauce. Cover the grill again and allow to cook for another 15-20 minutes.\nRepeat, turning the chicken pieces over, basting them with sauce, covering, and cooking for another 10-30 minutes.\nNOTE that timing will depend on your grill set-up, the size of your chicken pieces, and how cold your chicken pieces are to start with! If you are grilling smaller pieces of chicken on a charcoal grill, they may be done much earlier. The goal is to maintain a low enough grill temp so that the chicken cooks "low and slow".\n5 Finish with a sear or remove from heat when done: The chicken is done when the internal temperature of the chicken pieces are 160\xc2\xb0F for breasts and 170\xc2\xb0F for thighs, when tested with a meat thermometer.\nOr if you insert the tip of a knife into the middle of the thickest piece and the juices should run clear, the chicken is done.\nIf the chicken isn\'t done, turn the pieces over and continue to cook at a low temperature.\nIf you want, you can finish with a sear on the hot side of the grill. To do this, put the pieces, skin side down, on the hot side of the grill. Allow them to sear and blacken slightly for a minute or two.\n6 Paint with more barbecue sauce to serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nTuscan Chicken Pasta Skillet Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 25 minutesMarinating time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the marinade:\n1/4 cup olive oil\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/2 teaspoon dried Italian seasoning\nFor the dinner:\n1 1/2 pounds boneless skinless chicken breasts\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n12 ounces cherry tomatoes (about 2 cups), halved\n1 tablespoon minced garlic\n8 ounces spaghetti\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup quartered marinated artichokes hearts, drained\n1/3 cup Kalamata olives, pitted and sliced\n1/4 cup freshly grated parmesan cheese\n6 basil leaves, thinly sliced\n2 teaspoons chopped fresh parsley (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: In a small bowl, combine 1/4 cup olive oil, 1 teaspoon salt, 1/2 teaspoon pepper, and Italian seasoning. Cut each chicken breast lengthwise to create 4 long, thin pieces. Place chicken in a shallow dish. Pour marinade over the chicken, turn to evenly coat. Let sit for 15 minutes before cooking.\n2 Cook the chicken: Heat a large high-sided skillet or saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat. Add 2 tablespoons of olive oil. Once the oil is hot, add the chicken. Cook until the chicken is golden brown and fully cooked, about 6 to 8 minutes per side.\nTransfer chicken to a cutting board to rest while cooking the pasta.\n3 Cook the pasta: Add tomatoes, garlic, spaghetti, 4 cups water, and 1/2 teaspoon salt to the skillet. Bring to a boil over high heat. Cook and stir frequently, until the pasta is tender and water has mostly evaporated\xe2\x80\x94about 9 to 11 minutes. You want to have a small amount of water in the pan to create a light sauce.\nAdd more water if needed, 1/2 cup at a time for a softer pasta. Turn off the heat.  \n4 Finish and toss: Cut the chicken into 1/4-inch thick slices. Add the artichoke hearts, olives, Parmesan cheese, sliced chicken, and basil. Toss to combine. If you'd like a thicker sauce, you can add 1 or 2 tablespoons of butter. Taste and season with more salt and pepper as desired.\n5 Serve: Garnish pasta with parsley, then divide among plates and serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nHow to Grill Juicy Boneless Skinless Chicken Breasts\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesBrining time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIt's always a good idea to use a meat thermometer when cooking meat that's at least an inch thick. I take chicken off the grill at a little bit lower temp (155\xc2\xb0F) than is usually recommended for poultry, but that's because the chicken will continue to cook for several minutes once it's off the heat and resting. Taking the chicken off the heat at this temperature helps insure that the meat doesn't overcook and get dried out. If you feel more comfortable taking the chicken off the heat at a higher internal temperature, please feel free to do so.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the brine:\n4 cups water\n1/4 cup Diamond Crystal kosher salt (or 3 tablespoons sea salt or Morton's kosher salt)\nFor the chicken:\n1 1/2 to 2 pounds boneless skinless chicken breasts\n3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil (plus more olive oil for the grill)\n1 1/2 teaspoons paprika\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Brine the chicken breast: In a large bowl, whisk the salt in the water to dissolve. Add the chicken breasts to the brine. Put in the refrigerator and chill for 30 minutes.\n2 Prepare your grill: Arrange your grill so that one side is for high direct heat, and the other side is cooler. Alternatively, you can use a grill pan, set over medium-high heat.\n3 Coat chicken with oil and paprika: Remove chicken breasts from brine and pat dry. Coat with olive oil, and sprinkle evenly with paprika.\n4 Grill the chicken breasts: Brush some olive oil on the grill grates. Place chicken breasts on the hot side of the grill (or on the grill pan). Let the chicken grill, undisturbed, until the pieces start getting some grill marks (you can lift up one to check).\nWhen the chicken pieces have browned on one side, turn them over, and move them to the cooler side of the grill. Cover, and let them finish cooking.\nRemove chicken from grill when the internal temperature of the chicken reaches 155\xc2\xb0F.\n5 Let the chicken breasts rest: Cover the breasts with foil. The chicken will continue to cook in its residual heat while it rests. Let it rest 5 to 10 minutes before cutting and serving.\nServe with grilled peppers, pineapple salsa, or just a squeeze of lime!\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nEasy Chicken Lo Mein Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nDAD ADD: Sriracha Roasted Veggies\n8 ounces cremini mushrooms, quartered\n1/2 red pepper, sliced\n1 tablespoon sesame oil\n1 to 2 teaspoons sriracha hot sauce\nFor the sauce:\n3 tablespoons soy sauce\n1 tablespoon hoisin sauce\n2 teaspoons sesame oil\n2 tablespoons hot water\nFor the lo mein:\n8 ounces lo mein noodles, fresh or dried\n1 teaspoon sesame oil\n1 tablespoon vegetable oil\n1 pound boneless chicken breast, sliced thin\n1/2 head green cabbage, shredded (about 3 cups)\n1 large carrot, grated\nFor the garnish:\nFresh scallions, chopped\nSesame seeds\nSpecial equipment:\nWok or large skillet\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 If making the Sriracha Roasted Vegetables: Heat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F. In a small bowl, toss quartered mushrooms and red peppers with the sesame oil and sriracha. Spread out on a baking sheet.\nWhile you make the Chicken Lo Mein, bake for 15 minutes until tender and blistered in spots.\n2 Stir the sauce ingredients together and set near the stove.\n3 Cook the lo mein noodles: Bring a large amount of salted water to a boil. Add the noodles and cook until tender, usually around 4 minutes, but check the package directions for the noodles you are using.\nDrain the noodles and toss with sesame oil to prevent sticking.\n4 Cook the chicken: Heat a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat. Once hot, add the vegetable oil once that's hot, add the chicken. Cook until the chicken is just barely cooked through, 5 to 6 minutes, stirring frequently. (The chicken will continue to cook with the vegetables, so it's ok if it seems a little undercooked right now.)\n5 Add the vegetables: When chicken is cooked, add cabbage and carrots, and continue to stir and cook until the veggies wilt and the liquid they release is mostly evaporated, 2 to 3 minutes.\n6 Add the noodles and sauce: Add noodles along with sauce and stir with the chicken and veggies to combine. The sauce should coat the noodles and other ingredients. If the dish seems too dry, add more water.\nTaste and adjust the flavor to your liking. It might need another dash of soy sauce, for example.\n7 Serve: Serve the Chicken Lo Mein topped with scallions, sesame seeds, and roasted veggies (optional).\nLeftovers can be stored in the fridge for 3 to 4 days and will reheat beautifully in the microwave.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nHow to Make Gravy\nCook time: 15 minutes\nWhen you cook a roast, whether it\'s turkey, chicken, beef, or lamb, you should end up with plenty of browned drippings and fat from the roast when it\'s finished.\nThe "drippings" are browned juices and fat. All of the flavor a gravy you make from the drippings comes from those browned bits. You need fat as a base for the gravy.\nIf you have pan juices, but they haven\'t browned at the bottom of the pan after the roast is done, you can put the empty pan back in the oven. Set the temp to 450 or 500\xc2\xb0F and cook until the juices evaporate and begin to bubble and brown at the bottom of the pan.\nIn this approach to making gravy, we break up the drippings as well as we can with a whisk, but don\'t worry about any browned bits in the gravy itself. If you want, you can pulse the gravy in a blender to make it smoother, but we never bother. The browned bits are the best part!\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\nMaking Gravy with Flour\n1 Remove all but 1/4 cup of fat from pan: Remove the roast from the pan. Remove excess fat leaving 4 Tbsp of fat plus juices and browned drippings in the pan.\n2 Scrape up drippings and place pan on stovetop on medium heat: Use a metal spatula to scrape up any drippings that are sticking to the pan. Place the pan on the stovetop on medium high heat.\n3 Sprinkle 4 Tbsp flour onto the drippings. Quickly stir with a wire whisk so that the flour gets incorporated into the drippings. Let the flour brown a bit if you want, before adding liquid in the next step. (You can also start with a slurry of flour and water if you want.)\n4 Whisk while slowly adding liquid: Slowly add stock, water, milk, cream, or a combination to the pan, whisking vigorously to dissolve the flour into liquid.\nAllow the gravy to simmer and thicken, and continue to slowly add liquid until you have about 2 cups of gravy. (You\'ll probably need to add 3 to 4 cups of liquid.)\n5 Season to taste with salt and pepper. (Always taste first before adding more salt! It may not need it.)\n  Making Gravy with Cornstarch\n1 Remove all but 1/4 cup of fat from pan: Remove the roast from the roasting pan. Pour off all but 4 Tbsp of the fat in the pan. If you don\'t have enough fat in the pan, add butter so that you have at least 4 Tbsp of fat in the pan.\n2 Scrape up browned drippings: While the pan is still warm, scrape the bottom of the pan with a metal spatula to loosen any browned drippings that might be stuck to the bottom of the pan.\n3 Place the pan on the stovetop on medium heat. If you are using a roasting pan that won\'t work well on the stovetop, scrape up all of the drippings and fat and put into a large shallow saut\xc3\xa9 pan.\n4 Make cornstarch slurry: Dissolve 4 Tbsp of cornstarch in the minimum amount of water needed to make a thin paste - about 1/2 cup.\n5 Pour the cornstarch slurry into the pan with drippings and use a wire whisk to blend into the drippings.\n6 Whisk while slowly adding liquid: Stir with a wire whisk until the gravy begins to thicken. As the gravy thickens, slowly add stock, water, milk, or cream, or some combination to the pan (I like to use stock, my mother usually uses water).\nAlternate stirring and adding liquid, maintaining the consistency you want, for several minutes (about 5 minutes).\nYou will probably add about 3 to 4 cups of liquid all together. Taking into consideration the evaporation that is occurring while the gravy is simmering, you will end up with about 2 cups of gravy.\nIf the gravy isn\'t thick enough, make more cornstarch slurry and whisk it into the pan.\n7 Season to taste with salt and pepper.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Print\nTandoori Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 40 minutesMarinating time: 6 hoursYield: Serves 4-6\nIf you don't have a grill, you can broil the chicken for a few minutes on each side to get some browning, then finish in a 325\xc2\xb0F oven until done.\nINGREDIENTS\n3 Tbsp vegetable oil\n1 teaspoon ground coriander\n1 teaspoon ground cumin\n1 teaspoon ground turmeric\n1 teaspoon cayenne\n1 Tbsp garam masala\n1 Tbsp sweet (not hot) paprika\n1 cup plain yogurt (can sub buttermilk)\n2 Tbsp lemon juice\n4 minced garlic cloves\n2 Tbsp minced fresh ginger\n1 teaspoon salt\n4 whole chicken legs (drumsticks and thighs), or its equivalent, skinless, bone-in\nMETHOD\n1 Heat the spices in oil: Heat the oil in a small pan over medium heat, then cook the coriander, cumin, turmeric, cayenne, garam masala and paprika, stirring often, until fragrant (approximately 2-3 minutes). Let cool completely.\n2 Whisk spices into yogurt, add lemon juice, garlic, salt, ginger: Whisk the cooled spice-oil mixture into the yogurt, then mix in the lemon juice, garlic, salt and ginger.\n3 Cut deep slashes into chicken, coat with marinade, chill: Cut deep slashes (to the bone) in 3-4 places on the leg/thigh pieces. Just make 2-3 cuts if you are using separate drumsticks and thighs. Coat the chicken in the marinade, cover and chill for at least an hour (preferably 6 hours), no more than 8 hours.\n4 Prepare grill: Prepare your grill so that one side is quite hot over direct heat, the other side cooler, not over direct heat. If using charcoal, leave one side of the grill without coals, so you have a hot side and a cooler side. If you are using a gas grill, just turn on one-half of the burners.\nUse tongs to wipe the grill grates with a paper towel soaked in vegetable oil.\n5 Shake off excess marinade, place chicken on hot side of grill: Take the chicken out of the marinade and shake off the excess. You want the chicken coated, but not gloppy.\nPut the chicken pieces on the hot side of the grill and cover. Cook 2-3 minutes before checking.\nTurn the chicken so it is brown (even a little bit charred) on all sides\n6 Move to cool side of grill, cover and cook: Move chicken to the cool side of the grill. Cover and cook for at least 20 minutes, up to 40 minutes (or longer) depending on the size of the chicken and the temperature of the grill. The chicken is done when its juices run clear.\nLet it rest for at least 5 minutes before serving. It\xe2\x80\x99s also great at room temperature or even cold the next day.\nServe with naan, and Indian flatbread, or with Indian style rice, with yogurt-based raita on the side.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b'Print\nPressure Cooker White Chicken Chili Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nYou can also make this recipe using leftover shredded or diced cooked chicken or turkey. Reduce the cooking time to 5 minutes at high pressure.\nFor a thicker chili: After the chili is cooked, stir in 1 tablespoon cornstarch mixed with 1 tablespoon water. Use your pressure cooker\xe2\x80\x99s Saut\xc3\xa9 setting to simmer the chili for a minute or two until it thickens.\nFor a dairy-free chili, leave out the sour cream.\nFor stovetop pressure cookers: Saut\xc3\xa9 the vegetables, herbs, and spices as directed, over medium heat. Cook the chili for 8 minutes at high pressure, perform a quick or natural pressure release, then continue with the recipe as written, shredding the chicken and adding it back to the pot with the sour cream and cilantro.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n4 cloves garlic, minced\n1 large green bell pepper, seeded and chopped\n2 jalapen\xcc\x83o peppers, seeded and chopped (leave the seeds in if you like it spicy)\n3 celery stalks, chopped\n1 medium yellow onion, chopped\n2 teaspoons ground cumin\n2 teaspoons dried oregano\n1 teaspoon ground coriander\n1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper (optional)\n2 teaspoons salt\n2 (15-ounce) cans cannellini beans, rinsed and drained (or 3 cups homemade beans)\n1 1/2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken breasts, tenders, or thighs\n1 cup chicken broth\n1 cup sour cream\n1/2 cup chopped fresh cilantro\nSpecial equipment:\n6-quart electric pressure cooker, like the Instant Pot\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Saut\xc3\xa9 the garlic and vegetables: Select the saut\xc3\xa9 setting on your pressure cooker and heat the olive oil and garlic for 2 minutes, until the garlic is bubbling.\nAdd the bell pepper, jalapen\xcc\x83os, celery, and onion, and saute\xcc\x81 for about 5 minutes, until the vegetables are softened.\n2 Add the spices, beans, and chicken: Add the cumin, oregano, coriander, cayenne, and salt and saute\xcc\x81 for about 1 minute more, until aromatic.\nPour the beans over the vegetables, layer the chicken pieces on top, and pour in the broth. Do not stir. \n3 Pressure cook the chicken: Secure the lid on your pressure cooker in its sealing position. Cancel the saut\xc3\xa9 program, then select the manual setting and set the cooking time for 15 minutes at high pressure. (The pot will take about 10 minutes to come up to pressure before the cooking program begins.) \n4 Release the pressure: Perform a quick pressure release by moving the pressure cooker\xe2\x80\x99s lid to its vented position, or let the pressure release naturally.\nAt this point, you can also leave the chili on your pressure cooker\xe2\x80\x99s Keep Warm setting for up to 10 hours, then continue with the recipe when you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to serve.\n 5 Shred and season the chicken: When the pressure has fully released, open the pot and use a pair of tongs to remove the chicken to a carving board or dish. Using a pair of forks, break up the chicken into shreds.\nAdd the shredded chicken back to the pot along with the sour cream and cilantro and stir to combine. Taste for seasoning and add more salt if needed.\n6 Serve the chili: Ladle the chili into bowls. Serve hot, with tortillas or cornbread on the side.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nAir Fryer Chicken Wings Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 1 hourOptional Refrigeration time: 6 hours\nThe baking powder trick yields super-crispy wings and is worth planning ahead. But you\xe2\x80\x99ll still have delicious wings without it: Omit the baking powder, but still season the wings with the kosher salt before air-frying them.\nIf you can\xe2\x80\x99t find gochujang, try another favorite sauce for chicken wings and use the same air fryer method.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the wings:\n3 pounds chicken wing drumettes and flats\n3 teaspoons baking powder\n2 teaspoons kosher salt\nFor the sauce:\n2 tablespoons gochujang\n2 tablespoons soy sauce\n1 tablespoon rice wine vinegar\n2 teaspoons sesame oil\n1 teaspoon sugar\n3 tablespoons butter, melted and kept warm\nFor the sesame mayonnaise dipping sauce:\n1 cup mayonnaise\n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil\n3/4 teaspoon sugar\n1/8 teaspoon sriracha\nTo garnish:\nThinly sliced scallions, for garnish\nToasted sesame seeds, for garnish\nThin spears of cucumber\nThin slices of radish\nSpecial equipment:\nAir Fryer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Season and rest the wings: Pat the wings dry, if needed. In a large bowl, add the wings and toss them with the baking powder and salt until evenly coated.\nSpread the wings around the bowl so they are in a single layer and refrigerate them, uncovered, for at least 6 hours and up to 24 hours.\n2 Air fry the wings: Heat the air fryer to 380\xc2\xb0F. Open the drawer and fit as many wings as you can in it without crowding them (for my 4.4-quart air fryer, this was 1-1/2 pounds of wings, or half the batch). Close the drawer. Cook for 25 minutes, shaking the drawer every 5 minutes to shuffle the wings around.\n3 Make the sauce: As the wings cook, make the sauce. In a medium bowl, whisk together the gochujang, soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, sesame oil, and sugar. Set aside.\n4 Make the sesame mayonnaise: In a small bowl, whisk together the mayonnaise, sesame oil, sugar, and sriracha until smooth. Set aside.\n5 Increase the air fryer temp: Once the wings have cooked for 25 minutes, increase the temperature of the air fryer to 400\xc2\xb0F. Cook the wings for another 5 minutes. This gets them nice and brown and especially crispy.\n6 Sauce and serve the wings: Mix the melted butter with the sauce (it might solidify a bit, but the heat of the wings will re-melt it). Add the wings to a large bowl, pour over half the sauce and toss the wings in the sauce.\n7 Serve and eat: Transfer to a serving platter and sprinkle with scallions and sesame seeds, if you like. Serve immediately, accompanied by the cucumbers, radishes, and sesame mayonnaise for dipping.\n8 Cook the remaining wings: Reduce the temperature of your air fryer back to 380\xc2\xb0F. Repeat steps 2 and 4. Toss them with the remaining sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Print\nGoldfish Chicken Tenders Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: About 20 chicken tenders\nFor the even crispier tenders, place a metal rack inside the baking sheet and bake the tenders on top of the rack.\nINGREDIENTS\nNonstick spray, for sheet pan\n2 cups Goldfish cheese crackers, well crushed\n1 cup all-purpose flour\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 teaspoon black pepper\n3 large eggs\n2 pounds chicken breast, sliced into strips about 2-inches long and 1/2-inch thick\nDAD ADD: Goldfish Chicken Sandwich\n1 6-inch sub roll\n1 tablespoon mayonnaise\n1/2 cup shredded iceberg lettuce\n3 to 4 Goldfish chicken tenders\nPickled banana peppers\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Preheat the oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Line a baking sheet with foil and spray with nonstick spray (or brush with oil).\n2 Crush the crackers: Place the crackers in a zip-top plastic bag and seal it. Using your hands, a rolling pin, a mallet, or the hands of your children, crush the Goldfish as much as you can, but don't turn them into flour. You want some inconsistencies in shape; it'll make for better texture.\n3 Prep the assembly line: Find three medium bowls. Stir together the flour, salt, and pepper in one. Whisk the eggs together in the second bowl. Add the crushed Goldfish crackers to the last one.\n4 Bread the chicken: Working with a few pieces of chicken at a time, add to seasoned flour and coat well. Then shake off any extra flour, move to the eggs and coat well, and finally add to crushed Goldfish. Press the Goldfish on so they really stick and form a good crust.\nTransfer coated chicken to the baking sheet. Repeat until all the chicken tenders are coated.\n5 Bake the chicken: Bake chicken tenders for about 20 minutes until they are cooked through, or reach an internal temperature of 165\xc2\xb0F in the thickest part of the tenders. You can also test one of the thicker ones by cutting it in half and making sure it\xe2\x80\x99s cooked through.\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s no need to flip these, but you can flip them halfway through if they are browning too much on one side.\nServe tenders while warm with a veggie and/or side salad and any dips you want, such as ketchup or bbq sauce. My kids loved honey! You can also make the Dad Add and have a sandwich!\nHow to Reheat Leftover Tenders\nYou will probably have leftovers, which will keep for 3 to 4 days in the fridge. They reheat perfectly, but they will get soggy if you reheat them in the microwave. Either reheat them gently in a nonstick skillet over low heat until warmed through, or put them on a baking sheet and reheat them until they\xe2\x80\x99re crispy, 7 to 8 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint"
b"Save It Print\nChicken Tikka Masala Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 20 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nLeftover chicken tikka masala tastes phenomenal the next day because the spices develop more flavor overnight.\nAvoid using Greek yogurt if possible for this recipe. If it's all you can find, buy the Greek yogurt with the highest fat content you can find and mix it with a little whole milk to get the consistency of regular yogurt. This will give the sauce some insurance against separating.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken:\n1 1/4 pounds boneless skinless chicken breasts, thighs, or a mix\n6 tablespoons plain whole milk yogurt\n1/2 tablespoon grated ginger\n3 cloves of garlic, minced\n1 teaspoon cumin\n1 teaspoon paprika\n1 1/4 teaspoons salt\nFor the tikka masala sauce:\n2 tablespoons canola oil, divided\n1 small onion, thinly sliced (about 5 ounces, or 1 1/2 cups sliced)\n2 teaspoons grated ginger\n4 cloves garlic, minced\n1 tablespoon ground coriander\n2 teaspoons paprika\n1 teaspoon garam masala\n1/2 teaspoon turmeric\n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n1 (14-ounce) can crushed fire-roasted tomatoes (regular crushed tomatoes work, too)\n6 tablespoons plain whole milk yogurt\n1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1/2 teaspoon salt\nCooked rice, to serve\nCilantro, to garnish\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the chicken: Trim chicken thighs of any extra fat. Chop into bite-sized pieces about 1/2 to 1-inch wide. Place the chicken thigh pieces to a medium bowl.\nAdd the yogurt, ginger, garlic, cumin, paprika and salt. Using your hands, combine the chicken with the spices until the chicken is evenly coated.\n2 Marinate the chicken: Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and let the chicken marinate in the fridge for at least 45 minutes or as long as overnight. (Marinating for 4 to 6 hours is perfect.)\n3 Cook the chicken: In a large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of canola oil over medium-high heat. Add the chicken thigh pieces and cook for about 6 to 7 minutes, until they\xe2\x80\x99re cooked through. Transfer to a plate and set aside.\n4 Toast the spices: Wipe down the pan you used to cook the chicken. Heat remaining canola oil over medium heat. Add the onions and cook for 5 minutes, until softened, stirring often.\nAdd the grated ginger, minced garlic, coriander, paprika, garam masala, turmeric, black pepper, salt, and cayenne. Let the spices cook until fragrant, about 30 seconds to a minute.\n5 Make the sauce: Add the crushed tomatoes to the pan with the spices and let everything cook for 4 minutes, stirring often. Add the yogurt and stir to combine.\n6 Simmer the sauce: Reduce the heat to medium-low and let the sauce simmer for another 4 minutes. Add the chicken pieces to the pan and coat with sauce.\n7 Serve: Serve over cooked basmati rice and garnish with cilantro.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Save It Print\nChicken Piccata Pasta Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 6 servings\nINGREDIENTS\n1 pound penne pasta\n3/4 cup all-purpose flour\n1 1/4 teaspoons salt\n1 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\n2 large eggs\n1 1/2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken breasts, sliced into cutlets about 3/4-inch thick\n1/2 cup olive oil\n2 tablespoons butter\n1 small white onion, diced\n2 cloves garlic, sliced\n1/2 cup chicken stock\nJuice from 1 lemon (about 3 tablespoons of juice)\n1/4 cup capers\n1/4 cup fresh minced parsley\nSalt and pepper, to taste\nFor the DAD ADD: Buttered Italian Breadcrumbs:\n2 tablespoons butter\n2/3 cup Italian breadcrumbs\n1/4 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Cook the pasta: Bring a large pot of heavily salted water to a boil, and add the pasta. Cook until al dente, 8 to 10 minutes or according to package instructions. Scoop out and reserve about 1/2 cup of the pasta-cooking water, and then drain the pasta. Set aside.\n2 Make the Dad Add \xe2\x80\x93 Buttered Breadcrumbs: In a small skillet, melt the butter over low heat. Add breadcrumbs and stir them well so they evenly soak up the butter.\nCook on low heat until the breadcrumbs start to brown, about 3 minutes. Stir occasionally to prevent burning. Watch them closely, as they can go from perfect to burned quickly.\n3 Prep the chicken: Mix together the flour, salt, and pepper in a shallow bowl. Whisk the eggs in a second shallow bowl. Dip the chicken breasts first in the egg and then coat them with the flour mixture. They should have a very light coating on them. Let chicken rest on a plate.\n4 Fry the chicken: Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat. When the oil sizzles immediately when you sprinkle a little flour in it, it's ready. Add the chicken pieces and cook for 4 to 5 minutes per side (8 to 10 minutes total). Check cooked chicken with a meat thermometer to make sure it reaches an internal temperature of 165\xc2\xb0F.\nRemove chicken from the skillet, and let it rest while you finish the dish.\n5 Make the piccata sauce: Pour out all but about 2 tablespoons of the oil in the skillet, and add the 2 tablespoons butter. Turn the heat down to medium-low, and add onions and sliced garlic. Stir the veggies, cooking for a few minutes until they soften.\nAdd chicken stock and lemon juice, and using a wooden spoon, scrape up any bits stuck to the pan.\n6 Finish the dish: Add the cooked penne to the skillet. Toss the penne with the lemon butter sauce. If the pan seems dry, add enough of the reserved 1/2 cup pasta cooking water so the pasta no longer seems dry.\nAfter the chicken has cooled slightly, chop the skillet fried chicken into big chunks, and add back into the penne mixture. Garnish with fresh parsley and capers.\n7 Garnish and serve: Serve the penne while warm, topping each bowl with the crispy buttered Italian breadcrumbs.\nThis dish keeps great in the fridge for 3 to 4 days. If you can plan ahead on the portion you will keep for leftovers, it\xe2\x80\x99s best to actually store the chicken and pasta separately. Otherwise, the chicken will get soggy. Reheat the chicken in a 350\xc2\xb0F oven for about 8 minutes, and then chop and add to reheated penne pasta.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nThe Best Dry Brined Roast Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 1 hour, 20 minutesDry Brining time: 24 to 72 hoursYield: Serves 4\nINGREDIENTS\n1 5- to 6-pound chicken\n1 lemon\n2 tablespoons olive oil\n2 3/4 teaspoons kosher salt\n1 1/4 teaspoons freshly cracked pepper\n1 1/4 teaspoons dried thyme\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the pan: Line a rimmed baking sheet with foil and set a baking rack on top or use a roasting pan with a roasting rack.\n2 Make the spice rub: Zest and quarter the lemon. Combine the lemon zest, juice from 1/4 of the lemon, 1 tablespoon olive oil, 2 1/2 teaspoons salt, pepper and thyme together in a small bowl.\nSave the lemon quarters (even the one you squeezed dry) to insert into the cavity.\n3 Season the chicken: Pat the outside of the chicken dry with a paper towel. Slide your fingers between the skin and the breast meat to loosen the skin. Try to separate the skin from around the legs as well.\nRub 3/4 of the spice mixture under the skin and into the breast and leg meat. Rub the remaining spice mixture inside the cavity of the bird. Insert the lemon quarters in the cavity.\n4 Truss the chicken: To truss the chicken, cut a piece of kitchen twine about 15 inches long. Tuck the wings under the bird as best you can. Center the twine under the back end of the chicken so equal lengths of twine are where you tucked the wings in.\nLift up each side of the twine crossing it over the top of bird\xe2\x80\x99s body, wrap it around the legs. Tie the legs together.\n  5 Let the chicken air dry for 24 hours: Place the bird, baking sheet and all, into your refrigerator uncovered for 24 to 72 hours. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t have the room in your refrigerator it\xe2\x80\x99s ok to put the chicken on a plate and transfer it to the baking sheet when you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to roast the bird.\n6 Prepare the oven: When ready to roast, move your oven rack to the second lowest spot in the oven. Preheat the oven to 375\xc2\xb0 F degrees.\n7 Add extra seasonings: The chicken will look a little desiccated after the 24-72 hour rest. That\xe2\x80\x99s a good thing! It means your chicken will have crispy skin!\nTransfer the baking sheet from the fridge to the counter. Rub the outside of the chicken with 1 tablespoon of olive oil, a 1/4 teaspoon of kosher salt, and a few cracks of fresh ground pepper.\n8 Roast and baste the chicken: Place the baking sheet into the oven and roast for 1 hour at 375\xc2\xb0 F degrees. Then turn the oven up to 425\xc2\xb0 F degrees for the remaining 20 minutes or until the temperature in the thickest part of the breast reaches 160\xc2\xb0 F degrees.\nCheck the chicken at the 45-minute mark and baste it. You may have to tip the pan a little to the corner to get to the juices. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a baster don\xe2\x80\x99t worry, just use a long-handled spoon to scoop up and pour the drippings over the chicken.\nContinue to baste every 15 to 20 minutes until it reaches a deep, rich, golden color, the skin is crispy, and the chicken has finished cooking through.\n9 Rest the chicken: Remove the chicken from the oven when the temperature in the thickest part of the breast reads about 160\xc2\xb0F. Let it rest for 5 minutes. The temperature will continue to rise to reach 165\xc2\xb0F.\nIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a thermometer that\xe2\x80\x99s ok. The chicken is cooked through when you slice into it and the juices run clear.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nMoo Goo Gai Pan (Chinese Chicken and Mushroom Stir Fry) Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 4 to 6 servings\nIf you don't have a wok or another large, deep saute pan, cook everything in stages, removing ingredients from the pan after they are cooked in each step. Toss all the ingredients together when adding the sauce and cook until the chicken is cooked through.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken:\n1 1/2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken breast\n1 large egg\n1 tablespoon cornstarch\nFor the stir fry sauce:\n1 1/2 cups chicken stock\n3 tablespoons soy sauce\n2 tablespoons corn starch\n1 tablespoon hoisin sauce\n1 tablespoon oyster sauce\n1/2 teaspoon Chinese five spice powder\nPinch of ground white pepper\nFor the vegetables:\n1 tablespoon vegetable oil\n3 carrots, peeled and sliced thinly on a diagonal\n3/4  cup (3 ounces) snow peas\n2 teaspoons grated fresh garlic\n1 teaspoons grated fresh ginger\n2 cups (5 ounces) shiitake (or white button) mushrooms, sliced\n1/3 cup (4 ounces) canned water chestnuts, drained\n1/3 cup (4 ounces) canned bamboo shoots, drained\nKosher salt, to taste\nTo serve:\n6 cups cooked jasmine rice\nSpecial equipment:\nWok, or large skillet\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prep the chicken: Using a sharp knife, slice each chicken breast in half lengthwise from the thin tip to the wider end, creating into two long strips. Thinly slice each strip against the grain into bite-sized pieces.\nThe goal here is to create bite-sized pieces of chicken that are all about the same size and shape. However you end up with that, you're good to go!\n2 Mix the cornstarch and soak the chicken: In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the egg and 1 tablespoon of the cornstarch until smooth. Toss the sliced chicken breast in the egg mixture to coat thoroughly. Allow the chicken to soak in the mixture while you prepare your sauce.\n3 Make the stir fry sauce: In a separate bowl, combine the chicken stock, 2 tablespoons cornstarch, soy, hoisin, and oyster sauces, the five spice powder, and white pepper. Whisk the mixture together and set aside.\n4 Preheat the wok and arrange your ingredients: Begin preheating your wok, or a large, deep skillet, over high heat and turn on your stovetop\xe2\x80\x99s ventilation fan. Drain the chicken of any excess egg mixture and return the chicken to its bowl.\nArrange your ingredients next to the stove in the following order: vegetable oil, chicken, carrots and snow peas, garlic and ginger, mushrooms, water chestnuts and bamboo shoots, and mixed sauce. This will help things go quickly once you\xe2\x80\x99ve begun cooking.\n5 Cook the chicken: When the wok has heated (a flick of water should evaporate on contact), carefully add the vegetable oil, quickly followed by the chicken. Stir fry the chicken for 4 minutes, tossing occasionally with a wooden spoon.\n6 Stir fry the veggies: Add the carrots and snow peas and cook for an additional 4 minutes, stirring often. Make a well in the center of the pan and add the garlic and ginger. Cook in the center of the pan until fragrant, for about 1 minute, and then mix them in with the rest of the ingredients.\nAdd the mushrooms, chestnuts, and bamboo shoots. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 3 minutes.\n7 Add the sauce: Make another well in the center of the pan and add the sauce. Cook for 2 minutes, or until the sauce starts to bubble and thicken slightly.\nFold the stir fry ingredients into the sauce to coat completely. Bring the sauce up to a simmer, and then reduce the heat to low. Cook for a minute longer.\n8 Serve: Remove from heat and immediately serve spooned over the jasmine rice with extra hoisin sauce on the side.\nLeftovers are best stored apart from the rice in an airtight container in the fridge for two days. Reheat in the microwave or in a skillet on the stovetop.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nHerbes de Provence Skillet Chicken with Potatoes and Greens Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 35 minutesMarinade time: 2 hoursYield: 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the marinade:\n1 1/2 pounds boneless skinless chicken tenders, tenderloin, or thinly sliced chicken breasts\n1 1/2 tablespoons herbes de Provence\n1 1/4 teaspoons Kosher salt\n1 teaspoon freshly ground pepper\nZest of one lemon\n1 1/2 tablespoons lemon juice\n3 cloves minced garlic\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nFor the vegetables:\n2 teaspoons olive oil\n3 tablespoons butter, divided\n1 1/2 pounds B-sized or baby potatoes\n1/2 yellow onion\n1/2 teaspoon Kosher salt\nA few cracks of freshly ground pepper\n2 handfuls (2 packed cups) Swiss chard or spinach\n1/3 cup halved pimento-stuffed Spanish olives\n1 teaspoon red wine vinegar\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Label the bag: Use a sharpie to write the date and title of the recipe on a gallon-sized zip top bag so you can easily find it on SimplyRecipes.com when you want to cook it. Alternatively, write the cooking instructions on the bag, and date it.\n2 Combine the ingredients: Roll down the opening of the bag a little just so you don\xe2\x80\x99t accidently get raw chicken juices on the outside of the zip top. Add the chicken, spices, zest, lemon juice, garlic and olive oil.\nRemove as much air as possible and seal the bag. Smoosh the chicken around so it\xe2\x80\x99s coated in the marinade.\n3 Lay the chicken flat in the freezer and freeze for up to 6 months:\nAlternatively, you could skip the freezer and let it marinade in the fridge for a couple of hours and up to two days, then cook it according to the directions below.\n 4 Thaw the chicken before cooking: When ready to cook, take the chicken out of the freezer in the morning before you go to work, and it will be ready to cook by the end of the day.\n5 Prepare the vegetables: If the b-sized potatoes are larger than a golf ball, quarter them; if they are smaller just half them. Slice the onion. Wash the Swiss chard, remove the stems and chop them. Then cut the leaves into strips about an inch thick. Cut the olives in half.\n  6 Cook the chicken: Set a large skillet over medium heat add 2 teaspoons of olive oil and 1 tablespoon butter. Once the oil shimmers and the butter melts, add the chicken and any marinade in the bag.\nIf any chicken is folded up, unfold it so it lays flat in the pan. Cook the chicken for 2 minutes, then flip it.\n7 Add the vegetables: Add the potatoes, onion, and 1/4 cup water to the pan with the chicken. Cover with a lid. Let everything simmer together for about 10 minutes.\n8 Finish the potatoes and make the sauce: Remove the chicken to a plate (leaving the vegetables in the skillet) and tent with foil. Add the remaining 2 tablespoons of butter, 1/4 teaspoon of salt and a few cracks of freshly ground pepper to the skillet. Stir the potatoes, cover and cook for another 10 minutes.\nTurn the heat up to medium high to reduce the liquid and finish cooking the potatoes uncovered. This should take about 2 to 3 minutes depending on how much liquid is in the pan.\nWhen you can easily pierce the potatoes with a fork, add the chard leaves and chopped stems, olives, and red wine vinegar. Toss gently until the greens are just wilted.\n9 Serve: Nestle the chicken back into the pan. Bring the whole thing over to the table and serve.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nChinese Orange Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 20 minutesCook time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the orange sauce:\nZest from 1 orange\n1/4 cup orange juice\n1/4 cup soy sauce\n1/4 cup water\n1/3 cup rice vinegar\n1 tablespoon cornstarch\n1 tablespoon sesame oil\n1/2 cup sugar\nFor the chicken:\n1 1/2 pounds boneless skinless chicken thighs\n2 large eggs\n1 teaspoon salt\n1/4 teaspoon black pepper\n1/2 cup cornstarch\n1/2 cup all-purpose flour\n2 cups vegetable oil, for frying\n2 cloves garlic, chopped\n1 large shallot, chopped\nTo garnish and serve:\nSliced scallions, garnish\nSesame seeds, garnish\nCooked white rice, to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Make the orange sauce: Whisk together sauce ingredients in a medium bowl. Set aside.\n2 Prep the chicken: Cut chicken into about 1-inch cubes. Whisk eggs with salt and black pepper in a bowl and add chicken. Stir together.\nIn a separate bowl, whisk together flour and cornstarch. Remove chicken from eggs with a slotted spoon or tongs, letting excess egg drain off, then transfer to cornstarch mixture and coat well.\n2 Fry the chicken: Add oil to a large 10- to 12-inch skillet. Heat over medium-high heat until it reaches 350\xcb\x9aF. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t have a thermometer, you can also test the temperature by sprinkling in some flour and it should fizzle immediately.\nOnce oil is hot, fry the chicken in two batches. The oil might not completely cover the chicken\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s okay. Cook for 3-4 minutes. Flip the chicken pieces and cook until the chicken is cooked through, about 3 to 4 more minutes. Total cook time is about 6-8 minutes.\nRemove fried chicken cubes and transfer to a plate lined with paper towels, so the chicken can drain. Repeat until all the chicken is cooked.\n3 Simmer the chicken in the sauce: Once chicken is done, pour out hot oil and wipe pan clean. Add a fresh tablespoon of oil along with chopped garlic and shallot. Cook for a minute and then add the sauce. Simmer the sauce until it starts to thicken.\nOnce the sauce is lightly bubbling, add fried chicken and toss together to coat. The sauce should continue to thicken and stick to the chicken. Let simmer for a minute or two more. Serve orange chicken over cooked white rice, garnished with sesame seeds and fresh scallions.\nLEFTOVERS! The orange chicken keeps well in the fridge for 5 days. Reheat in a skillet with a splash of water over low heat. Freeze the orange chicken for up to 3 months, but be sure to thaw it before reheating so the chicken doesn\xe2\x80\x99t clump together.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nClassic Baked Chicken\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 50 minutesYield: Serves 4\nEven if you intend to eat the baked chicken without its skin, leave the skin on for baking because it prevents the chicken pieces from drying out while they bake.\nIf you bought a whole chicken to start with, the chicken may have come with the neck and gizzards (often in paper in the cavity of the chicken). Use the chicken back and these giblets to make stock for gravy. Chop up the back a little, and put the back, gizzard, and neck into a small saucepan and cover with water by a half inch or so. Bring to a simmer and let simmer while your chicken is baking. Then strain and use the stock for making a richly flavored gravy.\nINGREDIENTS\nOne 3 to 4 pound chicken, cut into 8 parts (2 breasts, 2 thighs, 2 legs, 2 wings), excluding the back\nExtra virgin olive oil\nKosher salt\nFreshly ground black pepper\n1/2 cup low sodium chicken stock (see Recipe Note) or white wine for the gravy (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Trim and salt the chicken: Trim the chicken pieces of excess fat. Pat the chicken pieces dry with a paper towel. Sprinkle all sides with salt. Let the chicken pieces sit for 15 to 20 minutes to take the chill off.\n2 Preheat the oven to 400\xc2\xb0F (205\xc2\xb0C).\n3 Prep the chicken: Pat the chicken pieces dry with a paper towel. Rub olive oil over the chicken pieces and on the bottom of the roasting pan.\nSprinkle the chicken pieces all over with black pepper and a little more salt.\nArrange the chicken pieces in the pan so that all the pieces are skin-side up, and the largest pieces (the breasts) are in the center of the pan.\nDon't crowd the pan; allow room in between the pieces.\n4 Bake the chicken: Bake (uncovered) in the oven for 30 minutes at 400\xc2\xb0F (205\xc2\xb0C). This initial high heat will help brown the chicken.\nThen lower the heat to 350\xc2\xb0F (175\xc2\xb0C) and bake for and additional 10-30 minutes more until the juices run clear (not pink) when poked with a sharp knife or the internal temperature of the chicken breasts is 165\xc2\xb0F (74\xc2\xb0C), and of the thighs is 170\xc2\xb0F (77\xc2\xb0C) when tested with a meat thermometer.\nIf the chicken isn't browning well enough, place the chicken under the broiler for the last 5 minutes of cooking, until browned sufficiently.\n5 Let it rest: Remove from oven and transfer the chicken to a serving dish. Tent with aluminum foil and let rest for 5 to 10 minutes before serving.\n6 Make gravy: If you would like to make gravy with the drippings from the chicken, place the roasting pan with all its drippings on the stovetop and set the burner to medium heat.\nUse a metal spatula to scrape up the stuck drippings from the bottom of the pan. When the pan is hot, pour in some white wine or chicken stock to help loosen the drippings from the pan.\nTransfer the drippings and stock/wine mixture to a saucepan and heat on medium high until reduced to your desired thickness.\nIf you want the gravy even thicker, you can make a slurry with a little cornstarch or flour (a teaspoon) and water (1/4 cup), and add that to the gravy while it cooks.\n7 Serve: Serve with steamed rice, mashed potatoes, or Spanish rice.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Save It Print\nAir Fryer Fried Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 45 minutesMarinating time: 1 hourYield: 10 pieces of fried chicken\nAlternative Pan Fry Method: If you don\xe2\x80\x99t have access to an air fryer, you can make this fried chicken using a traditional pan fry method. Add enough oil to a cast iron skillet so the oil is about 1 1/2 inches up the side of the skillet. Heat oil until it reaches 350\xc2\xb0F. Add chicken pieces and fry for 8 minutes. Flip, and fry for another 8 minutes until golden brown. Test temperature; you might need a few more minutes for the dark meat pieces (thighs and legs).\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken: \n1 4-pound fryer chicken, cut into 10 pieces (2 breasts cut in half, 2 wings, 2 legs, 2 thighs)\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 teaspoon ground black pepper\n2 cups buttermilk\nFor the coating:\n2 cups all-purpose flour\n1 tablespoon seasoned salt\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1 tablespoon garlic powder\n1 tablespoon paprika\nSpray olive oil for cooking\nSpecial equipment:\nKrups Air Fryer\nThermapen Instant Read Thermometer\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: Season the chicken well with salt and pepper and then add it to a bowl with buttermilk. Chicken pieces should be covered with the buttermilk. Let it sit for at least an hour or up to overnight.\n2 Bread the chicken: To prepare the breading mixture, stir together flour, seasoned salt, salt, pepper, garlic powder, and paprika.\nRemove chicken pieces from buttermilk and shake off any excess; then dip in the flour mix and coat well. Transfer breaded chicken pieces to a clean plate or wire rack to rest.\n3 Air-fry the chicken: You will need to work in two batches if you are doing a full chicken. Spray the basket of your air fryer with nonstick spray. Place half of the pieces in the basket of your air fryer. Try to ensure the pieces don\xe2\x80\x99t touch. Air needs to circulate around them.\nSpray the chicken pieces lightly with spray oil. Place the basket in the air fryer and turn the air fryer to 350\xc2\xb0F. Cook for 14 minutes, then flip the fried chicken with tongs, spray lightly with oil a second time on the bottom side of the chicken, and cook for another 8 to 10 minutes.\nThe half-breast pieces and the wings will be done on the low end of that time range, and the dark meat pieces will need a full 24 to 26 minutes of time to be cooked through. The dark meat pieces should reach 175\xcb\x9aF.\n(NOTE: My method photo here only shows the temp at 148\xcb\x9aF to illustrate that the chicken can LOOK cooked but is actually not cooked through. A meat thermometer is vital.)\nDuring the air frying process, if you pull out the chicken and notice any dry flour spots on the chicken, spray those spots lightly with oil. The breading will never crisp up if it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have a tiny bit of oil to hydrate it. It will just burn.\n4 Serve: When the fried chicken is ready, let it rest on a plate for a few minutes before serving. Serve immediately with salad, coleslaw, mashed potatoes, or your favorite fried chicken sides!\nCooked fried chicken can be stored in the fridge for 5 days and reheated in a 300\xc2\xb0F oven for 8 to 10 minutes.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Print\nIndian Butter Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 30 minutesCook time: 30 minutesMarinating time: 30 minutes minimum, 8 hours maximumYield: 4 servings\nIf you have trouble finding the spices, you can substitute paprika for the Kashmiri Lal Mirch and skip the Kasuri Methi.\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the chicken and marinade:\n1 pound boneless, skinless chicken thighs, cut into roughly 1-inch cubes\n1/4 cup full-fat plain yogurt\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 tablespoon ginger garlic paste\n1 teaspoon dried coriander\n1 teaspoon Kashmiri Lal Mirch\n1 teaspoon cumin\nSalt to taste\nFor the sauce:\n8 to 10 whole almonds\n8 to 10 whole cashews\n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, divided\n1 tablespoon ginger garlic paste\n1 teaspoon sugar\n1 (15-ounce) can canned diced tomatoes\n2 tablespoons dried coriander\n1 1/2 teaspoons ground Garam Masala\n1/2 teaspoon ground Kashmiri Lal Mirch\n1/2 teaspoon salt\n1 cup water\n1/4 cup heavy cream\n1/2 tablespoon Kasuri Methi\nTo serve:\nCooked rice, roti, or naan bread\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: Bring the chicken and the rest of the marinade ingredients together in a large bowl. Using your hands, massage the marinade into the chicken.\nCover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 1 hour, or up to overnight.\n2 Soak cashews and almonds in water for at least an hour to (or up to overnight) before preparing the rest of the recipe.\n3 Cook the chicken: Heat a skillet or grill pan over medium-high heat. Drizzle a teaspoon of oil to the pan.\nWorking in batches, remove chicken from the marinade and grill them on the pan for 3 to 5 minutes on each side, until the chicken is cooked through (clear juice runs out of it when you cut into it). Do not crowd the pan.\nOnce cooked, transfer the chicken into a separate dish. Cover and set aside for later.\n4 Start making the sauce: Melt 1 1/2 tablespoons of the butter in a medium sized Dutch oven or a skillet on medium low heat. As soon as the butter melts, add the ginger garlic paste followed by sugar. Saut\xc3\xa9 for 1 to 2 minutes.\nStir in the tomato and cook for 8 to 10 minutes on medium high heat, until all the extra liquid is cooked off. The sauce should be a loose, paste-like consistency.\nAdd coriander, garam masala, Kashmiri Lal Mirch, and salt. Stir and cook on medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes. Turn off the heat.\n5 Puree the sauce with the nuts: Transfer the paste to a blender or the bowl of a food processor. Add the soaked cashews and almonds. Blend into a smooth paste.\n6 Finish the dish: Return the paste to the cooking pan over medium heat. Add the water to the paste and stir to make a smooth sauce.\nAs the sauce begins to boil, add the grilled chicken and heavy cream. Stir well. Cover the pan and simmer for 5 minutes.\n7 Rest the butter chicken: Turn off the heat and uncover the pan. Stir in the remaining 1/2 tablespoon butter and the kasuri methi. Cover again, and let the dish rest for 8 to 10 minutes so the flavor of kasuri methi can marry into the butter chicken.\n8 Serve: Serve the butter with a side of steamed basmati rice, roti, or naan. Leftovers will keep refrigerated, covered, for five days.\nYou can freeze this dish in an airtight covered container or a zip-top bag for a month. Thaw and reheat in a saucepan over medium-low heat to retain the texture.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Save It Print\nChar Siu Chicken Recipe\nPrep time: 5 minutesCook time: 30 minutesMarination time: 30 minutesYield: 4 servings\nThis recipe is easily doubled.\nIf your thighs are quite large, butterfly them:  Pat the chicken thighs with paper towels to remove excess moisture, then trim and discard any big fat pads. If the thighs are large or super uneven in thickness, butterfly each one. Lay the thigh, smooth-side down, on your cutting board. Wielding your knife horizontally, slash the big mound of flesh to create a flap of meat, stopping just shy of cutting all the way through. Fold back the meat flap that you just created. The thigh should now be about 50 percent longer and relatively even in thickness. If the result seems awkwardly large, cut it crosswise into two smaller, square-ish pieces. Set aside.\nReprinted with permission from Vietnamese Food Any Day: Simple Recipes for True, Fresh Flavors by Andrea Nguyen, copyright \xc2\xa92019. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large garlic clove, put through a garlic press or minced and mashed\n1/4 teaspoon Chinese five-spice powder\n2 tablespoons honey, preferably amber colored\nBrimming 2 tablespoons hoisin sauce\n1 1/2 tablespoons soy sauce\n1 tablespoon ketchup\nScant 2 teaspoons toasted sesame oil\n1 3/4 pounds boneless, skinless chicken thighs (See Recipe Note)\nSpecial equipment:\nCast iron grill pan or grill\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: In a large bowl, stir together the garlic, five-spice powder, honey, hoisin, soy sauce, ketchup, and sesame oil. Remove 3 tablespoons and set aside for glazing the chicken.\nAdd the chicken to the bowl, coating the pieces well. Cover with plastic wrap and marinate at room temperature for 30 minutes, or refrigerate up to 24 hours (return to room temperature before cooking).\n2 Grill the chicken: Lightly oil a cast-iron stovetop grill pan and set over medium-high heat. Add the chicken and cook for 6 to 10 minutes, turning several times.\nTo test for doneness, pierce the flesh with the tip of a knife: The chicken is cooked when clear juices flow out.\nDuring the last 2 minutes of cooking, when the chicken feels firm-ish, baste with the reserved marinade to freshen flavor and add sheen.\nAlternatively, prepare a medium charcoal fire or preheat a gas grill to medium and cook the chicken for 10 to 12 minutes, basting during the last 3 minutes.\n3 Serve: Transfer to a platter and let rest for 5 to 10 minutes before serving.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nItalian Skillet Chicken with Spinach, Tomatoes, and Onions Recipe\nPrep time: 12 minutesCook time: 25 minutesYield: 4 to 6\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the marinade\n1 1/2 pounds boneless skinless chicken tenders, tenderloin, or thinly sliced chicken breasts\n1 tablespoon dried oregano\n2 1/2 teaspoons dried thyme\n1 1/2 teaspoons Kosher salt\n1 teaspoon dried basil\n1 teaspoon freshly ground pepper\nZest from 1 lemon\n3 tablespoons lemon juice, from about 1 lemon\n3 cloves garlic, minced\n2 tablespoons olive oil\nFor the vegetables\n2 teaspoons olive oil\n1 pint cherry tomatoes\n1 medium red onion\n2 large handfuls spinach, about 2 packed cups\n1 teaspoon capers\n1 tablespoon butter\nCrusty bread, to serve\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Label the bag: Use a sharpie to write the date and the title of the recipe on a gallon-sized zip top bag so you can easily find it on SimplyRecipes.com when you want to cook it. Alternatively, write the cooking instructions on the bag.\n2 Combine the ingredients: Roll down the opening of the bag a little just so you don\xe2\x80\x99t accidently get raw chicken juices on the outside of the zip top. Add the chicken, spices, zest,  lemon juice, garlic and olive oil.\nRemove as much air as possible and seal the bag. Smoosh the chicken around so it\xe2\x80\x99s coated in the marinade.\n3 Lay the chicken flat in the freezer and freeze for up to 6 months.\nAlternatively, you could skip the freezer and let it marinade in the fridge for a couple of hours and up to two days, then cook it according to the directions below.\n4 Thaw the chicken before cooking: Take the chicken out of the freezer in the morning before you go to work, and it will be ready to cook by the end of the day.\n5 Prepare the onion: Peel and trim the stem ends of the onion, but leave the stem intact so it can keep the onion layers together. Slice the onion in half. Then slice each half into 5 wedges leaving a little stem with each one.\n6 Cook the chicken: Set a large skillet over medium heat add 2 teaspoons of olive oil. Once the oil shimmers, add chicken and any marinade in the bag. If any chicken is folded up, unfolded it so it lays flat in the pan. Cook the chicken for 2 minutes, then flip it.\n7 Add the vegetables: Add the onion wedges, tomatoes, and capers. Cover with a lid. Let everything simmer together for 12 to 15 minutes. The tomatoes should be soft, and the onions dull in color.\n8 Check the chicken: Check the chicken to see if it\xe2\x80\x99s cooked through by cutting a piece open. If the juices run clear, and you don\xe2\x80\x99t see any pink the chicken is ready. Use a fork to remove the chicken to a plate and tent with foil.\n9 Finish the sauce: Turn the heat up to medium high. Add 1 tablespoon butter to the sauce. Stir it in and let the sauce reduce uncovered for about 2 minutes. Add the spinach stir to coat a couple of times until the spinach has wilted.\n10 To serve: Nestle the chicken back into the pan, and season to taste with salt and pepper.\nBring the skillet to the table. Spoon up chicken, vegetables and sauces into shallow bowls or plates. Serve with crusty bread to sop up the sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b'Save It Print\nOld Bay Chicken Wings Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4-6\nINGREDIENTS\n3 pounds chicken wings, separated tips from drummettes\n8 Tbsp (1/2 cup or 1 stick) unsalted butter\n1 Tbsp Old Bay seasoning, plus more for dusting\n1 Tbsp lemon juice\nCocktail sauce for dipping\nMETHOD\n1 Preheat the oven to 425\xc2\xb0F. Allow the wings to come to room temperature (or else the sauce will be more difficult to spread on them). Pat the chicken wings dry.\n2 Make Old Bay sauce: Melt the butter in a small pot and whisk in the Old Bay and lemon juice. Let it cool enough to feel lukewarm.\n3 Mix the sauce again and toss the chicken wings in half the sauce.\n4 Bake: Arrange the wings in one layer on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, aluminum foil, or Silpat and bake at 425\xc2\xb0F for 25 minutes.\n5 Broil: Take the wings out of the oven and turn on the broiler. Set a rack about 6 inches under the broiler. Turn the wings over on the baking sheet and put under the broiler for 3-4 minutes, or until they are nicely browned.\n6 To serve, toss in the remaining sauce and set on a plate. Dust with more Old Bay and serve with your favorite cocktail sauce.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print'
b"Save It Print\nWhite Chicken Chili Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 45 minutesDry bean cooking time: 2 hoursYield: 4-5 servings\nIf you are starting with dry beans and want even more flavor, cook them in about 7 cups of chicken stock and then when done, use the stock that the beans haven't absorbed as a base for the chili.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 (15-ounce) cans white beans, drained OR 1/2 pound dry white beans\n1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil\n1 medium onion, chopped, about 1 1/2 cups\n1 clove garlic, minced, about 1 teaspoon\n2 teaspoons ground cumin\n1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper\n1/8 teaspoon ground cloves\n2 4-ounce cans chopped green chilies\n1 1/2 teaspoons dried oregano\n1 jalape\xc3\xb1o or serrano pepper, finely chopped (optional)\n2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken thighs (can use breast meat, but thighs will work better), trimmed of excess fat and diced into 1/2- to 3/4-inch pieces\n3 cups chicken stock\n1 1/2 cups grated Monterey Jack cheese\nIf cooking dry beans:\n1 1/2 teaspoons salt\n1 clove garlic\n1 bay leaf\nMETHOD\n1 If using dry beans, cook them first: Place the beans in a medium pot and cover with a couple inches of hot water, about 2 quarts. Add 1 1/2 teaspoons salt, 1 chopped garlic clove, and one bay leaf. Heat on high to bring to a simmer, cover, and reduce heat to very low to maintain a low simmer.\nCook for 2 to 3 hours or until the beans are cooked through and tender (note that cannelli beans will cook faster than navy beans, and older dry beans will take longer to cook than newer). Drain.\n2 Saut\xc3\xa9 onions with seasonings: In a large thick-bottomed pot, saut\xc3\xa9 onions in olive oil on medium high heat until tender, about 4 minutes. Add the garlic, cumin, cloves, and cayenne and cook a minute more. Add the green chiles and dried oregano. Add the minced jalape\xc3\xb1o or serrano chile if using.\n3 Add chicken and stock, and simmer: Add the chicken and chicken stock. Increase the heat to high, bring to a simmer, reduce the heat to low, cover and maintain the simmer for 20 minutes, until the chicken is cooked through.\n4 Add cooked beans: Add the drained cooked beans and cook for 15 minutes more. Taste for seasonings and add more salt to taste. Depending on how salty your chicken stock and beans are, you may need to add a teaspoon or more.\n5 Serve with toppings and tortillas or chips: Serve topped with grated cheese. Garnish with cilantro, chopped fresh tomato, salsa, chopped scallions, and/or guacamole. Serve with fresh warmed flour tortillas or tortilla chips.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b'Print\nQuick Chicken Pho Recipe\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 2\nFrom Andrea:\n"Great for pho beginners, this recipe is also terrific for cooks in a hurry. It involves less than 45 minutes, during which you\xe2\x80\x99ll doctor up store-bought broth so it says, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m pho-ish.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe keys to this streamlined approach include toasting spices and dry saut\xc3\xa9ing the ginger and green onion, which help to extract flavor fast. Poaching the chicken in the broth adds savory depth. You\xe2\x80\x99ll practice some fundamental pho techniques that you can apply elsewhere, too. Choose a broth that tastes like chicken, such as Swanson brand, which is less fussed up and easy to manipulate. You need two 14.5-ounce (411 g) cans or one 32-ounce (907 ml) carton."\nReprinted with permission from The Pho Cookbook: Easy to Adventurous Recipes for Vietnam\xe2\x80\x99s Favorite Soup and Noodles by Andrea Nguyen, copyright \xc2\xa9 2017. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.\nINGREDIENTS\n3/4-inch (2 cm) section ginger\n2 medium-large green onions\n1 very small (.5 oz | 15 g) bunch cilantro sprigs\n1 1/2 teaspoons coriander seeds\n1 whole clove\n3 1/2 to 4 cups (840 ml to 1 l) low-sodium chicken broth\n2 cups (480 ml) water\n6 to 8 ounces (180 to 225 g) boneless, skinless chicken breast or thighs\nAbout 1/2 teaspoon fine sea salt\n5 ounces (150 g) dried narrow flat rice noodles\n2 to 3 teaspoons fish sauce\nAbout 1/2 teaspoon organic sugar, or 1 teaspoon maple syrup (optional)\nPepper (optional)\nOptional extras: Bean sprouts, mint sprigs, Thai basil, cilantro leaves, lime wedges, thinly-sliced chili peppers\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Prepare the broth ingredients: Peel then slice the ginger into 4 or 5 coins. Smack with the flat side of a knife or meat mallet; set aside. Thinly slice the green parts of the green onion to yield 2 to 3 tablespoons; set aside for garnish. Cut the leftover sections into pinkie-finger lengths, bruise, then add to the ginger.\nCoarsely chop the leafy tops of the cilantro to yield 2 tablespoons; set aside for garnish. Set the remaining cilantro sprigs aside.\n2 Toast the broth ingredients: In a 3- to 4-quart (3 to 4 l) pot, toast the coriander seeds and clove over medium heat until fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes. Add the ginger and green onion sections. Stir for about 30 seconds, until aromatic.\n3 Add the broth and bring to a simmer: Slide the pot off heat, wait 15 seconds or so to briefly cool, then pour in the broth.\nReturn the pot to the burner, then add the water, cilantro sprigs, chicken, and salt. Bring to a boil over high heat, then lower the heat to gently simmer.\n4 Remove the chicken from the broth once cooked: After 5 to 10 minutes of simmering, the chicken should be firm and cooked through (press on it and it should slightly yield).\n5 Continue to simmer the broth without the chicken for another 15 to 20 minutes (for a total of 30 minutes simmering time).\n6 Shred the chicken: Transfer the chicken to a bowl, flush with cold water to arrest the cooking, then drain. Let cool, then cut or shred into bite-size pieces. Cover loosely to prevent drying.\n[Emma\'s note: If the chicken isn\'t quite cooked through when you begin to shred it, just split it into a few pieces and put it back in the broth for another few minutes until cooked through. The split pieces will quickly cook through.]\n7 Soak the rice noodles in hot water until pliable and opaque. Drain, rinse, and set aside.\n8 Strain the broth: When the broth is done, pour it through a fine-mesh strainer positioned over a 2-quart (2-liter) pot; line the strainer with muslin for superclear broth. Discard the solids. You should have about 4 cups.\nSeason with fish sauce and sugar (or maple syrup), if needed, to create a strong savory-sweet note.\n9 Finish the pho: Bring the strained broth to a boil over high heat. Put the noodles in a noodle strainer or mesh sieve and dunk in the hot broth to heat and soften, 5 to 60 seconds. Lift the noodles from the pot and divide between the 2 bowls. [Emma\'s note: I didn\'t find it necessary to soften my noodles any further. I just added them to the bowls and poured the hot broth over top. However, dunking them in the broth would make them more flavorful!]\nLower the heat to keep the broth hot while you arrange the chicken on top of the noodles and garnish with the chopped green onion, cilantro, and a sprinkling of pepper. Taste and adjust the broth\xe2\x80\x99s saltiness one last time. Return the broth to a boil and ladle into the bowls. Enjoy with any extras, if you like.\n[Emma\'s note: I just left the broth at a low simmer during this last step, rather than bringing it to a boil again. I thought it was plenty hot!]\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b'Print\nChicken Marbella Recipe\nPrep time: 15 minutesCook time: 1 hourMarinating time: 3 hoursYield: Serves 5-8\nAlthough the original recipe calls for 2 small chickens to be quartered, you could easily do this recipe with 5 pounds of chicken pieces, thighs and breasts.\nINGREDIENTS\n2 chickens, 2 1/2 lbs each, quartered, bone-in, skin-on\nCloves from 1/2 head of garlic, peeled and finely pur\xc3\xa9ed\n2 tablespoons dried oregano\nCoarse salt and freshly ground pepper to taste\n1/4 cup red wine vinegar\n1/4 cup extra virgin olive oil\n1/2 cup pitted prunes\n8 large pitted Spanish green olives, cut in half\n1/4 cup capers with a bit of juice\n3 bay leaves\n1/4 cup brown sugar\n1/2 cup white wine\n2 tablespoons fresh Italian parsley, finely chopped\nMETHOD\n1 Marinate the chicken: In a large bowl combine garlic, oregano, salt and pepper to taste, vinegar, olive oil, prunes, olives, capers with caper juice, and bay leaves. Add the chicken pieces and coat completely with the marinade. Cover and let marinate, refrigerated, several hours or overnight.\n2 Place chicken in baking pan, top with marinade, brown sugar, wine: Preheat oven to 350\xc2\xb0F. Arrange chicken in a single layer in one or two large, shallow baking pans and spoon marinade over it evenly. Sprinkle brown sugar over the chicken pieces and pour white wine around them.\n3 Bake until done: Bake for 50 minutes to 1 hour, basting frequently with the pan juices. Chicken is done when a sharp knife inserted into the thigh pieces, at their thickest point, run with clear yellow juices (not pink).\n4 Serve with pan juices: With a slotted spoon, move the chicken, prunes, olives, and capers to a serving platter. Pour some of the pan juices over the chicken and sprinkle generously with parsley. Serve remaining juices in a gravy boat.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nPrint'
b"Save It Print\nTuscan Chicken Pasta Skillet Recipe\nPrep time: 25 minutesCook time: 25 minutesMarinating time: 15 minutesYield: 4 servings\nINGREDIENTS\nFor the marinade:\n1/4 cup olive oil\n1 teaspoon kosher salt\n1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper\n1/2 teaspoon dried Italian seasoning\nFor the dinner:\n1 1/2 pounds boneless skinless chicken breasts\n2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil\n12 ounces cherry tomatoes (about 2 cups), halved\n1 tablespoon minced garlic\n8 ounces spaghetti\n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt\n1 cup quartered marinated artichokes hearts, drained\n1/3 cup Kalamata olives, pitted and sliced\n1/4 cup freshly grated parmesan cheese\n6 basil leaves, thinly sliced\n2 teaspoons chopped fresh parsley (optional)\nMETHODHIDE PHOTOS\n1 Marinate the chicken: In a small bowl, combine 1/4 cup olive oil, 1 teaspoon salt, 1/2 teaspoon pepper, and Italian seasoning. Cut each chicken breast lengthwise to create 4 long, thin pieces. Place chicken in a shallow dish. Pour marinade over the chicken, turn to evenly coat. Let sit for 15 minutes before cooking.\n2 Cook the chicken: Heat a large high-sided skillet or saut\xc3\xa9 pan over medium-high heat. Add 2 tablespoons of olive oil. Once the oil is hot, add the chicken. Cook until the chicken is golden brown and fully cooked, about 6 to 8 minutes per side.\nTransfer chicken to a cutting board to rest while cooking the pasta.\n3 Cook the pasta: Add tomatoes, garlic, spaghetti, 4 cups water, and 1/2 teaspoon salt to the skillet. Bring to a boil over high heat. Cook and stir frequently, until the pasta is tender and water has mostly evaporated\xe2\x80\x94about 9 to 11 minutes. You want to have a small amount of water in the pan to create a light sauce.\nAdd more water if needed, 1/2 cup at a time for a softer pasta. Turn off the heat.  \n4 Finish and toss: Cut the chicken into 1/4-inch thick slices. Add the artichoke hearts, olives, Parmesan cheese, sliced chicken, and basil. Toss to combine. If you'd like a thicker sauce, you can add 1 or 2 tablespoons of butter. Taste and season with more salt and pepper as desired.\n5 Serve: Garnish pasta with parsley, then divide among plates and serve warm.\nHello! All photos and content are copyright protected. Please do not use our photos without prior written permission. Thank you!\nSave It Print"
b"Print\nHow to Grill Juicy Boneless Skinless Chicken Breasts\nPrep time: 10 minutesCook time: 10 minutesBrining time: 30 minutesYield: Serves 4\nIt's always a good idea to use a meat thermometer when cooking meat that's at least an inch thick. I take chicken off the grill at a little bit lower temp (155\xc2\xb0F) than is usually recommended for poultry, but that's because the chicken will continue to cook for several minutes once it's off the heat and resting. Taking the chicken off the heat at this temperature helps insure that the meat doesn't overcook and get dried out.
